点燃理性的火焰

To Light the Flame of Reason

二十一世纪的清晰思路

Clear Thinking for the Twenty-First Century

克里斯特·史都马克

Christer Sturmark

道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特 (Douglas Hofstadter) 撰稿并作序

With contributions and a foreword by Douglas Hofstadter

康涅狄格州吉尔福德

Guilford, Connecticut

这是 Globe Pequot 的印记，是 Rowman & Littlefield Publishing Group, Inc. 的贸易部门。

美国国会图书馆出版品目錄數據

Library of Congress Cataloging-in-Publication Data

姓名：Sturmark，Christer，1964 年–作者。| Hofstadter，Douglas R.，1945 年–作者。

Names: Sturmark, Christer, 1964– author. | Hofstadter, Douglas R., 1945–author.

标题：点燃理性的火焰：二十一世纪的清晰思考/克里斯特·斯图马克 (Christer Sturmark)、道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特 (Douglas Hofstadter)。

Title: To light the flame of reason : clear thinking for the twenty-first century / Christer Sturmark, Douglas Hofstadter.

描述：马里兰州兰翰：普罗米修斯，Globe Pequot 的印记，Rowman & Littlefield 出版集团的贸易部门，2022 年。| 包括索引。| 摘要：“点燃理性的火焰是关于清晰思考的艺术，这种艺术在我们现在生活的世界比以往任何时候都更需要。为任何想在这个充满民粹主义教条、反科学态度和伪哲学的世界中更好地航行的人而写的”——由出版商提供。

Description: Lanham, MD : Prometheus, an imprint of Globe Pequot, the trade division of The Rowman & Littlefield Publishing Group, 2022. | Includes index. | Summary: “To Light the Flame of Reason is all about the art of clear thinking, an art that is needed now more than ever in the world we now live in. Written for anyone who wants to navigate better in this world filled with populist dogmas, antiscience attitudes, and pseudo-philosophy”—Provided by publisher.

标识符：LCCN 2021033686 (印刷本) | LCCN 2021033687 (电子书) | ISBN 9781633887749 (精装本) | ISBN 9781633887756 (epub)

Identifiers: LCCN 2021033686 (print) | LCCN 2021033687 (ebook) | ISBN 9781633887749 (cloth) | ISBN 9781633887756 (epub)

主题：LCSH：宽容。| 真理。| 理性。| 思想与思考。| 世俗人文主义。

Subjects: LCSH: Toleration. | Truth. | Reason. | Thought and thinking. | Secular humanism.

分类：LCC HM1271 .S786 2022（印刷版）| LCC HM1271（电子书）| DDC 179/.9—dc23

Classification: LCC HM1271 .S786 2022 (print) | LCC HM1271 (ebook) | DDC 179/.9—dc23

CONTENTS

  8. Contents
  9. 序言道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特
  10. Foreword Douglas Hofstadter
  11. 前言Christer Sturmark
  12. Foreword Christer Sturmark
  13. 序言：关于昨日的世界和今日的世界
    1. 全球性精神病
    2. 致命的迷信
    3. 瑞典的极端主义和迷信
    4. 我们需要的是一个新的启蒙时代
  14. Prelude: Concerning Yesterday’s World and Today’s World
    1. A Global Psychosis
    2. Fatal Superstition
    3. Swedish Extremism and Superstition
    4. What We Need Is a New Age of Enlightenment
  15. 第一部分

    清晰思考的艺术
    1. 第一章以开放的心态面对世界：关于寻求知识所需的工具和指南针
      1. 我的坎坷旅程
      2. 心胸开阔
      3. 解释和奥卡姆剃刀
      4. 思维陷阱
      5. 理性与智慧
      6. 拥有思想，形成人生哲学
      7. 我的观点
      8. 世俗人文主义
      9. 插曲：关于灵性和流动
    2. 第二章我相信我知道：关于现实、知识和真理
      1. 什么是知识？
      2. 看似真实的东西真的是真实的吗？
      3. 事实问题和品味问题
      4. 真理是什么？
      5. 绝对真理与相对真理
      6. 社会建构
      7. 后现代主义与教育
      8. 相对主义与政治
      9. 插曲：关于三大谜团
    3. 第三章基于充分理由的信念：关于一个人信念的依据
      1. “那么，你相信什么呢？”
      2. 相信科学是一种信仰吗？
      3. 知识诚实
      4. “非凡的主张需要非凡的证据”
      5. 揭开难以置信的面纱
      6. 插曲：探索国际象棋中的对手动作和人生游戏中的对手动作
    4. 第四章什么是科学？关于理论、实验、结论和科学的本质
      1. 科学的核心
      2. 实验、拒绝和修改：科学的核心
      3. 演绎推理过程
      4. 归纳推理过程
      5. 案例研究：路易斯·巴斯德和自然发生论
      6. 可证伪性
      7. 数学及其绝对真理
      8. 盲法实验和安慰剂
      9. 科学的阴暗面
      10. 宗教与科学可以互相兼容吗？
      11. 插曲：论科学的实用性
    5. 第五章头脑里的鬼魂：关于我们奇妙却又容易被愚弄的大脑
      1. 我们的大脑蒙蔽了我们的眼睛
      2. 社会思维和抽象思维
      3. 道德思考
      4. 人类的大脑是为了宗教而设计的吗？
      5. 我们非常人性化的心智理论
      6. 奇思妙想
      7. 插曲：论天堂和乐园
    6. 第六章自然世界：关于自然主义、不可知论和无神论
      1. 自然主义和唯物主义
      2. 无神论者是煽动者
      3. 美国生活中的无神论
      4. 无神论者是没有道德的人
      5. 不可知论者还是无神论者？
      6. 许多不可知论者实际上是无神论者
      7. 无神论者到底相信什么？
      8. 对无神论的十三个偏见
      9. 无神论的重生与消失
      10. 插曲：关于迷信和魔术
    7. 第七章无需上帝也能行善：论善、恶与道德
      1. 邪恶的问题
      2. 全能的——是还是不是？
      3. 主以神秘的方式行事
      4. 有些邪恶并非真实存在，尽管表面上如此
      5. 上帝真的是仁慈的吗？
      6. 道德不需要上帝
      7. 宙斯与湿婆之战
      8. 夏娃总是对的
      9. 世俗的邪恶观和道德观
      10. “问题仅仅在于人类误解了宗教”
      11. 道德的自然根源
      12. 同情与认同
      13. 插曲：论犯罪、惩罚和责任
    8. 第八章新时代信仰与理性危机：关于人们的怪异观念的信仰
      1. 不合理的信念
      2. 积极思考与伪科学
      3. 以 Nikken 为例
      4. 顺势疗法
      5. 利用古代和科学的威望
      6. 量子物理学与新时代
      7. 分类错误和科学阶梯
      8. 案例研究：占星术
      9. 第二个案例研究：迈尔斯-布里格斯测试
      10. 同步性
      11. 案例研究：Hug 和 Bug
      12. 新时代偏见
      13. 幕间：走进神秘的香格里拉
  16. PART I

    THE ART OF THINKING CLEARLY
    1. CHAPTER ONE To Meet the World with an Open Mind: Concerning the Tools and Compass Needed in the Quest for Knowledge
      1. My Own Bumpy Trip
      2. To Have an Open Mind
      3. Explanations and Ockham’s Razor
      4. Traps in Thinking
      5. Rationality and Wisdom
      6. Having Ideas and Forming a Philosophy of Life
      7. My Point of View
      8. Secular Humanism
      9. Interlude: On Spirituality and Flow
    2. CHAPTER TWO I Believe That I Know: Concerning Reality, Knowledge, and Truth
      1. What Is Knowledge?
      2. Is What Seems Real Really Real?
      3. Matters of Fact and Matters of Taste
      4. What Is Truth?
      5. Truth as Absolute, Truth as Relative
      6. Social Constructions
      7. Postmodernism and Education
      8. Relativism and Politics
      9. Interlude: On Three Great Mysteries
    3. CHAPTER THREE Beliefs Based on Good Reasons: Concerning the Grounds That Underlie One’s Convictions
      1. “But What Do You Believe in, Then?”
      2. Is Belief in Science a Kind of Faith?
      3. Intellectual Honesty
      4. “Extraordinary Claims Require Extraordinary Evidence”
      5. Unmasking What Is Implausible
      6. Interlude: On Exploring Rival Moves in Chess and Rival Moves in the Game of Life
    4. CHAPTER FOUR What Is Science? Concerning Theories, Experiments, Conclusions, and Science’s Essence
      1. At the Very Heart of Science
      2. Experimentation, Rejection, and Revision: The Very Core of What Science Is
      3. Deductive Processes of Inference
      4. Inductive Processes of Inference
      5. Case Study: Louis Pasteur and Spontaneous Generation
      6. Falsifiability
      7. Mathematics and Its Absolute Truths
      8. Blind Experiments and Placebos
      9. The Darker Side of Science
      10. Are Religion and Science Mutually Compatible?
      11. Interlude: On the Usefulness of Science
    5. CHAPTER FIVE Ghosts in the Head: Concerning Our Wonderful but Easily Fooled Brains
      1. Our Brains Pull the Wool over Our Eyes
      2. Social Thinking and Abstract Thinking
      3. Moral Thinking
      4. Was the Human Brain Designed to Be Religious?
      5. Our Very Human Theory of Mind
      6. Magical Thinking
      7. Interlude: On Heaven and Paradise
    6. CHAPTER SIX A Natural World: Concerning Naturalism, Agnosticism, and Atheism
      1. Naturalism and Materialism
      2. Atheists as Provocateurs
      3. Atheism in American Life
      4. Atheists as Beings with No Morality
      5. Agnostic or Atheist?
      6. Many Agnostics Are Actually Atheists
      7. What Does an Atheist Actually Believe?
      8. Thirteen Prejudices about Atheism
      9. Atheism’s Rebirth and Disappearance
      10. Interlude: On Superstition and Hocus-Pocus
    7. CHAPTER SEVEN Being Good without Needing God: Concerning Goodness, Evil, and Morality
      1. The Problem of Evil
      2. Omnipotent—Yes or No?
      3. The Lord Works in Mysterious Ways
      4. Some Kinds of Evil Aren’t Real, despite Appearances
      5. Is God Actually Good?
      6. Morality Has No Need for a God
      7. The Fight between Zeus and Shiva
      8. Eve Is Always Right
      9. A Secular View of Evil and Morality
      10. “The Problem Is Merely That Humans Misinterpret Religion”
      11. The Natural Roots of Morality
      12. Empathy and Identification
      13. Interlude: On Crime, Punishment, and Responsibility
    8. CHAPTER EIGHT New Age Beliefs and the Crisis of Reason: Concerning People’s Beliefs in Strange Ideas
      1. Unreasonable Beliefs
      2. Positive Thinking and Pseudoscience
      3. Nikken as a Case Study
      4. Homeopathy
      5. Exploiting the Cachet of Antiquity and That of Science
      6. Quantum Physics and the New Age
      7. Category Errors and the Ladder of Sciences
      8. A Case Study: Astrology
      9. Second Case Study: The Myers-Briggs Test
      10. Synchronicity
      11. Case Study: Hug and Bug
      12. New Age Prejudices
      13. Interlude: On the Mystic Land of Shangri-La
  17. 第二部分

    通向新启蒙之路
    1. 第九章当宗教脱离正轨：关于狂热主义、极端主义和基督教式塔利班主义
      1. 上帝讨厌女人吗？
      2. 天主教会反对堕胎
      3. 犹太教中的性别隔离
      4. 伊斯兰教法和开罗宣言
      5. 宗教与传统：妇女受压迫问题研究
      6. 亵渎、叛教和言论自由
      7. 伊斯兰国
      8. 北欧恐怖分子
      9. 基督教极端主义
      10. 约书亚世代
      11. 等候基督的再来
      12. 基督教塔利班
      13. 耶稣将粉碎不信者
      14. 插曲：关于人类苦难和医疗实践
    2. 第十章我们的起源之争：关于进化论、神创论和反科学
      1. 达尔文的遗产
      2. 猴子审判，1925 年
      3. 进化论取得了几次胜利
      4. 智能设计
      5. 美国学校的智能设计
      6. 瑞典的创造论
      7. 插曲：论正常与异常
    3. 第十一章思想史：关于世俗启蒙运动的根源
      1. 理性、同情心和各种“黄金法则”
      2. 古代哲学
      3. 三位知识巨人
      4. 以人为本
      5. 中世纪
      6. 文艺复兴
      7. 理性主义者和经验主义者
      8. 启蒙运动
      9. 世俗哲学、道德和政治
      10. 启蒙运动是一场争取自由的运动
      11. 十九世纪
      12. 自由思想者和无神论者
      13. 插曲：论自由意志
    4. 第十二章我们时代的世俗声音：关于敬畏、政治和宗教
      1. 美国第一个人文主义协会
      2. 爱因斯坦的宗教信仰之谜
      3. 当今世俗声音
      4. 插曲：关于瞬间移动和对死亡的恐惧
    5. 第十三章启蒙运动：关于自由、权利和尊重
      1. 普世权利与人类解放
      2. 身份陷阱
      3. 伊斯兰教与宗教批判
      4. 本质主义与人性观
      5. 性别本质主义和性别视角
      6. 什么是宗教自由？
      7. 例如：锡克教徒和刀
      8. 追求道德独立而非宗教自由
      9. 宗教与医学伦理
      10. 论世俗主义与社会健康
      11. 当今世界宗教信仰正在兴起还是衰落？
      12. 插曲：关于感恩与愧疚感
    6. 第十四章我们应该教给孩子什么？关于信仰、科学以及学校如何谈论生活
      1. 让孩子们发现真实的世界
      2. 瑞典的宗派学校
      3. 学校的宗教教育
      4. 学校的全新生活哲学
      5. 插曲：论自然与超自然
  18. PART II

    THE PATHWAY TO A NEW ENLIGHTENMENT
    1. CHAPTER NINE When Religion Runs off the Rails: Concerning Fanaticism, Extremism, and Christian-Style Talibanism
      1. Does God Hate Women?
      2. The Catholic Church’s Opposition to Abortion
      3. Sexual Apartheid in Judaism
      4. Sharia and the Cairo Declaration
      5. Religion and Tradition: A Study in the Oppression of Women
      6. Blasphemy, Apostasy, and Freedom of Speech
      7. ISIS
      8. Nordic Terror
      9. Christian Extremism
      10. The Joshua Generation
      11. Waiting for the Second Coming of Christ
      12. Christian Taliban
      13. Jesus Shall Crush the Nonbelievers
      14. Interlude: On Human Suffering and Medical Practice
    2. CHAPTER TEN The Battle over Our Origins: Concerning Evolution, Creationism, and Anti-science
      1. Darwin’s Legacy
      2. Monkey Trial, 1925
      3. Evolution Scores a Couple of Victories
      4. Intelligent Design
      5. Intelligent Design in American Schools
      6. Creationism in Sweden
      7. Interlude: On the Normal and the Abnormal
    3. CHAPTER ELEVEN The History of Ideas: Concerning the Roots of Secular Enlightenment
      1. Reason, Compassion, and Various “Golden Rules”
      2. The Philosophy of Ancient Times
      3. Three Intellectual Giants
      4. Humanity at the Focal Point
      5. The Middle Ages
      6. The Renaissance
      7. Rationalists and Empiricists
      8. The Enlightenment
      9. Secular Philosophy, Morality, and Politics
      10. The Enlightenment as a Movement for Freedom
      11. The Nineteenth Century
      12. Freethinkers and Atheists
      13. Interlude: On Free Will
    4. CHAPTER TWELVE Secular Voices in Our Day: Concerning Awe, Politics, and Religion
      1. The First Humanist Society in the United States
      2. The Myth of Albert Einstein’s Religiousness
      3. Secular Voices Today
      4. Interlude: On Teleportation and the Fear of Death
    5. CHAPTER THIRTEEN Enlightenment: Concerning Freedoms, Rights, and Respect
      1. Universal Rights and Human Liberation
      2. Identity as a Trap
      3. Islam and the Criticism of Religion
      4. Essentialism and Viewpoints on Humanity
      5. Gender Essentialism and the Lens of Gender
      6. What Is Religious Freedom?
      7. Example: Sikhs and Knives
      8. For Ethical Independence Rather Than Religious Freedom
      9. Religion and Medical Ethics
      10. On Secularism and Social Health
      11. Is Religious Belief Rising or Falling in Today’s World?
      12. Interlude: On Gratitude and Feelings of Guilt
    6. CHAPTER FOURTEEN What Should We Teach Our Children? Concerning Faith, Science, and How Schools Talk about Life
      1. Let Children Discover the World as It Truly Is
      2. Sectarian Schools in Sweden
      3. Religious Education in Schools
      4. A Fresh New Philosophy of Life for Schools
      5. Interlude: On the Natural and the Supernatural
  19. 后记与致谢
  20. Afterword and Words of Thanks
  21. 笔记
  22. Notes

指导

  9. 序言道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特
  10. Foreword Douglas Hofstadter
  11. 前言Christer Sturmark
  12. Foreword Christer Sturmark
  13. 序言：关于昨日的世界和今日的世界
  14. Prelude: Concerning Yesterday’s World and Today’s World
  15. 内容开始
  16. Start of Content
  17. 后记与致谢
  18. Afterword and Words of Thanks
  19. 笔记
  20. Notes

前言

FOREWORD

道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特

Douglas Hofstadter

我为本书写序言是我的荣幸，也是我的荣幸。将本书翻译成英文也是我的荣幸，我满怀热情地从事这项工作已有数年。

It is a great pleasure and a great honor to write the foreword to this book. And it has also been a great pleasure and a great honor to translate this book into English—a task in which I have been engaged, with love, for several years.

直到 2016 年初，我才听说过克里斯特·斯图马克，当时他通过电子邮件邀请我参加在斯德哥尔摩举行的一个小型研讨会，主题是“知识的极限”。他提到了几位可能会参加的人，其中一些人我认识或听说过，这让我很感兴趣。我碰巧很久以前就住在斯德哥尔摩，非常喜欢这座城市，所以这是一个我无法抗拒的诱惑。我想补充一点，这位不知名的绅士的邀请信写得非常生动，真诚友好，这也有助于打破平衡。

I had never heard of Christer Sturmark until early 2016, when, via e-mail, he invited me to participate in a small symposium in Stockholm on the topic “limits to knowledge.” He mentioned several people who would probably be there, some of whom I knew or had heard of, and I was intrigued. I happened to have lived in Stockholm long ago and was very fond of the city, so it was a temptation I couldn’t resist. I might add that this unknown gentleman’s invitation was written in a very lively and genuinely friendly manner, which also helped tip the balance.

我刚才说我从未听说过克里斯特，当时我真心相信这一点，但当我到达斯德哥尔摩时，我发现我大错特错。克里斯特给我看了一封他 1980 年代初写给我的热情粉丝信（一封真正的邮政信），当时他还是一个十几岁的摇滚音乐家，然后他给我看了我给他的回信，他给我的回信，以及我给他的第二封回信……我完全忘记了这一切！显然，我很久以前对他的风格的反应一定与我最近的反应相似。2016 年，克里斯特仍然像他年轻时一样孩子气十足、热情洋溢。

I just told you that I had never heard of Christer, and that’s what I sincerely believed at the time, but when I arrived in Stockholm, I found out that I was quite wrong. Christer showed me an enthusiastic fan letter (a genuine postal letter) that he had written to me back in the early 1980s, when he was a teenaged rock musician, and then he showed me my reply to him, and his reply to me, and my second reply to him . . . I had completely forgotten all that! Clearly, my long-ago reactions to his style must have been similar to my much more recent reactions. In 2016, Christer was still just as boyish and ebullient as he had been as a very young man.

2016 年，我在斯德哥尔摩参加了他的研讨会，度过了一段愉快的时光，尤其是结识了维也纳数学家兼作家卡尔·西格蒙德，他后来成为了我的好朋友。但卡尔并不是我通过克里斯特结识的唯一好朋友。另一位朋友就是克里斯特本人。事情是这样的。

I had an excellent time at his symposium in Stockholm in 2016, especially getting to know the Viennese mathematician and writer Karl Sigmund, who later became a great friend. But Karl wasn’t the only good friend I made thanks to Christer. The other friend was Christer himself. Here’s what happened.

研讨会结束的那天，克里斯特邀请了几位参会者到他位于利丁厄岛的家中共进晚餐，利丁厄岛位于穿过 Lilla Värtan 海峡，来到斯德哥尔摩。我永远不会忘记那天晚上，他的前妻、至今仍是好友的 Gunilla Backman 为我们演唱了一首我自己的歌曲，由数学家 Anders Karlqvist 用钢琴伴奏。我感动得流下了眼泪。

The day the symposium ended, Christer invited a handful of participants to dinner at his house on the lovely island of Lidingö, just to the east of Stockholm, across the Lilla Värtan Strait. I’ll never forget how that evening his former wife and still great friend Gunilla Backman sang one of my own songs for us, accompanied by mathematician Anders Karlqvist at the piano. It practically moved me to tears.

然后，克里斯特惊讶地发现我会说瑞典语，便主动给我一本他新写的书《二十一世纪的启蒙运动》。这本书很厚，但克里斯特笑着说：“别担心，这本书是用非常简单的瑞典语写的。你很容易就能读懂。”他的意思是，这本书不是用浮夸的学术术语、晦涩的瑞典方言、古代诗歌之类的语言写的。事实上，这本书是用相当复杂的瑞典语写的，对我来说读起来并不容易。不过幸运的是，我不用字典就能理解我看到的大部分内容。

And then Christer, who had just discovered with great surprise that I spoke some Swedish, spontaneously offered me a copy of his brandnew book Upplysning i det tjugoförsta århundradet (“Enlightenment in the Twenty-First Century”). It was a hefty tome, but Christer smiled and said, “Don’t worry—it’s in pretty simple Swedish. You’ll easily be able to read it.” What he meant was that it wasn’t written in pompous academic jargon or in an obscure Swedish dialect or in ancient verse or anything of the sort. In actual fact, it was written in quite sophisticated Swedish and not at all a piece of cake for me to read. Luckily, though, I could make sense of most of what I saw without using a dictionary.

一开始，我完全不知道这本书讲的是什么，但在回家的航班上，我翻阅了一遍，非常感兴趣。我可以看出，这本书为人类在充满冲突的世界中共同生活和相处提供了一种理想的个人愿景；事实上，这是一首对宽容、清晰思维和对科学的信仰的雄辩赞歌。在某些方面，它让我想起了马丁·加德纳的经典著作《以科学的名义流行和谬误》，马丁·加德纳是我的偶像。对我来说，在青少年时期阅读这本书是一次改变人生的经历。

At the outset, I had no idea what the book was about, but on my flight home, I paged through it and got very intrigued. I could see that it was giving a personal vision of an idealistic way for human beings to live together and get along in a world filled with conflict; in fact, it was an eloquent paean for tolerance, clear thinking, and belief in science. In some ways, it reminded me of the classic book Fads and Fallacies in the Name of Science by Martin Gardner, a hero of mine. For me, reading that book in my teenage years had been a life-changing experience.

克里斯特的书深深地吸引了我一生的理想主义和对科学的信仰，回到家后，我突然想到也许我可以把它翻译成英文。这样做，我不仅帮了克里斯特一个忙，也帮了自己一个忙，因为翻译他的书会迫使我努力学习瑞典语，自从 1966 年我在瑞典住了半年以来，我一直很喜欢瑞典语。此外，假设这本书出版了，我希望为英语世界的人们做一件好事，让他们能够获得一套有价值的理想主义思想。这些都是我提出建议的极好理由，令我高兴的是，克里斯特对我的提议感到兴奋。他为什么不应该高兴呢？毕竟，一位他曾经钦佩的作家现在提出做他的翻译，纯粹是出于友谊！还有什么比这更让他惊讶和欣慰的呢？

The flavor of Christer’s book deeply appealed to my lifelong sense of idealism and belief in science, and once I was home I suddenly had the idea that maybe I could translate it into English. In so doing, not only would I be doing Christer a favor but also I would be doing myself a favor, since translating his book would force me to work hard on my Swedish, a language I’ve loved ever since 1966, when I lived in Sweden for half a year. Moreover, assuming that the book got published, I would hopefully be doing a favor for people in the English-speaking world, by making a valuable set of idealistic ideas available to them. Those were all excellent reasons for my suggestion, and to my delight, Christer was thrilled with my offer. And why shouldn’t he have been? After all, an author whom he had once admired was now offering to be his translator, purely out of friendship! What could have surprised and gratified him more than that?

2016 年秋天，我热切地投入到这项工作中。在几个月的时间里，我每天翻译大约一页，总共完成了这本书的三分之一。那时，我在印第安纳大学休假一年迫在眉睫，我已经计划在乌普萨拉的伟大大学度过三个冬季月份。我突然想到，在乌普萨拉的三个月里，一个非常合适的项目就是在那里完成翻译，离斯德哥尔摩只有一个小时左右的车程，这样克里斯特和我就可以不时见面，讨论各种细节。

In fall 2016, I eagerly plunged into the task. During the course of several months, I translated roughly a page a day, altogether doing maybe one-third of the book. At that point, my sabbatical year from Indiana University was looming, and I had already been planning to spend the three winter months at the great university in Uppsala. It struck me that a very appropriate project to undertake during my three Uppsala months would be to complete the translation right there, only an hour or so away from Stockholm, so that Christer and I could meet from time to time and discuss all sorts of details.

事实确实如此。在 2017 年 12 月至 2018 年 2 月的寒冷黑暗时期，我和妻子 Baofen 多次从乌普萨拉乘火车前往斯德哥尔摩，然后前往位于利丁厄（位于斯德哥尔摩的另一边）另一边的 Christer 家，在那里我们度过了一段美好的时光，彼此更加了解。就这样，一次偶然的演讲邀请变成了一段伟大的友谊。

Indeed, that’s just what happened. During the cold, dark months from December 2017 through February 2018, my wife Baofen and I took the train several times from Uppsala to Stockholm, then made our way out to Christer’s home on the far side of Lidingö (itself on the far side of Stockholm), and there we all had a wonderful time getting to know each other better. And in this way, a casual lecture invitation turned into a great friendship.

现在让我谈谈克里斯特的书本身，因为这正是人们对序言的期望——而且确实如此。

Now let me say some things about Christer’s book itself, since that’s what people expect from a foreword—and rightly so.

《点燃理性之火》（作者用英文诗意地重新命名）源于克里斯特年轻时对逻辑、数学和科学的热情。小时候，他对宇宙的悖论、奇异和魔力着迷。但他很快意识到，虽然有很多神秘之处，但也有一种方法可以研究和揭开许多神秘之处——即通过科学和数学。他全身心投入到这些学科的研究中，也投入到相关活动中，比如国际象棋（他仍然喜欢下国际象棋，尤其是和他的小儿子利奥一起下）。

To Light the Flame of Reason (as the author poetically renamed it in English) sprang out of Christer’s youthful passion for logic, math, and science. As a boy, he was fascinated by the universe’s paradoxicality, strangeness, and magic. But he soon came to see that although there was plenty of mystery, there was also a way to study and to penetrate much of the mystery—namely, through science and mathematics. He threw himself into the study of those disciplines, and also into related activities, like chess (which he still loves to play, especially with his young son Leo).

通过与思想世界的密切接触，人们确信存在着一种超越一切教条、迷信和宗教的真理，如果全人类都能够接受这种真理，那么将开启一个奇妙的启蒙时代，甚至可能带来世界和平。

Out of this intense engagement with the world of ideas came a conviction that there is a kind of truth that transcends all dogmas, all superstitions, and all religions, and that if humanity as a whole were to embrace that sort of truth, it would open up a marvelous period of enlightenment and could even bring about world peace.

多年来，克里斯特对科学本身的涉足——一开始是计算机科学，后来是其他科学——逐渐演变成一种十字军东征（如果我敢用这个煽动性的词的话）——一场以科学为基础的对所有种族、生活方式、文化和信仰体系的人们进行宽容的十字军东征。

Throughout the years, Christer’s involvement with science itself—computer science at the start, but then other sciences—gradually turned into a kind of crusade (if I dare use that inflammatory word)—a crusade for a science-based tolerance of people of all races, lifestyles, cultures, and belief systems.

克里斯特发现，世界上已经有一群志同道合的人在思考这个问题，他们就是世俗人文主义者，他们相信仁慈对待所有人，不是出于宗教原因，而是出于对宽容和清晰思维力量的信仰，也出于对我们在这个微小的蓝绿色星球上集体脆弱性的深刻感受，这个星球在数十亿颗恒星之间旋转，而我们自己又在数十亿个星系之间旋转。换句话说，一种深刻的谦卑感启发了克里斯特（以及其他世俗人文主义者）尝试与这个星球上的其他生物和睦相处，而不是成为盲目的、偏见驱动的仇恨的牺牲品，并与所谓的“敌人”进行持续的恶性战斗。

Christer discovered that there was already a worldwide movement of kindred spirits who thought along these same lines—namely, secular human-ists—people who believe in benevolence towards all humans, not for religious reasons but out of a belief in the power of tolerance and clear thinking, and also out of a vivid sense of our collective fragility on this tiny blue-green sphere spinning its way among billions of stars, themselves among billions of galaxies. In other words, a sense of profound humility inspired Christer (and other secular humanists) to try to get along with the other beings on this planet, rather than falling victim to blind, prejudice-driven hatreds and engaging in constant vicious battles with supposed “enemies.”

最终，始终是个理想主义者的克里斯特决定创立自己的出版公司——Fri Tanke（“自由思想”），用瑞典语出版高质量的书籍，同时创办一份名为Sans（“感觉”）的杂志，该杂志解释和倡导科学、逻辑和世俗人文主义哲学，同时反对伪科学、迷信和原教旨主义宗教。

Eventually, Christer, ever the idealist, decided to found his own publishing firm—Fri Tanke (“Free Thought”)—and to publish high-quality books in Swedish, as well as a magazine called Sans (“Sense”), which would explain and advocate science, logic, and the philosophy of secular humanism, while arguing against pseudoscience, superstitions, and fundamentalist religions.

克里斯特的梦想成真了，这在一定程度上要归功于他的好友 Björn Ulvaeus（ABBA 乐队成员）的帮助，几年前他成为了一位颇具影响力的瑞典出版商。Fri Tanke 出版的众多书籍中，有许多我最敬佩的一些思想家的书籍译本，例如理查德·道金斯、丹尼尔·丹尼特、丽贝卡·戈德斯坦、米哈伊尔·戈尔巴乔夫、安德鲁·霍奇斯、史蒂芬·平克等。

Christer’s dream came true, thanks in part to help from his good friend Björn Ulvaeus (of ABBA fame), and some years ago he became an influential Swedish publisher. Among the many books issued by Fri Tanke are numerous translations of books written by some of the thinkers I most admire, such as Richard Dawkins, Daniel Dennett, Rebecca Goldstein, Mikhail Gorbachev, Andrew Hodges, Steven Pinker, and numerous others.

随着时间的流逝，克里斯特的知名度不断提高，他成为了瑞典著名的演讲者和电视名人，代表了世俗人文主义思想。人们经常看到他反驳占星家，他们声称每个人的命运都是由星星决定的，或者与坚持认为达尔文进化论是骗局的宗教神职人员辩论，或者捍卫自己的信条，即瑞典法律应该像有组织的宗教一样尊重无神论哲学。尽管克里斯特总是彬彬有礼，但他总是热衷于公开捍卫他深信不疑的所有这些立场，无论这样做有多难。我对他的热情和勇气表示敬意！

As the years passed, Christer’s increasing visibility led him to become a well-known speaker and television personality in Sweden, representing the ideas of secular humanism most of all. He often could be seen arguing against astrologers who claimed everyone’s fate was predestined in the stars, or debating with religious clerics who insisted that Darwinian evolution was a hoax, or defending his own credo that the philosophy of atheism should be every bit as respected by Swedish laws as organized religions are. Though unfailingly polite, Christer was always passionate about publicly defending all these stances in which he believed so deeply, no matter how hard it was to do so. My hat is off to him for his fervor and his courage!

当我住在乌普萨拉并经常与克里斯特交流时，我很快发现他也在身体力行他所宣扬的理念。他是瑞典移民的斗士，尤其是那些因宗教迫害而逃到瑞典的难民。我亲眼目睹克里斯特如何为一位孟加拉博客作者提供巨大的个人帮助，这位博客作者因为仇恨自由思想和宽容的恐怖分子的死亡威胁而逃离祖国——正是这些极端分子残忍地袭击并差点杀死了巴基斯坦女童教育活动家、少女马拉拉·优素福扎伊。

While I was living in Uppsala and interacting with Christer quite frequently, I soon discovered that he was also practicing what he preached. He was a crusader for immigrants in Sweden, especially for people who had fled to Sweden as refugees from religious persecution. I saw firsthand how Christer gave enormous personal help to a Bangladeshi blogger who had fled his native land because of the threat of death from terrorists who hated free thinking and tolerance—the same kinds of extremists who had brutally attacked and nearly killed the teenaged girl Malala Yousafzai, who was an activist for education for girls in Pakistan.

简而言之，我开始敬佩克里斯特，他是一位思想家、作家、出版商和人。我们现在是亲密的朋友，我们之间的联系部分在于我们对人类抱有一种年轻的理想主义希望。他的书——这本书——清晰、具体、令人愉快地表达了他的理想主义观念。克里斯特和我一样，喜欢用例子和故事来表达他的观点，并且他在本书的每一章中都很好地运用了这些例子和故事。

In short, I came to admire Christer as a thinker, writer, publisher, and human being. We are now close friends, and part of what binds us is that we share a kind of youthful idealistic hope for humanity. His book—this book—expresses his sense of idealism clearly, concretely, and enjoyably. Christer, like me, loves examples and stories to get his points across, and he uses them well in every chapter of this book.

此外——也许在这里，我发现了我对他的影响——他在写作时喜欢玩弄形式。就像在《哥德尔、埃舍尔、巴赫》中，我在更严肃的章节和更有趣的对话之间交替，克里斯特在他的书中也在更严肃的章节和更有趣的“插曲”之间交替，在这些插曲中，他允许自己更自由地表达纯粹的个人感受。

Moreover—and here, perhaps, I detect a little trace of my own influence on him—he likes playing with form when he writes. Just as in Gödel, Escher, Bach, I alternated between more serious chapters and more playful dialogues, so Christer, in his book, alternates between more serious chapters and more playful “interludes,” in which he allows himself a bit more liberty in expressing purely personal feelings.

作为之前几本书的译者，我拥有相当多的翻译经验，而我作为译者的风格之一就是随心所欲——我称之为“诗意谎言感”。我允许自己在某些地方以与原文略有不同的方式表达内容，因为我认为这样在英语中效果会更好。我有时也会随心所欲地建议添加（或可能删除）一些想法。在这本书中，我使用的这种傲慢风格并不比我之前翻译的书少——但我的优势在于，我可以随时询问原作者我建议的细微改动是否能被他接受。令我欣慰的是，克里斯特几乎总是会给我开绿灯。这使得作者和译者之间的关系非常愉快和随和，在过去的几年里，我们作为合作伙伴，在互利互惠中获得了极大的乐趣，实现了将克里斯特的原著彻底移植到我的语言和文化中（即英语和美国文化），而克里斯特的原著当然深深植根于他自己的瑞典语言和文化的本土。

As a translator of several previous books, I had quite a lot of experience in translation, and part of my style as a translator is that of taking lots of liberties—I call this “poetic lie-sense.” Here and there, I allow myself to say things somewhat differently from the way they were expressed in the original, as I think it will work more effectively that way in English. I also sometimes take the liberty to suggest adding (or possibly dropping) a few ideas here and there. In this book, no less than in earlier books I’d translated, I used this brash style—but I had the advantage that I could always ask the original author if the small changes that I was suggesting were acceptable to him. To my gratification, Christer nearly always gave me a green light. This made for a very pleasant and easygoing relationship between author and translator, and during these past few years we’ve had great fun in our give-and-take as partners in the realization of this radical transplantation, into my language and my culture (namely, the English language and the American culture), of Christer’s original book, which of course was deeply rooted in his own native soil of the Swedish language and culture.

现在这本书已经完成，我会怀念我们愉快的作者/译者互动，但现在是我着手新项目的时候了——虽然我不再翻译克里斯特的书，但我们的友谊将继续发展和繁荣。最重要的是，我热切希望克里斯特的梦想——一个真正开放的社会，一个普遍宽容和普遍尊重科学的社会——能够实现，这要归功于他自己的贡献——尤其是这本极具启发性和深刻个人色彩的书。

Now that it’s done, I will miss our delightful author/translator interactions, but it’s high time for me to move on to new projects—and although I will no longer be translating Christer’s book, our friendship will continue to grow and flourish. Most of all, I fervently hope that Christer’s dream of a truly open society with universal tolerance and a universal reverence for science will come to exist, aided by his own contributions—especially by this highly stimulating and deeply personal book.

2020 年 11 月 17 日

November 17, 2020

印第安纳州布卢明顿

Bloomington, Indiana

前言

FOREWORD

克里斯特·史都马克

Christer Sturmark

年代有时，在我最黑暗的时刻，我担心我的同胞正在慢慢地但肯定地失去清晰和独立思考的能力，理性和合理性。

Sometimes, in my darkest hours, I am worried that my fellow humans are slowly but surely losing the capacity of clear and independent thinking, of reason and rationality.

我认为，随着柏林墙的倒塌和冷战的结束而开启的全球自由思想和价值观时代似乎已经悲剧地结束了。

The global era of liberal ideas and values, which I see as having begun with the fall of the Berlin Wall and the end of the Cold War, seems tragically to have come to an end.

21 世纪第三个十年伊始，世界发生的许多事态发展让我愈发担忧。世界遭受了由新型冠状病毒引起的 COVID-19 全球大流行。全球科学家的不懈努力以前所未有的速度研发出了疫苗——这无疑充分证明了科学和协作的力量。但与此同时，我们看到反疫苗接种运动日益增多，这些运动往往（但并非总是）建立在“新世界秩序”阴谋论的基础上——一个不存在的组织，据称由精英阶层控制（通常被认为是犹太人，因此遵循了典型的反犹太主义趋势），其目标是创建一个世界政府，通过控制思想的微芯片和疫苗控制全人类，并将世界人口减少到目前的十分之一。

Many developments in the world at the start of this, the third decade of the twenty-first century, are making me increasingly worried. The world has been hit by the global pandemic of COVID-19, caused by a new coronavirus. Frantic work by scientists throughout the world has resulted in the development of vaccines with a speed never seen before—certainly an impressive proof of the power of science and collaboration. But at the same time, we are seeing an increase in anti-vaccination movements, often (but not always) founded on conspiracy theories about a “New World Order”—a nonexistent organization supposedly controlled by an elite (often believed to be Jewish, thus following classic antisemitic trends) having the goal of creating a world government that would control all of humanity through mind-controlling microchips and vaccines, and would reduce the world population to one-tenth of its current size.

美国新世界秩序阴谋论的根源可以追溯到激进的反政府右翼势力，以及担心出现反基督者的末日主义基督教原教旨主义势力。

The roots of the New World Order conspiracy theory in the United States can be traced to the militant antigovernment Right and the end-ofthe-world brand of fundamentalist Christianity that fears the emergence of an Antichrist.

QAnon阴谋论是美国兴起的又一怪异思想：其信徒声称，有一个崇拜撒旦的恋童癖组织，经营着涉及政客、警察和政府机构的全球性性交易业务。没有人可以信任。

The QAnon conspiracy is another example of bizarre thinking that is on the rise in the United States: Its believers allege that there is an organization of pedophiles who worship Satan and who are running a global sex- trafficking business that involves politicians, police, and government institutes. No one can be trusted.

但阴谋论只是问题的一小部分：在世界各地，有这样一种观念正在传播：应该禁止某些嘲笑各种信仰体系的文字或图片，而那些违反这些原则的人应该被处以死刑。

But conspiracy theories are just a small part of the problem: Throughout the world, ideas are spreading to the effect that certain words or pictures that make fun of various belief systems should be banned, and that those who break these principles should be punished by death.

我们很多人都记得1989年伊朗领导人阿亚图拉·霍梅尼对萨尔曼·拉什迪发布的教令，他命令全世界的穆斯林杀死拉什迪。

Many of us remember the fatwa on Salman Rushdie pronounced by the Iranian leader Ayatollah Khomeini in 1989, by which he ordered Muslims throughout the world to kill Rushdie.

这些思想正在迅速传播，言论自由在世界范围内越来越多的国家受到威胁。

These kinds of ideas are spreading fast, and freedom of speech is under threat in an increasing number of countries throughout the world.

2020年10月16日，法国中学教师塞缪尔·帕蒂被一名年轻穆斯林斩首。在讨论言论自由的启蒙思想时，帕蒂在课堂上展示了伊斯兰教先知穆罕默德的漫画。

On October 16, 2020, the French middle-school teacher Samuel Paty was beheaded by a young Muslim. Paty had shown cartoons of the Islamic prophet Muhammad in class, during a discussion about the enlightenment idea of freedom of expression.

在波兰，一个非常保守的天主教政权上台了。在匈牙利，情况也大体如此。这些国家的言论自由和独立新闻受到严重限制。

In Poland, a very conservative and Catholic regime has come to power. In Hungary, the trend is much the same. The freedom of speech and independent press are severely limited in these countries.

2018 年，意大利选出了一个联合政府，由民粹主义政党（五星运动）和一群属于北方联盟（前身为北方联盟）的极右翼分子共同执政。北方联盟的成立理念是将意大利从那不勒斯以南的所有地区驱逐出境。在奥地利和俄罗斯，极右翼民粹主义和保守的道德价值观正在迅速蔓延。

In 2018, a coalition government was elected in Italy, jointly ruled by a populist party (the Five Star Movement, or Movimento Cinque Stelle) and a group of right-wing extremists belonging to the Lega (formerly Lega Nord), a party founded on the idea of ejecting from Italy all parts of the country from Naples southward. In Austria and Russia, right-wing populism and conservative moral values are quickly gaining ground.

在菲律宾，总统罗德里戈·杜特尔特在打击毒品和伊斯兰圣战分子的斗争中拒绝尊重人权和合法权利。他经常自豪地宣称他亲手杀死了犯罪嫌疑人，并有计划地支持行刑队对吸毒者和其他罪犯进行法外处决。许多街头流浪儿童都是受害者。杜特尔特还鼓励他的士兵强奸妇女。

In the Philippines, President Rodrigo Duterte refuses to respect human and legal rights in his fight against drugs and Islamist jihadists. He has often proudly stated that he personally killed criminal suspects, and he has systematically supported death squads carrying out extrajudicial killings of drug users and other criminals. Many street children were among the victims. Duterte has also encouraged his soldiers to rape women.

中国最近的事态发展也令人担忧。信息技术被广泛用于监控和控制公民，随着经济的发展，这个国家变得更加专制，而不是减少专制。而在土耳其，伊斯兰主义和民族主义思想占据了主导地位，而在印度，印度教民族主义者掌权。

Recent developments in China are also highly worrisome. Information technology is widely used to monitor and control the citizens, and as the economy is developing, the country is becoming more authoritarian, rather than less so. And in Turkey, Islamism and nationalistic ideas have taken over, while in India, Hindu nationalists have come to power.

最后但同样重要的是，美国曾是世界大部分地区的启蒙和希望灯塔，但四年来（2017-2020）一直由一位似乎不适合执政的总统领导。那个时代现在已经结束，但这个国家已经严重两极分化，很难在很长一段时间内治愈。

And last but certainly not least, the United States of America, formerly a beacon of enlightenment and hope for much of the world, has been led for four years (2017–2020) by a president who seems unfit to run anything. That era is over now, but the country is deeply polarized in a way that will make it difficult to heal for a long time.

那么，解决这一切的办法是什么呢？

So, what is the antidote to all this?

我认为，我们需要复兴我所说的“启蒙价值观”。我认为我们需要复兴清晰思考的艺术，并实现世俗伦理的复兴。

What is needed, I believe, is a revival of what I call “enlightenment values.” I believe we need to revive the art of clear thinking and bring about a renaissance of secular ethics.

这本书是我为这一发展做出贡献的尝试。我相信一个人必须从自己做起，从小处着手。如果每个人，无论年老还是年轻，都决定以开放的心态帮助建立一个新世界，并尝试更加系统化和清晰地思考，那么我们就离我的愿景更近了一步。

This book is my attempt to contribute to such a development. I believe that one must begin with oneself, and work on a small scale. If each human being, whether young or old, were to decide to try to help build a new world in an open-minded way and were to try to be a bit more systematic and clear thinking, we would be well on the way toward my vision.

我也希望这样的理想能够被纳入世界各地的学校体系。如今，许多学校可以说处于危机之中。这与其说是由于纪律和行为问题，不如说是由于对知识和理解的本质失去了洞察力。世界各地的学校和大学的学生需要接触一种更哲学的方法；他们需要更多地练习仔细清晰的思考，更多地意识到生活的复杂性，更深入地探究人类存在的本质。只有当我们真正认识到自己是善于反思、有意识的人时，我们才能充分参与生活并改善生活，不仅是为了我们自己，也是为了他人。

I also harbor a hope that such ideals could come to be included in the school systems throughout the world. Today, many schools could be said to be in a state of crisis. It’s not so much due to problems of discipline and behavior but, rather, to a loss of perspective about the nature of knowledge and understanding. Students in schools and universities throughout the world need to be exposed to a more philosophical approach; they need to have more exercises in careful and clear thinking, greater awareness of life’s complexities, and deeper probing into the nature of human existence. Only when we truly recognize ourselves as reflecting, conscious humans can we fully participate in life and improve it, not only for ourselves but also for others.

我们还必须认识到，伦理和道德价值观不一定源于宗教。伦理学是哲学的一个长期分支，与宗教没有不可或缺的联系。事实上，道德价值观可以牢固地扎根于完全非宗教、世俗和人文主义的方式中。我们必须让我们的孩子知道，科学的世界观是最迷人的，科学与人文主义的伦理学相结合，可以奠定个人世界观的基础。

We also crucially need to realize that ethical and moral values do not have to stem from religion. Ethics is a long-standing branch of philosophy, and it has no indispensable link with religion. Indeed, moral values can be solidly grounded in a totally nonreligious, secular, and humanist fashion. We have to let our children know that a scientific outlook on the world is the most fascinating one there is, and that science, together with a humanist form of ethics, can ground a personal worldview.

本书源于我对二十一世纪前二十年理性与启蒙的关注，在此期间，宗教原教旨主义、伪科学、文化相对主义、后真相相对主义、阴谋论和其他反科学态度在世界各地如野火般蔓延。

This book grew out of my concern about rationality and enlightenment during the first twenty years of the twenty-first century, in which religious fundamentalism, pseudoscience, cultural relativism, post-truth relativism, conspiracy theories, and other antiscientific attitudes have been spreading like wildfire throughout the world.

这本书的项目始于几年前，当时我用瑞典语写了一本关于二十一世纪新启蒙运动必要性的书——这种启蒙运动将恢复理性、清晰的思维以及基于世俗人文主义的道德和宽容。

This book project started a few years ago, when I wrote a book in Swedish about the necessity for a new enlightenment for the twenty-first century—an enlightenment that would bring back reason, clear thinking, and ethics and tolerance grounded in secular humanism.

你现在正在读的这本书就是从那本书中衍生出来的，是我与我少年时代的智力英雄，几年后成为我的好朋友道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特教授的精彩合作。他的书《哥德尔、埃舍尔、巴赫：永恒的金辫》在我二十出头的时候改变了我的生活，它让我放弃了成为流行歌星（或至少是流行音乐家，但两者都没有实现）的（充满激情但不切实际的）野心，转向数学、哲学、计算机科学，最终转向写作和科学出版。你会在第 1 章中读到更多相关内容。

The book you are now reading grew out of that book, in a wonderful collaboration with my intellectual hero from my teenage days, and now, as of a few years, my good friend, Professor Douglas Hofstadter. His book Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid changed my life when I was in my early twenties, and it turned me away from the (passionate but unreasonable) ambition to become a pop star (or at least a pop musician, neither of which happened) and turned me toward mathematics, philosophy, computer science, and eventually writing and science publishing. You’ll read more about that in chapter 1.

我与道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特合作撰写这本书的故事在道格拉斯的前言中已经讲得很清楚了，所以我就不再重复了。他的语言能力和多才多艺使他能够先将我的整个瑞典语手稿翻译成英语，1然后我们一起工作了三个月，道格访问了我的母校乌普萨拉（我在那里学习计算机科学），为英语读者创作了我的“启蒙宣言”的共同写作版本。我很高兴这本书还将以中文、俄语和韩语出版，所以希望我的启蒙信息能够传达给更多的读者，而不仅仅是少数瑞典语使用者。

The story of how I came to collaborate with Douglas Hofstadter on this book is well told in Doug’s foreword, so I will not repeat it here. His language skills and versatile mind made it possible for him to first translate my entire Swedish manuscript to English,1 and then we worked together for three months while Doug visited my alma mater in Uppsala (where I studied computer science) to create this co-written version of my “enlightenment manifesto” for an English-speaking audience. I am thrilled that the book will also be published in Chinese, Russian, and Korean, so hopefully my enlightenment message will reach a much larger audience than just the tiny set of speakers of Swedish.

本书由两部分组成。第一部分采用“微观视角”。我的目标是为读者提供工具，让他们能够在日常生活中更清晰、更有效地思考。我希望提供关键和见解，让复杂、精致、多维的思想得以绽放并发挥其全部潜力。

This book consists of two parts. Part I comes from taking a “micro-perspective.” In it, my aim is to give the reader tools with which to think more clearly and more effectively in the everyday world. I want to provide keys and insights that will allow complex, sophisticated, multidimensional thoughts to bloom and to reach their full potential.

第二部分采取了总体的“宏观视角”。我的目标是提出一个新的启蒙时代的政治和哲学愿景——一个自由世俗的世界，人们不会受到教条或迷信的限制或压迫，一个没有种族主义、性别歧视或其他偏见的开放社会，一个人权占据中心地位的社会。2

Part II takes an overarching “macro-perspective.” Here my aim is to present a political and philosophical vision of a new Age of Enlightenment—a vision of a free and secular world in which people are not limited or oppressed by dogmas or superstitions, an open society without racism or sexism or other prejudices, a society where human rights occupy center stage.2

我希望这本书能为人们提供一些工具，使他们能够得出更深刻的结论，做出更明智的决定，从而帮助他们发展反思和分析的能力。归根结底，这一切都归结为清晰思考的艺术。在某种程度上，这意味着一个人的思想和推理应该清晰而敏锐，而不是模糊和草率。但这也意味着一个人应该仔细思考，而不是仅仅基于少量证据就仓促做出判断。我希望本书的实用性能够自然而然地从我对如何学习将我们的思维过程建立在对我们如何获取和处理知识的坚实理解之上的讨论中体现出来。

My hope is that this book can furnish people with tools with which to draw deeper conclusions and make wiser decisions, thereby helping them develop their capacities of reflection and analysis. In the final analysis, what it all comes down to is the art of thinking clearly. In part, this means that one’s thoughts and reasoning should be lucid and sharp, not blurry and sloppy. But it also means that one should think things through carefully, not just leap to snap judgments based on little evidence. I hope that this book’s usefulness will flow naturally out of my discussion of how we can learn to ground our thought processes in a solid understanding of how we acquire knowledge and process it.

我也知道，有些人肯定会把我的立场看作是对宗教信仰的批判。但是，我想强调的是，这绝对不是我的态度。在过去的二十年里，我结交了许多朋友，既有宗教人士，也有非宗教人士，其中有拉比、伊玛目、耶稣会士、科学家和哲学家。所有这些朋友和熟人极大地丰富了我的思想。

I am also aware that some people will inevitably take my position as a critique of religious beliefs. However, I wish to emphasize that this is truly not my attitude. Throughout these past twenty years, I’ve made many friends, both religious and nonreligious ones—among them rabbis, imams, Jesuits, scientists, and philosophers. My thoughts have been greatly enriched by all these friends and acquaintances.

我非常尊重每个人的个人信仰。我知道宗教在人的生活中起着非常重要的作用，尤其是在悲伤和绝望的时期。虽然我个人不相信任何形式的死后生活、超自然存在或造物主，但我知道许多宗教人士都有这样一种令人欣慰的信仰，我完全尊重这一点——但遗憾的是，我无法提供任何替代它的东西。尽管我无法提供任何支持，证明我们死后会以任何合理的方式继续活着，但我希望能够提供一个令人信服的理由，让我们主要关注我们在地球上的生活。（即使来世还有来世，那也不是一个不全身心投入现在地球上生活的好理由。）

I have the highest respect for everyone’s personal beliefs. I know that religion can play a very central role in a person’s life, especially in periods of grief and despair. Although I personally do not believe in any kind of life after death or supernatural being or creator, I know that many religious people have such a comforting belief, and I fully respect that—but alas, I am unable to offer any replacement for it. Hopefully, though, even if I cannot provide any support for the idea that we continue to live on in any reasonable sense after we die, I will be able to offer a convincing reason to focus primarily on our life on this earth. (Even if there were a life after this one, that would not be a good reason to be less than fully engaged with one’s life right now here on earth.)

最后，我想鼓励读者以批判的眼光阅读本书。毕竟，我对“新启蒙”的整个想法恰恰就是以批判的方式审视主张和判断。请不要因为本书不时涉及哲学而感到沮丧。许多人认为哲学很难，甚至晦涩难懂，但我认为这是一种误解。弹钢琴很难吗？嗯，这完全取决于你是想弹巴赫还是《一闪一闪的小星星》。关于哲学，也可以这样说。事实上，我经常和我十一岁的儿子利奥谈论哲学和存在主义问题，他问我的问题与我们成年人问的问题非常相似。任何年龄的人都可以进行哲学思考。这取决于你如何处理问题，以及你处理哲学的哪些方面。

Finally, I want to encourage my readers to read this book with a critical eye. After all, my whole idea of a “new enlightenment” is precisely that of examining claims and judgments in a critical manner. Please do not be put off by the fact that this book deals, from time to time, with philosophy. Many people think that philosophy is difficult or even opaque, but I think this is a misconception. Is it hard to play the piano? Well, it all depends on whether you are trying to play Bach or “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.” Much the same could be said concerning philosophy. I actually talk quite often about philosophical and existential questions with my eleven-year-old son Leo, and the questions he asks me are quite similar to the questions we grown-ups ask. Philosophizing can be done by people of any age. It just depends on how you approach the questions, and which aspects of philosophy you tackle.

在这本书中，在连续的章节之间，你总会发现一个关于某个主题的“插曲”（就像一顿大餐中两道较丰盛的菜肴之间供应的少许柠檬冰糕）。这些插曲在形式上比章节更自由一些，有时也更个人化；它们也可以提出谜语而不回答它们。

In this book, between successive chapters you will always find an “Interlude” (like a dash of lemon sherbet served between two heavier courses of a long meal) on some topic or other. These interludes are a bit freer in form than the chapters and are sometimes more personal; they can also pose riddles without answering them.

我个人认为，通过“新启蒙”实现的觉醒有助于社会更加开放，生活方式更加民主，并为全人类创造更有利的生活条件。在我看来，在当今全球化的世界中，世俗的人类观和世俗的道德原则是实现各国人民和平共处的最有希望的途径。我们必须对地球上的生命负责，就此时此刻。今天有太多人遭受着各种形式的宗教或迷信压迫。因此，我提出的世俗观除了是一个带来启蒙的计划之外，还是一个带来解放的计划。

Personally, I feel that a reawakening through a “new enlightenment” can contribute to a more open society, to a more democratic way of life, and to more favorable living conditions for all human beings. In my opinion, in today’s globalized world, a secular vision of humanity and a secular body of ethical principles are the most promising avenues to bring about peaceful coexistence among peoples. We must take responsibility for life on earth, in the here and now. Too many people today suffer from religious or superstitious oppression of one form or another. The secular vision I am proposing is thus, aside from being a plan to bring enlightenment, a plan to bring liberation.

我将这本书命名为《点燃理性的火焰：二十一世纪的清晰思考》，因为我的梦想是让它成为新启蒙时代的乐观宣言。

I have called the book To Light the Flame of Reason: Clear Thinking for the Twenty-First Century because my dream is for it to be an optimistic manifesto for a new Age of Enlightenment.

2021 年 1 月 1 日

January 1, 2021

瑞典斯德哥尔摩

Stockholm, Sweden

序幕关于昨日的世界和今日的世界

PRELUDE Concerning Yesterday’s World and Today’s World

我不相信天启宗教。

我不会与你的永生有任何关系；

我们这一生已经够悲惨了，

而不需要对另一个人进行荒谬的推测。

— 拜伦勋爵，1822 年 3 月 8 日致托马斯·摩尔的信

I do not believe in revealed religion.

I will have nothing to do with your immortality;

we are miserable enough in this life,

without the absurdity of speculating upon another.

—Lord Byron, letter to Thomas Moore, March 8, 1822

我奥地利作家斯蒂芬·茨威格（1881-1942）在巴西的一间酒店房间里写下了他对旧世界崩溃的著名描述。这本书是他最后的绝望宣言，写完后，他自杀了，他的妻子也自杀了。这本书于 1942 年在瑞典首次出版，书名为《昨日的世界》（实际上，它是用德语印刷的，书名为《昨日的世界》）。茨威格长期以来一直是欧洲最受欢迎的作家之一，但纳粹主义迫使他流亡，他的书在德国被焚毁。

It was in a hotel room in Brazil that the Austrian writer Stefan Zweig (1881–1942) wrote his famous description of the collapse of the Old World. That book was his final desperate manifesto, and after he had finished writing it, he took his own life, and his wife took hers as well. The book first appeared in print in Sweden in 1942 under the title The World of Yesterday (actually, it was printed in German, and its title was Die Welt von Gestern). Zweig had for a long time been one of Europe’s most popular writers, but Nazism had driven him into exile, and in Germany his books were burned.

《昨日的世界》源于茨威格对周围世界已经疯狂的感受。他经历过这样一个时期：直到第一次世界大战前，欧洲盛行的道德准则和对未来的信念突然被连根拔起，取而代之的是狂热和非理性。正如他所说（德文由安西娅·贝尔译）：

The World of Yesterday grew out of Zweig’s sense that the world around him had gone crazy. He had lived through a period in which the ethical compass and the belief in the future that had pervaded Europe up until World War I were suddenly uprooted and replaced by fanaticism and irrationality. As he puts it (as translated from the German by Anthea Bell):

所有末日的灰马都席卷了我的生活：革命和饥荒、货币贬值和恐怖、流行病和移民；我亲眼看到大众意识形态成长和蔓延，如意大利的法西斯主义、德国的纳粹主义、俄国的布尔什维克主义，而最重要的则是毒害了我们欧洲文化之花的终极瘟疫，即普遍的民族主义。

我无助地、无助地目睹了人类以难以想象的方式重新陷入人们认为早已被遗忘的野蛮状态。其蓄意的非人道教条计划。我们这一代人在几百年后再次看到没有实际宣战的战争、集中营、酷刑、大规模盗窃、对无防御城市的轰炸、过去五十代人从未见过的兽性，希望后代不会再看到这些。1

All the pale horses of the apocalypse have stormed through my life: revolution and famine, currency depreciation and terror, epidemics and emigration; I have seen great mass ideologies grow before my eyes and spread, Fascism in Italy, National Socialism in Germany, Bolshevism in Russia, and above all the ultimate pestilence that has poisoned the flower of our European culture, nationalism in general.

I have been a defenseless, hapless witness of the unimaginable relapse of mankind into what was believed to be long-forgotten barbarism, with its deliberate program of inhuman dogma. It was for our generation, after hundreds of years, to see again wars without actual declarations of war, concentration camps, torture, mass theft, and the bombing of defenseless cities, bestiality unknown for the last fifty generations, and it is to be hoped that future generations will not see them again.1

茨威格接着指出了他所经历的时代的矛盾之处：

Then Zweig goes on to point out the paradoxical aspect of the times he had lived through:

然而矛盾的是，当我们的世界将道德时钟倒转一千年时，我也看到人类在技术和智力领域取得了前所未有的成就，瞬间超越了数百万年来取得的一切成就：用飞机征服天空，话语在说出的瞬间传遍世界各地，征服太空，分裂原子，战胜最隐蔽的疾病。几乎每天都有昨天还不可能的事情成为可能。在我们这个时代，人类作为一个整体从未如此邪恶地行事，也从未取得如此近乎神圣的进步。2

Yet paradoxically, at the same time as our world was turning the moral clock back a thousand years, I have also seen mankind achieve unheard-of feats in the spheres of technology and the intellect, instantly outdoing everything previously achieved in millions of years: the conquest of the air with the airplane, words traveling all over the world at the moment when they are spoken, the conquest of space, the splitting of the atom, the defeat of even the most insidious diseases. Almost daily, things still impossible yesterday have become possible. Never until our time has mankind as a whole acted so diabolically, or made such almost divine progress.2

全球性精神病

A Global Psychosis

除了茨威格描述的欧洲中心主义视角外，我们很难不发现它与当今世界的相似之处。互联网通过网站、电子邮件以及 Facebook 和 Twitter 等社交媒体将世界上大多数人联系在一起。

Aside from the Eurocentric perspective in Zweig’s description, it is hard not to see parallels with the world of today. The internet has linked most of the people of the world together through websites, e-mail, and social media like Facebook and Twitter.

茨威格的描述涉及这样一个事实：欧洲从一个科学进步惊人、对未来充满信心、充满启蒙精神的奇妙时期，迅速转变为一个充满非理性和狂热的噩梦时期。而今天，这种情况又再次发生，只不过是在全球范围内发生。科学进步从未像今天这样令人印象深刻。挖掘信息和知识从未像今天这样容易。独裁政权和其他极权主义政权从未像今天这样难以让其人民处于无知的黑暗之中。让全球观众看到、听到或阅读自己的作品从未如此简单。

Zweig’s description concerns a Europe that had moved rapidly from a marvelous period of astonishing scientific progress, deep belief in the future, and a spirit of enlightenment to a nightmarish period of irrationality and fanaticism. And exactly that is happening once again today, but now on a global scale. Never has scientific progress been so impressive as nowadays. Never has it been so easy to dig up information and knowledge as today. Never has it been so hard for dictatorships and other totalitarian regimes to keep their populations in the murk of ignorance. Never has it been so simple to make oneself be seen, heard, or read by a global audience.

然而，与此同时，世界却陷入了一种群体性精神错乱。每天都有同性恋者被杀害或监禁，这都是由于某些人对上帝旨意的解读。妇女因为被禁止堕胎而死亡。人们被石头砸死，或者被砍断双手，因为他们的性取向设想神圣的法律。宗教原教旨主义者在互联网上发布斩首视频，敦促观众加入他们的圣战。人们被蒙骗，以为上帝可以通过奇迹治愈致命疾病。关于必须驱除的巫婆或恶魔的神话导致了虐待或死亡的案例，其中甚至儿童也常常成为受害者。

And yet, simultaneously, the world has been hit by a form of mass psychosis. On a daily basis, homosexual people are being killed or imprisoned, thanks to certain people’s interpretations of God’s will. Women are dying because they have been denied abortions. People are being stoned to death, or are having their hands chopped off, because of the way they happen to conceive of divine laws. Religious fundamentalists post videos of beheadings on the internet, urging viewers to join them in their holy war. People are hoodwinked into thinking that God can cure deadly diseases through miracles. Myths about witches or demons that must be exorcised result in cases of maltreatment or death, in which even children are too often the victims.

自 1979 年阿亚图拉·霍梅尼在伊朗掌权以来，自 1989 年柏林墙倒塌和冷战结束以来，最重要的是自 2001 年 9 月世贸中心遭受袭击以来，非理性、迷信和狂热似乎在我们周围越来越盛行。例子多种多样；以下列表是一个很小但具有代表性的样本。

Since Ayatollah Khomeini’s seizure of power in Iran in 1979, since the fall of the Berlin Wall and the end of the Cold War in 1989, and most of all, since the attack on the World Trade Center in September 2001, it seems that irrationality, superstition, and fanaticism have been making ever greater gains all around us. Examples are manifold; the list that follows is a tiny but representative sampler.

2015 年 11 月，巴黎及其北部郊区发生了一系列恐怖袭击事件。发生了多起大规模枪击事件，以及一起发生在咖啡馆和餐馆的自杀式爆炸事件。袭击者杀死了 130 人，其中包括 90 名正在巴塔克兰剧院观看音乐会的人。伊斯兰国（通常称为“ISIS”，或称“哈里发国”）声称对袭击事件负责。

In November 2015, a series of terrorist attacks took place in Paris and the city’s northern suburbs. There were several mass shootings and a suicide bombing at cafés and restaurants. The attackers killed 130 people, including 90 who were attending a concert at the Bataclan theater. The Islamic State (usually called “ISIS,” or as they call themselves, “The Caliphate”) claimed responsibility for the attacks.

2016 年 7 月 14 日，法国国庆日当天，一辆重达 19 吨的卡车故意冲撞尼斯英国人大道上正在庆祝的人群。86 人死亡，459 人受伤。伊斯兰国声称对此次袭击负责。

On Bastille Day in France—July 14, 2016—a nineteen-ton truck was deliberately driven into a crowd of people celebrating on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice. Eighty-six people died and 459 were injured. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks.

2017 年 4 月 7 日，斯德哥尔摩也发生了一起类似的卡车袭击事件，造成 5 人死亡，多人受伤。卡车司机宣誓效忠伊斯兰国。

A similar attack with a truck took place in Stockholm on April 7, 2017, killing five people and injuring many more. The driver had sworn allegiance to the Islamic State.

2017 年 9 月，印度记者高丽·兰克什 (Gauri Lankesh) 在班加罗尔家门外遭枪杀。兰克什以强烈批评本邦印度民族主义组织而闻名。2016 年，她因撰写一篇文章指控印度人民党成员盗窃而被判诽谤罪。

In September 2017, Indian journalist Gauri Lankesh was shot dead outside her home in Bangalore. Lankesh was known as a fierce critic of Hindu nationalist organizations in her state. In 2016, she had been convicted of libel because of an article she wrote, accusing members of the Bharatiya Janata party of theft.

2016 年，堪萨斯州一伙自称“十字军”的民兵因策划针对索马里穆斯林移民的恐怖袭击而被指控。他们计划对一处有许多穆斯林移民居住的公寓楼发动炸弹袭击，该公寓楼内还有一座清真寺。

In 2016, a band of militiamen in Kansas, calling themselves “Crusaders,” were charged in a terrorist plot against Somali Muslim immigrants. They were planning a bomb attack on an apartment complex where many Muslim immigrants lived, and which was also home to a mosque.

2018年，印度北方邦一名肉贩因涉嫌屠宰牛（牛在印度教中被视为圣物）遭到警方殴打，随后在德里一家医院去世。自2010年以来，因所谓的圣牛纠纷引发的暴力事件已造成28名印度人死亡，其中24人为穆斯林，124人受伤。

In 2018, a meat seller in Uttar Pradesh, India, was beaten up by the police because of allegations that he had slaughtered cows (cows are believed to be holy in the Hindu religion), and he later died in a Delhi hospital. Since 2010, 28 Indians, of whom 24 were Muslims, have been killed, and 124 have been injured, in acts of violence sparked by disputes over the allegedly sacred cows.

2018 年，一群佛教暴徒袭击了斯里兰卡的清真寺和穆斯林拥有的企业，造成两人死亡。斯里兰卡是一个佛教徒占多数的国家。自 2012 年以来，当地的紧张局势和暴力事件一直受到强硬派佛教徒及其组织 BBS（即 Bodu Bala Sena，意为“佛教力量”）的煽动。

In 2018, a Buddhist mob attacked mosques and Muslim-owned businesses in Sri Lanka, resulting in two deaths. Sri Lanka is a Buddhist-majority country. Since 2012, tensions and violence there have been fueled by hard-line Buddhists and their organization BBS, or Bodu Bala Sena (meaning “Buddhist Power Force”).

2012年，萨维塔·哈拉帕纳瓦尔在怀孕第17周时流产。当时她住在爱尔兰，医院的医生拒绝取出胎儿。他们给她的解释是：“这是一个天主教国家。”一周后，她因血液中毒去世。

In 2012, Savita Halappanavar had a miscarriage in the seventeenth week of her pregnancy. She was residing in Ireland, and the doctors in the hospital refused to remove the fetus. The explanation they gave her was: “This is a Catholic country.” She died of blood poisoning one week later.

2014 年 2 月，乌干达总统约韦里·穆塞韦尼签署了一项法律，允许对同性恋者判处死刑。同时，该法律还规定，任何人若被认定为同性恋者，必须举报。这项受圣经启发的法律背后的理由得到了圣公会的热烈支持。法律生效的第二天，一家乌干达报纸公布了 200 名涉嫌同性恋者的姓名和照片，从那一刻起，他们每个人都生活在死亡的威胁之下。（2014 年 8 月，该法律被废除，但纯粹是出于形式上的原因，当时乌干达宪法法院裁定，通过该法律时出席的议会成员太少。然而，乌干达的一些基督教会仍在继续推动该法律再次通过。同性恋在乌干达仍然是一种犯罪。）

In February 2014, Uganda’s president Yoweri Museveni signed a law that permitted the death penalty for homosexuals. At the same time it also became mandatory to report anyone whom one believed to be homosexual. The reasoning behind this Bible-inspired law was eagerly supported by the Anglican Church. On the day after the law came into force, a Ugandan newspaper published the names and photographs of 200 alleged homosexuals, every one of whom, from that moment on, lived under the constant threat of death. (In August 2014, the law was annulled, but for purely formal reasons, when Uganda’s constitutional court ruled that too few members of parliament had been present when the law was passed. Some Christian churches in Uganda are continuing, however, to push for the law to be passed again. Homosexuality is still a crime in Uganda.)

2013 年 3 月，布隆迪天主教会要求政府阻止教会的一个分支团体进行每月一次的朝圣之旅。朝圣者们前往他们认为圣母玛利亚显灵的地方，但教会声称显灵是假的，并想阻止朝圣者前往那里。这导致警方和朝圣者每月都会发生冲突。在其中一次冲突中，警方向朝圣者开枪，造成 10 人死亡，35 人受伤。

In March 2013, the Catholic Church in Burundi asked the state to prevent a splinter group of the church from making its monthly pilgrimage. The pilgrims made their way to a spot where they thought that the Virgin Mary was making an apparition, but the church claimed that the apparition was false and wanted to prevent the group from going there. This resulted in monthly skirmishes between the police and the pilgrims. On one of these occasions, the police shot into the group, killing ten people and injuring thirty-five.

2014 年，在苏丹，27 岁的 Mariam Yahia Ibrahim 因宣称自己是基督徒而非穆斯林而被判处绞刑。（1983 年，苏丹制定了伊斯兰教法，第 10 章对此进行了详细描述。）尽管她已怀孕八个月，但这位年轻女子仍被判处鞭刑一百下，然后才执行死刑。在国际社会的强烈抗议之后，她被释放并飞往美国。

In 2014, in Sudan, twenty-seven-year-old Mariam Yahia Ibrahim was sentenced to death by hanging for having declared herself Christian rather than Muslim. (In 1983, Sudan had instituted Sharia law, which is described in some detail in chapter 10.) Though she was eight months pregnant, the young woman was nonetheless sentenced to be whipped one hundred times before her execution was to take place. After a huge international outcry, she was liberated and flown to the United States.

2014 年，文莱迈出了实施伊斯兰教法的第一步。这一初步措施包括将婚外怀孕、缺席周五祈祷以及传播除伊斯兰教以外的任何宗教定为犯罪。惩罚范围从罚款到监禁。第二阶段，穆斯林偷窃和饮酒将被处以鞭刑，甚至可能被切断四肢或其他身体部位。这些法律于 2015 年生效。2016 年进入第三阶段，通奸、同性恋者性交和亵渎先知穆罕默德都将被处以石刑。

In 2014, Brunei took the first step toward instituting Sharia law. This initial step involved the criminalization of extramarital pregnancy, of missing Friday prayers, and of proselytizing for any religion other than Islam, with the punishment ranging from fines to prison terms. In the second step, theft and the consumption of alcohol by Muslims were made punishable by whippings or possibly by cutting off of limbs or other body parts. These laws came into force in 2015. In 2016 came the third step, in which adultery, sexual intercourse between homosexuals, and blasphemy against the prophet Muhammad would all be punished by stoning to death.

2018 年 6 月，孟加拉国世俗博主 Shahzahan Bachchu 被不明身份的袭击者杀害。不幸的是，这只是孟加拉国一系列世俗活动人士被杀事件中的一个例子。此前，2015 年，世俗出版商 Faisal Arefin Dipan 被砍死。在此之前，世俗博主 Avijit Roy 也被谋杀。同样在 2015 年，捍卫无神论观点的博主 Niloy Neel 在首都达卡的家中被砍死。一些孟加拉国世俗博主设法逃往瑞典，并于 2017 年和 2018 年在那里获得了临时庇护。

In June 2018, the secular Bangladeshi blogger Shahzahan Bachchu was killed by unknown attackers. This, unfortunately, is just one example in a series of killings of secular activists in Bangladesh. Earlier, in 2015, the secular publisher Faisal Arefin Dipan was hacked to death. Prior to that, the secular blogger Avijit Roy was also murdered. Also in 2015, the blogger Niloy Neel, who defended atheist views, was hacked to death in his home in Dhaka, the capital city. Some Bangladeshi secular bloggers managed to flee to Sweden, and in 2017 and 2018, they were granted temporary asylum there.

2017 年和 2018 年，缅甸许多穆斯林罗兴亚人遭到佛教极端分子的袭击和杀害。幸运的是，许多罗兴亚人成功逃往孟加拉国，如今他们住在难民营中。

In 2017 and 2018, many members of the Muslim Rohingya people in Myanmar were attacked and killed by Buddhist extremists. Luckily, many Rohingas managed to escape to Bangladesh, where today they are living in refugee camps.

2015 年，一名极端正统的犹太反同性恋极端分子袭击了耶路撒冷的同性恋骄傲节，刺死一人，致数人受伤。袭击者在袭击发生前三周才刚从监狱获释，此前他因 2005 年的类似袭击被判入狱十年。

In 2015, an ultra-Orthodox Jewish anti-gay extremist attacked a Gay Pride festival in Jerusalem, stabbing one person to death and injuring several others. The attacker had been released from prison just three weeks before the attack, after having served ten years for a similar attack he made in 2005.

2015 年 1 月，激进的伊斯兰分子闯入法国讽刺杂志《查理周刊》的编辑会议，造成 12 人死亡，多人受伤。受害者的“罪行”涉及发表批评各种宗教（包括伊斯兰教）的讽刺画。袭击后，肇事者逃走，在警方为期三天的严密搜查后最终被击毙。与此次袭击有关的是巴黎一家犹太商店的另一起袭击，当时有数人被劫持为人质。法国警方试图解救人质时，一些人质死亡。

In January 2015, militant Islamists invaded a meeting of the editors of the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, killing twelve people and injuring many more. The victims’ “crime” involved the publication of satirical drawings that criticized various religions, including Islam. After the attack, the perpetrators fled and were eventually killed, after an intense police search that lasted for three days. Linked to this attack was another attack on a Jewish shop in Paris, in which several people were taken hostage. Some of the hostages died when the French police attempted to liberate them.

同月，尼日利亚东北部的一个市场发生两名自杀式炸弹袭击，造成数人死亡。袭击者是两​​名十几岁的女孩，她们腰间各挂有炸弹，她们引爆了炸弹，并炸死了受害者。

In that same month, several people were killed by two suicide bombers in a market in northeast Nigeria. The perpetrators were two teenage girls, each wearing a bomb strapped to her waist, who blew themselves up, along with their victims.

是什么驱使人们做出所有这些狂热行为，又是什么导致了这些行为背后怪异的信念？

What is it that drives people to carry out all these fanatical acts, and what gives rise to the bizarre beliefs underlying such acts?

人们不禁要问，是什么让这么多人说他们爱戴和崇敬一个似乎能够接受人们行为如此野蛮的神。他们自称爱戴的神灵也让大量无辜的人因各种自然灾害遭受难以想象的苦难。什么样的神灵会让在泰国度假的儿童在一场巨大的海啸中失去父母？当周围的人都死了，而感谢神灵在一次公共汽车事故中拯救了他们，这又是一种什么样的道德？当他们的神灵允许（或导致）世界各地每天发生灾难时，许多信徒认为，这个神灵只是对干细胞研究和同性恋者的爱之行为等所谓邪恶行为作出了正当的愤怒反应。

One can’t help but wonder what makes so many people say that they love and revere a god who seems to accept the fact that people act so barbarically. The god whom they claim to love also lets vast numbers of innocent people suffer inconceivably as a result of all sorts of natural catastrophes. What kind of god is it that lets children on vacation in Thailand lose their parents in a gigantic tidal wave? And what kind of morality does a person have who thanks God for having saved them in a bus crash, when people sitting all around them died? At the same time as their god allows (or causes) disasters to take place every single day throughout the world, many believers presume that this god is merely reacting with justifiable wrath at such supposedly evil acts as stem-cell research and acts of love committed by homosexuals.

这位神似乎也无法容忍某些人不相信他。在许多国家，否认上帝存在的“罪行”应受到法律制度最严厉的惩罚。上帝似乎确实有一套特殊的优先顺序。所以我想问：为什么数十亿人要尊敬或崇拜这样的神？

This god also seems unable to tolerate not being believed in by some people. In many countries, the “crime” of denying God’s existence merits the legal system’s most severe punishments. God would certainly seem to have a peculiar set of priorities. And so I wonder: Why on earth should billions of people respect or worship such a god?

致命的迷信

Fatal Superstition

世界各地的非理性思维不仅体现在宗教极端主义的表现形式中，魔幻思维等迷信观念也十分普遍，而且可能危及生命。

Irrational thinking throughout the world crops up not only in expressions of religious extremism. Magical thinking and other superstitious notions are also widespread, and moreover, they can be life threatening.

2014年10月，印度恰蒂斯加尔邦一名55岁妇女被家人折磨致死，原因是家人怀疑她通过巫术给家人带来疾病。家人将辣椒粉抹在她的眼睛和耳朵上，然后用藤条将她打死。

In October 2014, a fifty-five-year-old woman in the Indian state of Chhattisgarh was tortured and murdered by her own family members because they suspected that she, through witchcraft, had brought illness upon a family member. Chili powder was smeared all over her eyes and into her ears, and then she was caned to death.

巴西一名罹患癌症的十二岁女孩最终去世，因为她的父亲更相信具有治愈能力的“神医”，而不是使用化疗和放疗的现代癌症治疗方法。

A twelve-year-old girl in Brazil who was suffering from cancer died because her father believed more in a “miracle doctor” supposedly having healing powers than in the modern treatment of cancer using chemotherapy and radiation.

英国一家耶和华见证人基督教派的成员拒绝让他们的孩子输血，因为这违背了他们的宗教信仰。耶和华见证人相信《旧约》（创世记 9:4；利未记 17:10；申命记 12:23）和《新约》（使徒行传 15:28-29）都要求他们不要使用他人的血液。然而，2014 年 3 月，英国一家法院裁定父母无权阻止输血。

A British family who were members of the Christian sect of Jehovah’s Witnesses refused to let their child have a blood transfusion because that would go against their religious convictions. Jehovah’s Witnesses believe that both the Old Testament (Genesis 9:4; Leviticus 17:10; Deuteronomy 12:23) and the New Testament (Acts 15:28–29) command them to abstain from using the blood of others. In March 2014, however, an English court ruled that the parents did not have the authority to stop the blood transfusion from taking place.

这很好，但在许多其他国家，父母的迷信比孩子的生命更受尊重。在美国 37 个州，法律明确规定，如果父母因宗教信仰而拒绝给孩子提供医疗服务，他们不能对孩子可能遭受的任何伤害承担法律责任。

This was good, but in many other countries, parents’ superstitious beliefs are accorded higher respect than their children’s lives. In thirty-seven U.S. states, there are laws that clearly state that if parents deny a child medical treatment because of religious convictions, they cannot be held legally responsible for any harm that might come to the child.

进化论是现代医学研究和实践的基础。然而，近一半的美国公民认为达尔文理论是错误的，人类，正如他们现在的样子，是上帝创造的。对他们来说，人类和猿类之间可能存在任何联系，或者人类可能随着时间的推移而发生变化，这是不可想象的。

The theory of evolution lies at the base of modern medical research and practice. Yet nearly half of all U.S. citizens believe that Darwin’s theory is false and that humans, exactly as they are today, were created by God. To them it is inconceivable that there could exist any kind of link between humans and apes, or that humans might have changed throughout time.

整整三分之一的美国人相信鬼魂和心灵感应。四分之一的美国人相信占星术，也相信耶稣将在未来五十年内重返人间。一些美国政客认为，我们无需担心全球变暖，因为耶稣重返人间后会解决我们所有的问题。

A full one-third of the American populace believes in ghosts and telepathy. One American in four believes in astrology, and also in the idea that Jesus will come back to earth within the next fifty years. Some American politicians believe that we don’t need to worry our heads over global warming because Jesus will solve all our problems when he returns to earth.

2014年5月，印度人民党（BJP）的印度民族主义者纳伦德拉·莫迪（Narendra Modi）出任印度总理，当时，BJP国会议员拉梅什·波克里亚尔·尼尚克（Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank）在一场政治辩论中表示，占星术远远领先于科学，而科学与占星术相比实际上是“侏儒”。

In May 2014, the Hindu nationalist Narendra Modi, of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), became prime minister of India. At that time, the BJP parliament member Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank stated in a political debate that as trology was far ahead of science, and that science was in fact “a pygmy” compared to astrology.

瑞典的极端主义和迷信

Swedish Extremism and Superstition

当然，瑞典也未能免受宗教极端主义和迷信的影响。自 2012 年夏天以来，数百名瑞典人前往叙利亚，与宗教圣战分子并肩作战。

Of course, Sweden is not immune to religious extremism and superstition. Since summer 2012, hundreds of Swedes traveled to Syria in order to fight hand in hand alongside religious jihadists.

布罗斯镇的两位父母断定他们十二岁的女儿被恶魔附身了。他们向当地一家自由教会（非国家支持的基督教会）的牧师寻求帮助，以驱除恶魔。女孩受到了严重的虐待，父母和牧师都被判入狱。那一年不是 1613 年，而是 2013 年。不久之后，又一起疑似驱魔案的酷刑案件在同一个城市引起了轰动。

Two parents in the town of Borås concluded that their twelve-year-old daughter was possessed by evil spirits. They sought help from the pastor in a local free church (a non-state-sponsored Christian church) in order to drive out the demons. The girl was severely mishandled, and both the parents and the pastor were sentenced to jail terms. The year was not 1613 but 2013. Not too long after that, yet another case of torture in a suspected case of exorcism created a stir in the same city.

在瑞典儿童遭受驱魔师虐待的同时，瑞典电视台却兴高采烈地播放基于这种鬼魂信仰的娱乐节目，包括“鬼屋”和自称能与死者灵魂沟通的灵媒降神会。TV4 频道的负责人认为这一切都是无害的娱乐。

At the same time as children in Sweden are mistreated by exorcists, Swedish television channels happily show entertainment programs based on just such belief in spirits, featuring “haunted houses” and seances with mediums who claim to be able to communicate with the souls of dead people. The responsible officials on Channel TV4 consider it all to be harmless fun.

瑞典北部的一名少女与一名经常殴打她的男子同居。她向一名算命师寻求建议，算命师用塔罗牌预测了她的未来。算命师表示，她只是在感情上遇到了麻烦，但塔罗牌显示，如果两人有了孩子，她的伴侣会对她更加热情。算命师的建议让她不再寻求帮助。她对塔罗牌的信任意味着她将在未来许多年里继续受害。

A teenage girl in northern Sweden was living with a man who regularly beat her. She sought advice from a fortuneteller, who divined her future using Tarot cards. He stated that she was simply going through a troublesome patch in her relationship, but that the Tarot cards showed that her partner would become much warmer to her if they had children together. The fortuneteller’s advice made her stop seeking help. Her trust in the Tarot cards meant that she would continue to be victimized for many more years.

一名属于绿党的瑞典议员要求议会调查局对天空中可疑的尾迹进行调查，这种尾迹被称为“化学尾迹”。（“化学尾迹”对尾迹的解释源于一种阴谋论，该阴谋论声称喷气式飞机在飞行时在天空中留下的白线是控制天气、人类行为和无数其他现象的秘密尝试的一部分。事实上，尾迹是在喷气发动机喷出的热气体与高空的冷空气接触时产生的。这些线条只是冰晶流。）绿党前任领导人声称，美国中央情报局和俄罗斯是这些天空神秘现象的幕后黑手；而一名属于中间党的议员则声称，飞机喷洒化学物质是为了控制天气。

A Swedish parliament member belonging to the Green Party requested that the parliament’s investigation bureau look into suspicious contrail lines in the sky, which were referred to as “chemtrails.” (The “chemtrail” interpretation of contrail lines stems from a conspiracy theory that claims that white lines in the sky, left by jet planes as they fly, are part of a secret attempt to control the weather, human behavior, and countless other phenomena. In actual fact, contrail lines arise when the hot gases expelled by the jet engines come in contact with cold air at high altitudes. The lines are just streams of ice crystals.) The Green Party’s previous leader claimed that the CIA and Russia lay behind these mysterious displays in the sky, and a parliament member belonging to the Center Party claimed that airplanes were spraying out chemicals in an attempt to control the weather.

瑞典基督教价值党（www.kristnavardepartiet.se）规模虽小，但声势浩大，它力图全面禁止堕胎。它还力图推翻禁止鞭刑儿童的禁令，并竭尽全力阻挠体外受精。3该党还力图阻止同性婚姻，并剥夺同性伴侣收养孩子的权利。该党成员还认为，在学校教授进化论是有害的。

Sweden’s small but vocal Christian Values Party (www.kristnavardepartiet.se) seeks to totally ban abortion. It also aims to overturn the ban on caning children and does its best to obstruct in vitro fertilization.3 The party also seeks to block same-sex marriage and to deny same-sex couples the right to adopt children. Its members also believe that the teaching of evolution in schools is harmful.

在瑞典南部，有一所由基督教末日教派普利茅斯兄弟会支持的学校。（普利茅斯兄弟会的名字取自英国普利茅斯市，该教派于 1832 年在此首次集会。在瑞典，该教派成立于 19 世纪 70 年代，如今拥有大约 400 名成员。）教派成员不允许其子女上公立学校，甚至拒绝与非教派成员同桌吃饭。在等待耶稣的第二次降临期间，他们的孩子应尽可能少地与周围社会接触。妇女不得留短发，婚后不得外出工作。教派成员不得看电视或听收音机。他们不得在大学学习或参加任何选举。然而，瑞典议会决定以“普利茅斯兄弟会”的名义为该教派的学校提供​​联邦支持。宗教自由。这些孩子因此受到广泛的洗脑，这似乎根本不重要。

In southern Sweden, there is a school supported by the Christian doomsday sect known as the Plymouth Brothers. (The Plymouth Brothers took their name from the city of Plymouth in England, where the movement’s first gathering took place in 1832. In Sweden, this cult was established in the 1870s, and today it boasts roughly four hundred members.) Sect members do not allow their children to go to public schools and even refuse to eat at the same table as nonmembers of the sect. Their children should have as little contact as possible with the surrounding society, while they are awaiting the second coming of Jesus. Women are not allowed to have short hair, and they must not work outside the home after marriage. Sect members are not allowed to watch television or listen to the radio. They must not study at a university or vote in any election. And yet, the Swedish parliament decided that the sect would receive federal support for its school, in the name of religious freedom. That these children are thereby exposed to extensive brainwashing seems not to matter in any way.

宗教、“新纪元”运动、庸医和迷信并非无害。我们人类的信仰是一件非常重要的事情。然而，政客、记者和整个社会对不同信仰的态度往往不一致。

Religion, the “New Age” movement, quack medicine, and superstition are not harmless. What we humans believe is a matter of major importance. And yet, politicians, journalists, and society in general are often inconsistent in their attitudes toward different sorts of beliefs.

假设你有一个好朋友，在某个时候，他越来越怀疑是否该服用糖尿病药物。你对他的行为非常担心，并严厉地质问他。他解释说，他不会吃药，因为他认为药里被中情局下了毒。他说，他们要抓他——他们想杀了他。

Suppose that you have a good friend who at a certain point becomes more and more skeptical about taking his diabetes medicine. You grow very worried about his behavior and confront him sternly. He explains that he won’t take his medicine because he thinks it has been poisoned by the CIA. They are out to get him, he says—they want to kill him.

你打电话给医生，讲述了刚刚发生的事情。医生对你的朋友进行了检查，并报告了诊断结果：偏执妄想症、精神障碍、精神疾病。你的朋友接受了治疗。

You call up a doctor and relate what just happened. The doctor investigates your friend and reports the diagnosis: paranoid delusions, psychic disturbances, mental illness. Your friend is offered treatment.

另一位好友刚刚与同居伴侣断绝了长期关系。你认为这是一个错误，并问她为什么这么做。她回答说，在参加了一个名为“生命之道”的基督教团体的会议后，她意识到自己不能再与伴侣生活在一起，因为他们还没有结婚。她害怕地坚持说，她将因婚前性行为而永远受到地狱的惩罚。此外，她永远不会让脏话从嘴里说出来，因为那样她也会遭受同样的命运。

Another good friend just broke off her long-term relationship with her live-in partner. You think this is a mistake and ask her why she did this. She replies that after attending a meeting of the Christian group called “The Word of Life,” she realizes that she no longer can live with her partner because they aren’t married. She fearfully insists that she will be punished forever in hell for having had sex before marriage. Moreover, she won’t ever let a swear word cross her lips, because then she will suffer the same fate.

你再次打电话给医生，请他检查一下你的朋友。结果医生给了她同样的诊断：偏执妄想症、精神障碍、精神疾病。但事实并非如此——社会反而说她只是“重生了”。她只是变得虔诚了，仅此而已。

You call up the doctor once again and ask him to check out your friend. It turns out he gives the same diagnosis to her: paranoid delusions, psychic disturbances, mental illness. But no—society says instead that she is just “reborn.” She has simply become religious, that’s all.

社会对这两个朋友的评价完全不同，尽管朋友 #2 死后地狱在等着她的可能性甚至比 CIA 给朋友 #1 的糖尿病药下毒的可能性还要小。毕竟，CIA 至少存在，而且众所周知，它还毒害了某些它认为是威胁的人。

Society judges these two friends of yours in totally different ways, although it is even less likely that hell is awaiting friend #2 when she dies than that the CIA has poisoned friend #1’s diabetes medicine. After all, the CIA at least exists, and it is even known to have poisoned certain people that it considered to be a threat.

显然，社会的普遍衡量标准并不是基于什么是合理的、什么是不合理的。其他因素在决定什么是合理的行为、什么不是合理的行为方面发挥着作用。

It’s obvious that society’s general measuring rods are not based on what is sensible and what is not sensible. Other factors play a role in determining what is considered to be reasonable behavior, and what is not.

人们为什么要在宗教、新纪元运动或迷信中寻求确定性？人们为什么要相信这些奇怪的想法和教条？这个问题很复杂，答案也有很多——不仅仅是社会学的答案，还有政治学、心理学和进化生物学的答案。

Why do people seek certainty in religions, in the New Age movement, or in superstitions? Why do people believe in such strange ideas and dogmas? The question is complicated, and there are many answers—not just sociological answers but also political ones, psychological ones, and ones coming from evolutionary biology.

我们日益全球化的世界可能会引发不安全感、无根感和身份危机。对某些人来说，解决方案是在新时代运动的温暖舒适感中寻求安全感。新时代已成为 X 世代的宗教：占星术、顺势疗法、风水、塔罗牌、灵气（日语中为“万能生命能量”）治疗、虹膜诊断技术、中国替代医学、磁疗、心理综合、脉轮平衡、克里安摄影等庸医主张和其他伪科学思想正在疯狂传播，尤其是在媒体的帮助下，如洪水般源源不断地传播。

Our ever-more globalized world can give rise to feelings of insecurity, rootlessness, and identity crisis. For some people, the solution is to seek security in the warm fuzzy feelings of the New Age movement. The New Age has become Generation X’s religion: quack medical claims such as astrology, homeopathy, feng shui, Tarot cards, Reiki (“universal life energy” in Japanese) healing, iris-based diagnosis techniques, Chinese alternative medicine, magnet therapy, psychosynthesis, chakra balancing, Kirlian photography, and other pseudoscientific ideas are spreading like crazy, particularly with the help of the media, in a ceaseless flood.

玩世不恭的剥削者开设了“领导力和个人发展”课程，网络上也出现了金字塔式的快速致富计划，这些计划都是受新时代运动的启发。各种治疗严重疾病的庸医都以能带来神奇、快速的效果为卖点。伪科学和新时代理念正在诱惑越来越多的人，许多人不仅被欺骗，还被利用——有时甚至会带来悲惨的后果。

Courses in “leadership and personal development” are launched by cynical exploiters, as are pyramid-style get-rich-quick schemes on the web, inspired by the world of the New Age movement. All sorts of quack treatments for serious illnesses are hawked with the promise of bringing fantastic, rapid effects. Pseudoscientific and New Age ideas are luring more and more people, and many are not only tricked but also exploited—sometimes with tragic consequences.

当信徒们面临没有任何证据支持这些理论、没有任何迹象表明这些理论是正确的事实时，他们常常会指出新纪元思想所引发的批评——即对真理概念本身的批评。主张无所谓真假，所以这个观点认为——它们只是对某些人或某些文化是正确的。 “这样那样的事情对你来说可能不正确，但对我来说是正确的！”

When believers are confronted with the fact that there is nothing to support these theories, nothing that would indicate that they are true, they often point to a criticism inspired by New Age thinking—namely, criticism of the very concept of truth. Claims are not true or untrue, so this idea runs—they are merely true for certain people or true for certain cultures. “Such-and-so may not be true for you, but it’s true for me!”

某些知识界和瑞典文化辩论都鼓励这样的观点：所有真理都是相对的（即，真理因人而异），没有一套文化价值观比其他文化价值观更好。不幸的是，这种不切实际的想法无助于对抗击全球变暖或提高我们的普遍道德意识。事实上，恰恰相反，它们欺骗了那些最需要参与新启蒙运动的人。这种相对主义立场实际上是人们智力懒惰的结果，他们宁愿轻率地从一个想法跳到另一个想法，也不愿通过仔细思考得出结论。相对主义者似乎不明白的是，如果没有客观真理，那么你甚至不可能对任何事情都犯错！因此，相对主义是一种方便的自我强化信仰体系。

The notion that all truth is relative (i.e., that what is true varies from person to person), and that no set of cultural values is better than any other, is encouraged in certain intellectual circles, as well as in Swedish cultural debates. Unfortunately, such wishy-washy ideas do nothing to help in the fight against global warming or to raise our general moral consciousness. In fact, quite the contrary, they fool exactly those people who most need to be involved in the project of a new enlightenment. Such a relativist stance is really the result of intellectual laziness on the part of people who prefer to glibly slip from one idea to another rather than reaching conclusions through careful deliberation. And what the relativists don’t seem to understand is that if there is no objective truth, then you can’t even be wrong about anything! Relativism is thus a conveniently self-reinforcing belief system.

然而，在相对主义者中，对那些选择为自己的信仰寻求清晰性和科学依据的人怀有偏见。有科学倾向的人经常会遇到相对主义者或新时代主义者的反对，例如：“你只相信科学能解释的东西！你怎么这么狭隘？”或者，“那爱情呢？难道你不相信爱情吗？显然你无法解释爱情，所以这意味着你不相信爱情！”

And yet, among relativists, prejudices flourish against people who have chosen to seek clarity and a scientific basis for their beliefs. Scientifically inclined people often run into relativist or New Age objections such as this: “You only believe in what science can explain! How can you be so narrow-minded?” Or else, “Well, what about love? Don’t you believe in love? Obviously you can’t explain love, so that means you can’t believe in it!”

为了捍卫他们模糊的思维方式，一些相对主义者和新时代主义者试图让自己免受批评，他们回避根据出现的新事实重新考虑自己的观点。在诸如“你只不过是一个科学原教旨主义者！”之类的奇怪侮辱背后，往往是对科学及其实践者的极大无知——以及对科学及其实践者的蔑视和不宽容。

To defend their blurry ways of thinking, some relativists and New Agers try to make themselves immune to criticism, and they shy away from reconsidering their views in light of new facts that crop up. Behind such weird insults as “You’re nothing but a science fundamentalist!,” there is often a great well of ignorance of—and a contempt and an intolerance for—science and its practitioners.

瑞典是一个相当世俗的国家。宗教在我们的社会中不再扮演重要角色，尤其是与许多其他国家相比。大多数瑞典公民认为自己不信教。瑞典路德教会（曾是官方的国教）如今所传递的信息如此不明确和模糊，以至于很少有人再关心它的教义。

Sweden is a quite secular country. Religion no longer plays a large role in our society, especially in comparison with many other countries. Most Swedish citizens consider themselves nonreligious. The Swedish Lutheran Church (once officially the state religion) today has such an unclear and blurry message to offer that few people care at all about its teachings anymore.

但瑞典也是欧洲的一部分，而整个欧洲的情况要严重得多。许多当代欧洲政客坚持认为欧洲应该有一套基督教价值观，而在波兰等国家，原教旨主义基督徒实际上正在执掌政府。

But Sweden is also part of Europe, and in Europe as a whole the situation is considerably more serious. Many contemporary European politicians are insisting that Europe should have a Christian set of values, and in countries like Poland, fundamentalist Christians actually are running the government.

在美国，尽管长期以来官方一直实行政教分离，但保守的基督教运动对该国政治有着重大影响。许多天主教国家也是如此，当然，迅速发展的伊斯兰教政治形式也是如此，它到处寻求将伊斯兰教法确立为国家法律，并使《古兰经》成为全人类的终极指导原则。
