In the United States, despite the long-standing official separation of church and state, the conservative Christian movement exerts major influences on the country’s politics. The same holds for many Catholic countries and, of course, for the rapidly evolving political form of Islam, which everywhere seeks to install Sharia law as the law of the land and make the Koran become the ultimate guiding principle for all human beings.

我们需要的是一个新的启蒙时代

What We Need Is a New Age of Enlightenment

宗教信仰对社会和政治有着非常严重的影响。全世界对妇女权利、堕胎法、干细胞研究、避孕药、儿童权利、动物权利、安乐死、同性恋、婚姻、科学等问题的看法都深受宗教观点的影响。

Religious beliefs have very serious consequences as far as society and politics are concerned. Opinions about such matters as women’s rights, abortion laws, stem-cell research, contraceptives, children’s rights, animal rights, euthanasia, homosexuality, marriage, science, and so forth are all deeply affected by religious views throughout the world.

如今，国际政治充斥着寻求新世俗启蒙运动和坚持保守世界观的思想冲突。这场冲突不仅对世界政治产生了重大影响，而且影响到所有普通民众的生活。无论是在欧洲还是在世界其他地方，都在进行一场反对恐怖主义和宗教原教旨主义的战争。曾经充满希望的阿拉伯之春已经失去了希望。毒气爆发，世界进入了一个寒冷的冬天，伊斯兰国的崛起和衰落让世界看到了长期以来最残酷的暴力。

Today, international politics is pervaded by a conflict of ideas between those who seek a new secular enlightenment and those who cling to a conservative view of the world. This conflict not only affects world politics in the highest degree but also touches the lives of all ordinary people. Both in Europe and in the rest of the world, a war is being waged against terrorism and religious fundamentalism. The once-promising Arab Spring ran out of gas and turned into a cold winter, and the rise and fall of the Islamic State showed the world the most gruesome violence it had seen in a long time.

宗教原教旨主义最糟糕的形式，其后果在乌干达、苏丹、叙利亚和伊拉克等国家都可以看到，在我们这个地区，这种形式并没有得到太多的支持。但是，原教旨主义背后的基本态度，比如声称道德原则直接由上帝决定，却非常普遍，甚至在瑞典这样一个进步的（而且大多是非宗教的）国家也是如此。

The worst forms of religious fundamentalism, whose consequences we see in such lands as Uganda, Sudan, Syria, and Iraq, don’t have a great deal of support in our part of the world. But the basic attitudes underlying fundamentalism, such as the claim that the principles of morality were dictated directly by God, are very widespread, even in a progressive (and mostly non-religious) country like Sweden.

我们确实需要把这一切抛在身后，因为这些想法属于一个过去的时代。我们需要制定一种新的以启蒙为导向的世俗人文主义来取而代之，其中最核心的是人性。我们需要重新唤醒定义启蒙时代的基本价值观和理想。我们需要接受这样的观点：我们所居住的世界是自然的一部分，它没有超自然或魔法力量的痕迹。只有当这种世界观占主导地位时，对人及其关系的尊重才会占据中心地位，而不是人与一个或多个神的关系。伦理问题应该与宗教脱节。这并不意味着问题会变得更容易——只是意味着思想的检验和判断不会受到宗教教条的深刻污染和限制。

We truly need to put this all behind us, for these are ideas that belong to a bygone era. In their place we need to formulate a new enlightenment-oriented secular humanism, in which what is deeply human is found at the very core. We need to reawaken the basic values and ideals that defined the original age of enlightenment. We need to accept the idea that the world we inhabit is part of nature, and that it has no trace of supernatural or magical forces. Only when such a worldview predominates will respect for people and their relations occupy center stage, as opposed to people’s relations to one or more gods. Ethical questions should be detached from religion. This doesn’t mean that the questions become any easier—just that ideas are tested and judged without being profoundly tainted and constrained by religious dogmas.

这种世俗人文主义建立在自由思想的力量之上，即研究和理解自然世界的力量。尽管并非所有事物都可以研究或理解，​​但对知识和理解的真诚追求建立了一种灵活、非教条的世界观。好奇心和开放性是这种态度的核心。科学方法的谨慎和开放性测试以及科学的创造性和反思性思维方式提供了关键工具。清晰的、受科学启发的思维帮助我们理解了许多其他事情，其中​​包括，一个人可以善良，并且可以被激励去做出道德上善良的行为，而不必屈服于或受到所谓的神圣力量的限制。

Such a form of secular humanism builds on the power of free thought—the power to investigate and understand the natural world. Although not everything can be investigated or understood, the sincere quest for knowledge and understanding establishes a flexible, nondogmatic attitude toward the world. Curiosity and openness lie at the core of such an attitude. The scientific method of careful and open-minded testing, as well as science’s creative and reflective ways of thinking, provides key tools. What clear, science-inspired thinking helps us understand, among many other things, is that a person can be good and can be motivated to carry out morally good actions without ever bowing to, or being limited by, supposedly divine forces.

这种态度还体现在，人们渴望走向世俗的社会结构和世俗的政治形式，在这种形式下，所有处于特定境况的人都会得到同等的尊重和考虑，无论他们拥有何种信仰或文化背景。在这样的社会中，法律、规范和公共场所不反映任何形式的宗教假设，而是反映一套与任何宗教无关的人类道德原则。宗教和政治是分开的。每个人都可以相信自己愿意相信的，只要它不侵犯他人的权利，并且公民不被强迫信奉国家宗教。

This attitude is also characterized by a desire to move toward a secular structure for society and a secular form of politics, in which all people in a given situation are treated with equal respect and consideration, independently of what beliefs or cultural background they might have. In such a society, the laws, the norms, and the public places do not reflect religious presumptions of any sort but, rather, a human set of ethical principles not linked to any religion. Religion and politics are kept apart. Every person can believe what they wish to believe, as long as it does not infringe on others, and as long as citizens are not compelled to submit to a state religion.

这种世俗的人类观体现了对人类的坚定信念，相信人类的能力，相信人类成长和改变的潜力。它体现了这样一种理念：人类生活中的善良源自内心，而非上天强加。

Such a secular vision of humanity represents a strong belief in human beings, in their abilities, and in their potential to grow and change. It represents the idea that goodness in human life comes from within, rather than being imposed from on high.

今天，互联网塑造的全球社会正在迅速成型。不仅企业，国家也日益全球化，当然个人也同样如此。全世界的人们都可以发出自己的声音，并被倾听，并以前所未有的方式在知识和技能方面展开竞争。由于社交媒体的存在，孤立的个人可以在政治发展中发挥比以往更大的作用。今天，比以往任何时候都有更多的人能够获得信息和知识，越来越多的人关注世界局势。越来越多的人有机会通过自己的行动来改变现状。

Today, the global society forged by the internet is taking shape quickly. Not just companies but countries are becoming increasingly globalized, and, of course, individuals are doing so as well. People throughout the world can raise their voices and be heard, and compete in terms of knowledge and skills as never before. Thanks to social media, isolated individuals can play a larger role than ever in political developments. Today, more people have greater access to information and knowledge than ever was dreamed of before, and more people are concerned about the world situation. More people have the chance, through their own actions, to make a difference.

我们每个人，作为个体，都很重要。因此，我们每个人都应该有意识地、反思性地选择自己对现实、世界和人类的看法，这一点至关重要。这意味着，我们所有人都必须训练自己清晰思考的艺术。

Each one of us, as an individual, matters. It is thus vitally important that each of us should choose, in a conscious and reflective manner, our own views of reality, of the world, and of humanity. And this means that it is crucial for us all to train ourselves in the art of thinking clearly.

第一部分

Part I

清晰思考的艺术

THE ART OF THINKING CLEARLY

第一章

CHAPTER ONE

以开放的心态看待世界关于寻求知识所需的工具和指南针

TO MEET THE WORLD WITH AN OPEN MIND Concerning the Tools and Compass Needed in the Quest for Knowledge

判断一个人，要看他提出的问题，而不是他的答案。——皮埃尔·马克·加斯通，莱维斯公爵1

Judge a man by his questions rather than his answers.—Pierre-Marc-Gaston, duc de Lévis1

西我想知道，如果我们头顶的天空一直都是阴云密布，我们人类还会对世界和宇宙同样好奇吗？当人们在繁星点点的夜晚仰望天空时，最有可能首先提出这些伟大的存在主义问题。那里有什么？我从哪里来？我为什么存在？为什么总有东西，而不是什么都没有？成为人类意味着什么？我应该相信什么？我将如何决定我的道德价值观？最后，生命的意义是什么？

Would we humans have been just as curious about the world and the universe if the sky above us had always been cloudy? I wonder. The great existential questions were most likely first posed when people looked up at the sky on a starry night. What is there out there? Where do I come from? Why do I exist? Why is there something at all, instead of just nothing? What does it mean to be human? What should I believe in? How am I going to decide on my moral values? And lastly, what is the meaning of life?

每个人从童年走到成年，走过一段坎坷的人生旅程，都会以新的方式遇到这些永恒的问题，并在余生中继续思考这些问题。

Each person making the bumpy trip from childhood to adulthood runs into these same eternal questions in a fresh way, and continues, for the rest of their life’s trip, to reflect about them.

我的坎坷旅程

My Own Bumpy Trip

小时候，我喜欢读奇幻故事。我最喜欢的一本是刘易斯·卡罗尔 (1832-1898) 的《爱丽丝梦游仙境》。2仙境是一个奇妙的地方，一切皆有可能，但爱丽丝却是个怀疑论者。我总是想起故事中她遇到白皇后的情景。爱丽丝天真地说：“不可能的事情是不能相信的。”白皇后傲慢地反驳道：“我敢说你没有多少练习。我小时候，每天都要练习半个小时。有时候，我在早餐前就相信了多达六件不可能的事情。”

As a child I loved to read tales of fantasy. One of my favorites was Alice in Wonderland by Lewis Carroll (1832–1898).2 Wonderland was a fantastic place where anything was possible, but Alice was a skeptic. I always think of the time when, in the story, she meets the White Queen. Alice innocently says, “One can’t believe impossible things,” to which the White Queen haughtily retorts, “I daresay you haven’t had much practice. When I was younger, I always did it for half an hour a day. Why, sometimes I’ve believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.”

当我还是个孩子的时候，我认为爱丽丝的态度很无聊。显然，人们应该相信不可能的事情！好奇心当时已经成为我生活中强大的驱动力。

When I was a child, I thought that Alice had a boring attitude. Obviously one should believe in what is impossible! Curiosity was already then a strong driving force in my life.

小时候，我以为我能仅凭意念的力量移动物体，这要感谢以色列魔术师尤里·盖勒。1972 年，盖勒出现在美国电视上，数百万观众看到他无需触碰钥匙就能让钥匙弯曲，手表突然​​停止。他成功地让许多人相信他拥有真正的超心理力量，让他能够仅凭专注的力量让物体移动，但持怀疑态度的魔术师，尤其是雷·海曼和詹姆斯·兰迪，揭露了他是如何依靠诡计的。然而，他们揭穿真相的真相并不为公众所知，当然我小时候也不知道。

When I was little, I thought I could move things with the force of thought alone, thanks to the Israeli magician Uri Geller. In 1972, Geller appeared on television in the United States, and millions of viewers saw keys bending and watches suddenly stopping without his ever touching them. He succeeded in convincing many people that he had true parapsychological powers, allowing him to make things move by the pure power of concentration, but skeptical magicians, especially Ray Hyman and James Randi, revealed how he depended on trickery. Their debunking, however, was not known to the general public, and certainly not to me as a child.

我从小就清楚地记得尤里·盖勒，当然，我相信他的魔力。很多时候，我坐在那里盯着火柴盒，集中我所有的力量，试图让它移动——哪怕只是一点点，哪怕只是一毫米！我多么渴望这件事发生！也许我只是想觉得自己与众不同、很特别。既然我想相信，为什么不相信呢？但这从来没有奏效过。在某个时候，我开始怀疑，事情不会仅仅因为我希望它们成真而变成现实。今天我知道尤里·盖勒是个骗子。他确实骗了我。

I remember Uri Geller so clearly from my childhood, and, of course, I believed in his magical powers. Many was the time I sat there staring at a matchbox, concentrating all my powers on it, trying to make it move—just a little bit, just a tiny bit, even just a millimeter! I so yearned for it to happen! Maybe I just wanted to feel that I was different and special. Why not believe it, when I wanted to believe it? But it never worked. At some point, I started to suspect that things wouldn’t become true merely because I wanted them to be true. Today I know that Uri Geller was a faker. He certainly faked me out.

随着年龄的增长，我开始如饥似渴地阅读有关物理和其他科学的书籍。我最喜欢的读物是幻想和科幻小说。我认为艾萨克·阿西莫夫的《基地三部曲》和 JRR 托尔金的《指环王》是杰作。渐渐地，我对世界的了解越来越多，开始与我对“魔法”现象的迷恋相冲突。我内心的那个孩子非常想相信魔法、超心理现象、神和其他超自然生物，但我却无情地长大了。

As I grew older, I started to devour books about physics and other sciences. Among my favorite readings were fantasy and science fiction novels. I thought that The Foundation Trilogy by Isaac Asimov and Lord of the Rings by J. R. R. Tolkien were masterworks. Gradually, my growing knowledge about the world started competing with my fascination with “magical” phenomena. The child in me dearly wanted to believe in magic, parapsychological phenomena, gods, and other supernatural beings, but I was inexorably growing older.

我在瑞典玛丽弗雷德（位于斯德哥尔摩以西约三十英里）的一个小镇（其实只是一个村庄）长大，除了常见的体育运动外，这里给孩子们提供的活动非常有限。但我并不喜欢体育运动。我这辈子从来没有踢过足球或打过冰球。十二岁那年，我开始痴迷数学。当其他孩子踢足球时，我会独自坐在房间里，在方格纸上画曲线。我很快就开始编写德州仪器 TI59 袖珍计算器的程序，然后是计算机（ABC 80）。我真的是个十足的书呆子。

I grew up in the tiny town—really just a village—of Mariefred, Sweden (about thirty miles west of Stockholm), which had an extremely limited supply of things for kids to do, aside from the usual sports. But sports were not for me. I have never played soccer or ice hockey in my life. When I turned twelve, I became obsessed with mathematics. While other kids were playing soccer, I would sit all alone in my room and plot curves on graph paper. I soon started to program a Texas Instruments TI59 pocket calculator, and then a computer (an ABC 80). I really was quite the nerd.

十五岁时，我读到了英国哲学家伯特兰·罗素（1872-1970）的著作。我首先读的是他的回忆录，这给我留下了深刻的印象。罗素不仅是一位哲学家，他还是一位政治活动家，他希望对他人产生影响。他对我十几岁时的人生选择产生了决定性的影响。有一天，我读了他的书《我为什么不是基督徒》（1958 年），这本书为我对哲学的兴趣铺平了道路，激发了我对社会和政治参与的兴趣。1950 年，罗素被授予诺贝尔文学奖，“以表彰他丰富多彩、意义重大的著作，他在这些著作中倡导人道主义理想和思想自由。” 3

When I reached the age of fifteen, I came across the writings of the British philosopher Bertrand Russell (1872–1970). I first read his memoirs, which made a strong impression on me. Russell was not just a philosopher; he was also a political activist, and he wanted to have an impact on others. He certainly had a decisive influence on my choices in life as a teenager. At some point, I read his book Why I Am Not a Christian (1958), which paved the way for my interest in philosophy and sparked my interest in society and in political engagement. In 1950, Russell was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature “in recognition of his varied and significant writings in which he champions humanitarian ideals and freedom of thought.”3

大约在这个年龄，我开始不情愿地意识到，仅仅因为希望某件事是真的而相信它，是一种不诚实的智力行为。我也开始明白，在没有充分理由的情况下相信某件事甚至可能是不道德的。如果我可以相信任何我想相信的东西，那么我对待别人可能就完全是武断的。

At around this age, I started, reluctantly, to realize that it was intellectually dishonest to believe in something just because I wanted it to be true. I also began to understand that it could even be immoral to believe in something without a good reason to do so. If I can believe in anything I want, then my treatment of other people may be totally arbitrary.

我开始意识到，一个人必须能够证明自己的信念。一个人必须有一个合理的理由来相信一个陈述是真实的。因此，我最终放弃了对魔术和超心理现象的信仰；然而，我仍然喜欢表演魔术，直到今天我仍然会表演一些魔术。

I started to see that one has to be able to justify one’s beliefs. One has to have a plausible reason for taking a statement as true. And thus I eventually gave up my belief in magic and in parapsychological phenomena; however, I continued to love performing magic tricks, and I still do some magic today.

我发现现实世界充满了奇妙的奥秘，这取代了我脑海中的奇幻思维。科学世界中未解之谜让我着迷，这是任何奇幻的愿望都无法比拟的。数学、物理、化学和生物学中的奥秘对我来说更有趣，因为它们是真正的奥秘。它们同样神奇，尽管这个词的意义更抽象。

Taking the place of magical thinking in my mind was my discovery that the real world is filled with wonderful mysteries. Unsolved riddles in the world of science fascinated me in a way that no magical wishful thinking ever had. Mysteries inside mathematics, physics, chemistry, and biology were much more interesting to me, since they were genuine mysteries. They were just as magical, though in a more abstract sense of the word.

我永远不会忘记我第一次遇到逻辑悖论。那是愚人节。那天早上，一位喜欢数学的年长朋友对我说：“今天是愚人节，我要用一种以前从来没有人骗过你的方式骗你！”这听起来有点吓人，而且很有挑战性。因此，我整天都非常注意他说的和做的每一件事，但似乎没有什么是陷阱。终于夜幕降临。我试图回顾这一天，弄清楚他何时或如何试图欺骗我，但我记不起任何可疑的事情。我想了又想，到了睡觉时间，我却难以入睡。第二天我又遇到了我的朋友，恼怒地告诉他我昨晚没睡，因为他没有遵守诺言，没有骗我。

I’ll never forget my first experience with logical paradoxes. It was April Fool’s Day. That morning, an older friend of mine who liked math said to me, “Today is April Fool’s Day, and I’m going to trick you in a way that no one has ever tricked you before!” This was a little scary-sounding—and challenging. Therefore, all day long I paid extremely close attention to everything he said and did, but nothing seemed like a trap at all. Eventually evening fell. I tried to look back on the day and figure out when or how he had tried to trick me, but I couldn’t recall anything suspicious. I thought and thought, and when bedtime came, I had a hard time falling asleep. The next day I ran into my friend again and told him with annoyance that I hadn’t slept the night before, because he had broken his promise of tricking me.

然后他得意洋洋地说：“所以你昨天就预料到我会骗你了？”

Then he said triumphantly, “So you expected I would trick you at some point yesterday?”

“是的。”

“Yes.”

“但我没有骗你，不是吗？”

“But I didn’t trick you, did I?”

“不。”

“No.”

“但你相信我会这么做吗？”

“But you believed I was going to?”

“是的。”

“Yes.”

“那么，我骗了你，不是吗？你轻信了我早上告诉你的话！”

“Well, then—I fooled you, didn’t I? You gullibly fell for what I told you in the morning!”

听到这句话，我意识到我的朋友确实以前所未有的方式欺骗​​了我——他没有欺骗我。或者说，他根本没有欺骗我，所以他欺骗了我。多年后，我发现我的朋友从他读过的一本美国哲学家和逻辑学家雷蒙德·斯穆里安的书中借用了这个自相矛盾的技巧。4

On hearing this, I realized that my friend had indeed fooled me as never before—by not fooling me. Or rather, he didn’t fool me at all, hence he fooled me. Many years later, I found out that my friend had borrowed this paradoxical trick from a book he’d read by the American philosopher and logician Raymond Smullyan.4

青春期的叛逆让我不想再做书呆子，至少要让自己看起来很酷，尤其是在女孩面前。我想到的解决办法是学弹吉他，并试着组建一支摇滚乐队。这是我在斯特兰奈斯读高中时的主要活动，斯特兰奈斯是一个较大但仍然很小的城镇，位于玛丽弗雷德西北约十英里处。我经常逃学，乘通勤火车去斯德哥尔摩，在那里我非常热衷于音乐和去夜总会。

My teenage rebellion made me want to stop being a nerd and to get at least a few points for being cool, especially with girls. The solution I hit on was to learn to play the guitar and to try starting a rock band. This was my main activity while I was in high school in the larger but still very small town of Strängnäs, about ten miles northwest of Mariefred. I played hooky pretty often, taking the commuter train into Stockholm, and there I got very involved with music and going out to nightclubs.

二十岁那年，我在一个摇滚乐队里弹吉他，当时我非常确定自己会成为一名音乐家。我们的乐队名叫“英雄”，他们发行了一张唱片，从那时起，我开始频繁前往伦敦，希望在音乐界建立联系，并希望在那里获得唱片合约。（如果你从我们乐队的名字中看出了大卫·鲍伊的影响，那你就没错。）但最终，我发现伦敦的夜总会生活和音乐场景根本不合我的口味，甚至让我迷失了方向。这可不是什么好事，过了一段时间，我决定回到瑞典老家。

At age twenty, I was playing guitar in a rock band and was pretty sure that I was going to be a musician. Our group, called “Heroes,” had put out a record, and at this point I started making frequent trips to London with the goal of establishing contacts in the music world and hopefully getting a recording contract there. (If in our band’s name you pick up on the influence of David Bowie, you aren’t wrong.) In the end, however, I found that London’s nightclub life and music scene weren’t my cup of tea, after all, and were even causing me to lose my bearings. This was no good, and after a while, I decided to go back home to Sweden.

在回家的路上，我碰巧买了一本道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特 1979 年出版的书《哥德尔、埃舍尔、巴赫：永恒的金辫》。在回家的路上以及接下来的几周里，我一口气读完了整本书。它以丰富的对位法处理艺术、音乐、数学和哲学，给我留下了不可磨灭的印象。它让我看到了一个全新的世界。这就是我想要的生活！我十几岁时对数学的热情被重新唤醒，我突然决定在乌普萨拉大学学习数学、哲学和计算机科学。我意识到我想把所有这些兴趣结合在一起，而音乐只是一种爱好。事实上，在霍夫施塔特的书广为人知之后，做个书呆子也并不那么不酷了。即使是我们这些书呆子也有希望了！

On my trip home, I happened to buy a copy of Douglas Hofstadter’s 1979 book Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid. I gobbled the entire book down during the trip home and throughout the next couple of weeks. It deals with art, music, mathematics, and philosophy in a rich contrapuntal fashion, and it left an indelible impression on me. It opened my eyes onto a whole new world. This was what I wanted my life to be about! My earlier teenage passion for mathematics was reawakened, and all at once I decided to study math, philosophy, and computer science at Uppsala University. And I realized that I wanted to weave all these interests together, with music being just a hobby instead. And actually, being a nerd wasn’t so uncool after Hofstadter’s book became well known. There was hope even for us nerds!

今天我不得不承认，我可能偶尔会表现得有点儿过头，但我非常感激我在大学期间获得的思维工具。5

Today I have to admit that I may occasionally have gone a bit overboard with my nerdity, but I am unbelievably grateful for the thinking tools that I acquired during my university days.5

心胸开阔

To Have an Open Mind

一个人能经历的最愉快的旅程是好奇心和惊奇感驱使下的知识和洞察力之旅。这种旅程的奇妙之处在于，你走得越远，你会发现有越多的东西可以发现。你理解得越多，你就越意识到，原则上可以理解的东西你实际上理解的是多么少。

The most enjoyable trip one can take is the trip to knowledge and insights, driven by curiosity and a sense of wonder. What’s amazing about such a trip is that the farther you travel, the more you find there is to discover. The more you understand, the more you realize how little of all that is in principle understandable you actually do understand.

要踏上这样的旅程，背包里最好有合适的装备。某些类型的装备是必要的，以避免落入陷阱和误入歧途，但最重要的是，你需要一个指南针来找到正确的方向。这本书就是关于这样的工具的，它试图为读者提供这样的指南针。但它也涉及人们很容易陷入的陷阱和死胡同。

To take such a trip, it’s best to have the proper gear in one’s backpack. Certain types of equipment are needed in order to avoid falling into traps and going astray, but above all one needs a compass to find the right direction. This book is about such tools, and it tries to supply its readers with such a compass. But it also deals with the traps and blind alleys that one can so easily wind up in.

一个重要的工具是开放。人们应该心胸开阔。但“开放”到底意味着什么？我经常和不同的人讨论这个问题，我发现“开放”这个概念经常被误解。让我举个例子。

An important tool is openness. People should be open minded. But what does “to be open” really mean? I have often broached this issue with various people, and I’ve observed that the concept “open” is frequently misinterpreted. So let me give an example.

你和朋友正在看一档关于鬼屋的电视节目。节目中有一个“灵媒”，她会举行降神会，并声称能与死者交谈——那些已经去往“另一边”的人。之后，你们俩讨论了这个节目。你的朋友声称，死者的鬼魂和灵魂确实存在，而且有人能与他们交流。

You and a friend are looking at a TV show about a supposedly haunted house. Taking part in the show is a “medium” who holds seances and claims to speak with the deceased—people who have passed over to “the other side.” Afterward, the two of you discuss the program. Your friend claims that ghosts and spirits of dead people really exist, and that there are people who can communicate with them.

你回答说你相信没有这种鬼魂或灵魂，所谓的“灵媒”要么是骗子，要么就是在自欺欺人。然后你的朋友说：“拜托！你应该更开明一点！不要这么狭隘！对鬼魂是否存在，要更开明一点。”

You reply that you believe there are no such ghosts or spirits, and that so-called “mediums” either are charlatans or are fooling themselves. Your friend then says, “Come on! You should be more open minded! Don’t be so narrow! Just be more open-minded about whether ghosts exist or not.”

我经常会遇到这种情况！有时是在电视辩论中，有时只是在普通的闲聊中。但之前的对话中发生了一些奇怪的事情。这两个人中哪一个更开放？如果你只看他们相信什么，你能分辨出来吗？一个人的开放程度不应该与他的信仰有关，不是吗？它不应该由一个人在新的事实和证据的基础上改变自己观点的意愿来衡量吗？

How often have I wound up in just that position! Sometimes it’s been in a debate on television, other times just in ordinary chit-chat. But there is something weird going on in the earlier conversation. Which of the two is more open minded? Can you tell if you look solely at what they believe? One’s degree of openness shouldn’t have to do with what one believes, should it? Shouldn’t it instead be measured by how willing one is to change one’s opinion, on the basis of new facts and pieces of evidence?

认为鬼魂不存在的怀疑论者肯定是两者中思想最不开放的。这种人可能会坚持说：“我永远不会相信鬼魂的存在，即使我在光天化日下遇到活生生的鬼魂！”显然，这不是一种非常开放的心态。但如果有一天证明人类死后灵魂会继续存在于另一个境界，而且有可能与这些“灵魂”建立沟通渠道，那么怀疑论者可能会改变主意，开始相信与死者交谈。

The skeptic who thinks that ghosts don’t exist can certainly be the less open minded of the two. That person might rigidly insist, “I will never, ever believe in ghosts, even if I encounter one in the flesh in broad daylight!” Clearly, this is not a very open state of mind. But if one day it were proven that human souls continue to exist in another realm after death, and that it was possible to set up communication channels with these “spirits,” then the skeptic might change their mind and might start believing in talking to the dead.

但也有可能是信鬼者思想不够开放。想象一下，这个人说：“我曾经目睹过一个非常奇怪的事件，我无法解释，我永远不会相信我所看到的事件有科学的解释。我永远相信鬼的存在！”在这种情况下，可以说这个人非常固执己见——与思想开放相反。

But it could also be the ghost-believer whose mind is less open. Just imagine this person saying, “I once witnessed a highly strange event that I couldn’t explain, and I won’t ever believe that there is a scientific explanation of what I saw. I’ll always believe in ghosts!” In such a case, it’s sensible to say that this person is very dogmatic—the opposite of open minded.

假设我和我的朋友正在讨论其他星球上的生命。我说我认为其他星球上有生命，但我的朋友说这很愚蠢。我们俩中谁的思想更开放？显然，如果只看我们对这个话题的看法，就不可能回答这个问题。

Suppose that my friend and I are discussing life on other planets. I say that I think there is life on other planets, but my friend says this is silly. Which of us is the more open-minded one? Clearly it’s impossible to answer the question if one looks solely at what we believe on this topic.

让我们再举一个例子。假设我的腿上放着一个封闭的小黑盒子，我对我的两个朋友亚当和夏娃说：“你觉得这个盒子里有苹果吗？用你所有的直觉和常识猜一下吧……那么现在——你觉得这里面有苹果吗？”

Let’s take another example. Suppose I have a small, closed black box sitting on my lap, and I say to my two friends Adam and Eve, “Do you think there’s an apple in this box? Just make a guess, using all your intuition and common sense. . . . So now—do you think there’s an apple in here?”

亚当发誓他相信盒子里有苹果，而夏娃则相信盒子是空的。仅仅知道他们中的一个相信有苹果，而另一个相信没有苹果，我们无法确定他们中哪一个更开放。总而言之：一个人的开放程度不取决于他相信什么，而取决于当新的事实和发现出现时，他有多愿意改变自己的想法。

Adam swears that he believes there is an apple in the box, while Eve believes the box is empty. Simply knowing that one of them believes there is an apple, while the other believes there is not one, we can’t determine which of the two is more open minded. In sum: one’s degree of openness is not a function of what one believes, but of how willing one is to change one’s mind, when new facts and discoveries come to light.

然而，今天我们经常会碰到这样的人：如果甲相信鬼魂、飞碟和外星人绑架，而乙怀疑这些事情，那么甲显然比乙思想开放。这种观点有什么道理？难道一个人只因为相信难以置信、听起来疯狂的想法就被认为思想开放吗？这当然没有道理。

Today, however, one frequently runs into people who claim that if Person A believes in ghosts, flying saucers, and alien abductions while Person B is a skeptic of such things, then clearly A is more open minded than B. What sense is there behind such a view? Does one get credit for open-mindedness simply because one believes in implausible, crazy-sounding ideas? Surely that doesn’t make sense.

让我们再来做一次思想实验，它清楚地表明，单凭信仰并不能正确判断一个人的思想开放程度。当代欧洲有很多极右翼人士，有些人甚至否认二战期间发生了大屠杀。这种立场完全令人难以置信。但我们是否应该说，这些人比我们更开放，正是因为他们持有这种信念，而我们这些傻瓜却坚信大屠杀确实发生过？不，这不仅愚蠢，而且极其愚蠢。

Let’s try another thought experiment that clearly shows that looking at beliefs alone cannot be the right way to determine someone’s degree of open-mindedness. In contemporary Europe there are a lot of people on the extreme right, including some who go so far as to deny that the Holocaust took place during World War II. This is a completely implausible stance. But should we say that these people are more open minded than we are, precisely because they hold this belief, while we simpletons are convinced that the Holocaust did take place? No; that would be not just silly but deeply foolish.

那些坚称人类从未登上过月球、1969 年所谓的登月全是假的、只是好莱坞工作室拍摄的人们，他们的思想有多开放？这种态度并不比相信登月确实发生过更开放。

How open minded are those folks who staunchly assert that no human has ever stood on the moon, and that the supposed moon landing in 1969 was all fakery, just filmed in a Hollywood studio? Such an attitude is hardly more open minded than believing that a moon landing actually did happen.

相反，“开放”这一特质应该被视为好奇心的近亲。开放意味着始终保持敏感，并且每当遇到新的事实或观点时，总是寻找重新评估自己价值观和想法的方法。

The trait of “openness” should instead be thought of as being a close cousin to curiosity. To be open-minded means to be constantly sensitive and always on the lookout for ways to reevaluate one’s values and one’s ideas, whenever one runs into new facts or viewpoints.

然而，要仔细思考一个想法，光有开放的心态是不够的。你还需要一个标准来判断什么是合理的。瑞典哲学家英格马尔·赫德尼斯提出了一个非常简单但有用的原则，他称之为“知识诚实原则”：只有当你有充分的理由认为一个想法是真的时，你才相信它。

More than just open-mindedness is needed to allow an idea to be thought through carefully, however. One also needs a criterion for what is sensible to think of as possibly true. Swedish philosopher Ingemar Hedenius stated a very simple but helpful principle that he called “the principle of intellectual honesty”: Believe in an idea if and only if you have good reasons to think it is true.

这意味着你应该准备好探索所有可能的替代方案，以便从中选择出最合理或最合理的方案。这种态度才是最好的、最真实的开放态度，与那些乐于接受任何随意想法的人形成鲜明对比。这种天真的轻信几乎不配被称为“开放”；它只是一种不成熟思维方式的表现。在美国，有一句口号说：“不要思想太开放，否则你的大脑会掉出来。”谁会想有这么开放的思想呢？

This implies that you should be ready to explore all conceivable alternatives in order to choose which among them is the most plausible or reasonable. Such an attitude would constitute the best and truest kind of openness, in contrast to someone who will gladly swallow any random idea that’s thrown at them. Such naïve gullibility hardly merits the label “open”; it is simply a symptom of an immature thinking style. In the United States, there is a slogan that says, “Don’t be so open minded that your brain falls out.” Who would want to be that open minded?

然而，许多人相信一些没有合理或可信依据的东西。一些不合理的想法只是具有很高的社会地位，或者被认为是令人兴奋或神秘的。这就是“新时代精神”如今如此受欢迎的原因之一。但如果一个人觉得对自己和他人保持理智诚实很重要，那么像这样无关紧要的“理由”就不会影响一个人对一个想法的真假判断。

And yet, many people believe in things that have no reasonable or plausible support. Some unreasonable ideas simply have high social status, or they are considered thrilling or mystical. That’s one of the reasons that “New Age Spirituality” is so popular today. But if one feels it is important to be intellectually honest with oneself and with others, then irrelevant “reasons” like that will not play into one’s judgments of an idea’s truth or falsity.

解释和奥卡姆剃刀

Explanations and Ockham’s Razor

有一个非常古老的基本哲学原理，它主张对给定的现象选择最简单的解释。让我们举个例子。

There is a very old fundamental philosophical principle that advocates selecting the simplest of rival explanations for a given phenomenon. Let’s take an example.

假设有一天我回到公寓，发现窗户被打破了，电视机也不见了。对于我所看到的情况，有很多种可能的解释，以下是三种：

Suppose that one day I come home to my apartment and I notice that the window has been broken and the TV set is missing. There are any number of possible explanations for what I see, of which here are three:

  1. 一个外星人从一个飞翔的茶壶降落到地球，闯入我的公寓，并拿走了我的电视。
  2. An extraterrestrial descended to earth from a flying teapot, broke into my apartment, and made off with my TV.
  3. 一个窃贼闯入了我的公寓并偷走了我的电视机。
  4. A burglar broke into my apartment and made off with my TV.
  5. 我的电视被中央情报局的秘密特工传送到了另一个维度，所用的技术是当今科学所未知的。
  6. My TV was teleported to another dimension by secret CIA agents, using techniques unknown to current-day science.

这三种解释中最简单、最合理，因而也是最好的解释是第二种解释（除非我们遇到新的信息，让我们有理由认真对待第一种或第三种解释）。

The simplest and most sensible of these three explanations, and thus the best of them, is #2 (unless we come across new pieces of information that give us reason to take alternative #1 or #3 seriously).

这种想法也适用于那些被声称是超自然现象或灵异现象的现象。例如，考虑以下两个说法：

This same kind of thought should apply to phenomena that are claimed to be supernatural or paranormal. Consider, for example, the following two claims:

  1. 我相信，要理解人类的超自然能力，最好通过第七感的假设，它能传达原本无法获得的信息和知识。
  2. I believe that paranormal-seeming abilities in a human being are best understood through the postulation of a seventh sense, which conveys information and knowledge that would otherwise be inaccessible.
  3. 我认为，人类的超自然能力最好通过特定领域的研究人员开发的科学解释来理解。这些解释包括…… 6
  4. I believe that paranormal-seeming abilities in a human being are best understood through scientific explanations developed by researchers in the given domain. These explanations involve . . .6

还有什么比相信科学解释是最简单、最合理，因而也是最好的更谦逊、更开放呢？

What could possibly be humbler and more open minded than believing that scientific explanations are the simplest and the most plausible, and therefore the best?

好的解释很简单，这一观点通常被称为“奥卡姆剃刀” 。7

The idea that good explanations are simple is a stance that is usually called “Ockham’s razor.”7

有时人们会听到这样的说法：“科学永远无法解释 X！”，其中 X 可能是意识的本质、生命的起源或宇宙的起源。但这种自信满满的言论既武断又有局限性。谁能预测人类最终能够（或不能）解释什么？我们今天无法解释某件事，并不意味着它永远无法解释。

Sometimes one hears a statement like “Science will never be able to explain X!,” where X might be the nature of consciousness, the origin of life, or the origin of the universe. But such cocksure pronouncements are both dogmatic and limited. How can anyone foretell what humanity will (or will not) eventually be able to explain? The fact that we today can’t explain something doesn’t mean that it will never be explicable.

这种自信满满的说法往往是由于混淆了已解释的内容和原则上可解释的内容。意识的本质就是一个很好的例子。许多人都曾思考过意识是如何在大脑中产生的，并提出了一些合理的理论，但目前还没有一个完整的、被所有科学家都认同的、完全被接受的意识理论；然而，这并不意味着意识在未来某一天是否会被解释。人们应该对未来的知识保持开放和谦虚的态度，并这样说：“今天的科学还没有完全解释意识的本质，但也许在未来我们能够做到这一点。我们今天还不知道。”

Self-assured claims of this sort often are due to a confusion between what has been explained and what is, in principle, explainable. The nature of consciousness is a good example. There are many people who have pondered how consciousness arises in the brain and have offered plausible theories about it, but there is still no complete and totally accepted theory of consciousness that all scientists agree on; however, this doesn’t imply anything about whether consciousness will one day be explained in the future. One should simply be open minded and humble about future knowledge, and say something like this: “Today’s science has not fully explained the nature of consciousness, but perhaps in the future we will be able to do so. We just don’t know, today.”

在新纪元运动中，人们经常会听到这样的说法：“我曾亲身经历过一个我无法解释的事件，所以这一定是超自然现象！”但是，为什么一个人无法自己解释某件事就意味着它没有科学解释，而且永远不可能、永远不会有科学解释呢？更健康的观点是，如果一个人自己无法解释某件事，那么也许其他人可以解释——比自己知识渊博或资历更高的人。认为自己无法解释某个神秘事件比长期的研究更可靠，这种想法是傲慢的，因为长期的研究可能会找到真正的解释。忽视科学发现的价值，认为自己的亲身经历是最终的权威，只会暴露出严重缺乏谦逊。

In the New Age movement, one often runs into claims like this: “I was present at an event that I couldn’t explain, so it must be supernatural!” But why should the fact that one can’t explain something on one’s own mean that there is no scientific explanation for it, and never could be, never will be? A healthier outlook would be to think that if one can’t explain something oneself, then perhaps someone else could do so—someone with greater knowledge or better qualifications than oneself. It is arrogant to assume that one’s own inability to explain a given mysterious event is more reliable than long traditions of research, which might be able to point toward a genuine explanation. To dismiss the value of scientific findings and to think of one’s own personal experience as the ultimate authority merely reveals a serious lack of humility.

仅凭自己有限的生活经验来判断，并拒绝所有科学研究的集体成果，这种态度很少会带来新的见解。有人说：“我当时在场，但我没能弄清楚，所以这根本就不可能被弄清楚！”，这只不过是将自己解释既定谜团的能力（或无能）与更普遍、永恒的“可解释性”含义相混淆。他们真正想说的是：“如果我不能弄清楚当时发生了什么，那么天哪，没人能弄清楚。”这只是自大而已；人们应该更谦虚一些。

To proceed solely on the basis of one’s own limited life experience and to reject all the collective results of scientific research is an attitude that seldom leads to new insights. Someone who says, “I was there and I couldn’t figure it out, so it just can’t be figured out!” is merely confusing their own ability (or inability) to explain the given mystery with a more general, timeless meaning of “explainability.” What they are really saying is this: “If I can’t figure out what happened that time, then by God, nobody can.” This is just cocky; one should be more humble.

思维陷阱

Traps in Thinking

苏格拉底非常明智，他指出，人们不应该自以为知道某事，而实际上他们并不知道。在判处他死刑的法庭面前，他在辩护中说道（或者至少柏拉图告诉我们），“我比这个人聪明；很可能我们俩都不知道任何有价值的东西，但他以为自己知道某事，而实际上他并不知道，而当我不知道时，我也不认为自己知道。所以我可能比他聪明，因为我不会去想我不知道的事情。” 8

Socrates was very wise when he observed that one should not believe that one knows something, when in fact one doesn’t know it. In his defense plea before the court that sentenced him to death, he said (or at least this is what Plato tells us), “I am wiser than this man; it is likely that neither of us knows anything worthwhile, but he thinks he knows something when he does not, whereas when I do not know, neither do I think I know. So I am likely to be wiser than he to this small extent, that I do not think what I do not know.”8

高估自己的知识并不好。让判断误入歧途也不好。英国哲学家弗朗西斯·培根（1561-1626）是第一批提出我们所有人都容易陷入的一些思维陷阱的人之一。培根认为，科学应该这样组织起来：有用的。研究结果应该被收集和传播，特别是通过学术机构和期刊，这样就不会一再犯同样的错误。在1620 年出版的《新工具》（“新工具”）中，他写道：“人的思想远非清澈均匀的玻璃，事物的光束应该按照其真实发生率反射，不，它更像是一个充满迷信和欺骗的魔镜。” 9

To overestimate one’s knowledge is not good. Nor is it good to let one’s judgment be led astray. English philosopher Francis Bacon (1561–1626) was one of the first people to formulate some of the thinking traps that we all fall into so easily. Bacon believed that science should be organized so as to be useful. Results of research should be collected and distributed, particularly through academies and journals, so that the same mistake is not made over and over again. In Novum Organum (“The New Tool”), published in 1620, he writes, “The mind of man is far from the nature of a clear and equal glass, wherein the beams of things should reflect according to their true incidence, nay, it is rather like an enchanted glass, full of superstition and imposture.”9

培根曾写过四种“偶像”（他用这个词不是指“假神”，而是指“假观念”），它们常常会误导思想，并可能导致通向知识的旅程在死胡同中戛然而止。在以下列表中，我用自己的话描述了培根的四种偶像：

Bacon wrote of four “idols” (and by this term he does not mean “false gods” but, instead, “false ideas”) that often lead thought astray and that may cause the voyage toward knowledge to come to a dead halt in a blind alley. In the following list, I describe Bacon’s four idols in my own words:

  1. Idola tribus（部落偶像）：第一个认知陷阱是我们人类倾向于过度概括。我们根据我们习惯的解释情况的方式和使用习惯性观念来解释事实。我们给自然赋予一种可能根本不存在的秩序。我们进行分类，我们认为如果某个类别的某些成员具有某种属性，那么所有成员也必须如此。通过这种认知陷阱，我们产生了对女性、德国人、同性恋者、非洲人或您能想到的任何其他类别的偏见，我们决定将其概括并用于我们的进一步思考。
  2. Idola tribus (the idol of the tribe): The first cognitive trap is that we humans tend to overgeneralize. We interpret facts on the basis of our habitual ways of interpreting situations and using our habitual notions. We ascribe to nature an order that may well not be there. We categorize and classify, and we believe that if some members of a category have a certain property, then so must all members. Through this cognitive trap are born prejudices against women, Germans, homosexuals, Africans, or whatever other category you can think of, which we have decided to generalize and to use in our further thoughts.
  3. Idola fori（市场偶像）：第二个认知陷阱是不加批判地让自己的思想被时髦的词语、陈词滥调和普遍的观点所引导。人类语言并不精确，而是模糊的。明确自己在说什么很重要，否则很可能导致完全不必要的误解，语言可能会主宰思想。一个例子是本章前面讨论过的术语“开放性”；它经常被错误地使用，因此它将我们的思维引向错误的道路。
  4. Idola fori (the idol of the marketplace): The second cognitive trap is to uncritically let one’s thought be guided by faddish words, clichéd phrases, and widespread opinions. Human language is not precise but blurry. It is important to pin down what one is speaking about, for otherwise one may well cause totally unnecessary misunderstandings, and language may come to dominate over thought. An example is the term openness, discussed earlier in the chapter; it is often used in an erroneous way, and thus it guides our thinking down wrong avenues.
  5. Idola specus（洞穴偶像）：第三个认知陷阱是仅从自己的角度看待世界，从而让一厢情愿的想法阻碍了真相。此外，我们自身的局限性（无论是天生的还是后天训练的结果）决定了我们如何解释观察到的事物。在这里，我们遇到了所谓的“认知偏见”，即我们倾向于寻求对我们已经相信的东西的确认，而不是寻找可能对我们的信仰产生怀疑的事实。本章前面讨论过的一个例子是说：“我无法解释它，所以它一定是无法解释的。”
  6. Idola specus (the idol of the cave): The third cognitive trap is to see the world solely from one’s own perspective, thus letting wishful thinking get in the way of truth. In addition, own’s own limitations, whether innate or the result of training, determine how we interpret things we observe. Here we run into what is called “cognitive bias,” which is our tendency to seek confirmation of what we already believe, instead of looking for facts that might cast doubt on what we believe. An example, discussed earlier in this chapter, is to say: “I can’t explain it, so it must be unexplainable.”
  7. Idola theatri（戏剧偶像）：第四个认知陷阱是对权威或著名的教义、学说或传统不加批判地相信。一种权威是大师，他建立了一套关于一切的理论，他的弟子盲目地遵循这些理论。另一种权威是模糊、空洞的神学思想体系，就像在剧院里看的戏剧一样，是纯粹凭空想象出来的。有些人声称它属于受人尊敬的古老传统，这很难成为不加批判地相信它的理由；事实上，这一事实本身就是对其进行特别批判性审查的充分理由。
  8. Idola theatri (the idol of the theater): The fourth cognitive trap is to have an uncritical belief in authorities or in famous teachings, doctrines, or traditions. One type of authority is the guru who has built up a theory about everything, and whose disciples blindly follow such theories. Another type is a fuzzy, fluffy theological system of thought, which, just like a play one sees in a theater, is dreamed up out of pure imagination. That some people claim it belongs to a venerated ancient tradition is hardly a reason to buy uncritically into it; in fact, that very fact is a good reason to give it especially critical scrutiny.

理性与智慧

Rationality and Wisdom

理性和智慧意味着什么？我所说的“理性思考”是指连贯、无矛盾的推理。理性论证按定义由合理的推理步骤组成，也就是说，论证由一系列合乎逻辑的步骤组成（但前提可能是明智的，也可能是愚蠢的）。相反的概念——“非理性推理”——表示一连串混乱、不合逻辑的思维，它可以将人引向天下任何地方。

What does it mean to be rational and wise? By “rational thinking,” I mean coherent, contradiction-free reasoning. A rational argument consists, by definition, of plausible steps of reasoning, which is to say, the argument consists of a series of logical steps (but the premises may be either wise or silly). The opposite notion—that of “irrational reasoning”—denotes a confused and illogical chain of thoughts, which can lead one anywhere under the sun.

理性推理的优点是结果总是正确的，这是一种机械的方式。也就是说，只要输入是真的，逻辑推理步骤的输出总是正确的。但理性论证的结论不一定是真的；事实上，如果至少一个前提是错误的，那么理性论证的结果也将是错误的。

The advantage of rational reasoning is that the result is always correct, in a mechanical manner. That is, the output of a logical step of reasoning is always true, as long as the inputs are true. But the conclusion of a rational argument doesn’t have to be true; in fact, if at least one of the premises is false, then the result of a rational argument will be false as well.

例如，如果我们以以下内容作为前提：

For example, if we take the following as our premises:

  1. 所有类型的动物，无论是现在生存的还是已经灭绝的，都是六千年前创造的；
  2. All types of animals, whether now living or now extinct, were created six thousand years ago;
  3. 恐龙是已经灭绝的动物。那么我们可以从中得出以下合乎逻辑的结论：
  4. Dinosaurs are extinct animals. then we can draw the following logical conclusion from them:
  5. 恐龙是在六千年前诞生的。
  6. The dinosaurs were created six thousand years ago.

虽然推理模式完美无缺，但前提 (a) 是错误的，因此结论也是错误的。错误的前提必然导致错误的结论！

Even though the reasoning pattern is flawless, premise (a) is false, and therefore, the conclusion is false. False premises invariably lead to false conclusions!

嗯……我很好奇，读者，你是否注意到我在最后几句话中犯了一个严重的逻辑错误。如果你注意到了，恭喜你！如果你没有找到，那么你可以尝试找到它。提示：使用至少一个错误前提的逻辑论证真的必须得出错误的结论吗？

Hmm . . . I am curious, reader, whether you happened to notice a serious logical error that I just committed in the last few sentences. If you did, my congratulations! If you didn’t, then you might try to find it. Hint: Does a logical argument that uses at least one false premise really have to lead to a false conclusion?

答案是：不。我的观点是错误的。是我的翻译道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特向我指出了这个严重的缺陷。我很感谢他这样做，尤其是他提供了以下四个简单的反例，表明我错了：

The answer is: no. I was wrong in my claim. It was my translator, Douglas Hofstadter, who pointed out this serious flaw to me. I am grateful to him for having done so, and especially for providing the following four simple counterexamples, showing how wrong I was:

前提 1：1 + 1 = 1（错误）

Premise 1: 1 + 1 = 1 (false)

前提 2：2 + 2 = 5（错误）

Premise 2: 2 + 2 = 5 (false)

结论（通过加法）：3 + 3 = 6（正确）

Conclusion (by addition): 3 + 3 = 6 (true)

前提1：Christer Sturmark出生在中国（假）

Premise 1: Christer Sturmark was born in China (false)

前提2：中国人都能说流利的瑞典语（错误）

Premise 2: Chinese people all speak fluent Swedish (false)

结论：Christer Sturmark 能说一口流利的瑞典语（正确）

Conclusion: Christer Sturmark speaks fluent Swedish (true)

前提 1：巴拉克·奥巴马出生在肯尼亚（错误）

Premise 1: Barack Obama was born in Kenya (false)

前提 2：肯尼亚人都有肚脐（正确）

Premise 2: Kenyan people all have belly buttons (true)

结论：巴拉克·奥巴马有肚脐（真实）

Conclusion: Barack Obama has a belly button (true)

前提 1：巴拉克·奥巴马出生在夏威夷（真实）

Premise 1: Barack Obama was born in Hawaii (true)

前提 2：每个在夏威夷出生的人都会成为美国总统（错误）

Premise 2: Every Hawaiian-born person becomes U.S. president (false)

结论：巴拉克·奥巴马成为美国总统（真实）

Conclusion: Barack Obama became U.S. president (true)

这四个有趣的例子清楚地表明，我之前所说的“如果至少一个前提是错误的，那么理性论证的结果也将是错误的”是完全错误的。当然，这是一个诱人的想法，也许你认为它完全有道理。当然，我自己也完全相信了，但现在，读者，你知道事情比这更微妙一些。对我来说，教训是，我们都活到老学到老，通过这样做，我们可以慢慢但肯定地成为更好、更清晰、更有逻辑、更理性的思考者。

These four amusing examples clearly show that what I claimed earlier—“if at least one of the premises is false, then the result of a rational argument will be false as well”—was completely and utterly wrong. It was a tempting idea, to be sure, and maybe you thought it made perfect sense. Certainly I myself fell for it lock, stock, and barrel, but now, reader, you know that things are a bit subtler than that. The lesson for me is that we all live and learn, and by so doing, we can slowly but surely become better and clearer and more logical and more rational thinkers.

理性论证的结论不一定在道德上正确或正确。理性论证不需要具有任何道德维度；然而，只有在前提中没有道德价值观的情况下才会如此。由于道德价值观因人而异，单一理性方法得出的结论在所有人看来并不相同，因为不同的人会以不同的道德观念作为前提。此外，从一个角度看来合理的东西在另一个角度看来可能不合理。因此，理性取决于具体情况。

The conclusion of a rational argument doesn’t have to be morally right or correct. A rational argument does not need to have any moral dimensions; however, this will be the case only if there are no moral values in the premises. Since moral values can vary from one person to another, the conclusions reached by a single rational method will not seem the same to all people, since different people will take different moral ideas as their premises. Moreover, what seems rational from one point of view will seem irrational from another. Rationality is thus context dependent.

如果一个成年人给圣诞老人写信，这种行为可以说是不理智和愚蠢的。但一个五岁的孩子给圣诞老人写信是完全合理的。孩子真的相信圣诞老人的存在，并且这封信会影响圣诞老人在圣诞树下留下什么礼物。

If an adult were to write a letter to Santa Claus, the act could be described as irrational and silly. But a five-year-old child writing a letter to Santa Claus is fully reasonable. The child really believes that Santa Claus exists, and that the letter can have an effect on what presents Santa will leave under the Christmas tree.

为了使理性在道德上公平，我们还需要智慧。只有理性并不能带来智慧。那么，智慧的概念是什么意思呢？智慧行为与理性行为有什么区别？理性意味着得出的结论与已知事实没有逻辑冲突。理性结论必须符合前提的逻辑，并且必须没有矛盾。但智慧不止于此。

For rationality to be morally fair, we need wisdom in addition. Rationality alone does not give wisdom. What, then, is meant by the notion of wisdom? And what distinguishes wise behavior from merely rational behavior? To be rational means to draw conclusions that are not in logical conflict with known facts. A rational conclusion must logically follow from the premises and must be contradiction free. But wisdom is more than that.

人类智慧与目的有关，而不只是与手段有关。智慧与道德上的善恶有关。智慧需要理性，但理性不需要智慧。理性论证是一系列机械的逻辑步骤，而智慧包括道德判断和仔细审视结论的含义。智慧比理性更全面，但正因为如此，智慧更难以用精确的描述来捕捉。

Human wisdom has to do with ends, not just with means. Wisdom has to do with what is morally good or bad. Wisdom requires rationality, but rationality does not require wisdom. A rational argument is a mechanical chain of logical steps, whereas wisdom includes moral judgments and a careful look at what the conclusions imply. Wisdom is more comprehensive than rationality, but for that reason it is far harder to capture in a precise description.

明智的推理是理性的，但理性的推理并不总是明智的。

Wise reasoning is rational, but rational reasoning is not always wise.

拥有思想，形成人生哲学

Having Ideas and Forming a Philosophy of Life

世界是什么样的？我应该如何生活？什么才是真正重要的？我们每个人在一生中迟早都会思考这些问题。我们都试图为自己描绘出一幅至少相当一致的世界图景，即世界是什么样的，以及我们应该在这个世界里做什么。我们每个人最终都会构建出自己的人生哲学。

What is the world like, and how should I live? What really matters? Sooner or later in life, we all ponder such questions. We all try to make for ourselves at least a fairly consistent picture of how the world is and what we ought to do in it. Each of us winds up constructing our own personal philosophy of life.

拥有人生哲学意味着一个人对现实的本质有一种信念，并有一种关于应该如何生活在现实中、应该如何对待自己、他人、其他生物和环境的感觉。任何人生哲学都有这两个方面，其中一个是描述性的（试图说明事物是怎样的），另一个是规范性的（试图说明我们认为事物应该是怎样的）。描述性方面试图理解宇宙是如何构成的，而规范性方面则旨在建立一套价值观体系和对人性的认识。所有宗教和其他人生哲学都包括这两个维度。

Having a philosophy of life means that one has a belief about the nature of reality and a sense of how one should live in it, and how one should treat oneself, other people, other living creatures, and the environment. Any philosophy of life has these two aspects, one of them being descriptive (trying to say how things are) and the other being normative (trying to say how we feel things should be). The descriptive aspect tries to reach an understanding of how the universe is constituted, while the normative aspect aims at establishing a system of values and a sense for human nature. All religions and other philosophies of life include these two dimensions.

“宗教”这一概念是文化的一种表现形式，很难用一个普遍认可的、包罗万象的描述来概括。一个简单的定义可能是“相信一种更高的、超自然的力量，这种力量人类与人相关，反之亦然。”宗教往往基于一个或几个神或其他超自然生物的概念。许多宗教人士谈到“一个个人和有意识的神”，而其他人对神的概念则比较模糊。10

The concept of “religion” is a manifestation of culture that is not easy to capture in a generally agreed-upon, all-encompassing description. A simple definition might be “the belief in a higher, supernatural power to which humans relate, and vice versa.” Often, religions are based on the concept of one or several gods, or other supernatural beings. Many religious people speak of “a personal and conscious god,” while others have a vaguer notion of what God is.10

当然，人生哲学可以基于一种不涉及任何神灵或超自然力量的现实观。人生哲学不需要神奇的存在；它只需要提供一套广泛、清晰、连贯的思想，既有描述性的，也有规范性的。神灵和超能力是可选的特征。因此，虽然每种宗教都算是一种人生哲学，但并非每种人生哲学都是宗教。

A philosophy of life can of course be based on a vision of reality that does not involve any kind of god or supernatural power. A philosophy of life doesn’t need magical beings; it just needs to provide a broad, clearly formulated, and coherent set of ideas, on both the descriptive and the normative side. Gods and superpowers are optional features. Thus, although every religion counts as a philosophy of life, not every philosophy of life is a religion.

你知道，相信没有神的存在通常被称为无神论。它的对立面——有神论——是相信有神（或众神）。有神论或无神论本身就是一种人生哲学吗？瑞典国家百科全书对“人生哲学”的定义如下：“一套理论和价值观的思想，它产生或对人类和宇宙的广阔图景产生重大影响；它表达了一套基本信仰，包括一套价值观。” 11

As you know, holding the belief that no god exists is usually called atheism. Its opposite—theism—is the belief that there is a god (or gods). Does theism or atheism by itself constitute a philosophy of life? Well, the Swedish national encyclopedia defines the notion “philosophy of life” as follows: “A theoretical and value-laden set of ideas that gives rise to, or exerts a major influence on, a broad picture of humanity and the universe; it expresses a set of basic beliefs and includes a system of values.”11

因此，我们不能说任何一套旧观念都构成了关于生命的哲学。例如，如果我相信其他星球上存在生命，这本身就不是一种生命哲学。它只是关于一个孤立问题的想法。它没有道德含义（即没有规范性）。

For this reason, one can’t say that just any old set of ideas constitutes a philosophy of life on life. For example, if I believe that life exists on other planets, that in itself is not a philosophy of life. It’s just an idea about one isolated issue. It has no moral implications (i.e., no normative side).

如果我是无神论者，即如果我相信没有神存在（或者如果你愿意，上帝不存在），情况也是如此。再说一次，这种立场仅仅是关于一个孤立问题的观点；它还不足以构成一整套人生哲学，包含各种伦理含义等等。有神论也是如此。有神论——相信上帝——并不一定意味着一整套丰富的人生哲学。它可能只是一种孤立的信仰。

The same holds if I am an atheist—that is, if I believe that no god exists (or if you prefer, that God doesn’t exist). Once again, such a stance is merely a point of view about one isolated question; it’s not rich enough to constitute a whole philosophy of life, with all sorts of ethical implications and so forth. And much the same is true for theism. Theism—belief in God—doesn’t necessarily imply a whole rich philosophy of life. It can be just a single isolated belief.

希望停止对动物进行痛苦的试验，或禁止堕胎，或让所有工作获得完全相同的报酬——这些本身都不是人生哲学。然而，它们中的每一个都可能是一个人人生哲学的立场，因此属于那个人的道德观。总之，人生哲学是一个广泛且相当一致的思想体系。

The desire to put a halt to painful tests carried out on animals, or to forbid abortion, or to have all jobs paid exactly the same—none of these is, in itself, a philosophy of life. Each of them might be a position coming out of a person’s philosophy of life, however, and thus belonging to that person’s set of moral views. In sum, a philosophy of life is a broad and reasonably consistent system of ideas.

生命哲学的描述性方面不仅包含关于什么是有效知识以及如何最好地利用有效知识的理论（在哲学中，这被称为“认识论”），还包含关于什么存在、什么是真实的理论（这被称为“本体论”）。

The descriptive side of a philosophy of life contains not only a theory of what valid knowledge is and how one should best use it (in philosophy, this would be called “epistemology”) but also a theory of what exists and what is real (this would be called “ontology”).

人生哲学的规范方面包括关于人类价值观和人权的基本思想，通常还包括关于种族主义或反种族主义、女权主义、动物权利、环境问题等的观点。我们拥有的所有价值观都属于人生哲学的这一方面。

The normative side of a philosophy of life includes basic ideas about human values and human rights, and usually, in addition, views about such things as racism or antiracism, feminism, animal rights, environmental issues, and so forth. All the values that we have belong to this side of our philosophy of life.

大多数人在人生的某个时刻都会思考生存的基本问题，尽管有些人会思考很多，而有些人则不会。但无论我们思考这些事情的次数多少，我们都会对这些问题有所思考。如果没有基本的人生哲学，我们将很难在世界上航行，也很难以一致的方式看待我们的环境。

Most people, at some point in their lives, muse about the basic questions of existence, although some do so a great deal, and others not so much. But no matter how much or how little we ponder on such things, we all have some thoughts on these issues. Without a basic philosophy of life, we would have a hard time navigating around in the world and seeing our environment in a consistent manner.

人生哲学的基本问题是什么？当然，这些问题可以用许多不同的方式来描述。最核心的问题列表可能包括以下内容：

What are the basic questions in a philosophy of life? Of course they can be described in many different ways. A list of the most central questions might include the following entries:

  1. 关于知识和认知的问题。我们能了解现实吗？如果能，我们能知道什么？如何知道？知识到底是什么？我们能用什么方法来获得知识？这些都是认识论问题，属于知识论。
  2. Questions about knowledge and knowing. Can we know something about reality? If so, what can we know, and how? What is knowledge, in the end? What methods can we use to reach knowledge? These are epistemological questions, belonging to the theory of knowledge.
  3. 关于存在什么以及现实的本质的问题。这些都是本体论问题。它们包括关于上帝或众神可能存在的问题、“上帝”概念的含义以及这种概念与我们关于世界的其他知识或信仰的兼容性或不兼容性的问题。这类问题属于神学或宗教哲学。
  4. Questions about what exists and about the nature of reality. These are ontological questions. They include questions about the possible existence of a god or gods, the implications of the “God” concept, and the compatibility or incompatibility of such a concept with the rest of our knowledge or beliefs about the world. These sorts of questions belong to theology, or the philosophy of religion.
  5. 关于道德的问题——道德的本质、存在和正当性。什么是好的道德行为的特征？我们如何判断某一行为在道德上是否正确？是否存在独立于个人想法和欲望的客观道德？哲学的这一方面就是伦理学。
  6. Questions about morality—its nature, its existence, and its justification. What characterizes a good moral act? How can we decide whether a given act is morally right or not? Is there an objective morality, independent of one’s ideas and desires? This aspect of philosophy is ethics.
  7. 关于人类本质的问题，涉及善与恶、命运、意识、死亡和永生。我们有自由意志吗？意识是超越大脑化学反应的东西吗？邪恶存在吗？如果存在，它是什么？这些问题属于形而上学。
  8. Questions about the nature of humanity, involving good and evil, fate, consciousness, mortality, and immortality. Do we have free will? Is consciousness something over and above the chemistry of the brain? Does evil exist? If so, what is it? These questions belong to metaphysics.
  9. 关于我们应该如何组织我们的社会生活和生活条件的问题。社会的功能或作用是什么？一个人应该如何与当局和法律相处？我们有哪些权利和义务人类对其他人和其他生物有什么看法？这类问题大多在政治哲学中讨论（有时也在伦理学中讨论）。
  10. Questions about how we should organize our social life and living conditions. What is the function or role of society? How should a person relate to authorities and laws? What rights and duties do we have with respect to other people and other living creatures? These sorts of questions are mostly discussed in the philosophy of politics (and sometimes also in ethics).

你（或任何人）为什么要考虑这些问题呢？嗯，一个很好的理由就是纯粹的好奇心。你对世界是怎样的或应该怎样的一点兴趣都没有，那你就太冷漠了。另一个原因是思考这些问题可以丰富你的生活。你对世界的探索越深入，它就越迷人。

Why should you (or anyone) consider such questions at all? Well, one good reason is plain old curiosity. You’d have to be pretty blasé to have no interest at all in how the world is, or ought to be. Another reason is that pondering such questions enriches your life. The more deeply you probe the world, the more fascinating it becomes.

另一个原因可能是，你要弄清楚，你的想法是否真的是独立思考的结果，还是你对父母、朋友或你成长的社会代表告诉你的事情不加思索地接受——你的“文化遗产”。如果你在某个时候不加思索地接受了一套关于人类和世界的教条、价值观和想法，那么这些就不是你真正自己的想法，你就有可能成为一个容易被他人操纵的木偶。在这种情况下，你应该至少在你的一生中反思一次你的价值体系，并发展你自己的人生哲学。永远不会太晚。

Another reason can be to figure out if the ideas you have are really the result of independent thinking, or if they instead come from an unreflective acceptance of things that you were told by your parents, your friends, or representatives of the society you grew up in—your “cultural inheritance.” If, at some point, you unquestioningly bought into a set of dogmas, values, and ideas about humanity and the world, then those are not truly your own ideas, and you run the risk of being a marionette easily manipulated by others. In such a case, it would behoove you, at least once in your life, to reflect about your value system and to develop your own philosophy of life. It is never too late.

我的观点

My Point of View

我们每个人都有自己的视角，即观察世界的角度。我于 1964 年出生在一个种族和经济都相当同质的国家，从物质角度来说，大多数人都过着相当不错的生活。人们有一种外在的安全感——我们的国家两百年来从未经历过战争。我小时候，大多数女性都是家庭主妇，尽管许多人对这个角色感到不安；事实上，妇女解放运动很快就要开始了。现在，当我回首往事时，我看到了一系列与平等和性别角色有关的广泛社会变革。我也在一个民主国家长大，这个国家实行自由市场经济，自由企业与强大的公共部门相结合。多年来，移民（主要来自欧洲、亚洲和非洲）从涓涓细流变成了洪流。最后但并非最不重要的是，我参与了 20 世纪 90 年代的一场重大数字革命；由于这场革命，瑞典成为世界上计算机和互联网领先的国家之一。如今，瑞典是全球化程度最高的国家之一，民族多元化程度也很高，这与我成长的年代不同。总之，在我的国家，我亲眼目睹了社会生活、经济生活和政治生活的巨大变化。

Each of us has a point of view—a spot from which we look out at the world. I was born in 1964 in a country that was racially and economically quite homogeneous, and in which most people had pretty good lives, materially speaking. There was an outward sense of security—our country hadn’t been in a war in two hundred years. When I was a kid, most women were housewives, although many were restless in that role; indeed, the women’s liberation movement was soon going to be launched. Now, as I look back, I see a set of broad social changes that had to do with equality and gender roles. I also grew up in a democracy with a free-market economy, a blend of free enterprise with a strong public sector. Through the years, immigration, largely from Europe, Asia, and Africa, changed from a trickle into a flood. Last but not least, I was part of a major digital revolution in the 1990s; as a result of this revolution, Sweden became one of the leading nations in the world with computers and the internet. Today Sweden is among the most globalized of all countries, and it is now ethnically highly diverse, unlike when I was growing up. In short, in my country, I have witnessed vast changes in social life, economic life, and political life from the inside.

在这段动荡时期，我 20 岁左右时意识到，我对世界的看法是世俗的，这意味着首先，我认为上帝的概念只是人类创造的神话，其次，我对人的意义持人文主义观点。因此，我是一个世俗人文主义者——直到今天，我仍然是。这就是本书论点背后的观点。

During this period of upheaval, I realized, when I was around twenty, that I had a secular outlook on the world, meaning first that I saw the concept of God as merely a human-created myth, and second, that I had a humanistic view of what it means to be a person. I was therefore a secular humanist—and that’s what I still am today. This is the point of view that lies behind the arguments in this book.

我们生活在一个拥有各种生活哲学、意识形态和价值体系的人们必须能够共存和合作的世界。对我来说，世俗人文主义就是对世界有一套经过深思熟虑的态度，不仅要考虑现实的本质，还要有一套健康、合理的价值观，这将有助于实现这种共存。

We live in a world where people with highly varied philosophies of life, ideologies, and value systems have to be able to coexist and cooperate. For me, secular humanism is all about having a carefully considered set of attitudes about the world, not just concerning the nature of reality but also including a healthy and sensible set of values, which will help such coexistence to come about.

这个观点在情感和头脑上都是站得住脚的，无论是理性的还是道德的。

This is a point of view that is tenable, rationally and morally, both for the heart and for the head.

世俗人文主义

Secular Humanism

那么世俗人文主义到底是什么呢？正如我之前提到的，“世俗”一词源于拉丁语形容词saecularis，意为“世俗的”，与“教会的”（或“教会的”）相对。在目前的用法中，“世俗”指的是人类事务不应与宗教思想或宗教规则混杂在一起（更不用说受其控制）的观念。

So what is secular humanism really about? The term “secular” originated, as I mentioned earlier, from the Latin adjective saecularis, meaning “worldly,” in contrast to “ecclesiastical” (or “churchly”). In current usage, “secular” refers to the idea that human affairs should not be mixed in with (let alone controlled by) religious ideas or religious rules.

至于“人文主义”一词，在瑞典语中实际上有三种截然不同的含义：

As for the word “humanism,” in Swedish it actually has three quite different meanings:

  1. 人文主义是教育的目标。在瑞典，如果一个人在大学里主修人文学科，例如艺术史或比较文学，那么他就可以称自己为人文主义者。
  2. Humanism as a goal in education. One can call oneself a humanist in Sweden if, at the university, one’s major focus is or was the humanities, such as art history or comparative literature.
  3. 人文主义是对人类福祉的普遍关注。如果一个人对人民和人权有着强烈的承诺（当然，无论是无神论者、基督徒、穆斯林、佛教徒还是其他任何人），那么他就可以说是瑞典语中的人文主义者。
  4. Humanism as a general concern for the welfare of human beings. One can say one is a humanist in Swedish if one has a strong commitment to people and human rights (which of course one can have as an atheist, as a Christian, as a Muslim, as a Buddhist, or as anything else).
  5. 人文主义作为一种非宗教的生活哲学。
  6. Humanism as a nonreligious philosophy of life.

而在英语中，这三个不同的意思则对应着三个不同的词，第一个意思为“人文学科”，第二个意思为“人道主义”，第三个意思为“人文主义”（有时也称“世俗人文主义”）。

In English, by contrast, there are three different words corresponding to these different meanings. The first meaning is conveyed by “the humanities”; the second by “humanitarianism”; and the third by “humanism” (or sometimes “secular humanism”).

因此，“世俗”和“人文主义”这两个词单独存在时含义不同。一个人可以是世俗的，但同时又信仰上帝。持这种立场的人认为他们对上帝的信仰纯粹是私人的事情，他们认为社会应该以一种不提倡或偏袒任何特定宗教信仰的方式组织起来。

The words “secular” and “humanism” thus have different meanings when they stand alone. An individual can be secular, yet at the same time believe in a god. Someone with such a stance considers their belief in God to be a purely private affair, and they feel society should be organized in a way that doesn’t advocate or privilege any particular religious conviction.

当这两个词并列时，例如“世俗人文主义”，其含义是一种广泛的人生哲学，不涉及神或超自然力量；相反，重要的是人和他们的关注点。

When the two words are juxtaposed, as in “secular humanism,” the meaning is a broad philosophy of life involving no gods or supernatural powers; instead, what matters are people and their concerns.

世俗人文主义对现实的解释方式建立在世界是自然的而非超自然的观念之上。世界由物质、能量和自然法则组成。没有理由相信存在超自然的存在，如神灵和精灵，或任何形式的魔法力量。

Secular humanism’s way of construing reality builds on the notion that the world is natural, not supernatural. The world consists of matter, energy, and the laws of nature. There is no reason to believe that there are supernatural beings, like gods and spirits, or magical powers of any sort at all.

因此，世俗人文主义是一种人生哲学，但不是宗教。还有许多其他人生哲学认为不需要神灵。在这一组无神论或无神论观点中，可以算作中国人生哲学儒教，以及禅宗、上座部佛教和道教。12

Secular humanism is therefore a philosophy of life, but it is not a religion. There are numerous other philosophies of life that don’t see a need for godlike beings. Among this group of nontheistic, or atheistic, viewpoints, one can count the Chinese philosophy of life Confucianism, as well as Zen Buddhism, Theravada Buddhism, and Taoism.12

世俗人文主义还涉及人类对彼此的态度以及对我们生活的世界的态度。它强调每个人的自由、自主、价值和责任。它相信人们寻求知识和从经验中学习的能力。13

Secular humanism also deals with humans’ attitudes toward each other and toward the world we all live in. It emphasizes each person’s freedom, autonomy, value, and responsibility. It has faith in people’s ability to seek knowledge and to learn from experience.13

我发现很多人把世俗人文主义和无神论混为一谈。后一个概念将在本书后面仔细讨论，但在这里我想解释一下它与世俗人文主义的关系。

I have found that many people conflate secular humanism and atheism. The latter concept will be carefully discussed later in the book, but here I wish to explain how it is related to secular humanism.

无神论者是相信没有神的人。这种观点仅限于一个问题：有神吗？由于无神论只涉及这个问题，因此它并不构成完整的人生哲学。相比之下，世俗人文主义是一种丰富而全面的世界观，包括价值观。无神论只是世俗人文主义基于自然的观点的一个方面，因此世俗人文主义者始终是无神论者，但无神论者不一定是世俗人文主义者。

An atheist is a person who believes that there are no gods. This idea is limited to just one question: Is there a god? Since atheism deals only with this question, it does not constitute a full philosophy of life. Secular humanism, by contrast, is a rich and comprehensive view of the world, including values. Atheism is merely one facet of secular humanism’s nature-based viewpoint, so a secular humanist is always an atheist, but an atheist isn’t necessarily a secular humanist.

换言之，无神论与世俗人文主义之间的关系，可以类比为“耶稣不是弥赛亚”这一思想信仰与犹太教和伊斯兰教之间的关系，这两种宗教都是认同这一信仰的广泛人生哲学。虔诚的犹太教徒和穆斯林相信耶稣不是弥赛亚，但显然，坚持这一信仰并不意味着你必须是犹太人或穆斯林。

To put it another way, the relationship between atheism and secular humanism can be compared to the relationship between the intellectual belief “Jesus was not the Messiah” and the religions Judaism and Islam, both of which are broad philosophies of life that agree with that belief. Practicing Jews and Muslims believe that Jesus was not the Messiah, but obviously, holding that belief doesn’t mean you have to be a Jew or a Muslim.

插曲：关于灵性和流动

INTERLUDE: ON SPIRITUALITY AND FLOW

您曾经经历过存在性眩晕吗？

Have you ever experienced existential vertigo?

偶尔，晚上我会和儿子 Leo 一起走到露台上，并排躺下，仰望星空。当然，最好在没有路灯、没有人造光的地方这样做。寒冷的冬夜是最好的，因为那时的星空最明亮。

Once in a while I step out with my son Leo onto our patio in the evening, and we lie down side by side and stare up at the stars. Ideally, of course, one should do this in a place where there are no streetlights, no artificial light at all. And cold winter nights are the best since they are the clearest.

如果 Leo 和我运气好的话，我们可以看到木星，用一副普通的双筒望远镜，我们可以看到它的四颗卫星。我们可以看到无数的星星，银河系的中心在天空中形成一条乳白色的条纹。（顺便说一句，银河系的瑞典语名称是“Vintergatan”，意思是“冬日街道”。）所以，Leo 和我，两个小小的地球人，就在这里，在我们银河系的外缘附近，而它只是数十亿个其他星系中的一个。

If Leo and I are in luck, we can see Jupiter, and with a pair of ordinary binoculars we can make out four of its moons. We see myriads of stars, and the center of the Milky Way forms a milk-white streak high up in the sky. (Incidentally, the Swedish name for the Milky Way is “Vintergatan,” meaning “the Winter Street.”) So here we are, Leo and I, two tiny earthlings, somewhere near the outer edge of our galaxy, which is just one among billions of other galaxies.

有一次，我们突然意识到，我们可能向下看而不是向上看——毕竟，宇宙中哪个方向是“向上”的？谁或什么来决定这一点？在这样的时刻，我有时会措手不及，发现自己陷入了“存在性眩晕”之中。我清楚地感觉到自己是某个比我广阔得多的东西中无限微小的一部分。然后，利奥和我几乎不复存在，只是浩瀚宇宙中的两粒尘埃。这可能被称为精神体验吗？

One time, it occurred to us that we might be looking down instead of up—after all, what direction is “up” in the universe? Who or what would determine that? In moments like that, I can occasionally be caught off guard, and I find myself spinning in “existential vertigo.” I have the clearest feeling of being an infinitely tiny part of something that is infinitely vaster than I am. Leo and I then almost cease to exist, other than as two dust particles in the vast reaches of the cosmos. Could this possibly be called a spiritual experience?

我的宗教朋友向我保证，上帝是任何真正的精神体验中不可或缺的因素。然而，我不相信这一点。当我将自己整个人投入广阔的星空、宇宙深不可测的深处时，那种兴奋和敬畏的感觉在我心中激起了比任何超自然神话或传说都更强烈的精神反应。

My religious friends assure me that God is an indispensable ingredient in any genuinely spiritual experience. I, however, don’t buy into that. The feeling of exaltation and awe when I plunge my whole self into a vast starry sky, into the universe’s unfathomable depths, evokes in me a far more powerful spiritual reaction than any supernatural myth or legend could possibly do.

这种感觉也会在非常不同的情况下被唤起。当我坐在钢琴前和其他人一起演奏音乐时，我通常必须非常努力才能弹奏出正确的音符，并且不会错过关键的和声，尽管我是个业余爱好者。但偶尔会发生一些非常特别的事情：我忘记了自己在做什么，突然间我只是音乐“流动”的一部分。在这种时候，我成为了比我更大的事物的一部分——在这种情况下，音乐体验感觉大于其各部分的总和。这对我来说也是非常精神上的，但它没有宗教或神秘的含义。

This kind of feeling can also be evoked in very different circumstances. When I sit at the piano and make music with other people, I usually have to sweat pretty hard just to hit the right notes and not to miss crucial harmonies, amateur that I am. But once in a while something very special transpires: I lose track of what I’m doing and suddenly I’m just part of the musical “flow.” At such times, I become part of something bigger than myself—in this case, a musical experience that feels greater than the sum of its parts. This, too, is deeply spiritual for me, but it has no religious or mystical overtones.

有人说，每个人都需要宗教信仰。事实真的如此吗？谁来决定什么才算宗教信仰？

Some people say that every human being has a need for religion. Can that really be the case? And who will decide what counts as religion?

如果我们真正需要的是一种没有教条、没有神、没有罪恶感、没有羞耻感、没有对地狱的恐惧、不需要强迫别人按照“上帝的规则”生活、不需要无休止地为真假而争斗的生活哲学，那又会怎样？如果我们真正需要的是一种肯定开放和探索的生活哲学，鼓励对艺术、音乐、文学、自然、宇宙、现实和其他人类的惊奇、迷恋和深厚感情的生活哲学，那又会怎样？

What if what we really need is a philosophy of life without dogmas, without gods, without guilt, without shame, without a fear of hell, without the need to force other people to live according to “God’s rules,” and without endless bitter fighting over what is true and what is false? What if what we really need is a philosophy of life that affirms openness and questing, that encourages wonderment, fascination, and deep feelings for art, music, literature, nature, the cosmos, reality, and for other human beings?

对我来说，灵性不是超自然的，而是与自然本身息息相关的。我们都只是更伟大事物的微小碎片。我们是人类的微小部分，宇宙的微小部分，现实的微小片段。这个想法对我来说已经够令人眼花缭乱了；我觉得没有必要用神灵或魔法来给它增添色彩。

For me, spirituality is not supernatural but has everything to do with nature itself. We are all just tiny pieces of something much greater. We are small pieces of humanity, tiny parts of the universe, minuscule slices of reality. This thought is dizzying enough for me; I feel no need to spice it up with divine beings or magical powers.

第二章

CHAPTER TWO

我相信我知道关于现实、知识和真理

I BELIEVE THAT I KNOW Concerning Reality, Knowledge, and Truth

科学家的与众不同之处并不在于他相信什么，而在于他相信的方式和原因。他的信仰是尝试性的，而不是教条的；它们基于证据，而不是权威或直觉。——伯特兰·罗素

It is not what the man of science believes that distinguishes him, but how and why he believes it. His beliefs are tentative, not dogmatic; they are based on evidence, not on authority or intuition.—Bertrand Russell

我为了能够形成自己对现实的看法，你需要一些工具和一些概念词汇。你需要理解诸如真理、学习、信仰和知识等概念。你还需要自己决定要做出哪些基本假设。看似真实的东西是真的吗，还是只是一场梦？一切可能只是我脑海中的幻影吗？或者真正的真理和谬误存在吗？而且，理性到底有什么好的理由呢？

In order to be able to formulate your own viewpoint on reality, you will need some tools and a vocabulary of concepts. You’ll need to understand concepts such as truth, learning, faith, and knowledge. You’ll also need to decide for yourself which basic assumptions you will make. Is what seems real really real, or is it just a dream? Could everything be just an apparition inside my head? Or do genuine truths and falsities exist? And what good reason is there for being rational, anyway?

具有理性态度的人并不声称能够对有关世界本质的所有问题给出明确而详尽的答案。当代科学和知识尚未达到能够解释我们星球和宇宙中所有现象的程度，而且几乎肯定永远不会达到这一程度。因此，拥有理性态度意味着在智力上保持谦逊。这意味着经常对自己认为理所当然的思想和概念进行自我批评——尤其是那些自己特别执着的思想和概念。这与传统的宗教态度形成了鲜明对比。

Someone with a rational attitude does not claim to be able to give definitive and exhaustive answers to all questions about the nature of the world. Contemporary science and knowledge are not yet at the point where they can explain all the phenomena on our planet and in our universe, and they almost surely never will be. Therefore, having a rational attitude means being intellectually humble. It means frequently engaging in self-critical examination of the ideas and concepts that one takes for granted—especially those that one is particularly strongly attached to. This contrasts strongly with traditional religious attitudes.

许多宗教对现实的解释都以绝对主义的方式表述事物，或声称事物如何运作，完全基于宗教著作和传统。当今科学尚无法解释的事物据说可以通过“上帝”来解释，这等于将这些问题扫到地毯下。以下是例子：“我们不知道生命是如何起源的，所以一定有一位上帝创造了它。”或者，“我们不知道宇宙是如何诞生的，所以一定有一位上帝创造了它。”或者又比如，“我们不知道我们头骨里的意识是什么，所以它一定来自上帝。”等等。

Many religious interpretations of reality are characterized by absolutist ways of phrasing things, or by claims about how things behave, based solely on religious writings and traditions. Things that today’s science cannot yet explain are supposedly explained by reference to “God,” which amounts to sweeping such issues under the rug. The following are examples: “We don’t know how life originated, so there must have been a god that created it.” Or, “We don’t know how the universe arose, so a god must have created it.” Or again, “We don’t know what this consciousness inside our skulls is, so it must have come from God.” And so on.

但人们可以采取完全不同的态度。这里有一个简单的寓言来说明我的意思：

But one could instead have a totally different kind of attitude. Here’s a simple parable to show what I mean:

我不明白如何才能建造出像我住的这样的房子。我自己笨手笨脚，连拧灯泡都做不到。但这并不意味着我相信一定是有神建造了我的房子。就目前而言，我只能接受这样一个事实：我不知道它是如何建造的。某件事现在对我来说是个谜，并不一定意味着它对所有人来说永远都是个谜。也许我只是不明白！也许我只是还没有正确的思维工具！

I don’t understand how it’s possible to build a house like the one I live in. I myself am all thumbs, and I can barely screw in a lightbulb. But that doesn’t mean that I believe that some god must have built my house. For the time being, I’ll simply have to accept the fact that I don’t how it was put together. The fact that something is a mystery to me right now doesn’t necessarily mean that it will forever be a mystery for all people. Maybe I just don’t understand it! Maybe I just don’t yet have the right mental tools!

正如这个寓言中所说，人们必须接受这样一个事实：当今许多重大问题和谜团仍未得到解答。也许有一天它们会被科学解释——或者可能不会。

As in this parable, one simply has to accept the fact that many of today’s big questions and mysteries are still unanswered. Perhaps one day they will be explained by science—or perhaps they won’t.

什么是知识？

What Is Knowledge?

什么是知识？我们能知道什么？什么是真理？我们如何确定某件事是真还是假？正如前面提到的，试图回答这些问题的哲学领域被称为认识论或知识理论。现在我们将熟悉一些基本工具，以便我们能够以最佳方式利用我们的推理能力。

What is knowledge? What can we know? What is truth? How can we determine whether something is true or false? The area of philosophy that tries to answer these questions is called, as was mentioned earlier, epistemology or the theory of knowledge. We will now familiarize ourselves with some basic tools so that we can make use of our faculty of reason in the best possible way.

我知道瑞典首都的名字。所以在这个具体案例中，我有知识。但一般的知识难道不会比这个简单的例子复杂得多吗？为了说我们知道某事，必须满足哪些确切的标准？知道某事究竟意味着什么？

I know the name of Sweden’s capital. So I have knowledge, in this specific case. But might not knowledge in general be far more complex than this trivial example? What are the exact criteria that must be met so that we can say we know something? What does it mean, really, to know something?

如果我们要谈论知识，必须满足三个标准——信念、真理和强有力的理由。为了让我知道某件事（我称之为“X”），以下条件必须全部满足：

Three criteria must be met if we’re going to talk about knowledge—namely, belief, truth, and strong reasons. For me to know something (I’ll call it “X”), the following must all hold:

  1. 我相信
  2. I believe
  3. X 为真。
  4. X is true.
  5. 我有充分的理由相信X。
  6. I have strong reasons for believing X.

很容易看出，第一个条件必须满足。我不能不相信某件事，就不知道它。如果我不相信巴黎在法国，那么我当然不知道它在法国。

It’s easy to see that the first condition has to be met. I can’t know something without believing it. If I don’t believe that Paris is in France, then I certainly don’t know that it is in France.

我们可以想象这样的情况：X 是真的，我有充分的理由相信 X 是真的，但第一个标准不满足：我只是拒绝相信 X 是真的。举个例子，我的一个朋友在背后说了我坏话，而我已经从几个独立的、可靠的消息来源得知了这件事（因此我有充分的理由相信它）。但我仍然不想相信它，所以我坚决拒绝接受它。在这种情况下，我当然不知道我被说坏话了；如果我甚至不相信它，我怎么会知道呢？然而，后两个标准得到了满足。我的这种行为并不理性，但从心理上来说是可以理解的。

We can imagine situations where X is true and I have good reasons to believe X is true, but where the first criterion is not met: I simply refuse to believe that X is true. Take the case where a friend of mine has said mean things about me behind my back, and I’ve been told about this by several independent, reliable sources (thus I have good reasons to believe it). But I still don’t want to believe it, and so I staunchly refuse to accept it. In such a case, I certainly don’t know that I have been badmouthed; how could I know it if I don’t even believe it? And yet the last two criteria are met. Such behavior on my part wouldn’t be rational, but it would be psychologically understandable.

那么第二个标准呢？显然，如果我们想要知道某件事，它必须是真的。我们可以有一个想法，并且有充分的理由相信它，但我们仍然可能对它判断错误，因为这个想法可能就是错的。

What about the second criterion? It’s obvious that something has to be true if we are to know it. We can have an idea and have good reasons for believing it, but we can still be wrong about it, since the idea could simply be wrong.

假设我读过几本关于历史话题的书，并与许多知识渊博的人讨论过这个问题。那么我就有充分的理由相信我对这个话题很了解。但很可能我读的书包含了错误的信息，而我交谈的人也得到了误导，甚至对我撒谎。我坚信的一些观点根本不正确。因此，即使我有充分的理由相信它们，我也不知道它们。

Suppose that I have read several books about some topic in history and have talked with numerous knowledgeable people about it. Then I have good reasons for believing I am knowledgeable about the topic. But it could easily be that the books I read contained wrong pieces of information, and that the people I spoke with were misinformed or even were lying to me. Some of the ideas that I strongly believe in are simply not true. Thus I don’t know them, even if I have good reasons to believe them.

最后我们来谈谈第三个条件：坚实的依据。关于 X 的知识不仅仅涉及 X 是真实的和我相信 X。我还必须有充分的理由相信 X。让我举个例子。假设有一天，突然间，一个小小的内心声音告诉我，我厨房桌子上的碗里有 213 颗杏仁。假设碰巧这是完全正确的。我相信的说法是正确的，但我的直觉不能算作知识。

Finally we come to the third condition: the strong grounds. Knowledge of X involves more than just X being true and my believing X. It’s also crucial that I have good reasons for believing X. Let me give an example. Suppose that one day, out of the blue sky, a little inner voice whispers to me that there are 213 almonds in the bowl on my kitchen table. And suppose that just by chance, this is exactly right. The statement that I believe is true, but my hunch can’t be counted as knowledge.

归根结底，我没有任何充分的理由支持我的想法。我没有数过坚果的数量，甚至没有用常识很好地估计过它们的数量；我只是碰巧猜对了。碗里实际上有213颗杏仁。不过，我只是猜测，我的猜对只是运气好而已。我当然不知道碗里有 213 颗杏仁。总之，我们需要充分的理由才能将真实信念算作知识。

It all comes down to the fact that I don’t have any good reason backing up my idea. I haven’t counted the nuts, or even made a good estimate of their number using common sense; I simply happen to be right on the money. There actually are 213 almonds in the bowl. I’m just guessing, though, and it’s merely a piece of luck that I’m right. I certainly don’t know there are 213 almonds in the bowl. In sum, then, we need good reasons for a true belief to be counted as knowledge.

“信仰”和“知识”这两个词经常被放在一起对比。但在日常用语中，“我知道X”仅仅意味着我有充分的理由相信X。当我说我“知道”地球是圆的或者巴黎在法国，我只是说我相信它，确信它，有信心，并且有很多很好的理由相信它。当然，从原则上讲，即使是像这样的基本信念，我也可能是错的；也许自从我还是个婴儿以来，我就一直在这些话题上被欺骗。

The words “faith” and “knowledge” are often placed in contrast to each other. But in everyday speech, “I know X” merely means that I have very good reasons for having faith in X. When I say that I “know” that the earth is round or that Paris is in France, all I mean is that I believe it, am convinced of it, have faith in it, and have lots of very good grounds for believing it. Of course I could, in principle, turn out to be wrong even in basic beliefs like these; maybe I’ve been systematically lied to on these topics since I was a baby.

从知识论的角度来看，信仰和知识并不是对立的概念。然而，我们刚才谈到的“信仰”的意义与宗教意义上的“信仰”相反，宗教意义上的“信仰”意味着“我接受这是真的，没有任何证据或证据”。如果你相信某件事仅仅是因为你想相信它——因为它让你感觉良好，或者因为它给你对未来的希望——那么这并不是将你的信仰称为知识的充分理由。尽管如此，人们往往正是因为这些事情让他们感觉更好或给他们对未来的希望而相信它们。

From a knowledge-theoretic perspective, faith and knowledge are not opposite notions. The sense of “faith” we’ve just been speaking of is, however, in contrast to the religious sense of “faith,” which means “I accept this as true without any proof or evidence.” If you believe in something merely because you want to believe in it—because it makes you feel good or because it gives you hope for the future—then this is not a sufficient reason to call your belief knowledge. Nonetheless, people often believe things precisely because those things make them feel better or give them hope for the future.

看似真实的东西真的是真实的吗？

Is What Seems Real Really Real?

让我们暂时看看关于信仰的最根本的问题。任何看过电影《黑客帝国》的人至少都考虑过我们的整个世界只是幻觉的可能性。

Let us for a moment take a look at the most radical questions about belief. Anyone who has seen the movie The Matrix has at least considered the possibility that our entire world is just an illusion.

据我们所知，经过数百万年的自然选择，我们的大脑进化而来，其目的是处理通过感官获得的信息。我们的大脑使我们能够在世界中定位自己，因为进化选择了那些在提供有助于生存的信息方面表现最好的大脑。但是，有什么理由相信我们的大脑为我们提供了关于世界的真实信息，而不是仅仅帮助我们在环境中生存的信息呢？如果世界忠实地反映在我们的大脑中，那么进化目标又是什么呢？毕竟，进化选择大脑纯粹是因为它们具有生存能力，而不是因为它们具有识别真相的能力。

As far as we know, our brains evolved, through millions of years of natural selection, for the purpose of processing information that reached us via our senses. Our brains allow us to orient ourselves in the world, since evolution selected those brains that did the best in supplying information that aided survival. But what reason is there for believing that our brains give us true information about the world, rather than information that merely helps us survive in our environment? What evolutionary goal would be served by having the world faithfully mirrored in our brains? After all, evolution selected brains purely for their ability to survive, not for their ability to recognize truths.

然而，我们人类几乎作为副作用，发展出了一种独特的能力，可以发现和识别真理，即使是深藏不露的真理。这在数学领域最为明显。许多数学是在没有丝毫物质世界支撑的情况下发展起来的，然而，很久以后，一件又一件“没有支撑”的数学却成为描述物质世界物理定律的核心。1

And yet we humans, almost as a side effect, developed a unique capacity for finding and recognizing truths, even deeply hidden ones. This is clearest in the domain of mathematics. Much of mathematics was developed without even the slightest anchoring in the material world, and yet, much later, piece after piece of “unanchored” math turned out to be central in describing the physical laws governing the material world.1

几个世纪以来，哲学家们一直在思考人类是否能够了解自己身体之外的事物。我们为什么要依赖感觉器官输入大脑的信息呢？事实上，我们都知道我们的感官有时会欺骗我们，所以它们可能只是一直在欺骗我们？难道一切都不是梦，是幻觉吗？如果我闭上眼睛，我面前的桌子还会存在吗？我睁开眼睛时能确定它存在吗？

For centuries, philosophers have pondered about whether humans can know anything at all about things outside their own bodies. Why should we rely on information that is fed into our brains by our sensory organs? In fact, we all know that our senses can trick us at times, so could they simply be tricking us all the time?
