Couldn’t everything be a dream, a hallucination? Will the table in front of me continue to exist if I close my eyes? Can I even be sure that it exists when my eyes are open?

哲学家们设想的这些困境是完全合理的。我们不能 100% 确定现实存在于我们之外，独立于我们的思想。我们也不能完全确定明天早上太阳会升起，甚至我们是否真的存在了超过三分钟。也许世界是在三分钟前从头开始创造的，我们童年的所有记忆都预先植入了我们的大脑……

These dilemmas dreamed up by philosophers are quite legitimate. We can’t be 100 percent sure that reality exists out there, independently of our minds. Nor can we be completely sure that the sun will come up tomorrow morning, nor even that we really have existed for longer than three minutes. Maybe the world was made from scratch just three minutes ago, with all our memories of childhood pre-implanted in our brains . . .

我们也不能 100% 肯定除了我们自己的意识之外，还有其他意识存在。难道所有其他的人和生物都只是我们想象出来的吗？这种观念的哲学术语是唯我论。伯特兰·罗素眼中闪烁着光芒，提出了以下反对唯我论的论点：

Nor can we be 100 percent sure that any consciousness other than our own exists. Could it be that all other people and beings are simply figments of our imagination? The philosophical term for such a notion is solipsism. Bertrand Russell, with a twinkle in his eye, gave the following argument against solipsism:

阅读一本书与创作一本书的体验截然不同；然而，如果我是一个唯我论者，我应该假设我创作了莎士比亚、牛顿和爱因斯坦的作品，因为它们已经进入了我的体验。看到它们比我自己的书好得多，而且花费我少得多的劳动，我花这么多时间用笔而不是用眼睛创作是愚蠢的。2

Reading a book is a very different experience from composing one; yet, if I were a solipsist, I should have to suppose that I had composed the works of Shakespeare and Newton and Einstein, since they have entered into my experience. Seeing how much better they are than my own books, and how much less labor they have cost me, I have been foolish to spend so much time composing with the pen rather than with the eye.2

在实践中（即在日常生活中），哲学家对现实本质的不确定性意味着什么？它是否应该影响有思想的人的日常行为和日常思考？对这个问题唯一合理的答案是“不”。

What, in practice (that is, in everyday life), is implied by the uncertainty that philosophers have about the nature of reality? Should it affect the daily actions and the daily thinking of thoughtful people? The only reasonable answer to this question has to be “no.”

即使严格来说我们无法知道现实是否存在，我们也可以认为它极有可能存在。以下是支持这一观点的三个简单论据：

Even if, strictly speaking, we cannot know that reality exists, we can consider it extremely probable. Here are three simple arguments for this viewpoint:

  1. 现实似乎大体上是稳定的，大体上是一成不变的，时时刻刻都是如此。即使我闭上眼睛，桌子仍然在那里。我的房子每天都差不多一样。所有这些都表明，我们不是时时刻刻都在随机地遇到事情，而是我们陷入了一种存在可靠规律的境地——也就是自然法则。
  2. Reality seems largely stable, largely the same, from moment to moment. The table stays there even after I’ve closed my eyes. My house looks about the same from one day to the next. All this suggests that we’re not just encountering random things from moment to moment, but rather that we are plunged into the midst of a situation where there are reliable regularities—that is, laws of nature.
  3. 如果我和我的意识存在，那么为什么其他人就不能存在呢？这难道不是最简单的假设吗？
  4. If I and my consciousness exist, then why shouldn’t the same hold for others? Isn’t that the simplest possible assumption?
  5. 进化使我们更好地生存。为了生存，最好正确地而不是错误地解读环境。如果我在等着过马路，发现一辆车朝我的方向快速驶来，如果我相信这辆车可能会撞到我，那么这对我的生存更有帮助。
  6. Evolution shaped us to survive well. And for survival purposes, it’s better to interpret one’s environment correctly instead of wrongly. If I’m waiting to cross a street and spot a car coming fast in my direction, it’s much more helpful to my survival if I believe that the car might run me over than if I don’t.

进行哲学思考总是令人振奋的，即使它们涉及激进的怀疑论。但是当日常生活中出现这种论点时（“你怎么知道她偷了车？你无法确定任何事情！”），人们应该保持警惕。仅仅因为从严格的哲学意义上来说没有什么是绝对确定的，并不意味着所有可以想象的可能性都是同样可能的。

It’s always stimulating to entertain philosophical reflections, even if they involve radical skepticism. But when arguments of that sort are brought up in ordinary life (“How can you know she took the car? You can’t know anything for certain!”), one should be on one’s guard. Just because nothing is absolutely certain in a strict philosophical sense, that doesn’t mean that every imaginable possibility is equally likely.

凭借理性和强烈的好奇心，我们可以踏上旅程，追寻关于现实的真知灼见。我们可能永远无法到达目的地，但借助清晰的思维，我们可以越来越接近目的地。

Armed with reason and a lively curiosity, we can set off on a voyage toward true knowledge about reality. We may never reach our destination, but we can come closer and closer with the help of clear thinking.

事实问题和品味问题

Matters of Fact and Matters of Taste

我们可以区分两种关于现实的问题，对它们应该稍作区分：事实问题（客观问题）和品味问题（主观问题）。关于事实的问题有明确的答案——要么正确，要么错误。但对于品味问题，情况并非如此。

We can distinguish between two sorts of questions about reality, which should be treated a bit differently: matters of fact (objective questions) and matters of taste (subjective questions). There are clear answers to questions about matters of fact—answers that are either true or false. But for matters of taste, this isn’t the case.

以下是关于事实的一个例子：“篮子里有三个苹果。”篮子里的苹果数量与观察者无关。要么篮子里有三个苹果，在这种情况下，这个说法是正确的，要么篮子里有超过或少于三个苹果，在这种情况下，这个说法是错误的。所以在这种情况下，我们处理的是事实，而不是品味问题。

Here’s a sample claim about a matter of fact: “There are three apples in the basket.” The number of apples in the basket doesn’t depend on the observer. Either there are three apples in the basket, in which case the claim is true, or there are more or fewer than three apples in it, in which case the claim is false. So in this case, we are dealing with a matter of fact, not one of taste.

不可否认，苹果性存在边界情况——例如，烂苹果、未成熟的苹果、部分被吃掉的苹果——因此在某些情况下，两个理性的人可能会对苹果数量产生分歧。而且“在篮子里”的含义也存在边界情况。（例如，假设篮子太窄，苹果垂直堆放，最高的苹果的重心略高于篮子边缘。这是“在篮子里”吗？）第二种歧义可能会使问题更加模糊。如果读者愿意，我们可以用希望更清晰的例子“3 是质数”来代替这个事实例子。

Admittedly, there are borderline cases of apple-ness—for instance, rotten apples, immature apples, partially eaten apples—so that in certain circumstances, two reasonable people might disagree on the apple count. And there are also borderline cases of what “in the basket” might mean. (Suppose, for instance, that the basket is so narrow that the apples are stacked up in a vertical pile, with the highest one’s center of gravity being located slightly higher than the basket’s rim. Is it “in the basket”?) This second type of ambiguity could blur the question even more. If the reader prefers, then, we can replace this example of a matter of fact by the hopefully sharper example “3 is a prime number.”

另一个事实的例子是：“地球是平的。”事实上，这是错误的。

Another example of a matter of fact is the claim: “The earth is flat.” This, as a matter of fact, is false.

那么“其他星球上有生命”这个说法又如何呢？这是事实问题还是个人喜好问题？它似乎是事实问题，应该要么是真的，要么是假的；然而，我们不知道是哪一种，而且我们可能永远也找不到答案。尽管如此，要么外星某处有生命，要么没有生命。我们不知道答案，甚至可能永远不知道，但这并不会使这个说法变得不客观。

And what about the claim “There is life on other planets”? Is this a matter of fact or one of taste? It seems to be a matter of fact, and it should be either true or false; however, we don’t know which it is, and we may never find out. Nonetheless, either there is life somewhere out there, or there isn’t. The fact that we don’t know the answer, and even may never know it, doesn’t make the claim less objective.

“这房子闹鬼”、“死后还有生命”和“上帝存在”等说法也是关于事实的陈述，它们要么是真的，要么是假的。当然，当我们去检验这些说法的真实性时，这假设我们已经就“闹鬼”、“生命”和“上帝”这些概念的某种定义达成了一致。

Such claims as “This house is haunted,” “There is life after death,” and “God exists” are also statements about fact, and each of them is either true or false. To be sure, this supposes that we have agreed on some definition of the concepts “haunted,” “life,” and “God” when we go to examine these claims’ truth.

就事实而言，有既定的方法可以区分真假。这包括科学方法，我们将在后面的章节中仔细讨论。通过遵循这些方法，我们可以合理地判断哪些说法是真的，哪些是假的。

As far as matters of fact are concerned, there are established methods to distinguish what is true from what is false. This includes the scientific method, which we will look at carefully in a later chapter. By following such methods, we can make reasonable judgments about which claims are true and which are false.

但对于品味问题，情况就完全不同了。如果我说“Lady Gaga 比 Beyoncé 好”，而你反驳说“Beyoncé 比 Lady Gaga 好”，我们谁说的是实话？当然都不是！我们只是品味和偏好不同，仅此而已。所以这是品味问题。我可以喜欢你不喜欢的东西，反之亦然。

With questions of taste, though, it’s quite another matter. If I declare “Lady Gaga is better than Beyoncé” and you counter with “Beyoncé is better than Lady Gaga,” which of us is telling the truth? Neither, of course! We simply have different tastes and preferences, that’s all. So this is a matter of taste. I can like something that you don’t like, and vice versa.

即使没有关于 Lady Gaga 和 Beyoncé 哪个更好的客观答案，我们之间的交流仍有许多真实的说法。例如，事实上我喜欢 Lady Gaga 胜过我喜欢 Beyoncé。所以如果你对我说：“不，你不喜欢 Lady Gaga 的程度不比你喜欢 Beyoncé 的程度高！”我会对你生气，因为你的说法是错误的。

Even if there’s no objective answer as to which of Lady Gaga and Beyoncé is better, there are many true statements about our exchange that can be made. For example, it’s a fact that I like Lady Gaga better than I like Beyoncé. So if you were to say to me, “No, you don’t like Lady Gaga any more than you like Beyoncé!,” I would get annoyed at you, since what you’re claiming is false.

关于事实（或品味）问题的分歧往往只是表面上的分歧。以上帝存在的问题为例。如果你说“上帝存在”，而我说“上帝不存在”，那么只有当我们对“上帝”一词的意思相同时，我们才会真正产生分歧。如果你说“上帝”时，你的意思是“爱”，那么我们都同意上帝确实存在。但如果我所说的“上帝”是某个坐在云端的胡子拉碴的老人，而你接受这个定义，那么我们都同意上帝不存在。

Disagreements concerning questions of fact (or of taste) often turn out to be only apparent disagreements. Take, for instance, the question of God’s existence. If you say “God exists” while I say “God doesn’t exist,” we’ll only be genuinely disagreeing if we mean the same thing by the word “God.” If it turns out that when you say “God,” you mean “love,” then we both agree that God does exist. But if what I mean by “God” is some very old scraggly bearded fellow who’s sitting up on a cloud, and if you accept this definition, then we’re in agreement that God doesn’t exist.

品味问题也是如此。如果我们真的要争论 Lady Gaga 和 Beyoncé 哪个更好，那么我们我们不得不在语言层面之外产生分歧。例如，我们不得不用“更好”这个词来表达相同的意思。但在音乐方面，“更好”的含义并不明确。当我说音乐“更好”时，也许我的意思是“音乐上更具原创性”，而当你说“更好”时，也许你的意思是“更受公众的赞赏”。在这种情况下，我们实际上并没有分歧，因为你的观点和我的观点可以同时成立。

Much the same holds for matters of taste. If we are going to be in genuine disagreement about which of Lady Gaga and Beyoncé is better, then we have to disagree in more than just a linguistic sense. For instance, we both have to mean the same thing by the word “better.” But, in music, it’s unclear what “better” means. When I say “better” regarding music, perhaps I mean “more musically original,” whereas when you say it, perhaps you mean “more admired by the public.” In such a case, we aren’t really in disagreement, since your view and mine can both be true at the same time.

如果我们学会区分事实问题和个人品味问题，许多不必要的争吵就可以避免。太多的讨论以失败告终，因为参与者使用的某些相当常见的表达方式并不代表同一个意思。

Many unnecessary quarrels could be avoided if we were taught how to distinguish between matters of fact and matters of taste. Too many discussions wind up on the rocks because the participants just don’t mean the same thing by certain fairly common expressions they use.

真理是什么？

What Is Truth?

人们曾尝试过许多理论来描述真理是什么。最合理的理论通常被称为对应论。对应论的名称源于这样一种观点，即真理意味着关于世界的论述与世界本身之间存在着对应关系和联系。“那里有一个苹果”这个说法只有当那里真的有一个苹果时才是真的。亚里士多德（公元前 384-322 年）在他的《形而上学》一书中提出了这样的观点：“说是的说它不是，或说不是的说它存在，都是错误的；说是的说它存在，或说不是的说它不存在，都是正确的。” 3

Many theoretical attempts have been made at describing what truth is. The most reasonable such attempt is usually called the correspondence theory. The name comes from the idea that truth implies that there exists a correspondence, a link, between what is being said about the world and the world itself. The statement “There’s an apple right there” is true if and only if there really is an apple right there. Aristotle (384–322 BCE) gave essentially this point of view in his book Metaphysics: “To say of what is that it is not, or of what is not that it is, is false, while to say of what is that it is, and of what is not that it is not, is true.”3

符合论的真理概念理所当然地认为，现实的哲学观点通常被称为现实主义。这意味着现实存在，并且在某种意义上，它的存在与我们对它的先入之见无关。相反的概念被称为反现实主义，它声称不存在独立于我们人类观念的现实。

The correspondence theory’s notion of truth takes for granted the philosophical view of reality that is usually called realism. This means that reality exists and, in a certain sense, does so independently of our preconceptions of it. The opposite notion is called antirealism, which claims that there is no reality independent of our human notions.

我们需要对世界抱有现实的态度，才能应对日常环境，更不用说科学实验室的情况了。如果没有现实的态度，我们就无法与环境产生联系。

A realistic viewpoint about the world is needed for us to be able to deal with our everyday environment, not to mention situations in scientific laboratories. Without a realistic viewpoint, we would simply be unable to relate to our environment.

对应论和哲学实在论并非如此简单。以以下断言为例：我的餐桌上有一颗淡蓝色的钻石。

Correspondence theory and philosophical realism turn out not to be so simple. Take the following assertion: There’s a light-blue diamond on my dining room table.

这是真的吗？根据真对应论，只有当我的餐桌上真的有一颗淡蓝色的钻石时，这句话才是正确的。但“钻石”是什么意思？“淡蓝色”又是什么意思？这些都是人类创造的概念。“蓝色”，就像所有与其他颜色词不同，这个概念与我们的眼睛和大脑作为光的传感器的工作方式有关，而副词修饰语“light”导致“blue”的变体，这种变体肯定没有明确的界限，人们可以永远争论下去。因此，形容词“light-blue”充满了各种模糊和歧义。

Is it true? According to the correspondence theory of truth, this statement would be true if and only if there really is a light-blue diamond on my dining room table. But what does “diamond” mean? And what does “light-blue” mean? These are notions that humanity created. “Blue,” just like all other color words, is a concept that has to do with the way our eyes and brains work as sensors of light, and the adverbial modifier “light” results in a variation on “blue” that certainly has no sharp cutoff, and that people can argue about forever. The adjective “light-blue” is thus fraught with all sorts of blurriness and ambiguity.

那么“钻石”又如何呢？这也是人类的发明。世界上哪些石头可以算作钻石？有各种各样的“未经雕琢的钻石”，专家们可能会争论它们是否真的是钻石。那么“钻石”的含义又如何呢？它仅仅意味着“菱形”？那么它适用于纸牌（四种花色之一）的含义又如何呢？

What about “diamond”? This, too, was a human invention. What stones in the world count as diamonds? There are all sorts of “diamonds in the rough” about which experts could squabble as to whether they actually are diamonds or are not. And what about the meaning of “diamond” that merely means “lozenge-shaped”? And what about the meaning that applies to cards (one of the four suits)?

那么“在”是什么意思呢？如果桌子上铺着布垫呢？放在布垫上的物品也算在桌子上吗？如果陶瓷烛台放在桌子上的布垫上，蜡烛也算在桌子上吗？蜡烛顶部的火焰呢？它也在桌子上吗？

And what does “on” mean? What if the table has a cloth mat on it? Are objects sitting on the mat also on the table? Does a candle whose ceramic candlestick has been placed on the cloth mat that is lying on the table also count as being on the table? And what about the flame atop the candle—is that, too, on the table?

我们构建概念和词语是为了交流世界，以便他人能够理解我们在交谈时的想法——但这并不意味着使用熟悉概念的句子的含义总是准确的。如前所述，即使仅由常用词组成的句子也可能不准确！

We construct our concepts and words so that we can communicate about the world, so that others can understand what we have in mind when we are speaking with them—but that doesn’t mean that sentences using familiar concepts are always precise in their meanings. As the foregoing shows, even sentences made up solely of common words can be anything but precise!

另一个问题与给定概念如何与世界相对应有关。以“圣诞老人”一词为例。尽管我们成年人知道没有圣诞老人，但我们在购物中心和广告中经常看到圣诞老人。那么我们如何使用这个词？它指的是什么？当我们都知道只有一个圣诞老人时（而且，让事情更复杂的是，我们还知道这个“独特”的实体实际上并不存在） ，将它复数化有什么意义？

Another question has to do with how a given concept corresponds with the world. Consider the term “Santa Claus.” Even though we adults know there is no Santa Claus, we see Santa Clauses all the time in shopping centers and in advertisements. So how do we use this word? What does it refer to? What sense does it make to pluralize it, when we all know that there is only one Santa Claus (and, to complicate matters, when we also know that this “unique” entity is in fact nonexistent)?

我上学的时候，我们学到了原子是一个微小的太阳系，中间有一个原子核，电子围绕原子核旋转，就像行星围绕太阳旋转一样。

When I went to school, we learned that an atom was a tiny solar system with a nucleus in the middle and electrons in orbits around the nucleus, just like the planets orbiting around the sun.

事实上，这幅图与现实没有太大关系。是的，原子是由原子核和“在轨道上”围绕的电子组成的，但“轨道”的概念对于原子和行星来说是截然不同的，因为根据量子力学，原子中的电子并不是在特定时刻定位到特定点；相反，在每个时刻，每个电子都模糊地位于空间中所有可能的点，但概率不同。太阳系模型帮助我们以一种简单而有用的方式想象原子这种方式尤其适用于首次在学校引入“原子”概念的学校。但我们不应该将这种现实教学模式与“外面”存在的现实相混淆。

In actual fact, this image doesn’t have too much to do with reality. Yes, atoms consist of nuclei with electrons “in orbit” around them, but the concept of “orbit” is wildly different for atoms and for planets because, according to quantum mechanics, an electron in an atom is not localized to a specific point at a specific moment in time; rather, at each moment, each electron is blurrily located at all possible points in space, but with different probabilities. The solar-system model helps us envision atoms in a simple and helpful manner, especially when the concept of “atom” is first being introduced in schools. But we should never confuse such pedagogical models of reality with the actual reality that is “out there.”

量子力学是一门非凡的学科，因为它的方程和计算使我们能够以惊人的精度预测各种物理实验的结果。从这个意义上说，我们可以说我们的现实量子力学模型是正确的，而且它们几乎完美地发挥作用。但即便如此，我们对量子力学系统（如原子）的想象仍然与我们基于周围普通物体的日常想象不符。量子力学粒子能够同时出现在许多地方——事实上，在无数个地方！——这与我们多年来对世界的日常直觉发生了剧烈冲突。

Quantum mechanics is a remarkable subject since its equations and calculations allow us to predict with astonishing precision the results of all sorts of physics experiments. In that sense, we can say that our quantum-mechanical models of reality are true, and they function nearly perfectly. But even so, we have no imagery for quantum-mechanical systems (such as atoms) that is compatible with our everyday imagery based on the ordinary objects surrounding us. The ability of quantum-mechanical particles to be in many places at the same time—in fact, in infinitely many places!—clashes violently with the day-to-day intuitions about the world that we have built up over years of life.

同样，两个量子力学粒子可以相互纠缠，这一点也同样适用（只是更加违反直觉） 。这意味着，无论两个纠缠粒子相距多远，只要观察到其中一个处于特定状态（例如，其自旋指向“向上”），另一个粒子的状态就会立即确定为相反状态（因此其自旋指向“向下”）。这两个粒子似乎是宇宙相连的，即使相隔宇宙很远。这是量子力学中一个非常神秘的方面。阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦对此深表怀疑，他称之为“幽灵般的超距作用” 。4

The same can be said (only it’s even more counterintuitive) about the fact that two quantum-mechanical particles can be entangled with each other. What this means is that whenever one of two entangled particles is observed to be in a particular state (say, with its spin pointing “up”), then the state of the other particle is instantly determined to be in the opposite state (thus with its spin pointing “down”), no matter how far the two are from each other. It seems that the two particles are cosmically linked, even way across the universe from each other. This is a profoundly mystifying aspect of quantum mechanics. Albert Einstein was deeply suspicious of it, and he famously called it “spooky action-at-a-distance.”4

由于量子力学充满了看似神秘的现象，它在新纪元圈子里风靡一时。不幸的是，新纪元思想的追随者很少对量子物理学的真正含义有所了解，在新纪元的著作中，我从未遇到过任何我能理解的量子启发思想——他们只是随口说出一些听起来很花哨的词。要是量子力学真的那么简单就好了！

Since quantum mechanics is filled with phenomena that seem mystical, it has become all the rage in New Age circles. Unfortunately, disciples of New Age thinking seldom have any inkling of what quantum physics is actually about, and in New Age writings I have never once run into any quantum-inspired idea that I could make head or tail of—they just toss about fancy-sounding words. If only quantum mechanics were that simple!

这一切是否意味着我们永远无法真正准确、确定地描述现实？并非如此；我们绝对可以做到。并非所有对现实的描述都同样好；有些描述比其他描述更好。如果桌子上有三个苹果，那么说“桌子上有三个苹果”要比说“桌子上有四个苹果”或“桌子上有三个橘子”或“桌子底下有三个苹果”或“沙发上有三个苹果”等更准确。即使我们处理完全是我们自己发明的概念，我们也不能随便编造一堆随机陈述并认为它们都同样正确。

Does all this mean that we can never describe reality with genuine precision and certainty? Not at all; we can definitely do so. Not all descriptions of reality are equally good; some are better than others. If there are three apples on the table, then it’s more accurate to say “there are three apples on the table” than to say “there are four apples on the table” or “there are three oranges on the table” or “there are three apples under the table” or “there are three apples on the sofa,” and so forth. Even when we are dealing with concepts that we have completely invented ourselves, we can’t just make up a bunch of random statements and think they are all equally true.

在科学中，我们总是可以通过进行实验来检验哪些关于世界的陈述更好。最准确地预测实验结果的模型或描述实际上是“最真实的”。

In science, we can always try to determine which statements about the world are better by carrying out experiments to test them. The models or descriptions that most accurately predict the experimental results are in practice the “truest.”

我们的现实模型也可以应用于构建技术——机器和工具。如果这些技术有效，那么它们就是有效的，无论其背后的理论性质如何。以蓝色 LED 灯的发明为例，该发明于 2014 年获得了诺贝尔物理学奖。得益于这项发明以及已经存在的红色和绿色 LED 灯，人们能够生产出白色LED 灯（红色 + 绿色 + 蓝色 = 白色）。这项技术上的成功并不意味着我们的光性质理论构成了对光的精确和完整的描述。但该理论足够精确，使我们能够生产出白色 LED 灯。有时，即使人们对产生这些应用的科学模型存在疑问，科学的应用也会非常出色。

Our models of reality can also be applied to construct technology—machines and tools. If those work, then they work, no matter what the nature of the theories behind them is. Take the invention of blue-colored LED lights, which was rewarded with the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2014. Thanks to this invention, along with already-existent red and green LED lights, people were able to produce white LED light (red + green + blue = white). This technological success didn’t mean that our theory of light’s nature constituted a precise and complete description of light. But the theory was accurate enough to allow us to produce white LED lights. Sometimes science’s applications work beautifully, even when there are lingering questions about the scientific models that give rise to them.

绝对真理与相对真理

Truth as Absolute, Truth as Relative

这种态度通常被称为批判现实主义，即认为存在一种真实的现实，我们可以越来越多地了解其本质，但可能永远无法完全了解。然而，在过去的几十年里，出现了一种完全不同的关于真理的观点，并在某些学术界非常流行。这就是真理是一个相对概念的想法。这是什么意思呢？

The attitude that there is a true reality whose nature we can learn more and more about, but probably will never reach in full, is usually called critical realism. In the last few decades, however, a completely different viewpoint about truth has arisen and become very popular in some academic circles. This is the idea that truth is a relative notion. What does that mean?

好吧，就拿这句常见的话来说：“对我来说是正确的，对你来说不一定是正确的。”这句话表明，没有任何客观的描述或真理，一切都取决于考虑情况的人。也就是说，一个人对现实的看法与世界实际情况没有任何关系；它们只是表达个人想法、社会关系、意识形态和各种权力的载体。

Well, take this common utterance: “What’s true for me doesn’t have to be true for you.” It suggests that there aren’t any objective descriptions or truths, but that everything depends on the person who’s considering the situation. That is, a person’s claims about reality don’t have anything to do with how the world actually is; they are merely vehicles for phrasing one’s personal thoughts, one’s social connections, one’s ideologies, and the various powers that one wields.

这种激进的真理观可以追溯到一种哲学观念，在某种程度上，这种观念与真理的符合论截然相反。这种观念被称为真理的连贯论，奇怪的是，它起源于逻辑和数学。这种理论认为，只要一个陈述与其他陈述的系统兼容，并且它们都处理同一框架中的概念，并且相互兼容，那么它在某个框架中就是真实的。换句话说，只要框架具有内部的 一致性——属于它的陈述不需要与外部世界一致。

This radical view of truth can be traced back to a philosophical notion that in a way is the diametric opposite to the correspondence theory of truth. It is called the coherence theory of truth, and oddly enough, it originated in logic and mathematics. This theory maintains that a statement is true in a certain framework as long as it is compatible with a system of other statements, all of which deal with notions in that same framework, and are mutually compatible. In other words, statements belonging to a given framework can be called “true” as long as the framework has internal consistency—there’s no need for the statements belonging to it to agree with the external world.

让我用非常个人的方式来说明这一点。我永远不会忘记，当我还是个孩子的时候，当我了解到二进制数是基于二进制而不是十进制时，我有多么兴奋。例如，我了解到“1111”代表十五，因为它是 1•2 3 + 1•2 2 + 1•2 1 + 1•2 0或 8 + 4 + 2 + 1 的简写。同样，“1001”代表九，因为它是 1•2 3 + 0•2 2 + 0•2 1 + 1•2 0或 8 + 1 的简写。我学会了如何用二进制加法和乘法。例如，我发现 10 × 10 = 100。现在你可能会觉得我的这个发现很无趣，因为你已经知道了！十乘以十等于一百！但这不是这个等式在二进制中的意思。用二进制表示，即二乘以二等于四（即 [2 1 + 0•2 0 ] × [2 1 + 0•2 0 ] = 2 2 + 0•2 1 + 0•2 0）。

Let me illustrate this in a very personal way. I will never forget how deeply excited I was when, as a youngster, I learned about binary numbers, built on base two rather than on base ten. I learned, for instance, that “1111” stands for fifteen, as it is shorthand for 1•23 + 1•22 + 1•21 + 1•20, or 8 + 4 + 2 + 1. Likewise, “1001” stands for nine, as it is shorthand for 1•23 + 0•22 + 0•21 + 1•20, or 8 + 1. I learned how to add numbers in binary, and how to multiply them. Thus I discovered, for instance, that 10 × 10 = 100. Now you may find this discovery of mine rather uninteresting, since you already knew it! Ten times ten equals one hundred! But that’s not what this equation means, in binary. In binary, it means two times two equals four (that is, [21 + 0•20] × [21 + 0•20] = 22 + 0•21 + 0•20).

两个英文句子都是真的，但在表达这两个句子的符号串“10 × 10 = 100”中，一次使用二进制，一次使用十进制，有些符号代表不同的东西。无论选择哪种方式都可以，只要你保持自洽。二进制是一个系统；十进制是另一个系统。它们每个都是内部一致的。

Both English sentences are true, but in the string of symbols “10 × 10 = 100,” which expresses both sentences, once using binary and once using decimal notation, some of the symbols stand for different things. Either choice is fine, so long as you remain self-consistent. Binary is one system; decimal is another system. Each one of them is internally consistent.

然后我还了解到，虽然“10 + 10 = 100”这个等式在二进制中是正确的，但在十进制中却是错误的。当然，在二进制中，它的意思是“二加二等于四”，而在十进制中，它的意思是“十加十等于一百”。这两个说法中，第一个说法再正确不过了，而第二个说法再错误不过了！

And then I also learned that the equation “10 + 10 = 100” is true in binary, although it is false in decimal notation. In binary, of course, it means “two plus two equals four,” whereas in decimal notation, it means “ten plus ten equals one hundred.” The first of these two claims couldn’t be truer, while the second of them couldn’t be falser!

对于我这个孩子来说，这一切都令人大开眼界。它以前所未有的清晰方式向我展示了符号如何与思想相对应，以及这种联系虽然随意，但可以系统地扩展，从而可以有完全独立的思想集，用相同的符号来表达，但指代不同的事物。这令人非常兴奋和自由！

For me, as a kid, all this was amazingly eye-opening. It showed me, in a far clearer way than ever before, how symbols correspond to ideas, and how the connection, though arbitrary, can be extended systematically so that there can be totally independent sets of ideas expressed using the same symbols but referring to different things. This was deeply exciting and liberating!

真理的连贯性理论最早出现于 1830 年左右，当时非欧几里得几何被发现。非欧几里得几何的一条公理是对具有两千年历史的欧几里得几何公理的否定。这条公理通常被称为欧几里得的“平行公理”，其内容如下：“给定一条直线l和不在l上的点P，存在且仅存在一条通过P点与 l 平行的直线。 ”这个陈述在欧几里得几何框架中是正确的，但在非欧几里得几何框架中却是错误的。因此，直白地说，在一个系统中为真的陈述在另一个系统中就是错误的，反之亦然。这听起来很像作为相对概念的真理！

The coherence theory of truth first arose around 1830, when non- Euclidean geometry was discovered. One of this geometry’s axioms was the negation of an axiom in the two-thousand-year-old Euclidean geometry. This axiom, often called Euclid’s “parallel axiom,” ran as follows: “Given a line l and a point P not on l, there exists one and only one line through P that is parallel to l.” This statement was true in the framework known as Euclidean geometry, but it was false in the framework known as non-Euclidean geometry. Thus, to put it bluntly, a statement that was true in one system was false in the other, and vice versa. This sounds very much like truth as a relative notion!

嗯，是的，但不要这么急。。。事实证明，平行公理（及其否定）中使用的术语“线”在两个不同的世界中指的并不是同一个概念，因此，同一陈述对某些人而言是正确的，而对其他人而言是错误的，这并不是真的。例如，两条欧几里得平行线之间的距离总是相同的，而两条非欧几里得平行线之间的距离会有所不同。简而言之，欧几里得线和非欧几里得线是截然不同的两类，这就是为什么比较这两种几何学如此令人着迷的原因。这意味着，存在于这两种几何学中的术语“线”指的并不是同一个概念。在非欧几里得世界中，不存在任何欧几里得线，而在欧几里得世界中，也不存在任何非欧几里得线！

Well, yes, but not so fast. . . . It turned out that the term “line,” which was used in the parallel axiom (and its negation), didn’t refer to the same notion in the two different worlds, so it wasn’t really the case that the same statement was true for some folks and false for others. For instance, two Euclidean parallel lines are always at the same distance from each other, whereas the distance between two non-Euclidean parallel lines varies. In short, Euclidean lines and non-Euclidean lines are horses of very different colors, which is why the two geometries are so fascinating to compare. And this means that the term “line,” which exists in both geometries, isn’t referring to the same concept. In a non-Euclidean world, there don’t exist any Euclidean lines, and in a Euclidean world, there don’t exist any non-Euclidean lines!

所有这些并不比“10 + 10 = 100”这个等式在二进制中为真而在十进制中为假更令人困惑。同样，句子“芝加哥在东边”对某些人来说可能是正确的，对另一些人来说可能是错误的。原因很简单：当旧金山人说出“这里”这个词时，它指的并不是波士顿人所说的同一个地方，就像二进制中的“10”和十进制中的“10”指的并不是同一个数字一样。

All this is no more confusing than the fact that the equation “10 + 10 = 100” can be true in binary while also being false in decimal. Likewise, the sentence “Chicago is east of here” can be true for some people and false for others. The reason is quite simple: the word “here,” when uttered by a San Franciscan, doesn’t refer to the same place as when it is uttered by a Bostonian, just as “10” in binary doesn’t refer to the same number as “10” in decimal.

由于非欧几里得几何的发现（以及后来发现的其他奇异几何），数学家和逻辑学家逐渐习惯了这样一种观点：看似相同的表达式在不同的概念宇宙中可能具有不同的含义。这并不意味着这些思想家认为真理是相对的；而是意味着他们明白某些术语的含义可能会根据上下文而变化。因此，一个陈述在一个公理系统中可能为真，而在另一个公理系统中为假——但这两个陈述谈论的并不是同一件事。这种情况表面上类似于真理相对主义，但这并不是真理变成依赖于观察者的模糊概念的情况。事实上，真理仍然是数学中一个核心而固定的概念。

Thanks to the discovery of non-Euclidean geometry (and later on, of other exotic geometries), mathematicians and logicians grew accustomed to the idea that expressions that looked identical could mean different things in different conceptual universes. This didn’t mean that these thinkers thought that truth was relative; it meant that they understood that the meaning of some terms could shift according to context. A statement could thus be true in one axiomatic system and false in another—but the two statements weren’t talking about the same things. This was a situation that superficially resembled truth-relativism, but it was not a situation where truth became a slippery notion that depended on the observer. Indeed, truth remained a central and fixed notion in mathematics.

顺便说一句，各种“竞争”几何的发现表明，各种内部自洽的数学系统都可以存在，而不必与物理宇宙相对应。然后出现了一个问题，即哪种“竞争”几何适用于现实世界。最终我们了解到，我们所居住的广阔宇宙是用非欧几里得几何描述的，尽管在实际的尺度上，我们可以将我们的世界视为欧几里得几何。

By the way, the discovery of diverse “rival” geometries showed that all sorts of internally self-consistent mathematical systems can exist that don’t have to correspond to the physical universe. The question then arose as to which of the “rival” geometries applied to the actual world. Eventually we learned that the vast cosmos we inhabit is described by a non-Euclidean geometry, although on a down-to-earth practical scale, we can treat our world as Euclidean.

当数学家们能够构建出看似有“不同真理”的竞争系统时，他们会很高兴；然而，他们明白，这并不使真理相对化。他们明白，这一切意味着，尽管对立理论中对应的实体具有相同的名称，但它们并不是同一事物。

Mathematicians are delighted when they can construct rival systems that appear to have “different truths”; however, they understand that this doesn’t make truth relative. They understand that all this means is that corresponding entities in the rival theories, though called by the same name, are not the same things.

尽管真理的连贯理论可以帮助数学家理解彼此封闭的“竞争”公理系统，但它并不适用于数学以外的领域——而数学家们在几个世纪前努力学习并最终吸收的关于真理和一致性的微妙教训不应该被随意地误用到整个世界，因为世界不是一个公理系统，更不用说竞争公理系统的集合了。

The coherence theory of truth, though it helps mathematicians understand “rival” axiomatic systems that are sealed off from one another, is not applicable to areas outside of mathematics—and the subtle lessons about truth and consistency that mathematicians struggled with and finally absorbed a couple of centuries ago should not be nonchalantly misapplied to the world at large, for the world is not an axiomatic system, let alone a collection of rival axiomatic systems.

否认真理是客观的，不仅幼稚和错误，更糟糕的是，这在道德上是有问题的。在政治上，这变得非常严重：当一个人相信任何符合他个人目标的东西时，他就会相信任何他想要相信的东西，而不是相信理智和理性引导他相信的东西。

To deny that truth is objective is not only naïve and wrong, but worse yet, it is morally problematic. In politics, it becomes very serious: one believes whatever one wishes when it agrees with one’s personal goals, instead of believing what sense and reason would lead one to believe.

如果你认为森林里有巨魔，而我不相信有，那么我们其中一个人就是对的，另一个人就是错的。即便我们无法弄清楚我们中谁是对的（不做大量调查的话），我们也希望我们都同意我们中只有一个人是对的。你可能会争辩说，森林里潜伏着巨魔的想法对于你的文化中有着悠久传统的连贯世界观（或“宇宙观”）至关重要，因此它一定是正确的。但这将是个荒谬而空洞的论点。假设有人打了你一巴掌，然后对你说：“在我的现实中没有打你一巴掌，所以这无所谓。”你会接受这种奇怪的真理相对主义吗？

If you think there are trolls out there in the woods, and I don’t believe there are any, then one of us is simply right, and the other is simply wrong. Even if we can’t figure out which of us is right (without doing a lot of investigation), hopefully we agree that only one of us can be right. You might argue that your idea of trolls lurking in the woods is central to a coherent worldview (or “cosmology”) that has a long tradition in your culture and that it therefore must be true. But that would be an absurd and hollow argument. Suppose someone slapped you in the face and then said to you, “No slap of your face occurred in my reality, so it doesn’t matter.” Would you accept such a weird relativism of truth?

如果人们接受真理相对论，那么赫尔曼·戈林在纽伦堡审判中就可以通过辩称他的现实与法官的现实不同而被判无罪。如果法庭允许这种观点，那么任何人都不会被判有罪。任何旧的说法都必须按字面意思来理解，因为没有哪句话比其他说法更正确或更真实。

If people were to accept the relativism of truth, then Hermann Göring could have been found innocent in the Nuremberg Trials by arguing that his reality was different from the judge’s reality. If this kind of viewpoint were allowed in courts, then no one could ever be found guilty of any crime at all. Any old statement would have to be taken at face value, since no statement would be any righter or truer than any other one.

真理相对主义者的观点——“一切都同样正确”——很容易导致社会变得和全世界的宗教原教旨主义社会一样不道德，他们对真理的看法十分自信和封闭，严密无懈可击，他们的成员常常不介意杀死那些不同意他们观点的人。

The viewpoint of truth-relativists—that “everything is equally correct”—could easily lead to a society just as immoral as the societies of religious fundamentalists throughout the world, who have cocksure and totally closed viewpoints, airtight and waterproof, about what truth is, and too often, their members don’t mind killing people who don’t agree with them.

奇怪的是，真理相对主义也是一种自我挫败的观念。如果它的思想真的有效，那么“所有真理都是相对的”这一主张本身只会对喜欢它的人是正确的，而对不喜欢它的人则是错误的。也就是说显然是荒谬的。简而言之，真理相对主义是一种自相矛盾的哲学，经过研究就会发现它已经土崩瓦解。

Curiously, truth-relativism is also a self-defeating notion. If its ideas really were valid, then the claim “All truths are relative” would itself be true only for those people who liked it, and false for people who didn’t. That is surely absurd. In short, truth-relativism is a self-contradictory philosophy, which, upon investigation, falls to pieces.

有一些语言现象表面上与真理相对主义相似，比如前面提到的情况，“芝加哥位于这里的东边。”一个句子可以是真也可以是假，这取决于说这句话的人。如果瑞典国王说“我住在斯德哥尔摩”，他说的是真话，但如果住在密歇根州安娜堡的艾丽丝·阿普尔特里说“我住在斯德哥尔摩”，她就是在说假话。同一句话既是真话又是假话！显然，这并不能证明真理相对主义是有效的。尽管这两个人使用了相同的词组，但他们只是在提出不同的主张。当瑞典国王说“我”时，他指的是一个人，而艾丽丝·阿普尔特里说“我”时，指的是另一个人。

There are linguistic phenomena that on the surface resemble truth-relativism, such as the case mentioned earlier, “Chicago is east of here.” A sentence can be true or false, depending on who says it. If the king of Sweden says, “I live in Stockholm,” he is telling the truth, but if Alice Appletree, who lives in Ann Arbor, Michigan, says “I live in Stockholm,” she is uttering a falsity. The very same statement is both true and false! Well, obviously this doesn’t show that truth-relativism is valid. The two people are simply making different claims, despite using the same sets of words. When the Swedish king says “I,” he is talking about one person, while Alice Appletree, when she says “I,” is talking about someone else.

或者如果我说“花在钢琴的右边”，如果我正坐在钢琴前准备弹奏，这句话可能是正确的，但如果我在钢琴凳上转身，面朝另一个方向，那么这句话就变成了错误的。短语“右边”取决于一个尚未指定的参考框架，因此这个陈述充满了歧义。但是一旦参考框架被指定，这个陈述就失去了歧义，要么是真的，要么是假的。

Or if I say, “The flowers are to the right of the piano,” this can be true if I’m sitting facing the keyboard, ready to play, but if I spin around on the piano bench so that I’m facing the other way, then it becomes false. The phrase “to the right of” depends on a frame of reference that hasn’t been specified, so the statement is imbued with ambiguity. But once the frame of reference has been specified, then the statement loses its ambiguity and becomes either true or false.

运动和速度也是相对的。我们都熟悉这一点，比如坐在车站里一列静止的火车上，透过车窗看着旁边的火车。突然间，另一列火车开始移动。或者是我的火车刚刚开始移动？这很难说！物体的速度总是相对于某个固定的框架（即参考系）给出——光除外，无论观察者处于哪个参考系，光相对于任何观察者的速度总是完全相同的。这个非常违反直觉的想法是阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦（1879-1955）于 1905 年提出的（狭义）相对论的核心。

Movement and speed are also relative. We all are familiar with this from sitting in a train sitting still in a station and looking out the window at the train that is right next to ours. All at once the other train starts to move. Or is it my train that just started to move? It can be hard to tell! The speed of an object always has to be given relative to some fixed framework (i.e., frame of reference)—except for the case of light, which always moves at exactly the same speed relative to any observer, no matter what frame of reference the observer is in. This highly counterintuitive idea is the crux of (special) relativity, developed by Albert Einstein (1879–1955) in 1905.

爱因斯坦出生于德国乌尔姆，后来成为瑞士人，然后成为美国人。他的相对论是对伽利略·伽利莱（1564-1642）最初提出的更早的“相对论原理”的概括，该原理声称物理学中的所有参考系都同样好（意味着物理定律在所有参考系中都同样成立）。实际上，伽利略的原理仅限于所谓的“惯性”参考系，即相对于彼此以恒定速度移动的参考系，以及机械实验（力学是伽利略时代唯一已知的物理学分支）。然而，爱因斯坦推测伽利略的原理可以从机械现象扩展到电磁现象 现象（特别是光）。这个看似微小的思想进步导致了 20 世纪初物理学的巨大革命。

Einstein was born in Ulm, Germany, and later he became Swiss and then American. His theory of relativity was a generalization of a far earlier “principle of relativity” originally posited by Galileo Galilei (1564–1642), which claimed that all frames of reference in physics are equally good (meaning that the laws of physics hold equally in all of them). Actually, Galileo’s principle was limited to so-called “inertial” frames of reference, meaning frames moving at constant speeds with respect to each other, and to mechanical experiments (mechanics being the only branch of physics that was known in Galileo’s day). Einstein, however, conjectured that Galileo’s principle could be extended from mechanical phenomena to electromagnetic phenomena (meaning light in particular). This seemingly tiny mental step led to a gigantic revolution in physics early in the twentieth century.

几年后，爱因斯坦进一步推广了伽利略经典原理，使之在所有参考系中都成立，无论它们如何运动，这种超级推广被恰当地称为“广义相对论”，而早期的“相对论”则被重新命名为“狭义相对论”。据说，爱因斯坦在乘坐火车时喜欢​​拿相对论开玩笑，问列车长：“对不起，芝加哥在这列火车上停吗？”

A few years later, Einstein further generalized his generalization of Galileo’s classic principle so that it would hold in all frames of reference, no matter how they were moving, and this super-generalization was called, appropriately enough, “general relativity,” and the earlier “theory of relativity” was rebaptized as the “theory of special relativity.” It is said that Einstein enjoyed joking about relativity theory when he was riding in a train, by asking the conductor, “Excuse me, but does Chicago stop at this train?”

近年来，真理相对主义在学术界最重要的倡导者之一是美国哲学家理查德·罗蒂（1931-2007）。5罗蒂认为，一切真理观念都植根于我们对现实作出的基本公理，以及我们在思考和体验世界时所选择的方法。

In recent years, one of truth-relativism’s foremost advocates in the academic world was the American philosopher Richard Rorty (1931–2007).5 Rorty thought that all notions of truth are grounded in the basic axioms that we make about reality, and in the methods that we choose when we consider the world and experience it.

一个典型的例子是 1615 年伽利略被指控为异端。他发表了与天主教教义不相容的天文学成果，天主教教义主张太阳围绕地球旋转。红衣主教罗伯特·贝拉明是梵蒂冈在审判中的代表。伽利略邀请红衣主教通过他的望远镜（他自己制造的）观察天空，以核实他的主张。然而，贝拉明拒绝通过望远镜观察，他说他在《圣经》中找到的论据比任何科学仪器所能提供的论据都要好。6伽利略选择了客观观察的方法，而贝拉明选择了圣经提供的福音。

A classic example is when Galileo was accused of heresy in 1615. He had published astronomical results that were incompatible with the teachings of the Catholic Church, which asserted that the sun rotated around the earth. Cardinal Robert Bellarmine was the Vatican’s representative in the trial. Galileo invited the cardinal to check out his claims, by looking out at the heavens through his telescope (which he himself had made). Bellarmine, however, declined to peer through the tube, saying that he could find better arguments in the Bible than anything that could be provided by any scientific instrument.6 Galileo chose the methods of objective observation, while Bellarmine chose the gospels offered by holy scripture.

那么：是地球绕着太阳转，还是太阳绕着地球转？根据真理相对论者理查德·罗蒂的说法，这完全取决于你选择如何将自己与现实联系起来。他认为，没有事实可言，也没有客观的方法来说明这两个天体中哪一个绕着另一个转。

And so: Does the earth rotate around the sun, or does the sun rotate around the earth? According to truth-relativist Richard Rorty, it all depends on how you choose to relate yourself to reality. He believed that there is no fact of the matter, no objective way to say which of the two celestial bodies rotates around the other.

另一位激进的真理相对主义者是 1947 年出生的法国哲学家布鲁诺·拉图尔，他认为物体只有在被注意到时才存在。7他举了细菌的例子，声称细菌在发现者发现之前并不存在。

Another radical truth-relativist is the French philosopher Bruno Latour, born in 1947, who believes that objects do not exist until they are noticed.7 He offers the example of bacteria, claiming that they didn’t exist before their discoverers found them.

罗蒂和拉图尔都犯了一个错误，那就是混淆了现象的描述和现象本身。当然，在细菌被发现之前，人们不可能谈论细菌及其特性。还有其他关于人们死于疾病的理论。但这并不意味着细菌是在人类意识到它们的时候才开始存在的。8

The mistake Rorty and Latour both make is to confuse the description of a phenomenon with the phenomenon itself. Of course people couldn’t talk about bacteria and their properties before they were discovered. There were other theories of why people died of sicknesses. But this doesn’t mean that bacteria only began to exist at the moment that we humans became aware of them.8

客观现实是存在的，包括原子，尽管科学模型总是临时的，可能会被修改，因此不是“完美无缺和永恒”的绝对意义上的“真实”。科学家不是教条主义者，而是愿意接受新证据。（顺便说一句，科学家拒绝宣称他们已经达到了绝对和最终的真理，即使有大量证据支持一套想法，这种诚实的态度也表明了科学态度的深刻谦逊。）但最极端的真理相对主义者走得更远，完全否认“真理”的概念，以及现实的存在。不幸的是，这种立场往往伴随着对科学的深深无知，甚至对科学的蔑视。

An objective reality exists, which includes atoms, even though science’s models are always provisional and subject to revision, thus not “true” in the absolute sense of “perfectly flawless and everlasting.” Scientists are not dogmatists but are open to new evidence. (Incidentally, this intellectually honest refusal, on the part of scientists, to declare that they have reached the absolute and final truth, even when there is enormous evidence for a set of ideas, demonstrates the profound humility of the scientific attitude.) But the most extreme of truth-relativists go even further, flat-out denying the very concept of “truth,” as well as the existence of reality. Unfortunately this stance is often accompanied by deep scientific ignorance and even contempt for science.

真理的概念不能相对化。另一方面，我们有理由相信，政治和经济权力等各种因素会影响我们在社会学和其他社会科学等学科中的优先事项和想法，也许还会影响自然科学中的一些想法。特别是，这些问题会对政府和其他资助机构将资助哪些类型的研究产生巨大影响。但这并不意味着真理的概念本身就不可靠。如果一种理论有效，那么它就独立于可能导致人们相信它的因素。

The notion of truth cannot be relativized. On the other hand, it’s quite reasonable to believe that various factors, such as political and economic power, affect our priorities and our ideas in such disciplines as sociology and other social sciences, and perhaps also some ideas in the natural sciences. In particular, such matters can have huge effects on what types of research will be financed by governments and other funding agencies. But this doesn’t allow one to conclude that the very concept of truth is unreliable. If a theory works, then it does so independently of the factors that might lead people to believe in it.

社会建构

Social Constructions

社会建构主义理论虽然因多种原因而备受质疑，但它却植根于一个非常合理的前提，即人们的生活条件会影响他们对周围世界的看法，特别是他们对研究和科学分析的看法。种族、性别、阶级和政治意识形态等因素会影响社会进行何种类型的研究以及哪些结果被视为重要。

The theory of social constructivism, though highly dubious for many reasons, is nonetheless rooted in a very reasonable premise—namely, that the conditions in which people live have effects on the perspectives they adopt about the world around them and, in particular, their perspectives about research and scientific analysis. Factors such as race, gender, class, and political ideology exert influences on what type of research is pursued by a society and what results are taken as important.

这种影响的一个典型例子是苏联遗传学家特罗菲姆·李先科（1898-1976）。他在 20 世纪 30 年代批评了达尔文的进化论，并提出了另一种带有意识形态色彩的物种起源理论。他声称，遗传不是由基因或染色体决定的，而是可以通过环境因素改变的。他的理论大多是错误的，但它们是新颖的，并且他们在意识形态上与马列主义一致，因此向斯大林求助。相比之下，西方接受的科学理论孟德尔遗传学则被贴上了“资产阶级伪科学”的标签。9

A classic example of this effect is the Soviet geneticist Trofim Lysenko (1898–1976), who, during the 1930s, criticized Darwin’s theory of evolution and launched an alternative, and ideologically colored, theory of the origin of species. He claimed, among other things, that heredity is not determined by genes or chromosomes, but can be modified by environmental factors. His theories were mostly erroneous, but they were novel and were ideologically aligned with Marxism-Leninism, and thus they appealed to Stalin. By contrast, Mendelian genetics, the scientific theory accepted in the West, was labeled “bourgeois pseudoscience.”9

社会建构主义受到法国哲学家米歇尔·福柯（1926-1984）等思想家的启发，该主义认为，科学对知识的探索并非表面看起来的那样；事实上，福柯认为科学是一种邪恶的工具，其设计目的明确是为了帮助白人、异性恋、资产阶级、中年和经济富裕的男性边缘化穷人、妇女、同性恋者、少数民族以及整个非欧洲文化。

Social constructivism, inspired by such thinkers as French philosopher Michel Foucault (1926–1984), claims that the scientific quest for knowledge is not what it seems to be; indeed, Foucault saw science as an evil tool designed expressly to help white, heterosexual, bourgeois, middle-aged, and economically well-off males to marginalize poor people, women, homosexuals, ethnic minorities, and non-European cultures in general.

不幸的是，历史表明，科学有时就是这样被利用的。在 19 世纪和 20 世纪的相当长一段时间里，生物学和人类学被用来为种族压迫辩护。此外，医学科学被用来为将表现出异常行为的人关起来并进行脑白质切除术辩护。（脑白质切除术是一种脑外科手术，由葡萄牙神经学家安东尼奥·埃加斯·莫尼兹 (António Egas Moniz，1874-1955) 于 20 世纪 30 年代发明。它涉及切断连接额叶和大脑其他部分的神经通路。其背后的想法是治疗患有严重焦虑症或精神病行为的患者，使他们更加平静；然而，该手术也摧毁了患者人格和情感生活的重要部分，现在不再使用这种手术了。）被认为偏离社会道德规范的女性被迫接受绝育手术。这些例子表明，科学和“社会工程学”在我们的历史上是如何被滥用的，它们常常被用来支持压迫和将人们分成不同的阶级，并且总是按照当前统治当局的意愿行事。

History shows, unfortunately, that science has at times been exploited in just this way. During the nineteenth century and for quite a while during the twentieth, biology and anthropology were used in order to justify racist oppression. Also, medical science was used to justify the locking-up of, and the performing of lobotomies on, individuals exhibiting deviant forms of behavior. (Lobotomy is a surgical operation on the brain, introduced in the 1930s by Portuguese neurologist António Egas Moniz (1874–1955). It involves cutting the nerve pathways that link the frontal lobes to the rest of the brain. The idea behind it was to treat patients who had grave anxiety problems or psychotic behavior, to make them calmer; however, the procedure also destroyed important parts of the patient’s personality and emotional life, and it is no longer used anywhere.) Women who were perceived as deviating from society’s moral norms were forced to undergo sterilization. Such examples show how science and “social engineering” have been misused in our history, and how they are often cited as support for the oppression and the separation of people into different classes, always following the whims of the currently reigning authorities.

社会建构主义分析在很多情况下都是有益且合理的。当我们试图理解我们生活的环境时，洞察社会建构非常重要。这类理论在这方面大有裨益。事实上，我们一直被社会建构所包围：例如，当我们在杂货店使用硬币时，我们就是在利用社会建构。毕竟，硬币只是一小块冲压的金属，其价值和作为日常交易工具的功能不是物品本身固有的，而只是由我们的社会建构而成。

Social-constructivist analysis can be helpful and justifiable in many cases. Insight into social constructions is important when we are trying to understand the context in which we live. Here such theories have much to contribute. We are in fact surrounded by social constructions all the time: for instance, when we use coins in a grocery store, we are using a social construction. After all, a coin is just a little stamped piece of metal, whose worth and function as a tool in everyday transactions is not intrinsic to the object but is merely constructed by our society.

然而，把所有现实都看作是社会建构是有问题的。传统的“男性气质”和“女性气质”社会建构就是一个明显的例子。自古以来，女性就与感情联系在一起，而男性则与理性和智慧联系在一起。这些古老的社会建构至今仍被广泛接受，但它们不仅是错误的，而且极大地限制了个人的潜力和机会。

To take all of reality as a mere social construct is problematic, however. The traditional social constructs of “masculinity” and “femininity” provide a clear example. Since time immemorial, women have been associated with feelings, and men with reason and intellect. These ancient social constructs are still largely accepted today, but they not only are false but also extremely limiting for the potential and the chances of an individual person.

其他有害的社会观念包括有关性取向、性关系和家庭性质的规范，以及关于消费主义、成功和地位的无数假设。10

Other harmful social constructs are norms concerning sexual orientations, sexual relationships, and the nature of the family, as well as myriad assumptions about consumerism, success, and status.10

后现代主义与教育

Postmodernism and Education

社会建构主义和真理相对主义通常被认为属于被称为后现代主义的思想潮流。11 “社会建构”这一短语只是当代社会学术语体系的一部分，该术语属于后现代主义综合症，其中还包括文化相对主义和密切相关的价值相对主义概念。

Social constructivism and truth-relativism are usually considered to belong to the overarching trend of ideas called postmodernism.11 The phrase “socially constructed” is but one part of a system of contemporary sociological jargon that belongs to a postmodernist syndrome that also includes cultural relativism and the closely associated notion of value-relativism.

后现代主义引发了深刻的认识论、道德和政治问题。后现代主义最极端的版本声称自然科学只是一种社会建构——一个随机的“故事”，并不比任何人随意编造和传播的随机故事更有说服力。

Postmodernism gives rise to deep epistemological, moral, and political problems. The most extreme versions of postmodernism claim that the natural sciences are just a social construction—a random “tale” no more valid than any other random tale that anyone might choose to make up out of whole cloth and to propagate.

1996 年，美国物理学家艾伦·索卡尔（1955-）以后现代主义的有力批评者的身份加入到这场争论中。他欺骗了流行学术期刊《社会文本》的编辑，让他们发表了一篇他写的完全荒谬的文章。他向期刊投稿时，表面上是一篇社会建构主义文章，批评将爱因斯坦的广义相对论与量子力学结合起来的尝试。他这篇讽刺性文章的标题非常晦涩难懂，叫做《超越界限：迈向量子引力的变革性解释学》，是对“解构主义”写作风格的荒谬嘲讽。在这篇文章中，索卡尔扮演了一个傲慢的知识分子形象，用大量标准的后现代主义术语，巧妙地攻击了“所谓的科学方法”。

In 1996, American physicist Alan Sokal (1955– ) jumped into the fray as a powerful critic of postmodernism when he tricked the editors of the trendy academic journal Social Text into publishing a completely nonsensical article he had written, which he submitted to the journal ostensibly as a social-constructivist criticism of attempts to combine Einstein’s theory of general relativity with quantum mechanics. His sarcastic article, with the wonderfully obscure title “Transgressing the Boundaries: Towards a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravity,” was an absurd spoof of the “deconstructionist” style of writing. In it, Sokal donned a haughty intellectual persona who virtuosically attacked “the so-called scientific method,” using rafts of standard postmodernist jargon terms.

例如，索卡尔的后现代主义形象写道，“外部世界的特性独立于任何个人”的概念仅仅是“启蒙运动后长期霸权强加于西方知识界的教条”。这个真理相对主义者的形象继续坚持认为，科学研究“不能相对于来自异见或边缘化社区的反霸权叙事主张特权的认识论地位”。（简而言之，科学没有对真理的有效主张；任何人都有自己的真理。）索卡尔不断地滔滔不绝地讲着行话，用伪科学的论据留下甚至借用了相信超感官知觉和其他超自然现象的新纪元思想，都是为了制造出一种对男性的强烈攻击的假象，攻击杂志编辑们所谓的“男性中心科学”。正如索卡尔所希望的那样，编辑们完全被他的骗局所蒙骗。12

Thus, for instance, Sokal’s postmodernist persona wrote that the concept of “an external world whose properties are independent of any individual human being” was merely “dogma imposed by the long post-Enlightenment hegemony over the Western intellectual outlook.” This truth-relativist persona went on to insist that scientific research “cannot assert a privileged epistemological status with respect to counterhegemonic narratives emanating from dissident or marginalized communities.” (In simpler words, science has no valid claim to truth; any person has their own truths.) On and on he went, did Sokal, spewing jargon and using pseudoscientific arguments left and right, even borrowing New Age ideas from believers in ESP and other paranormal phenomena, all in order to give the appearance of making an ardently male-bashing attack on what the journal’s editors would have called “phallocentric science.” And just as Sokal had hoped, the editors fell for his hoax—lock, stock, and barrel.12

另一个后现代主义胡言乱语的典型例子来自我的祖国瑞典。几年前，我参加了一场关于学校的辩论，一位教育学教授参加了小组讨论。这位教授声称，科学的进化论和圣经的创世记述只是关于人类故事的两个不同的“故事”或范式。他们没有讨论其中哪一个比另一个“更真实”。在我看来，这种立场在智力上是不诚实的。如果一切都只是意见问题，那么辩论任何事情还有什么意义呢？

Another fine example of postmodernist nonsense is furnished by my own land of Sweden. A few years ago, I participated in a debate about schools, in which an education professor was part of a panel discussion. The professor claimed that the scientific theory of evolution and the biblical account of creation are simply two different “tales,” or paradigms, about the story of humanity. There was no discussion about whether one of them was “truer” than the other. To my mind, such a stance is intellectually dishonest. If everything is just a matter of opinion, then what sense does it make to debate about anything?

这种态度的另一个典型例子来自瑞典教育学教授莫伊拉·冯·赖特。1998 年，她为瑞典教育部撰写了一份关于学校物理教学的报告。在报告中，她声称物理课程中的“科学内容”应该“为了平等”而修改，她用以下措辞拒绝科学思维过程：

Another prime example of such an attitude came from Swedish education professor Moira von Wright. In 1998, she wrote a report for the Swedish Ministry of Education about physics teaching in schools. In it, she claimed that the “scientific content” in physics courses should be modified “for the sake of equality,” and in the following terms she rejects the process of scientific thinking:

科学思维优越性的观念与平等和民主的理想是不相容的。……在科学界，某些思维和推理方式比其他方式更受重视。……如果人们没有注意到这一点，就有可能得出误导性的结论——例如，盲目地从科学思维更理性的观点跳到科学思维应该取代日常思维的观点。13

The notion of the superiority of scientific thinking is incompatible with the ideals of equality and democracy. . . . In the scientific community, some ways of thinking and reasoning are rewarded more than others. . . . If one fails to notice this, one runs the risk of drawing misleading conclusions—for example, mindlessly jumping from the idea that scientific thought is more rational to the idea that it should replace everyday thinking.13

在同一报告的后面，冯赖特写道：

Later in the same report, von Wright writes:

物理学教科书认为向学生传达机械和确定性的世界图景至关重要，并强调其优越性，这对平等意味着什么？强加这种具有固定解释的狭隘知识与我们学校的平等目标是不相容的——然而，这正是大多数物理学教科书所做的，从而有助于维持科学世界中男性和女性之间不对称和等级制的关系。当物理学被不加批判地提出为唯一真理时，它就采取了科学主义的立场，从而对学生的知识获取施加了（消极的）象征性力量。…… 14

具有性别意识和性别敏感度的物理学将涉及一种关于物理学的关系观点；此外，物理学中大量的标准科学内容必须被删除。15

What does it imply for equality that physics texts consider it crucial to convey to students a mechanical and deterministic picture of the world, and that they stress its superiority? To impose such narrow knowledge having a fixed interpretation is incompatible with our schools’ goal of equality—and yet, this is exactly what most physics texts do, thereby contributing to the maintenance of the asymmetrical and hierarchical relationship between the masculine and the feminine in the scientific world. When physics is uncritically put forth as the only truth, it takes on a scientistic stance and thus exercises a (negatively) symbolic power over students’ acquisition of knowledge. . . .14

A gender-conscious and gender-sensitive physics would involve a relational point of view about physics; moreover, a great deal of the standard scientific content of physics would have to be removed.15

冯赖特的报告结论如下：

The conclusion of von Wright’s report is as follows:

也许，首先，我们应该以一种新的方式问自己，如何让女孩对自然科学职业更感兴趣。例如，我们可以扭转局面，提出一个新颖的问题，而不是老生常谈的“我们如何才能让女孩对物理学更感兴趣”这个问题：我们如何才能让物理学对性别和女性视角更感兴趣？16

Perhaps, to start off, we should ask ourselves in a new way how to get girls to be more interested in careers in the natural sciences. For instance, in place of the old stock question about how we might try to interest girls more in physics, we could turn things around and pose the novel question: How can we get physics to be more interested in gender, and in the feminine perspective?16

冯赖特的报告态度不仅是反智的，也是反科学的。此外，它还认为女性的理性思考能力不如男性，这是对女性的傲慢。然而，从 2010 年到 2016 年，莫伊拉·冯赖特一直担任斯德哥尔摩索德托恩大学的校长。

The attitude of von Wright’s report is not just anti-intellectual but also anti-scientific. And in addition, it is condescending toward women to assume that they are less able than men to think in a rational manner. And yet, from 2010 through 2016, Moira von Wright served as president of Södertorn University in Stockholm.

相对主义与政治

Relativism and Politics

当真理相对论思维渗透到政治领域时，它就变得更加令人担忧。例如，假设统计研究表明瑞典女性的平均工资低于瑞典男性（事实确实如此）。然后想象一下瑞典议会中的一场辩论，一位政治家走上讲台说：“嗯，这项研究对你来说可能是正确的，但对我来说却不正确！我认为事实是女性比男性挣得多！”

Truth-relative thinking grows even more worrisome when it worms its way into politics. Suppose, for example, that statistical studies show that Swedish women have a lower average salary than Swedish men do (which is in fact the case). Then imagine a debate in the Swedish parliament in which a politician takes the podium and states: “Well, that study may be true for you, but it isn’t true for me! My truth is that women earn more than men do!”

任何不接受客观事实存在的政客都会有大麻烦。显然，在有关社会和政治的辩论中，真相往往很难揭晓，而政客们往往会选择他们想要揭露的现实的任何方面。他们会仔细选择关注什么，忽略什么，尤其是在进行涉及数字和统计数据的陈述时。如果主题足够复杂，那么几乎不可能确定所讨论的统计数据是否是“精心挑选的”，以支持特定的解释。

Any politician who doesn’t accept the idea that there are objective facts out there is in big trouble. Obviously it’s often hard to arrive at the truth in debates about society and politics, and politicians often choose whichever aspect of reality they want to bring out. They carefully choose what to focus on and what to ignore, especially when making presentations involving numbers and statistics. If the subject matter is sufficiently complex, it becomes almost impossible to decide if the statistic in question was or was not “cherry-picked” so as to lend support to a particular interpretation.

统计数据不会撒谎，就像许多人认为的那样（至少在它们没有被故意伪造的情况下），但人们可以精心选择信息片段，以强调现实的某一方面。这样，统计数据就可以用来操纵人们。政客和其他在社会中扮演重要角色的人也擅长将事实与事实混杂在一起。价值观。一些被呈现为纯粹事实的东西可能会潜移默化地传达出大量隐藏的意识形态。

Statistics do not lie, as many people believe (at least as long as they haven’t been intentionally falsified), but one can carefully select pieces of information in order to place stress on just one aspect of reality. In this way, statistics can be used to manipulate people. Politicians and other people with important roles in society are also skilled at presenting facts mixed in with values. Something that is presented as purely factual can subliminally convey a great deal of hidden ideology.

统计数据是描述现实的一种方式，但它无法说明复杂联系的运作方式——而这正是政客们经常玩弄和扭曲的。一方可以声称就业率上升，而另一方可以声称失业率上升。这两种说法都有统计数据支持，事实上，在同一时期，这两种说法都可能是正确的。要理解为什么会出现这种情况，需要仔细分析——即使是仔细的分析也可能忽略其他重要因素。换句话说，打击政治上的相对主义是一场非常艰难的战斗，但这场战斗至关重要，因为声称真理不存在既不诚实也不道德。做出这样的断言就是陷入极其危险的境地。

Statistics is a way of describing reality, but it doesn’t tell anything about the way that complex links work—and that’s what politicians often play with and distort. One party can claim that employment has gone up, and the opposing party can claim that joblessness has risen. Both claims are supported by statistics, and in fact both can be right in the same time period. To understand how this can be the case requires careful analysis—and even careful analysis may leave out other important factors. In other words, combating relativism in politics is a very difficult battle, but it is vital that it be fought, because to claim that truth does not exist is both dishonest and immoral. To make such a claim is to plunge into profoundly treacherous waters.

插曲：关于三大谜团

INTERLUDE: ON THREE GREAT MYSTERIES

我们是否会知道一切是如何开始的？

Will we ever come to know how everything began?

我的床头柜上总是摆放着三本书，它们都是关于我认为的存在的三大谜团。第一本书讲的是宇宙的起源；第二本书讲的是生命的起源，讲的是从无生命物质到有生命物质的转变；第三本书讲的是意识的奥秘。这些书本身和它们的作者会不时更换，但你总能在我的床头柜上找到关于这三个谜团的书。

On my nightstand I always place three books about what I consider to be the three greatest mysteries of existence. The first one deals with the origin of the universe; the second one deals with how life began, about the transition from inanimate to animate matter; and the third one deals with the mystery of consciousness. The books themselves, and their authors, change from time to time, but at all times you will find books on my nightstand about these three mysteries.

我从小就对这三个谜语着迷，在这方面我并不独特，因为这些问题通常被认为是我们所知的最大谜团，而且自从我们人类能够思考以来，它们就一直困扰着我们。

These three riddles have fascinated me ever since I was small, and in this respect I am hardly unique, for these questions are often considered the greatest mysteries we know, and we humans have wondered about them as long as we have been able to wonder.

纵观历史，有洞察力的研究人员、哲学家和思想家曾构想出各种理论来回答宇宙起源、生命起源和意识本质的问题，但目前对这些问题的答案尚无统一的共识。我们与生俱来的好奇心总是推动着我们继续前行，试图解答这些问题。

All through history, insightful researchers, philosophers, and thinkers have dreamed up various theories to answer questions about the origin of the universe, the origin of life, and the nature of consciousness, but at the present, there is no uniform consensus on the answers. Our innate curiosity is always pushing us further along the pathway to try to answer these questions.

有些人声称，这些问题永远无法用科学来解答。他们说，这些问题超出了科学的范畴，所有这些谜题都无法解决。解答这些问题是宗教的神圣职责，而不是科学的职责。

Some people claim that scientific answers will never be found for these questions. They lie beyond the realm of science, so they say; all these riddles are unsolvable. It is religion’s sacred duty to answer them, not science’s.

不幸的是，我终其一生都无法理解这种论点。在我看来，这是一种完全陌生的思维方式，需要提前驳斥认为科学终有一天能够解答我们今天认为是谜的问题。为什么有人要否认通往知识的新途径？当一个人可以睁大眼睛面对世界时，为什么要闭上眼睛呢？

Unfortunately, I cannot for the life of me comprehend this line of argument. It strikes me as an utterly alien style of thinking to dismiss in advance the notion that science will one day be able to answer questions that we today consider to be mysteries. Why should anyone deny the idea of new pathways to knowledge? Why should one shut one’s eyes, when one can face the world with one’s eyes wide open?

这种消极态度会阻碍一切可能性。说“这永远不可能实现；我们永远不会知道；这是不可能的！”会让人觉得太局限了。几个世纪以来，科学已经解决了无数的谜团，而这些谜团在以前的人们看来是无解的。我们学会了如何飞行；我们学会了如何治愈疾病；我们了解了难以想象的遥远恒星是由什么构成的以及它们的能量来源是什么；我们学会了如何在极小的尺度（实际上是微观的！）和极大的尺度（实际上是天文的！）上观察新现象。多亏了自然选择理论，我们才得以解释自然界中各种复杂而美丽的生物。曾经完全无法解释的现象如今已不再是谜。为什么这种事情不能一再发生呢？

Such negative attitudes shut out possibilities. It feels so limiting to say, “This will never be done; we will never come to know this; it’s impossible!” Down through the centuries, science has solved innumerable mysteries that for people at an earlier time had seemed hopelessly unsolvable. We learned how to fly; we learned how to cure diseases; we learned what the inconceivably distant stars are made of and what their source of energy is; we learned how to see new phenomena on incredibly tiny scales (literally microscopic!), and on incredibly vast scales (literally astronomical!). Thanks to the theory of natural selection, we have explained nature’s enormous variety of complex and beautiful creatures. Phenomena that once were totally inexplicable are today no longer mysteries. Why shouldn’t this sort of thing happen over and over again?

我希望我们都能以更开放、更谦逊的态度对待我们尚不了解的事物。也许有一天，我们都能轻松理解意识是如何作为构成我们大脑的数十亿个神经元（和数万亿个突触）活动的产物而产生的。

I wish we all had a more open and humbler attitude about what we don’t yet understand. Maybe someday we will all easily understand how consciousness arises as an emergent result of the activities of the billions upon billions of neurons (and trillions upon trillions of synapses) that constitute our brains.

也许有一天，我们能解释生命是如何从无生命物质中起源的，通过化学过程和来自地球遥远地方的巨大热量，我们称之为太阳的热量。也许在遥远的将来，我们能够通过量子物理学的飞跃来解释宇宙的创造（奇迹般地从无到有）——或者也许需要某种我们还没有看到过的其他宇宙学理论。

And perhaps one day we will explain how life originated from inanimate matter, through chemical processes and a great warmth coming from far away from our planet, a warmth that we call the sun. Perhaps in a remote time we will be able to understand how the universe’s creation (something coming miraculously out of nothing) can be accounted for through the remarkable leaps of quantum physics—or perhaps it will take some other kind of cosmological theory of which we don’t yet have even a glimmer.

或者，也许我们永远都无法找到这些谜团的解释。但目前还不得而知。我当然不想提前否定任何事情。毕竟，我们有限的知识在不断发展。谦逊和开放让我不得不说：“也许有一天我们最终会解开所有这些谜团。”

Or, perhaps, we just won’t ever find any explanation for these mysteries. But that is unknown right now. I surely wouldn’t want to discount anything in advance. After all, our limited knowledge is in constant development. Humility and openness require me to say, “Maybe one day we will finally fathom all these mysteries.”

在那之前，我会继续在床头柜上阅读这三本书——总是新作家写的，总是有新想法的。阅读这样的书让我感觉我的思绪飞扬，非常快，非常高。这是一种令人眼花缭乱的感觉。也许，在某个美好的日子，我的床头柜上只有一本书——这本书会对所有这些问题给出合理且有充分依据的答案。

Until then, I will continue to read those three books on my nightstand—always ones by new writers, always ones with new ideas. Reading such books gives me the feeling that my thoughts are soaring, very fast and very high. It is a dizzying feeling. And perhaps, one lovely day, there will be just one single book on my nightstand—a book that will give plausible and well-supported answers to all these questions.

第三章

CHAPTER THREE

基于合理理由的信仰关于一个人信念的依据

BELIEFS BASED ON GOOD REASONS Concerning the Grounds That Underlie One’s Convictions

问题的根本原因在于，在现代社会，愚昧的人过于自信，而聪明的人却充满怀疑。——伯特兰·罗素

The fundamental cause of the trouble is that in the modern world the stupid are cocksure while the intelligent are full of doubt.—Bertrand Russell

否自从我们开始探索现实和真理的本质以来，无数的问题出现了：我应该相信什么？我为什么要相信它？相信某件事究竟意味着什么？

N ow that we’ve begun exploring the nature of reality and truth, numerous questions arise: What should I believe? Why should I believe it? What does it really mean to believe in something?

“信仰”一词有多种含义。当人们谈论一天中的时间或肯尼亚的首都时，人们经常会说“我想现在是 5 点左右”或“我相信是内罗毕”。这是一种信仰。相比之下，“我相信亨利”这句话不仅意味着人们确信亨利存在，还意味着人们对亨利有信心和信念。人们还可以说“我相信正义”，这意味着人们希望看到正义无处不在。

The word “belief” has numerous meanings. When one is talking about the time of day or what the capital of Kenya is, one often says things like, “I think it’s about 5 o’clock” or “I believe it is Nairobi.” This is one type of belief. By contrast, the phrase “I believe in Henry” means not only that one is convinced that Henry exists but also that one has confidence and faith in Henry. One can also say, “I believe in justice,” meaning that one wishes to see justice everywhere.

“我有信仰”这个短语通常暗示对一个或多个神的宗教信仰，但它也可以不带有任何宗教含义，例如“我相信你”。

The phrase “I have faith” often suggests a religious belief concerning one or more gods, but it can also be used without any religious implications, as in “I have faith in you.”

那么，相信某件事意味着什么呢？区分两种信仰是有意义的。

What, then, does believing in something involve? It makes sense to distinguish between two sorts of belief.

第一种信念可以称为“认知信念”（来自拉丁语cognitio，意为“知识”）。这可以描述为相信某物以特定方式表现或具有某种属性。一个典型的例子是“我相信现在是五点钟”。类似的例子还有“我相信明天早上会下雨”或“我相信其他星球上有生命”。认知信念是对真理的主张。

The first could be called “cognitive belief” (from the Latin cognitio, meaning “knowledge”). This can be described as the belief that something behaves in a particular manner or has a certain property. A typical example is “I believe that it’s five o’clock.” Similarly for “I believe it’ll rain tomorrow morning” or “I believe there is life on other planets.” A cognitive belief is a claim of truth.

第二种信念是类似信仰的信念。这种信念完全是关于信心、信念、信任和依赖。它更多的是相信某事或某人，而不是相信某事是事实。“我相信你”并不意味着“我相信你存在”（尽管这当然是隐含的），而是“我知道我可以永远依赖和信任你。”

The second sort of belief is faith-like belief. This kind of belief is all about confidence, faith, trust, and reliance. It’s more about believing in something or someone than about believing that something is the case. “I believe in you” doesn’t mean “I believe you exist” (although of course this is implied) but, rather, “I know that I can always rely on and trust you.”

我们都有许多所相信的事物，既有认知意义上的，也有信仰意义上的。

We all have many things that we believe in, both in the cognitive sense and in the faith-like sense.

我们对世界的大多数想法都是认知信念。我们相信我们面前的桌子是存在的。我们相信我们自己是存在的。我们相信世界上周存在，下周也会存在。我们相信明天早上太阳会升起（好吧，如果我们在 12 月 21 日左右在瑞典北部，也许不会！）。我们相信地球围绕太阳旋转。从认识论意义上来说，这些事情都无法得到明确和绝对的证明，即完全和永恒的确定性，但尽管如此，我们显然有充分的理由提出这些真理主张。

Most of our ideas about the world are cognitive beliefs. We believe that the table in front of us exists. We believe that we ourselves exist. We believe that the world existed last week and will exist next week. We believe that the sun will come up tomorrow morning (well, maybe not, if we’re way up north in Sweden around December 21!). We believe that the earth rotates around the sun. None of these things can be definitively and absolutely proven in the epistemological sense of total and eternal certainty, but nonetheless, we clearly have excellent reasons for making these claims of truth.

为了清楚地思考信仰的本质，我们必须区分证据和证明。我们经常听到有人说，人们无法证明科学理论（例如进化论）是正确的。事实确实如此。“证明”一词在其最纯粹的意义上仅适用于数学论证。1

In order to think clearly about the nature of beliefs, one has to distinguish between evidence and proof. We often hear it said that one cannot prove that scientific theories—for example, the theory of evolution—are true. This is certainly the case. The term “proof,” in its purest meaning, applies only to mathematical arguments.1

在数学之外，这种严格的证明并不存在；因此，从纯粹的认识论角度来看，我们永远无法从逻辑上证明爱因斯坦的引力理论是正确的，甚至无法证明地球是圆的。然而，数学之外的陈述无法以这种严格而狭隘的意义得到证明，这一事实丝毫不意味着数学之外的所有认知信念都同样有充分的理由（或同样缺乏充分的理由）。虽然科学不能也不会给我们绝对可靠的证据，但它的力量在于它为各种理论提供了证据（有的强，有的弱）。

Outside of math, strict proofs of this sort don’t exist; therefore, from a purely epistemological point of view, we can never logically prove that Einstein’s theory of gravity is correct, nor can we even prove that the earth is round. The fact that statements outside of mathematics cannot be proven in this strict and narrow sense, however, doesn’t in the least imply that all cognitive beliefs outside of math are equally well (or equally poorly) grounded. Although science can’t and doesn’t give us absolute and infallible proofs, its power is that it gives us pieces of evidence (some stronger and some weaker) for various theories.

人类信仰各种各样的事物。无论有意还是无意，我们都会通过接受某些观念、拒绝其他观念来构建我们自己的现实形象。

Humans believe in all sorts of things. We all build up, whether consciously or not, our own image of reality by accepting certain ideas and rejecting others.

当我们试图描述我们周围的世界是如何构成的（换句话说，当我们从事自然科学时），我们会制定关于事物如何运作的理论（或思想或模型）。出于前面给出的原因，我们无法对一个理论做出无懈可击的证明，但我们仍然可以通过仔细检查支持该理论的各种思想以及从该理论得出的各种结论的真实性来找到它的证据。每次我们验证一个支持或结论时，我们都会为该理论增加可信度。我们也可以证伪理论（即证明它们不起作用）；当用来检验我们合理猜测的实验与我们的预测不一致时，就会发生这种情况。

When we try to describe how the world around us is constituted (in other words, when we engage in natural science), we formulate theories (or ideas, or models) about how things behave. For the reasons given earlier, we can’t make a watertight proof of a theory, but we can nonetheless find pieces of evidence for it by carefully checking out the truth of various ideas that would support the theory, and of various conclusions that follow from the theory. Each time we verify a support or a conclusion, we add credibility to the theory. We can also falsify theories, (i.e., show that they do not work); this happens when experiments to check our plausible guesses disagree with what we had predicted.

相信一种理论意味着相信某些事物以某种方式运作，或具有某些特性。当然，我们可以有相当不坚定的信念，例如“我不太确定，但我怀疑……”，我们也可以有非常强烈的信念，例如“我毫无疑问地确信……”，但无论我们处于这个连续体的哪个位置，我们仍然只处理可能性，而不是绝对的确定性。当对同一现象有几种相互竞争的理论时，我们通常会相信我们认为具有最有力证据的理论。

To believe in a theory means to believe that certain things behave in a certain manner, or have certain properties. Of course we can have rather half-hearted beliefs, such as “I’m not too sure, but I would suspect that . . .,” and we can have extremely strong beliefs, such as “I am convinced beyond any doubt that . . .,” but wherever we may be located along this continuum, we are still dealing only with likelihoods, never with absolute certainties. When there are several rival theories about the same phenomenon, we generally believe the one that we consider to have the strongest total evidence.

当我们说我们知道某件事时，我们的意思是，我们不仅相信这件事，而且我们有充分的理由这样做。

When we say that we know something, we mean not only that we believe in that thing but also that we have strong reasons for doing so.

除了认知信念之外，我们大多数人还具有类似信仰的信念。因此，我们相信我们的朋友和亲人。我们对他们的能力充满信心。我们也可能宣称我们相信爱情，或者相信民主等政治理想——这意味着我们对这些抽象概念的力量和力量充满信心。

Aside from having cognitive beliefs, most of us also have faith-like beliefs. Thus, we believe in our friends and in our loved ones. We have confidence in their abilities. We may well also declare that we believe in love, or in a political ideal such as democracy—meaning that we have confidence in the power and strength of those abstractions.

我们无意识地不断依赖着自己的感官。这种依赖是一种信仰般的信念。如果我们的眼睛告诉我们花园里有一棵树，那么我们就相信它就在那里。当然，如果对这棵树的存在仍有疑问，我们也可以走进花园去触摸它，但要从这一行为中得出任何结论，我们仍然必须像信仰一样依赖我们的触觉。如果我们不相信自己的感官，在这个世界上生存和活动就会非常困难。如果我们没有这样的信念，生活就会非常困难。

We constantly rely, unconsciously, on our senses. This kind of reliance is a faith-like belief. If our eyes tell us there is a tree in the garden, then we believe that it is there. Of course, if there remains some doubt about the tree’s existence, we can also walk out into the garden and touch it, but to draw any conclusions from that act, we would still have to rely, in a faith-like manner, on our sense of touch. Without having faith in our senses, it would be very difficult to survive and move about in this world. If we had no such faith, it would be very hard to live.

“那么，你相信什么呢？”

“But What Do You Believe in, Then?”

我经常被问到这样的问题：“那么，你相信什么呢？你肯定相信一些东西！”，通常用一种沮丧的语气说出来。

I have often been confronted with the question, “But what do you believe in, then? Surely you must believe in something!,” usually expressed in a frustrated tone of voice.

我从未完全理解这个问题背后的原因，因为当然，我——像每个理智的成年人一样——有无数的信仰：我只是碰巧不相信任何神。但那一个不信并不意味着我没有信仰！毕竟，我也是人。那么好吧——我有什么样的信仰呢？

I’ve never fully understood what lies behind this question since, of course, I—like every sane adult human being—have myriads of beliefs: I just don’t happen to believe in any god. But that one disbelief doesn’t mean that I am beliefless! I am, after all, human. So all right—what sorts of beliefs do I have?

那么，从认知的角度来看，这里有一些典型的例子。我相信 10 + 10 = 100（二进制！）；我相信车沿着棋盘的行和列移动，但不对角线移动；我相信我的车有方向盘，没有龙骨；我相信物质是由原子组成的；我相信生物是由细胞组成的；我相信遗传是由DNA组成的基因传递的；我相信独角兽只存在于童话故事书中；我相信其他星球上有生命；我相信达尔文的进化论正确地描述了物种起源。我还相信“上帝”是人类创造的概念，这个词不指代任何事物，也不对应外部世界的任何现实。

Well, on the cognitive side of the ledger, here are a few typical examples. I believe that 10 + 10 = 100 (in binary!); I believe that rooks move along a chessboard’s rows and columns, but not diagonally; I believe that my car has a steering wheel but not a keel; I believe that matter is made of atoms; I believe that living creatures are made of cells; I believe that heredity is transmitted by genes made of DNA; I believe that unicorns are found only in fairy tale books; I believe that there is life on other planets; I believe that Darwin’s theory of evolution correctly describes the origin of species. I also believe that “God” is a concept that was created by humans and that the word doesn’t refer to anything, or correspond to any kind of reality in the external world.

在信仰方面，我也有无数的信念。当然，我对任何神都没有信仰般的信仰，因为那首先要求我对神有认知上的信仰（一个人不能依赖他完全不相信的东西！）。但是，举几个我信仰般的信念的正面例子，我相信人类的巨大潜力，相信人们的推理能力，相信我们愿意承担责任；我也相信平等、非种族主义、非性别歧视和人权。

On the faith-like side of the ledger, I also have a myriad beliefs. Of course I have no faith-like belief in any god, since that would first require me to have a cognitive belief in a god (one can’t rely on something that one totally disbelieves in!). But, to give some positive examples of my faith-like beliefs, I believe in humanity’s great potential, in people’s ability to reason, and in our willingness to take responsibility; I also believe in equality, nonracism, nonsexism, and human rights.

以上是我对本节标题问题的一些回答。

Those are a few of my answers to the question forming this section’s title.

相信科学是一种信仰吗？

Is Belief in Science a Kind of Faith?

一种普遍的误解是，当某人相信科学时，这就相当于其他人相信上帝。问题是“相信科学”这句话具有误导性。相信科学是合理的，即对产生科学理论的方法有信心。科学信仰与人们仅仅凭信念接受的宗教主张截然不同，因为后者可能是错误的，甚至是欺诈的。当涉及到有关世界的问题时，科学建立在推理和测试方法之上，几个世纪以来，这些方法已被证明比来自预言、启示、梦境或圣经的主张可靠得多。

A widespread misconception is the idea that when someone believes in science, that is comparable to other people believing in God. The problem is that the phrase “believe in science” is misleading. It is reasonable to believe in science—that is, to have confidence in the methods that give rise to scientific theories. A scientific belief is very different from a religious claim that one merely accepts on faith, for such claims can be erroneous or even fraudulent. When it comes to questions about the world, science is built on ways of reasoning and testing that, throughout the centuries, have proven themselves to be of far greater reliability than claims coming from prophecies, revelations, dreams, or holy scriptures.

由此产生的结果是，大多数得到充分支持的科学观点为我们提供了有关周围世界的实用知识。如果一天晚上我向窗外望去，看到天空晴朗，然后我听到天气预报说第二天早上天空晴朗，那么我就可以非常有信心地相信我醒来时天气会晴朗。当然，这不是一种僵硬、固定、教条的信念。在我上床睡觉前，天空可能会变得阴沉，或者我可能会听到更新的天气预报说了一些不同的事情，然后我的期望就会改变。因此，我对第二天天气的信念是基于我多年来对世界的熟悉，也基于我的感官信息来源。我的信念可以随着函数的变化而灵活变化我收到的新证据。所有这些都类似于科学如何建立其结果，无论是物理学、化学、生物学还是任何其他科学。

A consequence of this is that most well-supported scientific ideas give us practical knowledge about the world around us. If one evening I look out the window and see that the sky is clear, and if I then hear a weather forecast predicting sunny skies the next morning, I can feel pretty confident that it’ll be sunny when I wake up. Of course this is not a rigid, fixed, dogmatic belief. The sky might grow overcast before I go to bed, or I might hear an updated weather forecast that says something different, and then my expectations will change. My belief about the next day’s weather is thus grounded in the familiarity with the world that I have built up over many years, and also in my sensory information sources. And my belief can flexibly change as a function of new evidence that I receive. All this is similar to how a science builds up its results, whether it’s physics, chemistry, biology, or any other science.

大多数人相信科学，因为我们通常都依赖知名且严肃的研究人员的发现。因此，我们对科学有着信仰般的信任，尽管这并不意味着我们会武断地相信我们读到的每一个科学主张。从长远来看，许多科学思想都是错误的；然而，科学的美妙之处在于，通过成千上万的人积极参与寻找真理的集体行动，错误思想最终会以稳定可靠的方式被清除，而真正的想法则作为遗产被留下来。

Most people believe in science, in the sense that we normally all rely on the findings of established and serious researchers. We thus have a faith-like belief in science, although that doesn’t mean that we dogmatically believe every scientific claim that we read. Plenty of scientific ideas turn out, in the long run, to be wrong; the beauty of science, however, is that through the collective act of thousands of people engaging actively in the search for truth, the false ideas eventually get weeded out in a steady and reliable fashion, and true ideas are left as their legacy.

在过去的几个世纪里，科学方法已被证明在描述世界、解释世界和预测世界事件方面非常成功。宗教信仰却并非如此。事实上，纵观历史，宗教经文和启示往往提供与我们今天所知直接冲突的世界观。

Throughout the past several centuries, the methods of science have proven themselves to be highly successful in describing the world, explaining the world, and predicting events in the world. The same cannot be said about religious beliefs. In fact, religious scriptures and revelations have, throughout history, often provided conceptions of the world that are in direct conflict with what we know today.

与宗教相反，科学通过不断检验其假设而不断进步；因此，它是一种自我修正的认知方式。然而，今天有许多人对科学持怀疑态度。在神学界，甚至有人声称科学需要神学才能自给自足。2一位失意的、幽默的研究人员曾经说过：“科学不是宗教。如果它是宗教就好了！因为这样，获得资金来支持研究就会容易得多。”

In contrast with religion, science progresses by constantly testing its hypotheses; it is therefore a self-correcting way of knowing. And yet today, there are many people who look upon science with great skepticism. In theological circles, there are even some people who claim that science needs theology in order to be self-sufficient.2 A frustrated researcher with a sense of humor once said, “Science is not a religion. If only it were one! For in that case, it would be far easier to get money to support research.”

知识诚实

Intellectual Honesty

在当今信息丰富的社会中，我们接触到的各种观念竞争激烈。在报纸上，我们可以看到占星术，在深夜电视节目中，我们可以看到治疗可怕疾病的神奇疗法广告，在网络上，我们听到各种神奇饮食的说法，等等。算命师和通灵师声称能够预测我们的未来或读懂我们的心思。小报上充斥着关于轮回或印度大师能凭空变出珠宝的文章。在街头集市上，小贩向我们兜售能给我们能量的磁性手镯或能恢复我们生活和谐的水晶。各种各样的福音传教士建议（或要求）我们应该相信这个或那个神。面对这些无休止的相互竞争的说法，一个理智的人究竟如何才能弄清楚他们应该相信什么？

In today’s information-rich society, there is a furious competition among ideas that we are exposed to. In newspapers we can read astrological horoscopes, on late-night television we can see ads for magical cures to dreaded diseases, on the web we are fed claims of miracle diets, and on and on. Fortunetellers and psychics claim to be able to reveal our future or to read our minds. Tabloid newspapers overflow with articles about reincarnation or Indian gurus who can make jewels appear out of thin air. In street fairs, hawkers offer to sell us magnetic bracelets that will give us energy or crystals that will restore harmony to our lives. And various kinds of evangelists suggest (or demand) that we ought to believe in this or that god. Given this relentless onslaught of competing claims, how on earth can a sane person figure out what they ought to believe?

很多说法、想法和产品经常摆在我们面前，却没有任何严肃的知识或研究作为支撑。相反，幕后隐藏的只是赚钱或传播意识形态的欲望。我们迫切需要一种理智且可验证的方法来核实这么多说法的真实性。

Claims, ideas, and products are often paraded in front of us without any serious knowledge or research backing them up. Instead, what lies behind the scenes is simply the desire to make money or to propagate an ideology. We desperately need a sane and verifiable way of checking out the veracity of so many claims.

如果一项科学发现在实验中得到了合理的证实，那么相信它是合理的。至少我们可以信赖一项科学发现，直到出现新的、更可靠的发现来取代它。当然，这意味着我们需要始终对测试和修改我们的信念持开放态度。

It is reasonable to believe in a scientific finding if it has been reasonably well confirmed in experiments. At least we can rely on a given scientific finding until a new and more reliably confirmed finding comes along to replace it.
