This, of course, means that we need to be open at all times to the idea of testing and revising our beliefs.

可惜的是，我们永远找不到任何铁证如山的数学证据来证明天空中没有到处都是随机飞行的茶壶，或者我们不是一直在穿过看不见、无味、完全无声、无形的大象。但是，我们无法以绝对无懈可击的方式反驳这些非常愚蠢的想法，并不意味着我们应该相信它们！试图反驳死后生命的想法也是如此；我们当然无法以逻辑上不可反驳的方式反驳它，但另一方面，我们有什么理由相信它呢？

We won’t, alas, ever find any ironclad mathematical proof that the heavens aren’t filled with randomly flying teapots, or that we aren’t constantly walking through invisible, odor-free, perfectly silent, intangible elephants. But the fact that we can’t disprove these very silly ideas in an absolutely watertight fashion doesn’t mean that we should believe in them! The same goes for trying to disprove the idea of life after death; we certainly can’t disprove it in a logically indefeasible fashion, but on the other hand, what reason do we have for believing it?

你怎么知道下次走到镜子前时，你能看到自己？也许你根本就不在那儿！也许下次你张开手时，你手里握着的鹅卵石不会掉到地上，而是会悬在半空中！或者也许那只在厨房窗户外盘旋的小蜂鸟会突然飞过玻璃窗而不会打破它，然后变成一只会飞的恐龙，咬掉你的头！但我们都怀疑这些事情，而且理由很充分。尽管如此，我们无法证明它们。证明仅限于数学。

How do you know that the next time you walk in front of a mirror you’ll be able to see yourself? Maybe you won’t be there at all! And maybe the next time you open your hand, the pebble you’re holding in it won’t fall to the ground but will just sit there, suspended in mid-air! Or maybe that little hummingbird hovering outside the kitchen window will suddenly fly right through the glass pane without breaking it, then turn into a flying dinosaur, and bite your head off! But we all doubt these things, and for very good reasons. Nonetheless, we can’t prove them. Proof is limited to mathematics.

但是，如果我们对任何事情都不确定，我们该如何应对生活呢？当我们问自己这样的问题时，最好记住英格玛·赫德尼乌斯的智识诚实原则：“只有当你有充分的理由认为某个想法是真的时，你才相信它。”虽然听起来微不足道，但这是一个重要的原则，可以帮助我们在日常生活中导航。应该检验想法，甚至奇怪的说法也应该给予机会。你还能在哪里找到比这更开放的态度呢？这就是赫德尼乌斯原则如此重要的原因。

But if we can’t be sure of anything, how can we manage in life? When we ask ourselves such questions, it is good to keep in mind Ingemar Hedenius’s principle of intellectual honesty: “Believe in an idea if and only if you have good reasons to think it is true.” Though trivial sounding, this is an important principle that can help us navigate around in the everyday world. Ideas should be tested, and even strange claims should be given a chance. Where could you ever find a more open-minded attitude than that? This is why Hedenius’s principle is important.

每当你遇到关于世界本质的新主张时，问问自己这样的问题：“有充分的理由认真对待这个想法吗？有充分的理由驳斥它吗？还有其他方法吗？解释其主张的方法是什么？解释其主张的最佳方式是什么？其背后的证据有多强？这一主张与我们已知的其他事实相吻合吗？它不太可能还是可信？有人提出这个想法是否有隐藏的原因？”

Whenever you run into a new claim about the world’s nature, ask yourself such questions as these: “Are there good reasons for taking this idea seriously? Are there good reasons for dismissing it? Could there be other ways of explaining what it claims? What would be the best way to explain what it claims? How strong is the evidence behind it? Does this claim mesh well with other things that we know are true? Is it improbable or plausible? Could there be hidden reasons that someone is proposing this idea?”

在生活中的许多情况下，我们必须依赖他人的想法和知识。我们必须相信物理教科书中的内容，因为我们知道这些教科书是由物理学专家编写的。相反，我们很少或根本不相信小报上那些引人入胜、耸人听闻的标题，例如美国的《世界新闻周刊》 （可惜现已停刊）、英国的《每日镜报》或瑞典的《晚报》。请看以下令人愉悦的《世界新闻周刊》标题样本：

In many situations in life, we must rely on the ideas and the knowledge of other people. We have to believe what we find in physics textbooks, knowing that they were written by professional experts in physics. Contrariwise, we place little or no faith in the juicy and lurid headlines that we encounter in tabloid newspapers, such as the Weekly World News (now defunct, alas) in the United States, the Daily Mirror in Britain, or Aftonbladet in Sweden. Consider the following delightful sampler of Weekly World News headlines:

“世界上最丑的女人照镜子后死亡”

“World’s Ugliest Woman Dies after Looking in Mirror”

“海豚长出人类的手臂”

“Dolphin Grows Human Arms”

“阿道夫·希特勒是个女人！”

“Adolf Hitler Was a Woman!”

“猎鸭人射杀天使”

“Duck Hunter Shoots Angel”

“1939 年失踪的飞机着陆！”

“Plane Missing since 1939 Lands!”

“新墨西哥州发现撒旦头骨！”

“Satan’s Skull Found in New Mexico!”

“哈勃望远镜拍摄的天堂”

“Heaven Photographed by Hubble Telescope”

“天生人面马！”

“Horse Born with Human Face!”

“巴拉克·奥巴马是个机器人！”

“Barack Obama Is a Robot!”

“少女吃掉 4,000 块海绵蛋糕！”

“Teenage Girl Eats 4,000 Sponges!”

“希拉里·克林顿收养外星婴儿！”

“Hillary Clinton Adopts Alien Baby!”

“泰坦尼克号幸存者在救生筏上被发现！”

“Titanic Survivors Found on Board Life Raft!”

“NASA拍摄太空幽灵照片”

“NASA Takes Photo of Ghosts in Space”

“金枪鱼三明治里发现迷你美人鱼！”

“Mini-Mermaid Found in Tuna Sandwich!”

“乍得海岸发现 5000 年前的不明飞行物”

“5,000-Year-Old UFO Found off the Coast of Chad”

“农夫射杀 23 磅重的蚱蜢”

“Farmer Shoots 23-Pound Grasshopper”

“秃头男子用头煎鸡蛋”

“Bald Man Fries Eggs on His Head”

是什么让我们对这些标题心存怀疑？哪些线索让我们保持警惕？

What makes us read these headlines skeptically? What clues put us on our guard?

嗯，有时是因为它们的难以置信。有时是它们的离谱。有时是它们的怪诞。有时是它们的幼稚。有时是它们与魔术的相似之处。有时是它们的幽默感。有时是因为我们以前见过“类似”的东西。换句话说，在接触了足够多的小报头条新闻后，我们开始对“这种胡说八道”产生一种无意识的第六感。

Well, sometimes it is their sheer implausibility. Sometimes it is their outrageousness. Sometimes it is their grotesqueness. Sometimes it is their childishness. Sometimes it is their similarity to magic. Sometimes it is their humorousness. Sometimes it is because we have seen “similar” things before. In other words, after being exposed to enough tabloid headlines, we start to develop an unconscious sixth sense for “this kind of nonsense.”

另一种说法是，在长期阅读小报标题的过程中，我们逐渐学会识别某些重复出现的模式。小时候，我们对这些标题感到好奇和好笑，但随着时间的推移，我们学会了怀疑。

Another way of stating this is that in reading tabloid newspaper headlines over a long period of time, we gradually learn to recognize certain recurrent types of patterns. When we were little, we were intrigued and amused by such headlines, but throughout time, we learned to be suspicious.

显然，你不可能独自检验每一个可能的说法，所以你必须依靠别人来帮助你找到方法。因此，我们都需要培养一种意识，即哪些类型的权威是我们可以信任的，哪些类型的“权威”根本不是真正的权威。一位物理学教授大概比我懂物理。《纽约时报》大概比《世界新闻周刊》可靠得多。但这并不意味着我们应该在任何时候、任何情况下盲目依赖某些来源。我们不能随便相信每一位物理学教授说的每一句话，也不应该不加批判地接受我们在《纽约时报》上读到的每一个字。归根结底，经过足够的训练和经验之后，你自己必须能够判断你所遇到的说法的合理性。

You obviously can’t check out every single possible claim on your own, and so you have to rely on others to help you find your way. We all therefore need to develop a sense for which types of authorities we can trust, and which types of “authorities” are not actual authorities at all. A physics professor presumably knows more physics than I do. The New York Times is presumably far more reliable than the Weekly World News. But that doesn’t mean that there are certain sources that we should blindly rely on at all times and in all circumstances. We can’t just go around believing everything that every single physics professor utters, nor should we accept uncritically every single word that we read in the New York Times. In the final analysis, after enough training and experience, you yourself have to be able to judge the plausibility of the claims you encounter.

在一场豪华宴会上，坐在你旁边的优雅女士告诉你，她被外星人绑架了，并被关在外星人的飞船里两周。她还说，她家里有一些从飞船上拿走的物品，她很乐意把它们给你看。你大概会持怀疑态度。但你为什么怀疑呢？本质上，这是因为她的说法与你之前的所有经验和你一生中学到的关于这个世界的所有教训相悖。此外，虽然不那么重要，但如果这种外星人绑架事件真的发生过，那么所有报纸肯定会广泛报道。

The elegant lady sitting next to you at a fancy banquet tells you that she was kidnapped by space aliens and was held in their spaceship for two weeks. She adds that in her house she has some objects that she took from the spaceship and that she’d be more than happy to show them to you. You, presumably, are skeptical. But why are you skeptical? Essentially, it’s because her claim runs against all your prior experiences and all the lessons you have learned about the world throughout your whole life. Additionally, though a bit less important, if such alien abductions really took place, then surely they would be widely reported in all the newspapers.

你断定你的同桌在胡说八道——但你能证明那是胡说八道吗？不，你只能认为她的故事极不可能。

You conclude that your tablemate is talking nonsense—but can you prove that it’s nonsense? No, all you can do is take her tale as being extremely unlikely.

如果对她的故事最简单、最合理的解释是她确实被外星人绑架了，那么你相信她的故事是有道理的。但在这种情况下，这并不是最简单、最合理的解释。更简单、更可能的情况是，她只是在和你开玩笑，或者她想欺骗你，或者她极度需要关注，或者她喝醉了，或者她患有严重的精神疾病——甚至她只是想把你引诱回她家。或者她只是感到困惑或疲倦。所有这些对她那牵强附会的故事的解释都比让你（或任何其他人）相信所谓的外星人绑架确实发生过要合理得多。

It would make sense for you to believe her tale if the simplest and most reasonable explanation for her tale is that she really was abducted by space aliens. But in this case, that is not the simplest and most reasonable explanation. Much simpler and more likely are such possibilities as that she is just pulling your leg, or that she wants to trick you, or that she is desperate for attention, or that she is drunk, or that she is seriously mentally ill—or even that she just wants to lure you back to her house. Or maybe she’s just confused or tired. All of these explanations for her far-fetched story are far more reasonable than for you (or anyone else) to swallow the idea that the alleged alien abduction really took place.

“非凡的主张需要非凡的证据”

“Extraordinary Claims Require Extraordinary Evidence”

当一个人听到一个令人惊讶的故事时，一个很好的经验法则是问自己以下问题：这个说法最有可能的解释是它真的是真的吗？另一个很好的经验法则是卡尔·萨根的名言“普通的说法只需要普通的证据，但非凡的说法需要非凡的证据。”卡尔·萨根（1934-1996）是一位极具影响力的美国天体物理学家和作家，他的这句朗朗上口的名言呼应了伟大的法国天文学家和数学家皮埃尔·西蒙·德·拉普拉斯（“非凡说法的证据分量必须与其奇异性成正比”）和英国哲学家大卫·休谟（“明智的人会根据证据来判断自己的信念”）。3

An excellent rule of thumb, when one is told a surprising tale, is to ask oneself the following: Is the most likely explanation of this claim that it really is true? Another excellent rule of thumb is Carl Sagan’s dictum “Ordinary claims only need ordinary evidence, but extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.” Carl Sagan (1934–1996) was a highly influential American astrophysicist and author, and his catchy phrase echoes earlier statements by the great French astronomer and mathematician Pierre Simon de Laplace (“The weight of evidence for an extraordinary claim must be proportioned to its strangeness”) and British philosopher David Hume (“A wise man proportions his belief to the evidence”).3

你的一个朋友告诉你明天会下雨。你相信她，因为没有特别的理由怀疑她的话。她补充说，她刚刚看了电视上的天气预报，而你没有看。第二天，也许会发现她的话是错的，但即便如此，你相信她也是非常合理的。

You have a friend who tells you that it’s going to rain tomorrow. You believe her because there’s no particular reason to be suspicious of her utterance. She adds that she just watched the weather report on television, which you did not do. Now the next day it may turn out that her statement was wrong, but even so, it was extremely reasonable of you to have believed her.

另一位好友告诉你，西藏僧人在冥想时可以飘浮在空中。经过一番思考，你得出结论，他的说法与整个现代科学世界观背道而驰。它与我们所有涉及引力和支配受力物体运动的经典定律的经验相矛盾。这并不意味着你可以用严密的数学严谨性证明你朋友的说法是错误的。但经过几分钟的思考，你意识到，如果西藏僧人真的可以在空中飘浮，这将构成一个革命性的科学事实，并将在新闻媒体上迅速传播开来。第一个观察到飘浮僧人并描述这一现象并提供有力证据的人肯定会获得诺贝尔物理学奖。但这样的事情并没有发生。

Another good friend tells you that Tibetan monks can float in the air when they meditate. After a bit of thought, you conclude that his claim runs headlong against the entire modern scientific worldview. It contradicts all our experience involving gravity and the classical laws that govern the motion of objects that are subject to forces. Now this doesn’t mean that you can prove, with watertight mathematical rigor, that your friend’s claim is wrong. But after a few more minutes of thought, it occurs to you that if Tibetan monks really could hover in the air, this would constitute a revolutionary scientific fact, and it would have spread like wildfire in the news media. The first person to have observed a hovering monk and to have described the phenomenon and given strong evidence for it would surely have received a Nobel Prize in Physics. But no such thing has taken place.

难道这仍是一个全新的现象，只是还没有见诸报端？好吧，你的朋友补充说，冥想的僧侣在半空中悬浮并不是什么新鲜事；事实上，这种现象在西藏已经持续了数千年。他还随口说，他自己没有亲眼目睹过，但他从一位朋友那里听说的，这位朋友认识一位在西藏生活多年的非常聪明的人。

Could it nonetheless be a totally new phenomenon that simply hasn’t yet hit the newspapers? Well, your friend adds that meditating monks who hover in mid-air are nothing new; in fact, this has been going on for thousands of years in Tibet. He also casually states that he himself hasn’t witnessed it, but he heard it from a friend of his, who knew someone very smart who had lived for many years in Tibet.

突然间，你脑子里突然冒出一句口号：“只有当你有充分理由相信一个想法是真的时，你才相信它”。确实存在悬空的僧侣，或者冥想的僧侣无聊地停留在地面上。在虚心考虑了朋友的说法后，你决定有充分的理由相信，世界上所有的僧侣，包括西藏的僧侣，都受到重力定律的影响，即使在冥想时也是如此，因此他们不太可能——极其不可能——悬空在半空中。

All at once, out of the blue, the little slogan “Believe in an idea if and only if you have good reasons to think it is true” pops into your head. Either there exist hovering monks, or the meditating monks are boringly stuck on the ground. After open-mindedly considering your friend’s statement, you decide that there are good reasons for believing that all the monks in the world, including those in Tibet, are subject to the laws of gravity, even when they are meditating, and so they are very unlikely—fantastically unlikely—to be hovering in mid-air.

你得出这个结论并不表明你过于怀疑或固执己见。恰恰相反！这表明你非常乐于思考你遇到的新事物，你会小心谨慎地考虑各种说法，尤其是非常谨慎地考虑一些不同寻常的说法。在这种情况下，你的仔细思考让你得出结论：你的朋友很可能被他自己的朋友蒙蔽了双眼，或者在证人和说闲话的人的链条中有一个薄弱环节，他不知不觉地被骗了，甚至在撒谎。

The fact that you draw this conclusion doesn’t show that you are overly skeptical or dogmatically closed minded. Quite the contrary! It shows that you are highly open to thinking about new things that come your way, that you consider claims with care, and extraordinary claims with extraordinary amounts of care. In this case, your careful reflection led you to the conclusion that your friend most likely was hoodwinked by his own friend, or perhaps that in the chain of witnesses and tale-tellers there was one weak link, who was unwittingly taken in, or who even was lying.

揭开难以置信的面纱

Unmasking What Is Implausible

另一种寻找合理思考不寻常主张的绝佳方法是所谓的归谬法。基本上，这个想法是进行一个思想实验。首先，你假设你正在考虑的想法是正确的，然后尽你所能看看它的真实性会导致什么样的后果。它会导致荒谬吗？如果是这样，那么得出这个假设是错误的结论是很有意义的。

Another excellent method for finding a reasonable way to think about unusual claims is the principle called reductio ad absurdum. Basically, the idea is to carry out a thought experiment. First you suppose that the idea you’re considering is true, and then you do your best to see what sorts of consequences its truth would lead to. Could it lead to absurdities? If so, it makes good sense to conclude that the tentative assumption is false.

让我们来思考一下物理学中这种思想实验的经典例子。4

Let’s think about a classic example of such a thought experiment in physics.4

大约 2300 年前，亚里士多德声称不同质量的物体下落的速度不同。他认为，一磅重的石头下落的速度比十磅重的石头慢。但近 2000 年后，伽利略认为亚里士多德错了，所有物体下落的速度实际上都一样快（在真空中）。5伽利略能够推理出这一结论。他的归谬法思路如下。

Some 2,300 years ago, Aristotle claimed that objects having different masses fall at different speeds. A stone weighing one pound falls more slowly than a stone weighing ten pounds, so he thought. But nearly 2,000 years later, Galileo believed that Aristotle had been wrong, and that all objects actually fall equally fast (in a vacuum).5 Galileo was able to reason his way to this conclusion. Here is how his reductio ad absurdum line of thought ran.

假设亚里士多德是对的，十磅重的石头下落的速度比一磅重的石头快得多。现在让我们想象一下，在松开两块石头之前，用一根很细的绳子把它们绑在一起。十磅重的石头会被下落较慢的一磅重的石头拉住。相反，较轻的石头会被较重的石头拉得更快。因此，轻的石头会比没有被绑住时下落得更快，而较重的石头会比没有被绑住时下落得更慢。结论是，两块绑在一起的石头（总重11磅）下落的速度会比单独放置10磅石头时的速度慢一些。但这与亚里士多德的说法相矛盾，亚里士多德认为，较重的物体（11 磅的“组合石”）下落的速度会比较轻的物体（10 磅的石头）更快。

Let’s suppose that Aristotle was right, and that a ten-pound stone falls much faster than a one-pound stone falls. So now let’s imagine tying the two stones together with a very light string before we release them. The ten-pound stone will be held back by the slower-falling one-pound stone. Conversely, the lighter stone will be pulled along faster by the heavier one. So the light stone will fall faster than it would have if it were not tied to anything, while the heavier stone will fall more slowly than it would have otherwise. The conclusion is that the two tied-together stones, which together weigh eleven pounds, will fall a bit more slowly than the ten-pound stone would fall when on its own. But this contradicts Aristotle’s claim, which is that a heavier object (the eleven-pound “compound stone”) will fall more quickly than a lighter object (the ten-pound stone).

因此，我们仅凭想象推理就得出了这样的结论：复合石块下落的速度既比 10 磅重的石块慢，又比它快。这是荒谬的（显然，两个相反的结论不能同时成立），因此，我们必须推翻导致我们陷入这个箱形峡谷的最初假设（即亚里士多德的说法）。

And so, by using pure imaginative reasoning, we have reached the conclusion that the compound stone will fall both more slowly and also more quickly than the ten-pound stone. This is absurdum (two opposite conclusions cannot both hold at the same time, obviously), and as a result, we have to revoke the initial assumption (namely, Aristotle’s claim) that led us into this box canyon.

因此，归谬法的原理是，首先通过尝试假设某个主张为真来“尝试”该主张，然后通过推理确定这个想法是否会导致自相矛盾（或完全不合理的后果）。如果发生这种情况，那么人们应该回过头来拒绝暂时假设为真的主张。简而言之，这是归谬法的秘诀：

The principle of reductio ad absurdum, then, is that one first “tries on” a claim by tentatively assuming it’s true, and then determining if this idea leads, via reasoning, to a self-contradiction (or to completely unreasonable consequences). If this happens, then one should go back and reject the claim that was tentatively assumed true. In short, here’s the reductio ad absurdum recipe:

  1. 假设你被告知的主张X是正确的。
  2. Assume that Claim X, which you’ve been told, is true.
  3. 通过推理，检查这会导致的后果。
  4. By reasoning, check out the consequences that this would lead to.
  5. 如果它导致疯狂或自相矛盾的后果，则拒绝主张 X。
  6. If it leads to crazy or self-contradictory consequences, reject Claim X.

这是另一个关于归谬法如何运作的例子。一位流动发明家敲开你的门，试图向你推销一块小水晶。他告诉你，这块水晶中蕴含着奇妙的能量，如果你戴在身上，你会感觉非常好。此外，如果你把水晶放在车里，你的油耗会降低 20%。这块水晶的价格只有 99 美元，转眼间你就能用省下的油费弥补它的成本。那么……你应该相信这个吗？

Here’s another example of how reductio ad absurdum works. An itinerant inventor knocks at your door and tries to sell you a little crystal. He tells you that this crystal has fantastic energies trapped inside it, and that you will feel incredibly good if you wear it on your body. Moreover, if you place the crystal inside your car, your fuel consumption will go down by 20 percent. The crystal costs only $99, so quick as a wink you’ll make up for its cost in your fuel savings. So . . . should you believe this?

让我们看看我们是否能利用归谬法原理。让我们假设发明者说的是实话。因此，这种晶体的工作原理与广告宣传的完全一致。那么，既然如此，为什么所有汽车制造商不都已经将这种晶体内置到他们的汽车中呢？任何一家汽车制造商都会欣喜若狂，因为有这样一种装置，他们的汽车比竞争对手的汽车效率高 20%！这在市场上将是多么不可思议的优势！

Let’s see if we can make use of the principle of reductio ad absurdum. So let’s assume the inventor is telling the truth. The crystal thus works exactly as advertised. Well, in that case, why wouldn’t all auto manufacturers have already built such crystals into their vehicles? Any of them would be overjoyed to have a device that would make their cars 20 percent more efficient than their competitors’ cars! What an incredible advantage that would be in the marketplace!

那么，难道不是因为发明者还没有告诉任何汽车制造商这个小装置吗？嗯……那么为什么发明家会向所有汽车制造商隐瞒极其宝贵的信息吗？假设通用汽车 (GM) 可以购买这种晶体的专有权，并可以获得通用技术的专利。如果所有通用汽车的效率都比竞争对手高出 20%，通用汽车将获得相对于所有竞争对手汽车制造商的巨大优势。

Well, couldn’t it simply be the case that the inventor hasn’t yet told any car manufacturer about this little device? Hmm. . . . Now why would an inventor hold back incredibly valuable information from all auto manufacturers? Suppose that General Motors (GM) could purchase exclusive rights to this crystal and could also get a patent for the general technique. If all GM cars were 20 percent more efficient than their rivals, GM would gain a huge advantage over all rival car makers.

现在，通用汽车极有可能愿意为这个绝佳机会向发明者支付一大笔钱。那么，为什么发明者不选择用这种非常简单的方式致富呢？他可能是一个非常理想主义的人，只想帮助世界，对金钱问题毫不在意吗？但在这种情况下，他为什么要以 99 美元的价格卖给你他的水晶呢？他为什么不直接把他的水晶送给你（和其他人）呢？正如你所见，整个场景变得越来越不合理、越来越荒谬、越来越愚蠢、越来越荒谬。所以，归根结底，我们正在处理一个荒谬的归谬法案例。

Now in all likelihood, GM would be willing to pay the inventor a very high sum for this marvelous opportunity. So why hasn’t the inventor chosen to become hugely rich in this very simple manner? Is he perhaps a highly idealistic person who merely wishes to help the world, and who doesn’t give a hoot about money matters? But in that case, why is he trying to sell you his crystal for $99? Why isn’t he just giving his crystals away to you (and others)? As you can see, the whole scenario is growing more and more unreasonable, more and more absurd, more and more dumb, more and more absurdum. And so, bottom line, we are dealing with a case of reductio ad absurdum.

我们首先假设这位流浪发明家说的是真话，然后我们表明这种假设导致了荒谬的后果。结果是这位发明家关于他的水晶的说法几乎肯定是错误的。

We first presumed that the wandering inventor was telling the truth, and then we showed that this assumption led to absurd consequences. The upshot is that the inventor’s claim about his crystal has been shown to be almost certainly false.

在现实世界中，没有一种推理方法是绝对正确的，即使在数学领域，真正杰出的思想家也会在思维过程中犯下严重错误。让我们来看看乔瓦尼·吉罗拉莫·萨凯里 (1667-1733) 的奇怪案例，他是一位非常有独创性的意大利数学家和耶稣会牧师，他一生的最高目标是通过严格证明欧几里得的平行公设（前面提到过）是正确的来捍卫他的英雄欧几里得。

No method of reasoning is infallible in the real world, and even inside mathematics, truly brilliant thinkers can make serious mistakes in their thought processes. Let us take a look at the curious case of Giovanni Girolamo Saccheri (1667–1733), a very original Italian mathematician and Jesuit priest whose life’s highest goal was to defend his hero Euclid by rigorously proving that Euclid’s parallel postulate (mentioned earlier) was true.

在萨凯里之前，许多人都曾尝试过这种方法（尽管总是徒劳无功），但没有人敢走归谬法的路。萨凯里认为这是一条理想的道路，于是他勇敢地假设欧几里得平行公设的否定为真。这当然是一种大胆的做法。这位大胆的耶稣会士随后证明了一个又一个全新的定理，所有这些定理都基于这个奇怪的新公设，这个公设是他鄙视的，但他还是决定去探索。尽管每个新定理都与他的直觉相悖，但萨凯里还是咬紧牙关，坚持写了几百页。终于有一天，他得出了一个令他感到极其奇怪和难以置信的结果（即三角形的面积存在一个最大可能值），他赶紧举手投降，并宣称：“这个结果与直线的性质相悖！ ”

Before Saccheri’s day, many people had tried to do this (though always in vain), but none had ventured down the reductio ad absurdum pathway. Saccheri decided that this was the ideal route to follow, so he took a wild bull by the horns by assuming that the negation of Euclid’s parallel postulate was true. This was certainly a daring approach. The bold Jesuit then proceeded to prove one brand-new theorem after another after another, all of them based on this strange new postulate, the postulate that he despised but had nonetheless decided to explore. Although each new theorem ran deeply against his intuitions, Saccheri just gritted his teeth and kept on going for a couple of hundred pages. Finally one day, he hit a result that struck him as so extremely strange and implausible (namely, that there is a maximum possible area for triangles) that he effectively threw up his hands and famously proclaimed, “This result is repugnant to the nature of the straight line!”

对他来说，这意味着他遇到了完全荒谬的事情。这正是他想要的！哈利路亚！按照前面讨论过的归谬法，萨凯里欣喜地回过头来，拒绝了导致“令人厌恶”结果的最初假设——当然，这个假设是对欧几里得神圣平行公设的否定。好吧，如果必须拒绝对欧几里得公设的否定，那么就必须接受欧几里得公设本身。目标实现了！好极了！

This meant to him that he had hit up against total absurdity. Just what he wanted! Hallelujah! Following the reductio ad absurdum recipe discussed earlier, Saccheri joyously went back and rejected the initial assumption that was responsible for the “repugnant” result—and this assumption, of course, was the negation of Euclid’s sacred parallel postulate. Well, if the negation of Euclid’s postulate had to be rejected, then Euclid’s postulate itself had to be accepted. Goal achieved! Hurrah!

萨凯里在生命的最后阶段出版了一本名为《Euclides ab omni naevo vindicatus》（摆脱所有缺陷的欧几里得）的书，在书中他阐述了自己的发现。由于这本书及其充满自信的书名，人们一度相信，至少部分人相信，欧几里得的平行公设终于得到了严格证明，欧几里得得到了证明。对于萨凯里和欧几里得来说，这是多么快乐的日子啊！

Near the end of his life, Saccheri published a book called Euclides ab omni naevo vindicatus (Euclid Freed of Every Flaw) in which he set forth his findings, and thanks to this book and its self-confident title, it was believed for a while, at least by some, that Euclid’s parallel postulate had finally been rigorously proven, and that Euclid had been vindicated. What a happy day for Saccheri and for Euclid!

但不幸的是，萨凯里内心深处的“厌恶”并不是真正的矛盾或悖论。这只是一种情绪反应，一种直觉，一种直觉。大约在萨凯里去世一百年后，其他几位勇敢的数学家（最著名的是匈牙利数学家亚诺什·波约耶和俄罗斯数学家尼古拉·罗巴切夫斯基）追随他的脚步，拒绝了欧几里得的平行公设，并接受了与之相反的公设——但这些坚强的人并没有简单地宣称他们的结果荒谬或令人厌恶，而是慢慢地开始看到一种新的几何形状在他们眼前形成，这种几何形状的“直线”并不像欧几里得线那样笔直，但其内在的逻辑虽然令人惊讶，但却无可挑剔。事实上，在这种几何形状中，三角形的最大可能面积是完全合理的。于是非欧几里得几何就同时在匈牙利和俄罗斯诞生了——事实上，是双重诞生。

But unfortunately, the “repugnance” that Saccheri felt so viscerally was not a true contradiction or paradox. It was just an emotional reaction, just a gut feeling, just an intuition. And roughly one hundred years after Saccheri’s death, a few other courageous mathematicians (most famously, the Hungarian János Bolyai and the Russian Nikolai Lobachevsky) followed in his footsteps by rejecting Euclid’s parallel postulate and accepting a rival postulate in its place—but these hardy souls, instead of simply declaring their results absurd or repugnant, slowly began to see a new kind of geometry taking shape before their eyes, one whose “straight lines” weren’t straight in the same way that Euclidean lines are straight, but one whose inherent internal logic, though surprising, was nonetheless impeccable. Indeed, it was perfectly reasonable—in this geometry—that there was a maximum possible area for triangles. And thus was born non-Euclidean geometry—indeed, doubly born—in both Hungary and Russia at the same time.

由于他的先入之见过于固执，可怜的萨凯里神父错失了创立“萨凯几何”的机会。虽然他很勇敢，但勇气不够。他滥用了归谬法原理，声称自己太早、太容易地发现了他渴望已久的荒谬。“对直线性质的厌恶”并不是把他所有奇怪的定理抛诸脑后的充分理由。因此，教训是，一个人必须极其小心地思考，不要让自己太容易被偏见所左右（或误导）。当然，说起来容易做起来难。毕竟，在很多方面，合理和明智是一门艺术，而不是一门科学。

Because he was too rigid in his preconceptions, poor Padre Saccheri missed his chance at founding what would surely have been called “Saccherian geometry.” Though courageous, he was not courageous enough. He misused the principle of reductio ad absurdum by claiming to have found the longed-for absurdity a bit too early, a bit too easily. “Repugnance to the nature of the straight line” was not a good enough reason to throw all his strange theorems out the window. And so the lesson is that one has to be extremely careful in one’s thinking, and not let oneself be too easily led (or misled) by one’s prejudices. This is easier said than done, of course. After all, in many ways, being reasonable and sensible is an art, not a science.

许多人愿意将神奇的力量归因于异国西藏僧侣，将治愈能力归因于神秘的水晶，将超自然力量归因于稀有人类。如果有人对这些归因表示怀疑，通常会遇到这样的反对：“你无法证明僧侣在冥想时没有悬空！你为什么这么狭隘？你应该更开明一点！不是所有事情都能用科学来解释！多表现一点谦虚吧！”

Many people are willing to attribute magical powers to exotic Tibetan monks, or healing powers to mysterious crystals, or paranormal powers to rare human beings. If one then expresses skepticism about these attributions, one often runs into the objection, “You can’t prove that the monks aren’t hovering in mid-air when they’re meditating! Why are you so limited? You should be more open minded! Not everything can be explained through science! Show a bit more humility!”

我们再次发现自己陷入了普遍的、非理性的反理性偏见之中。在如此具有挑战性的背景下，重申这一事实就变得更加重要：几乎不可能有比一个愿意接受各种想法、考虑其后果并接受任何得到最有力支持的想法的人更开放的思想。相反，如果有人愿意接受缺乏任何有力证据支持的想法，并且即使出现强有力的证据支持相反的想法，他们也不准备改变主意，那么这个人很难被称为“开放的”。事实上，这种僵化、教条的立场是封闭偏见的标志。

We find ourselves once again among the widespread and irrational prejudices against rationality. In such a challenging context, it becomes all the more crucial to repeat the fact that it is hardly possible to be more open minded than a person who is willing to entertain ideas of all sorts, who will consider their consequences, and who will accept whichever ideas turn out to have the strongest support. If, by contrast, someone is willing to buy into ideas that lack any strong evidential support, and if they are not prepared to change their mind even when strong evidence appears for rival ideas, then that person can hardly be called “open minded.” In fact, such an inflexible, dogmatic stance is the hallmark of closed-minded prejudice.

这些讨论中的一个特殊情况是当问题涉及某事物是否存在时。不可能给出某事物不存在的铁证（例如大脚怪或尼斯湖水怪），但原则上完全有可能给出某事物存在的有力证据。

A special case in these discussions is when the question concerns whether or not something exists. It’s not possible to give an ironclad proof of something’s nonexistence (think of Bigfoot or the Loch Ness monster, for instance), but in principle it is quite possible to give strong evidence of something’s existence.

假设你有一位朋友声称绿天鹅存在。

So suppose you have a friend who claims that there exist green swans.

“不，不，不！”你抗议道。“没有这种东西！绿天鹅根本不存在！”

“No, no, no!” you protest. “There aren’t any such things! Green swans don’t exist!”

“给我提供证据来证明这一说法！”你的朋友反驳道。

“Give me evidence for that claim!” retorts your friend.

好吧，现在你陷入了困境。如果你想给出强有力的证据证明没有绿天鹅，你就必须走遍地球，检查你遇到的每一只天鹅。但即使这样也不足以证明你的说法。你还必须明确证明你在搜寻过程中没有错过一只天鹅。这太过分了！

Well, now you’re in a fix. If you want to give powerful evidence that there aren’t any green swans, you’ll have to travel throughout the earth and check out every last swan that you come across. But even that won’t suffice to prove your claim. You also have to definitively prove that you didn’t miss a single swan in your search. That’s too much!

你认为不存在绿天鹅的信念建立在你和他人的观察中都没有绿天鹅的基础上。但你无法给出绿天鹅不存在的无可辩驳的证据——只能给出部分证据。（顺便说一句，假设绿天鹅确实存在不会导致荒谬，因此归谬法在这种情况下不起作用。）另一方面，如果你的朋友想证明你错了，她所需要做的就是拿出一只绿天鹅！因此，似乎负担证据在你的朋友身上，而不是你身上。你可以平静地靠在扶手椅上，建议她去追逐绿天鹅。

Your belief that there don’t exist green swans is built upon the lack of green swans both in your own observations and in those of other people. But you can’t give irrefutable evidence for the nonexistence of green swans—only partial evidence. (And by the way, assuming that green swans do exist will not lead to an absurdity, so the reductio approach won’t work in this case.) On the other hand, if your friend wants to prove you wrong, all she needs to do is to produce one single green swan! It would seem, then, that the burden of proof lies on your friend, not on you. You can calmly lean back in your armchair and suggest to her that she should set out on her green swan chase.

西藏僧侣在空中盘旋的情况也大体如此。如果僧侣在冥想时能飞翔，那么证明他们存在应该轻而易举；你只需要让其中一人在受控条件下飞翔，然后找人拍下他们的视频。但要证明他们不存在，你只能提供部分证据。正如我们之前所说，证明某物不存在的证据必然是较弱的——零散的证据，综合起来，形成一个合理的趋势。然而，在所谓空中盘旋的僧侣的案例中，这种证明他们不存在的部分证据仍然构成一个强有力的论据（只要没有确凿的证据支持他们在空中盘旋）。

Much the same holds for the case of the hovering Tibetan monks. If monks can fly while meditating, then it should be easy as pie to show that they exist; all you need is that one of them should do so under controlled conditions, and have someone take a video of them. But to show they don’t exist, all you can do is present partial evidence. As we said earlier, the evidence for something’s nonexistence is necessarily of a weaker sort—scattered pieces of evidence that, taken together, add up to a plausible trend. In the case of the allegedly hovering monks, however, such partial evidence of their nonexistence still amounts to a strong argument (as long as no concrete evidence turns up in favor of their hovering).

在所有关于某个假设实体（盘旋的僧侣、喜马拉雅雪人、超感知觉、希格斯玻色子、绿天鹅、魔鬼、鬼魂、暗物质、亚特兰蒂斯大陆、上帝）存在或不存在存在争议的情况下，举证责任都在于那些声称该实体存在的人。

In all situations where there is a dispute about the existence or nonexistence of some hypothesized entity (hovering monks, the Himalayan Yeti, ESP, the Higgs boson, a green swan, the devil, ghosts, dark matter, the continent of Atlantis, God), the burden of proof lies on those who claim the entity in question exists.

插曲：探索国际象棋中的对手动作和人生游戏中的对手动作

INTERLUDE: ON EXPLORING RIVAL MOVES IN CHESS AND RIVAL MOVES IN THE GAME OF LIFE

你是国际象棋选手吗？我希望如此——至少偶尔会下。

Are you a chess player? I hope so—at least an occasional player.

你的棋艺越高超，在采取下一步行动之前考虑的可能行动集就越小。这听起来很奇怪吗？

The better a chess player you are, the smaller the set of possible moves you will consider before making your next move. Does that sound odd?

其实不应该。下棋的目的是找出最佳走法，而你必须在非常有限的时间内完成这一目标，因为棋钟总是在滴答作响（至少在严肃的竞技比赛中）；因此，关键是不要浪费宝贵的时间去检查一大堆糟糕的走法。相反，你需要将注意力集中在那些有希望的几步走法上，当然，你的目标是从中选出最好的一步。

Well, it shouldn’t. The goal in chess is to find the best move, and you have to do so in a very limited amount of time, since the chess clock is always ticking away (at least in serious competitive play); therefore, it’s key not to waste precious time checking out a whole bunch of terrible moves. Instead, you want your mind to pinpoint and focus down on just those few moves that are promising, and among those, of course, your goal is to pick the very best one.

同样，当我们面对复杂的世界时，我们也能——也必须——凭借多年经验所积累的知识，尽最大努力快速分辨出哪些是好的，哪些是坏的，从而优先考虑下一步该走哪条路（即在人生游戏中下一步该走哪一步）。只有这样，我们才能对世界有更深的理解。

Much the same holds when we find ourselves facing questions about the complex world we live in: with the help of knowledge accumulated over years of experience, we can—and we must—do our very best to quickly sort out promising from unpromising potential futures and thus prioritize our mental explorations of what path to take next (that is, which “move” to make next in the game of life). Only in this way can we reach deeper levels of understanding of the world.

长期经验所获得的广博、深奥和细致的知识的一个极其重要的功能是，它可以帮助人们将探索保持在合理的限度内——顺便说一句，“限度”一词通常带有负面含义，但在这里并不适用。恰恰相反，我的意思是具有高度积极影响的限制。

One extremely central function of the vast, deep, and intimate knowledge that comes out of long experience is that it can help keep one’s explorations within reasonable limits—and by the way, the negative connotations usually attached to the word “limit” don’t apply here. Quite the contrary, I mean limitations that have highly positive effects.

为了具体说明我的意思，我将用国际象棋来比喻生活。在棋盘上出现的大多数情况下，原则上每个玩家可以采取大约 35 种不同的走法。（这取决于玩家处于游戏的开局阶段、中局还是残局，但一般来说 35 种走法是相当准确的估计。）然而，熟练的国际象棋玩家知道，几乎所有这 35 种走法都不是很好——事实上，大多数都很糟糕。因此，优秀的玩家会迅速将注意力集中在少数几步走法上——最多三、四或五步。他们如何从这 35 种走法中挑选出这些精选的几步呢？这全归功于多年的经验！

To show concretely what I mean, I will use chess as a metaphor for life. In most situations that arise on a chessboard, each player has about thirty-five different moves that could be made in principle. (It depends a bit on whether one is in an opening stage of the game, in the middlegame, or in the endgame, but thirty-five is a pretty accurate estimate in general.) A skilled chess player knows, however, that nearly all of those thirty-five-odd moves are not very good—in fact, most of them are downright terrible. And so good players quickly focus down on just a handful of moves—three, four, or five at most. And how do they pick those select few out of the thirty-five? It’s all thanks to years of experience!

在复杂的国际象棋比赛中，国际象棋大师试图快速从各种可能中找出明智之举，找出熟悉的模式，并将其与多年比赛中遇到的情况进行巧妙的类比。对国际象棋情况的深入了解大大减少了国际象棋大师寻找下一步行动的时间。国际象棋经验较少的人根本看不到这些模式，也找不到这些类比。由于缺乏经验，他们会接受国际象棋大师一瞬间就会放弃的各种动作，甚至不知道自己哪里出了问题。

In a complex situation in a chess game, a Grandmaster, trying to rapidly sort out the wise possibilities from the wild ones, spots familiar patterns and makes subtle analogies to situations previously encountered throughout years and years of play. This intimate knowledge of chess situations drastically reduces the Grandmaster’s search for what to do next. People who have less chess experience simply won’t see those patterns and won’t spot those analogies. Because of their lack of experience, they will be open to all sorts of moves that the Grandmaster would discard in a flash, and they won’t even have an inkling of what’s deeply wrong with them.

大师级棋手显然不应该听从刚学会规则的孩子的胡思乱想，甚至不应该听从下过一百盘棋的狂热业余棋手的“建议”。听取这些新手的意见会完全浪费大师级棋手宝贵的时间，因为棋钟正在滴答作响。千万不要这么开放！毕竟，棋局就像生命一样，是有限的！

A Grandmaster should obviously not listen to the random musings of a child who’s just learned the rules, nor even to the “advice” offered by an enthusiastic amateur who’s played a hundred games. Listening to such novices would be an utter waste of the Grandmaster’s crucial time, with that chess clock ticking away. It’s vitally important not to be that open minded! After all, chess games, like lives, are finite!

但是，什么时候该划清界限呢？特级大师是否应该听从一位赢得过几场地方锦标赛的 12 岁国际象棋神童的直觉？或者假设这位年轻的国际象棋神童最近与马格努斯·卡尔森（2021 年现任世界冠军）交手，并让他大吃一惊？什么时候应该放开思路，接受那些原本看似出乎意料的想法？好吧，这些都是微妙的判断，显然没有固定的秘诀可以完美地给出“正确”的答案。

But at what point does one draw the line? Should a Grandmaster listen to the intuitions of a twelve-year-old chess prodigy who has won a few local tournaments? Or suppose that this young chess prodigy had recently played against Magnus Carlsen (the current world champion as of 2021) and given him a run for his money? At what point should one open one’s mind up and entertain ideas that might otherwise seem to be coming out of left field? Well, these are subtle judgment calls, and obviously there can be no fixed recipe that will flawlessly give the “right” answer.

在日常生活中，我们不可能一直对一切保持开放态度。我们不可能探索所有善意的建议四面八方。我们必须依靠自己的亲身经历（以及我们所拥有的间接经验）来筛选出明智的人选，以便我们能够快速缩小选择范围。

In everyday life, we simply cannot constantly be open minded about everything. We can’t explore all well-meaning suggestions coming at us from all directions. We have to rely on our own personal experience (and the vicarious experiences we have had) to sort out the wise from the wild, allowing us to quickly pare down our options.

因此，如果你以前每次尝到肝脏都讨厌它，那么你不必再持开放态度尝试它。同样，我也不能继续尝试阅读我过去一直讨厌的作者的新书，即使一堆封底宣传对这些书大加赞赏。而 Birgitta，尽管她的朋友 Gunilla 善意地劝说，也不必继续尝试她已经尝试过几次的相同的在线约会服务，而且总是以灾难性的结果。要有足够的自信来依靠你的经验！（只要你有很多经验。）

Thus you don’t have to be open minded about trying liver yet again, if every time you tasted it in the past you always hated it. And by the same token, I can’t afford to keep on trying to read new books by an author whom I’ve always hated in the past, even if a bunch of back-cover blurbs praise the books to the skies. And Birgitta, despite the well-meaning urgings of her friend Gunilla, doesn’t have to keep on trying the same online dating service that she has already tried several times, always with utterly disastrous results. Be self-confident enough to rely on your experience! (As long as you have lots of it, that is.)

如果你在生活的某个方面拥有丰富的知识和经验，你就可以而且应该有足够的自信迅速拒绝大多数随机的想法和善意的建议，就像大师迅速拒绝新手的建议一样。当然，偶尔的外部建议是好的，希望你（或大师）有足够的经验来认识到这种建议与其他建议的质量不同。但当然，没有绝对的保证。通过迅速拒绝大多数外部建议，你自然会冒着丢掉宝贵的东西的风险——把孩子和洗澡水一起倒掉——但这就是生活。生活就像国际象棋一样，总是要冒险——但希望这是深思熟虑的冒险，深思熟虑的冒险，植根于多年的经验。

If you have much knowledge and experience in a given aspect of life, you can and you should be sufficiently self-confident to rapidly dismiss most of the random ideas and well-meant suggestions that come your way, just like the Grandmaster who rapidly dismisses suggestions from greenhorns. Of course, the occasional outside suggestion is good, and hopefully you (or the Grandmaster) will have had enough experience to recognize that that suggestion is different in quality from the others. But, of course, there’s no ironclad guarantee. By rapidly dismissing most outside suggestions, you naturally run the risk of throwing out something precious—throwing out the baby with the bathwater—but that’s life. Life, like chess, is always a matter of risk taking—but hopefully it’s well-considered risk taking, thoughtful risk taking, rooted in long years of experience.

假设数学家 A 多年来一直在探索数论中的某个难题，并将这个问题告诉了不是数论学家的数学家 B。B 从未听说过这个问题，他脱口而出：“嘿，我认为这可能与素数的分布有关。你应该看看。”A 是否应该突然放下一切，尝试探索 B 的直觉？当然，在这种情况下，有各种各样的未知因素，但在其他所有条件相同的情况下，知识渊博的 A 仅仅因为 B 这个外行人的反应而立即改变思路，这是完全没有意义的。B 说的话很可能是幼稚和错误的。当然，如果 B 是 A 所从事的数论领域的世界级专家，情况就会大不相同，因为那时 B 也会从中汲取深厚而广博的知识。

Suppose that mathematician A has been exploring a certain difficult problem in number theory for many years and tells mathematician B, who is not a number theorist, about the problem. B, who has never heard the problem before, blurts out, “Hey, I think it probably has to do with the distribution of the prime numbers. You should check it out.” Should A just suddenly drop everything and try to explore B’s hunch? Well, there are of course all sorts of unknown factors in such a situation, but all other things being equal, it wouldn’t make any sense at all for the far more knowledgeable A to just switch tracks instantly, simply because B, a greenhorn outsider, reacted that way. Most likely what B said is naïve and wrong. Of course, it would be very different were B a world expert in the area of number theory that A is working in, because then B, too, would be drawing on deep and vast knowledge.

尽管我们不应该将生活与下棋混为一谈，但人们肯定可以从下棋与生活的奇妙类比中获得启发。

Although one should not confuse life with a chess game, one can certainly gain insights from the wonderful analogies to life that chess playing affords.

第四章

CHAPTER FOUR

什么是科学？关于理论、实验、结论和科学的本质

WHAT IS SCIENCE? Concerning Theories, Experiments, Conclusions, and Science’s Essence

整个科学不过是日常思维的提炼。——阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦，《物理与现实》，1936 年

The whole of science is nothing more than a refinement of everyday thinking.—Albert Einstein, Physics and Reality, 1936

一个每时每刻，我们都在建立关于事物在世界上如何运作的信念。如果没有关于世界本质的这种信念，我们就会迷失方向：我们不知道在面对任何情况时该做什么。因此，每个人的大脑都在不断努力工作，试图尽可能多地理解周围发生的事情。1

At every moment we are building up beliefs about how things behave in our world. Without such beliefs about the world’s nature, we would be lost: we wouldn’t have any idea what to do in any situation we faced. Each human brain is therefore constantly hard at work, trying to make as much sense as it possibly can of what is going on in its surroundings.1

人类对世界的了解越多，我们寻求新知识的动力就越大。这种滚雪球式的过程从生命早期就开始了；想想一个小孩为了生存和不伤害自己需要掌握多少知识——好奇的孩子通过玩耍实验获得这些知识，就像好奇的科学家进行细致的实验一样。在探索周围环境时，孩子会不断尝试，把各种各样的东西放进嘴里尝尝，扭动和翻转东西，试着把一个东西放进另一个东西里，建塔并看着它们倒塌，爬上桌子和椅子，钻到床底下，在沙发上跳上跳下——简而言之，就是不断地检查一切。

The more we humans come to understand the world, the more inspired we are to go hunting for new knowledge. This snowballing process starts early in life; just think how much knowledge a small child has to have in order to survive and not hurt itself—and the curious child acquires such knowledge by playful experimentation, just like a curious scientist carrying out careful experiments. When exploring its environment, the child proceeds by trial and error, putting all sorts of objects in its mouth to taste them, twisting and turning things about, trying to put one thing into another thing, building towers and watching them fall down, climbing up on tables and chairs, sliding under beds, jumping on and off of sofas—in short, incessantly checking everything out.

当然，孩子们最终会受到瘀伤、割伤、抓伤、刺伤和电击——但这些因无尽的好奇心而产生的痛苦会一点一点地让孩子们对世界是如何形成和运作的有了更广泛、更深入、更亲密的理解。这包括对其他人、各种动物、树木和植物、水、天气和风的感觉，对什么会浮在水面上什么会沉下去的感觉，对什么味道好什么味道不好的感觉。孩子们了解了马车、三轮车、自行车和汽车，了解了电、电线、插头和插座，了解了烤面包机、炉灶、冰箱和微波炉……

Children, of course, wind up getting bruises, cuts, scratches, splinters, and shocks—but bit by bit, all of this pain due to endless curiosity leads the child to an ever vaster, ever deeper, ever more intimate understanding of how the world is made and how it works. This includes a sense for other people, for all sorts of animals, for trees and plants, for water, weather, and wind, for what will float and what will sink, for what tastes good and what tastes bad. The child learns about wagons, tricycles, bicycles, and cars, about electricity, wires, plugs and outlets, about toasters, stoves, refrigerators, and microwave ovens . . .

幼儿对世界的知识，只有一小部分来自成人的描述和解释，但大部分知识来自幼儿自己的探索和反复试验。然而，随着幼儿的成长，他们所获得的知识开始越来越多地来自他人，而不是他们自己的亲身经历。曾经频繁的直接测试变得越来越分散，信息越来越多地来自以下活动：阅读书籍、杂志和报纸；看电视、电影和视频；在网上仔细搜索想要的东西；在网上偶然发现随机的东西；与朋友进行无数次意想不到的对话；吸收由此获得的间接见解；倾听和思考在广阔的公共话语舞台上听到的无数相互矛盾的观点……

A small part of a young child’s world knowledge is acquired from adults who describe things and explain things, but the majority comes from the child’s own poking around and exploring, from repeated trials and errors. Eventually, though, as children grow, the knowledge they are acquiring starts to come more and more from other people, rather than from their own personal experiences. The direct tests that once were so frequent become more and more spaced out, and instead information comes more and more often from such activities as reading books, magazines, and newspapers; watching television, movies, and videos; carefully searching for desired things on the web; accidentally bumping into random things on the web; having countless unpredictable conversations with friends; absorbing the vicarious insights that are thus made available; listening to and pondering the myriad clashing opinions that one hears in the wide arena of public discourse . . .

当然，许多相互冲突的观点只是观点，而不是事实。而且，它们中的大多数几乎在我们的生活中不起任何作用。当然，我们可能会不断阅读和记录所谓的“新闻”，但只要它不直接影响我们，我们就不需要对其真实性或非真实性持立场（尽管我们有时可能会出于兴趣或好奇心，更仔细地思考我们遇到的某些说法）。然而，当某个说法或观点出于某种原因对我们个人变得重要时——当我们想将其作为我们自己行动的基础并让它指导我们做出重要决定时——我们就应该回到年轻人的个人试错模式。

Many of these clashing opinions are just opinions, of course—not facts. And most of them play almost no role in our lives. To be sure, we may constantly read and register what is called “news,” but as long as it doesn’t touch us directly, we don’t need to take a position on its truth or lack thereof (although of course we may on occasion be led, by interest or curiosity, to reflect more carefully on certain claims that we’ve encountered). Yet the moment a claim or an opinion becomes important to us personally, for one reason or another—the moment we want to use it as a basis for our own actions and let it guide us in our own vital decisions—that’s when we ought to return to the youngster’s mode of personal trial and error.

这正是科学方法的用武之地。事实上，科学不过是一种更系统的寻求知识的方式，人们使用的方法基本上和小孩子一样：不把任何事情视为理所当然，而是通过扭曲和转动，通过触摸、品尝和嗅闻，通过与具体现实密切互动，亲自检查一切。

And this is exactly where the scientific approach comes in. In truth, science is nothing but a more systematic quest for knowledge, where one uses basically the same methods as little children do: one takes nothing for granted, one checks everything out oneself, by twisting it and turning it around and around, by touching it and tasting it and smelling it, by intimately interacting with concrete reality.

科学的核心

At the Very Heart of Science

科学是一种高度结构化和系统化的方法，通过反复试验来探索广阔的世界。早在公元前 2000 年，巴比伦人（以及不久之后的古希腊哲学家）就开发了调查方法和思维方式，可以说这些方法和思维方式为科学奠定了基础。

Science is a highly structured and systematic method of exploring the wide world by means of trial and error. As early as 2000 BCE, the Babylonians (and not too much later, the ancient Greek philosophers) developed methods of investigation and ways of thinking that can be said to have laid the groundwork for science.

伊斯兰哲学家穆罕默德·伊本·哈桑（965-1038）经常被描述为科学方法的创始人。他住在巴士拉和开罗，写了《光学论》，其中写道：

Islamic philosopher Muhammad ibn al-Hasan (965–1038) is often described as the founder of the scientific method. He lived in Basra and Cairo, and wrote “Kitāb al-Manāẓir” (A Treatise on Optics), which contained,

除其他外，他还对光学和视觉进行了科学描述。他提出了进行系统和重复实验的想法，以支持或反驳假设和理论。他将观察、实验和逻辑推理结合在他的视觉理论中，根据该理论，光线从物体上反射到人的眼睛，而不是相反。2

among other things, a scientific description of optics and of vision. He devised the idea of carrying out systematic and repeated experiments in order to support or refute hypotheses and theories. He combined observations, experiments, and logical reasoning in his theory of vision, according to which light rays bounce off objects and into one’s eyes, rather than the reverse.2

在科学中，事实、假设和理论是有区别的。事实通常是一个非常具体的观察，或实验的结果。理论是一组更大的思想，其目的是预测或解释实验的结果。“理论”一词用于描述一组相互关联的想法，这些想法可以解释特定事件或一般现象。因此，理论比单个陈述更复杂。单独提出的不确定主张通常称为假设（希腊语意为“猜测”）。

In science, a distinction is made among facts, hypotheses, and theories. A fact is usually a very specific observation, or the result of an experiment. A theory is a larger set of ideas whose purpose is to predict or explain the results of experiments. The term “theory” is used to describe a set of interrelated ideas that explain a specific event or a general set of phenomena. Theories are therefore more complex than individual statements. An uncertain claim presented on its own is usually called a hypothesis (a Greek word meaning “guess”).

在进行科学研究时，人们会提出可检验的假设，这些假设来自于他们想要验证的理论。然后根据各种观察和实验来检验这些假设。从这个意义上讲，假设是对一类观察到的现象的首次粗略解释，而理论则是对一类观察到的现象的更雄心勃勃的解释。

When doing science, one proposes testable hypotheses that come from a theory that one wishes to check out. The hypotheses are then checked against various observations and experiments. A hypothesis is, in this sense, a first crude attempt at explaining a narrow class of observed phenomena, while a theory is a more ambitious explanation of a wide class of observed phenomena.

科学理论不仅要与既定事实相符，还必须能够预测至少一些实验的结果。无法做出任何预测的理论是空洞的。因此，假设和理论必须是可检验的——这意味着必须有某种方式可以证伪它们（即证明它们是错误的）。如果一个理论或假设不可检验，那么它在科学上就是无用的。

A scientific theory not only has to be compatible with already-established facts; it also has to be able to predict the results of at least some experiments. A theory that cannot make any predictions is vacuous. Hypotheses and theories therefore have to be testable—meaning that there must be some manner in which they can be falsified (that is, shown to be wrong). If a theory or hypothesis isn’t testable, then it is scientifically useless.

让我们来看看科学史上的一个故事，它清楚地展示了理论和假设之间的区别，也展示了科学的真正运作方式。这就是海王星的发现故事。

Let’s take a look at an episode in the history of science that clearly shows the difference between theories and hypotheses, and that also shows how science really works. This is the story of the discovery of the planet Neptune.

17 世纪初，德国数学家约翰尼斯·开普勒 (1571–1630) 发表了三条描述行星绕太阳运行的定律。除其他外，他指出行星的运动既不是圆形的，也不是匀速的，这违背了数千年来盛行的信念（或可以说是教条）。

At the start of the seventeenth century, German mathematician Johannes Kepler (1571–1630) published three laws describing the motions of planets in their orbits around the sun. He showed, among other things, that the planets’ motions were neither circular in shape nor uniform in speed, thus going against beliefs (or dogmas, one might say) that had reigned for thousands of years.

几十年后，艾萨克·牛顿（1643-1727）提出了自己的引力理论，使开普勒的运动定律更加清晰和精确。他的理论在很多方面都是违反直觉的。毕竟，像太阳这样的天体怎么可能产生一种神秘的力量，这种力量遍布整个太空，并影响到距离它非常遥远的物体？然而，这是牛顿新理论的重要组成部分。许多批评家认为该理论是超自然和神秘的。但到了 19 世纪初，牛顿的引力理论和开普勒描述行星轨道的定律已经牢固确立。

Several decades later, Isaac Newton (1643–1727) made Kepler’s laws of motion clearer and more precise by proposing his own theory of gravitation. In various ways his theory was counterintuitive. After all, how could a heavenly body such as the sun give rise to a mysterious force that pervaded all of space and that affected objects that were immensely remote from it? Yet this was part and parcel of Newton’s new theory. Many critics saw the theory as supernatural and mystical. But by the start of the nineteenth century, Newton’s theory of gravitation and Kepler’s laws describing the planetary orbits were firmly established.

法国天文学家乌尔班·勒威耶（1811-1877）是巴黎索邦大学的教授，他对行星运动进行了广泛的研究。他仔细观察后发现，天王星在穿越星空时，其运动存在非常轻微的不规则性。乍一看，这些异常与牛顿和开普勒定律不符。因此，勒威耶提出了一个假设：天王星轨道的微小偏差一定是由位于天王星轨道之外某处的新未知行星的引力引起的。

French astronomer Urbain Le Verrier (1811–1877) was a professor at the Sorbonne in Paris, and he carried out wide-ranging investigations of the planetary motions. His careful observations revealed that there were very slight irregularities in the motion of the planet Uranus as it crossed the starry vault. These aberrancies could not, at first sight, be reconciled with Newton’s and Kepler’s laws. For this reason, Le Verrier came up with a hypothesis: the tiny deviations in Uranus’s pathway must be caused by the gravitational force due to some new, unknown planet lying somewhere out beyond the orbit of Uranus.

在这一猜测的指导下，他利用他的老朋友——牛顿和开普勒的可靠理论，进行了理论计算。这使他得出了一个具体且可测试的预测：一颗此前从未见过的行星，质量为m，轨道为o，应该可以在时间t和天空位置p处观测到（当然，这些数字是精确的）。然后，他给柏林天文台的天文学家约翰·加勒写了一封信，告诉他应该在何时何地看到这颗假设的行星。这封信于 1846 年 9 月 23 日到达，当天晚上，加勒证实了勒威耶的预测，在预测的确切位置发现了一颗新行星。

Guided by this guess, he then carried out theoretical calculations using his old friends, the reliable theories of Newton and Kepler. This led him to a concrete and testable prediction: A heretofore unseen planet having mass m and following orbit o should be observable at time t and position p in the heavens (where of course these were given as precise figures). He then sent a letter to astronomer Johann Galle at the Berlin Observatory, saying exactly when and where the hypothesized planet should be visible. The letter arrived on September 23, 1846, and that very evening Galle confirmed Le Verrier’s predictions, spotting a new planet exactly where it had been predicted.

这个故事清楚地表明了理论、假设、观察和可测试性之间的关系。然而，许多人认为理论比事实更弱。他们会大喊：“但那只是理论！”这只是对“理论”一词在科学中的用法的误解。

This story clearly shows the relationship among theories, hypotheses, observations, and testability. Many people, nonetheless, think that theories are weaker than facts. They will cry out, “But that’s just a theory!” This is simply a misunderstanding of the word “theory” as it is used in science.

在普通用语中，“理论”一词通常表示某人在没有太多证据的情况下提出的想法。我们经常听到这样的话：“哦，原来这就是你对珠宝从锁着的办公桌抽屉里消失的理论！”或“警方推测有两个劫匪参与其中，而不只是一个。”在这种情况下，“理论”一词意味着一种合理的猜测，已经提出来供人们考虑，但尚未得到任何强有力的支持。

In ordinary parlance, the word “theory” usually denotes an idea proffered by someone without too much evidence. We often hear such things as, “Oh, so that’s your theory as to why the jewel disappeared from the locked desk drawer!” or “The police theorized that two robbers were involved, not just one.” In such cases, the term “theory” means a plausible guess that has been put out there for people to consider as a possibility, but without yet having any strong support.

但在科学界，“理论”一词的含义则大不相同。它描述的是一组紧密相连的思想，这些思想不仅在逻辑上连贯，而且可以解释许多不同的现象，此外，还可以产生新的预测。一组思想必须通过各种方式得到证实才能获得“理论”这一受人尊敬的标签；在此之前，它只是随机的猜测。

But in scientific circles, the word “theory” has quite a different meaning. It describes a set of tightly interrelated ideas that not only are logically coherent but also provide an explanation for many diverse phenomena and, moreover, can give rise to new predictions. A set of ideas has to earn the respected label of “theory” by being confirmed in various ways; until then, it’s just random guesswork.

当然，日常思维和科学思维之间并没有一条严密的界限，因此“理论”一词具有一定程度的模糊性。有时它表示一种只有最薄弱支持的观点，而有时它表示一组紧密结合的观点，具有巨大的支持，当然，这两个极端之间的任何观点也是可能的。

Of course there isn’t a watertight boundary between everyday thinking and scientific thinking, and the term “theory” therefore has a certain degree of ambiguity to it. Sometimes it denotes an idea having only the flimsiest of support, while other times it denotes a tight cluster of ideas having enormous support, and anything in between these two extremes is of course also possible.

在科学中，任何理论都应该始终保持开放的修改和改进，这一点至关重要，但与此同时，一套值得被称为“理论”的思想必须已经通过了无数的可信度测试，因此它有大量的证据支持它。其中一些证据可能非常有力，而另一些证据可能相对较弱。但科学理论总是有一定程度的证据和支持。

In science, it’s crucial that any theory should always be open to modifications and improvements, but at the same time, for a set of ideas to deserve the label of “theory,” it must already have passed numerous tests of credibility, so that it has numerous pieces of evidence supporting it. Some of these pieces of evidence may be extremely strong, and others may be relatively weak. But scientific theories always have some degree of evidence and support.

爱因斯坦的广义相对论是一个得到极强支持的理论，历经了一百多年的实验检验。达尔文的进化论也得到了世界各地观测的极强支持。另一方面，所谓的“暗物质”和“暗能量”理论仍在研究中，它们解释了一些现象，但对其他现象却完全无法解释。

Einstein’s theory of general relativity is an extremely strongly supported theory, which has survived well over one hundred years of experimental tests. Darwin’s theory of evolution is also very strongly supported by observations throughout the world. On the other hand, there are theories of so-called “dark matter” and “dark energy” that are still being worked out, and that explain some phenomena but leave other phenomena totally unexplained.

理论物理学中有一门奇特的知识体系，被称为“弦理论”，它充满了完全自洽的数学思想，但迄今为止没有任何实验支持。因此，弦理论是“理论”一词的一个相当反常的例子，但弦理论之所以被视为理论（至少在某些人眼中），是因为它的思想和方程都非常紧密地结合在一起（打个比方，想想非欧几里得几何的许多内部一致的定理），即使它们还没有得到实验支持（即使它们从未得到过哪怕一丝实验支持）。

There is a curious body of knowledge in theoretical physics known as “string theory,” which is filled to the brim with perfectly self-consistent mathematical ideas, but which so far has no experimental support at all. For this reason, string theory is a pretty anomalous case of the term “theory,” but what makes string theory count as a theory (at least in the eyes of some) is that its ideas and equations all cohere very tightly (for an analogy, think of the many internally consistent theorems of non-Euclidean geometry), even if they haven’t yet been experimentally supported (and even if they never receive the tiniest trace of experimental support).

简而言之，科学理论的可能性范围很广，从非常有力的证实到相当不靠谱。科学家习惯于他们的“理论”一词涵盖了广泛的可信度；然而，外行人经常抓住这个术语的模糊性，用它来嘲笑那些让他们不舒服的理论。这就是为什么我们偶尔会听到这样恼火的爆发：“但进化论只是一种理论！”说这些话的人没有意识到，进化论是一个得到充分证实的科学理论，因此，它被视为真理，而不是推测。

In short, there is a whole gamut of possibilities for scientific theories, ranging from very strongly confirmed to quite rickety. Scientists are used to the fact that their word “theory” covers a wide range of degrees of credibility; however, lay people often seize upon this vagueness in the term and use it to heap scorn on theories that make them uncomfortable. This is why we occasionally hear such annoyed outbursts as “But evolution is only a theory!” People who say such things don’t realize that evolution is a deeply corroborated scientific theory, and as such, it is accepted as truth, not as speculation.

那么，什么使得一个理论被视为科学呢？在科学领域，自然科学和社会科学之间存在着标准区别。这两类科学彼此之间有很大不同，即使这种差异经常被局外人夸大。自然科学的主要目标是找到描述自然如何运作的一般规律。粒子物理学理论不仅仅描述位于南达科他州的粒子在 1912 年的行为，或者更一般地说，描述南达科他州粒子的行为，还描述特定类型的所有粒子在任何时间和任何给定情况下的行为。

What, then, makes a theory count as being scientific? Within science, there is a standard distinction between the natural sciences and the social sciences. These two types of science are quite different from each other, even if the differences are often exaggerated by outsiders. The primary goal of the natural sciences is to find general laws that describe how nature works. A theory of particle physics doesn’t merely describe how the particles located in South Dakota behaved in the year 1912, or, more generally, how the particles in South Dakota behave, but how all particles of a specific type behave at all times and under any given circumstances.

在社会科学中，人们往往对个人或具体案例更感兴趣。目标可能是描述特定文化的风俗和传统，或描述剧作家奥古斯特·斯特林堡在其作品中表达的人性观。另一方面，在某些社会科学中，尤其是心理学，目标是制定非常普遍的理论，例如视觉感知在大脑中是如何运作的，为什么人们在一定年龄后学习一门语言时通常会有外国口音，或者是什么让人们记住某些事情而忘记其他事情。

In the social sciences, one is often more interested in the individual or the specific case. The goal might be to describe a particular culture’s customs and traditions, or to describe the view of humanity that playwright August Strindberg expresses in his writings. On the other hand, in some of the social sciences, especially psychology, the goal is to formulate very general theories, such as how visual perception works in the brain, or why people generally have foreign accents if they learn a language after a certain age, or what makes people remember some things and forget others.

定义“科学”一词很重要，原因之一是我们需要能够区分真正的科学和伪科学。伪科学是一种采用科学的外在表现，但不遵循真正科学方法的活动。因此，伪科学家可能会模仿真正的科学家，创造大量听起来很专业的术语；或者他们可能会养成写下充满希腊字母和下标的长方程式的习惯，因为这看起来像物理学家所做的；或者他们可能会使用大量带有圆圈和箭头等的图形和看起来很复杂的图表，试图模仿真正科学所特有的严谨性和精确性。但在幕后，伪科学并不尊重科学的核心和不可或缺的原则，即反复试验、理论和实验、证实和反驳——简而言之，各种理论之间激烈的竞争，只有适者生存。

One reason that it is important to define the word “science” is that we need to be able to distinguish genuine science from pseudoscience, which is an activity that adopts the external trappings of science but that doesn’t follow the methods that characterize genuine science. Thus pseudoscientists may create large bodies of technical-sounding jargon, in imitation of what real scientists do; or they may take up the habit of writing down long equations filled with Greek letters and subscripts, because that looks like what physicists do; or they may use lots of graphs and complex-looking diagrams with circles and arrows and so forth, trying to imitate the rigor and precision that are characteristic of genuine science. But behind the scenes, pseudoscience does not respect the central and indispensable principle that makes science what it is—namely, trial and error, theory and experiment, confirmation and refutation—in short, a rough-and tumble competition among all sorts of theories, where only the fittest survive.

科学不仅仅是一组陈述、发现或问题的答案；它是一整套探索世界的方法。科学的本质特征是它对各种假设进行可靠的检验，并毫不留情地抛弃任何经不起严格推敲的假设。

Science is not just a set of statements or findings or answers to questions; it is an entire set of ways of exploring the world. The defining feature of science is that it subjects all sorts of hypotheses to reliable tests, and it mercilessly drops any hypothesis that doesn’t hold up under serious scrutiny.

这种方法的不断运用可以说是区分真科学和假科学的标准。自然科学中不依赖这种方法的主张——无法检验的主张——因此不是科学的。这样的说法可能是：“只要没有人以任何方式观察我，我就能在水上行走。”另一个可能是：“在月球背面的反质子表面的紫色洞穴中，住着数十亿只微小的隐形负质量大象。”有时，一个说法乍一看会给人一种科学的印象，尤其是当它用高度专业的术语表达时。但如果经过仔细审查，无法对其进行严格的检验，那么它就必须被归入伪科学的范畴。

The constant application of this method could be said to be the criterion that distinguishes between genuine science and fake science. Claims in the natural sciences that don’t rely on this method—claims that have no way of being tested—are therefore not scientific. Such a claim might be: “I can walk on water as long as no one is observing me in any way whatsoever.” Another might be: “There are billions of little tiny invisible negative-mass elephants that live in purple caves on the surface of antiprotons on the dark side of the moon.” Sometimes a claim can, on first glance, give the impression of being scientific, especially if it is couched in highly technical terms. But if, on careful scrutiny, it cannot be put to a rigorous test, then it must be relegated to the category of pseudoscience.

有时人们批评科学过于教条，过于相信“真理”。然而，这种批评是基于对科学实际运作方式的深刻误解。事实是，科学方法中存在着无情的自我批评过程，这意味着科学家不断试图检查和改进自己的结果，当然也包括同事的结果。

Sometimes science is criticized for being dogmatic, and for being too sure of its “truths.” This type of criticism, however, is based on a profound misunderstanding of how science actually works. The truth of the matter is that built into the scientific method is the process of merciless self-criticism, which means that scientists are constantly trying to check and recheck and improve their own results and, of course, also the results of their colleagues.

确实，有些科学家热衷于验证、证实和捍卫自己的想法，因此他们带有偏见，有些盲目，但其他科学家当然不会坚持这些想法，因此他们会弥补这些人的偏见和盲目。因此，任何有缺陷的理论在严酷的科学界都不会长久存在。

To be sure, some scientists are emotionally committed to verifying and confirming and defending their own ideas, and they are thus prejudiced and somewhat blinded, but of course other scientists are not committed to those ideas, and they will therefore make up for these people’s prejudices and blindnesses. As a result, any theory that is flawed will not last long in the harsh world of science.

实验、拒绝和修改：科学的核心

Experimentation, Rejection, and Revision: The Very Core of What Science Is

我们利用科学方法（即检验和修改理论）来获取知识。通过这种方式，我们逐渐建立起越来越完善的现实描述。

We use the methods of science—namely, testing and modifying our theories—to gain knowledge. In this manner, we gradually build up better and better descriptions of reality.

当然，几个世纪以来，科学界也犯过一些重大错误，比如有人认为可以通过头骨形状了解一个人的性格特征（这一观点被称为“颅相学”）。这一观点是由维也纳医生弗朗茨·约瑟夫·加尔（Franz Joseph Gall，1758-1828）提出的。这一观点基于这样的观点：大脑由许多器官组成，这些器官与各种心理功能、能力和性格特征相对应，例如色觉能力、语言能力、数学能力性情、音乐才能、性欲、胆怯、合群、自信、诚实、易怒、慷慨、利他、虔诚、可靠、忠诚、自我牺牲等等。颅相学的思想流传了相当长的时间，但它仍然是一门伪科学。

Of course throughout the centuries there have been major scientific mistakes, such as the idea that one can read someone’s personality traits from the shape of their skull (an idea called “phrenology”). This notion was proposed by Franz Joseph Gall (1758–1828), a physician in Vienna. The thought was based on the idea that the brain consists of a number of organs that correspond to various mental functions, abilities, and character traits, such as the faculty of color vision, the faculty of speech, mathematical ability, musical ability, sexual desire, timidity, gregariousness, self-confidence, honesty, irascibility, generosity, altruism, religiousness, reliability, devotion, self-sacrifice, and so forth. The idea of phrenology enjoyed quite a long life, but it was nonetheless a pseudoscience.

另一个例子是所谓的“N 射线”。1903 年，备受尊敬的法国物理学家 Prosper-René Blondlot (1849–1930) 宣布了这一发现，而就在那时，德国物理学家 Wilhelm Röntgen (1845–1923) 发现了 X 射线，随后 X 射线在某些语言中也被称作“伦琴射线”（当然，尤其是德语，还有瑞典语）。Blondlot 在对 X 射线进行实验后，确信自己发现了一种新形式的辐射，并以他担任教授的南锡大学的名字为其命名。许多其他研究人员迅速重复了他的实验，并兴高采烈地证实了 N 射线的存在。在最初宣布的第二年，Blondlot 和一百多位同事声称检测到了从各种物质（包括人体）中发出的 N 射线；然而，奇怪的是，这些射线显然不是由绿色木材或某些经过处理的金属发射的。一位名叫古斯塔夫·勒庞 (Gustave Le Bon，1841-1931) 的研究人员非常渴望获得荣誉，他声称他而不是布朗德洛特才是最初的发现者。（毫无疑问，勒庞希望凭借他的工作获得诺贝尔物理学奖，很明显，勒庞获得诺贝尔奖会让回文爱好者欣喜若狂。但遗憾的是，勒庞和回文爱好者们都失望了。）最后，尽管有所有这些初步确认，但事实证明根本没有这样的射线。过了一段时间，所有的实验都开始失败，很快整个事情就化为泡影。这些研究人员怎么会犯同样的错误？好吧，他们只是在欺骗自己，因为他们都想看到一些东西。这是科学界最著名的自欺欺人的故事之一。

Another example is given by the so-called “N-rays,” announced in 1903 by the highly respected French physicist Prosper-René Blondlot (1849– 1930), very shortly after German physicist Wilhelm Röntgen (1845–1923) had discovered X-rays, which subsequently acquired the name “Röntgen rays” in certain languages (especially German, of course, but also Swedish). Blondlot, after experimenting with X-rays, was convinced that he had discovered a new form of radiation, and he named it after the University of Nancy, where he was a professor. Numerous other researchers rapidly repeated his experiment and jubilantly confirmed the existence of the N-rays. In the year following the original announcement, Blondlot and more than a hundred colleagues claimed to have detected N-rays emanating from all sorts of substances, including the human body; oddly enough, however, the rays were apparently not emitted by green wood or by certain sorts of treated metals. One researcher, named Gustave Le Bon (1841–1931), was so eager for credit that he claimed that he, not Blondlot, was the original discoverer. (Undoubtedly Le Bon was hoping to receive the Nobel Prize in Physics for his work, and it’s clear that a Le Bon Nobel would have delighted palindrome lovers. But sad to say, Le Bon and palindrome lovers were disappointed.) In the end, despite all these initial confirmations, it turned out there weren’t any such rays at all. After a while, all the experiments started failing, and soon the whole thing had gone up in smoke. How could all these researchers have made the same mistake? Well, they simply fooled themselves, because they all wanted to see something. This is one of the most famous tales of scientific self-deception.

或许现代最臭名昭著的传说就是“冷聚变”，即两个原子核在室温或接近室温的条件下自发聚变，释放出巨大的能量（通常称为“结合能”）。如果这种现象是真实存在的，那么将意味着无限的能量唾手可得——这对人类来说是一种难以形容的恩惠。这种核聚变过程确实发生在极高的温度下，例如恒星内部，但它们也可以在日常温度下发生的想法是高度推测性的。尽管如此，1989 年，犹他州两位受人尊敬的化学家宣布进行了实验，整整一年，科学界都在激烈争论所谓的冷聚变是否真的存在。核聚变奇迹是否真实存在，人们对此众说纷纭。最终，由于这一奇迹从未在任何地方可靠地再现，人们对此结果持怀疑态度，从那以后，除了少数孤立的实验室外，再也没有人听说过冷聚变，这些实验室的工作没有得到可靠来源的支持，其研究结果也没有发表在主流期刊上，因为它们不符合必要的严谨标准。尽管如此，仍有科学家（或者说边缘科学家）希望冷聚变是真实的，并且仍在努力实现它。

Perhaps the most notorious such tale in modern times is that of “cold fusion,” defined as the spontaneous fusing together of two atomic nuclei at or near room temperature, releasing a huge burst of energy (usually called “binding energy”). If this phenomenon were real, it would mean that unlimited amounts of energy would be trivially available—an indescribable boon for humanity. Such nuclear-fusion processes do in fact occur at extremely high temperatures, such as within stars, but the idea that they could also occur at everyday temperatures was highly speculative. Nonetheless, in 1989, experiments were announced by two respected chemists in Utah, and for a whole year the scientific world hotly debated whether the claimed cold-fusion miracle was real or not. In the end, since it was never reliably reproduced anywhere, the finding was discounted, and since then nothing more has been heard of cold fusion, except in a few isolated laboratories whose work is not supported by reputable sources and whose findings are not published in mainstream journals, because they do not meet the requisite criteria of rigor. Nonetheless, there are still scientists (or rather, fringe-scientists) who want cold fusion to be true, and who are still trying to realize it.

幸运的是，这样的情况只是极少数，正如我们讲述的故事所揭示的那样，伪科学的泡沫迟早都会破灭（尽管可悲的是，新一代伪科学家不断吹出新的泡沫）。相比之下，科学的通常路径则截然不同：最初的发现得到证实、改进、发展和扩展，随着发现的增多，想法变得越来越深刻，越来越丰富。

Luckily, cases like these are a tiny minority, and as the tales we have told reveal, sooner or later every bubble of pseudoscience will pop (although, sad to say, new bubbles are constantly being blown by new generations of pseudoscientists). By contrast, the usual pathway in science is quite different: an initial finding is confirmed, refined, developed, and extended, and the ideas grow deeper and deeper and richer and richer as the discoveries multiply.

科学批评者有时会说：“依赖科学是没有意义的，因为每天都会出现以前被认为是错误的新事实。”艾萨克·牛顿和阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦的例子经常被拿来作为关键例子。他们的观点如下：“两个世纪以来，每个人都相信神圣的牛顿世界观，但后来爱因斯坦的出现表明伟大的牛顿错了。然后牛顿就直接消失了，就像这样！噗！迟早，爱因斯坦也会遭遇同样的事。而且这种情况会一直持续下去。所以你不能依赖科学中的任何事或任何人！”

Critics of science sometimes state: “It doesn’t make sense to rely on science, because every day new facts turn up that previously had been taken to be false.” Often the case of Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein is trotted out as a linchpin example. The argument runs as follows: “For two centuries, everyone believed in the holy Newtonian worldview, but then along came Einstein and showed that the great Newton had been mistaken. Newton then went straight out the window, just like that! Poof! And sooner or later, the very same thing will happen to Einstein. And on and on it’ll go. So you just can’t rely on anything or anyone in science!”

这种看似轻率的论点完全没有根据，因为它严重歪曲​​了事实。牛顿在 17 世纪末和 18 世纪初完成了他的工作。他创立了一套力学理论，其核心是他的三大运动定律和万有引力定律。这就是所谓的牛顿世界观，它完美地解释了两百年来行星和地球机械系统的运动。它还为气体（热力学）、液体（流体力学）、汽车、飞机以及数不清的其他机器的行为提供了完美的解释。

This glib-sounding argument is completely baseless because it wildly misrepresents the situation. Newton did his work at the end of the seventeenth century and the beginning of the eighteenth century. He created a theory of mechanics at whose core lay his three laws of motion and his law of gravitation. This was the so-called Newtonian worldview, and it perfectly explained the motions of the planets and of terrestrial mechanical systems for two hundred years. It also supplied perfect explanations for the behavior of gases (thermodynamics), of liquids (hydrodynamics), of cars, of airplanes, and of untold thousands of other machines.

大约两百年后，在二十世纪初，阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦提出了广义相对论，从某种意义上说，它对空间和时间的描述取代了牛顿的模型。爱因斯坦的理论比牛顿的理论稍微准确一点，但这并不意味着他证明了牛顿的理论是完全错误的或无用的。他怎么可能做这样的事情？毕竟，牛顿的理论多年来一直轰动一时！

Some two hundred years later, at the beginning of the twentieth century, Albert Einstein developed his theory of general relativity, a description of space and time that—in a certain sense—replaced Newton’s model. Einstein’s theory was a tiny bit more accurate than Newton’s, but that doesn’t mean that he showed that Newton’s theory was way off base or useless. How could he possibly have done such a thing? After all, Newton’s theory had worked sensationally for all those years!

事实是，牛顿理论根本没有被推翻，只是被赋予了新的意义。它是爱因斯坦理论的一个极限情况，即速度不是超快，接近光速（这种情况适用于所有宏观物体，如冰球、人、保时捷和行星），引力也不是非常强大（这种情况当然适用于地球引力场，也适用于太阳强大的引力，正是太阳引力产生了太阳系）。换句话说，爱因斯坦理论几乎与牛顿理论完全相同，除了在最不寻常的物理情况下，即速度极高或引力极强的情况下。

The truth is that Newton’s theory was not invalidated at all; it was simply cast in a new light. It emerged as a limiting case of Einstein’s theory—namely, when velocities are not super-fast, approaching the speed of light (and this condition holds for all macroscopic objects, like hockey pucks, people, Porsches, and planets), and when the force of gravity is not extremely powerful (and this condition holds for the earth’s gravitational field, of course, as well as for the sun’s much stronger gravitational force, which gives rise to the solar system). In other words, Einstein’s theory is almost exactly equivalent to Newton’s theory, except in the most unusual of physical circumstances, involving fantastically high velocities or fantastically strong gravitational fields.

可以说，爱因斯坦的引力理论比牛顿理论更接近现实。但同样重要的是要记住，只要我们处于日常情况中，牛顿理论就会给我们极其准确、近乎完美的预测。如前所述，牛顿理论本身是爱因斯坦理论的严格推论，在“低”速度（比有史以来建造的最快火箭的速度快得多）和“低”引力场（如普通恒星的引力场，当然还有行星的引力场，这些引力场要弱得多）下。而且牛顿理论仍然非常可靠，工程师们一直用它来建造桥梁、火箭、卫星、汽车、船只等等。只有在需要极其精确的测量时，比如 GPS 系统等设备所需的测量时，工程师们才偶尔需要使用爱因斯坦理论，以及后来发展起来的量子理论。

It is fine to say that Einstein’s theory of gravitation gives a better approximation to reality than Newton’s theory does. But it is also crucial to keep in mind that as long as we are in everyday situations, Newton’s theory gives us extremely accurate, nearly perfect predictions. As was stated earlier, Newton’s theory itself is a rigorous consequence of Einstein’s theory, at “low” velocities (much faster than the speed of the fastest rockets ever built) and “low” gravitational fields (like those of ordinary stars and, of course, those of planets, which are far, far feebler). And Newton’s theory is still super-reliable, in the sense that engineers use it all the time to build their bridges, their rockets, their satellites, their cars, their boats, and so forth. Only when it comes to extremely precise measurements, such as are needed in devices like GPS systems, do engineers occasionally need to make use of Einstein’s theory, and also quantum theory, developed somewhat later.

科学理论是对现实的良好近似，而且它们总是在不断改进。爱因斯坦的相对论和随后的量子理论比牛顿理论更接近现实，而且很有可能在未来的某个时候，它们也会被某种更精确的理论“取代”，但即使发生这种情况，它们也肯定不会“消失”——就像一百年前牛顿消失一样。这种想法只是误导性的想法。

Scientific theories are good approximations of reality, and they are always getting better. Einstein’s relativity theory and the subsequent quantum theory are better approximations to reality than Newton’s theory, and it’s quite possible that at some future time they, too, will be “supplanted” by some more accurate theory, but even if that happens, they will certainly not go “out the window”—no more than Newton went out the window one hundred years ago. That idea is just misguided thinking.

另一个案例是，在十九世纪，人们毫无疑问地证明了光是一种电磁波。这是苏格兰物理学家詹姆斯·克拉克·麦克斯韦（1831-1879）发现的奇妙方程的直接结果，这些方程将以前独立的电磁理论统一为一组优美的四个方程。从这个奇妙的统一中诞生了收音机、电视、电话、电动机、电影、微波炉以及二十世纪无数其他的技术进步。

For another case study, consider that, in the nineteenth century, it was proven beyond all reasonable doubt that light is a type of electromagnetic wave. This was a direct consequence of the wonderful equations discovered by Scottish physicist James Clerk Maxwell (1831–1879), which united the formerly independent theories of electricity and of magnetism into one single, beautiful set of four equations. Out of this marvelous unification came radio, television, telephones, electrical motors, movies, microwave ovens, and countless other technological advances of the twentieth century.

但在 1905 年，阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦利用他猜到的一个深刻类比，提出光可能根本不是由电磁辐射组成，而是由粒子组成！多年来，没有物理学家对这个想法表示赞赏。在这种信念下，爱因斯坦是一个叛徒、一个局外人、一个孤独的人。但 18 年后，在 20 世纪 20 年代初，关于光的实验发现（尤其是康普顿效应）根本无法与麦克斯韦方程相协调，这时，物理学家开始意识到，也许早在 1905 年，爱因斯坦对光的性质的描述就是正确的。但这并不意味着麦克斯韦将光描述为电磁波是错误的；这意味着这幅图景还有另一个更深的层次，在某些非常特殊的情况下，光表现出的行为只能用粒子图景来解释。但是在麦克斯韦的光理论起作用的所有情况下，它都继续起作用，并且将永远继续起作用——也就是说，在我们地球上通常遇到的几乎所有情况下。

But in 1905, Albert Einstein, exploiting a deep analogy that he had guessed at, suggested that maybe light did not consist of electromagnetic radiation after all but, instead, was made of particles! For many years, no physicists gave this idea the time of day. In this belief, Einstein was a renegade, an outlier, a loner. But eighteen years later, in the early 1920s, experimental discoveries about light (especially the Compton effect) were made that simply could not be reconciled with Maxwell’s equations, and at that point, it started dawning on physicists that maybe, way back in 1905, Einstein had been right, after all, about light’s nature. This didn’t mean, however, that Maxwell had been wrong when he described light as electromagnetic waves; what it meant was that there was another, deeper layer to the picture, and that under certain very unusual circumstances, light exhibited behaviors that could only be explained in terms of a particle picture. But in all the situations where Maxwell’s theory of light had worked, it continued to work, and always will continue to work—which is to say, in almost all situations that we on earth normally come across.

我们再一次看到，科学中“真”和“假”的含义比我们想象的要微妙得多。一个理论严格来说可能是假的，但从实际目的来看，它完全正确！这既适用于前面描述的牛顿世界观，也适用于麦克斯韦光波图。它们都曾被认为是普遍、完美、完全有效的，但现在我们明白，每个理论都有其有效性的局限性；然而，这并不会使这些理论在正常情况下失效。事实上，旧理论仍然是理解大多数普通情况的最佳方式，这就是为什么它们继续被作为高中和大学所有物理课程的核心来教授，并继续在所有工程学院中得到深深的依赖。

Once again, we see that the meanings of “true” and “false” in science are subtler than might be expected. A theory can be strictly speaking false, but for all practical purposes perfectly true! This holds both for the Newtonian world-view, as described earlier, and the Maxwellian picture of light as waves. Each of them was once considered to be universally, perfectly, totally valid, but now we understand that each theory has its limits of validity; however, that doesn’t invalidate the theories for normal situations. In fact, the old theories are still the best way to understand most ordinary situations, which is why they continue to be taught as the core of all physics curricula in high schools and universities, and continue to be profoundly relied on in all engineering schools.

目前，我们对光的理解是一种混合实体，有时像波，有时像粒子。这是一种不稳定的平衡，因为我们人类所知道的“现实生活中”没有任何东西以这种混合的方式运行，但我们必须习惯它，因为这是我们对这种神秘现象的最佳理解。即使是现代光图景的创始人爱因斯坦，也一直对自己的野兽——“光量子”（或我们现在所说的光子）感到困惑，直到他生命的尽头。1951 年，在他去世前四年，他在给终生朋友米歇尔·贝索的一封信中哀叹道：

At the present time, our picture of light is as a kind of hybrid entity, sometimes wavelike and sometimes particle-like. It is an uneasy balance, since nothing that we humans know “in real life” behaves in this mixed manner, but we have to get used to it, since it’s the best picture we have for this mysterious phenomenon. Even Einstein, who was the originator of our modern picture of light, remained baffled by his own beast, the “light quantum” (or photon, as we say these days), all the way until the end of his life. In 1951, only four years before his death, he laments in a letter to his lifelong friend Michele Besso:

经过五十年的自觉思考，我并没有更接近于回答“光量子是什么？”这个问题。当然，今天每个无赖都认为他知道答案，但他是在自欺欺人。3

All these fifty years of conscious brooding have not brought me any closer to answering the question “What are light quanta?” Today, of course, every rascal thinks he knows the answer, but he is deluding himself.3

也许未来的某一天，我们将对光的本质有比今天更深刻、更令人满意的认识，但这只是一个模糊的希望。

Perhaps someday in the future we will arrive at a deeper and more satisfying picture of the nature of light than we have today, but that is only a vague hope.

但无论我们目前对光的认识是否完全令人满意，它在应用方面都是极其准确和卓有成效的。例如，我们目前对光和原子的理解，即使不是这方面的终极知识，也足以让我们制造出奇妙的设备，让我们能够非常详细地了解我们体内发生的事情。特别是，我们经常在医院使用 MRI 扫描仪（代表“（核）磁共振成像”）来发现肿瘤，在实验室中也经常使用 MRI 扫描仪来研究身体各个器官的过程。

But whether our current picture of light is totally satisfying to us or not, it is extraordinarily accurate and extraordinarily fruitful in terms of its applicability. For example, our current understanding of light and of atoms, even if not the last word on the subject, is adequate to allow us to build wonderful devices that can give us very detailed pictures of the goings-on inside our bodies. In particular, we routinely use MRI scanners—standing for “(nuclear) magnetic resonance imagery”—in hospitals, to discover tumors, as well as in laboratories, to study the processes in various organs of the body.

MRI 扫描仪使用强磁场和无线电波，它们利用氢原子的某些特性，氢原子的原子核由单个质子组成。水分子 (H 2 O) 包含两个氢原子和一个氧原子，人体的大约四分之三由水分子组成。氢原子核（即质子）可以被认为是一个非常小的磁铁，它可以朝向各个方向，这取决于它所处的磁场（人们可以将磁场想象为由力线组成，质子“希望”沿着力线排列）。当 MRI 扫描仪产生强磁场时，无数微小的质子磁铁会沿着它快速排列。此时，无线电波被导向样本，质子吸收波的能量，从而改变它们的方向；然后，当无线电波关闭时，质子会返回到其原始方向，这样它们就会以新的外发无线电波的形式释放它们刚刚吸收的能量。但是这些无线电波现在包含有关氢原子位置的有用信息，当这些波被接收到时，它们可以被快速的计算机处理，从而可以产生非常精确的身体内部图像。

MRI scanners use strong magnetic fields and radio waves, and they exploit certain properties of the hydrogen atom, whose nucleus consists of a single proton. A water molecule (H2O) contains two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom, and roughly three-quarters of the human body consists of water molecules. The nucleus of a hydrogen atom—that is, a proton—can be thought of as a very tiny magnet that can face in various directions, as a function of the magnetic field that it is immersed in (one can think of a magnetic field as consisting of lines of force, along which the proton “wants” to align itself). When the MRI scanner produces a strong magnetic field, myriads of tiny proton-magnets rapidly line up along it. At that point, radio waves are directed at the sample, and the protons absorb the waves’ energy, which changes their orientation; then, when the radio waves are turned off, the protons return back to their original orientation, and in so doing they release the energy they just absorbed, in the form of new outgoing radio waves. But these radio waves now contain useful information about the positions of the hydrogen atoms, and when the waves are received, they can be processed by fast computers and thus can yield very accurate pictures of the interior of the body.

假设玛丽患有严重的慢性头痛，她去看医生，医生要求她做核磁共振检查。结果显示玛丽的大脑中某个特定位置似乎有一个良性肿瘤。手术很快就完成了，当外科医生打开玛丽的头骨时，他们发现肿瘤正好位于他们预期的位置，而且形状和形状都与预期完全一致。肿瘤的大小与 MRI 扫描仪提供的图片中预期的一样。外科医生切除了肿瘤，玛丽很快又恢复了健康，不再头痛。所以外科医生看到的图片是真的。从这个故事中我们可以得出什么结论？

Suppose that Mary is suffering from severe chronic headaches, and she goes to the doctor, who orders an MRI. The result shows that Mary has what seems to be a benign tumor in a specific spot in her brain. Soon an operation is done, and when the surgeons open up Mary’s skull, they find the tumor in the exact spot that they expected, and it also has the exact shape and size that they expected from the pictures provided by the MRI scanner. The surgeons cut out the tumor, and very soon Mary is once again healthy, with no more headaches. And so the picture the surgeons saw was true. What conclusions can we draw from such a story?
