MRI 扫描仪基于电磁辐射、磁场和构成原子核的粒子（在本例中为质子）的理论，以及所有这些实体相互作用的力的理论。外科医生在肿瘤应该出现的位置找到了它。这一惊人的成功（以及这些理论的数百万其他成功案例）是否意味着这些理论绝对完美？当然不是。

The MRI scanner was based on theories of electromagnetic radiation, of magnetic fields, and of the particles making up atomic nuclei (protons, in this case), as well as of the forces through which all these entities interact with one another. The surgeons found the tumor just where it should have been. Does this stunning success (along with the millions of other successes of these theories) mean that these theories are absolutely perfect? Certainly not.

例如，假设有一天，通过各种实验和宇宙​​学观测，弦理论能够比我们以前所了解的更深入地了解粒子的本质。4具体来说，假设我们了解到质子和其他粒子最好被认为是在十或十一维中“振动”的无穷小“弦”。如果发生这种情况，虽然这显然是弦理论的巨大胜利，但它绝不意味着使用 MRI 扫描仪（基于早期理论，而不是弦理论）发现的玛丽的肿瘤是一种幻觉。

Suppose, for instance, that string theory is someday shown, through various experiments and cosmological observations, to yield a far deeper view of the nature of particles than we ever had before.4 In particular, suppose that we learn that protons and other particles are best thought of as infinitesimal “strings” that “vibrate” in ten or eleven dimensions. If this happened, although it would clearly be a huge triumph for string theory, it would not imply in any way, shape, or form that Mary’s tumor, discovered using the MRI scanner (which was based on earlier theories, not on string theory), was an illusion.

从我们刚刚考虑的这个小故事中，我们可以得出一个重要的结论。当今物理学和化学的许多理论都有技术应用——测量仪器、计算机等等——这些设备的工作方式与发明者预期的完全一致（例如，显示物体内部）。现在，这些理论永远不会与将来某个时候（比如说，五十年或一百年）可能出现的更准确或“更真实”的理论发生任何重要的冲突。（如果它们确实发生冲突，那就意味着基于它们的设备是骗局，或者更糟的是，根本就不可能被发明或使用。）明天出现的理论可能比今天的理论更广泛、更深刻，因此也更“真实”，但即便如此，它们也不会使今天的理论失效。今天的理论永远不会被证明是错误的；它们只会被视为比新理论更不准确的近似值。

We can draw an important conclusion from the little story we’ve just considered. Many theories belonging to current-day physics and chemistry have technological applications—measuring instruments, computers, and so forth—and these devices work exactly as their inventors intended them to do (showing the insides of bodies, for instance). Now these theories will never turn out to clash, in any important sense, with more accurate or “truer” theories that might arise sometime down the line—in, say, fifty or one hundred years. (If they did clash, that would mean that the devices based on them would have been tricks, or worse yet, could never have been invented or worked at all.) The theories that will arise tomorrow may be both broader and deeper and thus “truer” than today’s theories, but even so, they will not invalidate today’s theories. Today’s theories will never be shown to be false; they will just come to be seen as less accurate approximations than the newer theories.

所有这些告诉我们，对现实的科学描述可以有好的、更好的，甚至更好的。所有这些“竞争性”描述可以拥有不同程度的准确性和质量，但它们都有其用处和适用范围。因此，它们更像是朋友，而不是它们是竞争对手，因为当其中一个失去部分准确性时，另一个就会占据上风。这就是科学的结构。

What all this teaches us is that there can be good, better, and even better scientific descriptions of reality. All these “rival” descriptions can possess diverse levels of accuracy and quality, but they all will have their usefulness and their range of applicability. They are therefore more friends than they are rivals, since one of them will take over in circumstances where the other loses some of its accuracy. This is how science is structured.

科学方法是如何运作的？为了解释这一点，我必须谈谈从已知事实得出结论的两种方法：演绎法和归纳法。

How does the scientific method work? To explain this, I will have to speak about two ways of drawing conclusions from known facts: deduction and induction.

演绎推理过程

Deductive Processes of Inference

科学研究包括逻辑推理的规则，即如何从前提中有效地得出结论。这些规则有一个名字：推理规则。它们的目的是维护真理。这意味着，如果我们将推理规则应用于一个或多个为真的前提（或“输入”），那么我们可以确保“输出”（即结论）也将为真。这是任何推理规则的关键定义属性：只要前提为真，其结论也必须是真的。

The act of doing science includes rules for logical reasoning—that is, how to validly draw conclusions from premises. These rules have a name: rules of inference. Their purpose is to preserve truth. This means that if we apply a rule of inference to one or more premises (or “inputs”) that are true, then we can be assured that the “output” (that is, the conclusion) will also be true. This is the key defining property of any rule of inference: its conclusion must be true, as long as the premises are true.

有许多有效的推理规则，这里我将给出几个例子。第一条规则称为肯定前件，其工作原理如下所示：

There are numerous valid rules of inference, and here I’ll give a few examples of them. The first rule is called modus ponens, and it works as shown in the following:

前提 1：如果将炉子上的燃烧器设置为“高”，那么放在燃烧器上的锅中的水会在一段时间后开始沸腾。

Premise 1: If a burner on a stove is set to “high,” then the water in a pot placed on the burner will start to boil after a while.

前提 2：我炉子的右前燃烧器设置为“高”。

Premise 2: The front-right burner on my stove is set to “high.”

结论：放在我炉子右前燃烧器上的锅里的水过一会儿就会开始沸腾。

Conclusion: The water in a pot placed on my stove’s front-right burner will start to boil after a while.

这个结论是从两个前提逻辑推导出来的，所以，只要两个前提成立，这个结论就一定成立。

This conclusion follows logically from the two premises, and so it has to be true, as long as the two premises are true.

我将展示的第二条推理规则称为否定结论规则，它的工作原理如下：

The second inference rule I’ll exhibit is called modus tollens, and here’s how it works:

前提 1：如果将炉子上的燃烧器设置为“高”，那么放在燃烧器上的锅中的水会在一段时间后开始沸腾。

Premise 1: If a burner on a stove is set to “high,” then the water in a pot placed on the burner will start to boil after a while.

前提 2：我放在炉子右前燃烧器上的锅里的水从未开始沸腾。

Premise 2: The water in a pot that I placed on my stove’s front-right burner didn’t ever start to boil.

结论：我炉子的右前燃烧器没有设置为“高”。

Conclusion: The front-right burner on my stove wasn’t set to “high.”

与以前一样，这个结论是从两个前提逻辑上得出的，所以，只要两个前提为真，这个结论就一定为真。

Just as before, this conclusion follows logically from the two premises, and so it has to be true, as long as the two premises are true.

推理的第一条规则用于确认某件事：如果 A 蕴含 B，并且我们知道 A，那么我们也知道 B。推理的第二条规则用于反驳某件事：如果 A 蕴含 B，并且我们知道 B 不是这种情况，那么我们得出结论 A 不可能是这种情况。

The first rule of inference is used to confirm something: If A implies B, and we know A, then we know B as well. The second rule of inference is used to refute something: If A implies B and we know that B isn’t the case, then we conclude that A cannot be the case.

我将展示的第三条推理规则称为实例化。您可以这样将其模式化：

The third rule of inference I’ll show is one that is called instantiation. Here is how you can schematize it:

前提 1：所有 X 都具有属性 P。

Premise 1: All X’s have property P.

前提 2：A 是 X。

Premise 2: A is an X.

结论：A具有属性P。

Conclusion: A has property P.

例如，假设我们知道所有成熟的草莓（即所有X）都具有红色的特性。还假设我们知道某个物体 A 是成熟的草莓。那么我们可以绝对肯定地得出结论：物体 A 是红色的。

Suppose, for example, that we know that all ripe strawberries (that is, all X’s) have the property of redness. Suppose also that we know that a certain object A is a ripe strawberry. Then we can conclude with absolute certainty that object A is red.

稍后，我们将看到这些推理规则在科学中是如何应用的。重要的是要记住，用推理规则得出的结论不一定与现实相符——毕竟，前提本身可能与现实不符！以下就是这样一个例子：

Later, we’ll see how these rules of inference are used in science. It’s important to remember that a conclusion reached with a rule of inference doesn’t have to agree with reality—after all, the premises themselves might not agree with reality! The following is such an example:

前提 1：所有的狗都有八条腿。

Premise 1: All dogs have eight legs.

前提 2：Fido 是一只狗。

Premise 2: Fido is a dog.

结论：Fido 有八条腿。

Conclusion: Fido has eight legs.

我们正确地使用了肯定前件推理，结论也符合前提的严密逻辑；然而，结论恰好不正确。这是因为第一个前提不正确。但逻辑并不关心前提的真实性；它只关心推理规则是否正确应用——在这里，肯定前件推理规则得到了正确的应用。我们可以肯定地说，如果两个前提都是真的，那么通过肯定前件推理得出的结论也将是真的。

We’ve used modus ponens correctly, and the conclusion follows with ironclad logic from the premises; however, the conclusion just happens not to be true. This is because the first premise is not true. But logic is not concerned with the truth of the premises; it is concerned solely with the rules of inference being applied in the proper way—and here the modus ponens rule was correctly applied. We can safely say that had the two premises both been true, then the conclusion reached via modus ponens would also have been true.

另一条经典的推理规则被称为“排中律” (有时称为“排中律”)。它陈述了一个显而易见的事实，即一个陈述及其否定不可能同时为真。例如，我的国王不可能被将军，也不可能被将军。这没有道理。地球不可能同时是圆的和非圆的(即平的)。这也没有道理。同样，尼斯湖水怪也不能同时存在和不存在！这有多大意义？没有太多意义。

Another classical rule of inference is known as tertium non datur (sometimes called the “rule of the excluded middle”). It states the obvious fact that a statement and its negation cannot both be true. It can’t be the case, for instance, that my king is in check and also that it is not in check. That doesn’t make sense. The earth cannot simultaneously be both round and non-round (i.e., flat). That also makes no sense. Similarly, the Loch Ness monster can’t both exist and not exist at the same time! How much sense would that make? Not too much.

我们将看到，这个推理规则在推理上帝是否存在以及关于现实本质的许多其他观点中发挥着重要作用。

As we will see, this rule of inference plays a significant role in reasoning about whether God exists, as well as in many other ideas about the nature of reality.

归纳推理过程

Inductive Processes of Inference

前面我描述了推理规则，这些规则对于得出结论的演绎方式至关重要。但也有归纳方式可以有效地得出结论。这涉及从关于单个案例（或几个案例）的陈述转向更广泛的概括。以下前提就是一个例子：每次我从手中放开一块石头，它都会掉到地上。这是我张开握着石头的手时的经历。使用归纳法，我得出这个更一般的结论：只要放开石头，石头就会掉到地上。

Earlier I described rules of inference that are central to the deductive manner of reaching conclusions. But there are also inductive ways of deriving conclusions validly. This involves moving from a statement about a single case (or a few cases) to a much wider generalization. The following premise is an example: Every time I release a stone from my hand, it falls to the ground. This is an experience I’ve had when I opened my hand that was holding a stone. Using induction, I draw this more general conclusion: Stones fall to the ground whenever one lets go of them.

与演绎规则相反，归纳规则不能保证从真实前提得出真实结论。前提可能为真，但结论可能为假。伯特兰·罗素 (Bertrand Russell) 的一个经典例子如下：

In contrast to deductive rules, an inductive rule isn’t guaranteed to lead from true premises to true conclusions. The premises can be true, and yet the conclusion can be false. A classic example due to Bertrand Russell runs as follows:

想象谷仓里有一只火鸡，每天中午都会得到喂食。起初它很胆小，多疑。但经过足够多次的重复，火鸡开始习惯这个想法。它注意到每天当教堂的钟声响起时（每天只响一次，恰好在中午），它就会得到喂食。所以前提是：“到目前为止，只要教堂的钟声响起，我就会得到食物。”归纳结论是向更大普遍性的飞跃：“每次教堂的钟声响起，我都会得到食物。”过了一段时间，每次教堂的钟声响起，火鸡就会直接去找农夫。然而，感恩节前一天，事情并不完全按照火鸡的期望进行。事实上，当教堂的钟声在中午响起时，火鸡就会当场被捡起来带走宰杀。火鸡了解到（虽然很遗憾，了解的时间很短），归纳法并不总是一种可靠的得出结论的方法。但结论往往非常可信，就像下落的石头一样。

Imagine a turkey in the barnyard that gets fed every day at noon. At first it is skittish and suspicious. But after sufficiently many repetitions, the turkey starts to get used to the idea. It notices that every day when the church bells ring (which they do only once a day, exactly at noon), it gets fed. So the premise is: “So far, whenever the church bells have rung, I’ve gotten food.” The inductive conclusion is a leap to greater generality: “Every time the church bells ring, I will get food.” After a while, the turkey starts going right up to the farmer every time the church bells ring. The day before Thanksgiving, however, things don’t go exactly according to the turkey’s expectations. In fact, when the church bells ring at noon, the turkey gets picked up right then and there and carried off to be slaughtered. As the turkey learns (though for a regretfully short time), induction is not always a reliable way to draw conclusions. But the conclusion is often very believable, as was the case with the falling stones.

重要的是要记住，科学结论在原则上始终是暂时的。即使归纳推理中的前提是正确的，结论也可能是错误的，正如我刚才用火鸡指出的那样。当出现新事实时，结论必须进行调整。我们永远无法严格意义上来说，每块石头都会在我们扔下时掉到地上，但我们可以认为这个结论是很有可能的。我们拥有丰富的经验，因此我们可以毫无顾虑地假设石头掉到地上的场景总是会发生。尽管这不是一个完全无懈可击的结论，但这并不意味着人们应该对此持怀疑态度。

It’s important to keep in mind that scientific conclusions are always, in principle, tentative. Even if the premises in an inductive inference are true, the conclusion can turn out false, as I’ve just pointed out with the turkey. The conclusion has to be adjusted when new facts arrive. We can never, in a strict sense, show that every stone will fall to the ground when we release it, but we can consider the conclusion to be very likely. We have lots of experience under our belt, so we can assume without worrying that the stone-dropping-to-the-ground scenario will always take place. The fact that it is not a totally watertight conclusion reached by perfect, ironclad logic doesn’t mean that one should feel skeptical about it.

科学研究通常基于一套理论上可检验的假设，然后从这些假设出发，运用归纳和演绎规则。有时这种研究方式被称为“假设演绎法”。

Scientific research is often based on a theoretically formulated set of testable hypotheses, and it then proceeds from these hypotheses, using both inductive and deductive rules. Sometimes this way of proceeding is referred to as “the hypothetico-deductive method.”

只要前提正确，演绎步骤正确，通过演绎得出的结论总是正确的。但是，当我们试图通过科学研究更深入地了解世界时，我们经常使用归纳推理规则。由于归纳结果不能保证为真，因此我们不能确定我们所有的结论，即使它们都是通过假设演绎法得出的，也总是与现实完全一致。

Conclusions reached via deduction are always true, as long as the premises are true and the deductive steps are carried out correctly. But when we are seeking to understand the world more deeply by doing science, we often use inductive rules of inference. Since the results of induction cannot be guaranteed to be true, we can’t be sure that all our conclusions, even though they were all reached by the hypothetico-deductive method, will always jibe exactly with reality.

描述科学的一个简单方法是：我们了解事物是如何联系在一起的，或者它们是如何运作的。我们对其行为提出理论。然后我们提出一组可检验的假设。（如果一个假设有任何解释价值，它必须以某种方式可检验。）然后我们开始调查现实中发生的事情。实验结果是否符合我们的预期？我们的假设要么得到证实，要么被驳斥。

A simple way of describing science is this: We get an idea about how things are connected, or how they work. We make a theory about their behavior. Then we generate a set of testable hypotheses. (If a hypothesis is to have any explanatory value, it has to be testable in some fashion or other.) We then start to investigate what happens in reality. Do the results of experiments agree with what we expected? Either our hypotheses are confirmed, or they are refuted.

这通常是一个反复的过程。人们会回过头来再次测试自己的想法，对其进行改进，然后再次测试。假设演绎法可以总结如下：

This is often an iterative, or repeated, process. One goes back and tests one’s ideas again, refines them, and tests them again. The hypothetico-deductive method can be summarized as follows:

  1. 从给定的理论开始，或者制定一个新的理论。
  2. Start out with a given theory, or formulate a new theory.
  3. 设计一个或多个可检验的假设。
  4. Devise one or more testable hypotheses.
  5. 通过观察或实验来检验这些假设。
  6. Test these hypotheses through observation or experiment.
  7. 根据测试的结果，理论的可信度将会增强或减弱。
  8. Depending on the results of the tests, the theory’s believability will be either strengthened or weakened.

归纳推理在这一切中扮演什么角色？当我们制定理论时，我们通常在第一步中使用归纳推理。例如，如果我们迄今为止看到的所有乌鸦都是黑色的，那么我们可以据此推测世界上所有的乌鸦都是黑色的。

What role does induction play in all this? We usually use induction in step 1, when we formulate a theory. For example, if all the ravens we’ve so far seen are black, then we could conjecture, on this basis, that all ravens in the world are black.

案例研究：路易斯·巴斯德和自然发生论

Case Study: Louis Pasteur and Spontaneous Generation

假设演绎法的一个经典应用是十九世纪中叶伟大的法国化学家和生物学家路易斯·巴斯德（Louis Pasteur，1822-1895）进行的一项实验。他设计这项实验是为了检验当时流行的“自然发生论”。

A classic application of the hypothetico-deductive method is an experiment that was carried out in the middle of the nineteenth century by the great French chemist and biologist Louis Pasteur (1822–1895). He devised this experiment to test the then-popular theory of “spontaneous generation.”

生命起源之谜一直困扰着人们。地球上的生命是如何产生的？无生命的物质如何变成有生命的？亚里士多德提出了“自然发生”的理论，即生命可以自然产生，许多世纪以来，这一理论一直占据主导地位。堆肥堆中成群的果蝇和腐肉中生长的蠕虫被认为是小动物在适宜环境中自然产生的证据。至少一些思想家认为这就是正在发生的事情。

People have always been puzzled by the mystery of the origin of life. How did life on earth come to exist? How can inanimate matter become living? Aristotle had the idea of “spontaneous generation,” meaning that life could just spring up on its own, and for many centuries this was the reigning theory. Fruit flies swarming in a compost pile and worms growing in rotting flesh were thought to be evidence of the spontaneous generation of small animals in a suitable environment. At least some thinkers argued that this was what was happening.

巴斯德并不这么肯定。他把两块肉放在桌子上。然后把其中一块肉移进一个封闭的抽屉里，另一块肉放在户外，暴露在环境中。为了检验自然发生论，巴斯德提出了一个可检验的假设：如果自然发生论是真的，那么蠕虫很快就会出现在两块肉中。实际情况是，几天后，放在户外的那块肉中出现了蠕虫。另一块放在封闭抽屉里的肉中没有蠕虫。巴斯德得出结论，他的实验表明自然发生论是错误的。他应用了推理规则的推论如下：

Pasteur wasn’t so sure. He placed two pieces of meat on a table. Then he moved one of them into a closed drawer, leaving the other one out in the open air, exposed to the environment. To test the theory of spontaneous generation, Pasteur created a testable hypothesis: if spontaneous generation is true, then worms should soon come to exist in both pieces of meat. What actually happened was that in the piece of meat that was left out in the open, worms appeared after a few days. The other piece of meat, in the sealed drawer, remained worm free. Pasteur concluded that his experiment had shown the theory of spontaneous generation to be wrong. He applied the deductive rule of inference modus tollens as follows:

前提 1：如果自然发生论正确，那么两块肉中都应该出现虫子。

Premise 1: If spontaneous generation is true, then worms should turn up in both pieces of meat.

前提 2：两块肉中没有一块出现虫子。

Premise 2: No worms turned up in one of the two pieces of meat.

结论：自然发生论并不正确。

Conclusion: The theory of spontaneous generation is not true.

对于一位严肃的研究者来说，一次实验不足以得出有力的结论。因此，巴斯德设计了一系列新的猜想，并用新的实验来验证它们。最终，他对肉片的实验使他否定了亚里士多德的自然发生理论。

For a serious researcher, one single experiment is not sufficient to draw a strong conclusion. Pasteur thus devised a series of new conjectures and tested them with new experiments. Eventually, his experiments with the pieces of meat led him to reject Aristotle’s theory of spontaneous generation.

巴斯德后来提出了自己的理论，即细菌漂浮在空气中，这些细菌会导致腐烂。这是我们目前对细菌和感染的理解的第一步，这一理论具有重大的实际意义——既对我们今天如何处理食物，又对我们如何避免伤口感染有重大意义。巴斯德后来的科学研究也具有重要意义；例如，他能够为患狂犬病的幼儿接种疫苗。这是医学史上的第一次。

Pasteur later formulated a theory of his own, which was that bacteria are floating in the air, and that these bacteria cause putrefaction. This was the first step in our current understanding of bacteria and infections, and the theory has major practical implications—both for how we handle food today, and for how we try to avoid letting wounds get infected. Pasteur’s subsequent scientific research was also of great import; for example, he was able to immunize a young child who had come down with rabies. This was a historical first in medicine.

这是科学寻求知识的核心所在。科学试图为我们提供对现实的准确描述。未能通过检验的理论将被抛弃。通过检验的理论将存活更久，但必须接受进一步检验。至少，这是科学理想的运作方式。

This is an example that lies at the very heart of science’s quest for knowledge. Science tries to give us accurate descriptions of reality. Theories that fail to pass tests are dropped. Theories that do pass tests live longer but have to be put to further tests. This, at least, is how science ideally functions.

什么时候可以合理地得出一个理论充分描述了现实的结论？答案是，当该理论能够比之前的理论更好地解释一种或多种现象，并且重复的测试一次又一次地得出相同的结果时。假设没有其他测试对给定的理论产生怀疑，该理论就会逐渐被科学界接受。如果该理论还可以应用于建造新的实验仪器和设计新的技术设备，那么人们可以说该理论已经证明了它的可行性。

When is it reasonable to conclude that a theory describes reality to an adequate degree? The answer is, it’s when the theory can explain one or more phenomena better than earlier theories, and when repeated tests give the same results over and over again. Assuming that there aren’t other tests that cast doubt on the given theory, the theory is gradually accepted by the scientific community. If the theory can furthermore be applied to the building of new pieces of experimental apparatus and the devising of new technical devices, then one can say that the theory has demonstrated its viability.

当然，科学界对接受新理论存在一定的阻力。一个理论越具有开创性和令人惊奇，科学界接受它之前需要的证据就越多。这就是为什么，例如，阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦在 1905 年提出的光是由粒子组成的激进观点遭到如此蔑视的原因——它太激进了，而且没有足够的实验证据。这是思想史上一个有点令人悲伤的插曲，但幸运的是，它相当例外。事实上，我们总体上应该感到非常欣慰，因为科学家并不是对任何新想法都轻易屈服的。如果科学的实践者不先认真审查任何旧的新想法，就热情地欢迎它，那么科学就只不过是一大堆真假教义的随机大杂烩。

Of course there is a certain resistance in science to the acceptance of new theories. The more pathbreaking and surprising a theory is, the more evidence is required before the scientific world will accept it. This is why, for instance, Albert Einstein’s radical suggestion, in 1905, of light as being composed of particles was treated with such disdain—it was just too radical, and there wasn’t sufficient experimental evidence for it. This was a somewhat sad episode in the history of ideas, but fortunately, it was quite exceptional. Indeed, we should in general be very relieved that scientists are not just instant pushovers for any new idea that comes along. Science would be nothing but a huge random mishmosh of true and false teachings if its practitioners were to warmly welcome any old new idea willy-nilly into the fold without seriously vetting it first.

经验和实验是科学实践的核心。但我们能一直依赖实验吗？也许实验者忘记了某些因素，或者也许想要找到某个结果的愿望影响了实验者的客观性？对一个孤立的实验结果持怀疑态度是完全合理的，尤其是当它与之前的结果有很大不同时。

Experience and experimentation are central in the practice of science. But can we always rely on experiments? Maybe the experimenter forgot about some factor, or maybe the desire to find a certain result affected the experimenter’s objectivity? It’s perfectly reasonable to be dubious about just one isolated experimental result, especially if it’s very different from previous results.

因此，测试和实验应可重复是一个关键原则。世界各地的其他研究人员应该能够在自己的实验室中重复给定的实验，当然他们应该得到结果是一样的。如果一个理论站得住脚，那么无论谁来测试它，它都应该有效。如果一个理论被广泛接受，那就意味着到目前为止，没有人能够找到它的任何漏洞。因此，似乎有理由假设该理论是对现实的良好描述，它可以以多种方式应用，至少在出现另一种更好的现实描述之前。

It is therefore a key principle that tests and experiments should be repeatable. Other researchers throughout the world should be able to repeat a given experiment in their own labs, and of course they should get the same result. If a theory holds water, then it should work no matter who is testing it. And if a theory is widely accepted, that means that no one—so far—has been able to find any holes in it. For this reason, it seems reasonable to assume that the theory is a good description of reality, which can be applied in diverse ways, at least until another description of reality comes along that is even better.

可证伪性

Falsifiability

维也纳哲学家卡尔·波普尔（1902-1994）是二十世纪最著名的科学哲学家之一。波普尔提出了“可证伪性”这一术语，并声称这一概念实际上是科学进步的核心。

Viennese philosopher Karl Popper (1902–1994) was among the twentieth century’s most famous philosophers of science. Popper introduced the term “falsifiability” and claimed that this notion, in actuality, is what lies at the core of scientific progress.

理论可证伪意味着必须有某种方法来设计实验或情境，从原则上可以证明该理论是错误的。换句话说，必须有某种方法来陈述足以明确证明该理论错误的内容。如果做不到这一点，那么该理论就缺乏科学内容，没有科学价值。

For a theory to be falsifiable means that there must some way to devise an experiment or a situation that could, in principle, show that the theory is wrong. Otherwise put, there must be some way to state what would suffice to definitively prove the theory wrong. If this can’t be done, then the theory lacks scientific content and has no scientific worth.

这样，证伪就是推论式推论规则的一个例子。我们有一个理论 A，它引发了一个实验，如果这个理论是正确的，那么应该会得到结果 B。我们进行了实验，结果发现它并没有给出结果 B，而是给出了非 B。然后我们可以演绎地得出结论，事实并非如此，也就是说，我们证伪了理论 A。

In this way, falsification is an example of the deductive rule of inference modus tollens. We have a theory A that gives rise to an experiment that, if the theory is correct, should give result B. We carry out the experiment, and it turns out that it doesn’t give result B but, instead, gives not-B. Then we can deductively conclude that not-A is the case, which is to say, we have falsified theory A.

根据波普尔的说法，这个想法是科学的真正核心。没有任何科学理论可以被认为是绝对正确的；充其量，它只是暂时正确，直到被证伪的那一天。正如他所说：

According to Popper, this idea is the true core of science. No scientific theory can ever be considered definitively true; at best, it is tentatively true, waiting until the day that it is falsified. As he puts it:

进步在于走向理论，这些理论告诉我们越来越多的东西——内容越来越丰富的理论。但是，理论说得越多，它排除或禁止的东西就越多，证伪的机会也就越大。因此，内容更丰富的理论可以接受更严格的检验。5

Progress consisted in moving towards theories which tell us more and more—theories of ever greater content. But the more a theory says, the more it excludes or forbids, and the greater are the opportunities for falsifying it. So a theory with greater content is one which can be more severely tested.5

可证伪性的概念也可以通过著名的“二十个问题”游戏来说明。人们提出一系列是非问题（最多二十个），试图弄清楚另一个人正在考虑什么样的物体（或动物或人）。当然，人们会选择答案提供尽可能多信息的是非问题。因此，理想情况下，每个新的问题将可能的对象（或动物或人）分成两个几乎相等大小的组——一组对应于“是”的答案，另一组对应于“否”的答案。这是试图找出谜语答案的最有效方法。（人们永远不会问一个几乎肯定事先知道答案的问题，因为那只是浪费了二十个允许的问题中的一个。）

The concept of falsifiability can also be illustrated by the well-known game of Twenty Questions. One poses a series of yes/no questions—twenty at most—to try to figure out what sort of object (or animal or person) another person is thinking of. Of course one chooses yes/no questions whose answers provide as much information as possible. Thus ideally, each new question cleaves the set of possible objects (or animals or people) into two nearly equal-sized groups—one group corresponding to a “yes” answer and the other to a “no” answer. This is the most efficient way to try to figure out the answer to the riddle. (One doesn’t ever ask a question to which one almost surely knows the answer beforehand, since that would simply be wasting one of the twenty allowed questions.)

进行实验来检验科学理论就像提出一个关于现实本质的问题。如果没有可能提出一个答案可能是“否”的问题，那么这个理论就不是科学理论。

Doing an experiment to test a scientific theory is like posing a question about the nature of reality. If there is no possible way to devise a question to which the answer might be “no,” then the theory is not a scientific theory.

无论提出什么实验问题，如果一个理论只能得出“是”的答案，那么它就是不可证伪的，因此它根本不能告诉我们有关这个世界的任何信息。科学的目标是告诉我们有关这个世界的信息，因此，一个只能得出“是”的理论不是科学的，而只是伪科学。6

A theory that only leads to “yes” answers, no matter what experimental question is being asked, is not falsifiable, and thus it tells us nothing at all about the world. The goal of science is to say things about the world, and a “yes”-only theory is thus not scientific but merely pseudoscientific.6

因此，可证伪性是区分科学与伪科学的一种方式。波普尔在自传中描述了他在成为教师之前如何思考科学的本质：

Falsifiability is thus a way to distinguish science from pseudoscience. In his autobiography, Popper describes how, before he became a teacher, he was pondering the nature of science:

在这一时期的早期，我进一步发展了关于科学理论（如爱因斯坦的理论）和伪科学理论（如马克思、弗洛伊德和阿德勒的理论）之间界限的想法。我清楚地认识到，理论或陈述之所以具有科学性，是因为它能够排除或排除某些可能发生的事件——禁止或阻止这些事件的发生。因此，理论禁止的越多，它告诉我们的就越多。7

Early during this period I developed further my ideas about the demarcation between scientific theories (like Einstein’s) and pseudoscientific theories (like Marx’s, Freud’s, and Adler’s). It became clear to me that what made a theory, or a statement, scientific was its power to rule out, or exclude, the occurrence of some possible events—to prohibit, or forbid, the occurrence of these events. Thus the more a theory forbids, the more it tells us.7

如果你提出了一个科学理论，那么你必须能够说出在什么情况下你会承认你的理论是站不住脚的。这就是波普尔区分科学和伪科学的著名“划界标准”。（更一般地说，科学哲学中的“划界问题”涉及如何以及在何处划一条界线来定义什么才是真正的科学。这样的界线可以划在科学和伪科学之间，也可以划在科学和宗教之间，也可以划在科学和迷信之间。）

If you offer a scientific theory, then you have to be able to say under what sorts of circumstances you would concede that your theory is untenable. This is Popper’s famous “demarcation criterion” for distinguishing science from pseudoscience. (More generally, the “demarcation problem” in the philosophy of science concerns how and where one can draw a line defining what counts as genuine science. Such lines can be drawn between science and pseudoscience, or between science and religion, or between science and superstition.)

数学及其绝对真理

Mathematics and Its Absolute Truths

是否存在绝对真理的科学发现——即使有新发现出现，也无法推翻的事实？是的，但仅限于一个领域：数学（以及逻辑等相关主题）。数学世界是真正的先验科学。（先验知识——拉丁语意为“从一开始”——是其有效性不依赖于感官体验或与物理世界的接触的知识。）

Do there exist any scientific findings that are absolute truths—facts that can never be overturned when new discoveries come to light? Yes, but only in one domain: mathematics (and related topics like logic). The world of math is truly an a priori science. (Knowledge that is a priori—Latin for “from the outset”—is knowledge whose validity doesn’t depend on sensory experiences or on contact with the physical world.)

我们可以先验地得出的结论是，我们无需离开我们舒适地坐着的扶手椅就能得出的结论。换句话说，我们不需要探索世界，做出这样或那样的观察，就能得出这样的结论。数学不依赖于任何类型的外部观察。所有结论都是通过逻辑推导得出的。 （或者至少从已发表的数学证明文章来看，情况似乎如此。但在现实生活中，数学家几乎总是首先通过跳过逻辑的类比直观地得出结论。数学家和我们其他人一样多地使用猜测，但他们会巧妙地掩盖自己的踪迹，通过撰写文章来掩盖原始猜测的痕迹，所有内容都用纯逻辑语言表达，有点像作者是机器人而不是人类。）这意味着数学定理一旦得到严格证明，就永远不会因任何外部观察、测量或经验而失效。（如前所述，数学定理是通过纯逻辑步骤从公理中推导出的陈述。一组形式符号加上一组公理加上一组推理规则构成了一个形式系统或公理系统。在这样的系统内推导出的定理在该系统内始终为真。）

A conclusion that we can reach a priori is one that we can draw without ever leaving the armchair in which we’re so comfortably ensconced. In other words, we don’t need to poke about in the world, making this or that observation, in order to draw such a conclusion. Mathematics does not depend on any type of external observations. All conclusions are reached via logical derivations. (Or at least from the published articles of math proofs, that’s how it would seem. In real life, though, mathematicians almost always first reach their conclusions intuitively, via analogies that skip over logic. Mathematicians use just as much guesswork as the rest of us do, but then they slyly cover their tracks by writing articles in which no traces of the original guesswork are visible, everything being couched in a purely logical language, a bit as if the author were a robot rather than a human being.) What this implies is that a mathematical theorem, once it has been rigorously proven, can never be invalidated by any kind of external observation, measurement, or experience. (As was mentioned earlier, mathematical theorems are statements that are derived via purely logical steps from axioms. A set of formal symbols, plus a set of axioms, plus a set of rules of inference constitute a formal system or axiomatic system. A theorem that is derived inside such a system is always true inside that system.)

当然，数学家也应该保持一定程度的谦逊。数学家和其他人一样，也会犯错误。即使没有实验可以推翻数学结果，人们在证明定理时也可能犯逻辑错误。因此，数学在科学界享有特殊地位。如果人们在推导定理时没有犯任何错误，那么可以说，这个定理将永远被载入定理博物馆。 （警告：已证明的定理只被供奉在属于人们使用过的形式系统的博物馆中。其他形式系统可能还有其他博物馆，在这些博物馆中，给定的定理根本不出现。事实上，1931 年，年轻的奥地利逻辑学家库尔特·哥德尔证明，在任何一个给定的足够复杂的公理系统中，都有某些陈述，人们肯定会希望它们是定理，因为它们表达了真理，但在给定的系统内没有证明。换句话说，在给定的公理系统中，真实的和可证明的之间存在着巨大的差距。哥德尔证明，在所有足够丰富的公理系统中，都有无数个真实但无法证明的陈述。这这个令人惊奇的结果，几十年后才被数学界所接受，被称为“哥德尔不完备定理”。

Of course there should be some degree of humility even among mathematicians. No less than other beings, mathematicians can make errors. Even if no experiment can reverse a mathematical result, one can nonetheless have made logical errors in one’s (alleged) proof of a theorem. Mathematics thus has a special status in the world of science. If one has not committed any errors in one’s derivation of a theorem, then the theorem is enshrined forever in the Museum of Theorems, so to speak. (Caveat: the proven theorem is enshrined only in the Museum belonging to the formal system one has used. There can be other Museums for other formal systems in which the given theorem doesn’t appear at all. In fact, in 1931, the young Austrian logician Kurt Gödel showed that, in any given axiomatic system of sufficient complexity, there are certain statements that one would definitely want to be theorems, because they express truths, but that have no proof inside the given system. In other words, there is a serious gulf between what is true and what is provable in a given axiomatic system. Gödel showed that there are infinitely many true but unprovable statements in all sufficiently rich axiomatic systems. This astonishing result, which took decades to be absorbed by the mathematical world, goes by the name of “Gödel’s incompleteness theorem.”)

盲法实验和安慰剂

Blind Experiments and Placebos

在科学探索世界时，如何避免犯错？当然，没有神奇的秘诀可以避免错误。几个世纪以来，马虎、一厢情愿和对荣耀和名望的追求使许多研究人员误入歧途。但是，尽管人性难免会犯错，但科学作为人类的集体活动，具有某些内在属性，可以作为保持诚实和走上正道的极好手段。（当然，这假定科学家是一个诚实的人。）这些方法中最重要的，尤其是在医学领域，就是所谓的盲测和双盲测试。

How can one avoid making mistakes when exploring the world scientifically? Of course, there is no magical recipe for avoiding mistakes. Sloppiness, wishful thinking, and the quest for glory and fame have led many a researcher astray, down through the centuries. But despite human fallibility, science as a collective human activity has certain built-in properties that serve as excellent devices to keep one honest and on the straight and narrow path. (Of course, this takes for granted that the scientist in question is an honest person.) Among the most important of these methods, especially important in the realm of medical science, are what are known as blind and double-blind tests.

此类测试的目的是消除研究人员的任何无意识偏见或一厢情愿的想法，并且当涉及人类受试者时，也要消除实验对象的这种倾向。今天我们意识到，在新型药物测试等情况下，一个人的欲望和信念可以产生积极和消极的影响。

The goal of such tests is to eliminate any unconscious biases or wishful thinking on the part of the researcher and, whenever human subjects are involved, to eliminate such tendencies on the part of experimental subjects as well. Today we realize that a person’s desires and beliefs can have both positive and negative effects in such situations as tests of new types of medicines.

失眠症患者可能希望每晚服用安眠药。患者可以从医生那里获得这种药物，但医生可能会在不告知患者的情况下，给患者一些糖丸而不是真正的安眠药。患者服用这些药物后，整晚都能安然入睡。这种效应被称为安慰剂效应（“安慰剂”在拉丁语中意为“我会取悦[你]”）。归根结底，一个人的心理期望有时可以产生与真正药物一样有效的医疗效果。

A patient who has insomnia may wish to take a sleeping pill every evening. The patient can obtain such pills from a doctor, but the doctor might, without telling the patient, give the patient just some sugar pills instead of true sleeping pills. The patient takes these pills and has no problem sleeping through the night. This effect is called the placebo effect (“placebo” being Latin for “I will please [you]”). It comes down to the idea that a person’s psychological expectations can sometimes have a medical effect that is just as efficacious as a genuine medicine.

安慰剂效应的反面被称为反安慰剂效应，即积极的期望导致消极的结果。这种现象的一个很好的例子出现在某些非洲基于自然的宗教中。在尼日利亚的一个小村庄里，一台燃气发电机有一天从其中一间小屋里消失了。有人偷了它。村里的巫医召集全村居民开会，宣布他施了一个诅咒，将立即对偷发电机的人生效。他声称，这个咒语会使偷发电机的人进食困难、胃痛剧烈，并逐渐变得非常虚弱。几天后，发电机突然又出现了。一个小男孩感到不舒服，然后他听说了这个咒语。他无法正常进食或饮水，最后，他带回了发电机。这是反安慰剂效应的一个明显例子。对魔法力量的信仰导致咒语症状的出现。安慰剂效应和反安慰剂效应都得到了仔细的研究和记录。

The opposite of the placebo effect is called the nocebo effect, and this is when having positive expectations leads to a negative result. A good example of this phenomenon shows up in certain African nature-based religions. In a tiny Nigerian hamlet, a gas-driven generator disappears one day from one of the huts. Someone stole it. The village’s witch doctor calls a meeting of all the village’s residents and announces that he has cast a curse that will take effect immediately on the person who stole the generator. The spell will, so he claims, make the person have trouble eating, have intense stomachaches, and gradually become very sick. A few days later, the generator suddenly reappears. A young boy had felt sick, and then he heard about the spell. He hadn’t been able to eat or to drink normally, and in the end, he brought back the generator. This is a clear example of the nocebo effect. The belief in magical powers causes the symptoms of the spell to appear. Both the placebo effect and the nocebo effect have been carefully researched and documented.

如果我们想研究一种新药的疗效，就必须使用所谓的盲测来避免安慰剂效应。这意味着一组受试者接受真正的药物，而另一组受试者接受一种看起来与真正药物一模一样的制剂，但实际上它只是糖丸，根本不含任何真正的药物。这两组受试者都不知道哪组服用的是真药，哪组服用的是糖丸。换句话说，受试者对于这一信息是“盲目的”。只有在这种受控的情况下，测试才能显示药物是否真的有效果，而不是仅仅归功于安慰剂效应或其他某种幸运干扰。

If we wish to investigate the effect of a new medicine, we have to avoid the placebo effect by using what is called a blind test. What this means is that one group of subjects receives the actual medicine, while another group of subjects receives a preparation that looks exactly like the actual medicine but it is actually just a sugar pill that doesn’t contain any genuine medicine at all. Neither of the groups knows which one is getting the actual medicine and which one is getting the sugar pills. In other words, the subjects are “blind” with respect to this piece of knowledge. Only under such controlled circumstances can the test show whether the medicine actually has an effect, and that it isn’t merely thanks to a placebo effect or some other kind of lucky interference.

在一些药物测试中，经常发现服用糖丸的组表现出强烈的积极作用。在这种情况下，这显然是安慰剂效应。希望服用正品药物的组表现出更强的积极作用。因此，两种积极作用之间的差异应该表明正品药物的效力有多强。如果两种积极作用之间没有任何差异，那么这种药物就没有价值。

In some tests of medicines, it often turns out that the group that received sugar pills shows a strong positive effect. In this case, it is clearly a placebo effect. Hopefully, the group that received the genuine medicine will show a stronger positive effect. The difference between the two positive effects should thus show how powerful the genuine medicine is. If there is no difference at all between the two positive effects, then the medicine is of no value.

如果研究人员有偏见或一厢情愿怎么办？这难道不会影响盲测的结果吗？当然！正因为如此，人们才设计了双盲实验。在这种情况下，研究人员和受试者都事先不知道哪组人吃了真药，哪组人吃了糖丸。只有对实验进行统计分析后，才能揭示哪组人吃了什么。

What if the researcher has some biases or engages in wishful thinking? Can’t that have an effect on the results of a blind experiment? Of course! It’s for this reason that people have devised double-blind experiments. In such situations, neither the researchers nor the subjects know in advance which group received the true medicine, and which one got the sugar pills. Only when the statistical analysis of the experiment has been carried out can it be revealed which group received what.

盲法和双盲实验对于涉及对人类影响的科学研究至关重要。这些想法在处理当今泛滥的伪科学治疗和药物时尤其重要，尤其是在新时代圈子和替代医学从业者中。不幸的是，这些实验和假药引诱和欺骗了许多人；受害者最终不仅在金钱上受骗，而且在情感上也受骗。通常与新时代医学（和其他替代医学）相关的方法和药物在以盲法或双盲方式进行适当和认真的测试时几乎总是会失败。

Blind and double-blind experiments are crucial to scientific research that involves effects on human beings. These ideas are particularly important in dealing with the plethora of pseudoscientific treatments and medications that are so rife today, especially in New Age circles and in practitioners of alternative medicine. These kinds of experiments, and fake medicines, unfortunately lure and deceive many people; the victims wind up getting tricked not only monetarily but also emotionally. The methods and medicines that are usually associated with New Age medicine (and other alternative types of medicine) almost always fall short when they are properly and seriously tested in a blind or double-blind manner.

那么，真正有效的替代药物应该叫什么名字呢？那么，它就是真正的药物。

And so, what should one call an alternative medicine that actually does work? Well, it is then a genuine medicine.

科学的阴暗面

The Darker Side of Science

有时我们会遇到表现出极大僵化的科学代表，也许最常见的情况是与医生打交道。我们都有过这样的经历：去看医生，感觉医生没有认真听我们说话。医生脑子里想的似乎比我们小灵魂想要表达的要重要得多。

There are times when we encounter representatives of science who exhibit great rigidity, perhaps most commonly when we deal with physicians. We’ve all had the experience of going to the doctor and feeling that we weren’t being listened to carefully. Whatever’s running through the doctor’s head would seem to be far more important than whatever our little souls might be trying to express.

如果您对医生的这种傲慢态度感到沮丧，那么请记住，这不是科学的错，而是科学的特定代表，他已经下定了决心，因此觉得没有必要听您的意见。

If you feel frustrated about this haughty attitude on the part of your doctor, then keep in mind that it’s not science that’s at fault here, but just this particular representative of science, whose mind was made up in advance and who therefore doesn’t feel any need to listen to you.

即使某人是科学从业者，也不能保证他不会作弊。显然，科学家的文化就像任何其他人类文化一样，充满了有自己情感需求和心理议程的人。因此，有些研究人员发表伪造的结果只是为了获得名誉和荣耀。

The fact that someone is a practitioner of science is not any surefire guarantee that the person will not cheat. Obviously the culture of scientists, just like any other human culture, is filled with people who have their own emotional needs and psychological agendas. Thus there are researchers who publish falsified results simply to gain fame and glory.

还有一些研究人员一直不愿接受新的事实和结果，因为如果他们接受这些事实和结果，他们就必须放弃他们长期以来的信念，而他们的职业生涯正是建立在这些信念之上。幕后还可能存在经济利益，这导致人们竭尽全力质疑新的结果，因为如果这些结果被接受，它们将损害长期确立的药物的销售。

There are also researchers who persistently balk at accepting new facts and results, because were they to accept them, they would have to abandon beliefs they had long had, and on which their careers were built. There can also be financial interests behind the scenes, which lead people to do their best to cast doubt on new results, since if the results were accepted, they would hurt the sales of a long-established medication.

溃疡研究就是一个例子。2005 年，Barry J. Marshall 和 J. Robin Warren 因发现一种名为幽门螺杆菌的细菌而获得诺贝尔医学奖。（这种细菌于 1982 年首次在患有慢性胃炎的患者的培养物中发现。）多年来，溃疡被认为是压力和营养不良的结果。但 Marshall 和 Warren 提出了不同的理论，即溃疡是由细菌引起的。一段时间后，Marshall 证实了他的理论。他决定自己喝下幽门螺杆菌培养物，不久之后，他就患上了严重的胃炎。因果关系得到证实，Marshall 和 Warren 随后证明，溃疡患者可以借助抗生素永久治愈。在将两者联系起来之前细菌感染与溃疡之间的关联已得到证实，但该病往往是慢性的，患者经常复发。

An example of this concerns research on ulcers. In 2005, Barry J. Marshall and J. Robin Warren were awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine for their discovery of a bacterium that was given the name Helicobacter pylori. (This bacterium was first discovered in 1982 in cultures taken from patients suffering from chronic inflammation of the stomach.) For many years, ulcers were seen as the result of stress and bad nutrition. But Marshall and Warren had a different theory, which was that ulcers were caused by a bacterium. After some time, Marshall was able to prove his theory. He decided that he himself would drink a Helicobacter bacterial culture, and soon thereafter he was stricken by a severe stomach inflammation. The causal link was confirmed, and Marshall and Warren then showed that patients with ulcers can be permanently cured with the help of antibiotics. Before the connection between bacterial infection and ulcers had been confirmed, however, the illness was often chronic, and patients often suffered relapses.

起初，马歇尔和沃伦的发现遭到的只有质疑。这关系到巨大的经济利益。由于制药业从各种溃疡药物中赚取了巨额利润，因此它不想让主流的溃疡理论受到质疑。毕竟，对于制药业来说，患者频繁复发总是比一劳永逸地治愈更好。马歇尔和沃伦的研究结果之所以没有发表，至少部分原因是，如果他们的发现被认真对待，将带来巨大的经济利益。

At first, Marshall and Warren’s discovery met nothing but skepticism. Very significant financial profits were at stake. Since the pharmaceutical industry earned a great deal of money from various ulcer medications, it had no interest in having the reigning theories of ulcers cast in doubt. After all, it’s always better for the pharmaceutical industry when patients suffer frequent relapses, rather than winding up being cured for once and for all. Marshall and Warren’s research results were held back from publication at least in part because of the high financial stakes if their findings were taken seriously.

一般来说，追求科学知识最终是所有方法中最成功的，但它可能需要比应有的更多的时间。因虚荣、金钱或固执而阻碍进步的尝试通常不会持续很长时间。有时科学研究人员被指责互相拍马屁，互相隐瞒错误。但事实上，科学研究界很难被描述为保护不成功的理论。任何成功推翻既定理论的研究人员都可能既富有又出名——甚至可能获得诺贝尔奖。这是试图证伪理论的强烈动机。

As a general rule, the quest for scientific knowledge is the most successful of all approaches in the end, but it can take much more time than it ought to. Attempts to hold back progress because of vanity, money, or stubbornness don’t generally succeed for very long. Sometimes scientific researchers are accused of patting each other on the back and of hiding each other’s mistakes. But in truth, the world of scientific research could scarcely be described as protective of unsuccessful theories. Any researcher who succeeds in blowing an established theory to bits will probably be both rich and famous—and may even win a Nobel Prize. That’s a pretty strong motivation to try to falsify theories.

宗教与科学可以互相兼容吗？

Are Religion and Science Mutually Compatible?

在公众讨论中，一个反复出现的问题是科学和宗教是否兼容。这个问题常常被用作进行冗长而深刻的冥想的借口。

A question that recurs time and again in public discussions is whether science and religion are compatible. This question is often turned into an excuse for lengthy and supposedly profound meditations.

但事实上，这个问题很容易回答：只要宗教不提出任何与科学知识相悖的主张，宗教和科学就是兼容的。更简单地说：只要宗教不对世界发表任何言论，那么就没有冲突。举个例子，关于相信造物主的问题，造物主从虚无中创造了宇宙，之后不再参与其中。实际上，相信这种神是毫无意义的。它没有告诉我们我们为什么在这里，我们要去哪里，我们应该如何生活，或者现实的本质。

But in truth, the question is rather easy to answer: Religion and science are compatible just so long as the religion in question doesn’t make any claims that run against scientific knowledge. More simply put: As long as religion doesn’t say anything about the world, then there’s no conflict. Take, for example, the question about belief in a creator who made the universe out of nothing, and thereafter played no role in it. A belief in this kind of god is, in practice, quite meaningless. It doesn’t tell us anything about why we are here, where we are headed, how we should live, or the nature of reality.

另一方面，如果一个人相信一个有各种欲望和力量的神，事情就会变得更加混乱。一个听祷告并创造奇迹的神肯定与科学不相容。灵魂在身体死亡后继续存在的概念、轮回转世或其他类似概念也与科学不相容。超自然观点。这些观点本身不一定是错误的，只是科学发现明确地表明它们是错误的。

On the other hand, if one believes in a god that has various desires and powers, things get messier. A god that listens to prayers and carries out miracles is definitely not compatible with science. Nor is the notion that the soul survives after the body dies, nor is the idea of reincarnation, or other similar supernatural views. It’s not that these kinds of ideas, in and of themselves, are necessarily wrong; it’s just that science’s findings unambiguously indicate that they are wrong.

另一个常见问题是，如今神学是否能以某种方式促进科学发展，或者反过来说，科学是否能促进神学发展。对于第一个问题，除了“不能”之外，我看不出还有其他可能的答案。无论神学的主张是否正确，它所讨论的问题都超出了科学的范畴（除了那些与科学直接冲突的神学主张）。然而，科学可以帮助神学放弃某些先入为主的观念，例如人类与自然进化不同，不是自然进化的结果这一论点。

Another frequent question is whether theology can in some way contribute to science these days or, conversely, whether science can contribute to theology. To the first question I can’t see any possible answer other than “no.” Whether or not its claims are correct, theology is all about questions that lie beyond the domain of science (except for those theological claims that directly conflict with science). Science, however, can help theology abandon certain preconceived notions, such as the thesis that humans stand apart from, and are not an outcome of, natural evolution.

宗教对科学有过什么贡献吗？是的，如果回顾科学史，就会发现它确实有贡献。世界是可理解的这一观念在历史上与存在一个智慧造物主这一观念联系在一起。如果人们不相信世界是可理解的，那么献身于科学就毫无意义。从这个意义上说，宗教为科学的进步铺平了道路。然而，这一事实并没有增加上帝或智慧造物主存在的可能性；但可理解性这一观念帮助科学取得了初步进展。

Has religion ever done anything useful for science? Well, yes—if one looks at the history of science, one has to say that it has. The notion that the world is comprehensible has historically been connected with the idea that there is an intelligent creator. If one didn’t believe in the world’s comprehensibility, then it would be pointless for one to devote oneself to science. In this sense, religion paved the way for science’s progress. This fact does not, however, increase the likelihood of the existence of a god or an intelligent creator; but the idea of comprehensibility helped science make its first inroads.

插曲：论科学的实用性

INTERLUDE: ON THE USEFULNESS OF SCIENCE

一个人能过于相信科学吗？毕竟，历史告诉我们，科学并不总是正确的。我们很容易忘记，科学不仅仅是生产大量关于世界的真理。科学远不止于此；科学是一种研究现实的方式——一种建立关于宇宙如何运作的模型、图像和理论的方式。科学对现实的描述经常需要修改，除了遵循科学道路，我们不知道还有什么更好的方法来获得关于现实的知识。从这个意义上说，不可能过于相信科学。

Can one believe too strongly in science? After all, history has taught us that science is not always right. It is easy to forget that science is not simply the business of producing huge batches of truths about the world. Science is far more than that; science is a way of investigating reality—a way of forging models, pictures, and theories about how the universe works. Science’s pictures of reality often have to be revised, and we don’t know any better way to attain knowledge of reality than by following the scientific path. In that sense, it’s not possible to believe too strongly in science.

我们所谓的科学实际上应该根据其发现的有效性来评判，它是否为我们提供工具和药物来战胜癌症或霍乱等疾病，或者是否为我们提供巧妙的方法来克服人们所熟悉的自然限制，如重力，使我们能够将人类送上月球，或者很快送上火星。

What we call science should actually be judged on the basis of how effective its findings are, when it gives us tools and medicines to defeat diseases like cancer or cholera, or when it gives us clever ways to overcome the familiar constraints of nature, such as gravity, allowing us to send humans to the moon, or perhaps soon to Mars.

科学总是向善的力量吗？好吧，想想硝酸甘油——它能拯救患有癌症的病人的生命。心脏虚弱的人——也会把人打得粉身碎骨。所有知识也是如此。科学是否道德取决于其发现如何被使用。知识本身是中性的。

Is science always a force for good? Well, consider the fact that nitroglycerin—the very same thing that can save the life of a patient with a weak heart—can also blow people to bits. And so it is with all knowledge. Whether science is moral or not comes down to how its findings are used. The knowledge in itself is neutral.

科学对于我们的日常生活有什么意义？当我们听到有关科学发现的新闻时，它通常涉及一些非常抽象和遥远的事情，例如 2012 年发现希格斯玻色子（我上班时几乎不需要知道这件事），或者 2014 年太空探测器罗塞塔号在发射约十年后着陆彗星表面。但我们不应忽视这样一个事实，即 2014 年诺贝尔物理学奖颁给了 LED 灯的开发。这项多年研发的成果改善了全球数亿人的生活。

What meaning does science have for us in our daily lives? When we hear a news item about a scientific finding, it often concerns something extremely abstract and remote, such as the discovery, in 2012, of the Higgs boson (hardly something that I need to know when I show up at my office), or the landing of the space probe Rosetta on the surface of a comet in 2014, some ten years after its launching. But we shouldn’t lose sight of the fact that the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics was given for the development of LED lights. This outcome of many years of research and development improved the lives of hundreds of millions of people all around the globe.

就我个人而言，科学几乎肯定延长了我的寿命，让我有机会拥有更多的经历。我很有可能比几百年前的祖先活得长一倍。我可以花两倍的时间与我亲爱的亲人在一起。我可以看着我的儿子长大，读书，玩游戏，获得零零碎碎的知识。多亏了科学，我才有这么多好运。我不断感谢科学给我这些惊人的礼物。

For me personally, science has almost certainly extended my life expectancy and given me the chance to have many more experiences. I have quite decent chances of living twice as long as my ancestors did, just a few hundred years ago. I can spend twice as much time with my precious loved ones. I can watch my son as he grows up, reads books, plays games, and gains bits and pieces of knowledge. And it’s thanks to science that I have all this good luck. I am constantly thankful to science for these astonishing gifts.

第五章

CHAPTER FIVE

头脑里的鬼魂关于我们奇妙却易被愚弄的大脑

GHOSTS IN THE HEAD Concerning Our Wonderful but Easily Fooled Brains

当我思考的时候，思考的不是我，而是我的大脑。——四岁的Leo Sturmark

When I think, it’s not me who’s thinking, but my brain that’s thinking.—Four-year-old Leo Sturmark

西为什么我们需要遵循科学方法来了解世界？难道我们奇妙的大脑本身就不够好，不需要对它们施加某种正式的纪律吗？

Why do we need to follow the methods of science in order to learn about the world? Aren’t our wonderful brains good enough by themselves, without imposing some kind of formal discipline on them?

科学家经常将人脑描述为“宇宙中最复杂的现象”。事实上，人脑的能力非常强大，令人惊叹。但即便如此，一个完全健康的大脑也可能以各种方式偏离轨道。

The human brain is often described by scientists as “the most complex phenomenon that we know in the universe.” And indeed, the capabilities of our brains are vast and truly stunning. But even so, a perfectly healthy brain can go off track in all sorts of ways.

我们的大脑蒙蔽了我们的眼睛

Our Brains Pull the Wool over Our Eyes

人类大脑有不少明显的缺陷，其中一些或全部缺陷可能会在未来一百万年左右的进化过程中得到修复。但就目前而言，我们只能忍受它们。

The human brain has quite a few salient shortcomings, some or all of which may well be repaired by evolution throughout the next million years or so. But for the time being, we’ll just have to put up with them.

视觉错觉

Optical Illusions

我所说的最简单的例子就是视觉错觉。我们很容易相信，两条长度完全相同的线，长度却相差很大。例如，请看图 5.1所示的两张桌子（这种错觉只是斯坦福大学杰出的心理学教授 Roger Shepard 在 20 世纪 80 年代初设计的众多错觉之一）。你会说钢琴凳左侧的对角直线与方形桌子远端边缘的水平线长度相同吗？可能不会。前者要长得多，不是吗？

The simplest example of what I mean is optical illusions. We can easily be convinced that two lines of exactly the same length have very different lengths. Look, for example, at the two tables shown in figure 5.1 (this illusion is just one of many designed by Stanford University’s brilliant psychology professor Roger Shepard in the early 1980s). Would you say that the diagonal straight line constituting the piano bench’s left side is the same length as the horizontal line constituting the squarish table’s far edge? Probably not. The former is far longer, isn’t it?

图 5.1. 两个表

Figure 5.1. Two Tables

事实上，不是这样的。这两条线段的长度完全相同。你的眼睛正确地告诉你，如果这两件家具并排摆放在一个房间里，左边的那件（钢琴凳）会比右边的那件（方形桌子）长得多，但你的大脑却把这个正确的信息转换成错误的想法，即图像中的两条线的长度相差很大。这个错误的推论很有说服力，不是吗？每次看到这张令人惊叹的图片，我仍然不敢相信，我必须真正测量它们。然后，我只是惊叹我的大脑对我玩的这个把戏。

Well, actually, no. The two line segments are exactly the same length. Your eye correctly tells you that if these two pieces of furniture were sitting side by side in a room, the left one (the piano bench) would be far longer than the right one (the squarish table) is wide, but your brain then converts that correct piece of information into the false idea that the two lines in the image are of vastly different lengths. The false inference is deeply compelling, isn’t it? Every time I look at this amazing image, I still can’t believe it, and I have to actually measure them both. And then I simply gasp at the trick my brain has played on me.

出于所有这些原因，我们需要工具来帮助我们了解真实的世界——这些工具比我们肉眼无法察觉的感官和容易受骗的大脑更可靠。

For all these reasons, we need tools to help us understand the world as it really is—tools that are more reliable than our unaided senses and our gullible brains.

联觉

Synesthesia

有时，我们的大脑会把一些信息拼凑在一起，得出一些非常有创意的结论，尽管这些结论毫无理性依据。一个典型的例子就是画出两个分别叫做“Kiki”和“Muma”的形状。看看图 5.2中的两个形状，看看哪个是“Kiki”，哪个是“Muma”。

On occasion, our brains put together pieces of information and draw wonderfully creative conclusions from them that have no rational basis. A classic case is the drawing of two shapes called “Kiki” and “Muma.” Take a look at the two shapes in figure 5.2 and decide which one is “Kiki” and which one is “Muma.”

图 5.2。这些图形叫什么？

Figure 5.2. What are these figures called?

几乎每个看到这两个图形的人都会确信，下面的那个叫“Muma”，上面的那个叫“Kiki”。那么，这其中可能的原因是什么呢？这些图片并没有展示你在日常生活中接触到的任何东西，而且这两个名字只是无意义的单词。那么，究竟是什么让你如此自信地得出结论，其中一个单词一定是其中一张图片的名字，另一个单词一定是另一张图片的名字呢？

Virtually everyone who looks at these two shapes is convinced that the one on the bottom is called “Muma” and the one on the top is called “Kiki.” Now what possible reason would there be for this? The pictures don’t show anything that you deal with in everyday life, and the two names are merely nonsense words. So what on earth would lead you to the confident conclusion that one of the words has to be the name for one of the pictures, and the other for the other?

没有什么合理的理由。原因很简单，我们听到的“Muma”比“Kiki”的声音更柔和、更圆润，而“Kiki”听起来更刺耳、更有棱角。我们倾向于认为底部的图像是柔和圆润的，而顶部的图像看起来更刺耳、更有棱角。

There is no rational reason. It simply comes down to the fact that we all hear “Muma” as a softer and rounder sound than “Kiki,” which tends to sound pricklier and more angular. And we tend to see the image on the bottom as soft and round, while the one on the top looks pricklier and more angular.

这种声音和形状之间的联系是一种联觉，即来自不同感觉器官的感觉的融合。联觉的另一个例子是许多人感觉某些数字与某些颜色相关联。因此，数字“7”对你来说可能是蓝色的，而“3”可能看起来是黄色的，等等。

This kind of connection between sounds and shapes is a form of synesthesia, which means a conflation of sensations coming from different sensory organs. Another example of synesthesia is the feeling many people have that certain digits are associated with certain colors. Thus the digit “7” might seem blue to you, while “3” might seem yellow, and so forth.

一个著名的联觉患者例子是丹尼尔·塔米特，他能背诵两万多位π数字（3.14159265358979323846264……）。在他的书《生于蓝色日子》（2006 年）中，他解释说，为了记住这么多数字，他并没有想到这些数字本身；相反，他在脑海中看到了它们，就像一系列颜色和起伏的风景。

A well-known example of a person with synesthesia is Daniel Tammet, who can recite more than twenty thousand digits of π (3.14159265358979323846264 . . .) by heart. In his book Born on a Blue Day (2006), he explains that to memorize so many digits, he didn’t think of the digits themselves; rather, he saw them in his mind’s eye, as a series of colors and undulating landscapes.

我们的大脑对我们耍了许多这样的花招，而我们却一点儿也不知道。幻觉并不总是与感官知觉有关。我们可怜的大脑在许多方面都容易受到影响。这是众多原因之一，因此我们必须开发科学程序和双盲测试。

Our brains play many such tricks on us, without our being in the least aware of them. And illusions don’t always involve sensory perception. Our poor brains are susceptible in many different ways. This is one reason, among many, that it is crucial that we have developed scientific procedures and double-blind tests.

锚定效应

The Anchoring Effect

以色列裔美国心理学家丹尼尔·卡尼曼研究了我们如何做决定，以及我们在做决定的过程中会受到哪些影响。1他发现并研究过一种现象，即所谓的锚定效应。这种现象的意思是，每当我们试图估计任何类型的数值时，我们都会无意识地受到刚刚看到的数字的影响，无论这些数字是否与手头的问题有关。

Israeli American psychologist Daniel Kahneman has investigated how we make decisions and how we can be influenced in our decision-making processes.1 One phenomenon that he has identified and studied is the so-called anchoring effect. The idea is that whenever we try to estimate a numerical value of any sort, we can be unconsciously biased by numbers that we have just seen, whether or not they have anything to do with the question at hand.

卡尼曼将这种偏见公之于众的例子之一是经典的“命运之轮实验”。2在这个实验中，受试者被问到一个答案在 1 到 100 之间的数字问题，例如“世界上有多少国家位于非洲？”（重要的是受试者不应该知道答案，因此只能猜测。）在受试者收到问题之前，他们首先被问到是否愿意使用彩票轮盘赌一下。（大多数人说是的。）这种轮盘通常可以停在 1 到 100 之间的任何数字上，但这个轮盘恰好被操纵成只停在 16 或 45 上。这个实验对许多不同的受试者（例如一千人）进行了多次。这意味着大约五百名受试者转动轮盘并在回答数字问题之前得到“16”；其他受试者，也是大约五百人，在回答之前得到“45”。

One of Kahneman’s examples that bring this bias out in the open is the classic “wheel-of-fortune experiment.”2 In this experiment, a subject is asked a question having a numerical answer between 1 and 100, such as “What percentage of the world’s nations are located in Africa?” (It’s crucial that the subject should not know the answer and, therefore, can only guess at it.) Before subjects receive the question, they are first asked if they would like to do a little gambling using a lottery wheel. (Most say yes.) Such wheels can normally stop on any number at all between 1 and 100, but this wheel happens to be rigged in such a way that it stops only on 16 or on 45. The experiment is done many times with many different subjects (say, one thousand). This means that roughly five hundred subjects spin the wheel and get a “16” before answering the numerical question; the other subjects, also roughly five hundred in number, get a “45” before answering.

结果表明，平均而言，猜中“16”的受试者对非洲国家所占百分比的猜测要低于猜中“45”的受试者。尽管彩票轮盘显然与他们收到的问题毫无关系，但这种偏见仍然存在。

It turns out that on the average, the subjects who got the “16” make lower guesses at the percentage of the world’s countries located in Africa than those who got the “45.” This bias occurs even though the lottery wheel obviously has nothing whatsoever to do with the question they received.

因此，受试者的估计会无意识地受到他们在猜测之前看到的数字的影响。这表明我们的大脑很容易被愚弄，而且它们并不总是做出有根据的猜测。当我们遵循直觉或“直觉”时，意识到这种弱点是很重要的。这种无意识的偏见在法庭案件或其他情况下尤其麻烦，在这些情况下，证人的数值估计可能会对有关各方产生重大影响。

The subjects’ estimates are thus unconsciously biased by the number they saw just before making their guess. This shows how easily our brains can be fooled, and how they don’t by any means always make well-grounded guesses. It’s important to be aware of such vulnerabilities when we are following our intuitions or our “gut feelings.” This kind of unconscious bias is particularly troublesome in court cases or other situations in which numerical estimates by witnesses can have major consequences for the parties concerned.

自我形象膨胀

Bloated Self-Images

我们人类也容易高估自己，对自己的形象过于乐观。一个明显的例子是这样的实验：实验对象在计算机屏幕上看到一百张随机选择的面孔的小照片。3屏幕上的众多照片中，有一张“恰好”是实验对象本人。然后实验者测量实验对象在屏幕上的众多面孔中找到并指出自己的面孔所需的时间。然后实验重复多次，每次都将面孔打乱，使它们出现在屏幕上的不同位置。

We humans also suffer from a tendency to overestimate ourselves and to have overly positive self-images. A clear example of this is an experiment in which a subject is shown one hundred small photos of randomly chosen faces scattered here and there on a computer screen.3 One of the many photos on the screen “just happens” to be of the actual subject of the experiment. The experimenters then measure the time it takes for the subject to find and point out their own face among the many on the screen. The experiment is then repeated a large number of times, each time with the faces scrambled, so that they appear in different locations on the screen.

然而，受试者不知道的是，经过一两次扫描后，他们自己的照片会被一张经过处理的照片所取代，这使得受试者看起来比实际更有吸引力（至少按照传统标准）。事实证明，受试者在随机面孔中找到经过增强的肖像的速度比找到未经增强的肖像的速度要快。

What subjects do not know, however, is that after the first run or two, their own photo gets replaced by a manipulated photo, which makes the subject look more attractive (at least by conventional standards) than they actually are. It turns out that subjects tend to locate their enhanced portrait among the random faces faster than they locate their unenhanced portrait.

毋庸置疑，这告诉我们，我们的自我形象有些令人不安。也许曾经人们对自己的外表有一点自满的感觉是有用的；也许有这种自我形象的人往往能更好地生存。但这对我们今天来说是好事吗？人们常说乐观主义者比现实主义者更快乐，但我们仍然应该意识到我们大脑的这种偏见。

What this tells us about our self-image is, needless to say, somewhat troubling. Perhaps it once was useful for people to have a slightly bloated sense of their own appearance; perhaps people who had that sort of self-image would tend to survive better. But is this a good thing for us today? It’s often said that optimists are happier than realists, but we should nonetheless be aware of this bias on the part of our brains.

焦点和盲点

Focus and Blind Spots

我们也并不像我们希望的那样善于观察。当我谈论哲学和清晰思考的工具时，我经常会播放一段取自一个著名实验的短片，实验对象观看一段六个人走来走去并来回抛篮球的视频，他们要数出三个穿白衣服的球员传了多少球。结果非常令人惊讶。观看视频片段的人对传球次数的了解程度差异很大。但还有更惊人的效果。我不想透露太多；相反，我强烈建议您自己查看视频，4并且只有在这样做之后才继续阅读。只需尝试准确计算三名身穿白色衣服的球员进行了多少次传球。

We are also not quite so observant as we might wish. When I give talks about philosophy and tools for clear thinking, I often show a short video taken from a famous experiment in which subjects watch a video of six people walking about and tossing basketballs back and forth, and they are supposed to count how many passes are made by the three players who are wearing white. The result is very surprising. The estimates of how many passes take place varies greatly among people who watch the video clip. But much more striking effects occur as well. I don’t wish to reveal too much; instead, I strongly recommend that you check out the video yourself,4 and that you read further only after having done so. Just try to count accurately how many passes are made by the three players in white.

很多观看该视频的人都没有注意到在传球的同时还发生的其他有趣的事情，而当他们第二次观看该视频时，他们都会感到非常惊讶。

Many people who watch this video are oblivious to other interesting things that occur in it at the same time as the ball passings, and they are quite amazed when they watch the video a second time around.

僵尸病毒的可能性

The Likelihood of a Zombie Virus

大脑缺陷的另一个例子是，大多数人都无法很好地评估风险和概率。我们的大脑构造并不特别适合进行此类判断，这一事实可能会导致非常严重的误判。通过进行以下思想实验来测试您自己的能力：

Another example of our brains’ deficiencies is how poorly most of us gauge risks and probabilities. Our brains are not particularly well constructed for such judgments, and this fact can give rise to very serious misjudgments. Test your own ability by carrying out the following thought experiment:

  1. 现在，一种丧尸病毒正在全国迅速蔓延。据了解，每五百人中就有一人会感染这种病毒。这些人将在一个月内全部变成丧尸，这对他们来说当然不是什么好事。
  2. Right now there is a zombie virus that is rapidly spreading throughout the country. It’s known that one out of five hundred people will catch the virus and become infected. All these people will turn into zombies within a month, which of course is not so great for them.
  3. 医生可以进行一项测试来检查自己是否携带病毒。但这项测试并不完全可靠。
  4. There is a test that one can take at the doctor’s office to check if one is carrying the virus. But the test isn’t totally reliable.
  5. 已经确定的是，对于任何感染病毒的人来说，测试的准确率是 100%。换句话说，任何感染病毒的人都会通过测试得知自己被感染了。
  6. It has been established that for anyone who has the virus, the test is 100 percent accurate. In other words, anyone who has the virus will learn from the test that they are infected.
  7. 还已确定，对于未携带病毒的人来说，该测试的准确率只有 95%。这意味着接受测试的所有健康人中有 5% 会出现假阳性，也就是说，他们会被告知自己被感染了，尽管他们并没有被感染。
  8. It has also been established that the test is only 95 percent accurate for those who are not carrying the virus. This implies that 5 percent of all healthy people who are tested will have a false positive, meaning that they will be told they are infected, even though they aren’t.

现在你不想变成丧尸，所以你很着急想知道自己是否被感染，于是你去看医生并做了检查。几天后，你收到了结果：检查结果显示你携带病毒！

Now you don’t want to become a zombie. Therefore, you are very anxious to find out if you’re infected or not, so you go to your doctor and get tested. After a few days, you receive the result: the test says that you are carrying the virus!

当然，你对这个结果很不满意。但你知道测试并不完全可靠，所以现在的问题是：你携带病毒的可能性有多大？请注意，我不是要得到确切的答案——只是一个粗略的估计。你被感染的几率是否更大少于或少于 50%？在查看答案之前，请先思考一下。5

Of course you’re very upset with this result. But you know that the test isn’t totally reliable, so now comes the question: How great are the chances that you really are carrying the virus? I’m not looking for an exact answer, mind you—just a rough estimate. Are your chances of being infected greater than or less than 50 percent? Think about this for a little while before you check out the answer.5

三门一车

Three Doors and One Car

我们也可能陷入与直觉激烈冲突的概率错觉。下面是一个典型的例子。你是电视智力竞赛节目的参赛者，一块大幕拉开，露出三扇紧闭的大门。主持人告诉你，其中一扇门后面有一辆全新的跑车。如果你打开那扇门，你就能得到这辆车！但另外两扇门后面是山羊，打开其中任何一扇门，你都会得到山羊。你很想赢得这辆车，但你对把一只山羊带回家并不那么兴奋。

We can also fall for probability illusions that clash violently with our intuitions. The following is a classic example. You’re a contestant on stage in a TV quiz show, and a big curtain is pulled back, revealing three large closed doors. The host tells you that behind one of the doors there is a brand-new sports car. If you open that door, you’ll get the car! But behind the other two doors are goats, and that’s what you’ll get if you open either of those ones. You’d love to win the car, but you’re not all that excited about taking a goat home.

主持人知道三扇门后面各是什么。当然，问题是你不知道。现在游戏规则很简单：

The host knows what’s behind each of the three doors. The problem, of course, is that you don’t know. Now the rules of the game are simple:

  1. 你首先要选一扇门，然后站在门旁边，但不能打开它。一旦你做出了选择，主持人就会走上前来打开另一扇门，而你会看到门后面有一只山羊。

    现在你站在两扇关着的门中的一扇门前，第三扇门是开着的，门后面站着一只山羊，十分显眼。主持人现在给你提供了一个新选项，你可以接受或拒绝：

  2. You are first to pick a door and then to go stand right next to it, but not to open it. As soon as you’ve made your choice, the host steps forward and opens a different door, and behind that door you see a goat.

    So now you are standing in front of one of just two closed doors, with the third door being open and a goat conspicuously standing behind it. The host now offers you a new option that you can take or reject:

  3. 您现在想换到另一扇关闭的门吗？还是只想继续留在您原来选择的那扇门？

  4. Would you now like to switch to the other closed door, or would you prefer to simply remain with your original choice of door?

您觉得如何？如果您进行更改，赢得汽车的机会会增加吗？还是会保持不变？在继续阅读之前，请先考虑一下。

What do you think? Will the chances of winning the car increase if you make the switch, or will they stay exactly the same? Think this over for a moment before reading any further.

大多数人说，在这个阶段，换不换门都无关紧要。一开始，当你选择一扇门时，你有三分之一的机会赢得汽车。现在你有了新的机会，从两扇门中挑选一扇。很明显，你现在站在“好”门前的几率为 50%，站在“坏”门前的几率为 50%。那么，此时换门到底有什么意义呢？一点意义都没有，对吧？

Most people say that it doesn’t matter one hoot whether you switch doors at this stage or not. When, at the outset, you chose a door, you had a one-in-three chance of winning the car. And now you have a new opportunity to choose one of just two doors. It would seem obvious that there is a 50 percent chance that you are right now standing at the “good” door, and a 50 percent chance that you are standing at the “bad” door. So what earthly purpose would it serve to switch doors at this point? None whatsoever, right?

但问题是，这种推理虽然看似完美，但却是完全错误的。事实上，你刚刚做出的改变奖金将使您赢得汽车的机会增加一倍：机会将从三分之一增加到三分之二！这种说法与我们的直觉相悖，但它是完全正确的。6

The problem, however, is that this reasoning, although seemingly perfect, is dead wrong. In truth, making the switch that you have just been offered would double your chances of winning the car: they would jump from one in three to two in three! This claim plays havoc with our intuition, and yet it is completely correct.6

让我们暂停一下，对正在讨论的内容进行一些分析。实际上，我们处于一个相当奇怪的认知领域，因为在我们看来，关于这个选门电视游戏，我们用铁一般的推理得出结论（即，我们换不换都无关紧要——我们赢得汽车的机会不会增加）。这不就是这本书的全部内容吗——使用推理，而不仅仅是依靠偏见、圣经或随机猜测来得出结论？但现在，不幸的是，我们被告知我们的推理不是推理，而是有缺陷的！我们被告知我们的推理过程误导了我们！那么，前面的讨论难道不是让我们怀疑我们的推理过程，而不是相信它们吗？那么，这种讨论难道不是在破坏这本书的关键论点——即我们应该始终使用推理来得出结论吗？

Let us pause for a moment to put some perspective on what is under discussion. We are actually in quite curious cognitive territory here because it seems to us that concerning this door-choosing TV game, we used ironclad reasoning to reach our conclusion (namely, that it doesn’t matter in the least if we switch or not—our chance of winning the car won’t be increased). Isn’t that what this book is all about—using reasoning, not just relying on prejudices or holy scriptures or random guesswork, to reach conclusions? But now, unfortunately, we’re being told that our reasoning wasn’t reasoning but, instead, was faulty! We are being told that our reasoning processes misled us! So doesn’t the preceding discussion lead us to doubt our reasoning processes, rather than to believe in them? And so, isn’t this discussion undermining the book’s key thesis—namely, that we should always use reasoning to reach conclusions?

好吧，不管我们喜欢与否，有时要找到真相是相当困难的，推理本身当然不是机械的或琐碎的。我对三扇门游戏的讨论试图表明，就像存在知觉错觉一样，也存在推理错觉。我们人类不仅容易受到视觉欺骗，而且容易受到逻辑欺骗——容易被听起来很顺耳的话语和看似完美的论点所蒙骗，从而误入歧途。

Well, whether we like it or not, reaching the truth is sometimes quite tricky, and reasoning itself is certainly not mechanical or trivial. What my discussion of the three-doors game is trying to bring out is that, just as there exist perceptual illusions, there also exist reasoning illusions. We humans are susceptible not only to being optically tricked, but also to being logically tricked—to being led down the garden path by falling for smooth-sounding words and flawless-seeming arguments.

美国逻辑学家雷蒙德·斯莫里安写了一本很棒的书，名为《福尔摩斯的国际象棋之谜》。7许多“国际象棋之谜”都与福尔摩斯和他忠实的朋友华生医生在他们经常光顾的伦敦国际象棋俱乐部中偶然发现的棋盘有关，而其他一些则在贵族庄园或甚至是在驶往异国他乡的轮船上遇到。所问的问题如下：“谁最后动了——白棋还是黑棋？”或“最后移动了哪个棋子？”或者是“最后拿走了哪个棋子？”这类谜题被称为逆向国际象棋分析谜题，这意味着在这类谜题中，他们需要查看国际象棋局势的快照，并逆向推理这种局势可能从何而来。

There is a wonderful book by American logician Raymond Smullyan, titled The Chess Mysteries of Sherlock Holmes.7 Many of the “chess mysteries” involve chessboards that Sherlock Holmes and his faithful friend Dr. Watson randomly stumble across in a London chess club that they frequent, while others are encountered in aristocratic country estates or even aboard steamships sailing to exotic destinations. The questions asked are of this sort: “Who moved last—White or Black?” Or “What piece was moved last?” Or perhaps “What piece was taken last?” Such puzzles are called retrograde chess-analysis puzzles, meaning that they involve looking at a snapshot of a chess situation and reasoning backward to where this situation could have come from.

图 5.3是华生医生讲述的一个示例问题。

Figure 5.3 is a sample problem, as narrated by Dr. Watson.

福尔摩斯第一个开口。“我解决的第一个逆行问题是‘不能王牌’。”

Holmes was the first to speak. “The first retrograde problem I ever solved was a ‘can’t castle.’”

图 5.3. 逆行棋题

Figure 5.3. A Retrograde Chess Problem

“你还记得那是什么吗？”雷金纳德爵士感兴趣地问道。

“哦，是的，”福尔摩斯回答，“只是我认为这太简单了，你不感兴趣——你知道，只不过是一件小事而已。”

“你为什么不给我们展示一下呢？了解你是如何开始解决这些问题的，并测试一下你的初始技能，也许会很有趣。”

“很好。”福尔摩斯摆出了如下姿势。

“这是黑方的一步，”福尔摩斯说。“黑方能王车易位吗？”

由于福尔摩斯将这个问题描述为“简单”，我认为我可能有机会解决它，因此尽了最大的努力。而且，我不得不自豪地说我是第一个解决它的人。我在阐述中犯了几个错误，但这些错误更多的是疏漏而不是推理错误，因此并不严重。以下是我给出的分析（所有空白都已填补）。

白棋的最后一步显然是走兵。黑棋的最后一步一定是吃掉在那之前走的白棋。这颗棋子一定是骑士，因为车不可能走到棋盘上没有任何黑棋兵能吃掉骑士，而黑后车也无法吃掉骑士，因为骑士无法从任何格子移动到那个位置。同样，主教也无法吃掉它，因为骑士唯一可能来自的格子是 d6，而它本来会在那里将王将死。因此，王或王的车已经吃掉了骑士。所以，黑棋不能王车易位。8

“Do you remember what it was?” inquired Sir Reginald with interest.

“Oh yes,” replied Holmes, “only I think it is too simple to interest you—a mere bagatelle, you know.”

“Why don’t you show it to us anyhow? It might be amusing to learn what got you started on these problems, and to test ourselves against your beginning skill.”

“Very well.” Holmes set up the following position.

“It is Black’s move,” said Holmes. “Can Black castle?”

Since Holmes had described this problem as “simple,” I thought I might have a chance of solving it, and so exerted myself to the utmost to do so. And, I cannot help but be proud to say I was the first to get it. I made a couple of mistakes in exposition, but the mistakes were more in the nature of omissions than of faulty reasoning, hence were not serious. Here is the analysis I gave (with all the gaps filled).

White’s last move was clearly with the pawn. Black’s last move must have been to capture the White piece which moved before that. This piece would have to have been a knight, since the rooks could not have got out onto the board. Obviously none of the Black pawns captured the knight, and the Black queen’s rook couldn’t have captured the knight because there is no square that the knight could have moved from to get to that position. Likewise the bishop couldn’t have captured it, since the only square the knight could have come from is d6, where it would have been checking the king. Hence either the king or the king’s rook has made the capture. So, Black can’t castle.8

这个谜题看起来可能很难，任何人都无法解开，但它却是本书所有谜题中最简单的一个。这个令人震惊的认识可能会让《福尔摩斯的国际象棋之谜》的读者感到畏惧，甚至可能变得智力低下。更糟糕的是，斯穆里安在许多问题中对读者施展了高超的花招。通常的情况是：华生分析给定的情况，并非常明智地谈论它。当我们阅读华生的分析并考虑他的推理时，我们发现其中没有任何缺陷。我们确信他已经揭示了谜题的真正答案。而且在一些谜题中（例如前面描述的谜题），华生确实是正确的，仅此而已。但有时，令我们惊讶的是，夏洛克·福尔摩斯（正如作者斯穆里安所传达的那样）非常温和地指出了华生刚刚所说的话中的一个微妙的缺陷。

This puzzle may seem hard enough to break anyone’s brains, and yet it is among the easiest of all the problems in the book. This shocking realization may make readers of The Chess Mysteries of Sherlock Holmes feel daunted, possibly even feeble minded. And to add insult to injury, Smullyan plays masterful tricks on his readers in many problems. What typically happens is this: Watson examines the given situation and speaks very sensibly about it. As we read Watson’s analysis and consider his reasoning, we find no flaw whatsoever in it. We are convinced that he has revealed the true answer to the puzzle. And in some of the puzzles (such as the one described earlier), Watson is indeed correct, and that’s all there is to it. But on occasion, to our surprise, Sherlock Holmes (as channeled by author Smullyan) very gently points out a subtle flaw in what Watson has just said.

事实证明，沃森忽略了一个不寻常的可能性，或者没有考虑到棋盘上的某个微妙事实，或者忘记了国际象棋的一些晦涩规则。突然间，一切都发生了变化！沃森突然意识到，我们读者也意识到，情况并不像他分析的那样，尽管他的推理完全令人信服。是的，沃森确实在运用推理；他肯定不是在胡乱猜测，也不是在遵循毫无根据的迷信或圣经。即便如此，沃森的推理虽然很诱人——甚至可能完全令人信服——但却是有缺陷的推理。

It turns out that Watson has overlooked one unusual possibility, or has not taken into account a certain subtle fact about the board, or has forgotten about some obscure rule of chess. All at once, everything swivels! Watson suddenly realizes, and we readers also realize, that the situation is not as he analyzed it after all, totally persuasive though his reasoning was. And yes, Watson was indeed using reasoning; he certainly wasn’t using just random guesswork or following baseless superstitions or holy scriptures. Even so, Watson’s reasoning, although tempting—and possibly even utterly convincing—was flawed reasoning.

让《福尔摩斯的国际象棋之谜》更具挑衅性的是，有时，华生会从这种认知冲击中好心地恢复过来，然后他会推理出一个完全不同的结论，一个更微妙的结论，考虑到福尔摩斯指出的棘手之处——然后福尔摩斯会接受华生的新结论并再次找出其中的漏洞！

What makes The Chess Mysteries of Sherlock Holmes even more provocative is that, on occasion, Watson will good-naturedly bounce back from such a cognitive shock, and then he will reason his way to a totally different conclusion, a subtler one that takes into account the tricky feature that Holmes pointed out—and then Holmes will take Watson’s new conclusion and once again poke holes in it!

事实证明，沃森又一次忽略了一些东西，但这次忽略的想法更加微妙。斯穆里安显然非常乐于欺骗读者，让他们不只一次，而是连续两三次忽略沃森推理中的致命漏洞！

It turns out that Watson has overlooked something yet again, but this time the overlooked idea is even subtler. Smullyan obviously takes enormous delight in tricking his readers, leading them to overlook fatal holes in Watson’s reasoning not just once, but two or three times in a row!

让我们来看看斯穆里安的福尔摩斯式的诡计。以下摘录自斯穆里安称之为“方向问题”的国际象棋谜题：

Let’s take a look at some Smullyanian Sherlockian shenanigans of this sort. The following extract is taken from the chess mystery that Smullyan calls “A Matter of Direction”:

我和福尔摩斯一起漫步来到俱乐部。俱乐部里空无一人，只有两个人：马斯顿上校，我们相当熟悉；还有一位举止优雅、聪明睿智的绅士，举止非常和蔼可亲、风趣幽默。

“福尔摩斯，”马斯顿从棋盘前站起身说道，“让我向你介绍我的一位好友，雷金纳德·欧文爵士。我们刚刚结束了一场非常奇妙、非常奇怪的比赛。双方的下法都极其疯狂，当然，这是完全合法的。”

“我明白了，”福尔摩斯看着棋盘说道。

Together, Holmes and I sauntered over to the club. It was empty except for two occupants: Colonel Marston, whom we knew fairly well, and a distinguished, intelligent-looking gentleman with a very pleasant and humorous manner.

“Why, Holmes,” said Marston, rising from his place at the chessboard, “let me introduce you to a very dear friend of mine, Sir Reginald Owen. We have just finished a most delightfully bizarre and eccentric game. The playing was utterly wild on both sides, though perfectly legal, of course.”

“So I see,” remarked Holmes, looking at the board.

图5.4显示了棋盘的位置。

Figure 5.4 shows the position of the chessboard.

福尔摩斯说：“马斯顿，为什么每次我看到你下棋，你好像总是在走白棋呢？”

马斯顿听后哈哈大笑，但突然脸色一沉。“福尔摩斯，”他说，“你怎么知道我下白棋了？我敢肯定，最后一步是在你或华生进屋前下出来的。你怎么可能知道？” 9

“Why is it, Marston,” said Holmes, “that every time I see you at chess, you always seem to be playing White?”

Marston laughed at this, but suddenly his face dropped. “Why, Holmes,” he said, “how on earth did you know I was playing White? I’m sure the last move was made some time before you or Watson entered the room. So how could you possibly know?”9

图 5.4. 棋盘的位置

Figure 5.4. Position of the Chessboard

故事到这里，虽然答案还没有揭晓，但仍然充满了有趣的妙语连珠。因此，我们直接跳到晚上，福尔摩斯和华生回到了福尔摩斯位于贝克街 221b 号的住所。穿上他最喜欢的睡袍，点燃他最爱的烟斗后，福尔摩斯转向华生，问了这个问题：

At this point, the story continues with amusing repartee, although the answer is not revealed. We’ll thus skip ahead to the evening, when Holmes and Watson have returned to Holmes’s domicile at 221b Baker Street. After donning his favorite dressing gown and stoking his well-loved pipe, Holmes turns to Watson and asks this question:

“你弄清楚我怎么知道马斯顿执白棋了吗？”

“为什么没有，”我回答道。“我用尽了你教我的所有方法，彻底检查了整个房间，却没有发现任何线索！”

福尔摩斯听了大笑起来。“整个房间，华生，整个房间！你还检查了大楼的其余部分吗？”

“我从来没想过这个，”我羞怯地承认。

“我亲爱的华生，”福尔摩斯笑得更厉害了，“你知道，我只是开玩笑。没必要检查整座大楼，甚至没必要检查整个房间，也没必要检查桌子，也没必要检查棋手，只要检查棋盘就行了。”

“棋盘？棋盘有什么奇怪？”

“为什么，华生，这个位置，这个位置。你不记得这个位置有什么特别之处吗？”

“是的，我确实记得，当时我认为这个位置极不寻常，但我不明白如何能从中推断出马斯顿执白棋！”

这时，夏洛克站了起来。“我们重新布置一下阵地……”

福尔摩斯回忆了下午的情形后说道：“现在，难道你不能推断出哪边是白方，哪边是黑方吗？”

我仔细地看了很久，却没有发现任何线索。“这就是你所说的‘逆向分析’的例子吗？”我问。

“这是一个很好的例子，”福尔摩斯回答道，“尽管它太简单了。但是现在你看不出任何线索了？”

“一点也没有，”我难过地说。“从表面上看，白棋似乎在南边。但这真的很肤浅。游戏显然处于残局阶段，其中一个王被赶到棋盘的另一端并不罕见。所以看起来白棋真的可以在任何一边。”

福尔摩斯绝望地问道： “华生，这件事没有什么引起你的注意吗？”

我又看了看棋盘。“嗯，福尔摩斯，我想有一个特点可能会引起任何人的注意，那就是黑王现在被白象将军了。但我看不出这与哪一方是白方有什么关系。”

福尔摩斯得意地笑了。“华生，你真是太有风度了。这就是逆向分析的用武之地！逆向分析必须深入过去。是的，过去，华生！既然黑方现在被将军，白方的最后一步会是什么？”

亲爱的读者，我认为这对您来说是一个绝佳的机会，您可以仔细查看这块板子，看看您能想到什么。也许它会与沃森注意到的一致，也许不一致。无论如何，请尝试一下，然后继续阅读。

我再次看了看棋盘，回答道：“为什么？这很可能是白棋 e5 上的棋子刚从 e4 上移开，就发现了主教的将军。当然，这是假设白棋在南。但另一方面，也可能是白棋在北，在这种情况下，他的最后一步是从 d5 上移开 d4 上的棋子。我认为没有理由在这两种可能性之间做出决定。”

“非常好，华生，但是如果真的像你所说的那样，白棋的最后一步棋是用 e5 或 d4 上的一个棋子进行的，那么黑棋在此之前立即采取的行动可能是什么？”

我又看了一遍，回答道：“显然是黑王，因为黑王是棋盘上唯一的黑棋。他不可能从 b8 或 b7 移动，因此他一定是从 a7 移动出了将军位置。”

“不可能！”福尔摩斯大喊。“如果他在 a7 上，他就会同时被白方后和 c5 上的另一个白方主教将军。如果后最后移动进行将军，黑方就会被主教将军。如果主教最后移动，黑方就会被后将军。这种不可能的将军在逆向分析中被称为‘假想将军’。”

我想了一会儿，意识到福尔摩斯说得对。“那么，”我惊呼道，“这个位置简直不可能！”

“一点也不，”福尔摩斯笑道。“你只是没有考虑到所有的可能性。”

“现在看看，福尔摩斯，你自己已经证明了黑方不可能有最后一步棋了！”

“我并没有证明这一点，华生。”

这时我有点不耐烦了。“哦，福尔摩斯，你刚才向我证明了黑王不可能有最后一步。”

“确实如此，华生，我证明了黑王没有最后一步可能，但这并不能证明黑王没有最后一步可能。”

“但是，”我大叫道，“国王是棋盘上唯一的黑棋！”

“现在棋盘上唯一的黑棋，”福尔摩斯纠正道，“但这并不意味着在白棋最后一步走棋之前，国王是棋盘上唯一的黑棋！”

“当然，”我回答道，“我真是太蠢了！白棋在最后一步可以吃掉黑棋。但是，”我比以往更加困惑地喊道，“最后走的 e5 或 d4 上的棋子都没有吃掉！”

“这只能证明，”福尔摩斯大笑道，“你原本的猜测，即白棋的最后一步是用这两个棋子中的一个下棋，是完全错误的。”

“不正确！”我困惑地大叫道。“怎么会这样？”

亲爱的读者，在我们继续探讨这个象棋谜题之前，我建议你先休息一下，并尽最大努力弄清楚福尔摩斯这句话的意思。华生看似无懈可击的分析怎么可能是错的呢？

好吧，既然你大概已经考虑过了，那就让我们继续……

然后我恍然大悟！“当然！”我得意地大叫。“现在我明白了！我之前怎么没看出来真是太傻了！白棋的最后一步是用 g2 的兵吃掉了 h3 上的黑棋。这一吃子同时将黑王牵制住了，也吃掉了黑棋，而正是这颗棋子——不管它是什么——导致了黑棋的下一步行动！”

“华生，你做的不错，不过恐怕不行！如果白棋的棋子刚刚在 g2 上，那么 h1 上的象又怎么可能到达那个方格呢？”

这又是一个难题！这时我说：“福尔摩斯，说真的，我现在完全相信这个情况根本就不可能！”

“真的吗？好吧，好吧！这只是我经常说的另一个例子：信念，无论多么坚定，并不总能保证真理。”

“但是我们已经用尽了所有的可能性！”我大声说道。

“除了一个，华生——碰巧的是，那个是正确的。”

“在我看来，我们确实已经涵盖了所有可能性。我确信我们已经证明这个立场是不可能的！”

福尔摩斯的表情变得严肃起来。“逻辑，”他回答道，“是最微妙、最脆弱的东西。如果使用得当，逻辑的力量是无比强大的，但稍稍偏离严格的推理就会导致最灾难性的后果。你说你可以‘证明’这个论点是不可能的。我希望你能试着给我一个完全严格的证明。我想，这样做，你可能会发现自己的谬误。”

“那好，”我同意了，“让我们逐一回顾一下这些可能性。我们——或者说你——确实证明了 d4 和 e5 上的棋子都不可能最后移动。对吗？”

福尔摩斯说：“当然。”

“H3 上的兵也是一样吗？”

福尔摩斯说：“对。”

“H1 上的主教肯定没有最后移动！”

福尔摩斯说：“又正确了。”

“而且，c5 上的另一个主教和白棋后肯定不可能最后动。而且，白棋王肯定也不是最后动的！”

福尔摩斯说道：“到目前为止我完全同意你的观点。”

“那么，”我说，“证明完毕！白棋不可能走到最后！”

“错了！”福尔摩斯得意地大叫道。“这完全是无稽之谈。 ”

“等一下，”我有些失控地喊道。“我已经把棋盘上的每一个白棋都算在内了！”

“是的，”福尔摩斯对我的惊愕感到很有趣，“但棋盘上的棋子不行。”

这时，我开始怀疑自己的理智了。“福尔摩斯，真的吗？”我绝望地大喊，“白棋最后动了，他刚刚动的棋子必须在棋盘上，因为黑棋还没有移动来吃掉它。你知道，棋子不会自己离开棋盘的！”

“错了，”福尔摩斯说，“这就是你的全部谬误！”

这时，我眨眨眼睛，摇了摇头，说服自己我真的醒了，尽量克制自己，平静而缓慢地说道：“福尔摩斯，你是说，下棋时，棋子可以不被吃掉就离开棋盘吗？”

“是的，”福尔摩斯回答。“只有一种棋子能做到这一点。”

“一个兵！”我长舒一口气说道。“当然，一个兵到了第八格后就会推进。但是，”我继续说道，“我看不出这对我们目前的情况有什么帮助，因为白棋皇后现在不在第八格——不管白棋朝哪个方向走。”

福尔摩斯回答道：“国际象棋中是否有规则要求棋子升级后必须升级为皇后？”

“不，”我回答道。“它可以升级为后、车、象或马。但这对我们有什么帮助？……你好，”我说，“当然！它可能已经升级为 h1 上的象——这当然意味着白方在北。但这怎么会给黑方留下最后一步呢？啊，我明白了！升级的白方棋子在 g2 上，并吃掉了h1 上的黑棋；这枚黑棋在那之前就走了一步！所以确实，白方一定是北方！”

福尔摩斯平静地微笑着说道：“很好，华生。”

“不过，有一件事让我很困惑，福尔摩斯：既然白棋可以再有一位后，为什么还要将他晋升为象呢？”

“华生，”福尔摩斯非常小心地回答，“这个问题属于心理学和概率，当然不是逆向分析，逆向分析不涉及概率，只涉及绝对确定性。我们从不假设一个玩家玩得很好，而只假设他玩得合法。因此，无论采取某一特定行动的可能性有多小，如果没有其他行动可能，那么这一定是实际采取的行动。正如我多次告诉你的那样，当排除了不可能的因素后，剩下的，无论多么不可能，都一定是事实。” 10

“Have you yet figured out how I knew Marston was playing White?”
