Such a person simply holds no belief in either direction about the matter. This is an agnostic stance. By contrast, someone who asserts “I believe God doesn’t exist” is revealing an opinion on the matter. This is an atheistic stance.

事实证明，许多自称不可知论者的人实际上是无神论者。他们的基本态度是，尽管他们认为不可能上帝存在，他们仍然对这种可能性持开放态度。但这实际上与无神论立场相吻合。毕竟，没有人能够绝对肯定地知道不存在任何可以想象的神。但只要一个人相信不存在这样的神，那么他就是一个无神论者。

It turns out that many people who call themselves agnostics are actually atheists. Their basic attitude is that, although they find it improbable that God exists, they are still open to the possibility. But this, in truth, coincides with the atheistic stance. After all, no one can know with absolute certainty that no imaginable type of god exists. But as long as one believes that no such thing exists, then one is an atheist.

人们普遍认为不可知论是一种“软”中间立场，介于有神论和无神论之间；然而，不可知论根本不是一种立场。事实上，它是一种立场的缺失。尽管如此，许多人似乎更愿意称自己为不可知论者，而不是称自己为无神论者。这可能是由于“无神论”一词在宗教根深蒂固的文化中具有负面含义。因此，认为不可知论观点比无神论观点不那么“强硬”或不那么教条是一种误解。

It is quite common to think that agnosticism constitutes a kind of “soft” intermediate position, located somewhere between theism and atheism; however, agnosticism is not a position at all. In fact, it’s the absence of a position. Nonetheless, many people seem to feel more at ease calling themselves agnostics than calling themselves atheists. This is probably a consequence of the negative connotations that the word “atheism” has taken on in cultures that are deeply steeped in religion. For this reason, it is a misconception to think that an agnostic outlook is somehow less “hard” or less dogmatic than an atheistic one.

当谈到其他类型的超自然生物（如精灵或独角兽）时，人们很少采取不可知论的立场；事实上，大多数人对这些生物以及托尔、奥丁和宙斯等古代神灵持怀疑态度。因此，大多数人对这些神灵持无神论态度，而不是不可知论态度。

It’s rare for people to take an agnostic stance when it comes to other types of supernatural beings, such as elves or unicorns; in fact, most people are very secure in their skepticism about such beings, and about old-time gods as Thor, Odin, and Zeus. Most people are thus atheistic about such gods rather than agnostic about them.

显然，如果一个人有科学观点，那么他应该随时准备改变自己的想法，只要有新的事实表明某种奇怪的实体存在。这不仅适用于原子、光子、夸克等，也适用于精灵、独角兽、鬼魂、巨魔、尼斯湖水怪等。但拥有这种科学的开放态度并不构成任何理由宣称自己对精灵、巨魔和其他童话般的生物的存在持不可知论（即无意见）。在这种情况下，无神论似乎是更合理的立场。至少奥卡姆剃刀原则会建议这一点，因为它是最简单的合理立场。

Clearly, if one has a scientific outlook, one should be prepared to change one’s mind whenever new facts come to light that suggest that strange entities of some sort exist. This holds not just for atoms, photons, quarks, and so forth but also for elves, unicorns, ghosts, trolls, the Loch Ness monster, and so on. But having such scientific open-mindedness does not constitute any reason to declare oneself agnostic (i.e., opinionless) about the existence of elves, trolls, and other fairy tale sorts of beings. In such cases, atheism seems like the more reasonable stance. At least Ockham’s razor would suggest this, since it’s the simplest reasonable position.

有时人们声称上帝存在超出了科学的范围，无法通过经验检验。如果事实上上帝的存在不是科学或实验可检验的说法，那么我们都应该避免就此事得出任何结论。毫无疑问，人们可以构想出符合这一观点的上帝观。例如，自然神论认为上帝首先创造了大爆炸，然后完全退出了世界，这显然是无法检验的。

Sometimes it is claimed that God exists beyond the range of science, not subject to empirical testability. If in fact God’s existence is not a scientific or experimentally testable claim, then we should all abstain from drawing any conclusions about the matter. Well, there’s no doubt that one can formulate visions of God that fit in with this vision. For example, a deistic theory positing that God first created the Big Bang and then withdrew totally from the world is clearly beyond testability.

然而，在这种情况下，上帝是否存在的问题就变得毫无意义了。如果上帝在我们的宇宙中根本不扮演任何角色，那么我们为什么要担心上帝是否存在呢？然而，当今世界各地的一神教并不以这种方式看待他们的各种神灵。对于他们每个人来说，上帝就像一个人——一个可以干预世界的人。上帝聆听祈祷。上帝创造奇迹。如果一个人有这样一种想象，即一个个人的、聆听祈祷、创造奇迹、干预生活的上帝，那么上帝存在的问题就会立即成为一个可以用经验检验的、因而也是科学的问题。

In that case, however, the question of God’s existence becomes uninteresting. If God plays absolutely no role in our universe, then why should we worry our heads about whether God exists? Today’s monotheistic religions throughout the world, however, do not see their diverse gods in this manner. For each of them, God is like a person—someone who can intervene in the world. God listens to prayers. God performs miracles. And if one has this vision of a personal, prayer-listening, miracle-performing, life-intervening God, then the matter of God’s existence immediately becomes an empirically testable, and thus scientific, question.

不难想象，有些实验的结果要么支持上帝存在的假设，要么推翻这一假设。例如，科学地研究祈祷与实际结果之间的统计相关性。这种实验已经进行过，但从未发现过这种相关性。当然，这种缺乏相关性并不能构成确凿的证据，证明上帝是人类欲望虚构出来的，与现实无关，但它增加了这种观点的可信度。

It’s not too hard to imagine experiments whose results would help either to support or to undermine the hypothesis that there exists a God. Consider, for example, scientifically investigating the statistical correlation between prayers and actual outcomes. Experiments of this sort have been carried out, but no such correlation has ever been detected. Of course, this lack of correlation does not constitute a watertight proof that God is a fiction dreamed up by human desires and is unrelated to reality, but it adds credibility to such a viewpoint.

无神论者到底相信什么？

What Does an Atheist Actually Believe?

让我们仔细看看无神论的真正含义。很多人有这样的印象：无神论者声称自己比别人理解得更深刻，知识比别人更多。当然，有些无神论者可能确实如此；毕竟，傲慢在社会各个领域都存在。但无神论本身并没有什么比有神论（相信上帝存在的信仰）更傲慢的地方。

Let’s take a closer look at what being an atheist really means. Many people have the impression that atheists claim to understand more deeply than others, and to have more knowledge than others. To be sure, this may be true of some atheists; after all, arrogance arises in all sectors of society. But there is nothing inherent in atheism that makes it more arrogant than theism (the belief that God exists).

关于无神论的另一个常见误解是，它僵硬而明确地声称已经证明上帝不存在。好吧，上帝不存在从严格意义上来说是无法证明的。但任何实体的不存在，如独角兽或超光速粒子，也是无法证明的，原因相同。

Another common misunderstanding about atheism is that it rigidly and categorically claims to have proven that God doesn’t exist. Well, God’s nonexistence is in a strict sense unprovable. But the nonexistence of any entity, such as unicorns or faster-than-light particles, is also unprovable, and for the same reasons.

如果我们举一个具体的例子（我们将借用伯特兰·罗素的一个生动例子），那么理解无神论的观点将更加容易。如果有人声称有一个茶壶在绕月球运行，那么对这一说法持高度怀疑态度似乎是合理的。此外，对这种说法采取不可知论的立场似乎是不合理的。你会说：“嗯……也许有一个茶壶在绕月球运行，也许没有——我怎么可能知道？”这种含糊不清的说法听起来相当愚蠢。

It will be easier to understand the atheistic standpoint if we take a concrete example (and we’ll borrow a vivid one from Bertrand Russell). If someone asserts that there is a teapot orbiting the moon, it would seem reasonable to be highly skeptical of the claim. Furthermore, it would seem unreasonable to adopt an agnostic stance toward such a claim. Would you be likely to say, “Hmm . . . maybe there is a teapot orbiting the moon, and maybe not—how could I possibly know?” Such wishy-washiness would sound rather silly.

理智的人（比如你和我）倾向于对这种茶壶的存在持“无神论”态度。我们积极地相信没有一个茶壶绕着月球运行，即使我们无法证明这一点。不管是好是坏，我们不可能飞到太空去搜寻真空无法探测绕月球运行的茶壶——即使我们能探测到，如果茶壶在月球上，我们也可能很容易错过它。然而，尽管我们做不到这一点，我们仍然相信——事实上，我们坚信——月球上根本没有这样的茶壶！毕竟，它怎么会到那里去呢？它到底为什么会在那里？有没有宇航员把茶壶带到月球上去呢？即使是这样，茶壶又是如何从月球表面进入绕月球运行的轨道的呢？

Sane people (such as you and me) are inclined to take an “atheistic” attitude about the existence of such a teapot. We actively believe that there is not a teapot orbiting the moon, even if we cannot prove this to be the case. For better or for worse, we can’t fly off into space and go scouring the vacuum for moon-orbiting teapots—and even if we could, we might easily miss the teapot, if it’s up there. And yet, although we can’t do this, we still believe—indeed, we strongly believe—that no such teapot is up there at all! After all, how would it have gotten up there? Why on earth would it be there? Might some astronaut have carried a teapot all the way to the moon? Even if so, how would the teapot then have gotten from the moon’s surface into an orbit around the moon?

声称有一个茶壶绕着月球旋转，根本就没有可信的依据。但现在，将这个说法与声称我的厨房柜台上有一个茶壶进行比较。我相信后一个说法，部分原因是我在那里看到过一个。这给了我一个强有力的理由相信那个地方有一个茶壶。但没有类似的事实支持声称有一个茶壶绕着月球旋转。因此，我得出结论，这是一个非常不可能的可能性。举证责任始终在于声称某物确实存在的人。

The claim that there’s a teapot orbiting the moon simply has no plausible underpinning. But compare this now with the assertion that there’s a teapot on my kitchen counter. I believe the latter claim in part because I see one there. This gives me a strong reason for believing that there is a teapot in that location. But no analogous fact lends support to the claim that there’s a teapot orbiting the moon. I thus draw the conclusion that this is a very unlikely possibility. The burden of proof always lies with the person who asserts that something actually exists.

无神论者相信上帝不存在，就如同普通人相信月球上没有茶壶一样。无神论者无法证明这种信念的真实性，但认为坚持这种信念是合理的，除非有人提出相反的有力证据。明智的无神论者并不固执己见；如果有新证据支持上帝存在，他们愿意重新考虑问题。

An atheist believes there is no God in much the same way as a normal person believes there is no teapot orbiting the moon. The atheist cannot prove the truth of this belief but feels justified in sticking to it until someone presents good evidence to the contrary. Sensible atheists are not dogmatic; they are ready to reconsider matters if new evidence turns up favoring the existence of God.

在我看来，对上帝存在持不可知论的观点——即不愿意猜测上帝是否存在，哪怕是尝试性地猜测——在当今时代是一种优柔寡断的立场。毕竟，我们对宇宙中各种现象的真实性或非真实性都有自己的看法：

To my mind, having an agnostic viewpoint about God’s existence—that is, being unwilling to speculate, even tentatively, about whether God might exist or not—is a wishy-washy position to adopt in this day and age. After all, we all have opinions about the reality or irreality of all sorts of phenomena in our universe:

  1. 我们都相信地球是圆的（尽管很少有人真正通过经验证实过）。
  2. We all believe that the earth is round (even though few of us have actually checked it out empirically).
  3. 我们都相信，月球周围不存在茶壶。
  4. We all believe that there is no teapot orbiting the moon.
  5. 我们都相信，只要我们抛出一块石头，它就会掉到地上，尽管我们无法证明下次抛出时一定会发生这种情况。
  6. We all believe that a stone will fall to the ground whenever we release it, even though we cannot prove this will happen the next time we try it out.

鉴于这些信念对于几乎所有有思想的人来说都是毫无疑问的，而我们无法从绝对意义上证明这些信念，那么我们为什么要像不可知论者敦促我们的那样，对上帝存在的问题如此胆怯呢？经过深思熟虑，不可知论者的立场似乎更像是一种在让自己相信任何事情之前非理性地坚持绝对、完全的确定性。

Given that such beliefs, none of which we can prove in an absolute sense, seem to lie beyond reasonable doubt for virtually all thinking humans, then why should we be so timid—as agnostics would urge us to be—about the question of God’s existence? Upon consideration, the agnostic stance seems more like an irrational insistence on absolute, total certainty before letting oneself believe anything.

另一方面，无神论的立场并不十分激进。例如，无神论者完全同意传统宗教信徒的观点，即各个民族历来所信仰的绝大多数神灵并不存在。世界各大宗教都基于多种不同类型的神灵。据说印度教有数百甚至数百万个神灵，所有这些神灵都是一个神的化身或化身。（在印度教中，化身是毗湿奴等神灵在人间以人或动物的形式出现。这个词在电脑游戏世界中获得了第二层含义——即玩网络游戏时所扮演的角色。）大多数基督徒坚决拒绝所有历史上声称存在的神灵，除了一个——即基督教神灵。无神论的立场与基督教的立场非常相似；它只是在你否认其存在的神灵名单上再添加一个神灵。

On the other hand, the atheistic stance is not a very radical one. For instance, atheists agree completely with believers in standard religions that the vast majority of gods that various peoples have believed in, down through the ages, do not exist. The world’s major religions are based on many different sorts of divine beings. Hinduism is said to have hundreds of gods, if not millions, all of them being incarnations or avatars of one single God. (In Hinduism, an avatar is the appearance on earth of a god such as Vishnu, in the form of a person or an animal. The word has acquired a second meaning in the world of computer games—namely, the character one adopts when playing an online game.) Most Christians firmly reject all the gods that historically have been claimed to exist, except for one—namely, the Christian one. Well, an atheistic stance is very similar to the Christian stance; it simply involves adding one more god to the list of gods whose existence you deny.

为什么这么多语言都给否认上帝存在的人贴上特定的标签？这样的词有必要吗？自然主义的宇宙观自然会导致无神论立场，但也会导致拒绝许多其他超自然的存在。在自然主义的世界里，不存在任何超自然的存在——那么为什么我们没有专门的词来形容那些拒绝其他类型存在的人呢？

Why do so many languages have a specific label for people who deny God’s existence? Is such a word necessary? A naturalistic outlook on the universe leads naturally to an atheistic stance, but it also leads to the rejection of many other supernatural beings. In a naturalistic world, no kind of supernatural being exists—so why don’t we have special words for people who reject other kinds of beings?

希腊神话中提到过塞壬——一种鸟形女性生物，用迷人的歌声迷惑水手，引诱他们前往她们的岛屿安瑟莫萨。数千年来，人们口口相传或以书面形式讲述塞壬的故事。尽管有这么多故事，但我们大多数人根本不相信塞壬的存在；我们认为它们纯粹是虚构的神话生物。然而，我们这些对塞壬持怀疑态度的人并没有被贴上特殊的标签，比如“无神论者”，其词源与“无神论者”一词相似。

Greek mythology spoke of sirens—birdlike feminine beings that bewitched sailors with their enchanting songs, luring them to their island, Anthemoessa. For thousands of years, people have told tales of sirens, both orally and in writing. Despite all these tales, most of us have no belief whatsoever in the existence of sirens; we think of them as purely imaginary mythical creatures. Yet there is no special label attached to us siren-doubting folks, such as “asirenist,” parallel in its etymology to the word “atheist.”

之所以没有“无神论者”这个词，而“无神论者”这个词却存在，是因为自古以来，人类社会和文化就与对某种神或众神的信仰紧密相连。如今对上帝的信仰已有数千年的先例。换句话说，从历史上看，相信上帝是正常的——这是人类的“默认”立场。从历史上看，不相信上帝是例外。此外，几个世纪以来，成为无神论者一直非常危险，即使在今天，在世界许多地方，成为无神论者也是极其危险的。塞壬生活（或曾经生活）在希腊海岸附近的想法并不是今天任何人的默认信仰，无论是瑞典人、希腊人还是美国人。为此原因在于，任何语言都不需要用一个特殊的词来表示那些坚信警报器不存在的人。

The reason no such word exists, while the word “atheist” does exist, is that since time immemorial, human societies and cultures have been deeply intertwined with belief in some sort of god or gods. A belief in God today has precedents going back thousands of years. To believe in God, in other words, is historically normal—it is the “default” stance of humanity. It is disbelief in God that is historically exceptional. Moreover, down through the centuries it has been very dangerous to be an atheist, and even today being an atheist is extremely dangerous in many parts of the world. The idea that sirens live (or used to live) off the coast of Greece is not the default belief of anyone today, whether they are Swedish, Greek, or American. For this reason, there is no need in any language for a special word denoting those who are committed to the idea that sirens don’t exist.

对无神论的十三个偏见

Thirteen Prejudices about Atheism

关于无神论，存在许多偏见和误解，在本节中，我们将讨论其中的很多（13 个，非常不错！）。我已经提到了一些，但现在让我们更系统地探讨这个话题。虽然以下一些偏见有些重叠，但我认为每一种都值得单独评论。

There are many prejudices and misimpressions about atheism, and in this section we’ll take a look at a good number (13 is a very good number!) of them. I’ve already touched on some, but now let’s go into the topic more systematically. Although some of the following prejudices overlap a bit, I feel that each one deserves its own separate comments.

1. 无神论者是一类特殊的人

1. Atheists Are a Special Brand of People

无神论者实际上并不是一群在某些方面都相似的特殊人。无神论者可以相信任何事物（除了上帝），并拥有任何可以想象的价值体系。想象所有无神论者都一样，就好比想象所有不打棒球的人都一样。不打棒球并不能说明一个人的内在本质。为了了解某个非棒球运动员，你必须与他/她进行一段时间的互动，逐渐了解他的喜好。

Atheists are not in fact a special brand of people who are all alike in some way. Atheists can believe in anything whatsoever (except for God) and have any imaginable value system. To imagine that all atheists are alike is similar to imagining that all people who don’t play baseball are alike. Not playing baseball is not a clue as to someone’s inner nature. In order to get to know a particular non-baseball player, you have to interact with that person over time and gradually come to understand their likes and dislikes.

所有非天主教徒是什么样的？所有非女权主义者是什么样的？所有非同性恋者是什么样的？他们的价值观是什么？这些问题听起来很荒谬。要了解任何非天主教徒、非女权主义者或非同性恋者是什么样的，你必须深入了解他们。无神论者也是如此。无神论者可以是世俗人文主义者，在这种情况下，我们至少可以猜测一点他们的价值观和态度。但无神论者也可能完全不同。

What are all non-Catholics like? What are all non-feminists like? What are all non-gay people like? What are their values? Such questions sound ridiculous. To know what any non-Catholic or non-feminist or non-gay person is like, you have to go deeper than the surface. The same holds for atheists. An atheist can be a secular humanist, in which case we can guess at least a little bit about their values and attitudes. But an atheist can also be completely different from that.

2. 无神论是一种人生哲学

2. Atheism is a Philosophy of Life

人们经常误以为无神论是一套完整的人生哲学。事实并非如此。无神论者只是对某一特定事实持有某种信念。一个人可以是无神论者，也可以相信占星术或顺势疗法、针灸或飞碟、鬼魂或独角兽。一切都是未知数。

A frequent misimpression about atheism is that it is a complete philosophy of life. This is not so. To be an atheist is simply to hold a certain belief about one particular factual matter. A person can be an atheist and also believe in astrology or homeopathy, in acupuncture or flying saucers, in ghosts or unicorns. All bets are off.

瑞典用于教授宗教的许多教科书将无神论与基督教、犹太教、伊斯兰教和印度教等世界主要宗教并列。这种分类虽然本意是好的，但却是基于误解。这就像有一本关于无神论的课程教科书运动类目中有关于篮球、网球、足球、高尔夫等运动的章节，还有一章是关于不从事任何球类运动的人的。如果这一章不描述这些人从事什么运动，那还有什么用呢？也许他们从事赛马、跳水比赛或射箭。这些活动可以而且应该作为单独的类别来处理。

A number of schoolbooks that are used in Sweden to teach about religion list atheism alongside the great world religions, such as Christianity, Judaism, Islam, and Hinduism. This classification, though well intended, is based on a misunderstanding. It is like having a textbook for a course on sports that has chapters about basketball, tennis, soccer, golf, and so on, and that then features a chapter about people who don’t engage in any sport that involves a ball. What purpose can such a chapter serve if it doesn’t describe what such people do engage in instead? Perhaps they engage in horse racing, or in diving competitions, or in archery. These activities can and should be handled as their own categories.

3. 无神论者憎恨上帝或对上帝感到愤怒

3. Atheists Hate God or Are Angry at God

悉尼圣公会大主教彼得·詹森（Peter Jensen）对无神论者发表了如下声明：

The Anglican archbishop in Sydney, Peter Jensen, made the following statement about atheists:

我们从无神论者的纯粹热情和恶毒中可以看出，他们似乎憎恨基督教的上帝……无神论和基督教一样，都是宗教信仰。它代表了人类对上帝的最新攻击，这种攻击源于人类对我们没有统治世界以及上帝要求我们将生命交给他的怨恨。4

As we can see by the sheer passion and virulence of atheists, they seem to hate the Christian God. . . . Atheism is every bit of a religious commitment as Christianity itself. It represents the latest version of the human assault on God, born out of resentment that we do not in fact rule the world and that God calls on us to submit our lives to Him.4

无神论者对上帝感到愤怒是一种普遍的偏见。但显而易见的是，人们不可能对自己认为不存在的人或事感到愤怒。

The notion that atheists are angry at God is a common prejudice. But it should be obvious that one cannot be angry at someone or something that one believes doesn’t exist.

另一方面，无神论者当然会对世界各地以上帝的名义进行的压迫和令人发指的行为感到极为不满。《旧约》中描述的上帝当然不是一个令人愉快的人物，但无神论与人与上帝的关系无关，因为对于无神论者来说，这种关系根本不存在。

On the other hand, atheists can certainly be extremely upset at the oppression and the heinous acts that take place throughout the world in the name of God. The god that is described in the Old Testament is certainly not a very pleasant figure, but atheism is not about one’s relationship to God, since for an atheist this relationship doesn’t exist at all.

4. 无神论者是极端分子、傲慢者、好战者、不宽容者……

4. Atheists Are Extremists, Are Arrogant, Are Militant, Are Intolerant . . .

无神论者并不意味着极端主义者或傲慢者。是的，有无神论者具有这些品质，但也有宗教人士具有这些品质。拥有任何这样的个人特质都不是无神论或有神论的结果。无神论者傲慢的观念可能源于宗教观念，即人们永远不应该敢于将自己与上帝相比。

Being atheistic does not imply being an extremist or an arrogant person. Yes, there are atheists who have these qualities, but so are there religious people who have these qualities. Having any such personal trait is not a consequence of theism or atheism. The notion that atheism is arrogant may spring from the religious notion that one should never dare to compare oneself to God.

某些无神论批评者提到“激进无神论者”。但“激进”一词通常适用于暴力或提倡暴力的人。人们可以在报纸上读到激进伊斯兰主义者发动恐怖袭击，或美国激进基督徒谋杀实施堕胎的医生的报道；然而，据我所知，“激进无神论者”唯一使用的武器是他们的笔和言论自由权。

Certain of atheism’s critics speak of “militant atheists.” But “militant” is a word that is usually applied to those who are violent or who advocate violence. One can read in newspapers about militant Islamists who carry out terrorist attacks, or militant Christians in the United States who murder doctors for carrying out abortions; however, as far as I am aware, the only weapons wielded by “militant atheists” are their pens and their right to free speech.

也许“好战”只是一种比喻，抱怨的只是无神论者为自己的立场激烈争论。但在这种情况下，我们也不得不抱怨各种类型的好战有神论者，包括原教旨主义基督徒、极端正统的犹太人等等。

Perhaps “militant” is meant only in a figurative manner, and the complaint is merely that atheists argue fervently for their stance. But in that case, we would also have to complain about militant theists of many stripes, including fundamentalist Christians, ultraorthodox Jews, and so forth.

称无神论者为“偏执者”要比称他们为“激进分子”稍微温和一些，但仍然是一个强烈的词。显然，在我们这个世界上，有很多事情是人们应该不能容忍的，比如对年轻女孩进行生殖器切割、砍断小偷的四肢、对家庭成员进行“荣誉谋杀”、强迫强奸受害者怀上强奸犯的孩子，以及用石头砸死通奸者，但大多数无神论者对这些事情的容忍程度可能并不比其他人高或低。如果无神论者对以宗教名义进行的这种残酷行为感到痛心，这可能更多是因为他们关心人权，而不是因为他们不相信上帝。

Calling atheists “intolerant” is a bit less harsh than calling them “militant,” but it’s still a strong term. It’s clear that in this world of ours there are plenty of things that one should be intolerant of, such as the genital mutilation of young girls, the chopping-off of thieves’ limbs, the “honor killing” of family members, the forcing of rape victims to bear the rapist’s child, and the stoning to death of adulterers, but probably most atheists are neither more nor less intolerant of these things than other people are. If atheists are distressed by such gruesome acts carried out in the name of religion, it probably comes more from their concern about human rights than from the fact that they don’t believe in God.

5. 无神论是一种比有神论更“坚定”的态度

5. Atheism Is a “Harder” Attitude Than Theism

无神论既不比有神论“更严格”也不比有神论“更宽松”，也不比有神论更僵化或更灵活。两者互为镜像。有神论者相信上帝存在；无神论者相信上帝不存在。两种立场都不可能比另一种更僵化或更灵活，因为它们是对称立场；然而，无神论本质上是一种谦逊的立场：它认为，既然没有令人信服的理由相信任何形式的上帝，就不应该得出上帝存在的结论。无神论者相信上帝不存在，除非有强有力的理由相信上帝不存在。

Atheism is neither “harder” nor “softer” than theism, nor is it more rigid or more flexible than theism. Each is the other’s mirror image. A theist believes that God exists; an atheist believes that God doesn’t exist. Neither stance can be more rigid or more flexible than the other, since they are symmetrical positions; however, atheism is by nature a humble stance: it’s the idea that since there is no convincing reason to believe in any sort of god, one should not draw the conclusion that God exists. An atheist believes that God doesn’t exist, until there is a powerful reason to believe otherwise.

6. 无神论只是另一种宗教

6. Atheism Is Just Another Religion

认为无神论是一种宗教是没有道理的。这种说法并不比说“不收集邮票是一种爱好”或“不打棒球是一种运动”更准确。这样做会将“爱好”或“运动”一词的含义远远超出其正常范围。同样，将无神论称为宗教也会将“宗教”的含义远远超出其正常范围。

It doesn’t make sense to suggest that atheism is a religion. Such a characterization is no more accurate than saying “not collecting stamps is a hobby” or “not playing baseball is a sport.” To do that would stretch the meaning of the word “hobby” or “sport” way beyond its normal bounds. Similarly, calling atheism a religion stretches the meaning of “religion” way beyond its normal bounds.

另一方面，如果我们从哲学意义上理解“宗教”一词（即人们相信但无法证明的东西），那么这句话在平凡的意义上是正确的。它的意思就是：“无神论是一些人坚信的观念。”嗯，显然无神论是一些人相信的观念，就像任何其他关于现实的说法一样。

If, on the other hand, we take the word “religion” in a philosophical sense (i.e., something that one believes in but cannot prove), then the sentence is true in a trivial sense. All it means is this: “Atheism is an idea that some people are convinced of.” Well, obviously atheism is an idea that some people believe in, just as is any other claim about reality.

关于世界的每一个信念都等同于一种信仰，但这个词的意义并不有趣。无神论表达了一种信仰，就像说“我认为明天太阳会升起”或“我相信尼斯湖水怪不存在”或“我预计下次选举将彻底改变国会的构成”表达了一种信仰一样。但这些信仰都与宗教无关。

Every belief about the world amounts to a faith, in an uninteresting sense of the word. Atheism expresses a faith, just as saying “I think the sun will rise tomorrow” or “I believe the Loch Ness monster doesn’t exist” or “I expect the next election will radically change the makeup of Congress” expresses a faith. But none of these faiths has anything to do with religion.

信仰陈述的合理性程度可能大不相同。一种信仰可能极其难以置信，而另一种信仰则基本上是不言而喻的。比较一下这两个陈述：“我相信这片树林里有巨魔”和“我怀疑这片树林里有巨魔”。两者都表达了对世界的可理解的看法，从这个意义上说，它们都表达了信仰，但它们的可信度程度却大不相同。所以如果有人告诉你，“是的，但你只是在表达一种信仰！”，不要被这个肤浅的标签所欺骗。

Statements of faith can have very different levels of reasonableness. One faith might be extremely implausible, while another is essentially self-evident. Compare these two statements: “I believe that there are trolls in these woods” and “I doubt that there are trolls in these woods.” Both express comprehensible visions of the world, and in that sense they both express faiths, but they are faiths of very different levels of plausibility. So if someone tells you, “Yes, but you’re just expressing a faith!,” don’t let yourself be fooled by this facile label.

7. 无神论者声称宗教是万恶之源

7. Atheists Claim That Religion Is the Root of All Evil

无神论者非常清楚，这个世界充满了各种与宗教无关的残酷和苦难。自然灾害——美国保险单中通常称之为“天灾”——即使不涉及任何人类残忍行为，也会给人们带来沉重打击。无神论者知道，人类残忍行为表现为多种形式，包括一些来自宗教的残忍行为和一些与宗教无关的残忍行为。毋庸置疑，宗教可以成为一些人生活中的积极力量。无神论者意识到，个人对上帝的信仰可以给人希望，可以给人安慰。毫无疑问，宗教有时会激励人们做好事，无神论者肯定会接受这一事实。

Atheists are perfectly aware that the world is full of all sorts of cruelty and suffering that have nothing to do with religion. Natural catastrophes—“acts of God,” as they are often called in insurance policies in the United States—can hit people very hard without any kind of human cruelty being involved. Atheists know that human cruelty manifests itself in many forms, including some varieties that come from religion and some that have nothing to do with religion. And it goes without saying that religion can be a positive force in some people’s lives. Atheists realize that a personal belief in God can give one hope and can offer consolation. There is no question that religions sometimes inspire people to do good things, and an atheist will certainly accept this fact.

我们还应该区分宗教作为个人生活哲学和宗教作为社会制度。对宗教作为制度的道德批评是，它们经常试图向外人灌输他们的信仰体系，然后让他们遵守其法律和仪式。这种行为可以受到合理的批评——无神论者和有神论者都一样。

One should also distinguish between a religion as a personal philosophy of life and a religion as a social institution. A moral criticism that can be leveled at religions as institutions is that they very often try to indoctrinate outsiders into their belief systems, and then to subject them to its laws and rites. This is a behavior that can legitimately be criticized—by atheists and theists alike.

8. 无神论者完全缺乏道德

8. Atheists Totally Lack Morality

有些人认为无神论者不可能有任何道德标准，也不相信人类的善良。在包括美国在内的许多国家，无神论者往往被视为缺乏道德原则的人。这就是为什么很少有美国人愿意接受无神论者担任总统候选人。

Some people believe that atheists cannot have any kind of moral standards and do not believe in the goodness of human beings. In many countries, including the United States, an atheist is often perceived as a person who lacks moral principles. This is why so few Americans are open to the idea of an atheistic candidate for president.

然而，认为所有无神论者都缺乏道德观念是完全错误的，原因很简单，道德与对任何神或其他超自然生物的信仰无关。一个人的道德可以而且应该完全根据他对待他人和动物的方式进行判断。如果你观察各种各样的人，你会发现无神论者就像宗教人士一样，行为既有道德的，也有不道德的。这两种类型的信徒在道德行为市场上都无法独占鳌头。

The idea that all atheists lack morality is way off target, however, for the simple reason that morality is not correlated with belief in any kind of god or other supernatural being. One’s morality can and should be judged solely by how one treats other people and animals. If you observe a wide spectrum of people, you will find that atheists, just like religious people, can behave morally or immorally. Neither type of believer has a corner on the market of moral behavior.

在宗教界，一种将无神论描绘成阴暗面的策略很常见，即断言，由于无神论者拒绝道德原则的神圣起源，他们完全愿意并愿意从事任何类型的行为。这种推理是错误的。显然，无神论者不认为道德原则来自上层，因为他们不相信有任何“上层”的存在可以让道德原则来自上层。但这并不意味着无神论者拒绝道德原则的概念，也不意味着他们认为任何任意的行为都是可以接受的。这个结论根本不符合前提。

One strategy for painting atheism in a somber light, common in religious circles, is to assert that, since atheists reject the divine origin of moral principles, they are totally open to, and willing to engage in, any type of behavior whatsoever. Such reasoning is fallacious. Obviously atheists do not think that moral principles come from on high, since they don’t believe that there is any being “on high” for them to have come from. But this doesn’t imply that atheists reject the notion of moral principles, or that they view any arbitrary kind of behavior as acceptable. The conclusion simply does not follow from the premises.

9. 无神论者只相信他们能看到和衡量的事物

9. Atheists Believe Only in What They Can See and Measure

有些人试图将无神论描绘成一种狭隘而迂腐的态度，认为除了那些可以在科学实验室中得到证实的思想之外，其他一切都会被否定。这是一种误解，至少可以这么说。和其他人一样，无神论者相信各种无法在实验室（或其他任何地方）测量或看到的东西。例如，许多无神论者深信人权、平等和爱。有些无神论者可能相信其他星球上存在生命。世俗人文主义者（当然也是无神论者）对他们所信仰的东西有更清晰的定义：他们相信任何有令人信服的论据的事物，无论该论据是否涉及测量。

Some people try to portray atheism as a narrow and pedantic attitude that dismisses all ideas except those that can be demonstrated in a scientific laboratory. This is a misimpression, to put it mildly. Like anyone else, an atheist believes in all sorts of things that cannot be measured or seen in a lab (or anywhere else). For instance, many atheists believe deeply in human rights, equality, and love. And some atheists may believe that life exists on other planets. Secular humanists (who of course are also atheists) have a clearer way of defining what they believe in: they believe in anything for which there is a convincing argument, regardless of whether the argument involves measurement or not.

10.无神论是一种意识形态

10. Atheism Is an Ideology

无神论经常被错误地指责为一种意识形态。事实并非如此。无神论无非就是神不存在的论点。这纯粹是一个真假问题，与任何意识形态无关。人们不能单从无神论中得出好价值观或坏价值观。因此，人们无法得出关于无神论者在其他重要问题上的立场的任何结论，例如干细胞研究、同性恋、堕胎、枪支管制、可持续性等。不言而喻，仅仅否认超自然的存在并不意味着有思想的人必须接受一整套关于生活中其他问题的既定观点和价值观。简而言之，无神论不是一种意识形态。

Atheism is often falsely accused of being an ideology. Not so. Atheism is no more and no less than the thesis that gods don’t exist. This is purely a matter of truth or falsity, and has nothing to do with any ideology. One cannot derive either good values or bad values from atheism alone. For this reason, one cannot draw any conclusions about where atheists stand on other important issues, such as stem-cell research, homosexuality, abortion, gun control, sustainability, and so on. It goes without saying that merely denying the existence of a supernatural being does not condemn a thinking person to accepting a whole set of predetermined opinions and values about all other questions in life. In short, atheism is not an ideology.

另一方面，宗教确实包含道德价值观，是典型的意识形态，因为它们规定了一系列关于世界和社会应该如何以及人们应该如何行动的道德态度和观念。

On the other hand, religions, which certainly do embrace moral values, are ideologies par excellence, since they prescribe sets of moral attitudes and ideas about how the world and society should be and about how people should act.

11.共产主义是无神论的，是可憎的，因此无神论也是可憎的

11. Communism Is Atheistic and Odious, and Therefore Atheism Is Odious

人们常常把共产主义政府的恶行归咎于无神论，但这种心理联系是非逻辑思维的结果。共产主义是一种意识形态，在很多方面与宗教非常相似，包括崇拜偶像和崇拜领袖。（想想今天的朝鲜。）确实，一些共产主义领导人，如约瑟夫·斯大林，既是无神论者，又是大屠杀者，但这两者之间没有因果关系。斯大林也留着小胡子，但这并不意味着我们应该得出结论，所有留胡子的男人都是大屠杀者。

The evil deeds of communist governments are often attributed to atheism, but this mental link is a result of illogical thinking. Communism is an ideology, very much like a religion in numerous respects, in that it includes cult figures and the worship of leaders. (Just think of North Korea today.) It is true that some communist leaders such as Joseph Stalin were both atheists and mass murderers, but there is no cause-and-effect connection. Stalin also had a mustache, but that doesn’t mean we should conclude that all mustachioed men are mass murderers.

众所周知，杀人犯中有很多都信仰上帝，而且信仰得十分虔诚。过去几年，ISIS 在伊拉克和叙利亚犯下的暴行只是众多例子之一。显然，我们不能仅凭这些例子就断定，所有信仰上帝的人都是杀人犯。

As is well known, there are plenty of mass murderers who believe in God—and ardently so. The atrocious acts committed in the past few years by ISIS in Iraq and Syria are just one example among many. Obviously, we cannot conclude from such examples that all people who believe in God are mass murderers.

导致这种结论的逻辑错误在于，他们混淆了两种现象之间的统计相关性和因果关系。例如，冰淇淋食用量异常高的日子和溺水事件异常多的日子之间存在很强的统计相关性。但这种相关性并没有揭示因果关系。人们溺水的原因不是吃冰淇淋。问题在于，一个关键变量——炎热的天气——被忽略了。每当天气炎热时，人们往往会吃更多的冰淇淋，也往往会更多地去游泳。因此，天气炎热时，溺水的风险就会上升。同样的混乱推理错误地将共产主义的邪恶（结果）归咎于无神论（原因）。虽然可能存在统计相关性，但这并不意味着存在因果关系。

The logical error that leads to such conclusions is that of confusing a statistical correlation of two phenomena with a cause-and-effect relationship. For example, there is a strong statistical correlation between days when there is an unusually high amount of ice-cream eating and days when unusually many drownings take place. But this correlation does not reveal a cause-and-effect connection. The reason people drown is not that they eat ice cream. The problem is that a certain key variable—namely, hot weather—has been left out of the picture. Whenever it’s hot, people tend to eat more ice cream, and people also tend to go swimming more. Therefore, when it’s hot, the risk of drowning goes up. Much the same kind of confused reasoning falsely pins the blame for the evils of communism (an effect) on atheism (a cause). Though there may be a statistical correlation, it doesn’t follow that there is a cause-and-effect link.

这种“推理”让人想起小报上那些引人注目的标题，比如“独自一人被困在电梯里怀孕了！”（该案例的实际情况是，一名女子被困在电梯里太久，以致于来不及及时服用事后避孕药。）

This type of “reasoning” recalls the attention-grabbing headlines in tabloid newspapers that blare such things as “Stuck All Alone in an Elevator, Got Pregnant!” (The actual situation in this case was that a woman was trapped in an elevator for so long that she wasn’t able to take her morning-after pill in time.)

12.纳粹主义是一种无神论意识形态

12. Nazism Was an Atheistic Ideology

不仅共产主义，纳粹主义也经常被拿来作为无神论导致的恐怖的例证。但正如我们在共产主义中看到的那样，这是逻辑上不合逻辑的结果。事实上，纳粹主义根本不是无神论！尽管希特勒本人与天主教会的关系复杂而模糊，但许多天主教神父都是纳粹分子，或者愿意与纳粹合作。在《我的奋斗》中，希特勒描述了他对天主教会的钦佩：

Not just communism but also Nazism is often trotted out as an example of the horrors that atheism leads to. But as we saw with communism, this is the result of a logical non sequitur. And the fact of the matter is, Nazism was anything but atheistic! Although Hitler himself had a complex and blurry relationship with the Catholic Church, many Catholic priests were Nazis, or willingly collaborated with the Nazis. In Mein Kampf, Hitler describes his admiration for the Catholic Church:

天主教会在这方面提供了一个有启发性的例子。神职人员独身制迫使教会不是从自己的队伍中招募牧师，而是逐步从人民群众中招募牧师。然而，很少有人认识到独身制在这方面的重要性。但这正是这一古老制度具有无穷活力的原因。因为通过不断地从下层人民中招募教会要员，教会不仅能够与民众保持本能的理解联系，而且能够确保自己始终能够利用这种形式只存在于民众中的能量。因此，这个庞大的组织具有令人惊讶的年轻、思维灵活和钢铁般的意志力。5

Here the Catholic Church presents an instructive example. Clerical celibacy forces the Church to recruit its priests not from their own ranks but progressively from the masses of the people. Yet there are not many who recognize the significance of celibacy in this relation. But therein lies the cause of the inexhaustible vigor which characterizes that ancient institution. For by thus unceasingly recruiting the ecclesiastical dignitaries from the lower classes of the people, the Church is enabled not only to maintain the contact of instinctive understanding with the masses of the population, but also to assure itself of always being able to draw upon that fund of energy which is present in this form only among the popular masses. Hence the surprising youthfulness of that gigantic organism, its mental flexibility, and its iron will power.5

显然，希特勒相信自己肩负着神圣的使命，要维护雅利安人种的纯洁性。在《我的奋斗》中，他这样描述犹太人：

It is clear that Hitler believed himself to have a divine mandate to safeguard the purity of the Aryan race. In Mein Kampf, he writes about the Jews:

这些民族的黑色寄生虫有计划地玷污我们毫无经验的年轻金发女孩，从而摧毁了世界上再也无法替代的东西。是的，两个基督教教派都漠然地看着这种对上帝恩典赐予地球的高贵而独特的生物的亵渎和毁灭。这对地球的未来的意义不在于新教徒是否击败了天主教徒，或者天主教徒是否击败了新教徒，而在于雅利安人是否为地球而保存下来或消亡。然而，这两个教派今天并没有与这种人的毁灭者作战，而是相互努力消灭对方。尤其是民粹主义的人，每个人在自己的教派中都有神圣的职责，那就是让人们停止肤浅地谈论上帝的旨意，而是真正地履行上帝的旨意，不让上帝的话语被亵渎。因为上帝的旨意赋予了人类形态、本质和能力。任何破坏他的作品的人都是在向主的创造物、神圣的旨意宣战。6

Systematically these black parasites of the nation defile our inexperienced young blond girls and thereby destroy something which can no longer be replaced in this world. Both, yes, both Christian denominations look on indifferently at this desecration and destruction of a noble and unique living creature, given to the earth by God’s grace. The significance of this for the future of the earth does not lie in whether the Protestants defeat the Catholics or the Catholics the Protestants, but in whether the Aryan man is preserved for the earth or dies out. Nevertheless, the two denominations do not fight today against the destroyer of this man, but strive mutually to annihilate one another. The folkish-minded man, in particular, has the sacred duty, each in his own denomination, of making people stop just talking superficially of God’s will, and actually fulfill God’s will, and not let God’s word be desecrated. For God’s will gave men their form, their essence and their abilities. Anyone who destroys His work is declaring war on the Lord’s creation, the divine will.6

这里我们看到希特勒认为新教徒和天主教徒应该停止互相争斗，而应该代表上帝与犹太人作战。他确信他的行为符合上帝的旨意。

Here we see that Hitler believed that the Protestants and the Catholics should stop fighting each other and should instead fight the Jews, on behalf of God. He was convinced that he was acting in line with God’s will.

不幸的是，许多牧师都服从了希特勒的命令。著名的新教主教马丁·萨塞（Martin Sasse，1890-1942 年）积极鼓励焚烧德国的犹太教堂。他认为阿道夫·希特勒应该惩罚杀害耶稣的犹太人，这是理所当然的。另一方面，一些牧师表现出极大的勇气，反对希特勒，其中最典型的例子就是迪特里希·朋霍费尔（Dietrich Bonhoeffer，1906-1945 年），他多年来一直强烈反对纳粹政权，是德国抵抗运动的一员。1945 年 4 月 9 日，就在欧洲胜利日前几周，朋霍费尔被纳粹绞死。

Unfortunately, many priests obeyed Hitler’s injunction. Prominent Protestant bishop Martin Sasse (1890–1942) actively encouraged the burning of synagogues in Germany. He considered it only proper and fitting that Adolf Hitler should punish the Jews for having killed Jesus. On the other hand, certain priests demonstrated great courage and opposed Hitler, a prime example being Dietrich Bonhoeffer (1906–1945), who vehemently spoke out for years against the Nazi regime and was part of the German resistance movement. On April 9, 1945, just weeks before VE-Day, Bonhoeffer was hanged by the Nazis.

宗教实际上是纳粹主义的核心，纳粹主义在很大程度上将其意识形态变成了一种新的宗教。每个德国士兵的救生衣上都刻有“Gott mit uns”（上帝与我们同在）的字样——这句口号令人不安地让人联想到“我们信仰上帝”（美国的国家格言）。

Religion was actually central to Nazism, which to a large extent turned its own ideology into a new kind of religion. In each German soldier’s life-jacket was found the inscription “Gott mit uns” (“God is with us”)—a slogan that is disturbingly reminiscent of “In God We Trust” (the national motto of the United States).

另一方面，希特勒对基督教的某些方面持强烈批评态度。他本人是否是基督徒很难确定，但有相当多的证据表明，他有一种宗教的世界观。

On the other hand, Hitler was highly critical of some aspects of Christianity. Whether he himself was a Christian is hard to pin down, but there is considerable evidence suggesting that he had a religious outlook on the world.

最后但并非最不重要的是，纳粹意识形态包含许多迷信、伪科学和神秘学元素。众所周知，纳粹“道德”不值一提，因此试图将无神论与纳粹主义联系起来抹黑无神论是非常不诚实的。

Last but not least, the Nazi ideology included many superstitious, pseudoscientific, and occult elements. Everyone knows that the Nazi “morality” was beneath contempt, and it is therefore deeply dishonest to smear atheism by trying to link it with Nazism.

13. 无神论者冷酷无情

13. Atheists Are Cold and Emotionless

有些人认为，无神论者比宗教人士更难欣赏艺术、音乐和其他美学创作。这又是一个奇怪的不合逻辑的推论。自然主义对宇宙的态度，并没有任何东西会使无神论者对艺术、音乐或自然的美和崇高不那么接受。事实上，有时情况恰恰相反。一个把世界看作自然的人，努力去理解大自然的内部运作，可以更深刻地欣赏我们周围的奇妙现象。

There are those who believe that atheists are less able than religious people to appreciate art, music, and other aesthetic creations. This is another bizarre non sequitur. There is nothing in the naturalistic stance toward the universe that would make an atheist less receptive to the beautiful and the sublime in art, music, or nature. In fact, sometimes it is quite the reverse. Someone who sees the world as natural, and who strives to fathom the inner workings of nature, can more deeply appreciate the amazing phenomena that surround us.

非洲大草原上生机勃勃的生命世界并没有因为我们对自然条件的了解而失去其魅力。当我们了解了大黄蜂的飞行方式时，它依然是一种令人惊奇的生物。当我们从音乐理论的角度了解了不同音符和和声之间的关系时，音乐并没有失去其美感和力量。物理学的奥秘令人难以置信，但它们是自然的。过去一百年量子物理学的发展为我们提供了更多令人难以置信的奥秘供我们思考。我们仍然完全无法解释其中的一些，但这并不意味着这些现象超越了自然。宇宙本身就足够奇妙和神秘，不需要任何魔法或超自然生物。

The teeming world of life on the African savanna does not lose any of its fascination as a result of our understanding the conditions of nature. A bumblebee is no less astonishing a creature when we understand how it flies. Music does not lose its beauty or power when we understand how different notes and harmonies are related to each other in the terms of music theory. The mysteries of physics are incredible, but they are natural. The development of quantum physics in the last hundred years gave us even more incredible mysteries to ponder. We still are completely unable to explain some of them, but that doesn’t mean that the phenomena transcend nature. The universe, just as it is, is sufficiently wonderful and mysterious, without any need for magic or supernatural beings.

无神论的重生与消失

Atheism’s Rebirth and Disappearance

无神论这个概念其实并不怎么有趣。它只是表示不相信神或众神。然而，历代以来，这个词已经变得如此情绪化，充满邪恶的内涵，以至于即使在今天，许多人一提到它就会产生非常负面的下意识反应。由于历史的缘故，看到一个词可以赋予如此大的唤起力量，真是令人着迷。然而，如今，这个词可能正在慢慢失去它的污​​名，并慢慢变得听起来中性，这也是理所当然的。

The concept of atheism is actually not terribly interesting. It just means the lack of belief in a god, or in gods. And yet, down through the ages, the word has become so emotionally charged and so fraught with evil connotations that, even today, many people have a profoundly negative knee-jerk reaction to any mention of it. It is quite fascinating to see how much evocative power a word can be imbued with, thanks to history. These days, however, it may be the case that the word is slowly losing its stigma and is slowly becoming neutral sounding, as well it should.

当这种情况发生时，就是放弃“无神论”和“无神论者”这些词的适当时机，因为它们只有在完全浸透宗教的文化中才有存在的理由。当我们真正拥有一个世俗社会的那一天到来时，我们将不再需要将我们的精神和语言精力集中在我们不相信存在的事物上。当那一天到来时，最好把注意力集中在我们真正相信的事物上。

When this happens, that would be the proper time to abandon the words “atheism” and “atheist” because they have a raison d’être only in a culture that is thoroughly steeped in religion. When the day comes around that we truly have a secular society, we will no longer need to focus our mental and linguistic energy on things that we don’t believe exist. When that day comes, it will be better to focus on things in which we genuinely believe.

插曲：关于迷信和魔术

INTERLUDE: ON SUPERSTITION AND HOCUS-POCUS

什么是迷信？迷信就是相信有吉利数字和不吉利数字，相信从梯子下面走过、看到黑猫或打碎镜子会带来厄运，相信灾难更有可能在星期五发生13 日，携带诸如兔脚之类的魔法护身符会给携带者带来好运，敲木头或交叉手指可以避开厄运，把大头针插进洋娃娃会伤害到远方的某人，建筑物的建造方式应优化“软”和“硬”能量的流动，将剃须刀片放在金字塔形物体下面会使刀片在一夜之间变得锋利，如果只需一口气吹灭蛋糕上的所有蜡烛，你秘密的生日愿望就会实现，随机选择的幸运饼干中的信息将揭示饼干开启者的命运——等等。

What is superstition? Superstition is believing that there are lucky and unlucky numbers, that walking under a ladder or seeing a black cat or breaking a mirror brings bad luck, that disasters are more likely to happen on Friday the 13th, that carrying a magical charm such as a rabbit’s foot will bring the bearer good luck, that knocking on wood or crossing one’s fingers will ward off bad luck, that you can hurt someone far away by sticking pins into a doll, that buildings should be constructed so as to optimize the flow of “soft” and “hard” energy, that placing razor blades underneath a pyramid-shaped object will sharpen them overnight, that your secret birthday wish will come true if you blow out all the candles on your cake with just one puff, that the message inside a randomly chosen fortune cookie will reveal the fate of the cookie-opener—and so forth.

所有这些观点的共同点是，没有充分的理由去相信其中任何一个，但它们都给信徒一种安全感，以及一种对我们周围所见混乱事件的控制的虚幻感觉。

What is shared by all these ideas is that there is no good reason to believe any of them, and yet they all give the believer a sense of security, and an illusory feeling of control of the chaotic flux of events that we see around us.

有人说，在门上挂一块马蹄铁会带来好运（当然，前提是马蹄铁的方向正确！）。有一个古老的故事，讲的是一位记者注意到丹麦伟大物理学家尼尔斯·玻尔的小屋门上挂着一块马蹄铁。这位记者立刻好奇起来。“你为什么把马蹄铁挂在那里？”记者问道，“这是否意味着你至少有一点相信这个古老的迷信？”故事中，玻尔对记者的问题笑了笑，回答道：“哦——那？不，我当然不相信任何愚蠢的迷信，但你知道，有些人说，即使你不相信这些东西，它们也会起作用！”

Some people say that a horseshoe hung above one’s door will bring good luck (provided, of course, that it is oriented in the right direction!). There’s an old story about a journalist who noticed a horseshoe hanging above the door of the cottage belonging to the great Danish physicist Niels Bohr. The journalist’s curiosity was immediately aroused. “Why,” asked the journalist, “did you hang a horseshoe up there? Does that mean that you believe, at least a little bit, in this old superstition?” As the story goes, Bohr smiled at the journalist’s question and replied, “Oh—that? No, of course I don’t believe in silly superstitions of any sort, but you know, some people say that these things work even if you don’t believe in them!”

伯特兰·罗素对迷信的概念非常清晰。他说：“迷信是别人的宗教。”他的意思是指，任何宗教信仰体系都不会被其信徒认为是迷信，然而其他人的宗教信仰却常常被草率地视为纯粹的迷信，即使对方的思想体系可能与自己的一样合理，也可能一样不合理。

Bertrand Russell had a very clear notion of what superstition is. He said, “Superstition is other people’s religion.” By this he meant that no religious belief system is considered by its adherents to be in the least superstitious, yet other people’s religious beliefs are often cursorily dismissed as mere superstitions, even though the rival set of ideas may be just as reasonable, or just as unreasonable, as one’s own.

20 世纪 50 年代初，一位不知名的儿童杂志编辑马丁·加德纳出版了一本名为《以科学的名义进行的时尚和谬论》（1952 年）的散文集。这本书文笔优美，见解深刻，令人震惊，而且很有趣，它致力于揭穿胡言乱语的艺术。在书中，加德纳以最高的艺术性和技巧，驳斥了二十多种高度多样化的伪科学和迷信。几年后，在这本经典著作第二版（1957 年）序言的开篇，他一本正经地写道：

In the early 1950s, an unknown children’s magazine editor named Martin Gardner came out with a collection of essays called Fads and Fallacies in the Name of Science (1952). Astoundingly well written, insightful, profound, shocking, and amusing, this book was devoted to the art of debunking of nonsense. In it, with the highest artistry and skill, Gardner tore apart some two dozen highly diverse types of pseudoscience and superstition. A few years later, in the opening paragraph of the preface to this classic work’s second edition (1957), he poker-facedly writes:

这本书的第一版引起了许多愤怒读者的好奇信件。最激烈的信件来自赖希教徒，他们愤怒的原因是这本书将生命能与（对他们来说）古怪的邪教相提并论，例如戴尼提。当然，戴尼提主义者对生命力学也有同样的看法。我听说顺势疗法者发现自己与整骨疗法和脊椎按摩疗法等骗子为伍，感到很受侮辱，肯塔基州的一位脊椎按摩师“可怜”我，因为我已经放弃了上帝赐予受苦人类的最大礼物——脊椎。贝茨博士的几位崇拜者给我写信，信写得非常糟糕，我怀疑写信的人急需一副好眼镜。奇怪的是，这些通信者中的大多数只反对其中一章，认为其他章节都很精彩。7

The first edition of this book prompted many curious letters from irate readers. The most violent letters came from Reichians, furious because the book considered orgonomy alongside such (to them) outlandish cults as dianetics. Dianeticians, of course, felt the same about orgonomy. I heard from homeopaths who were insulted to find themselves in company with such frauds as osteopathy and chiropractic, and one chiropractor in Kentucky “pitied” me because I had turned my spine on God’s greatest gift to suffering humanity. Several admirers of Dr. Bates favored me with letters so badly typed that I suspect the writers were in urgent need of strong spectacles. Oddly enough, most of these correspondents objected to one chapter only, thinking all the others excellent.7

最后那句话多么有说服力、多么人性化、多么令人难忘！

How telling is that last sentence—how deeply human—and how unforgettable!

在传统的基督教信仰中，尤其是那些向偏远地区派遣传教士的基督教信仰中，土著人民的宗教信仰一直被视为迷信。例如，相信树木或石头有灵魂，或为了安抚自然之神而跳祈雨舞和以各种形式的动物和人类祭祀，都被认为是迷信或巫术思维，是与恶灵和魔鬼的危险调情。

Within the traditional Christian faiths, especially those that send missionaries to remote lands, the religious beliefs of indigenous peoples have always been seen as superstitions. For instance, the belief that trees or stones have spirits, or the performance of rain dances and various forms of animal and human sacrifice to placate the gods of nature, are considered to be superstitions or magical thinking, and to constitute a dangerous flirtation with evil spirits and demons.

但是，基督教的天主教分支包含许多很难不被视为迷信的信仰。例如，1215 年第四次拉特兰会议上确立的变体论。该教义声称，在弥撒的圣餐部分，一块普通的面包和一些普通的葡萄酒“以一种超越理解的方式”变成了基督的身体和血液，尽管它们的外观、味道和气味完全不受影响。在 13 世纪的一次教会会议上，人们确定“基督的身体和血液实际上以面包和葡萄酒的形式存在于圣礼中，然后面包通过上帝的力量转化为身体，血液转化为葡萄酒。”在 16 世纪，马丁路德的宗教改革运动将这种思维方式称为魔法和迷信——并拒绝了它。

But Christianity’s branch of Catholicism involves a number of beliefs that would be hard not to see as superstitious. Consider, for example, the notion of transubstantiation, which was established in the Fourth Lateran Council, in 1215. This doctrine asserts that, “in a way surpassing understanding,” an ordinary piece of bread and some ordinary wine literally turn into the body and blood of Christ during the Eucharist portion of a mass, although their appearance, taste, and odor remain completely unaffected. In a church council in the thirteenth century, it was determined that “Christ’s body and blood are actually found in the sacrament, in the form of bread and wine, and then the bread is transubstantiated into the body and the blood into wine through the power of God.” In the sixteenth century, Martin Luther’s Reformation movement branded this type of thinking as magical and superstitious—and rejected it.

传统宗教习俗中的另一个例子是圣人崇拜，即历史人物的部分遗体被保存数个世纪之久并受到崇拜，因为人们相信这些遗体被赋予了神奇的力量。

Another example taken from traditional religious practices is the cult of saints, whereby parts of the bodies of historical figures are preserved for centuries and are worshipped, as they are believed to be imbued with magical powers.

对于非宗教人士来说，这种做法只能被称为“骗术”。

For nonreligious people, such practices can only be called “hocuspocus.”

“hocus-pocus filiocus” 这个词是一种魔法咒语，至少可以追溯到 17 世纪。所有迹象都表明，这个短语起源于基督教仪式。具体来说，天主教的仪式变体论包括拉丁语短语“Hoc est enim corpus meum”（“这是我的身体”）和“filioque”（“和儿子的”）。听起来很神秘的短语“hocus-pocus filiocus”是完整天主教咒语的缩写和混乱版本（“hoc est . . . corpus . . . filioque”），由无数虔诚的弥撒信徒共同发明，他们热爱仪式，但几乎不会说拉丁语。混乱的短语自动呈现出主持弥撒的牧师赋予原始短语的所有美妙的魔法、不可理解和神奇的味道。

The words “hocus-pocus filiocus” are a magical incantation that goes back at least as far as the seventeenth century. All indications are that this phrase has its origins in Christian rites. To be specific, the Catholic ritual of transubstantiation includes the Latin phrases “Hoc est enim corpus meum” (“This is my body”) and “filioque” (“and of the son”). The mystical-sounding phrase “hocus-pocus filiocus” is a shortened and garbled version (“hoc est . . . corpus . . . filioque”) of the full Catholic incantation, collectively invented by the minds of myriad pious mass-goers who loved the ritual but spoke little or no Latin. The garbled phrase automatically took on all the delicious flavors of magic, incomprehensibility, and miraculousness that were attached to the original phrase by the priests who conducted masses.

所谓的“迷信”会随着时间而改变。例如，在瑞典，人们一度普遍相信妖精和精灵的存在；然而，如今，任何相信这些事物的瑞典人都会被视为疯子。

What is called “superstitious” changes over time. In Sweden, for instance, goblins and elves were once generally believed to exist; today, however, any Swede who believes in such things is looked upon as a nutcase.

一百年后，人们会如何看待当今普遍存在的鬼神信仰，耶稣将水变成酒并从死里复活的教义，整个世界在几千年前仅用六天就被创造的教义，星座可以透露一个人的性格和命运，手掌上的纹路可以揭示一个人的命运，飞碟中的外星人曾造访过我们的星球并与一些人类接触？

In a hundred years’ time, how will people look upon today’s common beliefs in ghosts and spirits, or the dogma that Jesus turned water into wine and was resurrected from the dead? Or the dogma that the entire world was created in but six days only a few thousand years ago? Or the idea that one’s zodiacal sign tells secrets about one’s character and fate, or that the lines on one’s palms reveal one’s destiny? Or that aliens in flying saucers have visited our planet and had contact with some humans?

或者，正如超感知觉（ESP）的信徒所主张的那样，某些天赋异禀的人可以在数千英里之外进行心灵交流？或者，正如心灵感应的信徒所主张的那样，有些人可以仅凭意念的力量就弄弯钥匙和勺子？或者，正如所谓“奇点”的信徒所主张的那样，在未来十五到二十年内，我们都能够将大脑的微电路上传到计算机内存中，从而作为软件生物永生？

Or, as believers in ESP maintain, that certain gifted people can communicate mind-to-mind at thousands of miles of distance? Or, as believers in telekinesis maintain, that some people can bend keys and spoons by the sheer power of thought? Or, as believers in the so-called “Singularity” maintain, that, in the next fifteen to twenty years, we will all be able to upload our brain’s microcircuitry into computer memories and thereby live forever as software creatures?

谁知道呢——今天的股市预测技术和神奇的减肥方法最终会被视为骗局吗？一百年后，人们会如何看待今天的超对称粒子理论、暗物质和暗能量理论？弦理论和“膜”理论又如何？大爆炸和与之相伴的大挤压又如何？多元宇宙、虫洞和时间旅行又如何？好吧，我们只能拭目以待。如果奇点论者是对的，我们中的许多人不仅会在一百年后还活着，甚至会在一千年、一百万年、十亿年后还活着……

And who knows—might today’s stock-market prediction techniques and miracle weight-losing methods eventually come to be seen as nothing but flim-flam? What will people think, in a hundred years, about today’s theories of supersymmetric particles, and of dark matter and dark energy? What about string theory and the theory of “branes”? What about the Big Bang and its complementary companion, the Big Crunch? What about multiverses and wormholes and time travel? Well, we’ll just have to wait to see. And if the Singularitarians are right, many of us will be alive not just a hundred years from now, but even a thousand, and a million, and a billion years from now . . .

第七章

CHAPTER SEVEN

无需上帝也能行善论善、恶与道德

BEING GOOD WITHOUT NEEDING GOD Concerning Goodness, Evil, and Morality

上帝是否愿意阻止邪恶，但却不能阻止邪恶？那么，他就不是万能的。

如果他有能力却不愿意，那么他就是恶毒的。

他既能又愿意吗？那么邪恶从何而来？

难道他既不能，又不愿意吗？那为什么叫他神呢？

—伊壁鸠鲁

Is God willing to prevent evil, but not able? Then He is not omnipotent.

Is He able, but not willing? Then He is malevolent.

Is He both able and willing? Then whence cometh evil?

Is He neither able nor willing? Then why call Him God?

—Epicurus

我在自然界中，善与恶不可避免地并存。接受自然界没有超自然力量这一观念的人不会思考恶的存在与上帝的恩典如何相容。对他们来说，恶的存在根源于自然原因，与各种形式的恶的斗争必须永不停歇。但对于有宗教信仰的人来说，一个严重的问题出现了：善与恶怎么能同时存在呢？

In a naturalistic world, there will inevitably be both good and bad. People who accept the idea of a natural world without supernatural forces will not brood about how evil’s existence is compatible with God’s grace. For them, the existence of evil is rooted in natural causes, and the battle against evil in its many forms must simply be waged without stop. But for people who are religious, a serious problem arises: How can both good and evil exist at one and the same time?

邪恶的问题

The Problem of Evil

上帝死于奥斯维辛。

God died in Auschwitz.

只有通过这样的比喻，我们才能感受到纳粹集中营对犹太人和其他人实施的暴行有多么令人难以置信。如此规模的邪恶似乎与对全能仁慈的上帝的信仰完全不可调和。请看以下可怕的事件，我的一位朋友亲眼目睹了这一事件，他不知何故从奥斯维辛集中营的囚禁中幸存下来：

Only through such a metaphor could one attempt to convey a sense for how unfathomable were the atrocities carried out against Jews and others in Nazi concentration camps. Evil of that magnitude seems totally irreconcilable with belief in an all-powerful and benevolent God. Consider the following horrific event, which was witnessed by a friend of mine who somehow survived imprisonment in the camp at Auschwitz:

在我们的营地里，有一位妇女，她有一个年幼的孩子。她拼命想让她的孩子活下去，但徒劳无功。当孩子死了，她心烦意乱，试图逃跑。她很快就被抓获，我们这些囚犯都被迫围成一个大圈，围在她中间，两名党卫军士兵站在被俘女子的旁边。我们被要求观看他们如何处理逃跑者。他们先把她紧紧地拴在一棵树上，然后鞭打她。然后他们把她的胳膊、手和肩膀从关节处拉出来。他们继续残忍地折磨她，最后她倒地而死在我们眼前。

In our camp there was a woman who had a very young child. She tried desperately to keep her child alive, but in vain. When the child died, she was distraught and tried to escape. She was quickly captured and we prisoners were all forced to stand in a large circle around her. In the middle, standing near the captured woman, there were two SS men. We were made to watch how they handled runaways. First they chained her tightly to a tree and whipped her. Then they pulled her arms, her hands, and her shoulders out of their sockets. They continued torturing her so brutally that in the end she collapsed and died before our eyes.

我们怎么能相信一个允许这种事情发生在我们这个世界上的神呢？

How is it possible to believe in a god who would permit such things to take place in our world?

如果真的有神，一位无所不知、无所不能的神，那么为什么世界上还有这么多邪恶和苦难？这个谜题被称为神义论问题，希腊语意为“上帝的正义”。自古以来，神学家和哲学家们就一直在努力解决这个问题；事实上，这是反对三大亚伯拉罕宗教（犹太教、基督教和伊斯兰教）的圣书中所描述的神存在的最有力的论据之一。

If there is a god, an omniscient and omnipotent god, then why is there so much evil and suffering in the world? This mystery is known as the problem of theodicy, a Greek word meaning “God’s justice.” Theologians and philosophers have grappled with it since time immemorial; indeed, it is one of the strongest arguments against the existence of the god who is described in the holy books of the three Abrahamic religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

全能的——是还是不是？

Omnipotent—Yes or No?

宗教人士为了证明他们对上帝的信仰是正当的，想出了许多方法来解决神正论问题。其中一种方法就是接受上帝并非万能的观念。上帝在创造人类时赋予每个人自由意志；上帝因此限制了自己的权力。每个人都有自由做出道德上正确或错误的决定。由于人们有自由意志，他们可能会做坏事，而上帝却无能为力阻止他们。

Religious people, in trying to justify their belief in God, have dreamed up numerous ways of solving the problem of theodicy. One solution is simply to accept the idea that God is not all-powerful. In creating humanity, God endowed each person with free will; God thereby limited his own powers. Each person had the freedom to make morally right or wrong decisions. Thanks to their free will, people could carry out evil deeds, and God would be helpless to prevent them.

但我们可以很容易地想象一个世界，那里的人们拥有自由意志，而上帝也无所不能。在这样的世界里，上帝可以在必要时干预人类事务，以防止人们因自由而犯下恶行。例如，上帝可以干预，防止人们自相残杀。只要人们在道德上正确的选择之间做出选择，他们就可以运用自由意志。但如果有人即将选择做一件道德上错误的事情，那么全能的上帝就会介入，在恶行发生之前将其扼杀在萌芽状态。

But one can easily imagine a world where people had free will and God was also all powerful. In such a world, God could intervene in human affairs, when needed, to prevent evil deeds stemming from people’s freedom. For instance, God could intervene to keep people from killing each other. People could use their free will as long as they were choosing between morally good alternatives. But if someone were about to choose to do a morally bad act, then an all-powerful God could jump in and nip the evil deed in the bud before it was carried out.

上帝也可能以这样的方式创造了宇宙，即人们的选择总是好的。原则上，可以想象存在一个世界，在那里人们的自由选择总是会带来好的结果。事实上，这样的世界比一个选择有时带来好，有时带来坏的结果的世界更完美。如果一个全能的上帝存在，能够创造出最好的世界，那么他为什么不创造这样的世界呢？

God might also have created the universe in such a way that whatever people chose was always for the good. In principle, it’s conceivable for a world to exist in which people’s free choices would always bring about good. Such a world would, in fact, be more perfect than a world in which choices sometimes brought about good and other times evil. If an omnipotent God existed, capable of producing the best possible world, then why would he not have created a world of this sort?

这种试图解决神正论问题的方法只能解决道德恶的问题，即人们故意犯下的恶行，如谋杀、强奸、叛国和战争。但它甚至没有触及自然恶的问题，自然恶指的是不是人类意图的结果而发生的坏事，如地震、山体滑坡、火灾、海啸、飓风、火山爆发、流行病、踩踏事件、建筑物倒塌、船只沉没、飞机失事等。世界上有很多这样的苦难——绝对毁灭性，但却毫无理由地发生。如果有人被雷击中，或被埋在雪崩中，或患上致命的脑瘤，或在帮助邻居修补漏水时从屋顶上摔下来，他们的死亡当然是悲惨的，但这与任何人的邪恶意图无关。

This type of attempted solution to the theodicy problem only solves the problem of moral evil, which is to say, the problem of evil acts that are intentionally committed by people, such as murder, rape, treason, and war. But it doesn’t even touch on the problem of natural evil, which refers to bad things that happen that are not the result of human intentions, such as earthquakes, landslides, fires, tidal waves, hurricanes, volcanic eruptions, epidemics, stampedes, collapsing buildings, sinking ships, airplane crashes, and so forth. There is a great deal of suffering of this sort in the world—absolutely devastating, but happening for no good reason. If someone is struck by lightning, or is buried in an avalanche, or comes down with a fatal brain tumor, or falls from a rooftop while helping a neighbor repair a leak, their death is certainly tragic, but it has nothing to do with anyone’s evil intentions.

全能的神应该能够防止这种苦难，而由于赋予人们自由意志而权力有限的神也应该能够防止这种苦难。所有这些的结果是，将自由意志作为解决方案的一部分并不能解决神正论问题。

An all-powerful god should be able to prevent such suffering, and so should a god whose powers are more limited because of the fact of having granted people free will. The upshot of all this is that the theodicy problem is not resolved by bringing in free will as part of the solution.

主以神秘的方式行事

The Lord Works in Mysterious Ways

另一种神学理论试图解释为什么世界上存在邪恶，其大致内容如下：我们人类无法理解上帝允许邪恶存在的原因。我们理解的邪恶和苦难实际上服务于一个更崇高的目的，从足够长远的角度来看，它最终会成为好事，尽管我们现在可能还不明白为什么会这样。正如一句熟悉的口号所说：“上帝以神秘的方式行事。”

A different theological attempt to explain why there is evil in the world runs roughly as follows: We humans cannot understand God’s reasons for allowing evil to exist. What we interpret as evil and suffering actually serves a far higher purpose, and when it is viewed from a sufficiently long-term perspective, it turns out to be for the good, even though we, right now, may not be able to see how that could possibly be the case. In a familiar slogan, “The Lord works in mysterious ways.”

不幸的是，这样的“智慧箴言”不仅站不住脚，而且不道德、令人反感。首先，对一个孩子刚刚被学校恶霸杀害或死于车祸的人念诵这句话，会让人感到深深的冒犯。生命被残忍终结的人，长远的利益又在哪里呢？如果一个人死于他人的残忍或自然灾害，这种说法就很荒谬。诚然，经历可怕的磨难有时可以让人坚强，但死于地震或恐怖袭击的人很难说变得更坚强。

Unfortunately, such a “nugget of wisdom” not only is untenable but also immoral and repellent. To begin with, it would be deeply offensive to recite this phrase to someone whose child has just been murdered by a school bully or killed in a car accident. Where lies the long-term good for the person whose life has been brutally ended? If someone dies because of another person’s cruelty or because of a natural disaster, the argument is absurd. To be sure, going through terrible ordeals can occasionally strengthen people, but people who die in an earthquake or a terrorist attack can hardly be said to have been made stronger.

某些支持这种神正论​​方法的人可能会认为，在某个地方牺牲一个人的生命是为了在其他地方产生良好的影响。这似乎很讽刺。我们死后升入天堂，也许会因尘世的苦难而得到回报？这并不能解决神正论的问题，因为尘世仍然存在巨大的苦难。

Certain advocates of this approach to the theodicy problem might suggest that the sacrifice of one person’s life somewhere serves the purpose of creating a good effect elsewhere. This seems to be quite cynical. Are we perhaps rewarded for our earthly suffering after we have died and have gone to heaven? This does not solve the problem of theodicy, since great suffering still exists on earth.

仁慈全能的上帝会创造一个我们在生前和死后都不会遭受苦难的世界。

A benevolent and all-powerful God would set up a world in which we did not suffer either before or after death.

有些邪恶并非真实存在，尽管表面上如此

Some Kinds of Evil Aren’t Real, despite Appearances

让我们再看看另一种试图解释邪恶与上帝共存的方法。这将涉及扩展第一种方法来解决神正论问题，基本思路如下。

Let’s take a look at one further way of trying to explain away the coexistence of evil and God. This will involve extending the first approach to solving the theodicy problem, and the basic idea goes along the following lines.

道德邪恶是这个世界的真正组成部分，是人类自由意志的结果；然而，自然邪恶根本不存在。它不是实际存在的东西；相反，它是某种东西的缺失——也就是善的缺失。就像黑色不是真正的颜色，而只是光和颜色的缺失一样，在我们看来，自然邪恶只是善的缺失。

Moral evil is a genuine part of this world, and it is a result of human beings’ free will; however, natural evil simply does not exist. It is not an actual thing; it is, rather, the absence of a thing—namely, the absence of good. Much as black is not a true color, but merely the absence of light and color, so what looks to us like natural evil is merely the absence of good.

这种解决神正论问题的方法通常被称为“剥夺反应”，源自拉丁语privatio boni，意为“拿走好东西”。剥夺反应是一种文字游戏——一种将上帝从危险的神正论问题中拯救出来的绝望尝试。

This approach to the theodicy problem is often called the “privation response,” from the Latin privatio boni, meaning “taking away of good.” The privation response is a kind of play on words—a desperate attempt to save God from the treacherous theodicy problem.

假设这种缺失反应是正确的，也就是说，我们人类所认为的自然之恶仅仅是善的缺失。这很好，但这种语义上的吹毛求疵对那些生活被地震摧毁的人，或家人被海啸吞没的人来说有什么意义呢？他们的痛苦是极其真实的，无论我们将其描述为自然之恶还是善的缺失。如果上帝真的存在，而且全能、善良，他将能够创造一个包含更多善的世界——或者如果你愿意的话，一个没有痛苦的世界。这样的上帝还可以干预任何因善良缺失而导致痛苦的地方，并将人类（和动物）从可怕的痛苦中解救出来。

Suppose that the privation response were correct, meaning that what we humans perceive as natural evil is merely the absence of good. Fine, but how does this kind of semantic nitpicking matter to those whose lives have been shattered by an earthquake, or to someone whose family was swallowed up by a tsunami? Their suffering is overwhelmingly real, whether we describe it as natural evil or as absent goodness. If God truly existed and were all-powerful and good, he would be able to create a world that contained greater good—or if you prefer, a greater absence of suffering. Such a god could also intervene wherever an absence of goodness caused suffering and could release humans (and animals) from terrible agony.

尽管宗教试图解释神正论问题存在种种缺陷，但这些尝试经常被所谓的自由教会所认可，无论是在瑞典还是其他地方。在一次纪念奥斯维辛解放的活动中，我曾与一位瑞典著名神学家进行了辩论，他与瑞典自由教会组织有联系。教堂。这位男士所提倡的观点是，纳粹对奥斯维辛集中营囚犯的所作所为可能是因为上帝一旦赋予人们自由意志，就无法再干预。（我使用男性代词，因为它反映了宗教人士对上帝的普遍印象。在这个特定的语境中，我甚至使用了大写的H，只是为了明确表示我不是指神学家。）

Despite all the flaws in religious attempts to explain away the theodicy problem, such attempts are often cited approvingly in so-called Free Churches, both in Sweden and elsewhere. In an event commemorating the liberation of Auschwitz, I once took part in a debate with a leading Swedish theologian who was associated with a Swedish organization of Free Churches. The view this man advocated was that what the Nazis did to prisoners in Auschwitz might be explained by the fact that once God had given people free will, He could no longer intervene. (I use the masculine pronoun, since it reflects the nearly universal image that religious people seem to have of God. And in this particular context, I even used a capital H, just to make clear that I wasn’t referring to the theologian.)

这位神学家提出的另一种观点是，可能存在一个只有上帝才能理解的更高的道德目标，而纳粹在奥斯维辛和其他死亡集中营进行的种族灭绝可能只是达到这一更高目标必须付出的代价。

Another view that this theologian proposed was that there may be a higher moral goal that only God understands, and that the genocide conducted by the Nazis in Auschwitz and in their other death camps might simply be the price that had to be paid to reach that higher goal.

在我看来，这种观点不仅在逻辑上是错误的，而且非常愤世嫉俗。如果真的有一位全能的仁慈的上帝在观察奥斯维辛集中营发生的事情，他能阻止这一切吗？或者，阻止这一切是否需要上帝凌驾于囚犯或狱警的自由意志之上？答案其实很简单（至少如果你是一位全能的上帝的话）。只需要一个相当小的奇迹——例如，集中营的大门可能突然全部打开，让囚犯逃脱。另一个同样能产生同样效果的奇迹是让所有狱警突然患上肠胃流感，阻止他们执行残忍的处决。这两种干预都不会侵犯人类的自由意志，对于任何能够创造真正奇迹的超自然生物来说，实现这两种干预都是小菜一碟。

To my mind, this type of view is not only logically fallacious but also deeply cynical. If there truly were an omnipotent and good god who was watching what was going on in Auschwitz, would he have been able to prevent it? Or would preventing it have required that God override the free will of the prisoners or of the guards? The answer is actually very simple (at least if you are an all-powerful god). All it would take is a fairly minor miracle—for instance, the gates of the camp might all have suddenly sprung open, allowing the prisoners to escape. A different miracle that would have turned the trick equally well would have been to make all the prison guards suddenly come down with the stomach flu, keeping them from carrying out their bestial executions. Neither of these interventions would have infringed on human free will, and to make either of them happen would have been child’s play for any supernatural being that was able to work true miracles.

那么，上帝心中有一个更高的道德目标，可以证明奥斯维辛大屠杀是正当的，但对于我们脆弱的人类思维来说，这是不可理解的，这种想法又如何呢？好吧，即使情况确实如此，它也永远无法证明死亡集中营是正当的。一位全能的上帝当然可以实现任何可能存在的更高道德目标，而不需要给数百万无辜的人带来难以想象的痛苦。

What about the idea that God had a higher moral goal in mind, which would justify the mass murders in Auschwitz, but which would be incomprehensible to our feeble human minds? Well, even if this were the case, it could never justify the death camps. A god who was all powerful could certainly reach any kind of higher moral goal that might exist without needing to inflict inconceivable suffering on millions of innocent people.

逃离匈牙利纳粹统治的癌症研究员乔治·克莱因 (Georg Klein) 从神正论问题中得出了我认为最明智的教训：“上帝如此冷酷无情和恶毒，以至于他的行为唯一的借口就是他不存在。”

Cancer researcher Georg Klein, who escaped from Nazism in Hungary, drew what I consider to be the most sensible lesson from the theodicy problem: “God is so merciless and malevolent that the only excuse for His behavior is that He doesn’t exist.”

上帝真的是仁慈的吗？

Is God Actually Good?

那么，是什么让人们认为上帝是善良的呢？许多（如果不是全部）宗教人士都相信上帝是百分之百善良的；只是他的能力，以及他虽然上帝是伟大的，但上帝并没有伟大到能够阻止人们以上帝不赞成的方式利用自由意志对世人犯下的所有罪恶。很少有宗教人士对上帝是否善良表示怀疑。

What makes people think God is good, anyway? Many if not all religious people believe that God is 100 percent good; it’s just that his powers, although great, are not so great as to be able to prevent all the evil that people, using their free will in ways that God disapproves of, wreak on other people in this world. Very few religious people ever express doubts about whether God is good.

但事实上，事实怎么就不能恰恰相反呢？想象一下，上帝是百分之百邪恶的；只是他的力量虽然强大，却不足以阻止人们以上帝不赞成的方式运用自由意志，对这个世界上其他人施以的所有善意。人类的自由意志与完全邪恶的上帝相结合，很容易产生我们今天所看到的世界。尽管这个版本的上帝一直在尽其所能制造尽可能多的痛苦，但世界上仍然有很多善良和快乐，这一切都要归功于人类自由意志的存在。

In fact, though, why couldn’t the truth be exactly the opposite? Imagine instead that God is 100 percent evil; it’s just that his powers, although great, are not so great as to be able to prevent all the kindness that people, using their free will in ways that God disapproves of, lavish on other people in this world. The combination of human free will and a totally evil God could easily give rise to just the world that we see around us today. Even though this version of God is constantly doing everything he can so as to produce as much suffering as possible, there is still a great deal of goodness and pleasure in the world, and it’s all thanks to the existence of human free will.

这两种对世界的描述是镜像，它们中的每一个都同样可能。但后者的形象不那么吸引人。正如神义论问题所清楚表明的那样，一个更有可能的结论是，全能的、善良的上帝是一个幻想。

These two descriptions of the world are mirror images, and each of them is just as likely as the other. But the latter image is less appealing. A far more likely conclusion, as the theodicy problem so clearly shows, is that an all-powerful and good God is a chimera.

英国哲学家德里克·帕菲特1在 2014 年 10 月的一次谈话中告诉我，他直到八岁都信仰宗教，甚至想成为一名僧侣；然而，由于对神正论问题的深入思考，他逐渐放弃了对善良全能的上帝的信仰，尽管这是他在学校学到的。他觉得自己被深深误导了，对那些教他这些事情的权威失去了尊重。九岁时，他成为了一名无神论者，2014 年，他告诉我，在他看来，如果更少的人相信上帝，世界将会变得更美好。

British philosopher Derek Parfit1 told me, in a conversation we had in October 2014, that up until the age of eight he was religious, even to the point of wanting to become a monk; however, as a result of thinking hard about the theodicy problem, he slowly gave up his belief in a good and omnipotent God, even though this was what he had been taught in school. He felt deeply misled, and he lost respect for the authorities who had taught him such things. At age nine, he became an atheist, and in 2014, he told me that, in his opinion, the world would be a better place if fewer people believed in God.

道德不需要上帝

Morality Has No Need for a God

让我们来做个思想实验。想象一下问一个相信上帝的人：“是什么促使你做出道德行为？是因为道德是上帝赋予我们这些卑微人类的吗？”如果这个人的回答是“是的，我的道德源自上帝”，那么他们似乎不得不同意以下观点：“如果上帝要求你伤害或谋杀另一个人，你会心甘情愿地执行上帝提出的要求，不是吗？或者假设有一天你突然失去了对上帝的信仰。那么我应该害怕在你身边，不是吗，因为你的道德将消失得无影无踪？”

Let’s try a thought experiment. Imagine asking someone who believes in God, “What motivates you to act morally? Is it because morality was dictated to us lowly humans by God on high?” If the person’s answer is “Yes, my morality is derived from on high,” then it would seem that they would have to agree with the following: “If God were to ask you to injure or murder another person, you would willingly carry out this request from on high, wouldn’t you? Or suppose that one day you were suddenly to lose your faith in God. Then I should be terrified to be anywhere around you, shouldn’t I, since your morals would have vanished into thin air?”

相反，如果这个人的回答是“不，我的道德并非来自上帝”，那么无论上帝是否存在，他们似乎都会做出道德行为。他们道德行为的原因与他们对上帝存在与否的信仰无关。

If instead the person’s answer is, “No, my morality doesn’t derive from on high,” then it would seem that they would act morally whether or not God existed. The reason for their moral behavior would not be tied to their belief in the existence or nonexistence of God.

我们可以这样重新表述这个问题。一种行为在道德上是正确的，是因为上帝提倡它，还是相反，上帝提倡它，因为它在道德上是正确的？柏拉图（公元前 427-360 年）在他的对话《欧西弗罗篇》中已经仔细探讨了这个问题。在对话中，苏格拉底即将因无神论罪受审，他与欧西弗罗辩论，欧西弗罗表现得好像他完全知道虔诚和正义是什么。事实上，欧西弗罗对自己非常自信，他即将把自己的父亲告上法庭，因为后者的行为导致了父亲的死亡。

We could reformulate the question in the following way. Is an act morally right because God advocates it, or conversely, does God advocate it because it is morally right? This issue was already carefully explored by Plato (427–360 BCE) in his dialogue Euthyphro. In it, Socrates, who is just about to be brought to trial for the crime of atheism, debates with Euthyphro, who acts as if he knew exactly what piety and justice are. Euthyphro is in fact so sure of himself that he is about to bring his own father to court because an act of the latter resulted in a death.

尤西弗罗：是的，我应该说，一切神都喜爱虔诚和神圣，而他们所憎恶的则是相反的，不虔诚。

苏格拉底：尤西弗罗，我们是否应该探究这件事的真实性，还是仅仅接受我们自己和他人的权威说法？你觉得呢？

尤西弗罗：我们应该进行调查；而且我相信这个说法经得起调查的考验。

苏格拉底：我的朋友，我们一会儿就会知道得更清楚了。我首先想了解的是，虔诚或神圣的东西是因为它神圣而受到诸神喜爱，还是因为它受到诸神的喜爱而成为神圣的。2

Euthyphro: Yes, I should say that what all the gods love is pious and holy, and the opposite which they all hate, impious.

Socrates: Ought we to enquire into the truth of this, Euthyphro, or simply to accept the mere statement on our own authority and that of others? What do you say?

Euthyphro: We should enquire; and I believe that the statement will stand the test of enquiry.

Socrates: We shall know better, my good friend, in a little while. The point which I should first wish to understand is whether the pious or holy is beloved by the gods because it is holy, or holy because it is beloved of the gods.2

苏格拉底提出这个反问，是为了稍后揭示出只有一个合理的答案：

Socrates asks this rhetorical question so that he can later reveal that there is only one reasonable answer to it:

苏格拉底：那么，尤西弗罗，你对于虔诚有什么看法？根据你的定义，虔诚不是为所有的神所喜爱吗？

尤西弗罗：是的。

苏格拉底：因为它虔诚、神圣，还是出于其他原因？

尤西弗罗：不，这就是原因。

苏格拉底：因为神圣所以被爱，还是不因被爱所以神圣？

尤西弗罗：是的。

苏格拉底：神所珍视的事物，神就喜爱它，并且因为神喜爱它，所以才处于被神喜爱的状态吗？

尤西弗罗：当然了。

苏格拉底：那么，尤西弗伦，神所珍视的东西并不神圣，神圣的东西也不为上帝所喜爱，正如你所言；它们是两件不同的事情。

尤西弗罗：苏格拉底，你的意思是什么？

苏格拉底：我的意思是，我们承认神圣之物是因为它神圣，所以才被上帝所爱，而不是因为它被爱，所以才神圣。3

Socrates: And what do you say of piety, Euthyphro: is not piety, according to your definition, loved by all the gods?

Euthyphro: Yes.

Socrates: Because it is pious or holy, or for some other reason?

Euthyphro: No, that is the reason.

Socrates: It is loved because it is holy, not holy because it is loved?

Euthyphro: Yes.

Socrates: And that which is dear to the gods is loved by them, and is in a state to be loved of them because it is loved of them?

Euthyphro: Certainly.

Socrates: Then that which is dear to the gods, Euthyphro, is not holy, nor is that which is holy loved of God, as you affirm; but they are two different things.

Euthyphro: How do you mean, Socrates?

Socrates: I mean to say that the holy has been acknowledged by us to be loved of God because it is holy, not to be holy because it is loved.3

苏格拉底因此向欧西弗罗表明，一个行为是善的，不仅仅是因为神希望它发生；事实上，恰恰相反，神希望它发生，因为它是善的。由此可见，善的定义与神无关。

Socrates thus shows Euthyphro that an act’s being good is not merely because the gods want it to happen; indeed, quite to the contrary, the gods want it to happen because it is good. It follows that what defines the good is independent of the gods.

英国哲学家西蒙·布莱克本（1944-）在他的著作《伦理学：非常简短的导论》4中这样描述尤西弗罗：

British philosopher Simon Blackburn (1944–), in his book Ethics: A Very Short Introduction4 writes the following about Euthyphro:

关键在于，上帝或众神不应被视为专断之人。他们必须被视为选择允许和禁止的正确事物。他们必须像我们一样，坚持神圣或公正。他们这样做，并不是因为他们强大，或创造了一切，或在他们的礼物中有可怕的惩罚和丰厚的奖励。这并不代表他们是好人。此外，仅仅因为他们的权力而服从他们的诫命，将是卑躬屈膝和自私自利的。例如，假设我想做坏事，比如背叛某人的信任。如果我想：“好吧，让我看看，收获是这样的，但现在我必须考虑到上帝可能会严厉打击我，如果我这样做，那就不够好了。另一方面，上帝是宽容的，我很有可能通过忏悔或临终忏悔来搪塞他……”这些都不是好人的想法。善良的人应该想：“那是一种背叛，所以我不会这么做。”故事就这样结束了。用当代道德哲学家伯纳德·威廉姆斯的一句名言来说，进行宗教成本效益分析就是“想多了”。

The point is that God, or the gods, are not to be thought of arbitrary. They have to be regarded as selecting the right things to allow and to forbid. They have to latch on to what is holy or just, exactly as we do. It is not given that they do this simply because they are powerful, or created everything, or have horrendous punishments and delicious rewards in their gifts. That doesn’t make them good. Furthermore, to obey their commandments just because of their power would be servile and self-interested. Suppose, for instance, I am minded to do something bad, such as to betray someone’s trust. It isn’t good enough if I think: “Well, let me see, the gains are such-and-such, but now I have to factor in the chance of God hitting me hard if I do it. On the other hand, God is forgiving and there is a good chance I can fob him off by confession, or by a deathbed repentance later . . .” These are not the thoughts of a good character. The good character is supposed to think: “It would be a betrayal, so I won’t do it.” That’s the end of the story. To go in for a religious cost-benefit analysis is, in a phrase made famous by the contemporary moral philosopher Bernard Williams, to have “one thought too many.”

因此，通过外部神来绕道而行似乎比无关紧要更糟糕。它似乎扭曲了行为标准的概念。

The detour through an external god, then, seems worse than irrelevant. It seems to distort the very idea of a standard of conduct.

如果仅仅因为上帝如此标记了某种行为，就认为它是善的，那就意味着这种行为在实施时没有内在的道德价值。这意味着上帝可以想出任何随机的道德原则，这些原则从今以后将永远定义什么是“善”，仅仅因为上帝制定了这些原则，并自始至终规定了这些原则。上帝是邪恶的。那么，如果上帝是邪恶的，他难道不能发明一套鼓励邪恶行为的道德标准吗？在这种情况下，被视为“善”或“道德”的东西仅仅是上帝任意妄为的结果，这与我们根深蒂固的直觉背道而驰。难道我们都不相信折磨无辜的人总是应该被视为道德上错误和邪恶的，即使某个至高无上的神命令我们这样做？

If an act is considered to be good merely because God has so labeled it, it would mean that the act, when carried out, had no intrinsic moral value. This would imply that God can dream up any random moral principles whatsoever, and these principles will henceforth eternally define what is called “good” simply because God laid them out and dictated them from on high. In that case, if God were evil, couldn’t he invent a set of moral standards that encouraged evil acts? Such a scenario, in which what is deemed “good” or “moral” is merely a function of God’s arbitrary whims, runs deeply against our ingrained intuitions. Don’t we all believe that torturing innocent people should always be considered morally wrong and evil, even if some god on high were to command us to carry it out?

宗教人士肯定会反对，说上帝绝不会命令人们做出残忍的行为。他们会说，上帝认为酷刑是错误的，因此他命令我们不要折磨他人。他们还会说，上帝认为幸福是美好的，因此他敦促我们让别人幸福。

Religious people would surely object that God would never command people to carry out cruel acts. They would say that God considers torture to be wrong, and that he therefore commands us not to torture others. They would also say that God considers happiness to be good, and that he therefore urges us to make others happy.

这听起来很不错，但不幸的是，它与道德原则源自上帝这一观点相矛盾。事实上，它假定存在上帝本人必须尊重的客观道德标准。因此，即使是虔诚的宗教观点最终也会承认道德与上帝无关。虔诚的道德观是，上帝希望我们以某种方式行事，正是因为这些方式在道德上是正确的；不需要额外的神圣认可。

This sounds very nice, but unfortunately it contradicts the idea that moral principles stem from God on high. In fact, it presumes that there are objective moral standards that God himself has to respect. And thus even a deeply religious view winds up recognizing that morality is independent of God. A deeply religious view of morality is that God wishes us to act in certain ways precisely because those ways are morally correct; there is no need for an added-on divine seal of approval.

对于那些不信仰任何神的人来说，这种推理毫无问题。但对于信仰神的人来说，这构成了一个非常重要的困境，因为它表明道德并不依赖于神，也不来自上天。无论神是否存在，道德都存在于这个世界上。

For those who don’t believe in any god, this reasoning is unproblematic. But for believers in God, it constitutes a very important dilemma because it shows that morality does not depend on God or come from on high. Morality exists in this world, whether God exists or not.

宙斯与湿婆之战

The Fight between Zeus and Shiva

让我们进一步探讨一下这个主题。假设上帝决定了什么是道德上的善。那么声称上帝是善的意味着什么？毕竟，如果善仅仅在于服从上帝的命令，那么说上帝的意志是善的就是同义反复的——它只不过是一个循环论证。它只是断言上帝的意志与上帝的意志一致，这是一个空洞的陈述。为了能够有意义地断言上帝是善的，人们需要对善的本质有一个独立的认识。

Let’s explore this theme a little further. Suppose it were the case that God dictates what is morally good. Then what would it mean to claim that God is good? After all, if goodness consists merely in obeying God’s orders, then stating that God’s will is good is tautologous—it’s nothing but a circular statement. It merely asserts that God’s will agrees with God’s will, which is a vacuous statement. To be able to assert meaningfully that God is good, one needs an independent sense of what goodness consists in.

为了说明道德善恶仅由神谕决定是多么荒谬，让我们想象一下两位神之间的竞争：宙斯和湿婆。5获胜者的奖品将是永恒的全能。湿婆希望赢得这一奖品，以便大大改善人类的命运。具体来说，他希望为世界带来永恒的和平、幸福和正义。宙斯也希望获胜，但他打算使用他的全能以一种完全不同的方式。他首先期待着残酷地杀害绝大多数人类，然后奴役所有剩余的人类，把他们关进一个巨大的集中营里，在无法忍受的条件下，他们将累死。

To illustrate how absurd it would be if moral goodness were determined merely by a divine edict, let us imagine a competition between two gods: Zeus and Shiva.5 The winner’s prize will be eternal omnipotence. Shiva hopes to win this prize in order to vastly improve the lot of human beings. Specifically, he wants to bring about eternal peace, happiness, and justice in the world. Zeus, too, hopes to win, but he intends to use his omnipotence in a totally different fashion. He looks forward, first of all, to brutally murdering the vast majority of humanity, and then enslaving all the remaining humans, putting them to work in a giant concentration camp where, under unbearable conditions, they will work themselves to death.

命运注定，宙斯赢得了比赛。人们自然会认为发生了最不可思议的事情：一个邪恶而可怕的神变得无所不能，现在要把世界带入一个无尽的难以想象的邪恶和苦难时代。
