As fate would have it, Zeus wins the competition. One would naturally be inclined to think that the most unthinkable of events has occurred: an evil and fearsome deity has become all powerful and is now going to throw the world into an endless era of inconceivable evil and suffering.

但尽管人们一开始可能会这样反应，却忽略了关键点。宙斯利用他新获得的全能权力的第一个方式是改变道德原则的定义——也就是改变“善”的定义。他把对无辜人民的暴力屠杀变成了一种具有伟大道德价值和善的行为，他把对无辜人民的随机痛苦变成了公平和正义的缩影。他让被锁链束缚的奴隶成为人们可以追求的最有道德的生活。最后但并非最不重要的是，他将自己转变为一个道德完美的人——不是通过改变自己的行为，而是通过改变道德的本质。因此，他所创造的充满酷刑、奴役和大屠杀的世界，从定义上讲，在道德上值得称赞和令人向往。

But although this is how one might first react, it misses the key point. The first way that Zeus uses his newly won omnipotence is to change the definition of moral principles—that is, to change the definition of what is considered “good.” He turns the violent massacre of innocent people into an act of great moral worth and goodness, and he makes the inflicting of random suffering on innocent people epitomize fairness and justice. He makes being a slave in chains become the most virtuous life to which one can aspire. And last but not least, he converts himself into a morally perfect being—not by altering his own behavior, but by altering the very nature of morality. The world of torture, slavery, and mass murder that he has created thus becomes, by definition, morally laudable and highly desirable.

好吧，这个故事只有一个问题：它听起来完全是疯了。如果上帝是道德的唯一可能来源——也就是说，如果上帝是善良的化身——那么在一个没有上帝的宇宙中，从定义上讲，既没有善也没有恶。这意味着，一个没有上帝的宇宙中不可能存在任何负面或令人不快的东西，因为在这个宇宙中，既不存在道德上好的东西，也不存在道德上坏的东西。因此，说“没有上帝，宇宙中就没有道德；这样的宇宙是多么不道德！”是矛盾的。如果道德真理或标准不存在，那么也不可能存在任何不道德的东西。

Well, there is just one problem with this story: it sounds totally crazy. If God is the sole possible source of morality—that is, if God is the embodiment of goodness—then in a universe with no god, there would by definition be neither good nor evil. And this means that there couldn’t be anything negative or unpleasant about a godless universe, since in it, neither morally good things nor morally bad things would exist. It is thus a contradiction to state, “Without God, there would be no morality in the universe; how immoral such a universe would be!” If moral truths or standards don’t exist, then there can’t be anything immoral either.

如果上帝是道德的唯一源泉，那么无神的宇宙更应该被称为无道德宇宙，因为这样的宇宙缺乏道德。但“无道德”并不意味着“道德”或“不道德”。鱼既不是道德的也不是不道德的；鱼只是无道德的。

If God is the sole source of morality, then a godless universe should more aptly be called an amoral universe, in the sense that in such a universe there would be a lack of morality. But “amoral” doesn’t mean either “moral” or “immoral.” A fish is neither moral nor immoral; a fish is simply amoral.

当然，所有这些都只是哲学游戏，因为我们都很清楚，这个世界上确实存在着幸福和痛苦。我们只能得出一个结论——上帝不可能是道德原则的源泉。当然，人们很容易想象，上帝可以帮助人们理解和遵循道德原则，而不必成为这些原则的源泉。

All of this is of course merely philosophical game-playing, though, since we all know perfectly well that both happiness and suffering do exist in this world. We are left with only one conclusion to draw—namely, that a god cannot be the source of moral principles. To be sure, one can easily imagine that a god could help people understand and follow moral principles without being the source of those principles.

那么，关键问题实际上是：人们能否在没有任何神灵帮助的情况下找到并理解道德原则？正如我们将看到的，有很多证据表明他们可以做到。但首先让我们看看如果我们都按照我们所相信的上帝的意志行事，情况会怎样。

The key question, then, is actually the following: Could people ever find and understand moral principles without any help from any sort of god? As we will see, there is much evidence that they can. But first let us look at how things would be if we all actually acted on the basis of what we believe is God’s will.

夏娃总是对的

Eve Is Always Right

所有人的内心深处都拥有相同的道德价值观吗？只要环顾四周，你就会发现答案，答案显然是“不”。每天，许多人因为没有“正确”地看待上帝的道德真理而死亡。每天，出于“道德”原因，妇女受到压迫，宗教或少数民族受到歧视，无神论者受到迫害，同性恋者被杀害或投入监狱，人们因为无法获得“不神圣的”避孕方法而传播和感染艾滋病。人们以上帝的名义对待彼此的可恶方式可谓多得令人发指。

Do all people deep down share the same moral values? Just take a look around you and you will find the answer, and it is clearly “no.” Every day, many people die for the simple reason that they don’t happen to have the “right” views of God’s moral truths. Every day, for “moral” reasons, women are oppressed, religious or ethnic minorities are discriminated against, atheists are persecuted, homosexuals are murdered or thrown in jail, people spread and contract AIDS because they have been denied access to “unholy” birth control methods. The list is dismally long of abhorrent ways in which people treat each other—in God’s name.

但让我们来思考一下，遵守上帝的道德准则究竟意味着什么。为了简单起见，我们假设确实存在一位上帝，他从高处赐予我们一套道德准则。那么，遵守这些准则是道德的吗？或者，遵守这些神圣准则的人可能是不道德的？

But let us turn to the question of what it would truly mean to follow God’s moral code. Let’s assume, for simplicity, that there really exists a god who, from on high, has handed us a set of moral rules. Is it moral, then, to follow them? Or might it be that someone who follows these divinely given rules is acting amorally?

假设我有一个好朋友叫夏娃。夏娃有点不寻常，她声称自己所做的一切都是正确的。她真诚地相信她所有的观点、看法和价值观都是正确的，她毫不犹豫地告诉她遇到的每个人这是正确的。但这还不是全部；我自己完全接受夏娃的观点、看法和价值观总是正确的这一观点。总之，我相信夏娃。

Suppose that I have a good friend called Eve. Eve is a bit unusual, in that she claims that she is always right in everything she does. She sincerely believes that all her opinions, views, and values are inevitably correct, and she doesn’t hesitate to tell everyone she encounters that this is so. But that’s not all; I myself fully accept the idea that Eve’s opinions, views, and values are always right on the mark. In a word, I believe in Eve.

有一天，我的另一个朋友，当然叫亚当，向我询问了一些关于道德的问题。例如，他问我对同性恋权利和妇女权利的看法。当我回答说我主张人人平等，因此我认为不应该歧视妇女或同性恋者时，亚当问我为什么持有这种信念。我告诉他我持有这些观点是因为我的朋友夏娃持有这些观点，而且夏娃对每件事的看法总是正确的。亚当然后有点怀疑地说：“但你怎么知道你的朋友夏娃总是对的？”我坦率地回答说：“因为我非常具体地问过她，她亲自告诉我她总是对的。我记得这次谈话就像就在昨天。我从来没有忘记过。它深深地刻在我的记忆里。夏娃永远是对的。我相信夏娃。”

One day, another friend of mine, of course named Adam, asks me for my opinion about a number of questions about morality. For instance, he asks me what my view is of homosexuals’ rights and of women’s rights. When I reply that I advocate equality for all people, and therefore I believe that there should be no discrimination against women or homosexuals, Adam asks me why I hold this belief. I tell him I hold these opinions because my friend Eve holds them, and because Eve is always right about everything. Adam then says, a little suspiciously, “But how do you know your friend Eve is always right?” I candidly reply, “Because I asked her very specifically, and she personally told me that she’s always right. I remember the conversation like it was only yesterday. I’ve never forgotten it. It’s burned into my memory. Eve is always right. I believe in Eve.”

尽管我的解释很真诚，但亚当认为这种回答不够充分。即使我的道德信仰的所有后果都是好的，我仍然应该有更客观、更合理的理由来坚持这些信仰，而不仅仅是我的某个朋​​友把它们灌输给我。亚当建议我，我应该能够将我的观点建立在更坚实、更普遍的东西上，而不仅仅是循环论证。例如，我可以将夏娃的命令与似乎源于人类价值和人类尊严的基本观念的道德原则进行比较。他说，只有我自己首先思考并选择某些基本的道德原则（它们很可能最终与夏娃的道德原则相一致），我才能合理地认为自己是一个有道德的人。

Despite the sincerity of my explanation, Adam feels that this is an inadequate response. Even if all the consequences of my moral beliefs turn out to be good, I should still have a more objective and more plausible reason for holding these beliefs than just that some friend of mine spoon-fed them to me. Adam suggests to me that I should be able to ground my views in something more solid and universal, not just in circular reasoning. I might, for example, compare Eve’s dictates with moral principles that seem to flow from basic ideas about human worth and human decency. He says that only if I myself first think about and select certain basic moral principles (and they may well wind up coinciding with Eve’s moral principles) can I reasonably consider myself to be a moral person.

我同意亚当的假设。我认为道德主体应该通过一系列持续的道德检查和测试来建立一套道德规范。如果我选​​择以某种方式行事，仅仅是因为我的朋友夏娃告诉我这样做，那么我的行为就是不道德的。这种生活方式能被称为选择吗？如果我不愿意或无法测试支配我行为的行为准则，那么我就不是一个自主的生物，我根本没有真正的道德。总之，我是不道德的。

I agree with the hypothetical Adam. I feel that a moral agent should build up a set of morals through an ongoing series of moral checks and tests. If I choose to act in a certain way simply because my friend Eve told me to, I am acting amorally. Can this way of running my life even be called a choice? If I am unwilling or unable to test the rules of conduct that govern my behavior, then I am not an autonomous creature, and I have no genuine morality at all. In a word, I am amoral.

盲目地遵循他人的道德准则，而不进行自我反思和沉思，是一种智力上的屈服。一个人卑躬屈膝地屈服于别人假定的优越智慧，几乎就像自己只是一个被编程的机器人一样。这是一种盲目的行为方式。

Slavishly following another person’s moral dictates without engaging in one’s own reflections and ruminations is a type of intellectual surrender. One is obsequiously bowing to someone else’s presumed superior wisdom, almost as if one were merely a programmed robot. This is a mindless way to act.

同样，像机器人一样不断引用上帝的规则，引用所谓的神圣文本作为自己所有道德观的基础，也是愚蠢的。即使有人相信上帝直接对他们说话，告诉他们什么是道德上正确的，这个人仍然应该仔细考虑上帝从高处对他们的指示是否与他们本能地认为对待他人的正确方式相一致。真正的道德不是机器人式的。

And by exactly the same token, it is mindless to constantly quote God’s rules like a robot and cite supposedly sacred texts as the basis for all of one’s moral views. Even if someone believes that God has spoken directly to them and has told them what is morally correct, it still behooves that person to carefully consider whether what God dictated to them from on high agrees with what they instinctively feel is the right way to treat other people. Genuine morality is not robotic.

世俗的邪恶观和道德观

A Secular View of Evil and Morality

那么，世俗的思维方式如何看待我们这个世界上存在邪恶呢？首先，如果没有神存在，那么就不会出现神义论的棘手问题。人们只需对自己的行为负责。只有人类 人类可以为自己的道德行为和行为方式制定一套标准，以改善他人的生活。

What, then, is a secular way of thinking about the existence of evil in our world? First of all, if no god exists, then the knotty problem of theodicy does not arise. People are simply responsible for their own behavior. Only human beings can create a set of standards for their own moral behavior and ways of behaving that will improve the lives of others.

此外，严谨的推理和科学知识的不断发展有助于世界上善良的繁荣。借助医学研究，我们可以治愈越来越多的疾病。利用新形式的技术和精密工程，我们可以设计和建造更能抵御地震和其他自然灾害的建筑物。我们这个世界不可避免的“自然之恶”至少可以通过科学技术来减少。

Moreover, careful reasoning and the constant growth of scientific knowledge can contribute to the flourishing of goodness in the world. With the help of medical research, we can cure more and more diseases. Using new forms of technology and precise engineering, we can design and construct buildings that are more able to withstand earthquakes and other natural disasters. The “natural evil” that is inevitable in our world can at least be reduced through science and technology.

但是道德上的邪恶——人类造成的无数苦难——又该如何呢？我们似乎不可能完全消除它。人们总是会发怒，不友善的行为也永远是人类生活的一部分。尽管如此，通过不断发展民主、平等、教育和尊重人权，我们可以逐步减少世界上的道德邪恶。在当今日益全球化的环境中，许多合作组织纷纷成立，以对抗压迫、饥饿和贫困。当今的国际政治涉及的单方面决策越来越少，而通过双方协议做出的决策越来越多。所有这些都是明显的进步，但当然，所有这些好事可以进展得更快，我们应该做得更多。

But what about moral evil—the myriad sufferings caused by human beings? It seems unlikely that we can totally obliterate that. People will always be subject to fits of anger, and unkind acts will always be part of human life. Nonetheless, through the constant development of democracy, equality, education, and respect for human rights, we can step by step reduce the amount of moral evil in our world. In today’s increasingly globalized climate, numerous cooperative organizations have sprung up to combat oppression, starvation, and poverty. International politics today involves fewer decisions made unilaterally and more decisions made through mutual agreements. All this is clear progress, but of course all these good things could go considerably faster, and we should be doing still more.

如果人类开始认识到自己对自己所塑造的世界负有责任，如果人们认识到并不存在可以寻求指导的超自然存在，那么世俗道德将能够帮助世界朝着积极的方向发展。

If and when humanity comes to see itself as responsible for the world that it is shaping, if and when people realize that there is no supernatural being to turn to for guidance, then secular morality will be able to help the world move in positive directions.

“问题仅仅在于人类误解了宗教”

“The Problem Is Merely That Humans Misinterpret Religion”

在讨论宗教压迫和其他以宗教名义进行的邪恶行为时，我常常听到这样的话：“所有这些坏事都不是宗教本身的错，只是某些人误解了宗教的信息。”

In discussions of religious oppression and other evil acts perpetrated in the name of religion, I have often been told, “All that bad stuff is not the fault of religion itself—it’s just that certain people misinterpret the message of religion.”

这是一个了不起的论点——不是因为它是错误的，而是因为它是显而易见的事实。事实上，宗教不过是人类的观点而已。它还能是什么呢？如果一个人是原教旨主义者，他当然可以声称圣经是上帝口授的，并且包含绝对真理——在这种情况下，这个论点可能是有效的。但令人惊讶的是，许多自由派和温和派的上帝信徒提出这个论点来捍卫他们的宗教，反对宗教对坏事负有责任的指控。

This is a remarkable argument—not because it is false, but because it is trivially true. Religion is, in fact, nothing but human opinions. What else could it be? If one is a fundamentalist, one can of course claim that the holy scriptures were dictated by God and that they consist of absolute truths—and in that case, the argument might be valid. But quite surprisingly, many liberal and moderate believers in God bring this argument forth to defend their religion against accusations that it is in any way responsible for bad things.

另一种常见的为宗教的内在善性辩护是列出有宗教信仰的好人名单。马丁·路德·金（1929-1968）、特蕾莎修女（1910-1997）和德斯蒙德·图图（1931-）等人经常出现在这样的名单中。美国牧师和民权领袖马丁·路德·金一生提倡非暴力，反对种族隔离。为此，他于 1964 年获得诺贝尔和平奖。同样为此，他在 1968 年被暗杀。特蕾莎修女，本名 Ajnezë Gonxha Bojaxhiu，是一名罗马天主教修女，出生于当时的土耳其阿尔巴尼亚，即现在的马其顿。她一生大部分时间在印度生活，并于 1979 年获得诺贝尔和平奖。德斯蒙德·图图是一位南非牧师和教会领袖，因反对种族隔离而闻名。他于 1984 年获得诺贝尔和平奖。

Another common defense of religion’s intrinsic goodness is to make a list of good people who were religious. Such people as Martin Luther King Jr. (1929–1968), Mother Teresa (1910–1997), and Desmond Tutu (1931–) often show up in such lists. Martin Luther King Jr., the American minister and civil rights leader, advocated nonviolence and fought segregation for his entire life. For this, he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964. Also for this, he was assassinated in 1968. Mother Teresa, actually named Ajnezë Gonxha Bojaxhiu, was a Roman Catholic nun, born in what was at the time Turkish Albania, now Macedonia. She lived most of her life in India and garnered the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979. Desmond Tutu is a South African priest and church leader who became famous for his struggle against apart-heid. He received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984.

许多基督徒说：“德斯蒙德图图很优秀，因为他非常虔诚。”好吧，图图是一位令人钦佩的人，他长期为南非的种族隔离制度而战，毫无疑问应该受到称赞。但图图并不是在长期的种族隔离斗争中采取行动的唯一基督教力量。以荷兰归正会（南非新教的主要分支）为例，该教会强烈捍卫该国的种族隔离法，甚至引用了《圣经》中的论据。这个教会坚持认为南非应该禁止跨种族婚姻。这个教会将种族隔离视为神圣，其观点以《圣经》为基础。基督徒在声称宗教信仰带来道德时，故意从不提及这一点。它只是被掩盖了。

Many Christian people say, “Desmond Tutu was good because he was deeply religious.” Well, Tutu is an admirable human being, and he deserves without question to be hailed for his long-term fight against apartheid in South Africa. But Tutu was not the only Christian force acting in the long battles over apartheid. Consider the Dutch Reformed Church—the dominant branch of Protestantism in South Africa—which strongly defended the country’s apartheid laws, even using arguments taken from the Bible. This was the church that insisted that South Africa should forbid mixed-race marriages. This was the church that saw apartheid as sacred, basing its views on the Christian Bible. Christians conveniently don’t ever mention this when claiming that religiosity brings about morality. It’s just swept under the rug.

正如这些对比鲜明的例子所表明的那样，很多时候，当宗教人士做出高尚的行为时，人们会把很多功劳归于宗教，但当宗教人士做出可怕的行为时，人们却声称这不是宗教的错，而只是人类误解的不幸结果。6似乎很难否认存在双重标准——一种选择性的历史书写——当宗教人士谈论基督教如何影响种族隔离时，他们只提到德斯蒙德·图图，即硬币的正面，而忽视了硬币的另一面，即图图的邪恶，而图图的善良。

As these contrasting examples show, very often, when religious people do magnanimous acts, plenty of credit is dished out to religion, but when religious people carry out horrid acts, it’s claimed not to be religion’s fault but merely the unfortunate result of human misinterpretations.6 It seems hard to deny that there is a double standard going on—a kind of selective history-writing—when religious people, in talking about how Christianity impacted apartheid, cite only Desmond Tutu, the favorable side of the coin, and neglect the other side, which was just as evil as Tutu was good.

人们确实需要下定决心。宗教要么是善与恶的驱动力，要么两者都不是。

One really has to make up one’s mind. Either religion is a driving force for both good and evil, or it is a driving force for neither.

道德的自然根源

The Natural Roots of Morality

如果没有神来创造道德行为的原则，那么道德是否完全是主观的、可以随意决定的？在一个没有神的世界里，为什么让另一个人受苦，或者把一只豚鼠折磨致死，难道这是不道德的吗？如果没有上天的指引，道德原则还能存在吗？

If there is no god who created the principles of moral behavior, is morality then completely subjective and up for grabs? In a godless world, why would it be immoral to make another human suffer, or to torment a guinea pig to death? Can there be any moral principles at all if they are not handed down to us from on high?

以世俗方式思考道德的起点是以下三个简单的公理：

A starting point for thinking in a secular way about morality is the following simple trio of axioms:

  1. 快乐优于不幸。
  2. Happiness is preferable to unhappiness.
  3. 自由优于囚禁。
  4. Freedom is preferable to captivity.
  5. 不受苦总比受苦好。
  6. Not suffering is preferable to suffering.

从这个看似原始的起点出发，我们可以得出许多更进一步、更具体的道德规范。这些规范在人类历史的许多转折点中得到了清晰的阐述，例如法国大革命，其令人难忘的口号是自由、平等、博爱，以及更早的美国革命，其著名口号是“生存权、自由权和追求幸福的权利”。

From this primitive-seeming starting point, we can derive many further and more specific moral norms. Such norms have been clearly articulated in numerous turning points of human history, such as the French Revolution, marked by its memorable watchwords liberté, égalité, fraternité, and the earlier American Revolution, marked by its famous phrase “the right to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.”

进化心理学的研究清楚地表明，其他动物，如黑猩猩，也具有道德行为的能力。7因此，道德并不是人类独有的特征。

Research in evolutionary psychology has clearly shown that other animals, such as chimpanzees, have the ability to act morally.7 And thus morality is not an exclusively human trait.

但道德是怎么凭空而来的呢？

But how did morality come out of nowhere?

研究表明，道德行为的起源在于进化。如果生物受道德原则的指导，对群体中的其他成员表现出无私或利他的行为，那么群体生存的机会就会增加。

Research has demonstrated that the origins of moral behavior lie in evolution. If living beings are guided by moral principles and act unselfishly or altruistically toward other members of their group, the chances for the group’s survival go up.

某些其他动物物种，尤其是猿类，也具有基本的道德，但即使是吸血蝙蝠也表现出有限的道德。（我在这里指的是动物物种，而不是恐怖故事中的吸血鬼，它们当然不是特别有道德的生物。）如果它们在某些情况下表现出利他行为，它们长期生存的机会就会增加。吸血蝙蝠在夜间寻找食物，吸食牛和其他哺乳动物的血液。由于它们的新陈代谢率很高，所以它们必须每晚都寻找食物，但并不是所有的吸血蝙蝠每晚都能找到食物。因此，成功的吸血蝙蝠会与不太成功的同类分享食物，而后者在随后的夜晚会回报它们。

A rudimentary form of morality can be found in certain other animal species, especially apes, but even vampire bats exhibit a limited sort of morality. (I am referring here to the animal species, not to the vampires featured in horror stories, which of course are not particularly moral creatures.) If they behave altruistically in certain types of situations, their chances for long-term survival will be enhanced. Vampire bats hunt for food during the night, sucking blood from cows and other mammals. Because they have a high metabolic rate, they have to seek food every single night, but not all of them find food every night. Successful vampire bats therefore share their food with their less successful conspecifics, and the latter, on subsequent nights, will return the favor.

某些动物在发现掠食者接近其群体时，也会用各种声音相互警告。尽管它们会通过发出警告声来吸引掠食者的注意，从而增加它们被猎杀的机会，但它们还是会这样做。被捕获并吃掉。似乎可以合理地假设这些动物没有宗教信仰，由此可以推断，利他行为（例如警告他人自危）源于生物学，而不是上帝赐予的神圣文本。

It also happens that certain kinds of animals warn one another, using various sounds, when they spy a predator approaching their flock. They do this even though, by making the warning sounds, they will draw the predator’s attention to themselves and thus will increase their own chances of being caught and eaten. It seems quite reasonable to assume that such animals are not religious, and from this it would follow that altruistic behavior, such as warning others at one’s own peril, has its origin in biology, rather than in sacred texts handed from Providence.

人类和所有其他动物一样，必须不断奋斗才能生存，而合作已被证明是这一斗争中非常有效的策略。人类在发展初期似乎意识到，如果他们团结起来，和平共处，并肩工作，他们就能承担并完成大型项目。如果他们合作，他们还可以保护彼此免受威胁。部落中无私的成员比自私的成员寿命更长。

The human race, like all other animal species, must continually struggle to survive, and cooperation has shown itself to be a very effective strategy in this struggle. It seems likely that humans, in an early stage of their development, realized that they could undertake and accomplish large projects if they banded together and worked peacefully, side by side. They could also protect one another from threats if they cooperated. Unselfish members of a tribe lived longer than selfish ones.

因此，由于自然选择，合作的倾向被纳入人类的生存策略中，也就是人类基因组中。基因的主要功能之一是将我们的特征传递给下一代。尽管基因本身总是“自私地”行事，但正是由于这种特性，我们这些携带自私基因的人类在某些情况下可以采取自我牺牲的方式。例如，我们会为了拯救我们的孩子而牺牲自己的生命，因为我们被“编程”来传播我们自己的基因，而我们的孩子也与我们共享基因。从严格的进化角度来看，个体基因的生存比个体的生存更重要。

Thanks to natural selection, then, the tendency to cooperate became incorporated in the human strategy for survival—that is, in the human genome. One of the main functions of genes is to propagate our set of traits to the next generation. Although genes themselves always act “selfishly,” we humans who carry selfish genes can, thanks to that very property, act in self-sacrificial ways in certain situations. For instance, we will lay down our lives in order to save our children, because we are “programmed” to propagate our own genes, and our children share our genes. From a strictly evolutionary perspective, the survival of an individual’s genes is more important than the survival of the individual.

研究道德原则起源的研究人员经常谈到互惠利他主义。例如，以下观点：“如果我的群体成功击倒一头猛犸象，那么我们将拥有比所需更多的肉。但我们通常不会有这么好的运气。如果我们这次与邻近的群体分享食物，那么下次他们击倒猛犸象时，我们从他们那里获得一点食物的机会就会增加。”一般原则可以表述如下：“如果我现在帮助你，那么希望你下次也能帮助我。”这种利他主义经常出现在动物界，尤其是在我们最近的亲戚黑猩猩中。

Researchers who investigate the origins of moral principles often speak of reciprocal altruism. An example of this is the following idea: “If my group succeeds in bringing down a mammoth, then we will have more meat than we need. But we don’t often have such good luck. If we share our food this time with the neighboring group, then we’ll increase our chances of getting a little food from them the next time they bring down a mammoth.” The general principle can be formulated as follows: “If I help you now, then hopefully you’ll help me on another occasion.” This type of altruism arises often in the animal realm, and most of all among our nearest relations, the chimpanzees.

怀疑论者可能会说，如果利他主义是根植于我们基因中的，那么它几乎就像是“上天”传下来的（自然选择在其中扮演着摩西石板的角色）。如果是这样的话，那么当我们对他人仁慈和慷慨时，我们并不是在遵循我们的自由意志；我们实际上只是机械地行事，因为我们被编程（通过进化）以那种仁慈和慷慨的方式行事。圣经或古兰经不是我们的圣书，而是我们的 DNA。在这种情况下，也许我们人类毕竟不是那么高尚……

A skeptic could argue that if altruism is built into our genes, then it is almost as if altruism had been handed down from “on high” (where natural selection plays the role of Moses’s tablets). If that’s the case, then when we are kind and generous to others, we aren’t following our free will; we are actually just behaving mechanically, because we were programmed (by evolution) to behave in that type of kind and generous manner. Instead of the Bible or the Koran being our holy scripture, it’s our DNA. In which case, maybe we humans aren’t so noble after all . . .

同情与认同

Empathy and Identification

但是，人类世界中还有另一种截然不同的利他主义、慷慨和同情心产生的方式，这种现象直接来自我们的智慧。道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特 (Douglas Hofstadter) 在其 2007 年出版的《我是一个奇怪的循环》一书中，有一章名为“我们如何生活在彼此之中” ，其中描述了当大脑（或思维）的表征足够丰富，能够深刻地反映其他大脑（或思维）时达到的阈值。大多数成年人类（反社会人格者除外）的思维都已跨越这一阈值，这赋予了他们一种霍夫施塔特称之为“表征普遍性”的属性，他对此写道：

But there is another and very different way that altruism, generosity, and compassion arise in the human world, and that phenomenon comes directly from our intelligence. Douglas Hofstadter, in a chapter called “How We Live in Each Other” in his 2007 book I Am a Strange Loop, describes a threshold that is reached when a brain (or mind) becomes representationally rich enough to be able to mirror other brains (or minds) in a deep way. The minds of most adult humans (aside from sociopaths) have crossed that threshold, which gives them a property that Hofstadter calls “representational universality,” and about it he writes the following:

一旦超越了魔法的门槛，宇宙生物似乎不可避免地会变得贪婪地渴望体验其他宇宙生物的内心世界。这就是为什么我们有电影、肥皂剧、电视新闻、博客、网络摄像头、八卦专栏作家、《人物》杂志和《世界新闻周刊》等。人们渴望进入别人的头脑，从别人的头骨里“看外面”，吞噬别人的经历。

尽管我一直有些愤世嫉俗地描述它，但代表性的普遍性和它所创造的对间接体验的几乎永不满足的渴望与同情心相差无几，而同情心在我看来是人类最令人钦佩的品质。深刻地“成为”别人不仅仅是从理智上以他们的角度看待世界，并扎根于他们成长过程中塑造他们的地方和时代；它的意义远不止于此。它意味着接受他们的价值观，承担他们的愿望，实现他们的希望，感受他们的渴望，分享他们的梦想，为他们的恐惧而战栗，参与他们的生活，融入他们的灵魂。8

Once beyond the magic threshold, universal beings seem inevitably to become ravenously thirsty for tastes of the interiority of other universal beings. This is why we have movies, soap operas, television news, blogs, webcams, gossip columnists, People magazine, and The Weekly World News, among others. People yearn to get inside other people’s heads, to “see out” from inside other crania, to gobble up other people’s experiences.

Although I have been depicting it somewhat cynically, representational universality and the nearly insatiable hunger that it creates for vicarious experiences is but a stone’s throw away from empathy, which I see as the most admirable quality of humanity. To “be” someone else in a profound way is not merely to see the world intellectually as they see it and to feel rooted in the places and times that molded them as they grew up; it goes much further than that. It is to adopt their values, to take on their desires, to live their hopes, to feel their yearnings, to share their dreams, to shudder at their dreads, to participate in their life, to merge with their soul.8

这种自发的同情心——向处境艰难的人伸出援手——在几乎所有人的生活中都随处可见。这些行为都源于将自己与另一个有知觉的生物联系起来的能力——事实上，这是一种不可抗拒的倾向。一些相当随机但典型的例子包括，当发现一只蜜蜂在自己家里嗡嗡叫时，不去拍打它，而是小心地抓住它并把它带到户外；捡起一只走失的狗，读出它的名牌，并拨打上面的电话号码；追赶掉钱包的人，确保他们找回钱包（而不是自私地把钱包占为己有）；或者更平凡的例子，当使用飞机上的厕所时，小心地清理一个令人厌恶的脏厕所，或者在退房时给一个从未见过的女服务员留下一大笔小费。

Examples of this kind of spontaneous empathy—of reaching out to others who are in tough plights—are rife in the lives of nearly all humans. Such acts are all rooted in the ability—in fact, the irresistible inclination—to map oneself onto another sentient being. Some fairly random but typical examples include not swatting a bee that one finds buzzing about in one’s house, but carefully catching it and escorting it outdoors; picking up a lost dog, reading its nametag, and phoning the number on it; running after someone who has dropped their wallet and making sure that they get it back (rather than selfishly keeping its contents for oneself); or more mundanely, carefully cleaning up a repulsively soiled toilet that one finds when using an airplane lavatory, or simply leaving a big tip for a never-seen maid when one checks out of a hotel.

在所有这些情况下，人们都不抱有丝毫希望这种善举日后会得到回报；人们想要这样做的愿望仅仅来自于对那只不幸的蜜蜂的认同；或者对那条走失的狗的认同，或者对它疯狂的主人的认同；或者对不知情的钱包掉落者的认同，他很可能会在之后的某个时候发现钱包不见了而惊慌失措；或者对未来匿名的厕所使用者的认同，人们可以想象他会本能地对肮脏感到厌恶；或者对看不见的女仆的认同，她会感激能多一点零花钱。

In none of these cases is there the slightest hope that the kind act will be reciprocated later; the desire to perform the act comes simply from identifying with the unlucky bee; or with the lost dog, or with its frantic owner; or with the unsuspecting wallet-dropper, who might well be panicked upon finding that it was missing at some later point; or with the anonymous future lavatory user, who one imagines would be viscerally repelled by the filthiness; or with the unseen maid, who will appreciate having a little extra spending money.

所有这些在别人身上表现出的脆弱、恐惧、震惊或需要都是一个人在生命早期经历过的负面体验，因此他会想，“我当然不希望这种事情发生在我身上！”这正是与另一个生物认同的含义。或者换句话说，所有这些一个人可以选择给予另一个人的关心、快乐或宽慰都是一个人在生命早期接受过的积极体验，因此他会想，“如果这种事情发生在我身上，我会多么感激！”

All these types of vulnerability or fear or shock or neediness in someone else are negative experiences that one has been through oneself at earlier points in one’s life, and one thinks to oneself, “I certainly wouldn’t want that to happen to me!” This is exactly what identification with another creature means. Or to put it another way, all these types of caring or joy or relief that one can choose to give to another being are positive experiences that one has been the recipient of oneself earlier in life, and so one thinks to oneself, “How much I’d appreciate it if that were to happen to me!”

再次强调，将自己投射到他人的生活（反之亦然）是认同的意义，而与他人的认同是人类本性的深层方面，它会产生同理心。这与基因编程的利他主义无关，甚至与上层传承下来的“神圣”道德准则更无关。

Once again, this projecting of oneself into another’s life (or vice versa) is the meaning of identification, and identification with others is the deep facet of our human nature that gives rise to empathy. It has nothing to do with having been genetically programmed to be altruistic—and even less to do with “sacred” moral codes that have been handed down from on high.

以上所有内容清楚地表明，人类（以及动物）可以是善良的、富有同情心的和有道德的，而不需要神来指示他们以某种方式行事。

All of the foregoing shows clearly that people (as well as animals) can be good, compassionate, and moral, without any need for a divine being by whom they have been instructed to act in certain ways.

插曲：关于犯罪、惩罚和责任

INTERLUDE: ON CRIME, PUNISHMENT, AND RESPONSIBILITY

一个人何时需要对自己的行为负责？答案是：永远。但事情真的这么简单吗？

When is one responsible for one’s actions? The tempting answer is: always. But are things actually that simple?

道德责任的理念假定我们有自由意志，或者更准确地说，我们有可能选择要采取什么行动。如果我们所做的一切都是预先确定的，那么我们就永远无法做出选择，因此，我们就不能对自己的行为负责。因此，让我们假设人类可以做出选择。只要我们没有受到被枪击或折磨的威胁，每当我们选择如何行动时，我们都要对发生的事情负有道德责任。但有没有例外这条规则是否合理？我曾经读过一个法律案例，它让我对此深思熟虑，并让我怀疑事情是否真的像人们的第一本能反应所暗示的那样简单。

The idea of moral responsibility presumes that we have free will or, more precisely, that we have the possibility to choose what actions we will take. If everything that we did were predetermined, then we could never make choices, and as a result, we could not be held responsible for our behavior. Let us thus presume that humans can make choices. As long as we are not under threat of being shot or tortured, whenever we make a choice of how to act, we are morally responsible for what happens. But are there exceptions to this rule? I once read of a legal case that made me think long and hard about this, leading me to wonder if things are actually as simple as one’s first instinctive reaction would suggest.

一位性格温和的木匠，正和未婚妻坐在公园的长椅上。他从未犯过任何罪行，也从未表现出任何暴力倾向。然而，突然间，毫无征兆地，他开始语无伦次地说话，站起来，走到未婚妻背后，从工作服口袋里掏出一把刀，刺死了她。

A mild-mannered man—a carpenter by trade—was sitting on a bench in a park with his fiancée. He had never committed any crime and had never exhibited any tendencies toward violence. And yet suddenly, without any warning, he began to speak in a disjointed fashion, stood up, went behind his fiancée’s back, pulled out a knife that was in a pocket of his work clothes, and stabbed her.

女子设法逃脱并报警。她的未婚夫被抓获，并接受了一系列精神和神经学检查，在检查过程中，他被检测出患有高度恶性的脑瘤。肿瘤被证实可以手术切除，成功切除后，男子恢复了温和的性格，不再表现出暴力倾向。医生说，几乎可以肯定肿瘤是导致他行为异常的原因。那么，该男子是否应该因肿瘤引发的罪行而入狱呢？

The woman somehow managed to escape and notified the police. Her fiancé was captured and underwent a series of psychiatric and neurological tests, in the course of which a highly aggressive brain tumor was detected. The tumor turned out to be operable, and after it had been successfully removed, the man regained his gentle personality and showed no further violent tendencies. According to the doctors, it was almost certain that the tumor had caused his aberrant behavior. And so, should the man be imprisoned for his tumor-induced crime?

事情可能比这复杂得多。不久前，人们发现了一种名为“mao-A”的基因，这种基因负责产生一种蛋白质，这种蛋白质可以调节大脑前部化学物质血清素的吸收率。一小部分人患有布伦纳综合征，这是 mao-A 基因的一种突变，导致血清素和相关化学物质大量过量产生。因此，这些人缺乏控制冲动的能力，他们对周围的人或动物表现出破坏性、攻击性和暴力行为。他们还经常伤害自己。这样的人非常危险。

Things can get considerably more complicated than that. Not long ago, a gene called “mao-A” was discovered, which is responsible for the production of a protein that regulates the rate of uptake of the chemical serotonin in the front part of the brain. A tiny percentage of people suffer from Brunner’s syndrome, which is a certain type of mutation in the mao-A gene that results in a vast overproduction of serotonin and related chemicals. As a result, such people lack the ability to control their impulses, and they act destructively, aggressively, and violently toward people or animals in their vicinity. They also frequently injure themselves. Such people are extremely dangerous.

患有布伦纳氏综合症的人应该在多大程度上为自己的行为承担道德责任？由于他们不能被称为精神病患者，因此可以把他们送上法庭接受审判。然而，由于当今对大脑的科学理解，人们可以肯定地说，他们做出选择的能力已经大大降低，甚至完全被基因突变所摧毁。社会应该如何对待这样的人？如果他们犯了罪，应该如何审判他们？

To what extent should individuals suffering from Brunner’s syndrome be held morally responsible for their actions? Since they cannot be called mentally ill, they can be brought to court and tried. And yet, thanks to today’s scientific understanding of the brain, one can definitively say that their ability to make choices has been greatly reduced, if not totally destroyed, by the genetic mutation that afflicts them. How should society deal with such people? How should they be judged if they commit crimes?

如今，生物学和神经学的飞速发展给我们带来了越来越多的道德困境，未来，我们将面临各种棘手的道德责任问题。鉴于关于大脑以及人性本质的不可预测的发现层出不穷，许多我们关于道德责任的传统观念，通常植根于古代宗教文本和教义，将开始显得过于简单和不完整。其中许多观念将完全被抛弃。作为一个社会，我们必须学会以全新的方式思考一个人对自己的行为负有道德责任意味着什么。只有当一个人摆脱了旧教条的束缚时，他才有可能诚实而严肃地应对这种挑战。

Today’s rapid progress in biology and neurology is presenting us with an ever-increasing number of such ethical dilemmas, and in the future, we will find ourselves facing all sorts of thorny questions about moral responsibility. In the light of an inevitable flood of unpredictable discoveries about the brain, and thus about the essence of human nature, many of our traditional ideas about moral responsibility, often rooted in ancient religious texts and teachings, will start to look simplistic and incomplete. Many of them will go completely by the boards. As a society, we will have to learn to think in profoundly new ways about what it means to say that a person is morally responsible for what they do. Only when one is freed from the shackles of old dogmas can one hope to tackle this type of challenge honestly and seriously.

第八章

CHAPTER EIGHT

新时代信仰与理性危机关于人们相信奇怪的想法

NEW AGE BELIEFS AND THE CRISIS OF REASON Concerning People’s Beliefs in Strange Ideas

任何错误都是由外部因素（如情感和教育）造成的；理性本身不会犯错。——库尔特·哥德尔，1972 年 11 月 29 日

Every error is due to extraneous factors (such as emotion and education); reason itself does not err.—Kurt Gödel, November 29, 1972

西现在，我们将焦点从传统宗教转移到通常被称为“新灵性”或更常见的新时代信仰。在某些方面，新旧信仰之间没有明确的界限，但总体而言，与传统宗教相比，新时代思想是一种不太系统的意识形态，缺乏理论基础。事实上，新时代思想可以比作一个smörgåsbord（瑞典语中的“三明治桌”），渴望信仰的人可以自由挑选他们认为最开胃的食物，而忽略其他食物。新时代文化是个人主义的，而且正如我们将看到的，它往往以自我为中心。此外，它还具有玩世不恭的商业主义特征，因为事实证明，利用渴望信仰的人可以赚到很多钱。

We now shift our focus from traditional religions to what is often called “the new spirituality” or, more commonly, New Age beliefs. In certain respects, there is no sharp boundary between the older and newer styles of belief, but overall one can say that, compared to traditional religions, New Age ideas amount to a less systematic ideology and have fewer theoretical bases to rest on. In fact, the set of New Age ideas could be likened to a smörgåsbord (literally, a “sandwich table” in Swedish), where belief-hungry folks are free to pick and choose those items that they find most appetizing and ignore all the rest. The New Age culture is individualistic and, as we’ll see, quite often self-centered. Moreover, it is also characterized by a cynically commercialistic aspect, for it turns out that there is a great deal of money to be made by exploiting the belief-hungry.

不合理的信念

Unreasonable Beliefs

美国最近的一项民意调查显示，大约 32% 的人口相信鬼魂的存在，31% 的人口相信心灵感应，25% 的人口相信占星术，21% 的人口相信与死者沟通，20% 的人口相信轮回转世。1这些观念都没有得到直接的支持。例如，人们常说，当满月、了解世界或体验世界运作时，人们会发疯。相反，这些想法几乎总是基于未经证实的传闻和关于各种事件和事件的谣言。尽管如此，许多人还是全心全意地相信这些事情。

A recent poll in the United States showed that roughly 32 percent of the population believes in ghosts, 31 percent in telepathy, 25 percent in astrology, 21 percent in communication with the dead, and 20 percent in reincarnation.1 None of these notions enjoys any support coming from direct For instance, it is often said that people go crazy when there’s a full moon, knowledge of the world, or from experience with the world’s workings. Rather, such ideas are almost always based on uncorroborated hearsay and rumors about events and happenings of various sorts. Nonetheless, many people believe wholeheartedly in such things.

流行文化中充斥着许多人不假思索就接受的神话。例如，人们常说满月时人会发疯，患有精神分裂症的人有“人格分裂”，积极的态度可以治愈癌症，如果经常给婴儿播放莫扎特的音乐作为背景音乐，婴儿会变得更聪明。2尽管流行心理学中充斥着错误或推测性的观点，但包含这些观点的自助书籍在商业上非常成功。

Pop culture is filled with myths that many people unreflectingly accept. For instance, it is often said that people go crazy when there’s a full moon, that people who suffer from schizophrenia have “split personalities,” that cancer can be cured by a positive attitude, or that infants will become smarter if Mozart is frequently played to them as background music.2 Although pop psychology abounds with mistaken or speculative ideas, self-help books incorporating such ideas are commercially very successful.

但我们难道不应该只相信我们想相信的东西吗？当然我们可以这样做。每个人都有无可争辩的权利去相信任何想法。但关键问题是：努力​​相信真实的想法而不是虚假的想法有什么用处吗？我个人认为有用，而且使用完善的策略来实现这一目标是有意义的。

But shouldn’t we all just believe in whatever we wish to believe in? Of course we can do this. Every person has the indisputable right to believe in any idea at all. But the key question is this: Is there any utility in striving to believe in ideas that are true rather than in ones that are untrue? I personally believe that there is, and that it makes sense to use well-developed strategies to attain this goal.

如果一个人希望相信可信的事物而不是不可信的事物，那么他就必须仔细考虑可信信念和不可信信念之间的区别。简单来说，区别如下：不可信信念是那些没有当代知识支撑或与当代知识相悖的信念。不可信信念的典型例子包括：

If one wishes to believe in what is plausible rather than what is implausible, then one must carefully consider the nature of the difference between plausible and implausible beliefs. Slightly oversimplified, the difference is this: Implausible beliefs are those that have no support in, or that run counter to, contemporary knowledge. Typical examples of implausible beliefs include the following:

  1. 与该领域大多数专家的观点相矛盾的观点；
  2. beliefs that are contradicted by most experts in the area;
  3. 逻辑上不可能或极不可能的信念；以及
  4. beliefs that are logically impossible or extremely improbable; and
  5. 这些信念完全基于轶事和传闻，而不是基于科学发现。
  6. beliefs that are based solely on anecdotes and hearsay rather than on scientific findings.

积极思考与伪科学

Positive Thinking and Pseudoscience

在新纪元运动的圈子里，人们经常会遇到对批判性思维的明显蔑视。相反，新纪元运动者会谈论积极思维的重要性（好像批判性思维和对生活的积极态度无法共存）：“不要这么消极！不要到处散播负能量！要积极思考！”

In New Age circles, one often encounters a distinct scorn for critical thinking. Instead, New Agers speak of the importance of positive thinking (as if critical thinking and having a positive outlook on life could not coexist): “Don’t be so negative! Don’t go around spreading negative energy! Think positive instead!”

现在谁不想有积极的想法呢？显然，保持乐观、创造性地思考和开辟新路是重要且值得的。但这与不加批判不同。拒绝形成自己对某个主张是否可信的判断，绝不是积极思考。事实上，这实际上是对自己的思维能力采取消极态度。

Now who wouldn’t want to have positive thoughts? It is clearly important and worthwhile to try to be upbeat and to try to think creatively and along new pathways. But that is not the same thing as being uncritical. Refusing to formulate one’s own judgment about whether a claim is believable is hardly positive thinking. In fact, it is actually adopting a negative stance about one’s own powers of thought.

“批判性思维”这个表达也经常被误解。有些人认为它意味着消极、爱发牢骚和反常。但这远非准确。在这方面，想想电影评论家的工作——即写电影评论——会很有帮助。有时评论家会说一部电影很精彩，并对演员和其他方面给予热情洋溢的评价。有时评论家会写一部电影导演得很糟糕，或者它讲述的故事有点过于夸张。有些电影会得到高分，有些会得到低分。但成为一名电影评论家并不意味着一个人总是批评别人。如果是这样的话，那么电影评论对任何人都没有多大用处。

The expression “critical thinking” is also often interpreted erroneously. Some people think that it means being negative, whiny, and contrary. But that is far from accurate. In this connection, it is helpful to think about what a film critic does—namely, writing reviews of movies. Sometimes a critic will say that a movie is wonderful, adding glowing comments about the actors and other aspects of it. Other times a critic will write that a film was poorly directed or that the story it tells stretches one’s beliefs a bit too far. Some films will get high grades, others low grades. But to be a film critic certainly doesn’t mean that one is constantly critical. If that were the case, then movie reviews would be of very little use to anyone.

批判性思维意味着一个人思考自己听到的主张并尝试自己判断。它基于一个人谨慎推理的能力。如果一个主张经过检验并通过了所有的批判性测试，那么它就应该被接受。

Critical thinking means no more and no less than that one thinks about claims one hears and tries to judge them oneself. It is based on using one’s ability to reason carefully and cautiously. If a claim is checked out and passes all of one’s critical tests, then it should be accepted.

“新灵性”思想的倡导者们与用科学方法检验思想的真理性保持距离。他们认为，他们声称的奇迹或其他奇怪现象不需要在实验室中得到验证。仔细想想，采取这种态度也许并不奇怪，因为如果对这些现象进行认真研究，就会发现它们是毫无根据的。

Advocates of the ideas of the “new spirituality” keep their distance from the scientific way of testing ideas for truth. They don’t think that their claims of miracles or other strange phenomena need to be verified in a laboratory. And when you think about it, taking such an attitude is perhaps not so weird, since if the phenomena in question were actually carefully investigated, they would be revealed as groundless.

有时，新纪元文化会使用听起来像科学的语言。各种声称的现象都使用所谓先进的理论来描述，如人体中的“能量”、“经络”、“区域”和“脉轮”（在印度教和佛教中，脉轮是所谓的“生命能量中心”）。在某些新纪元运动中，甚至有仪器据说可以测量“能量场”或其他科学未知的力量。

Sometimes the New Age culture uses what sounds like scientific language. Various claimed phenomena are described using supposedly advanced theories of “energies,” “meridians,” “zones,” and “chakras” in the human body (a chakra, in Hinduism and Buddhism, is an alleged “center of vital energy”). In certain New Age movements, there are even instruments that supposedly measure “energy fields” or other forces unknown to science.

当有人提出没有科学依据的主张，却用听起来很科学的术语来描述它时，他们就是在搞伪科学。他们使用的语言表面上听起来像一篇科学文章，但文字背后却没有任何实质内容。伪科学的实践者经常会借用物理学中的各种术语，特别是量子物理学中的术语，使他们的想法听起来非常复杂。不幸的是，这种低劣的技巧误导了许多人，因为大多数人的科学知识相当匮乏。

When someone makes a claim for which there is no scientific evidence but uses scientific-sounding jargon to describe it, they are engaging in pseudoscience. The language being used sounds on the surface like that of a scientific article, but behind the words there is no substance. Often practitioners of pseudoscience will borrow various terms from physics, particularly from quantum physics, to make their ideas sound very sophisticated. Unfortunately this cheap technique misleads many people since most people’s scientific knowledge is quite scanty.

以 Nikken 为例

Nikken as a Case Study

利用伪科学进行商业运作的一个著名例子是 1975 年成立的日本日建公司 ( https://www.nikken.com )。该公司专门销售各种所谓的科学产品，该公司在世界各地取得了相当大的成功，包括瑞典。Nikken 的销售策略是通过金字塔计划进行的，每个特许经销商都会招募“低于他们的”新卖家，从而建立起自己的卖家等级网络。3

A well-known example of a business that exploits pseudoscience is the Japanese firm Nikken (https://www.nikken.com), launched in 1975. This company specializes in selling allegedly scientific products of various sorts, and it has had considerable success around the world, including in Sweden. Nikken’s sales strategy works through pyramidal schemes, where each franchise dealer recruits new sellers “below them,” thus building up a hierarchical network of their own sellers.3

日建公司会组织销售会议，在会议上，经验丰富的销售人员会给新招募的销售人员打气，试图展示日建产品的巨大成功。这种会议中弥漫的狂热气氛常常让人想起原教旨主义宗教派别的复兴会议。我本人就参加过这样的会议，会上我们所有人都被告知，如果我们开始使用日建产品，我们很快就会变得更加快乐，而且更加富有；然而，当我提出一些怀疑性问题时，我很快就被带离了会议。

Nikken organizes sales meetings in which newly recruited sellers are given pep talks by more experienced sellers, who attempt to demonstrate the great success of Nikken products. The feverish atmosphere that pervades such meetings is often reminiscent of the revival meetings of fundamentalist religious sects. I myself attended such a meeting, at which we attendees were all told that if we started to work with Nikken products, we would soon be not only much happier but also much richer; however, as soon as I raised some skeptical questions, I was rapidly escorted out of the meeting.

Nikken 最畅销的产品之一是 KenkoInsoles，一种鞋用磁性鞋垫。这些鞋垫据称具有治愈力，并能散发各种能量。让我们来看看 Nikken 如何利用听起来很科学的语言来给人留下其产品有严肃科学依据的印象。以下文字摘自宣传 Nikken 多种产品的宣传册。

One of Nikken’s best-selling products is KenkoInsoles, a type of magnetic insert for shoes. These inserts are claimed to possess a healing force and to emanate various sorts of energy. Let’s take a look at how Nikken exploits scientific-sounding language to give the impression that its products have a serious scientific basis. The following text is taken from a brochure advertising a number of Nikken products.

磁能是人体自然过程的内在组成部分，也是所有生物自然环境的一部分。

远东文化和传统中医（中医——数千年来中国和日本医疗保健的基础）的一个古老原则和重要组成部分是体内能量的流动。例如，这导致西方认识到替代疗法的价值。

此外，地球磁场在人类历史上发生了巨大变化，甚至在地球历史上多次逆转。自 19 世纪末以来，现代文明也发挥了作用，电磁场和辐射不断增长，所有这些都与人体的自然能量场相互作用。瑞典约有 3% 的人口被官方认定因环境中的电磁场而患有功能障碍；这是一个日益严重的问题。

日建开发了磁性技术来抵消这种影响，使我们的周围环境更像保护人类数百万年的自然磁场。日建的磁性产品有助于恢复人类生存和繁衍的条件。

Nikken 磁力技术的首次应用是 Nikken KenkoInsoles ®的设计，这是该公司于 1975 年推出的首款产品。从那时起，Nikken 的研究团队一直在进行研究，并发现磁场越复杂，对人体的作用就越有效。因此，我们现在提供四项重大发展：

场梯度技术：Nikken 产品（例如 Power-Patch ®、Kenkoseat ®和 KenkoDream ® Quilts）使用双极磁铁，无论是单个还是多个磁铁阵列。这些阵列的间距精确，可在磁铁之间产生磁流（磁通线）图案，从而利用多个极性和磁通量形成复杂的磁能场梯度。

EQL 磁技术：等边磁技术采用专利设计，通过最大限度地增加平面上可能的磁通线数量来增加磁表面活性。它增加了正极和负极的数量，从而产生了更多穿过该表面的磁力线。这种方法的实际结果是整个区域的磁场完全均匀。

动态磁技术：动态磁场比静态磁场更复杂，Magboy ®和 MagCreator ®通过两个旋转磁球实现动态磁场。这会产生深层穿透的三维磁场，以及舒缓放松的按摩滚轮！

磁张力技术：最近两项产品开发包括 Nikken 的专利磁张力技术，该技术开始将动态技术的一些三维复杂性带入静态形式。RAM ®（径向轴磁性）技术模块采用阶梯式排列的小型高科技磁球，可产生一系列重叠的张力磁场，而最新的 Dyna-Flux ®技术已融入新款 PowerChipTM。

Magnetic energy is an intrinsic part of the body’s natural processes and part of the natural environment for all living things.

An ancient principle and significant component of Far Eastern cultures and traditional Chinese medicine (TCM—the foundation of healthcare in China and Japan for thousands of years) is that of flows of energies in the body. This has led, for example, to the West recognising the value of alternative practises.

In addition, the magnetic field of the earth has changed substantially over human history, even reversing many times over the planet’s history. Modern civilisation has also played its part, with the growth of electromagnetic fields and radiation, since the end of the 19th century, all of which inter-react with the body’s natural energy fields. Approximately 3% of the population in Sweden are officially recognised as suffering functional impairment due to electromagnetic fields in the environment; this is a growing problem.

The use of magnetic technology was developed by Nikken to counterbalance this effect, and make our surroundings more like the natural magnetic field that has protected human beings for millions of years. Nikken’s magnetic products help to restore the conditions in which human beings are meant to live and thrive.

The first application of Nikken’s Magnetic Technology was the design of the Nikken KenkoInsoles®, the company’s first product when launched in 1975. Since then, Nikken’s research teams have continued the process of research and found that the more complex the fields, the more effective they are on the body. As a consequence, we now offer four major developments:

Field Gradient Technology: Nikken products such as the Power-Patch®, Kenkoseat®, and KenkoDream® Quilts use bipolar magnets, either singly or in a multiple-magnet array. The arrays are precisely spaced to produce a pattern of magnetic flow (flux lines) between the magnets, creating a complex field gradient of magnetic energy utilising multiple polarities and flux.

EQL Magnetic Technology: Equilateral Magnetic Technology uses a patented design that increases the magnetic surface activity by maximising the number of flux lines possible on a flat surface. It multiplies the number of positive and negative poles, thus creating more lines of force crossing this surface. The practical result of this approach is that the magnetic field is perfectly uniform over the entire area.

Dynamic Magnetic Technology: A dynamic magnetic field is more complex than a static field, and the Magboy® and MagCreator® achieve this effect with two rotating magnetic balls. This produces a deeply penetrating 3-dimensional magnetic field—and a soothing and relaxing massage roller as well!

Magnetic Tension Technologies: Two recent product developments include Nikken’s patented Magnetic Tension Technologies, which start to bring some of the 3-dimensional complexity of the Dynamic Technology into a static form. RAM® (Radial-Axis Magnetism) Technology Modules feature small hi-tech magnetic spheres in a stepped alignment that produce a series of overlapping magnetic fields in tension, while the latest Dyna-Flux® Technology has been incorporated into the new PowerChipTM.

到目前为止一切都清楚了吗？如果不是，别担心……没有一位物理学教授能理解这些含糊其辞的话。

Is everything crystal-clear so far? Well, if it isn’t, don’t worry. . . . No professor of physics can make head or tail of any of this doubletalk, either.

在 Nikken 销售会议上，销售人员通过简单的程序了解如何让潜在买家相信磁性插件的奇妙效果：

In the Nikken sales meetings, sellers learn, through a simple procedure, how they can convince would-be buyers of the fantastic effect of the magnetic inserts:

  1. 让对象（被说服购买产品的人）光着脚站在地板上。让他们将双手放在身后。
  2. Have the subject (the person to be persuaded to buy the product) stand on the floor in their stocking feet. Ask them to place their hands behind their back.
  3. 站在受试者身后，轻轻地将他们的手向下拉，再向后拉。受试者会很快失去平衡，必须向后退一步才能避免摔倒。
  4. Place yourself behind the subject and gently pull their hands down and back further. The subject will quickly lose their balance and will have to take a step backward to keep from falling.
  5. 重复此过程，但这次受试者佩戴 Nikken 磁性插入物。这一次，令人惊讶的是，受试者会感觉更强壮，不需要后退一步！
  6. Repeat this procedure but this time with the subject wearing Nikken magnetic inserts. This time around, amazingly enough, the subject will feel stronger and will not need to take a step backward!

卖家现在会很高兴地解释说，磁力插入物既提供能量又提供力量，使人保持平衡。这似乎是一个非常有效和可靠的演示，磁力插入物似乎发挥了很好的作用。

The seller will now explain with pleasure that the magnetic inserts provide both energy and force, allowing the person to maintain their balance. This seems to be a highly effective and reliable demonstration, and the magnetic inserts seem to have done their job very well.

然而，这个实验的几个方面值得我们深思：

There are a few aspects of this experiment, however, that give pause for thought:

  1. 这些磁性插入物可以创造或提供某种未知的能量或力量来对抗重力，使人在失去平衡时能够站立，这种想法完全违背了我们对自然法则的认识。这种力量是不存在的。这并不意味着我们已经证明整个说法都是胡说八道。事实上，可能存在某种完全未知的新现象和某种新的力量，即使这种情况极不可能。无论如何，沿着这些思路思考，我们还有理由批判性地反思所描述的测试。
  2. The idea that these magnetic inserts can create or provide some kind of unknown energy or force that opposes gravity and allows a person to stay standing when thrown off balance runs completely against our knowledge of the laws of nature. There is no known force of this sort. This doesn’t mean that we have proven that the whole claim is pure poppycock. Indeed, there just might be some kind of totally unknown new phenomenon and some new kind of force, even if this is extremely unlikely. In any case, thinking along these lines gives us further reason to reflect critically on the test as described.
  3. 实验是这样进行的：在第二次试验中，受试者已经对即将发生的事情做好了准备，因此，无论是有意识还是无意识地，都会调整自己的身体以保持站立。
  4. The experiment was carried out in such a way that in the second trial, the subject was prepared for what was going to happen, and thus, whether consciously or unconsciously, adjusted their body in such a way as to stay standing.
  5. 我们不能确定，第二次卖家是否有意识或无意识地拉动受试者的手，力度是否比第一次要小一些。
  6. We cannot be sure whether the second time around, the seller—either consciously or unconsciously—pulled the subject’s hands a little less vigorously than the first time around.

这些微妙的因素会严重影响实验。因此，我们无法确定实验中是否存在欺骗行为，或者是否存在某种安慰剂效应。当然，到目前为止，还没有任何证据表明实验存在欺诈行为；但是，如果我们是批判性思考者，我们肯定会保持警惕，并坚持进行更仔细的测试，然后再接受这些插入物确实有效的说法。

These kinds of subtle factors can seriously influence the experiment. For this reason, we cannot be sure whether trickery is taking place, or whether some sort of placebo effect is involved. Of course nothing so far stated proves definitively that the experiment is fraudulent; however, if we are critical thinkers, we are certainly led to be on our guard and to insist on making more careful tests before accepting the claim that these inserts actually work.

在这种情况下，有没有什么方法可以确定真相？有的。我们可以进行双盲测试。首先，我们制作第二对插入物，它们看起来与 Nikken 插入物一模一样，但是其中没有磁铁。接下来，我们请来一位不为 Nikken 组织工作的测试人员。然后我们让第三个人（同样与 Nikken 无关）以随机方式分发插入物对，这样受试者和测试人员都不知道当前使用的插入物对是否具有磁性。然后我们连续进行几次实验，始终随机选择要使用的插入物。

Is there any way to determine the truth definitively in such a situation? Yes, there is. We can do a double-blind test. First, we make a second pair of inserts that look exactly like the Nikken inserts, but that have no magnets in them. Next, we bring in a tester who does not work for the Nikken organization. Then we have a third person (again not involved with Nikken) hand out the pairs of inserts in a randomized fashion, so that neither the subject nor the tester knows whether the pair being currently used is magnetic. Then we carry out the experiment several times in a row, always randomly choosing which inserts to use.

当以这种方式进行测试时，我们很快发现不再有任何效果。无论哪种情况，受试者失去平衡的可能性都是相同的。在进行这项双盲测试之前，产生效果的原因是什么都无关紧要。这是受试者心中的安慰剂效应吗？是卖家厚颜无耻的造假吗？还是卖家心中的一厢情愿？我们不知道，而且这也不重要。我们唯一可以肯定的是，这种效果不是由磁性插入物产生的任何特殊力量引起的，而这正是我们试图确定的。

When the test is carried out in this fashion, we soon discover that there is no longer any effect. The subject is equally likely to lose their balance in either case. Whatever cause might have produced an effect before this double-blind test was carried out is irrelevant. Was it a placebo effect in the subject’s mind? Was it shameless fakery on the part of the seller? Or could it have been wishful thinking in the seller’s mind? We don’t know, and it doesn’t matter. All we know for sure is that the effect does not arise from any kind of special forces produced by the magnetic inserts, and that’s what we were trying to ascertain.

这个案例研究表明了一个非常重要的想法。对世界持怀疑态度并不意味着人们应该能够科学地解释所声称发生的每一种现象。更温和的立场是仔细检查所声称的现象是否真的存在。

This case study demonstrates a very important idea. Taking a skeptical attitude toward the world does not mean that one should be able to account scientifically for every phenomenon that is claimed to take place. A more modest stance is simply to check carefully whether or not the claimed phenomenon actually exists.

如果在双盲实验中，磁性插入物的神奇功效完全消失，那么我们没有必要仔细分析那些伪科学的胡言乱语，这些胡言乱语据说可以解释磁性插入物的神奇功效。如果人们在佩戴或不佩戴这些术语所标记的插入物时失去平衡的可能性相同，那么“场梯度技术”、“DynaFlux 技术”和“径向轴磁力技术模块”等听起来很花哨的短语实际上并不重要。

There is no reason for us to analyze carefully the pseudoscientific mumbo-jumbo that supposedly explains the wonderful powers of the magnetic inserts if in fact those powers completely vanish when a double-blind experiment is carried out. Such fancy-sounding phrases as “Field Gradient Technology,” “DynaFlux Technology,” and “Radial-Axis Magnetism Technology Modules” don’t really matter if people are equally likely to lose their balance with or without the inserts labeled by those terms.

销售磁性插件只是无数不道德的手段之一，这些手段都是利用容易上当的人来快速赚钱。掌握清晰思维的艺术可以帮助人们避免落入此类陷阱。

Selling magnetic inserts is just one of innumerable unscrupulous techniques for making a quick buck off of gullible people. Mastering the art of clear thinking helps one not to fall into such traps.

顺势疗法

Homeopathy

另一个基于庸医而取得商业成功的企业是被称为顺势疗法的“替代医学”。它基于德国医生 Samuel Hahnemann (1755–1843) 提出的理论。当时，人们流行使用金鸡纳树皮等植物来对抗高烧。Hahnemann 注意到，金鸡纳树皮在健康人身上产生的症状与该产品应该治愈的病人的症状相似。这一观察让他想到了一个概念，他用拉丁语表达为“Simila similibus curantur”（“用类似的东西治愈疾病”），由此产生了一种抗病方法，他称之为“顺势疗法”（“类似疾病”）。

Another example of a commercially successful business based on quack medicine is the “alternative medicine” known as homeopathy. It is based on a theory proposed by German doctor Samuel Hahnemann (1755–1843). At that time, it was popular to use the bark of plants such as Cinchona to combat high fevers. Hahnemann noted that Cinchona bark produced symptoms in healthy people that were similar to those in sick patients whom the product was supposed to cure. This observation suggested to him a notion that he expressed in Latin as “Simila similibus curantur” (“Cure an ill by something resembling it”), and from that came the disease-fighting approach that he called “homeopathy” (“similar disease”).

根据顺势疗法理论，各种症状和疾病可以通过使用引起这些问题的物质来治愈，但要非常稀释。哈内曼认为，过量服用药物弊大于利。这个想法本身就是一种明智的见解；然而，他随后的做法却走向了完全不同的方向。他声称药物越稀释，效果就越好。他创造了“增效”一词来表示增加药物的稀释度（因此，在他的理论中，是增加药物的有效性）。稀释过程也应该以特定的方式、遵循某些仪式进行，才能正常工作。

According to the homeopathic theory, various symptoms and illnesses can be cured by using substances that cause these problems, but in a very diluted form. Hahnemann believed that excessive doses of a medicine could do more harm than good. This idea in itself was an intelligent insight; however, the way he then proceeded went in a completely different direction. He claimed that the more diluted a medication was, the more effective it would be. He coined the term “potentization” for increasing the dilution (and thus, in his theory, the effectiveness) of a given medication. The process of dilution was also supposed to be carried out in a particular manner, following certain rituals, to work properly.

因此，顺势疗法药物被一次又一次地稀释，稀释倍数高达数百万倍——事实上，最终制剂中没有一个原始治疗物质的分子残留。顺势疗法医师解释说，在充分发挥效力后剩下的水保留了治疗物质的“记忆”，因此它继承了治疗物质的神奇力量。

Homeopathic medications are thus diluted over and over again, by a factor of many millions—in fact, in the end, not a single molecule of the original curative substance remains in the preparation. Homeopaths explain that the water that remains after full potentization retains a “memory” of the curative substance and thus that it inherits magical powers from it.

这种药物在法国、英国和德国等国家很受欢迎。在瑞典，许多保健食品商店以及其他替代药物商店都可以找到顺势疗法药物。

This kind of medication is popular in such countries as France, England, and Germany. In Sweden, homeopathic medicines can be found in many health-food stores, as well as in other outlets for alternative medicine.

顺势疗法药物唯一能起到的作用就是安慰剂的作用。这一点已经得到仔细的研究和证明。欧洲和美国都进行了双盲实验。顺势疗法的拥护者经常说：“也许科学还不能证明它有效，但这并不意味着它无效。有很多事情我们不明白。”但这是错误的逻辑。由于非常仔细的研究，科学确实能够证明顺势疗法无效。（顺势疗法的核心原则是物质越稀释，其效果越强，这导致了一些相当荒谬的后果。例如，如果你应该每天接受顺势疗法治疗，那么你应该非常小心，不要错过任何每天服用一次，因为如果你错过一两天，你可能会因服用过量而死亡！这种观点显然是荒谬的。）

The only kind of effect that a homeopathic medicine can have is as a placebo. This has been carefully researched and demonstrated. Double-blind experiments have been carried out both in Europe and in the United States. Defenders of homeopathy often say, “Maybe science hasn’t yet been able to show that it works, but that doesn’t mean it doesn’t work. There are lots of things we don’t understand.” But this is fallacious logic. Science has indeed been able, thanks to very careful research, to show that home-opathy does not work. (The central tenet of homeopathy—that the more diluted a substance is, the stronger is its effect—leads to some quite absurd consequences. For instance, if you are supposed to take a homeopathic treatment every day, then you should be extremely careful not to miss any day, because if you do miss a day or two, you might die of an overdose! This kind of viewpoint is clearly nonsensical.)

利用古代和科学的威望

Exploiting the Cachet of Antiquity and That of Science

许多理论都建立在有关世界如何运转和人类如何运作的古老迷信神话之上。这些理论的倡导者热切地指出，他们的思想植根于古老的传统，仿佛这种传统在某种程度上使他们更合法或更值得信赖。

Many theories build on ancient superstitious myths about how the world works and how people work. The advocates of such theories eagerly point out how their ideas are grounded in venerable traditions, as if this heritage in some way or other makes them more legitimate or more trustworthy.

不幸的是，教义和方法古老并不能自动保证它们就是好的。很长一段时间以来，人们试图通过放血来治愈疾病。人们用水蛭吸出病人的血液，希望使他们恢复健康。这种方法的广泛使用是由于对血液在疾病中的作用存在错误理论的结果。然而，人们长期以来相信放血这一事实并不意味着它是一种有效的治疗方法。过去的人们有理由相信他们，因为他们没有像我们今天这样系统的医学和生物学知识。我们不应该因为这一点而批评他们。但是，今天任何提倡放血作为疾病的普遍治疗方法的人都是在不顾大量相反证据的情况下这样做的。（在某些非常罕见的情况下，水蛭仍然用于医疗目的，但原因与过去完全不同。）

Unfortunately, the fact that teachings and methods are old is not an automatic guarantee that they are good. For a very long time, people tried to cure sicknesses by bloodletting. The blood of sick people was sucked out by leeches in the hopes of rendering them healthy. The widespread use of this method was a consequence of erroneous theories of the role of blood in diseases. The fact that people believed in bloodletting for a long time doesn’t mean, however, that it constitutes a valid method of curing diseases. The people of the long-gone past can be excused for believing as they did, because they had no access to a systematic body of medical and biological knowledge as we do today. We should not criticize them for that lack. But anyone who today would advocate bloodletting as a general cure for illnesses is doing so despite vast amounts of contrary evidence. (Leeches are still used for medical purposes in certain very rare situations, but for completely different reasons than in the old days.)

如今，新纪元文化竭力利用社会对科学的崇高敬意。能量、具有特定频率的振动，甚至量子力学等科学概念，都被那些对它们的含义一无所知的人轻率地利用。我们被“先知”撰写的论文所淹没，他们试图利用从真正的科学中借用的复杂而抽象的概念（或至少是文字！）来支持伪科学思想。

Today, the New Age culture tries hard to make hay from the high esteem in which science is held in society. Scientific concepts such as energy, vibrations having certain frequencies, and even quantum mechanics are glibly exploited by people who don’t have the faintest idea what they are talking about. We are awash in treatises written by “prophets” who try to buttress pseudoscientific ideas using complex and abstract concepts (or at least words!) borrowed from genuine science.

建立在当今真实知识基础上的方法和程序是首选。当然，这并不意味着当今的医学永远不会犯错，而只是说当今使用​​的方法至少比建立在无知和迷信基础上的方法要好。

Methods and procedures that build on the genuine knowledge that we have today are to be preferred. Of course this doesn’t mean that today’s medicine never makes mistakes, but merely that the methods that are used today are at least better than those that are built on ignorance and superstition.

有时伪科学家会利用纯粹的语言诡计来误导公众。因此，我们可以在众多新时代励志书籍中读到关于细胞的营养需求和健康饮食的重要性。细胞需要能量（从物理学和生物学角度来看，能量是技术意义上的能量）才能工作。到目前为止一切顺利。但在同一本书中，我们还会读到与“夺走你能量”的人交往的危险。如果你和这样的人呆在一起太久，你就会“失去能量”。我们被告知，我们必须保护自己免受“能量泄漏，不仅是来自我们自己的身体，还包括来自试图窃取我们能量的其他人”——事实上，这样的人被称为“能量吸血鬼”。在这里，“能量”一词被扭曲地使用——作为心理和情感特征的隐喻。

Sometimes pseudoscientists exploit purely linguistic trickery to mislead the public. Thus in numerous books of New Age inspiration we can read about the nutritive needs of cells and the importance of eating well. Cells require energy (energy in its technical sense, in terms of physics and biology) to be able to carry out their work. So far so good. But in the same books we will read about the dangers of associating with people who “take energy away” from you. If you hang around such people too much, you will “lose energy.” We are told that we have to protect ourselves from “energy leakage, not just from our own bodies but also from someone else who is trying to steal our energy”—in fact, such a person is called an “energy vampire.” Here, the word “energy” is being used in a distorted fashion—as a metaphor for a psychological and emotional characteristic.

类似的例子也发生在我们说“今天在健身房锻炼后，我精力充沛！”时。从物理学和生物学的角度来看，人们无法通过锻炼获得能量；事实上，恰恰相反——人们在锻炼时会消耗能量。当然，锻炼后，人们会感觉更健康、更敏捷、更有活力、更快乐，也更“精力充沛”。

A similar example of linguistic confusion occurs when we say, “After I exercised at the gym today I had so much energy!” From the point of view of physics and biology, one cannot gain energy from exercising; indeed, quite the contrary—one uses up energy while exercising. Afterward, of course, one can feel more fit, quicker, livelier, happier, and more “filled with energy.”

以这种隐喻的方式使​​用能量概念本身并没有错；但是，如果在这两个能量概念（一个是科学的，另一个是隐喻的）之间插入等号，那么就脱离了科学的范畴，而进入了伪科学的范畴。在新时代的著作中，很少甚至从未区分过同一术语的不同含义。因此，涉及此类概念的结论是错误的和不科学的。不幸的是，这种含糊不清的语言用法在新时代文化中非常典型。听起来很科学但实际上只是草率隐喻的概念被系统地利用，这种用法误导了许多人，诱使他们相信所断言的背后隐藏着一些严重的事情。

To use the notion of energy in this kind of metaphorical sense is not wrong in itself; however, if one inserts an equals sign between these two notions of energy, one scientific and the other metaphorical, then one has left the realm of science and verged over into that of pseudoscience. Seldom if ever, in New Age writings, is a distinction drawn between different meanings of the same term. The conclusions involving such notions are therefore erroneous and unscientific. Unfortunately this type of slippery linguistic usage is very typical of the New Age culture. Concepts that sound scientific but that in reality are just sloppy metaphors are systematically exploited, and such usages mislead many people, tricking them into believing that something serious lies behind what is being asserted.

量子物理学与新时代

Quantum Physics and the New Age

新纪元运动者们经常提及量子物理学的研究。其基本思想是，对此类基本领域的研究证实了“集体意识”等流行观念以及我们可以通过“星体投射”离开身体的想法。

It’s popular among New Agers to allude to research in quantum physics. The basic idea is that research into such fundamental domains justifies such trendy notions as “collective consciousness” and the idea that we can leave our bodies via “astral projection.”

如今，声称要找到量​​子物理学和新时代思想之间的深层联系的书籍比比皆是。在这些书中，我们读到量子物理学对领导技巧、清晰思维、健康、意识理解等的影响。达娜·佐哈尔和迪帕克·乔布拉等作家都曾推广过这种观点，并取得了巨大的商业成功。但不幸的是，他们所写的书的实际内容根本不是科学；而是伪科学的胡言乱语和琐碎的真理的大杂烩。

These days, books that purport to find deep links between quantum physics and New Age ideas are a dime a dozen. In them we read about the implications of quantum physics for leadership techniques, for clear thinking, for good health, for the understanding of consciousness, and on and on. Writers such as Danah Zohar and Deepak Chopra have promoted such views, and with enormous commercial success. But the actual content of the books they write is unfortunately not science at all; it is a hodgepodge of pseudoscientific claptrap and trivial truisms.

量子物理学研究的是物质的最基本成分，其中会遇到一些真正违背正常理解的现象。此外，量子力学迫使物理学家重新思考有关物质最深层本质的某些关键假设。但这并不意味着人们可以从量子物理学中得出关于其他科学领域的简单结论，例如生物学、心理学或意识本质的研究。

Quantum physics deals with the most basic constituents of matter, and in it one encounters phenomena that genuinely defy normal understanding. Moreover, quantum mechanics has forced physicists to rethink certain key assumptions about the innermost nature of matter. But this does not mean that from quantum physics one can validly draw simplistic conclusions about other scientific areas, such as biology, psychology, or research into the nature of consciousness.

量子力学并没有告诉我们上帝很可能存在，也没有告诉我们当一个人冥想得足够深时，他可以悬浮在空中。声称控制无限小粒子的定律也适用于人类，这是一个严重的错误。做出如此巨大的跨越是没有意义的。有意义的是测试从观察和实验中产生的新理论。人们总是可以根据他们脑海中浮现的任何东西来构想理论，但如果一个理论没有在实验中得到证实，它就只能停留在纯粹的猜测范围内。

Quantum mechanics does not tell us that God most likely exists, or that when one meditates sufficiently deeply, one can levitate off of the ground and hover in the air. To claim that the laws governing infinitesimally small particles apply also to human beings is to commit a serious error. It makes no sense to make such vast leaps. What does make sense is to test new theories that spring out of observations and experiments. People can always dream up theories based on anything that springs to their minds, but if a theory doesn’t find confirmation in experiment, it must remain in the realm of sheer speculation.

分类错误和科学阶梯

Category Errors and the Ladder of Sciences

粗略地讲，我们可以认为各种科学学科描述了现实的不同层次。因此，在最高层次上，我们是由我们的文化、社会、经济、审美观和法律形成的。再往下一层是心理层面，我们是由思想和情感形成和影响的。再往下是生物过程层面，而生物过程又是由遵循分子相互作用定律的化学过程组成的。然后分子由原子组成，原子由物理定律描述。原子内部的过程由物理学的一个分支——量子力学描述。总的来说，我们对世界的看法是一个多层次的结构，一个层次，可以用以下方式来表示：

In a crude approximation, one can think of the various scientific disciplines as describing different hierarchical levels of reality. Thus at the highest level, we are formed by our culture, our society, our economy, our aesthetics, and our laws. One level down lies the psychological level, where we are formed by and influenced by thoughts and emotions. Below that comes the level of biological processes, which in turn are made up of chemical processes that obey the laws of molecular interactions. And then molecules are made up of atoms, which are described by the laws of physics. The processes inside atoms are described by quantum mechanics, which is a branch of physics. Overall, then, our perspective on the world is a multitiered structure, a hierarchy, which can schematically be represented in the following fashion:

社会

Society

文化、经济、法律、艺术、文学、美学……

Culture, economy, law, art, literature, aesthetics . . .

⇓

⇓

心理学

Psychology

决策、感知、梦想、情感……

Decision making, perception, dreams, emotions . . .

⇓

⇓

生物学

Biology

细胞过程、蛋白质、突触、

代谢过程、进化……

Cellular processes, proteins, synapses,

metabolic processes, evolution . . .

⇓

⇓

化学

Chemistry

分子、化学反应、化学键……

Molecules, chemical reactions, chemical bonds . . .

⇓

⇓

物理

Physics

引力、电、磁、量子、

裂变、聚变、原子能……

Gravity, electricity, magnetism, quanta,

fission, fusion, atomic energy . . .

当然，某一特定层次上发生的事情取决于较低层次上发生的事情。从这个意义上说，不同层次是相互联系的。但是，每个层次上的现象都有其独特的性质，因此我们不能自动假设属于某一层次的概念和现象也属于其他层次。例如，我们人类有思想和经验这一事实并不意味着电子、碳原子和 DNA 分子等微观实体，或大学、公司和国家等宏观实体也有思想和经验。得出这样的结论就是犯了“分类错误”。我们可以通过以下例子进一步解释这一概念。

Of course, what happens on any particular level depends on what happens on lower levels. In that sense, the different levels are linked to each other. But there are phenomena on each level that have their own special qualities, and so we cannot automatically assume that concepts and phenomena that belong to one level also belong to other levels. The fact that we humans have thoughts and experiences does not imply, for instance, that such microscopic entities as electrons, carbon atoms, and DNA molecules, or such macroscopic entities as universities, companies, and nations, also have thoughts and experiences. To draw such a conclusion would be to make a “category error.” This concept can be further explained with the following example.

假设我们保管着一份可追溯到 18 世纪早期的非常古老的羊皮纸文件。羊皮纸上用深黑色墨水写着我国宪法。事实上，这份珍贵的文件是我们整个法律体系的基础。进一步假设，在 20 世纪早期，研究人员对这种墨水在这么长时间后仍能清晰可见的方式感到着迷。在用他们所能掌握的最佳技术对其进行分析后，研究人员一致得出结论，墨水持久的原因是其中存在某种化学物质。

Suppose that we have in safekeeping a very old parchment document dating back to the early eighteenth century. On the parchment is written, in dark black ink, our country’s Constitution. Indeed, this precious document is the foundation of our entire legal system. Suppose further that early in the twentieth century, researchers were fascinated by the way the ink had remained readable after such a long time. After analyzing it using the best techniques available to them, the researchers unanimously concluded that the reason for the ink’s durability was the presence of a certain chemical in it.

现在快进到现在。又过了一百年，我们的化学知识得到了极大的发展。研究人员再次分析了古羊皮纸上的墨水。然而，这一次，他们得出结论，墨水中并不含有早期研究人员所认为的任何化学物质。墨水持续保持深色、清晰易读和持久耐用的秘密原来是一种与人们所认为的完全不同的化学成分。一百年前的想法。因此我们必须彻底改变我们对墨水持久黑色的解释。到目前为止，没有问题……

Now fast-forward to the present. A hundred years more have passed, and our knowledge of chemistry has greatly developed. Researchers once again analyze the ink in the old parchment. This time, however, they conclude that the ink doesn’t have any of the chemicals in it that earlier researchers had thought. The secret of the ink’s continuing darkness, legibility, and durability turns out to be a totally different chemical constituent than people had thought a hundred years ago. And so we have to completely overhaul our explanation of the ink’s enduring blackness. So far, no problem . . .

新知识迫使我们修改有关羊皮纸上墨水的故事。但这是否意味着我们也必须修改对用该墨水书写的文本的法律含义的解释？我们现在是否应该感到有义务彻底改革我们的法律体系？不，显然不是。仓促得出这样的结论将犯下严重的分类错误。文件墨水的化学成分与文件的法律内容毫无关系，法律内容存在于更高、更抽象的层面上。

New knowledge forced us to revise our story about the ink on the parchment. But does that mean that we also have to revise our interpretation of the legal meaning of the text written using that ink? Should we now feel obliged to totally overhaul our legal system? No, obviously not. To jump to such a conclusion would be to make a grievous category error. The chemical composition of the document’s ink has no bearing whatsoever on the document’s legal content, which resides on a higher, more abstract level.

范畴错误的概念也许可以更简单、更生动地表达如下：一首诗不会因为用不同颜色的墨水写成而变得不那么美丽。

The notion of a category error can perhaps be conveyed more simply and more vividly as follows: A poem does not become less beautiful for being written in ink of a different color.

什么时候采取高层次的视角是合理的，即关注整体而不是其基本组成部分？一切不是都联系在一起的吗？如果我们认为科学是由一组明确的、有层次的层次组成的，这难道不会让科学显得过于僵化吗？

When is it justifiable to take a high-level perspective, in the sense of focusing on the whole rather than on its basic constituents? Isn’t everything tied together? If we think of science as being organized into an unambiguous, hierarchical set of levels, doesn’t that make science seem unduly rigid?

可以肯定的是，将实体视为整体非常重要。我们在医学研究中清楚地看到了这一点，它不断提醒我们，身心相互影响，紧密相连——事实上，它们是同一个东西。科学研究​​应该始终尝试从广阔的视角出发，最重要的是要大胆创新。

To be sure, considering entities as wholes is very important. We see this clearly in medical research, which constantly reminds us that mind and body exert influences on each other and are intimately coupled together—and are, in fact, one and the same thing. Scientific research should always try to take a broad perspective and should, above all, be daring and creative.

新理论层出不穷，其中有些理论肯定是相当激进的。但要成为科学的有效组成部分，它们必须通过实证检验。没有经过大量实验室测试的证实，任何科学结论都是无效的。分类错误的概念与从新科学发现中可以和不能合法得出的结论类型有关。它并没有说明什么是真的，什么不是真的。完全有可能的是，就在一些化学研究人员做出新发现，让我们更好地解释古羊皮纸上使用的墨水的性质的同时，法律学者也可能会发现，有理由迫使我们彻底修改对羊皮纸上文本的法律含义的理解——但如果发生这种情况，这两件事就毫无关联了。法律发现将完全独立于化学发现。这两个发现涉及羊皮纸的两个非常遥远的层面，彼此毫无关联。

New theories are being formulated all the time, and among them some will surely be quite radical. But to become valid parts of science, they must pass muster empirically. No scientific conclusion is valid without being confirmed by numerous laboratory tests. The idea of category errors has to do with the kinds of conclusions that can and cannot legitimately be drawn from new scientific findings. It says nothing about what is true and what is not true. It could perfectly well happen that at just the same time as some chemistry researchers make new discoveries that give us a much better explanation of the properties of the ink used in an old parchment, legal scholars might also discover that there are reasons compelling us to drastically revise our understanding of the legal meanings of the text on the parchment—but if that should happen, the two events would be unrelated. The legal finding would be totally independent of the chemical finding. The two findings, concerning two very distant levels of the parchment, would have nothing to do with one another.

类似的评论也适用于量子物理学和日常生活。新时代的人热情地谈论量子物理学及其“整体”观点。当然，在量子物理学中，我们仍然有许多不为人知的惊人现象，但这并不意味着量子物理学的这些神秘方面必然会解释生命其他领域的神秘现象。例如，被称为“纠缠”的量子现象，即两个在空间中相距甚远的粒子的状态紧密相连，这无疑是极其了不起的，但它并不能得出这样的结论：我们都只是一个伟大集体意识的微小部分，或者思想控制是可能的，或者宇宙对整个人类有一个长期计划。如果我们相信这样的想法，我们只是犯了基本的分类错误。

Similar comments apply to quantum physics and ordinary life. New Age people enthusiastically talk about quantum physics and its “holistic” perspective. Well, in quantum physics there are certainly many remarkable phenomena that we still do not understand, but this does not mean that these mysterious aspects of quantum physics will necessarily explain mysterious phenomena in other areas of life. For instance, the quantum phenomenon known as “entanglement,” whereby the states of two particles that are widely separated in space are intimately linked together, is undeniably extremely remarkable, but it does not lead to the conclusion that we are all just tiny parts of one great collective consciousness, or that thought control is possible, or that the cosmos has a long-term plan for humanity as a whole. If we fall for such ideas, we are simply making elementary category errors.

所有这些都不能掩盖这样一个事实：量子世界为我们提供了美丽的新隐喻，我们可以用它们来谈论各种日常现象。但是当它们应用到我们人类的生存层面时，它们就只是隐喻而已，没有别的。不幸的是，量子物理学和其他科学领域被新时代的人滥用，他们喜欢用更神秘和更刺激的术语来描绘世界（他们中的一些人还喜欢从天真和容易上当的人身上快速赚钱）。例如，有时有人声称除了我们的感觉告诉我们的东西之外，没有其他的现实，我们的意识控制着世界上发生的事情，或者整个宇宙的所有现象都以某种神秘的方式联系在一起。所有这些都是用伪科学的胡言乱语来陈述的，在外行人听来，就像是在表达量子物理学的深奥之处。

None of this belies the fact that the quantum world has given us beautiful new metaphors that we can use in talking about all sorts of everyday phenomena. But when they are applied to our human level of existence, these are just metaphors and nothing else. Unfortunately, quantum physics and other areas of science are abused by New Agers who like to paint the world in more mystical and thrilling terms (and some of them also like to make a quick buck off of naïve and gullible folks). For example, it’s sometimes claimed that there is no reality other than what our senses tell us, and that our consciousness governs what happens in the world, or that all phenomena all across the universe are somehow mystically tied together. All of this is stated using pseudoscientific gibberish that to the untrained ear sounds like it is expressing profundities of quantum physics.

伪科学家经常毫无顾忌地借用科学概念，尽管他们的做法很马虎，但表面上他们借用科学概念，让科学新手觉得他们的观点很新鲜、很令人兴奋，作者无需认真支持他们的观点。

Pseudoscientists often borrow scientific concepts without being in the least troubled by doing so in a sloppy and slapdash manner. Although it is merely window dressing, their seeming use of science makes their viewpoint come across to scientific novices as fresh and exciting, without the writers having to seriously back up any of the claims being made.

案例研究：占星术

A Case Study: Astrology

千万不要低估伪科学的强大诱惑力。古代占星术就是一个很好的例子。许多人对占星术持怀疑态度，阅读报纸上的星座运势只是为了消遣，但对其他人来说，这是一件非常严肃的事情。占星师靠提供建议谋生，据说他们告诉人们他们的真实身份、他们的感受以及他们将会遭遇什么样的命运。当然，所有这些都是来自遥远的星星。

One should never underestimate the powerful lure of pseudoscience. The ancient doctrine of astrology is an excellent case in point. Many people take astrology with a big grain of salt, reading horoscopes in the newspaper merely for entertainment, but for other people it is a very serious matter. Astrologers earn their living by giving advice and supposedly telling people what they really are, how they feel, and what fate will befall them. All this, of course, is courtesy of the distant stars.

星座运势是一种古老的算命方法，根据某人出生时的天体位置进行预测。占星术的拥护者希望将星座占卜行为称为科学，但它更像是一种伪科学。

Horoscopes are an ancient manner of fortunetelling based on the positions of heavenly bodies at the time of someone’s birth. Advocates of astrology wish to call the act of divination by horoscopes a science, but it is a far better example of a pseudoscience.

瑞典杂志《科学与公众》进行的一项民意调查显示，大约四分之一的瑞典人认为占星术是一门科学。这一数字与其他西方国家大致相同，而在非洲和亚洲某些地区，这一数字甚至更高。

A poll conducted by Swedish magazine Vetenskap & Allmänhet (Science and the Public) found that roughly one Swede in four considers astrology to be a science. This figure is roughly the same as in other Western nations, and in Africa and certain parts of Asia, it is even higher.

在印度，占星术几乎是普遍信仰，占星术“数据”可以决定婚姻、影响旅行计划和决定商业决策。在《怀疑论者》网站上，人们发现了以下相当惊人的新闻：

In India, where belief in astrology is nearly universal, astrological “data” can dictate marriages, affect travel plans, and determine business decisions. On the Skeptical Inquirer website, one finds the following rather amazing news item:

2001 年 2 月，印度大学资助委员会 (UGC) 决定为印度大学的占星学学士和硕士课程提供资金，印度占星学的游说活动达到了顶峰。其通告指出：“迫切需要振兴印度的吠陀占星学……并提供机会将这一重要科学推向世界。”在 UGC 宣布这一消息后的九个月内，印度 200 所大学中的 45 所已向 UGC 申请 150 万卢比（约 30,000 美元）的资助，以建立占星学系。4

The lobby for Indian astrology had its crowning glory when, in February 2001, the University Grants Commission (UGC) decided to provide funds for BSc and MSc courses in astrology at Indian universities. Its circular stated: “There is urgent need to rejuvenate the science of Vedic Astrology in India . . . and to provide opportunities to get this important science exported to the world.” Within nine months of the UGC’s announcement, forty-five of India’s 200 universities had applied for the UGC grants of 1.5 million rupees (about $30,000) to establish departments of astrology.4

占星术的信徒有时会这样捍卫自己的观点：“月亮影响潮汐，那么它为什么不能影响人类呢？毕竟，我们的身体大部分是由水组成的！行星和恒星为什么不能影响我们的生活呢？”可以举出各种各样的理由来证明这一论点的荒谬性，其中有四个：

Believers in astrology sometimes defend their views by saying, “The moon influences the tides, so why shouldn’t it affect human beings as well? After all, our bodies are mostly made of water! And why shouldn’t the planets and the stars also be able to influence our lives?” All sorts of reasons can be adduced for the silliness of this argument, among which here are four:

  1. 占星术主要不是关于月亮的，而是关于天空中行星和恒星的排列，即所谓的“黄道十二宫”。行星和恒星距离我们比月球远得多，而且它们对潮汐没有丝毫影响。
  2. Astrology is not primarily about the moon, but about the arrangement of the planets and stars in the sky, in so-called “signs of the zodiac.” The planets and stars are enormously much farther away from us than is the moon, and none of them has the slightest influence on the tides.
  3. 毫无疑问，我们的身体里含有大量的水，但月球对海洋的影响是因为每个海洋都含有大量的水。月球对我们体内如此微量的水没有任何明显的影响。
  4. No doubt our bodies have much water inside them, but the influence of the moon on the oceans is because each ocean contains a huge volume of water. The moon doesn’t have any noticeable effect on such minuscule quantities of water as are found in our bodies.
  5. 即使月球对我们体内水分的影响就像它对潮汐的影响一样——即通过引力将我们拉动一点点——这也与决定我们的性格或我们一生中将要经历的事件毫无关系。无论如何，地球引力对我们的影响远大于月球。
  6. Even if the moon affected the water in our bodies in the same way as it does tides—namely, by pulling us a little bit with its gravitation—this would have nothing whatsoever to do with determining our personalities or the events that will befall us in the course of our lives.
