In any case, the earth’s gravity has a far greater effect on us than does the moon’s.
  7. 如果月亮影响我们体内的水分，而这种影响又以某种方式决定了我们的性格，那么为什么这种至关重要的影响只发生在我们出生的那一刻，而不是在我们生命的后期呢？
  8. If the moon affects the water in our bodies, and if that effect somehow determines our personality, then why should it be that this crucial effect takes place only at the exact moment of our birth and at no later time during our life?

用月亮如何引起潮汐来论证占星术的有效性是完全错误的。但占星家总是可以反驳科学的反对意见，说：“我们不知道宇宙的所有规律。科学无法解释一切。那么为什么事情不能像我们说的那样呢？”

To cite how the moon brings about the tides as an argument for the validity of astrology is completely off base. But astrologers can always try to counter scientific objections by saying, “We don’t know all the laws of the universe. Science can’t explain everything. So why couldn’t things be as we say they are?”

这个论点在原则上是有道理的。占星术可能对现实说出一些真实的东西，即使它完全违背了当​​今对宇宙本质的理解，尽管我们甚至无法解释它为什么是真实的。然而，如果占星术有哪怕一丁点可证明的真理，我们就必须彻底改变我们对宇宙本质的看法。占星术是真实的几率几乎为零（正如一句老话所说，“在地狱中滚雪球的几率微乎其微”），但原则上它是可能发生的。尽管如此，驳斥占星术是有道理的，正如我们将在后面的解释中看到的那样。

This is an argument that in principle makes sense. Astrology might conceivably say something true about reality, even though it runs totally against the grain of today’s understanding of the nature of the universe and despite the fact that we couldn’t even begin to explain why it was true. If astrology had even a grain of demonstrable truth, however, we would have to profoundly revise our views of the nature of the universe. The chance of astrology being true is as close to zero as one can imagine (“a snowball’s chance in hell,” as an old phrase goes), but in principle it could happen. Nonetheless, it makes sense to dismiss astrology, as we shall see in the explanation that follows.

在过去的五十年里，占星术一直是科学研究的热门话题。一项典型的研究可能具有以下形式：

Astrology has been the subject of comprehensive scientific studies in the past fifty years. A typical piece of research might have the following form:

  1. 确定占星术认为特定的星座和行星排列与特定的性格特征或身体特征之间存在的明确联系。
  2. Determine what astrology considers to be a definite link between, on the one hand, a specific sign of the zodiac and planetary alignment with, on the other hand, a specific personality trait or bodily feature.
  3. 收集大量有关人们的星座、性格特征和身体特征的数据。
  4. Collect data concerning a large number of people’s horoscopes and their personality traits and bodily features.
  5. 通过统计评估，这些特征和特点在具有“正确”星座的人群中是否比完全随机分布时预期的更频繁地出现。
  6. Statistically evaluate whether these traits and features occur more frequently among people with the “right” horoscopes than would be expected if the distribution were completely random.

已经进行了许多此类研究，它们都表明占星术预测并不比随机猜测好。5这类研究的有趣之处在于它们不涉及任何占星术可能发挥作用的机制，因此它们与我们是否了解占星术无关。

Many such studies have been carried out, and they all show that the astrological predictions are no better than random guesses.5 What is interesting about these kinds of studies is that they do not involve in any way the mechanisms through which astrology might work, and they are thus independent of whether we understand astrology.

也有研究表明，人们热切地认为占星术的说法是真实的，并证实了他们自己先前的观点。例如，当五百人被给予一份相同的基于星座的性格描述，并告诉他们每个人这份描述都是他们自己独有的，大多数人声称在这份描述中认出了自己。（法国曾经进行过这样的实验，在实验中，所有受试者都获得了一份根据臭名昭著的法国杀人犯的出生数据绘制的星座图。）这种效果让我们更有理由拒绝占星术。

There are also studies that show that people eagerly take astrological claims as true and as confirming their own prior opinions. For instance, when five hundred people were given an identical horoscope-based personality description, and each of them was told that this description was uniquely their own, the majority of them claimed to recognize themselves in the description. (Such an experiment was once carried out in France, and in it, all the subjects were given a horoscope drawn up on the basis of the birth data belonging to an infamous French murderer.) This kind of effect gives us all the more reason to dismiss astrology.

两位英国社会心理学家马丁·鲍尔和约翰·杜兰特研究了什么样的人会相信占星术。不出所料，他们发现怀疑态度与受试者的科学知识水平之间存在明显的统计相关性。一个人的科学知识越多，他相信占星术的可能性就越小。6

Two British social psychologists, Martin Bauer and John Durant, looked into the question of what kinds of people are drawn toward a belief in astrology. As might be expected, they found that there was a clear statistical correlation between skepticism and the subjects’ level of scientific knowledge. The more scientifically knowledgeable a person was, the less likely it was that the person would believe in astrology.6

总而言之，占星术是一门伪科学，它不仅缺乏实验支持，而且事实上已经被大量实验彻底驳斥。占星术能够告诉人们他们的性格和命运的“科学”理论因此被证伪。

To sum up, astrology is a pseudoscience that doesn’t merely lack experimental support, but that has in fact been decisively refuted by a large number of experiments. The “scientific” theory that astrology has the power to tell people about their personalities and their fates is thereby falsified.

第二个案例研究：迈尔斯-布里格斯测试

Second Case Study: The Myers-Briggs Test

自古以来，我们人类就需要简化和系统化我们的生活，试图将彼此放入整齐的小分类框中。当我们相信我们能够将其他人归入明确、明确的分类框中时，我们的控制感就会大大增强。也许，我们知道自己确切地知道我们在与谁打交道，这让我们平静下来，减少焦虑。数千年来，占星术一直在帮助实现这一目标。

Since time immemorial, we human beings have needed to simplify and schematize our lives by trying to put each other into neat little categorical boxes. Our feeling of control is greatly enhanced when we believe that we are able to stick other people into unambiguous, sharply defined pigeonholes. Perhaps having the sense that we know exactly who we are dealing with serves to calm us and to reduce our anxiety. Astrology has lent a helping hand to this activity for thousands of years.

19 世纪，人们尝试用新方法来满足这种心理需求。种族生物学变得流行起来，颅相学也是如此（该学说声称可以通过检查一个人的头骨形状来了解其性格）。今天我们知道这些观念不仅是伪科学和毫无根据的，而且在道德上也是有害的。尽管如此，将他人归类的心理需求并没有消失。

In the nineteenth century, people tried to satisfy this psychological need with new methods. The biology of race became popular, as did phrenology (the doctrine that claims that a person’s personality can be read from examining the shape of their skull). Today we know that these notions not only are pseudoscientific and groundless but also are morally harmful. Nonetheless, the psychological need to pigeonhole others has not gone away.

当今瑞典和其他国家最受欢迎的性格测试之一是迈尔斯-布里格斯性格指标 (MBTI)。在公司中，MBTI 通常用于描述工作团队成员的心理特征，目的是使团队运作得更顺畅。该测试是由两位业余心理学家伊莎贝尔·布里格斯·迈尔斯和凯瑟琳·库克·布里格斯于 20 世纪 40 年代在美国设计的，他们受到瑞士心理学家卡尔·古斯塔夫·荣格提出的理论的启发。根据 MBTI，有 16 种不同的性格类型（比占星术多 4 种，占星术有 12 种，每个星座一种）。

One of today’s most popular personality tests, both in Sweden and in other countries, is the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI). In companies, the MBTI is often used to characterize the psychology of the members of a work group, the goal being to make the group function more smoothly. This test was designed in the 1940s in the United States by two amateur psychologists, Isabel Briggs Myers and Katharine Cook Briggs, who were inspired by theories that had been proposed by Swiss psychologist Carl Gustav Jung. According to the MBTI, there are sixteen distinct personality types (four more than in astrology, which has twelve, one for each sign of the zodiac).

MBTI 涉及四个量表或维度，每个量表或维度都有两个相反的极端特征，具体如下：

The MBTI involves four scales or dimensions, each of which is characterized by two opposing extremes, as follows:

外向（E）—内向（I）

Extrovert (E)—Introvert (I)

感知（S）—直觉（N）

Sensing (S)—Intuition (N)

思考（T）—感觉（F）

Thinking (T)—Feeling (F)

判断（J）—感知（P）

Judging (J)—Perceiving (P)

这意味着当今地球上每种类型大约有 4.5 亿人（假设这 16 种类型均匀分布）。

This means that for each type there are roughly 450 million people on earth today (assuming the sixteen types are equally distributed).

如果从上述四个维度中分别选择两个对立面中的一个，那么当然会产生十六 (= 2 × 2 × 2 × 2) 种不同的性格类型（见图8.1）。

If you choose one of the two opposites for each of the above four dimensions, this will of course yield sixteen (= 2 × 2 × 2 × 2) distinct personality types (see figure 8.1).

荣格启发的 MBTI 的基本思想涉及对比类型的行为特征，例如“现实/富有想象力”、“理性/富有同理心”和“思考/情感”。这些对比虽然听起来很有吸引力，但并不是真正的对立。例如，要想做得好，科学研究人员需要既富有想象力又现实。尽管现代心理学研究早已拒绝了卡尔·荣格的理论，但这似乎对 MBTI 的商业成功几乎没有影响。

The basic idea of the Jung-inspired MBTI involves contrasting types of behavioral traits, such as “realistic/imaginative,” “rational/empathetic,” and “thinking/feeling.” Such contrasts, though they sound appealing, are not genuine opposites. For instance, to do well, a scientific researcher needs to be both imaginative and realistic. Even though modern psychological research has long since rejected Carl Jung’s theories, that seems to have had little or no effect on the commercial success of the MBTI.

但即使这些理论大多只是新时代的愚蠢之谈，迈尔斯-布里格斯测试难道还不能揭示出一个人的性格吗？

But even if these theories are mostly just New Age silliness, couldn’t the Myers-Briggs test still reveal something about an individual’s personality?

鉴于 MBTI 是世界上最广泛使用的性格测试之一，独立研究人员对其进行了彻底调查。结果表明，该测试缺乏可靠性，因为结果不可重复。最简单的方法就是在两次不同的时间对同一个人进行相同的测试，两次测试之间间隔足够长的时间，当然不要提前告诉该人测试的内容。即使两次测试之间的间隔只有五周，也有多达一半的受试者在第二次测试中表现出与第一次不同的性格类型。然而，该测试背后的理论是，性格特征是天生的，不会在人的一生中改变。7

Given that the MBTI is one of the most widespread personality tests in the world, it has been thoroughly investigated by independent researchers. The upshot is that the test lacks reliability, in the sense that the results are not repeatable. The simplest way to show this is simply to give the same test to a given individual on two different occasions, with a sufficiently long interval between them, and of course without telling the individual in advance what is being looked for. Even if the interval between the two tests is as small as five weeks, as many as half of the subjects wind up on the second test with a different personality type than on the first go-round. And yet the theory behind the test is that personality traits are innate and do not change during the course of a person’s life.7

图 8.1. 不同的性格类型

Figure 8.1. Distinct Personality Types

MBTI 测试也缺乏有效性。该测试的支持者声称，某些 MBTI 性格类型在某些职业中出现的频率更高，例如教师。然而，综合研究表明，教师职业中 MBTI 特征的分布与随机选择的人口子集并没有显著差异。8

The MBTI test also lacks validity. Advocates of the test claim that certain MBTI personality types crop up much more often in certain professions, such as that of teacher. Comprehensive studies have shown, however, that the distribution of MBTI profiles in the teaching profession is not significantly different than in a randomly chosen subset of the population.8

总而言之，MBTI 测试与占星术一样，属于伪科学。然而，瑞典公司以及世界各地的其他公司却非常乐意向 MBTI 顾问支付大笔费用。

In sum, the MBTI test belongs to the same pseudoscientific class as astrology. And yet Swedish corporations, and other corporations all around the world, are perfectly happy to fork over large sums of money to MBTI consultants.

可以想象，该测试的作用有点像安慰剂，因为让工作小组的成员接受 MBTI 测试可能会让他们感觉自己被观察了，这可能会让他们更加小心地对待彼此。那会很好！但说实话，我建议用占星术。它不仅同样有效（也就是说，除了安慰剂效应外，根本没有效果），而且便宜得多。9

It is conceivable that the test acts a bit like a placebo, in the sense that subjecting the members of a work group to the MBTI might give them the sense that they are being observed, and this could lead them to be more careful about how they treat each other. That would be nice! But to tell the truth, I would recommend astrology instead. Not only is it equally effective (which is to say, not at all, aside from the placebo effect), but it is far cheaper.9

同步性

Synchronicity

新纪元圈子里经常被提及的一个概念是同步性（来自希腊语前缀syn-，意为“共同”，以及chronos，意为“时间”，因此本质上是“同时性”的希腊语版本）。对于那些原本对新纪元思想并不特别感兴趣的人而言，认为这个概念可能有些道理并不罕见。

A commonly tossed-about concept in New Age circles is synchronicity (from the Greek prefix syn-, meaning “co-,” and chronos, meaning “time,” thus essentially a Greek version of “simultaneity”). It’s not unusual for someone who is not otherwise particularly attracted to New Age ideas to have the sense that there may be something to this notion.

那么什么是同步性呢？基本概念是两个密切相关的事件同时或几乎同时发生，而它们之间没有任何明确或可理解的因果关系。例如，有一天，我决定去看望一位小学同学，而当天晚些时候，她恰好坐在我旁边的公交车上。现在，我的一部分心想：“哦，真是一个偶然的巧合！”但我的另一部分心想：“这太不可能了！这不可能是偶然的！这个事件中一定有什么隐藏的含义！”这就是“同步性”的含义。

So what is synchronicity, then? The basic idea is that of two intimately related events taking place at exactly or nearly the same time, without there being any clear or understandable causal connection between them. For example, one day I decided to look up an old schoolmate from elementary-school days, and later that very day, she happened to sit down right next to me on a bus. Now one part of me thought, “Oh, what a nice random coincidence!” But another part of me thought, “This is just too improbable! It can’t just be random! There must be some hidden meaning in this event!” That’s what is meant by “synchronicity.”

和 MBTI 一样，这一理论可以追溯到卡尔·古斯塔夫·荣格，某些“生活教练”和各种自助课程都热衷于利用这一理论。然而，同步性的概念是基于对概率的误解。让我们举一个简单的例子：假设此刻我正在想念一位亲爱的朋友，她给我打电话。“太神奇了！同步性！”但显然，关键问题是：“当她没有给我打电话时，我有多少次想到了她？”事实上，在她给我打电话的无数次中，我恰好在想念她，这并不奇怪。

Like MBTI, this theory harks back to Carl Gustav Jung, and it has been eagerly seized upon by certain “life coaches” and in self-help courses of various sorts. The notion of synchronicity is, however, based on misunderstandings of probability. Let’s take a simple example: Suppose that at the very moment I’m thinking about a dear friend she calls me on the phone. “How amazing! Synchronicity!” But clearly, the key question is this: “How many times have I thought about her when she didn’t call me?” The fact that I happened to be thinking about her on one of the innumerable occasions when she has called me is not all that surprising.

同样的事情也发生在我在公交车上遇到老同学的身上。这似乎不太可能，但问题是：“那天还有多少其他不太可能的巧合可能发生在我身上，但却没有发生？”从这个角度来看，公交车上的相遇并不是一件了不起的事情。事实上，我们身边随时都在发生着非常不可能发生的事件，但我们甚至没有注意到其中的绝大多数（我们也不应该注意到）。例如，当你得知最新中奖彩票的号码组合是（7、2、5、21、13、25、37）时，你会惊呼：“哦，多么难以置信！”从某种意义上说，你是对的，因为那个特定组合中奖的可能性极小，但任何预选组合中奖的可能性当然也极小。事实上，在巨额彩票中，一些极不可能发生的事情一定会发生。在这种情况下，极不可能的事情不仅是可能，甚至是不可避免的！

The same thing holds for my running into the old schoolmate on the bus. It might seem highly improbable, but the question is this: “How many other improbable coincidences might have happened to me that day but simply didn’t?” When seen in this light, the meeting in the bus wasn’t such a remarkable event. As a matter of fact, very unlikely events are happening all around us all the time, yet we don’t even notice the vast majority of them (and we shouldn’t). Consider, for example, learning that the latest winning lottery ticket’s combination was (7, 2, 5, 21, 13, 25, 37) and exclaiming, “Oh, how incredibly improbable!” You would be right, in a sense, since for that particular combination to win is extremely improbable, but of course it’s extremely improbable for any preselected combination to win the lottery. The fact is, in an enormous lottery, something that is enormously improbable will happen, without fail. And in such cases, something highly improbable is not just probable but even inevitable!

我们可以尝试一个思想实验来说明为什么同步性的想法是不可信的。让我们将“极不可能事件”定义为发生概率为百万分之一的事件。也就是说，它的概率是 1/1,000,000，或者换句话说，0.0001%。我们当然都同意，发生概率如此低的事件是非常不可能发生的事件。在我们的思想实验中，让我们还假设我们的大脑每秒可以记录大约一个有意识的时刻。也就是说，我们的大脑每月记录大约两百万个独立的时刻（我们睡觉的时间不计算在内）。因此，“极不可能事件”应该每月大约发生两次，而无需“同步性”的帮助。

We can try out a thought experiment that shows why the idea of synchronicity is implausible. Let’s define an “extremely unlikely event” as being one whose chance of occurring is one in a million. That is, its probability is 1 in 1,000,000, or otherwise put, 0.0001 percent. Surely we all agree that an event with this low a chance of happening is a very improbable event. In our thought experiment, let us also assume that our brains can register roughly one conscious moment per second. That is, our brains register roughly two million separate moments per month (the time when we are sleeping is not counted). An “extremely unlikely event” should thus happen roughly twice per month, without any help from “synchronicity.”

那么，为什么人们如此轻易地相信同步性，而且如此诱人呢？也许是因为它把我们的自我放在了画面的中心。你和你的生活似乎对宇宙本身来说变得很重要：“这不可能是随机的；宇宙一定是有意让我现在有这种经历。宇宙巨大的魔力已经合谋了——而且都是为了我！”正如这表明的那样，新时代文化是自恋的，而对同步性的信仰尤其清楚地揭示了这一事实。

Why, then, is it so easy and so tempting to believe in synchronicity? Perhaps because it puts our own ego in the center of the picture. You and your life seem to become important to the universe itself: “This can’t be random; the universe must have intended for me to have this experience just now. The universe’s vast magical powers have colluded—and all just for me!” As this shows, the New Age culture is narcissistic, and belief in synchronicity is a particularly clear revelation of this fact.

案例研究：Hug 和 Bug

Case Study: Hug and Bug

让我们来看一个典型的、被有些人称为同步性的案例。我的一个朋友曾向我吐露，她经常看到车牌上按顺序排列着“HUG”字母的汽车。她经常看到这样的车牌，以至于她确信这不可能是偶然的。在成千上万个三字母组合中，“HUG”为什么会出现得如此频繁？她说这里面一定有某种隐藏的含义，某种神秘的原因解释了为什么“HUG”到处追着她。这是爱的秘密信息吗？毕竟，爱和拥抱是紧密相连的。

Let’s take a look at a typical case of what some might call synchronicity. I have a friend who has confided in me that she surprisingly often sees cars whose license plates feature the letters “HUG” in that order. She sees such licenses so often that she’s convinced that it can’t be mere chance. Out of all the thousands and thousands of three-letter combinations that exist, why should “HUG” show up so often? She says there must be some hidden meaning in it, some occult reason that explains why “HUG” is pursuing her everywhere. Is it a secret message of love? After all, love and hugs are tightly linked.

好吧，这里有很多认知错误，但都混杂在一起了。首先，想想我朋友日复一日看到却没有意识到的所有车牌。当然，大多数车牌都没有被阅读或思考过，尽管有些车牌会被匆匆读过，然后立即被记住。忘记——左耳进，右耳出。问题是，如果你开始痴迷于“HUG”车牌，你几乎肯定会注意到你视野范围内的所有“HUG”。这是人类感知性质的直接结果。（如果你选择购买一辆红色汽车，因为红色汽车在你看来非常罕见，那么一旦你买了它，你首先会注意到的是，突然间似乎每个人都有一辆红色汽车。真烦人！）我们往往看不到我们不感兴趣的东西。所以我那位天真的“HUG”痴迷朋友在她眼前成群结队的“BUG”牌照、“HAG”牌照、“HUB”牌照和“HWG”牌照时不会注意。

Well, many cognitive errors are blurred together here. For starters, consider all the license plates that my friend sees day after day and doesn’t notice consciously. Most of them, of course, go by without being read or thought about at all, although a few will be fleetingly read and immediately forgotten—in one ear and out the other. The thing is, if you start obsessing about “HUG” license plates, you are almost sure to notice all the “HUGs” that come within your field of view. This is a straightforward consequence of the nature of human perception. (If you choose to buy a red car because red cars seem very rare to you, the first thing you’ll notice, once you’ve bought it, is that all of a sudden everybody seems to have a red car. How annoying!) We tend not to see things in which we have no interest. And so my naïve “HUG”-obsessed friend will pay no attention when “BUG” licenses, “HAG” licenses, “HUB” licenses, and “HWG” licenses by the droves go sailing by her eyes.

在目前有效的车牌中，“HUG”是否过多出现，这纯粹是一个事实问题，只要联系相应的官方政府机构，就不难核实。当然，出于某些不为人知的原因，这个三个字母的组合在车牌上出现的频率确实有可能高于其他组合。但如果是这样的话，那么所有“HUG”的出现都有着平凡、无聊且完全合乎逻辑的原因——而这正是同步性信徒最不想听到的事情！这样的人会更愿意相信，宇宙（或某种宇宙力量、大写的命运、因果报应、佛法或其他什么）希望他们以极不可能的频率遇到印有“HUG”字样的车牌。但如果“HUG”实际上比其他三个字母的组合更常见，那么它就不能证明同步性，而只是制造和分发车牌的政府机构存在疏忽大意的行为。

The question as to whether “HUG” is overrepresented in the set of currently valid license plates is purely a matter of fact, and should not be hard to check, by contacting the appropriate official government agency. Of course, it’s always possible that that three-letter combination actually occurs on licenses more often than some others, for some obscure reason. But if that’s the case, there would be a mundane, boring, and perfectly logical reason for all the “HUG” sightings—and that’s the last thing that a synchronicity believer wants to hear about! Such a person would far sooner believe that the universe (or some cosmic force, or Fate with a capital F, or karma, or dharma, or whatever) wants them to come across license plates that say “HUG” at an outrageously unlikely rate. But if “HUG” actually is more frequent than other three-letter combinations, it’s not a proof of synchronicity but simply a sign of sloppiness on the part of the government agency that manufactures and distributes license plates.

宇宙“希望”通过安排事物，让我在四处游荡时碰到大量神秘的“HUG”汽车，来向我这个年幼的我发送一封情书，这种想法，说得客气一点，是极端以自我为中心的。如果“宇宙”真的想给我这个年幼的我发送信息，它肯定可以用更简单的方法来实现，而不是让挂着特定车牌的四轮汽车在恰当的时刻突然出现在我眼前。为什么宇宙不能直接给我的手机发短信呢？当然，这看起来不那么神秘和“宇宙”，但效率要高得多。

The notion that the universe “desires” to send a love letter to little old me, by arranging things so that, as I wander hither and thither, I will bump into a mysteriously high density of “HUG” cars is, to put it mildly, self-centered in the extreme. If “the universe” really took it into its head to send little old me a message, surely it could do so in easier ways than by making four-wheeled vehicles with certain license plates materialize out of the blue, right before my eyes, at just the right moment. Why couldn’t the universe just send me a text message on my cell phone, instead? Of course that wouldn’t seem so mysterious and “cosmic,” but it would be a lot more efficient.

我们每个人都应该在判断概率的微妙挑战面前保持谦逊，我们每个人都应该警惕将不存在的、看似神秘的联系解读到事物的体系中，尤其是当对这种联系的信仰会导致我们将我们自己视为宇宙的全部时。

Each of us should remain humble before the subtle challenge of judging probabilities, and each of us should be wary of reading nonexistent, mystical-seeming links into the scheme of things, especially when belief in such links would lead us to taking our very own self for the universe’s be-all and end-all.

新时代偏见

New Age Prejudices

轮回、前世疗法、水晶疗法、占星术以及许多其他属于“新灵性”范畴的概念如今已成为许多人对待生活和工作态度的常态，而非例外。那些有勇气宣称自己的世界观不包括超自然现象、超自然生物或神秘主义的人常常被那些认为自己的立场更开放、更包容、更不傲慢的人贴上“无聊”、“有限”和“肤浅”的标签。但可悲的是，这样的人实际上是无知的，充满偏见。

Reincarnation, past-life therapy, crystal healing, astrology, and numerous other notions falling under the rubric of the “New Spirituality” are today more the rule than the exception in many people’s attitude toward their lives and their work. Those who have the courage to declare that their worldview doesn’t include supernatural phenomena, supernatural beings, or mysticism are often branded “boring,” “limited,” and “shallow” by people who consider their own stance to be more open minded, more inclusive, and less arrogant. But sad to say, such people are actually ignorant and filled with prejudices.

在前面的章节中，我们谈到了一些偏见，但在接下来的几页中，我将明确展示一些具体的偏见，并说明如何应对它们。对非信徒的一种偏见可以表达如下：

In previous chapters we have touched on some of these prejudices, but in the next few pages, I will explicitly exhibit a few specific ones and show how they can be countered. One such prejudice about nonbelievers might be expressed as follows:

你只相信科学可以解释的事物。你的教条观点拒绝任何科学无法解释的现象。在你僵化、封闭的头脑中，没有空间容纳无法解释或未知的事物。

You believe only in things that science can explain. Your dogmatic viewpoint rejects any phenomenon that science cannot explain. In your rigid, closed mind, there is no room left for the unexplained or the unknown.

对此的反驳可能是这样的：科学不需要能够解释为什么一个主张是正确的。科学所要求的只是该主张的证据，也就是说，相信它的某种理由。显然，一个主张越是违背已知的自然法则或标准观点，它所提出的证据就必须越有力，因为标准的科学信念已经有大量证据支持它们。

A retort to this might go as follows: Science does not need to be able to explain why a claim is true. What science asks for is simply evidence for the claim, which is to say, some reason for believing in it. Obviously, the more a claim runs against known laws of nature or against standard views, the stronger the evidence presented for it must be, since standard scientific beliefs have great masses of evidence supporting them already.

假设我在杂志上看到一则广告，其中介绍了一种神奇的治疗打鼾的天然新方法。我应该相信吗？好吧，就其本身而言，这一说法并不违背我所知道的任何先前的自然法则，也不违背我所拥有的任何经验。所以也许我应该相信它！另一方面，我知道有很多公司想利用引人注目的声明来快速赚钱，不幸的是，这些声明完全没有根据。我们已经看到过许多这样的例子。因此，如果我仅仅因为在杂志上看到这个说法就相信它，那就太天真了。但是，我到底需要什么才能开始认为它可能是真的呢？

Suppose I see an ad in a magazine that describes a marvelous new natural cure for snoring. Should I believe it? Well, in itself, the claim doesn’t run against any prior law of nature that I know, or any set of experiences I’ve had. So perhaps I should believe it! On the other hand, I know that there are many companies that want to make a quick buck using striking claims that, unfortunately, are utterly ungrounded. We’ve already seen a number of such examples. It would therefore be naïve for me to believe in this claim merely because I saw it in a magazine. But what would it take for me to start thinking it might be true?

理想的情况是，由一个公正、值得信赖的团队进行一个简单的测试，比如给一组打鼾严重的人服用天然药物，给第二组打鼾的人服用糖丸，而不告诉任何一组人他们接受了何种治疗。如果成员如果第一组的患者确实停止了打鼾，而第二组的患者仍然继续打鼾，那么我至少有一些逻辑理由可以想象这种天然药物可能确实有效。

It would be ideal to have a simple test that could be carried out by an impartial and trustworthy team, such as giving a natural medication to one group of heavy snorers and sugar pills to a second group of snorers, without telling either group what kind of treatment they have been given. If members of the first group do in fact stop snoring, while members of the second group keep on snoring away, then there are at least some logical grounds for me to imagine that the natural medication might actually work.

简而言之，我不需要知道为什么打鼾疗法有效，我就可以相信它有效；我只需要证据。但是一旦它被证实有效，那么科学的下一个任务就是试图找出它为什么有效。

In short, I don’t have to know why the snoring cure works in order to believe that it works; I just need evidence. But as soon as it’s known to work, then science’s next task is to try to find out why it works.

这是另一个典型的新时代对理性人的偏见，我们需要知道如何去对抗它：

Here is another typical New Age prejudice about rational people that one needs to know how to combat:

你心胸狭隘，思维局限。你一心想把所有事情都推理出来，所以你和我们其他人不一样。你冷漠、思想封闭、分析过度。你几乎毫无感情，你非常不信任自己的直觉。

You are narrow and limited. You are so determined to reason everything out that you aren’t like the rest of us. You are cold, closed minded, and hyper-analytic. You are next to feelingless, and you deeply mistrust all your gut feelings.

当然，理性与冷漠、狭隘和冷酷之间没有任何联系。事实上，那些对自己的信仰有清晰深思熟虑的人不太可能被肤浅的诡计或骗局所蒙骗。这是一种比仅仅依靠直觉更安全的生活方式。

Well, of course there is no connection at all between being rational and being cold, narrow minded, and emotionless. In fact, people who have clearly thought-out reasons for their beliefs are much less likely to fall for superficial trickery or con schemes. That’s a safer way to live than to rely solely on one’s gut feelings.

重要的是要意识到什么是合理的，什么是人们希望发生的事情。以读心术为例。我不相信读心术，尽管有时我希望它是真的。如果我确信某些人可以读懂别人的想法，我会觉得这很奇妙、很精彩、很迷人、很刺激（当然也非常令人担忧）。但希望它能发生并不意味着我相信读心术。仅仅因为希望某事发生就相信它，这在理智上是不诚实的。如果一个人遵循这条道路，那么他就可以相信任何事情。

It’s important to be aware of the distinction between what is plausible and what one wishes were the case. Take mind reading, for instance. I don’t believe in mind reading, although I sometimes wish it were real. If I were convinced that certain individuals could read other people’s thoughts, I would find that fantastic, wonderful, fascinating, and thrilling (although of course very worrisome as well). But wishing that it could happen doesn’t make me a believer in mind reading. It is not intellectually honest to believe in something simply because one wishes it were so. If one follows that pathway, then one can believe anything at all.

你似乎认为一个人应该只通过理性来做决定。你不明白，事实上，人们完全受感情支配。

You seem to think that one should make one’s decisions through reason alone. You don’t understand that people are in fact totally governed by feelings.

如果你认为人们仅仅通过理性的过程来做出决定并形成观点，那你就是在自欺欺人。

In thinking that people make decisions and form opinions solely through rational processes, you are fooling yourself.

当然，人类的决策并非完全通过推理做出。许多细致的心理学实验表明，决策受情绪的影响比大多数人认为的要大得多。感觉和欲望在所有人类决策中，情感都发挥着不可估量的作用。但在纯粹的感觉和纯粹的理智之间找到一个平衡点至关重要。正是因为我们受情感的驱使如此强烈，所以我们需要培养推理能力，并帮助它系统地发展。

Of course human decisions are not arrived at solely via reasoning. Many careful psychological experiments have demonstrated that decision making is far more driven by emotions than most people suspect. Feelings and desires play an incalculable role in all human decisions. But it is crucial to find a happy medium between pure feeling and pure intellect. It’s precisely because we are so strongly driven by emotions that we need to cultivate our ability to reason and help it to develop systematically.

医生通过理性思考和密集训练，可以确信某种治疗方法可以治愈患者。但除了这种理智上的认识之外，医生还希望患者通过治疗康复，并希望这种情况会发生。事实上，许多人选择成为医生的一个主要因素不仅是他们对理性的吸引力，而且是他们强烈的愿望，希望为受苦受难的人提供帮助和解脱。

A doctor, thanks to rational thinking and intensive training, can become convinced that a certain medical treatment may cure a patient. But above and beyond this intellectual realization, the doctor also wants the patient to recover through the treatment and hopes it will happen. Indeed, a central factor in many people’s choice to become doctors is not just their attraction to rationality but also their powerful desire to bring help and relief to people who are suffering.

政治家能够通过理性思考，看到某种行动有助于实现更大程度的社会平等。但仅凭这一事实并不足以激励政治家决定采取这一行动，政治家还需要有强烈的愿望来实现更大的平等。没有感情和愿望，就无法做出决定，也无法采取行动。应对复杂政治问题的最佳方式是将感情与理智结合起来——明智地运用理智和感情。毕竟，正如布莱兹·帕斯卡 (Blaise Pascal) 诗意地宣称的那样：“心有理智，但理智不知道。”但是，当感情完全取代理智时，决策就会变得困难。

A politician can, thanks to rational thinking, see that a certain action can help bring about greater social equality. But this fact alone is not sufficient motivation for the politician to decide to carry out this action; it also requires a strong desire, on the politician’s part, to achieve greater equality. Without feelings and desires, no decisions would be made and no actions would be carried out. The optimal way of reacting to complex political questions is to combine one’s feelings with one’s reasons—to use both head and heart in a judicious mixture. After all, as Blaise Pascal poetically declared, “Le cœur a ses raisons que la raison ne connaît point” (“The heart has its reasons that reason knoweth not”). But when feeling takes over completely from reason, then decision making can become problematic.

当然，有些决定应该完全凭感觉而不是逻辑来做。例如，一个人肯定会根据纯粹的情感因素来决定在客厅挂哪幅画或听哪种音乐。而一个人对人生伴侣的选择也主要是情感上的，尽管理性在这个决定中可能起着次要作用。（关于配偶选择，世界上有很多地方，完全不受自己控制的压力，比如父母的喜好，可能会控制一个人的决定。）

There are, of course, some sorts of decisions that should be made fully by feeling and not by logic. Thus, for instance, one would surely decide on the basis of purely emotional factors which painting to put up in the living room or what kind of music to listen to. And the choice of one’s life partner is mostly an emotional one, although reason may play a subordinate role in this decision. (Concerning mate choice, there are many parts of the world where pressures lying completely out of one’s own control, such as the preferences of one’s parents, may control one’s decision.)

另一方面，在很多类型的决定中，感情绝对不能被放任不管。这在涉及他人命运的决定中表现得最为明显。如果一名医生仅仅根据一时兴起，而不是根据广泛的技术培训和多年的经验来决定如何治疗患者，社会会如何看待他？或者想象一下，如果有关同性恋者在社会中的权利的法律 100% 由立法者的感情决定，会是什么样。

On the other hand, there are many types of decisions where feelings should definitely not be given free rein. This applies most clearly to decisions that involve the fates of other people. How would society look upon a doctor who decided how to treat patients on the basis of nothing but fleeting whims, rather than on the basis of extensive technical training and long years of experience? Or imagine if laws concerning the rights of homosexuals in society were 100 percent determined by the legislators’ feelings.

你总是相信自己最了解！但是没有人能比别人更好地解释自己的信仰。

You always believe that you know best! But no one can ever have better reasons for their beliefs than anyone else does.

这是一种普遍的观点，但完全是错误的。一个人的信仰理由可能比另一个人的信仰理由好得多。好的理由与公开的事实有关。如果你的观点与你掌握的信息一致，而我的观点只是随机产生的，那么你的想法比我的更有根据。那些声称水晶治疗和水晶疗法无效的人并不比那些声称水晶治疗和水晶疗法有效的人更武断。尽管前者更有根据，因此也是更合理的态度，但这种态度似乎让很多人感到困扰。

This is a common opinion, but it is completely wrong. One person can have far better reasons for their beliefs than another person does for theirs. Good reasons have to do with publicly available facts. If your viewpoint is in agreement with the information that is available to you, whereas my viewpoint was just plucked at random out of the blue, then your ideas are more grounded than mine are. People who state that crystal healing and crystal therapy do not work are not more dogmatic than those who state that crystal healing and crystal therapy do work. Although the former is the more grounded and thus the more reasonable attitude, such an attitude seems to trouble many people.

你如此怀疑，其实是对未知的恐惧，害怕失去立足点，跌入万丈深渊。

You who are so skeptical are actually frightened of the unknown, frightened of losing your footing and plummeting into an abyss.

这几乎不是事实。一个以事实判断为基础的世界观的人是一个思想开放、充满好奇心的人。好奇心、对知识的追求和科学研究实际上是理性的指导原则。新发现不断改变着我们对宇宙的认识。但是，那些不经过仔细论证就盲目跟风的人很可能害怕对自己的观点负责。

This is hardly true. Someone whose worldview is grounded in factual judgments is an open-minded and curious person. Curiosity, the pursuit of knowledge, and scientific research are in fact the lodestars of reason. New discoveries are constantly altering our picture of the universe. But people who will jump on board any old belief bandwagon, without requiring careful justification for their leap, are most likely frightened of taking responsibility for their opinions.

新时代运动劫持了某些观念，因为它们具有积极的含义。例如，“我是一个探索者”这句话是新时代运动的狂热者经常自豪地说出的。然而，它表明我们这些不是新时代运动的人不够开放、好奇、深刻或精神。相反，我们是肤浅、有限的人，对周围的世界不感兴趣；我们可能已经寻求真理一段时间，但已经放弃了。然而事实往往恰恰相反。也许我们这些非新时代运动的人应该说：“我们喜欢学习新事物；我们喜欢与那些知道我们一无所知的事情的人交流。相信一个人应该总是测试自己对各种话题的观点是积极和健康的。我们好奇并渴望新知识。这就是我们成为探索者的原因！”

The New Age movement has hijacked certain notions because they have positive connotations. For instance, the phrase “I am a seeker” is one that New Age–infatuated people often utter with pride. It suggests, however, that we who are not New Agers are not sufficiently open, curious, deep, or spiritual. Instead, we are superficial, limited people who aren’t interested in the world around us; we are people who may have sought the truth for a while, but who have given up. And yet the truth is often precisely the reverse. Perhaps we non–New Agers should say, “We love to learn new things; we delight in exchanges with people who know things of which we know nothing. It’s positive and healthy to be convinced that one should always test one’s viewpoints about various topics. We are curious and eager for new knowledge. And that’s what makes us seekers!”

我们这些不是新时代的人，是不断寻求事实、知识、洞察力、理解和经验的人。我们寻求的不是被欺骗庸医或江湖骗子。我们不寻求教条或非理性信仰的安全感。我们不寻求无法找到答案的地方。

We who are not New Agers are relentless seekers of facts, of knowledge, of insight, of understanding, and of experience. We seek not to be taken in by quacks or charlatans. We do not seek security in dogmas or irrational sets of beliefs. We do not seek answers where none can be found.

那些信奉新时代文化的人乐于认为自己很深奥，而认为我们只是肤浅的。但是，为什么新时代文化应该成为定义什么算作深奥、什么算作肤浅的参考点呢？许多新时代人都是探寻者，但探寻者的含义却截然不同；他们探寻的不是现实的真相。他们探寻的是一种能给他们带来心灵平静的信仰，而不是一种与世界真实情况相一致的信仰。

Those who espouse New Age culture are happy to think of themselves as deep, while thinking of us as merely superficial. But why should the New Age culture be the reference point for defining what counts as deep and what counts as shallow? Many New Agers are seekers in a quite different sense of the term; it is not truth about reality that they are seeking. What they are seeking is a type of faith that will give them peace of mind, as opposed to a faith that is consistent with the way the world truly is.

插曲：香格里拉的神秘土地

INTERLUDE: ON THE MYSTIC LAND OF SHANGRI-LA

地球上最美丽的土地是哪里？

What is the most beautiful land on earth?

香格里拉是英国作家詹姆斯希尔顿在 1933 年的小说《消失的地平线》中虚构的天堂。它被描述为位于西藏喜马拉雅山某处的一个深谷中。香格里拉的神话已被流行文化所取代，它变成了一个美丽的天堂，那里的人们永远不会变老，与自然和魔法永远和谐相处。西藏本身经常被描绘成真正的香格里拉，这片土地的传统可以追溯到几千年前，充满了古老的智慧和魔力。

Shangri-La is a fictitious paradise that was dreamed up by British writer James Hilton in his 1933 novel Lost Horizon. It was described as lying in a deep valley somewhere in the Tibetan Himalayas. The myth of Shangri-La has been taken over by popular culture, and it has turned into the vision of a beautiful, paradisial land where people never age and who live in permanent harmony with nature and with magic. Tibet itself has often been portrayed as being the true Shangri-La, a land whose traditions, going back many thousands of years, are filled with ancient wisdom and magic.

1999 年夏天，我在西藏荒野的帐篷里住了一个月。我去西藏是为了“偷运”几台电脑到青藏高原上的一所乡村小学校。我迫切地想亲眼看看这片被神话笼罩的土地，趁现在还来得及。

I spent one month of summer 1999 living out of a tent in the Tibetan wilderness. I had traveled to Tibet to “smuggle” a few computers into a little country school high up in the Tibetan plateau. I was eager to see for myself this myth-enshrouded land before it was too late.

西藏是我一生中去过的最美丽、最奇特的地方。阳光、群山、广阔的土地、动植物和西藏寺院给了我一种奇妙的体验，远远超出了平常。很容易理解为什么在西方世界，西藏仍然被浪漫地视为新时代的应许之地。

Tibet is the most beautiful and most exotic place I have ever visited in my life. The light, the mountains, the vast expanses, the flora and fauna, and the Tibetan monasteries gave me a wonderful experience, far beyond the ordinary. It is easy to understand why, in the Western world, there is still a romantic image of Tibet as the New Age’s promised land.

在我的旅途中，我有时会遇到其他外国人，他们来到西藏是为了实现自我，发展他们的精神世界。我特别记得我遇到的一位老太太。她想帮我处理相机里没电的电池，因为我们露营的西藏高原地区没有电（我们当时在海拔约一万七千英尺的地方）。这位女士相信她有神奇的力量，而且，既然我们在西藏，她的魔力应该比平常更强。她坐在壮观的山间湖泊旁，手里拿着我的电池，用她的灵能为它们充电。但不知为何，我的相机对她的灵能有抵抗力。尽管她试图给相机充电，但相机却无法工作，但幸运的是，尽管我没能用照片记录下那些风景、光线和自然美景，但今天我对那一天的记忆仍然和那天一样深刻。

During my trip, I sometimes met other foreigners who had come to Tibet to realize themselves and to develop their spiritual side. I remember particularly well an elderly lady I met. She wanted to help me with the dead batteries in my camera, since there was no electricity in the region of the Tibetan plateau where we were camping (we were at about seventeen thousand feet above sea level). This lady was convinced that she had magical powers, and moreover, since we were in Tibet, they should be even stronger than usual. She sat by the side of a spectacular mountain lake, holding my batteries in her hands to recharge them with her spiritual energy. For some reason, though, my camera was resistant to her spiritual energy. The camera refused to work despite her attempt to charge its batteries, but luckily, my memories of the landscape, the light, and the natural beauty are still just as strong today as that day, despite my having failed to capture them in photos.

1950 年，西藏被中国占领。1959 年，西藏的宗教和政治领袖达赖喇嘛逃离西藏，前往印度北部的达兰萨拉。达赖喇嘛不再是西藏的政治领袖。2011 年，他将这一职责移交给洛桑森格，后者现在是西藏流亡政府的总理。不过，达赖喇嘛仍然是西藏的宗教领袖。

Tibet was occupied by China in 1950, and in 1959, the country’s religious and political leader, the Dalai Lama, fled the country and went to Dharamsala in northern India. The Dalai Lama is no longer the country’s political leader; in 2011, he handed over that duty to Lobsang Sangay, who today is the prime minister in the exiled Tibetan government. The Dalai Lama remains, however, the country’s religious leader.

西藏拥有无与伦比的自然美景，但就人类生活条件而言，情况远没有那么美好。西藏是一个极其贫穷的国家；事实上，它的发展水平与十七世纪的瑞典相当。中国对藏人的压迫是严厉而残酷的。

Tibet has an unmatched physical beauty, but in terms of human living conditions, things are far less pristine. Tibet is an extremely poor country; in fact, its level of development is comparable to that of Sweden in the seventeenth century. The Chinese oppression of Tibetans is severe and brutal.

在我的这次旅行中，我认识了一位为流亡的西藏难民服务的西藏男子。多年后，他成为达赖喇嘛领导下的流亡政府的财政部长。几年前，他邀请我和妻子前往达兰萨拉会见西藏流亡政府。作为此次访问的一部分，他为我们安排了与流亡印度的西藏喇嘛嘉旺噶玛巴（即所谓的“噶玛巴喇嘛”）的会面。

In connection with my trip, I came to know a Tibetan man who was working for Tibetan refugees in exile. Many years later he became the finance minister in the exiled government under the leadership of the Dalai Lama. Several years ago he invited my wife and me to Dharamsala to meet the exiled Tibetan government. As part of that visit, he set up a meeting for us with Gyalwang Karmapa (the so-called “Karmapa Lama”), a Tibetan Lama who was living in exile in India.

嘉旺噶玛巴是藏传佛教最重要的教派之一噶玛噶举派的领袖。每一位新噶玛巴喇嘛都被认为是一位前任的转世。因此，嘉旺噶玛巴被认为是第十七世噶玛巴喇嘛，比第十四世达赖喇嘛“年长三世”。

Gyalwang Karmapa is the leader of the Karma Kagyu school, one of the most important schools of Tibetan Buddhism. Each new Karmapa Lama is believed to be the reincarnation of a predecessor. Gyalwang Karmapa is thus considered to be the seventeenth Karmapa Lama and, thus, “three reincarnations older” than the fourteenth Dalai Lama.

从很多方面来看，这是一次令人着迷的邂逅。一个从小就被不断重复的“自己是神”的话语包围的人，无法避免受到这种观点的影响。问题是这种影响是积极的还是消极的。

In many ways, this was a fascinating encounter. A man who grows up surrounded by constantly repeated statements that he is divine cannot avoid being influenced by this viewpoint. The question is whether the effect is positive or negative.

由于我不相信他在信徒眼中是神圣的，所以我们的会面很快就讨论了政治问题。

Since I did not believe that he was divine in any way except in the eye of believers, our meeting was soon taken up by political questions.

即使在我们这个地区，这种“尊贵”的喇嘛应该散发着精神智慧的光芒，这种印象非常强烈。在这次旅行开始的几周前，我在和一些朋友共进午餐时进行了以下对话。

The impression that a Lama of this great level of “dignity” should virtually glow with spiritual wisdom is very strong, even in our part of the world. Some weeks before the trip took place, the following dialogue played itself out over a lunch with some friends.

“当你有机会见到这位转世的神、这位圣人时，你一定要问一些关于灵性、神秘探索和内心旅程的深奥问题！”

“You’ll have to be sure to ask some deep questions about spirituality and the mystical quest and the inner voyage when you get the chance to meet this reincarnated god, this holy man!”

好吧，我不能不以略带严厉的语气回答：“不，我不打算问关于自我实现和内心旅程的肤浅和自我中心的问题。另一方面，我肯定会问他一些关于中国和西藏政治局势的敏感问题，以及中国在尊重西藏人权方面是否有任何进展。”

Well, I couldn’t let this comment go by without answering in a slightly harsh tone: “No, I don’t plan to ask superficial and self-absorbed questions about self-realization and the inner voyage. On the other hand, I will certainly ask him some touchy questions about the political situation involving China and Tibet, and whether there has been any progress in terms of China respecting human rights in Tibet.”

在西方的新时代圈子里，这种浪漫化——尤其是当它涉及到一个饱受压迫和欠发达的偏远国家时——有时会令人震惊。

This kind of romanticization, in New Age circles here in the West—especially when it involves a very remote country that is suffering from oppression and underdevelopment—can sometimes be shocking.

直到今天，我仍记得西藏是一种最罕见的自然体验，处于神秘主义的边缘。

To this day, I retain the memory of Tibet as a natural experience of the rarest sort, at the very edges of mysticism.

第二部分

Part II

通往新启蒙之路

THE PATHWAY TO A NEW ENLIGHTENMENT

第九章

CHAPTER NINE

当宗教脱离正轨时关于狂热主义、极端主义和基督教式塔利班主义

WHEN RELIGION RUNS OFF THE RAILS Concerning Fanaticism, Extremism, and Christian-Style Talibanism

不要以为我来是要把和平带到地上。我来并不是要带来和平，而是要带来刀剑。因为我来是要使人与父亲不和，女儿与母亲不和，媳妇与婆婆不和。人的仇敌就是自己家里的人。——马太福音 10:34–36（英王钦定本圣经）

Think not that I am come to send peace on earth: I came not to send peace, but a sword. For I am come to set a man at variance against his father, and the daughter against her mother, and the daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law. And a man’s foes shall be they of his own household.— Matthew 10:34–36 (King James Bible)

我在本书的前半部分，我试图描述清晰思考所需的基本要求。我的论点是，要清晰思考，我们人类需要对现实的本质、真理的本质以及相信某事的意义有所了解。我们还需要了解科学的运作方式：它的程序和方法。我指出了我们的大脑在许多方面容易产生幻想和不可靠，并主张将一个人的信仰建立在基于自然的现实之上，在这种现实中，善良不是来自天堂，而是来自我们自己。

I n this book’s first half, I have tried to describe the basic requirements that are needed to be able to think clearly. My thesis is that to think clearly, we humans need some understanding of the nature of reality, of the nature of truth, and of what it means to believe in something. We also need to understand the way that science works: its procedures and its methods. I have pointed out many ways in which our brains are fantasy prone and unreliable, and I have argued for basing one’s beliefs on a reality grounded in nature, a reality in which goodness comes not from heaven above but from within oneself.

然而，许多人，甚至许多非宗教人士，都坚信宗教和道德必然相互依赖。事实并非如此。宗教和道德可以自由存在，彼此独立。直白地说，好人可以是信徒，也可以是非信徒；坏人也可以是信徒，也可以是非信徒。或者反过来说，虔诚的人可以是道德的，也可以是不道德的；无神论者也可以是道德的，也可以是不道德的。认识到这些简单的事实是铺平新启蒙之路的关键先决条件。

And yet many people, even many nonreligious people, are convinced that religion and morality necessarily depend on each other. This simply is not the case. Religion and morality can freely exist, each one without the other. To state it in very blunt terms, good people can be believers or non-believers; bad people likewise can be believers or nonbelievers. Or, to turn it around, pious people can be moral or immoral; atheists likewise can be moral or immoral. Recognizing these simple facts is a key precondition for paving the way toward a new enlightenment.

在规划未来的道路之前，我们需要先熟悉当今世界最极端的宗教信仰。一旦我们敢于直面问题，我们就会意识到新的启蒙是多么迫切。

Before charting out the coming pathway, we need to familiarize ourselves with the most extreme sorts of religious beliefs that are found around the world today. Once we dare to face the problems squarely, we will realize how acute the need for a new enlightenment truly is.

上帝讨厌女人吗？

Does God Hate Women?

即使在今天，宗教也常常被视为所有“道德原则”的源泉，但这些原则却在世界各地不断贬低人类尊严。

Even today, religion is often seen as the fountainhead of all “moral principles,” yet these principles consistently degrade human dignity all around the world.

以宗教的名义对妇女进行普遍压迫是我们这个时代最普遍的侵犯人权行为。然而，对这一事实的普遍沉默与其广泛性成正比。这确实是一种令人难以理解的情况：毕竟，即使是婴儿，我们都学会了反抗压迫。我们中的许多人仍然记得 20 世纪南非的种族隔离制度；许多国家抗议南非对黑人的压迫，这种压迫的根源在于根据肤色划分人类。那么，我们今天怎么可能接受以宗教的名义进行的类似种族隔离——即基于性别的种族隔离和性压迫，而这些压迫在某些方面甚至比南非的种族隔离更为严重？

The universal oppression of women in the name of religion is our era’s most pervasive violation of human rights. And yet the widespread silence about this fact is proportional to its extensiveness. This is a truly incomprehensible situation: after all, even as infants we all learn to protest against oppression. Many of us still remember the South African apartheid regime in the twentieth century; many nations protested against South Africa’s oppression of black people, rooted in the division of humanity according to skin color. How, then, is it possible that we today accept a similar type of apartheid in the name of religion—namely, gender-based apartheid and sexual oppression, which in some ways are even more severe than the apart-heid in South Africa?

大多数宗教的核心都是一个创世故事，最终将女性描绘成低于男性。由此得出的结论是，男性和女性应该分开，应该以不同的方式对待——而且总是对男性有利。这导致男性拥有宗教的全部力量来支持他们控制社会及其法律的“权利”，这意味着女性的利益通常排在第二位。

Most religions have, at their core, a story of creation that winds up portraying woman as inferior to man. From this it follows that men and women should be separated and should be treated in different ways—and always to the advantage of men. This leads to males having the full weight of religion backing up their “right” to control society and its laws, which implies that women’s interests usually come in second place.

这当然对妇女造成了沉重打击。我们每天都能看到各种宗教教条以各种不同的方式践踏和压制妇女作为人类和公民应享有的不言而喻的权利。在世界上许多地方，妇女根本没有任何权利。在宗教渗透社会和立法的国家，或宗教最近才站稳脚跟的国家，情况尤其如此。这些国家典型的反女性歧视包括禁止堕胎、合法化强迫婚姻、纵容强奸和性侵犯，以及严格限制妇女的行动自由。此外，人们认为妇女的精神力量比男性弱，她们对自己的身体、生活、教育、经济自给自足、选择爱人和子女的法律控制权也较少。

This, of course, hits women hard. On a daily basis, we see evidence of how various religious dogmas, in many different ways, trample and squelch the self-evident right of women to be respected as human beings and citizens. In much of the world, women have no rights at all. This is particularly true in countries where religion permeates society and legislation, or where religion has recently taken a foothold. Typical of the anti-female discrimination in such lands are the outlawing of abortion, the legalization of forced marriage, the condoning of rape and sexual assault, and strict limitations on the mobility of women. Additionally, women are presumed to have less mental power than men, and they are given less legal control over their bodies, their lives, their education, their economic self-sufficiency, their choice of whom to love, and their children.

天主教会反对堕胎

The Catholic Church’s Opposition to Abortion

一个很好的例子就是人们对堕胎的态度。在世界许多地方，堕胎权是闻所未闻或受到极大限制的。

A good example of all this is one’s attitude toward abortion. In many parts of the world, the right to abortion is unheard of or exceedingly limited.

这种通过法律控制堕胎的做法导致了可怕的悲剧。因此，2007年，天主教国家尼加拉瓜通过了一项完全禁止堕胎的法律。结果，尼加拉瓜今天与智利和萨尔瓦多一起，享有世界上堕胎法最严格的荣誉。实施堕胎的医生会被判入狱。这不仅意味着妇女被禁止堕胎，而且她们不敢因怀孕并发症寻求医疗帮助。在这些国家，妇女害怕被指控试图自行堕胎，因为这也将受到法律的惩罚。

This type of abortion control through law leads to terrible tragedies. Thus in 2007, in the Catholic country of Nicaragua, a law was passed that totally prohibited abortion. As a result, Nicaragua today shares the honor, together with Chile and El Salvador, of having the strictest laws in the world concerning abortion. Doctors who carry out abortions are condemned to jail. This means not only that women are denied abortions but also that they don’t dare seek medical help for complications involved in pregnancy. In these countries, women are terrified of being accused of trying to induce their own abortions, because this, too, is punishable by law.

在萨尔瓦多，一名妇女在怀孕期间出现了危及生命的并发症，因试图自行堕胎而被判有罪，并因此被判入狱三十年。1

In El Salvador, a woman who had a life-threatening complication during her pregnancy was found guilty of having tried to induce her own abortion, and for this crime, she was sent to prison for thirty years.1

人权观察组织在其一份报告中发表了对一位年轻女子母亲的采访：

The organization Human Rights Watch, in one of its reports, published an interview with the mother of a young woman:

安吉拉 M. 22 岁的女儿是另一个例子。她因妊娠出血在马那瓜的一家公立医院待了好几天，但医院却一直没有对她进行治疗，尽管尼加拉瓜法律和指导方针规定，必须对这种危及生命的紧急情况进行治疗。2006 年 11 月，在全面禁止堕胎的法令实施几天后，安吉拉 M. 向人权观察组织讲述了医院明显缺乏关注的情况：“她一直在流血。所以我带她去了急诊室，但医生说她没什么问题。后来她感觉更糟了 [发烧和出血]，周二他们让她住院。他们给她打了点滴，她的血压很低。她说。‘妈妈，他们不给我治疗。’他们根本没有治疗，什么都没有。”

从当时医生的言论来看，Angela M. 认为她的女儿之所以得不到治疗，是因为医生们不愿意治疗与怀孕有关的紧急情况，因为他们担心自己可能会被指控提供治疗性流产。Angela M. 的女儿最终被转移到马那瓜的另一家公立医院，但为时已晚：“她死于心脏骤停。她全身发紫，无法辨认。就好像她根本不是我的女儿一样。” 2

Angela M.’s 22-year-old daughter is another case in point. Her pregnancy-related hemorrhaging was left untreated for days at a public hospital in Managua, despite the obligation, even under Nicaraguan law and guidelines, to treat such life-threatening emergencies. In November 2006, only days after the blanket ban on abortion was implemented, Angela M. told Human Rights Watch of the pronounced lack of attention: “She was bleeding. That’s why I took her to the emergency room but the doctors said that she didn’t have anything. Then she felt worse [with fever and hemorrhaging] and on Tuesday they admitted her. They put her on an IV and her blood pressure was low. She said. ‘Mami, they are not treating me.’ They didn’t treat at all, nothing.”

From comments made by the doctors at the time, Angela M. believes her daughter was left untreated because doctors were reluctant to treat a pregnancy-related emergency for fear that they might be accused of providing therapeutic abortion. Angela M.’s daughter was finally transferred to another public hospital in Managua, but too late: “She died of cardiac arrest. She was all purple, unrecognizable. It was like it wasn’t my daughter at all.”2

犹太教中的性别隔离

Sexual Apartheid in Judaism

2008 年，耶路撒冷一名年轻女子遭到几名极端正统犹太青年的袭击。他们闯入她的公寓，要求她立即搬离，声称有人在公司里发现了她一名未婚男子的尸体。他们让她闭上眼睛，并告诉她，如果她睁开眼睛，他们就会用催泪瓦斯刺伤她，弄瞎她的眼睛。然后他们强迫她说出她遇到的那个男人的名字。强行闯入她公寓的这群人属于极端正统的“道德警察” 。3

In Jerusalem in 2008, a young woman was assaulted by several ultraorthodox young Jewish men. They broke into her apartment and demanded that she immediately move out of it, claiming she had been observed in the company of an unmarried man. They made her shut her eyes and told her they would stab her and blind her with tear gas if she opened them. Then they forced her to reveal the name of the man she had met. The group that made the forced entry into her apartment belonged to the ultraorthodox “Morality Police.”3

在耶路撒冷某些极端正统的地区，女性被要求坐在公交车的最后面，与男性完全分开，还被告知她们不能和男性走在街道的同一侧。4作家 Jackie Jakubowski 在一篇关于极端正统犹太教拉比在以色列影响力日益增强的编年史中写道：

In certain ultraorthodox districts in Jerusalem, women are required to sit at the very back of buses, totally apart from men, and they are also told that they cannot walk on the same side of the street as men.4 Writer Jackie Jakubowski wrote, in a chronicle about the rising influence of ultraorthodox rabbis in Israel:

正统派拉比已经成为以色列自己的小教皇组织，他们认为自己垄断了犹太教，并声称有权影响国内政治（妇女地位和公民权利）和外交政策（定居点、占领、和平谈判）——他们的观点以某些属于完全不同时代的极端正统派拉比的言论为基础。5

The orthodox rabbinacy has become Israel’s own little papacy, which considers itself to have a monopoly on Judaism, and which claims the right to influence both domestic politics (women’s status and their civil rights) and foreign policy (settlements, occupation, peace negotiations)—basing their ideas on statements by certain ultraorthodox rabbis, belonging to a completely different era.5

简而言之，每当宗教对周围环境的影响力增强时，女性总是最大的失败者。

In short, whenever religion’s influence on its surroundings increases, women invariably wind up being the biggest losers.

伊斯兰教法和开罗宣言

Sharia and the Cairo Declaration

在传统伊斯兰教及其被称为伊斯兰主义的政治分支中，男女之间存在着明显的区分。伊斯兰主义通过所谓的“沙里亚法”来维持对妇女的压迫。“沙里亚”的粗略翻译意思是“神圣的法律”，它包括《古兰经》和先知穆罕默德的圣训（传统），这些传统可以在《圣训》中找到——圣训是描述穆罕默德生活和生活方式的文本。《古兰经》和圣训包含伊斯兰教的一般和详细戒律。《古兰经》据称是真主向穆罕默德启示的话语。圣训是对《古兰经》的补充，澄清、解释并使其总体思想更加精确。

In traditional Islam and its political branch known as Islamicism, there is a clear separation between men and women. Islamicism maintains the oppression of women through so-called “Sharia laws.” Roughly translated, “Sharia” means “the divine laws,” and it consists of the Koran and the sunna (traditions) of the prophet Muhammad, which are found in the haditherna—texts that describe Muhammad’s life and way of living. The Koran and the sunna contain Islam’s precepts, both general and detailed. The Koran is claimed to be the word of God, as revealed to Muhammad. The sunna act as a complement to the Koran, clarifying, interpreting, and making more precise its overarching ideas.

伊斯兰教法的法理部分称为fiqh，它源自两套称为usul（“根”）的主要来源，旨在用于解决社会纠纷。6

The jurisprudential part of Sharia is called fiqh, which grew from two sets of primary sources called usul (“roots”) and were intended to be used in the settlement of social disputes.6

对于伊斯兰教法的解释有很多不同的学派，而且解释差别很大。

There are many different schools of interpretation of Sharia, and the interpretations differ greatly.

阿拉伯语单词“sunna”指的是根据穆罕默德在世时所说、所做和所认可的事情而形成的传统。伊斯兰教法可分为三大类：

The Arabic word sunna refers to traditions that were formed and based on what Muhammad said, did, and approved of during his lifetime. Sharia laws can be classified under three main rubrics:

  1. 伊巴达特（Ibadat）：规范礼拜的规范。
  2. Ibadat: Norms regulating worship.
  3. Muamlat：民事和法律义务。
  4. Muamlat: Civil and legal obligations.
  5. 乌库巴特：惩罚。
  6. Uqubat: Punishments.

在不同伊斯兰国家，伊斯兰教法适用程度不同，例如在沙特阿拉伯，伊斯兰教法是最基本的法律体系，伊朗刑法和家庭法则有很大一部分以伊斯兰教法为基础；而在埃及，伊斯兰教法仅被视为实际立法的灵感来源。

Sharia law applies to different degrees in different Islamic countries. In Saudi Arabia, for instance, Sharia constitutes the most basic set of laws, while large parts of Iranian criminal law and family law build on Sharia; and in Egypt, Sharia law is merely seen as a source of inspiration for actual legislation.

在某些伊斯兰国家，伊斯兰教法主要适用于家庭法，而在伊朗等其他国家，它适用于犯罪和量刑。尽管对伊斯兰教法的解释千差万别，但伊斯兰教法在当今整个伊斯兰世界中都发挥着强大的规范力量。这意味着伊斯兰教法控制着伊斯兰国家数亿人的日常生活。

In certain Islamic countries, Sharia is applied mainly to family law, while in others, such as Iran, it applies to crimes and sentencing. Although its interpretations vary greatly, Sharia acts as a powerful normative force all across the Islamic world today. This implies that Sharia controls the day-to-day lives of hundreds of millions of people in Islamic lands.

如今，穆斯林世界的知识分子之间一直在争论如何解释和应用伊斯兰教法。一些人声称，伊斯兰教法只在制定的时代有效，今天应该根据现代对人权的理解进行调整。另一些人则认为，这些法律是“上帝赐予的”，因此是永恒的，不能也不应该在现代背景下重新解释。

These days there is an ongoing debate among intellectuals in the Muslim world about how Sharia should be interpreted and applied. Some claim that Sharia laws were valid only in the era in which they were created, and that today they should be adapted to modern understandings of human rights. Others maintain that the laws are “God given” and are thus eternal, and cannot and should not be reinterpreted in a modern context.

最受争议的伊斯兰教法是那些涉及鞭刑、残害和石刑的法条。欧洲在这一问题上的主要辩论者之一是牛津大学伊斯兰教教授塔里克·拉马丹，他的研究领域是伊斯兰教及其在现代的诠释。2005 年，他敦促伊斯兰世界暂停所有此类惩罚，直到穆斯林学者能够就如何在现代背景下解释伊斯兰教法达成一致。

The most debated of Sharia laws are those that concern the punishments of whipping, mutilation, and stoning. One of Europe’s leading debaters on this topic is Islamic professor Tariq Ramadan at Oxford University, whose research area is Islam and its interpretations in modern days. In 2005, he urged the Islamic world to suspend all such punishments until Muslim scholars could come to an agreement about how to interpret Sharia in a modern context.

在西方国家，人们普遍提倡辩论中的言论自由，这不仅包括批评思想和行为的权利，还包括尊重个人的责任。换言之，个人有权控制自己的生活、身体和良心，有权表达自己的意见，但必须接受对自己意见的批评。

In Western lands, there is general advocacy of freedom of speech in debates, which includes not only the right to criticize ideologies and actions but also the duty to maintain respect for individuals. In other words, individuals have the right to control their lives, their bodies, and their consciences, as well as the right to express their opinions, but they have to accept criticisms of their opinions.

相反，根据保守派对伊斯兰教法的解释，伊斯兰社会的法律不容置疑——它们是不可侵犯的。根据根据这些解释，任何亵渎神明或生活不公的人都会受到惩罚，这可能意味着失去他们的社会地位，或失去身体的一部分，甚至可能失去他们的整个生命。因此，尊重伊斯兰教和群体比尊重个人更重要。

According to conservative interpretations of Sharia law, by contrast, the laws of Islamic society cannot be questioned—they are inviolable. According to these interpretations, anyone who commits blasphemy or who lives un-righteously can be punished, which can mean a loss of their social status, or of parts of their body, or possibly even of their entire life. Respect for Islam and for the group is thus more important than respect for individuals.

1990 年，在开罗举行的伊斯兰合作组织 (OIC) ( https://www.oic-oci.org ) 会议上，约 57 个伊斯兰成员国批准了《开罗伊斯兰人权宣言》。7该宣言在某种程度上仿照了联合国的《世界人权宣言》，两份文件在很多段落中非常相似，但在某些关键领域，《开罗宣言》与联合国宣言存在根本性差异。《开罗宣言》指出，伊斯兰教法是“唯一的参考来源”。

In a meeting of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) (https://www.oic-oci.org) in Cairo in 1990, some fifty-seven Islamic member countries ratified the Cairo Declaration of Human Rights in Islam.7 This declaration was to some extent modeled on the United Nations’ Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and there are long passages where the two documents resemble each other greatly, but in certain key areas, the Cairo Declaration diverges radically from the United Nations declaration. The Cairo Declaration states that Sharia law is the “only source of reference.”

虽然哈乃斐派伊斯兰教法（逊尼派四大教法学派之一）明确禁止对非穆斯林犯下的亵渎罪判处死刑，但它规定，任何被判犯有亵渎罪的穆斯林都应被处决。8

While the Hanafi School of Islamic Law (one of the four Sunni schools of fiqh) explicitly bars the death penalty for blasphemy committed by non-Muslims, it states that any Muslim who is convicted of blasphemy should be executed.8

尤其是，人权从根本上服从于伊斯兰教法。例如，在《开罗宣言》第 22 条中，我们读到以下内容：

In particular, human rights are essentially made subordinate to Sharia laws. For example, in article 22 of the Cairo Declaration, we read the following:

  1. 每个人都有权以不违背伊斯兰教法原则的方式自由表达自己的观点。
  2. Everyone shall have the right to express his opinion freely in such manner as would not be contrary to the principles of the Shari’a.
  3. 每个人都有权按照伊斯兰教法的规范倡导正义、宣传善良、抵制错误和邪恶。
  4. Everyone shall have the right to advocate what is right, and propagate what is good, and warn against what is wrong and evil according to the norms of Islamic Shari’a.
  5. 信息是社会的必需品。不得利用或滥用信息，以致违反神圣性和先知的尊严，破坏道德和伦理价值观，或瓦解、腐蚀或伤害社会，或削弱其信仰。9
  6. Information is a vital necessity to society. It may not be exploited or misused in such a way as may violate sanctities and the dignity of Prophets, undermine moral and ethical values or disintegrate, corrupt or harm society or weaken its faith.9

《开罗宣言》第二条第（a）款和第（d）款规定：

Clauses (a) and (d) from Article 2 of the Cairo Declaration state:

一个。生命是上帝赐予的礼物，每个人都享有生存的权利。保护这一权利不受侵犯是个人、社会和国家的责任，除非出于伊斯兰教法规定的原因，否则禁止剥夺生命。

a. Life is a God-given gift and the right to life is guaranteed to every human being. It is the duty of individuals, societies and state to protect this right from any violation, and it is prohibited to take away life except for a Shari’a prescribed reason.

d.免受人身伤害的安全是一项有保障的权利。国家有义务保障这一权利，禁止在没有法律规定的理由的情况下侵犯这一权利。10

d. Safety from bodily harm is a guaranteed right. It is the duty of the state to safeguard it, and it is prohibited to breach it without a Chore-prescribed reason.10

塞内加尔穆斯林法学家、前联合国人权委员会秘书长阿达马·迪昂在1991年宣称，《开罗伊斯兰人权宣言》以维护人权的名义，对非穆斯林和妇女引入了不可容忍的歧视形式，同时故意对某些基本权利和自由采取限制性措施。他还认为，《开罗宣言》在伊斯兰教法的掩护下，合法化了体罚等行为，同时攻击了人类的完整性和尊严。11

Adama Dieng, a Senegalese Muslim jurist and former secretary-general of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights declared in 1991 that, in the name of the defense of human rights, the Cairo Declaration of Human Rights in Islam introduced intolerable forms of discrimination against non-Muslims and women, while deliberately taking a restrictive approach concerning certain fundamental rights and freedoms. He also opined that the Cairo Declaration, under the cover of Sharia law, gave legitimacy to practices like corporal punishment while attacking the integrity and dignity of humans.11

《开罗宣言》严重限制了言论自由权。由于一旦违反伊斯兰教法，一个人就会失去所有权利，因此该宣言对个人的保护具有极大的误导性。此外，宣言还敦促所有个人推广伊斯兰教法，并对任何被认为不正确的事情提出警告，这让每个人都成为了道德的守护者，或者道德警察的一员。

The Cairo Declaration severely limits the right to free expression. Since one loses all one’s rights as soon as one violates Sharia laws, the declaration’s protection for individuals is highly misleading. Moreover, all individuals are urged to promote Sharia and to warn of anything that is not considered correct, which turns each individual into a guardian of morality, or a member of the moral police.

伊斯兰教法对男女有所区分。根据伊斯兰教法的某些解释，女性无权自己做决定。相反，她必须依靠男性“监护人”或“保护者”，即她的父亲、丈夫、兄弟或最亲近的男性亲属。

Sharia makes a distinction between men and women. In certain interpretations of Sharia, a woman doesn’t have the right to make her own decisions. Instead, she must rely on male “guardians” or “protectors,” meaning either her father, her husband, her brother, or the next-closest male relative.

一些观察家不遗余力地指出，伊斯兰教法也包含有利于妇女的法律，例如丈夫必须供养妻子（！）并支付她们的生活费。但这几乎无关紧要；无论谁在各方面受到“优待”，该制度都维持着性别隔离。实际上，这意味着被丈夫和其他亲属拒绝的妇女完全得不到支持。

Some observers have taken pains to point out that Sharia also contains laws in favor of women, such as the fact that the husband is required to provide for his wives (!) and pay for their upkeep. But this is hardly relevant; the system maintains sexual apartheid, regardless of who is “favored” in various manners. In practice, this means that a woman who has been rejected by her husband and her other relatives is completely without support.

已婚妇女必须顺从丈夫的性欲。长期的传统规定了如果妻子拒绝满足丈夫，丈夫应该采取哪些措施。首先，他应该试着和妻子讲道理；如果这不能改变她的想法，那么他和她应该开始分房睡觉；最后，如果问题仍然存在，那么他有权殴打她。顺便说一句，根据伊斯兰教法，婚内强奸不被视为犯罪。

A married woman must accede to her husband’s sexual desires. Longstanding traditions define the steps the husband should take if his wife refuses to satisfy him. First, he should try to reason with her; if that does not change her mind, then he and she should start sleeping in separate rooms; and finally, if the problem persists, then he has the right to beat her. Incidentally, under Sharia, rape inside marriage is not considered to be a crime.

根据对沙里亚法的标准解释，以及伊斯兰教法的四个基本流派，穆斯林妇女不得与非穆斯林男子结婚（在这种情况下，除非该男子皈依伊斯兰教，否则婚姻无效），而穆斯林男子则可以与任何妇女结婚，只要她属于三个“亚伯拉罕教”（即伊斯兰教、犹太教或基督教）之一。在某些穆斯林国家，男人比妻子更有机会起诉离婚；只有在丈夫不支付她的生活费、患有精神疾病、依赖他人的情况下，她才能与丈夫离婚吸毒，或者阳痿。12但是丈夫可以在妻子不在场的情况下离婚，这意味着一个女人可能会在没有任何预兆的情况下与丈夫离婚——突然间陷入困境并且没有任何形式的支持系统。

According to the standard interpretation of Sharia, and according to all four fundamental schools of Islamic law, a Muslim woman is not allowed to marry a non-Muslim man (in such a case, the marriage is invalid unless he converts to Islam), whereas a Muslim man is allowed to marry any woman at all, as long as she belongs to one of the three “Abrahamic faiths” (that is, Islam, Judaism, or Christianity). In certain Muslim countries, a man has a better chance of suing for divorce than his wife does; she can divorce her husband only if he is not paying for her upkeep, is mentally ill, is dependent on drugs, or is impotent.12 But the husband can divorce his wife in her absence, which means that a woman can find herself divorced from her husband without any forewarning—all of a sudden out in the cold and without any kind of support system.

哈乃斐派对伊斯兰教法的一些解释导致女性的价值被认为只有男性的一半。兄弟被视为家庭的供养者，因此继承的财产是姐妹的两倍。同样的偏见也出现在某些法律情况下，例如作证犯罪。例如，在伊朗，任何男性都被认为是可靠的证人，但需要两名女性才能算作一名可靠的证人。13

A consequence of some Hanafi interpretations of Sharia is that a woman is considered to have half the worth of a man. Brothers, since they are considered to be family providers, inherit twice as much as their sisters do. This same bias also turns up in certain legal situations, such as testifying about a crime. In Iran, for example, any man is considered to be a reliable witness, but it takes two women to count as one reliable witness.13

这种对待女性的态度可能会导致荒谬的后果——例如，在谋杀案审判中。谋杀另一名男子的男子将被判处死刑。但如果一名男子谋杀一名女子并被判处死刑，那么在司法系统执行死刑之前，该女子的家人必须先向凶手的家人支付该男子一半的财产。由于该男子仅仅杀死了“半个人”，因此该女子的家人必须弥补凶手家人即将遭受的经济损失。14

This attitude toward women can lead to absurd consequences—for instance, when it comes to murder trials. A man who murders another man will be sentenced to death. But if a man murders a woman and is sentenced to death, then before the judicial system will carry out the execution, the woman’s family first has to pay the murderer’s family half of the man’s financial worth. As the man has merely killed “half a human,” the woman’s family is required to make up for the imminent financial loss to the murderer’s family.14

在伊朗，被判处石刑的男子和女子不会受到相同的惩罚。男子将被埋在地下，只露出腰部，露出双臂，而女子将被埋到脖子以下。15

In Iran, a man and a woman who have been sentenced to be stoned to death will not be punished identically. The man will be buried in the ground up to his waist, leaving his arms free, whereas the woman will be buried all the way up to her neck.15

某些国家有关于如何投掷石块的习俗：投掷石块的大小不得超过投掷者一只手可以握住的距离。这确保了受害者不会在投掷一块石块后死亡。现在，一个半埋的男人显然比女人更有可能用手臂保护自己。如果被告侥幸在被石块砸中后幸存下​​来，那么这个人就被认为是无辜的——当然，幸存下来的往往是男人。

Certain countries have a custom about how the stoning should be carried out: no stone can be larger than a thrower can hold in a single hand. This ensures that the victim will not die after the throwing of just one stone. Now a man who is only half buried obviously has a greater chance of protecting himself, using his arms, than does the woman. If by some chance an accused person survives being stoned, then that person is considered to be innocent—and of course it is men who survive much more often.

宗教与传统：妇女受压迫问题研究

Religion and Tradition: A Study in the Oppression of Women

根据《古兰经》，任何女性都必须遮盖自己，但遮盖到什么程度尚有争议。每个女性都必须戴面纱，以躲避那些不是她“保护者”的男性的视线。当然，这样做是为了不激起其他男性的性欲。因此，女性必须承担不被强奸的责任。

According to the Koran, any woman must cover herself, but to what extent is a matter of debate. Each woman must be veiled in order to hide herself from the view of men who are not her “protectors.” The reason, of course, is that she should not arouse other men’s sexual drives. It is thus the woman who must take the responsibility for not getting raped.

传统的宗教服饰，如犹太人的犹太小帽和锡克教徒的头巾，与一个人与宗教和社会的关系有关。但面纱则相反，象征着女人与男人的关系。如果她不遮住自己，那么她就会被认为试图引诱男人。这种假设当然是对相关女性的冒犯，但也是对于男性的侮辱，因为他们被认为无法控制自己的欲望。当一个年轻女孩被迫戴上面纱时，这一行为使她变得性感，也就是说，这意味着她已经被视为一个性感的人。因此，面纱不仅仅是一件衣服；它是整个伊斯兰教法体系对女性观点的象征。 （当然，西方女性所穿的比基尼和许多其他类型的暴露服装也将女性性感化——从而象征着西方对女性的集体看法，这种看法与基于伊斯兰教法的看法一样具有性别歧视。因此，在这种深刻的不对称中存在着一种奇怪的“对称性”。）

Traditional religious articles of clothing, such as yarmulkes for Jews and turbans for Sikhs, have to do with one’s relationship to one’s religion and one’s community. But a veil, by contrast, is a symbol of a woman’s relationship to a man. If she doesn’t cover herself, then she is assumed to be trying to lure men to herself. This assumption is of course offensive to the woman concerned, but it is also an insult to men, who are presumed to be incapable of controlling their lust. When a young girl is made to don a veil, that act sexualizes her, which is to say, it implies that she is already considered to be a sexual being. A veil is thus more than just an article of clothing; it is a symbol of the entire Sharia system’s view of women. (Of course, bikinis and many other types of revealing garments worn by women in the Western world also sexualize women—and thereby symbolize the West’s collective view of women, which is no less sexist than the Sharia-based view. There is thus a strange sort of “symmetry” in this profound asymmetry.)

20 世纪 60 年代的中东社会比现在更加自由。这一点可以从女性的着装风格等诸多方面看出。当时，女性穿裙子、化妆、上大学。然而，今天，街上到处都是蒙面女性。自 1979 年伊朗革命和 20 世纪 80 年代类似的伊斯兰主义夺取政权以来，伊斯兰教法取得了更大的进展。仅仅二十年时间，钟摆就摆到了强制戴面纱的地步，从而让女性服从男性。

In the 1960s, Middle Eastern societies were freer than they are today. This fact could be seen in such things as the way women dressed. In those days, women wore skirts, used makeup, and attended universities. Today, however, the streets are filled with women whose faces are covered. Ever since the Iranian revolution in 1979, and similar Islamist seizures of power during the 1980s, Sharia has made even more inroads. In only two decades, the pendulum has swung over to the mandatory wearing of veils and, thus, to female submission to men.

宗教对妇女的压迫就像一条红线贯穿了我们西方社会的历史。妇女被烧死在火刑柱上，被迫保持贞洁，被迫在集会上保持沉默，被剥夺投票权，并因未婚生子而被抛弃。西方社会花了数百年的时间才超越了这种对妇女的看法，但慢慢地，旧传统让位于人权，法律也得以制定，形成了更平等的社会。

Religious oppression of women runs like a red thread through the history of our Western societies. Women have been burned at the stake, pushed toward chastity, forced to remain silent in gatherings, denied the right to vote, and cast to the winds for having children out of wedlock. It has taken Western societies hundreds of years to transcend such views of women, but very slowly, the old traditions have given way to human rights, and laws have been created that form a more equal society.

仅仅因为男性至上主义的教义可以追溯到很久以前，就为反女性的传统和文化方面辩护是没有道理的。仅仅因为某件事是长期存在的传统，并不意味着它总是可以辩护的。事实上恰恰相反：如果某件事是传统，那就更有理由质疑它，并对其进行更严格的审查。

It is not justifiable to defend anti-female traditions and aspects of culture simply because the doctrine of male supremacy stretches way, way back into the past. The mere fact that something is a long-standing tradition doesn’t always mean it is defensible. Quite to the contrary, in fact: if something is a tradition, that is all the more reason to question it and give it even greater scrutiny.

在当今所有政治话题中，宗教社会对女性的系统性压制是最受关注的话题之一。许多人都在谈论“宗教自由”，但很少有人谈论这可能会带来什么真正的意思是。人们应该认真对待这个问题，并界定宗教自由的界限；否则，我们最终将回到历史上可耻的时期，类似于南非可耻的种族隔离。如果我们记住世界各地以宗教的名义对待妇女的方式，就很难避免得出上帝一定讨厌妇女的结论。

The systematic subjection of women in rigidly religious societies is among the most highly charged of all political topics today. Many people speak of “religious freedom,” but precious few speak of what that might ac tually mean. People should take the question seriously and define the limits of religious freedom; otherwise we will wind up returning to the shameful period of our history, analogous to South Africa’s shameful apartheid. If we keep in mind how women are treated in the name of religion throughout the world, it’s hard to avoid drawing the conclusion that God must hate women.

亵渎、叛教和言论自由

Blasphemy, Apostasy, and Freedom of Speech

根据盖洛普 2012 年的一项民意调查，全球约 13% 的人自称是无神论者，23% 的人表示自己没有宗教信仰。约 59% 的人自称有宗教信仰。

According to a Gallup poll conducted in 2012,16 roughly 13 percent of the world’s population call themselves atheists, while 23 percent say they are nonreligious. Approximately 59 percent describe themselves as religious.

无神论者和非宗教人士的比例似乎一直在增长。自 2005 年以来，自称无神论者的人数增加了 3 个百分点，而宗教人士的比例则下降了 9 个百分点。

The proportion of atheists and nonreligious people seems to be growing throughout time. Since 2005, the number of people calling themselves atheists has gone up by three percentage points, and the percentage of religious people has gone down by nine points.

尽管存在这些趋势，但如今批评宗教可能非常危险。在许多国家，质疑上帝的存在或批评各种宗教解释和表达实际上是违法的。近年来，在孟加拉国、埃及、印度尼西亚、伊朗、科威特、巴基斯坦和土耳其（仅举几个例子），都有人因亵渎神灵（侮辱神圣的事物）而被捕。

Despite these trends, criticizing religion today can be very dangerous. There are many countries in which it is actually illegal to question God’s existence or to criticize various religious interpretations and expressions. In recent years, people have been arrested for the crime of blasphemy (insulting something holy) in Bangladesh, Egypt, Indonesia, Iran, Kuwait, Pakistan, and Turkey (to name just a few examples).

然而，在某些国家的司法制度中，亵渎神明是非法的，但这并不能反映与之相关的广泛风险。亵渎神明者的危险来源有三种：（1）国家层面的行为者，（2）非国家行为者，（3）整个社会。

The illegality of blasphemy in certain lands’ judicial systems, however, doesn’t capture the broad range of risks associated with it. The sources of danger to those who commit blasphemy are of three different sorts: (1) actors at the state level, (2) non-state actors, and (3) the society at large.

2010 年，巴基斯坦一名基督教女性阿萨亚·比比因侮辱伊斯兰教先知被判处死刑，这是亵渎神明在国家层面受到惩罚的典型例子。阿萨亚·比比被关押了八年，但 2018 年，她终于被巴基斯坦最高法院释放。这一决定引发了伊斯兰组织的强烈抗议，要求公开处决她。据报道，她目前被关押在巴基斯坦境内一个未公开但安全的地点。许多西方国家都为她提供了庇护。

In 2010, in Pakistan, Asia Bibi, a Christian woman, was sentenced to death for insulting Islam’s prophet; this is a typical example of repercussions at the state level for blasphemy. Asia Bibi was held on death row for eight years, but in 2018, she was at last released by Pakistan’s Supreme Court. This decision sparked furious protests by Islamist groups demanding her public execution. She is currently reported to be detained in an undisclosed but secure location inside Pakistan. Many Western countries have offered her asylum.

此案还有其他非常危险的方面，特别是来自非国家行为者和个人行为者，在某些情况下甚至比国家司法体系判处的刑罚更危险。

There are other very dangerous aspects of this case, coming notably from non-state and individual actors, which in some cases are even more dangerous than the sentence imposed by the state’s legal system.

2011 年 1 月 4 日，时任旁遮普省省长、巴基斯坦最有影响力的政治家之一萨尔曼·塔西尔（他曾是巴基斯坦人民党部长塔西尔·阿卜杜拉·阿卜杜拉在露天市场被其保镖穆姆塔兹·卡德里用 AK-47 步枪向塔西尔开了 27 枪。《卫报》17 频道将这次枪杀事件描述为“巴基斯坦历史上最令人痛心的事件之一”。巴基斯坦政府随后宣布全国哀悼三天。

On January 4, 2011, Salman Taseer, at the time the governor of Punjab province, and one of the most influential politicians in Pakistan (he had been a minister of the Pakistan People’s Party), was killed in an open marketplace by Mumtaz Qadri, one of his own bodyguards, who shot Taseer twenty-seven times with an AK-47 rifle. The Guardian17 described the killing as “one of the most traumatic events in Pakistan’s history.” In its wake, the Pakistani government proclaimed a three-day nationwide period of mourning.

塔西尔被暗杀的原因是他直言不讳地批评巴基斯坦的亵渎法，尤其是批评法院对阿萨亚·比比的判决。塔西尔是一名自由派穆斯林，在他死后，五百名伊斯兰教士表示支持对他进行残酷谋杀，并敦促公众抵制他的葬礼。18这件事​​发生在政府哀悼期间。必须强调的是，最大的危险来自非国家行为者和社会领域。

The reason behind Taseer’s assassination was his outspoken criticism of Pakistan’s blasphemy law and, in particular, his criticism of the court’s verdict against Asia Bibi. Following the death of Taseer, who was a liberal Muslim, five hundred Islamic clerics voiced their support for his brutal murder and urged the public to boycott his funeral.18 This took place during the governmental mourning period. It is crucial to underline that the greatest dangers came from non-state actors and from the societal arena.

2016 年，塔西尔的刺客穆姆塔兹·卡德里被处决，约有两万五千人聚集在一起纪念他的死亡。这次集会导致支持杀害塔西尔的宗教党派和团体在全国范围内发动暴力活动，不得不出动武装部队驱散抗议者。

When Taseer’s assassin Mumtaz Qadri was executed in 2016, some twenty-five thousand people gathered to commemorate his death. This gathering led to countrywide violence by religious parties and groups that supported the killing of Taseer, and armed forces had to be called to disperse the protestors.

另一起引人注目的谋杀案也与阿萨亚·比比案有关。巴基斯坦少数民族事务部长、国家内阁中唯一的基督教成员沙赫巴兹·巴蒂于 2011 年 3 月 2 日遭枪杀，此时距离塔西尔遇刺仅两个月。自从阿萨亚·比比案判决以来，巴蒂因批评亵渎法而多次受到威胁。在去世前，他谈到了自己因坚定支持阿萨亚·比比而收到的死亡威胁，他知道这些威胁来自塔利班和基地组织。

Another notable killing was also connected to the case of Asia Bibi. Shahbaz Bhatti—Pakistan’s minister for minority affairs and the only Christian member of the nation’s cabinet—was shot dead on March 2, 2011, two months after the assassination of Taseer. Ever since the ruling on Asia Bibi’s case, Bhatti had been repeatedly threatened for his criticism of the blasphemy law. Before his death, he spoke about the death threats that he was receiving for his staunch support of Asia Bibi, and he knew that these threats came from the Taliban and al-Qaeda.

萨尔曼·塔西尔遇刺七个月后，他的儿子沙巴兹·塔西尔被塔利班组织绑架，被囚禁五年后才获释。19

Seven months later after Salman Taseer’s assassination, his son Shabaaz Taseer was abducted by a Taliban group and was only released after five years of captivity.19

虽然亵渎指控可能会导致宗教少数派成员在巴基斯坦和阿富汗等国家遭受可怕的法律后果，但这种虚假指控甚至会对虔诚的穆斯林造成严重伤害。穆斯林女性 Farkhunda Malikzada（来自阿富汗）和 Mashal Khan（来自巴基斯坦）的案件就是两个显著的​​例子。

While an accusation of blasphemy may lead to members of religious minorities suffering horrific legal consequences in countries like Pakistan and Afghanistan, false accusations of this sort can cause serious harm even to practicing Muslims. Two notable examples of this are the cases of the Muslim women Farkhunda Malikzada (from Afghanistan) and Mashal Khan (from Pakistan).

2015 年，马利克扎达被诬告焚烧《古兰经》的部分页面。马利克扎达在被暴徒私刑处死时戴着伊斯兰面纱，她是一名宗教研究毕业生，在当地一所伊斯兰宗教学校担任教师。她曾与一名穆斯林发生争执她与当地清真寺的阿訇就其他问题发生争执，结果她被指控焚烧《古兰经》。针对这一指控，马利克扎达表示，她是一名穆斯林，穆斯林不会焚烧《古兰经》。然而，对她的指控引发了谣言，一大群人聚集起来惩罚她；她被石头砸死，在一条公开的街道上被烧死。杀人时，现场有警察。

In 2015, Malikzada was falsely accused of burning some pages of the Koran. Malikzada, who was wearing an Islamic veil at the time of her death by mob lynching, was a religious studies graduate, and she had a teaching position at a local Islamic religious school. She had engaged in an altercation about other issues with the imam of a local mosque, and as a result, she was subsequently accused of burning the Koran. In response to this allegation, Malikzada stated that she was a Muslim and that Muslims do not burn the Koran. The accusation against her led to a rumor, however, and a large crowd formed to punish her; she was stoned and burned to death in an open street. At the time of the killing, there were police at the scene.

在这起残忍的杀戮事件发生后不久，喀布尔警察局长办公室发言人哈什马特·斯坦尼克扎伊在 Facebook 上写道：“这名[个人]和其他几名不信教者一样，以为这种行为和侮辱会让她获得美国或欧洲公民身份。但在达到目标之前，她就失去了生命。” 20

Shortly after this brutal killing, Hashmat Stanekzai, a spokesperson for the police chief’s office in Kabul, wrote on Facebook, “This [individual] thought, like several other unbelievers, that this kind of action and insult would get her U.S. or European citizenship. But before reaching her goal, she lost her life.”20

亵渎指控对个人造成的毁灭性打击与马沙尔·汗案类似。2017 年 4 月 13 日，他在巴基斯坦马尔丹的大学校园被同学私刑处死。死前，汗曾批评大学当局存在某些违规行为，随后当局对他和另外两名学生展开调查，指控他们三人在 Facebook 账户上发布亵渎言论，但从未发现相关证据。

A similar example of how an accusation of blasphemy can be devastating for an individual is the case of Mashal Khan. On April 13, 2017, he was lynched by classmates on the campus of his university in Mardan, Pakistan. Prior to his death, Khan had criticized the university authorities for certain irregularities, and subsequently the authorities opened an investigation against him and two other students, accusing all three of posting blasphemous items on their Facebook accounts, evidence for which was never uncovered.

汗的朋友向警方表示，马沙尔是一名虔诚的穆斯林。目击者告诉警方，暴徒袭击他并不是因为指控他亵渎神明，而是因为他被指控使用 Facebook 传播艾哈迈迪教。他被杀时，至少有 20 名警察在场。21随后的警方调查宣告马沙尔和另外两名被指控的学生无罪。

Khan’s friends stated to the police that Mashal was a devoted Muslim. Eyewitnesses to his murder told the police that the mob had attacked him not because of an accusation of blasphemy, but because he had been accused of spreading the Ahmadi faith using Facebook. When he was killed, at least twenty police officers were present.21 A subsequent police investigation cleared Mashal and two other accused students of all charges of blasphemy.

亵渎指控的受害者并不总是个人。2012 年 9 月 29 日，孟加拉国吉大港拉姆镇的整个佛教社区和六座古老的佛教寺庙被烧成灰烬，原因是 Facebook 上的一则谣言被精心策划并广为传播，大意是某些佛教徒团体侮辱了伊斯兰教先知。22

It’s not always an individual who is the victim of an accusation of blasphemy. On September 29, 2012, an entire Buddhist community and six ancient Buddhist temples were burned to ashes at Ramu, Chittagong, in Bangladesh, after a Facebook rumor had been carefully orchestrated and spread far and wide, to the effect that certain groups of Buddhists had insulted the Islamic prophet.22

在许多国家，叛教（放弃宗教信仰或改变宗教信仰）被认为是比亵渎更严重的罪行。2018 年，有 22 个国家将叛教定为犯罪。23其中12个国家（阿富汗、伊朗、马来西亚、马尔代夫、毛里塔尼亚、尼日利亚、卡塔尔、沙特阿拉伯、索马里、苏丹、阿拉伯联合酋长国和也门）将叛教定为死刑。巴基斯坦对亵渎罪判处死刑，亵渎罪一词非常模糊，几乎可以指代任何意思。简而言之，如今在全球十三个国家，如果你表示不相信上帝，你就会受到法律的处死。

In many countries, apostasy (the renunciation of one’s religion, or the changing of religious affiliation) is considered to be an even greater sin than blasphemy. In 2018, there were twenty-two countries in which apostasy was criminalized.23 In twelve of these (Afghanistan, Iran, Malaysia, Maldives, Mauritania, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Somalia, Sudan, United Arab Emirates, and Yemen), apostasy is punishable by death. Pakistan has a death sentence for blasphemy, a term so vague that it can mean almost anything. In short, in thirteen countries around the globe today, you can be legally put to death for stating that you do not believe in God.

2010 年，在马尔代夫群岛，在一位穆斯林演讲者演讲后的问答环节中，一位听众说他“是马尔代夫人，但不是穆斯林”。听众中的其他人袭击了他，他被警察带走。后来他被指控叛教，并受到死刑的威胁。根据马尔代夫法律，叛教必然会导致死刑，除非被告有机会改变主意并重新信奉穆斯林信仰。很明显，在这种情况下，撒谎掩盖自己突然改变主意比去见造物主更容易。当仅仅有某些想法就是一种犯罪时，人权就不可能存在。

In 2010 in the Maldive Islands, in a question-and-answer session after a talk given by a Muslim speaker, one audience member said that he was “Maldivian but not Muslim.” Other people in the audience attacked him, and he was carried off by the police. Later he was charged with apostasy and was threatened with a death sentence. According to Maldivian law, apostasy necessarily leads to the death penalty unless the accused, when given the chance, changes their mind and readopts the Muslim faith. It’s pretty obvious that, under such circumstances, it’s easier to lie about one’s sudden change of heart than to go to meet one’s maker.
