The Discovery Institute’s hidden agenda is religious, and that is something that the U.S. Constitution will not permit in American schools.

事实上，法庭在研究所的内部文件中发现了一份明确的战略宣言，即智能设计运动的使命是“打败科学唯物主义及其破坏性的道德、文化和政治遗产” 。15

The court in fact discovered, among the institute’s internal documents, a clearly formulated strategy declaration—namely, that the mission of the intelligent-design movement is “to defeat scientific materialism and its destructive moral, cultural and political legacies.”15

很难再清楚地表述这一点了。达尔文的物种起源理论被其敌人视为不道德、不道德和无神论。进化论被视为否定上帝和无神论。

One could hardly formulate it more clearly. Darwin’s theory of the origin of species is considered by its enemies to be unethical, immoral, and godless. Evolution is considered as god denying and atheistic.

但这样的推理是建立在一个很深的误解之上的：达尔文的理论并没有否认上帝存在的可能性，它只是否认了上帝存在的必要性。

But such reasoning is based on a deep misunderstanding: Darwin’s theory doesn’t deny the possibility of God’s existence—it only denies the necessity of God’s existence.

瑞典的创造论

Creationism in Sweden

在瑞典也有创造论者，主要是穆斯林和属于“瑞典自由教会”的基督徒。16由安德斯·加德伯恩( Anders Gärdeborn) 领导的瑞典创造论协会 Genesis 包括各种创造论运动。

In Sweden, too, there are creationists—principally Muslims and Christians belonging to “Swedish free churches.”16 The Swedish creationist society Genesis, led by Anders Gärdeborn, includes a variety of creationist movements.

瑞典另一位值得关注的创世论者是马茨·莫伦 (Mats Molén)，他在北部城市于默奥经营着一家名为“史前世界”的创世论博物馆。莫伦也曾是《创世纪》的领导者，但现在他主要在瑞典各地旅行，并在学校和其他教育机构发表关于创世论的演讲。

Another noteworthy creationist on the Swedish scene is Mats Molén, who runs a creationist museum in the northern city of Umeå, called “Den Förhistoriska Världen” (“The Prehistoric World”). At one time, Molén was also the leader of Genesis, but today he mostly travels around Sweden and gives talks about creationism in schools and other educational institutions.

史前世界博物馆在其网站上宣称自己思想极其开放（以下内容译自该博物馆的瑞典语网站）：17

On its website, the Prehistoric World Museum professes to being extremely open minded in the following manner (the following is translated from the Swedish website of the museum):17

运用哲学

首先，我们希望参观我们博物馆的人能够开始批判性地思考，而不仅仅是接受各种权威人士的说法（包括博物馆的说法）。这是所有人类社交的基础，也是民主的基础。这包括尊重他人的意见，即使你不同意。（如果我们都有相同的观点，就有被洗脑的风险！）

因此，我们欢迎就各种问题进行讨论。我们反对一切歧视和“象牙塔”式的推理（即有人认为自己比别人优越，因此不想讨论）。

如果您想更深入地探讨这些问题，我们也欢迎就地球历史的不同解释进行深入讨论（这仅适用于您想讨论的情况）。与当今问题相关的研究通常直接适用于实践，例如如何最好地建造桥梁或制造出一种好药，因此您不会犯太多错误。但无论古代历史如何发生，我们都在这里。因此，对过去和我们起源的其他解释通常不会带来直接的实际后果。例如，可以从科学文献中的讨论中看到这一点。

但关于起源的问题基本上是一个宗教/哲学问题，无论你是无神论者还是相信造物主。因此，出于各种原因，这个问题对许多人来说特别敏感，有些人甚至拒绝讨论他们的信仰。我们接受并理解后一种立场，但如果我们能够以开放的心态提出并讨论这些棘手的问题，我们也可以提出并讨论。

不幸的是，许多人将自己的信仰或宗教观点贴上“事实”或“科学”的标签。你可以相信你的信仰就是科学。然而，如果你想武断地提出这种信仰并称之为事实或科学，同时又不愿意让任何人批判性地审视和挑战这种信仰体系，那就有问题了。博物馆反对这种不民主、不科学的做法。

棘手的问题

这家博物馆名为“史前世界”（Den Förhistoriska Världen），由一个非宗派基督教协会管理，该协会与所有愿意合作并敢于讨论难题的人合作。但讨论难题并不是每个人都敢做的事情——但我们为您提供帮助，让您开始行动！

我们并不认为生命是没有意义的，但最近许多科学家和教科书作者却开始相信这一点。后一种信念往往是由于人们无意识地混淆了科学方法（一种探索世界和宇宙的方法）和认为生命没有真正目的的哲学/宗教。

很难理解为什么有人会对宣扬无意义的信仰感兴趣。无论如何，传达“生命没有意义，不会给任何人带来快乐”的信息是毫无意义的。（也许有人不知不觉地找到了传播信息的意义，无论信息是好是坏，是真是假？）

您可以在科学刊物中找到有关这种徒劳信念的信息（他们并不总是这样说，但基本思想就是无意义）。

许多科学家也表示，他们对发现真相不感兴趣。他们只对用自己的信仰/哲学/神学来解释一切感兴趣。（例如，参见科学期刊《自然》中 Scott Todd 的声明，此处引用了一篇由创造论科学家撰写的文章 [ https://creation.com/whos-really-pushing-bad-science-rebuttal-to-lawrence-s-lerner ]。）

后者，即排除所有想法，除了你自己相信的东西，不包括我们如何解决博物馆的问题。也就是说，我们相信开放和讨论，即使是关于最基本的问题。（然而，我们并不总是与我们链接到的网站有相同的观点。）——史前世界董事会

Working with philosophy

First of all we want that the visit at our museum will start to think critically and not just embrace what various authorities say (including what is said at the museum). This is fundamental to all human socializing, and also the basis for democracy. That includes respect for others’ opinions, even if you do not share them. (If we all have the same views, there’s a risk that it is brainwashing!)

We therefore welcome a discussion on various issues. We oppose all discrimination and the “ivory tower” kind of reasoning (i.e., someone consider themselves superior to others and therefore do not want to discuss).

If you want to go deeper into these issues, we also welcome a profound discussion about different interpretations of Earth’s history (this applies only if you want to discuss). Research related to today’s issues is often directly applicable in practice, such as how best to build a bridge or make a good medicine, so you can’t do too many mistakes. But regardless of how the ancient history took place we are here. Alternative explanations for the past and our origin therefore do not often provide immediate practical consequences. This can be seen for example of the discussion in the scientific literature.

But the question concerning origins is basically a religious/philosophical question, whether you’re an atheist or believe in a creator. Therefore, that question, for various reasons is extra sensitive to many people and some even refuse to discuss their faith. We accept and understand the latter position, but we can bring up and discuss even these difficult questions, if it can be made openmindedly.

There are unfortunately many who name their faith or religious view with the label “fact” or “science.” You can believe that your faith is science. However, there is a problem if you want to present dogmatically this faith and calling it fact or science, while at the same time you are not willing to let anyone critically examine and challenge this belief system. The museum is opposed to such an undemocratic and unscientific approach.

Tough questions

This museum, the Prehistoric World (Den Förhistoriska Världen) is run by a non-denominational Christian association which cooperates with all who wants to cooperate and who dares to discuss difficult questions. But discussing difficult questions isn’t something which all dare to do—but we offer you help to get started!

We do NOT believe that life is meaningless, as many scientists and authors of textbooks has come to believe lately. The latter belief is often due to unconsciously confusing the scientific method (which is a method to explore the world and the universe) with a philosophy/religion that says that there is no real purpose in life.

It is difficult to understand why someone might be interested in bringing out a faith of meaninglessness. It is anyways pointless with a message that life has no meaning and it isn’t making anyone happy. (Perhaps someone unwittingly finds a sense of just spreading a message, regardless of whether the message is good or bad, true or false?)

You can find information about this belief in futility in the scientific press (they do not always say so, but the basic idea is meaninglessness).

Many scientists have also stated that they are not interested in discovering what is true. They are only interested in explaining everything with their own beliefs/philosophies/theoiesy. (See for example a statement by Scott Todd, from the scientific journal Nature, here quoted in an article by creation scientists [https://creation.com/whos-really-pushing-bad-science-rebuttal-to-lawrence-s-lerner].)

The latter, to exclude all thoughts except what you believe in yourself, does NOT include how we address the issues at the museum. That is, we believe in openness and discussion, even about the most basic questions. (However, we do not always have the same views as the web sites we link to.)—The board of directors, the Prehistoric World

当然，我很高兴看到这种哲学的某些部分与本书提出的原则有着如此强烈的呼应，但当人们更仔细地观察时，就会发现它并不遵循这些原则。

It is of course pleasing to me to see how strongly some of this philosophy echoes the principles suggested in this book, but when one looks at it more carefully, one sees that it does not adhere to those principles.

瑞典很少有人认真对待神创论，但偶尔人们会在瑞典自由教会发布的通讯中看到有人指出，新发现的化石与研究人员迄今制定的物种谱系不一致。很容易想象出这样的得意洋洋的标题：“新发现表明达尔文错了！”

Very few people in Sweden take creationism seriously, but now and then one will see, in the newsletters put out by Swedish free churches, some note to the effect that a newly discovered fossil doesn’t agree with the family tree of species so far worked out by researchers. It’s easy to imagine the triumphant headlines: “New Discovery Shows Darwin Was Wrong!”

一个简单的类比就很好地揭示了这种论证的缺陷。想象一下，你在餐桌上摆放了拼图碎片，当你开始拼的时候，你很快就意识到这是一张老牌瑞典影星葛丽泰·嘉宝的照片，她因“我想一个人待着”这句台词而出名。当你快要拼完的时候，你失望地发现少了一两块碎片，然后你拿起一块似乎不适合拼图的碎片。如果你是一个创造论者，你可能会在这时惊呼：“好吧，你知道吗——一块不适合的碎片！我想这意味着它毕竟不是葛丽泰·嘉宝！”

The flaw in such an argument is nicely revealed through a simple analogy. Imagine you’ve laid out the pieces of a jigsaw puzzle on your dining room table, and as you start putting it together, you soon recognize that it’s a photo of old-time Swedish movie star Greta Garbo, famous for her line “I vant to be alone.” When you’ve nearly finished, you’re disappointed to see that a piece or two is missing, and then you pick up a piece that doesn’t seem to fit anywhere in the puzzle. If you were a creationist, you might at this point exclaim, “Well, what do you know—a piece that doesn’t fit in! I guess this means it isn’t Greta Garbo, after all!”

达尔文进化论整体上是正确的，并不意味着整个图景中的每一个微小细节都必须在任何时候都完全正确，也不意味着如果缺少哪怕是最微小的细节，整个图景就会失效。不言而喻的是，随着时间的推移，我们会发现自己在讲述所有不同物种如何相互关联的故事中添加了新的细节并修改了旧的细节。

For Darwin’s theory of evolution to be correct as a whole doesn’t mean that every tiny detail in the overall picture has to be exactly right at all moments, or that if even the slightest detail is missing, then the whole picture is invalidated. It’s self-evident that, as time progresses, we will find ourselves adding new details and revising old details in the story that tells how all the different species are related to one another.

事实上，近年来，DNA样本研究方法为我们提供了有关人类起源的新线索。例如，著名的瑞典研究人员Svante Pääbo绘制了尼安德特人的DNA图谱，多亏了他的工作18，我们现在知道尼安德特人不是我们的祖先（即不是智人的直系祖先），而是另一种与“我们”（即我们的直系祖先）平行生活的人类，直到大约三万年前。

Indeed, in recent years, methods involving DNA samples have given us new clues about our origin. For example, renowned Swedish researcher Svante Pääbo has mapped out the DNA of the Neanderthals, and thanks to his work18 we now know that the Neanderthals were not ancestors of ours (that is, not direct predecessors of Homo sapiens sapiens), but another type of human that lived in parallel with “us” (that is, with our direct ancestors) up until about thirty thousand years ago.

通过对 DNA 的理解，我们获得的所有关于生物学的新知识都指向同一个方向——即，这其中不存在智能设计。自然选择的过程完全是自然的。

All new knowledge we gain about biology through our understanding of DNA points in the same direction—namely, that there is no intelligent design involved. The process of natural selection does the job all by itself.

但从某种意义上说，智能设计确实存在！我最近有机会与 2018 年诺贝尔化学奖得主、加州理工学院的 Frances H. Arnold 进行了交谈。1993 年，她进行了首次酶的定向进化，酶是催化化学反应的蛋白质。她告诉我，智能设计标志运动试图利用她的研究作为他们非常不科学的假设的证据，这让她非常恼火。

But in a sense, intelligent design does exist! I recently had the chance to talk to the 2018 Nobel Laureate in Chemistry, Caltech’s Frances H. Arnold. In 1993, she conducted the first directed evolution of enzymes, which are proteins that catalyze chemical reactions. She told me that the intelligent de sign movement tries to use her research as evidence for their very unscientific hypothesis, which made her very annoyed.

事实是，阿诺德博士本人就是智能设计者，她既是人类又是科学家。她以智能设计师的身份，运用科学和智力技能指导进化。这才是真正的智能设计！

The truth is, Dr. Arnold is herself performing intelligent design, as a human and scientist. She uses science and her intellectual skills to direct evolution as an intelligent designer. Now that is genuine intelligent design!

插曲：关于正常与异常

INTERLUDE: ON THE NORMAL AND THE ABNORMAL

同性恋是不正常的吗？当然是的——就像出生在 1 月 1 日、身高 6 英尺 3 英寸或拥有绿色眼睛是不正常的一样。正常是一个统计概念，但它经常被错误地用作价值判断。

Is it abnormal to be homosexual? Well, sure—in the same way as it’s abnormal to be born on January 1, or to be six feet three inches tall, or to have green eyes. Normality is a statistical concept, but it is often erroneously used as a value judgment.

5% 到 10% 的人是同性恋，这一事实在统计学意义上稍显不正常，但从同样的统计学意义上讲，成为一名喜剧演员、花店老板、大学校长、犹太人或世俗人道主义者则要不正常得多。

The fact that somewhere between 5 and 10 percent of people are homosexual makes it slightly abnormal in a statistical sense, but in that same statistical sense, it is considerably more abnormal to be a comedian, a florist, a university president, a Jew, or a secular humanist.

通常，“正常”等同于“最常见”，因此，不寻常的事情在定义上就是不正常的。但这个词不应该带有任何价值判断。为什么不寻常的特征会引起恐惧、蔑视或辱骂等负面反应？

Usually, “normal” is equated with “most frequent,” so that unusual things are, by definition, abnormal. But no value judgment should be attached to that word. Why should unusual traits provoke negative reactions, such as fear, scorn, or verbal abuse?

古往今来，人们传统上所信奉的许多“宇宙权威”（如牧师）都对不同于自己的信仰体系，或大多数人不认同的性行为或社交互动类型持批评态度。然而，对此类行为最合理的立场应该恰恰相反，因为事实上，人类特征、经历和生活方式的多样性是丰富我们在这个星球上生存的源泉，而不是威胁。

Down through the ages, many of the “cosmic authorities” (such as priests) to which people have traditionally turned have cast a critical eye on belief systems that are different from their own—or on types of sexual behavior or social interaction that are not shared by the majority. And yet, the most reasonable stance toward such behaviors should be exactly the opposite, for in truth, a great diversity of human traits, experiences, and lifestyles is a source of enrichment, rather than a threat, to our existence on this planet.

如果某种异常行为会对自己或他人造成伤害，我们应当明确质疑。但这同样适用于正常行为。以吸烟为例。吸烟在美国曾经非常流行；人们认为吸烟完全正常。然而，人们最终开始怀疑吸烟的不健康，并质疑吸烟的合理性。如今，经过多年的医学研究，在美国，吸烟比不吸烟更加不寻常。换句话说，昨天被视为正常的行为今天就非常不正常了。

If an abnormal type of behavior is harmful to ourselves or to others, we should clearly question it. But that holds just as much for normal types of behavior. Take smoking, for instance. Smoking was once extremely popular in the United States; it was considered perfectly normal to smoke. Eventually, however, the unhealthiness of smoking started to be suspected, and the reasonableness of smoking was called into question. Today, as a result of years of medical research, it’s far more unusual in the United States to smoke than not to smoke. In other words, what yesterday was taken as normal is very abnormal today.

不幸的是，我们大多数人并不像关注那些打破常规的行为那样关注我们周围看到的行为。虽然后者常常让我们反感，但前者通常只会遭到沉默。但一个人的行为是否正常或打破常规并不重要，重要的是它是否有助于幸福和快乐。总之，社会认为的“正常”只是一个统计分布问题，不应与价值判断相混淆。

Unfortunately, most of us do not pay as much attention to behavior that we see all around us as we do to behavior that breaks the norms. While the latter often turns us off, the former is generally met with mere silence. But what matters about someone’s behavior is not whether it is normal or norm breaking; what matters is whether it contributes to well-being and happiness. In sum, what society considers “normal” is just a matter of statistical distribution and should not be confused with value judgments.

第十一章

CHAPTER ELEVEN

思想史关于世俗启蒙的根源

THE HISTORY OF IDEAS Concerning the Roots of Secular Enlightenment

勇于求知！——伊曼纽尔·康德，《什么是启蒙？》（1784年）

Dare to know!—Immanuel Kant, “What Is Enlightenment?” (1784)

电视关于人性的世俗观点的发展历史源远流长。现在我们来看看这种观点是如何从古老的哲学传统中发展出来的。从本质上讲，随着人们对神秘的超自然事件的恐惧以及对任意、严酷的神的恐惧开始减弱，世俗的人性观开始变得突出。

T he story of the development of the secular view of what it means to be human goes back a long way. We’ll now take a look at how this viewpoint grew out of venerable philosophical traditions. Essentially, the secular view of human beings started to come into prominence as people’s fear of mysterious supernatural events and their terror of arbitrary, harsh gods started to weaken.

理性、同情心和各种“黄金法则”

Reason, Compassion, and Various “Golden Rules”

几千年来，人类一直在苦苦思索诸如神如何存在、什么才是有意义的生活、什么决定了某种行为在道德上是否正确等谜题。这种不断的道德反思是人类生存状态的内在组成部分，而道德反思的核心要素是同情心（意为“共同受苦”或“分享感受”）。

For millennia, humanity has scratched its collective head over such riddles as how gods could exist, or what would constitute a meaningful life, or what determines whether a particular act is morally right or not. This kind of incessant moral reflection is an intrinsic part of the human condition, and a central element in moral reflection is compassion (meaning “co-suffering” or “sharing of feelings”).

同情他人的能力是人类的深层属性，但与许多人的想法相反，它并不是人类独有的属性。对黑猩猩和其他灵长类动物的实验表明，这些动物能够表现出同理心和同情心，甚至具有道德感。1

The capacity to feel compassion for others is a deep human attribute, but contrary to what many people think, it is not a uniquely human attribute. Experiments with chimpanzees and other primates have shown that such animals can show empathy and compassion, and that they even have a sense of morality.1

与他人“共患难”的能力是通过自然选择进化而来，是一种重要的生存策略。在西方世界，早在基督教将同情、怜悯和人权作为其传统的一部分形成之前，它们就被当作哲学概念来讨论。

The ability to “co-suffer” with another being evolved through natural selection as an important strategy for survival. In the Western world, empathy, compassion, and human rights were discussed as philosophical concepts long before Christianity formulated them as part of its traditions.

从公元前 900 年到公元前 200 年的七个世纪中，中国的儒教和道教、印度的印度教和佛教、希腊哲学以及以色列的一神论社会中都已经形成了关于同情的哲学思想。一个例子是《自在天经》（5，18）中的一条佛教原则：“己所不欲，勿施于人。”（《自在天经》是佛陀及其弟子们的思想和言论的早期汇编。）

Already in the seven centuries stretching from 900 BCE to 200 BCE, philosophical thoughts about compassion had been formulated in Confucianism and Taoism in China, in Hinduism and Buddhism in India, in Greek philosophy, and in the monotheistic society in Israel. An example is a Buddhist principle taken from the Udānavarga (5, 18): “Do not harm others in a way that you yourself would not wish to be harmed.” (The Udānavarga is an early collection of thoughts and utterances by Buddha and his disciples.)

在耆那教（与佛教在同一历史时期和同一文化环境中兴起于印度的宗教）的神圣经典中，人们可以找到这样的说法：“良好行为的原则是不伤害任何人。”

In the sacred writings of Jainism (a religion that arose in India during the same historical period and in the same cultural environment as Buddhism), one finds the following: “The principle of good behavior is not to harm anyone.”

在被称为“道教”的哲学运动中，人们可以发现类似的思想：“将邻居之得视为己得，将邻居之失视为己失。”（此引文取自《太上感应篇》，意为“世尊应报篇”）。

In the philosophical movement called “Taoism” (or “Daoism”), one finds similar thoughts: “Consider your neighbor’s gain to be your own gain, and your neighbor’s loss to be your own loss.” (This quote is taken from the T’ai-Shang Kan-Ying P’ien, meaning “Treatise of the Exalted One on Response and Retribution.”)

在印度的一些早期哲学文献中，也可以找到世俗哲学和思想潮流。因此，《奥义书》（用梵文写成的最古老的哲学文献，其标题传统上被译为“从师傅传给细心学生的秘密教义”）之一对梵天神的存在提出了质疑。大约公元前 600 年，出现了一个名为 Lokāyata 或 Cārvāka 的哲学流派，该流派避开了圣经和受人尊敬的传统传承。相反，它教导说，只有一个世界存在——物质世界。因此，Lokāyata 的信徒否认任何神的存在，也否认灵魂不朽。Lokāyata 清楚地表明，对宗教信仰的怀疑态度既不是最近才出现的，也不是西方独有的现象。2

In some early philosophical texts from India there can also be found secular philosophies and currents of thought. Thus one of the Upanishads (the oldest philosophical texts written in Sanskrit, and whose title is traditionally rendered as “secret teachings transmitted from master to attentive pupil”) calls into question the existence of the god Brahma. In roughly 600 BCE, there arose a philosophical school called Lokāyata or Cārvāka, which steered clear of holy scriptures and the transmission of venerated traditions. Instead, it taught that there exists only one world—the material world. Believers in Lokāyata therefore denied the existence of any sort of god, as well as the immortality of the soul. Lokāyata clearly illustrates the fact that a skeptical attitude toward religious belief is neither a recent development nor an exclusively Western phenomenon.2

中国思想家孔子生活在公元前五世纪，他完全独立于任何神灵或超自然观念制定了自己的道德和政治原则。虽然他没有明确否认神灵的存在，但他的教义侧重于人类及其尘世生存。孔子在耶稣诞生前五百年左右设计了黄金法则的一个版本：

Chinese thinker Confucius, who lived in the fifth century BCE, formulated his moral and political principles completely independently of any gods or supernatural notions. Although he did not explicitly deny the existence of gods, his teachings focused on human beings and their earthly existence. Confucius devised a version of the Golden Rule some five hundred years before the birth of Jesus:

子贡问：“有一句话可以指导人的一生吗？”

孔子回答说：“‘礼’又如何？己所不欲，勿施于人。” 3

Zi Gong [a disciple of Confucius] asked: “Is there any one word that could guide a person throughout life?”

The Master replied: “How about ‘shu’ [reciprocity]? Never impose on others what you would not choose for yourself.”3

耶稣是基督教的核心人物。没有确凿的证据证明他出生在何时何地，但很可能在公元前 4 年左右，巴勒斯坦出生了一位同名的人，他周围的人认为他是先知。大约 33 年后，在他去世后，基督教成为一种广泛传播的宗教。

Jesus is the central figure of Christianity. There is no strong evidence about where or when he was born, but most likely someone with that name was born in Palestine in roughly the year 4 BCE, and this person was taken by people around him to be a prophet. After his death roughly thirty-three years later, Christianity became a widespread religion.

基督徒倾向于认为《圣经》中的黄金法则优于前面提到的版本。基督教版本——即“己所不欲，勿施于人”——关注的是你应该做什么，而不是你不应该做什么。乍一看，这种源自《圣经》的积极表述似乎是最好的。但消极表述也有一些优势。瑞典科学和伦理哲学家 Birgitta Forsman 在她的著作《Gudlös etik》4中写道：

Christians tend to believe that the form of the Golden Rule found in the Bible is superior to the versions cited earlier. The Christian version—namely, “Do unto others as you would have others do unto you”—is concerned with what you should do, rather than what you should not do. And on first glance, it might well seem that this positive formulation, stemming from the Bible, is the best one. But the negative formulation also has some advantages. Swedish philosopher of science and ethics Birgitta Forsman, in her book Gudlös etik,4 writes:

对我来说，让别人安静下来，不要求他们做出某些行为，显然比强迫他们做我个人认为好的事情要好。毕竟，每个人的品味都不一样。……最坏的情况可以用一句巧妙的谚语来概括：“虐待狂是遵循黄金法则的受虐狂。”整个话题与关于积极权利和消极权利的政治和哲学问题密切相关。消极权利，例如不遭受酷刑、奴役或监禁的权利，通常被认为比积极权利更为根本。

It is clearly better for me to leave other people in peace and not to demand certain forms of behavior from them than to force them to do things that I personally think are good. Tastes, after all, can vary from person to person. . . . The worst case is captured in the clever saying, “A sadist is a masochist who follows the Golden Rule.” This whole topic is closely related to the political and philosophical question about positive and negative rights. Negative rights, such as the rights not to be subjected to torture, slavery, or imprisonment, are usually considered to be more fundamental than positive rights.

古代哲学

The Philosophy of Ancient Times

在古希腊，人们提出了许多关于人类及其在宇宙中地位的理论。希腊社会组织得足够完善，生存斗争并不是人们的主要关注点。至少对于一些思想家来说，他们还有时间去反思生活。这些希腊思想家催生了哲学、科学和戏剧——探索人类和世界本质的多种方式。

In ancient Greece, many theories were put forth about human beings and their place in the cosmos. Greek society was sufficiently well organized that the struggle to survive was not people’s main concern. At least for a few thinkers, there was time left over to reflect on life. These Greek thinkers gave birth to philosophy, science, and drama—diverse ways to explore the nature of humanity and of the world.

我们在这里也能感受到世俗人文主义思想的最早痕迹。据我们所知，希腊哲学家是第一批系统地思考世界是如何构造和运作的人。今天，这些哲学家通常被称为“自然哲学家”——关于自然本质的思想家。其中最重要的三位是泰勒斯、阿那克西曼德和阿那克西美尼，他们都生活在公元前六世纪和五世纪。

Here we can also sense the earliest traces of secular humanistic thinking. The Greek philosophers were the first people, as far as we can tell, to systematically ponder how the world was constructed and how it worked. Today, these philosophers are usually called “natural philosophers”—thinkers about the nature of nature. Three of the most important of them were Thales, Anaximander, and Anaximenes, all of whom lived in the sixth and fifth centuries BCE.

泰勒斯推测整个世界是由一种基本物质构成的，其他物质又由这种基本物质构成。他因此思考如何将世界的复杂结构和现象简化为更简单的事物。

Thales speculated that the entire world was made out of just one basic substance, out of which other substances could be formed. He thus reflected about how the world’s complex structures and phenomena could be reduced to simpler things.

阿那克西曼德通常被认为是天文学的创始人。但他也根据对化石的研究，提出了人类起源于海洋生物的理论。因此，他关于人类起源的思想比查尔斯·达尔文的进化论早了大约 23 个世纪。

Anaximander is often considered to be the founder of astronomy. But he also developed a theory, based on his study of fossils, of how people originated from creatures of the sea. His ideas about the roots of the human species thus anticipated Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution by some twenty-three centuries.

阿那克西美尼想象我们世界上的一切都起源于空气之海，所有其他物质均由空气的凝结或稀释而产生。

Anaximenes imagined that everything in our world originated in an ocean of air, and that all other substances arose from the condensation or the dilution of air.

这三位自然哲学家最重要的事实是，他们从不诉诸基于神话或宗教观念的解释；相反，他们努力将他们的思想建立在观察和理性思考的基础上。

A most significant fact about all three of these natural philosophers is that they never resorted to explanations based on myths or religious ideas; rather, they strove to ground their ideas in observations and rational thinking.

哲学家德谟克利特（约公元前 460-370 年）进一步发展了泰勒斯的思想，他最著名的理论是提出世界由微小不可分割的粒子组成的理论，他将这些粒子称为原子。（前缀“a”表示“没有”，“tom”表示“片段”，因此德谟克利特的单词“atom”本身由两个语义片段和四个字母片段构成，意思是“没有片段”。）因此，德谟克利特的哲学是自然主义的，他认为一切都是由原子构成的，遵循整个宇宙的机械自然法则。德谟克利特认为，即使是意识也是自然法则的结果，当我们死后，意识就不复存在了。

Philosopher Democritus (whose dates are roughly 460–370 BCE) further developed the ideas of Thales, and most famously he devised the theory that the world consists of tiny indivisible particles, which he called atoms. (The prefix “a” means “without,” while “tom” means “piece,” so Democritus’s word “atom,” itself built out of two semantic pieces and four alphabetic pieces, means “without pieces.”) Democritus’s philosophy was thus naturalistic, in that it saw everything as being made of atoms following mechanistic laws of nature that hold throughout the entire universe. Democritus believed that even consciousness arises as a result of the laws of nature, and that it ceases to exist when we die.

人们常引用德谟克利特的一句话：“除了原子和空虚的空间，什么都不存在；其他一切都是观点。”这当然不是事实，但它非常清楚地表明了他对现实的自然主义态度。

Democritus is often quoted as saying, “Nothing exists except atoms and empty space; everything else is opinion.” This is of course not true, but it very clearly shows his naturalistic approach to reality.

普罗泰戈拉（约公元前 485-415 年）的思想与德谟克利特的精神相同。在他的著作中，我们发现了这样一句话：“关于神，我无法知道他们是否存在，也不知道他们是什么类型，因为这个话题很晦涩，人类的生命又很短暂。”因此，虽然普罗泰戈拉并没有直接否认神的存在，但他基本上认为神是无关紧要的。他最为人所铭记的可能是这句话：“人是万物的尺度。”

Protagoras (roughly 485–415 BCE) developed ideas in the same spirit as Democritus. Among his writings we find this statement: “Concerning the gods, I have no means of knowing whether they exist or not, nor of what sort they may be, because of the obscurity of the subject, and the brevity of human life.” Thus, although Protagoras did not directly deny the existence of gods, he basically considered them to be irrelevant. He is probably best remembered for this statement: “Man is the measure of all things.”

公元前三世纪，有一位伟大的希腊哲学家伊壁鸠鲁。和德谟克利特一样，伊壁鸠鲁也认为，当一个有思想的生物死去时，构成其身体和思想的原子会散落到四面八方。风吹过，生物什么也不会留下。他还认为生命的意义在于我们在地球上短暂停留期间创造美好的事物，如果我们专注于生活中的小乐趣，我们就能获得内心的平静与和谐。这种关于生命的观点后来被称为伊壁鸠鲁主义。根据伊壁鸠鲁的说法，人是一个没有不朽灵魂的物理实体。而对伊壁鸠鲁来说，正义在于认真遵守我们人类制定的协议和合同，其目标是防止我们彼此伤害。

In the third century BCE, there lived the great Greek philosopher Epicurus. Like Democritus, Epicurus believed that when a thinking creature dies, the atoms constituting its body and its mind are scattered to the four winds, and that nothing remains of the creature. He also believed that the meaning of life lay in the creation of good things during our brief sojourn on earth, and that if we focus on life’s small pleasures, we can attain inner peace and harmony. This viewpoint about life later came to be known as epicureanism. According to Epicurus, a person is a physical entity that has no immortal soul. And justice, for Epicurus, resided in the careful following of agreements and contracts that we human beings draw up, whose goal is to keep us from doing harm to one another.

几个世纪以来，伊壁鸠鲁在西方文明的典型历史中几乎从未被提及，因为他的理论被认为与基督教神学不相容。

Throughout the centuries, Epicurus was hardly ever mentioned in typical histories of Western civilization, as his theories were considered to be incompatible with Christian theology.

所有这些早期思想家最重要的贡献不是他们提出的关于世界的精确思想，而是他们思考的是现实世界，而不是假想的神或众神社会。与中世纪哲学家不同——他们一生都在思考诸如“有多少天使可以在针尖上跳舞？”之类的奇怪而徒劳的问题——更早的希腊哲学家们思考的是可见、可听和可触及的现象。这样，他们认为世界是自然的，而不是超自然的。

The most important contribution of all these early thinkers is not the precise ideas that they proposed about the world; instead, it is the fact that they thought about the real world, rather than thinking about a hypothetical god or society of gods. Unlike medieval philosophers—who devoted their lives to the pondering of such bizarre and futile questions as “How many angels can dance on the head of a pin?”—the much earlier Greek philosophers asked questions about visible, audible, and tangible phenomena. In this way, they saw the world as being natural, rather than supernatural.

三位知识巨人

Three Intellectual Giants

可以公平地说，西方思想更多地源自三位希腊哲学家。这三位思想家——苏格拉底、柏拉图和亚里士多德——都生活在公元前四世纪和三世纪。

It is probably fair to say that Western thought derives more from three particular Greek philosophers than from anyone else. These three thinkers—Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle—all lived in the fourth and third centuries BCE.

柏拉图是苏格拉底的学生，亚里士多德是柏拉图的学生。这两位哲学家共同证明了，在谨慎研究的态度的指导下，借助推理工具，可以对人类和世界进行逻辑思考。

Plato was a pupil of Socrates, and Aristotle was a pupil of Plato. Together, these philosophers demonstrated that it is possible to think logically about human beings and the world with the help of the tools of reasoning, guided by an attitude of careful investigation.

苏格拉底展示了一种新的写作方法，即通过对话提出许多问题并探索各种可能的答案，这种方法可以用来调查和分析各种复杂而微妙的话题。苏格拉底只需提出一系列尖锐的问题，就能向他假设的对话伙伴传授见解和知识。这种技巧被称为苏格拉底方法。

Socrates showed how a new method of writing, consisting of dialogues in which many questions were posed and various possible answers were explored, could be used to investigate and analyze all types of complex and subtle topics. Merely by asking a series of penetrating questions, Socrates could impart insights and knowledge to his hypothetical dialogue partner. This technique became known as the Socratic method.

柏拉图在某种意义上是民主主义者，尽管不是今天意义上的民主主义者。他认为社会应该由开明的精英统治，而不是由公民统治。这很难说是民主！就知识而言，然而，他是一位民主人士——也就是说，他认为辩论中获胜的永远是最好的（即最合乎逻辑的）论点。辩论的成功与谁说了什么或辩论者如何表达自己无关；真理和客观性永远胜过个性和华丽的辞藻。

Plato was a democrat in a certain sense, although not in today’s sense. He believed that society should be governed by an enlightened elite, not by the citizenry. That is hardly democratic! As far as knowledge was concerned, however, he was a democrat—that is, he thought that it was always the best (i.e., the most logical) argument that would win in a debate. Success in debating did not have to do with who said what or with how debaters expressed themselves; truth and objectivity would always triumph over personality and rhetorical fanfare.

亚里士多德对理解世界的态度是探究。他还试图根据对人性的研究，制定一种植根于理性的道德观。他的主要关注点是如何在今生获得幸福和安康，而不是想象中的死后生活。

Aristotle’s attitude about understanding the world was one of investigation. He also tried to formulate a type of morality rooted in reason, based on his studies of human nature. His main focus was on how to attain happiness and well-being in this life on earth, as opposed to an imagined life after death.

毋庸置疑，所有这些古代哲学家在很多事情上都是错误的。今天我们比他们了解得更多。但他们开创了一种思维方式，这种思维方式自那时起就塑造了人类对知识的集体追求和好奇心的态度。

It goes without saying that all of these ancient philosophers were wrong about many things. Today we understand far more than they did. But they blazed the trail for a sort of thinking that ever since then has shaped humanity’s collective pursuit of knowledge and attitude of curiosity.

有趣的是，柏拉图的许多著作（如果不是大多数的话）至今仍存世，而伊壁鸠鲁的作品却几乎没有留存下来。这很可能是因为那些仔细抄写和翻译希腊文本的僧侣们认为伊壁鸠鲁的思想与他们对上帝的信仰不相容，因此他们不想以任何方式传播这些思想。就这样，基督教神学信条最终对古代哲学家可能影响我们今天的思想产生了巨大的影响。

It is interesting to note that many if not most of Plato’s writings are still extant today, while practically nothing written by Epicurus survived. In all likelihood, this is a result of the fact that the monks who carefully copied out and translated the Greek texts, thus assuring their survival, considered Epicurus’s ideas to be incompatible with their belief in God, and they thus did not wish to propagate them in any way. In this manner, Christian theological credos wound up having a huge effect on which ancient philosophers might influence our thinking today.

以人为本

Humanity at the Focal Point

希腊思想家并不关注神，而是将人性置于中心。他们认为，每个公民都有责任和义务学会更可靠的推理，发展道德原则，在社会中扮演负责任的角色，并与其他公民和谐相处，过上明智的生活。这并不意味着这些哲学家总是否认著名的希腊诸神的存在。但是，人与神的关系并不是他们试图理解自然世界和人类状况的重点。他们也不认为道德依赖于任何形式的神谕或天国权威。

The Greek thinkers, rather than focusing on gods, placed humanity at the center. They saw it as every citizen’s duty and obligation to learn to reason more reliably, to develop moral principles, to play a responsible role in society, and to live a sensible life in harmony with other citizens. This doesn’t mean that these philosophers always denied the existence of the famous Greek gods. But the relation of people to gods was not found at the focal point of their attempts to understand the natural world and the human condition. Nor was morality seen as reliant on any kind of divine pronouncement or celestial authority.

此外，希腊思想家认为，人的能力是可以提高的：人类具有发展和进化的潜力。古希腊以这种方式为整个西方世界的教育方式奠定了基础。这些哲学家的理想包括全面培养发展人们的智力和艺术能力，其中包括哲学、逻辑、修辞、数学、天文学和戏剧。

Moreover, the Greek thinkers believed that people’s abilities can be improved: that humanity has the potential to develop and evolve. In that way did ancient Greece set the stage for the style of education in the entire Western world. The ideals of these philosophers included an all-around development of people’s intellectual and artistic capacities, which included, among other things, philosophy, logic, rhetoric, mathematics, astronomy, and drama.

希腊人称这种理想的教育形式为paideia。罗马人很快采纳了这一概念，并给它取了类似的拉丁语名称humanitas。英语单词“humanism”源于这个拉丁语单词。因此，古希腊人文主义的起源与人类是不断进化的生物这一理念有关，即人类不受神或其他超自然生物或力量的影响。

The Greeks called this ideal form of education paideia. The Romans quickly adopted this notion for themselves, giving it the analogous Latin name of humanitas. From this Latin word comes the English word “humanism.” The origin of humanism in ancient Greece thus had to do with the idea of humans as evolving creatures, independent of gods or other supernatural beings or forces.

亚里士多德的学生之一是亚历山大大帝（公元前 356-323 年）。在他的统治下，希腊帝国不断扩张，直到囊括了当时希腊人所知的大部分世界。当罗马人在公元前二世纪最终击败希腊军队时，希腊的教育观念已经完全融入了罗马帝国的文化。罗马统治持续了大约六百年，一直到公元四世纪末。希腊的教育理念在整个时期都受到罗马人的尊重。

One of Aristotle’s pupils was Alexander the Great (356–323 BCE). Under his aegis, the Greek empire expanded until it included much of the world as it was then known to the Greeks. When the Romans eventually defeated the Greek army in the second century BCE, the Greek notions of education had already been fully absorbed into the Roman empire’s culture. The Roman reign lasted for roughly six hundred years, all the way until the end of the fourth century CE. The Greek ideals of education were respected by the Romans for this whole time.

罗马哲学家卢修斯·安纳乌斯·塞内卡出生于现在的西班牙城市科尔多瓦，距公元 0 年不到几年，所以他和耶稣是同时代的人。年轻时，他被送往遥远的罗马学习哲学和修辞学。塞内卡最终在罗马政治中扮演了重要角色，但最终被迫流亡。塞内卡是宗教的严厉批评者。以下是他对宗教最著名的愤世嫉俗的评论之一：“普通人认为宗教是真实的，智者认为宗教是虚假的，统治者认为宗教是有用的。”

Roman philosopher Lucius Annaeus Seneca was born in what is now the Spanish city of Córdoba, within a few years of 0 CE, so he was a contemporary of Jesus. As a young man, he was sent off to faraway Rome to study philosophy and rhetoric. Seneca wound up playing a major role in Roman politics, but eventually he was forced into exile. Seneca was a harsh critic of religion. The following is one of his more famous cynical commentaries on the topic: “Religion is regarded by the common people as true, by the wise as false, and by rulers as useful.”

中世纪

The Middle Ages

罗马帝国覆灭后，我们通常所说的中世纪开始了，这一时期持续了近一千年。从很多方面来看，“黑暗”的中世纪并不像我们今天所想的那么黑暗，但古希腊人对教育的理想愿景以及他们对人的关注，在占主导地位且不断发展的教会以及基督教式的神学理论面前退居次要地位。

After the fall of the Roman Empire, what we usually call the Middle Ages set in, and that period lasted nearly a thousand years. The “dark” Middle Ages were, in many respects, not as dark as today we tend to think, but the ancient Greeks’ ideal vision of education, as well as their focus on human beings, took a back seat to the dominant and ever-growing church, and to the Christian-style theory of divinity.

几乎所有艺术和智力努力都以宗教或神学为导向。教会——基本上是天主教会——竭尽全力确保它完全控制哲学教义和所有其他类型的教育。任何对任何事物产生怀疑的人任何违反宗教思想和宗教规则的人都会受到严厉的惩罚，如果不是绞刑或斩首（或其他可怕的处决方式），那么就是酷刑和长期的迫害。

Almost all artistic and intellectual efforts were oriented toward religion or theology. The church—basically the Catholic Church—did everything in its power to ensure that it had a total stranglehold on philosophical teachings and all other types of education. Anyone who cast doubt of any sort on religious ideas and rules was harshly punished, if not with hanging or beheading (or some other grisly type of execution), then with torture and lengthy persecution.

这一时期，欧洲第一批大学成立，但这些大学几乎只限于研究基督教神学。有关人类本身以及宇宙其他部分的思想，只有在与人类与上帝的关系相关时才会出现。

During this period, the first European universities were founded, but they limited themselves nearly exclusively to the study of Christian theology. Ideas about humanity itself, and about the rest of the cosmos, entered the picture only insofar as they related to humanity’s relationship to God.

就这样，希腊人的自然哲学被传给了中东的阿拉伯哲学家，尽管这并非有意为之，但这些哲学家们自己继续发展了这一哲学。因此，我们可以感谢阿拉伯和穆斯林世界，因为希腊哲学的大部分内容在那几个世纪里得以流传。

The natural philosophy of the Greeks was thus handed over, albeit unintentionally, to Arab philosophers in the Middle East, who continued to develop it themselves. We can therefore thank the Arab and Muslim worlds for the fact that much of Greek philosophy managed to survive through those centuries.

阿拉伯哲学家阿威罗伊（1126-1198 年）出生于当时的伊斯兰国家西班牙科尔多瓦，当时西班牙享有极大的思想自由。5阿威罗伊对亚里士多德的所有著作都进行了学术评论，并以此确保亚里士多德的思想能够传承给尚未出生的后代。在中世纪的欧洲，基督教占据主导地位，亚里士多德在很大程度上被抛入历史的尘埃中，被人遗忘；然而，由于阿威罗伊的学术成就，亚里士多德的哲学重新受到重视，并最终至少部分地融入了基督教神学。

Arab philosopher Averroës (1126–1198 CE) was born in Córdoba in what was then the Islamic land of Spain, which at that time enjoyed a great deal of intellectual freedom.5 Averroës wrote scholarly commentaries on all of Aristotle’s writings and, in that way, helped ensure that Aristotle’s ideas would be passed on to as yet unborn generations. In Europe, during the Middle Ages, when Christianity reigned supreme, Aristotle had been largely relegated to the dust piles of history and forgotten; however, thanks to Averroës’s scholarship, Aristotle’s philosophy came back into prominence and wound up being integrated, at least in bits and pieces, into Christian theology.

阿威罗伊认为，只要宗教著作与自然哲学家发展出的思想相矛盾，那么宗教文本就应该以隐喻或神话的方式进行解读，而不是从字面上理解。这是一种激进的立场，它为自然哲学和科学的繁荣铺平了道路，却牺牲了对《圣经》和《古兰经》的字面解读。通过这种方式，阿威罗伊奠定了坚实的思想基础，西方哲学的启蒙运动最终将以此为基础。

Averroës maintained, among other things, that whenever some piece of religious writing contradicted ideas that the natural philosophers had developed, then the religious text should always be interpreted either metaphorically or mythologically—not taken literally. This was a radical stance, and it cleared the way for natural philosophy and science to flourish, at the expense of literal interpretations of the Bible and the Koran. In this manner, Averroës laid down solid intellectual foundations on which the coming Enlightenment in Western philosophy would eventually be based.

文艺复兴

The Renaissance

直到 14 世纪末的意大利文艺复兴时期（法语单词renaissance意为“重生”），古希腊和罗马的人文主义教育理念才得以完全恢复生机。人类再次成为焦点。文艺复兴时期的“人”的概念从许多方面来说， “普世人” ( uomo universale ) 是对有关知识和人类潜力的长期被遗忘的观点的重新发现。

It was only in Renaissance Italy (the French word renaissance means “re-birth”), toward the end of the fourteenth century, that the humanistic ideals of education from ancient Greece and Rome were brought fully back to life. Humankind once again became the focal point. The Renaissance notion of a “universal man” (uomo universale) was, in many ways, a rediscovery of long-forgotten viewpoints concerning knowledge and the potential of humanity.

在文艺复兴时期，对人性和人类状况的研究成为主流——而且是以一种全新的方式。大学课程扩大到包括天文学、法律、几何学、医学和艺术等科目。这些科目的教师和他们的学生被称为人文主义者。文艺复兴时期的人文主义者发展了自己的新哲学传统，开始质疑教会处理“真理”概念的方式。特别是，他们提出了这样的观点：教会不再被视为知识的主要来源，甚至道德的主要来源。知识可以通过不同于甚至优于所谓来自上帝的启示的方式获得。一个人自己的观察和个人经历也可以成为获得知识的有效途径。独立思考成为一种美德，而不是一种令人恐惧或受到惩罚的行为形式。哲学的使命逐渐被视为提出好的问题，而不仅仅是恭敬地服务于基督教神学和教会制度。

The study of humanity and of the human condition emerged, during the Renaissance, into the foreground—and in a wholly new fashion. University courses expanded so as to include subjects like astronomy, law, geometry, medicine, and art. The teachers of these subjects, along with their students, came to be known as humanists. The Renaissance human-ists developed their own new philosophical tradition that started calling into question the church’s way of dealing with the concept of “truth.” In particular, they launched the idea that the church was no longer considered the primary source of knowledge, or even of morality. Knowledge could be gained in ways that were different from, and superior to, revelations supposedly emanating from God. One’s own observations and personal experiences could be just as valid a pathway to knowledge. Independent thinking became a virtue, rather than a form of behavior to be feared or punished. And the mission of philosophy gradually came to be seen as the asking of good questions, not merely the deferential serving of Christian theology and the institutions of the church.

人文主义者认为中世纪的宗教教义使人类屈从于上帝，他们希望恢复人类自尊和自主的状态。

The humanists believed that the religious teachings of the Middle Ages had rendered human beings subservient to God, and they wished to restore humanity to a state of self-respect and autonomy.

对天主教会的批评不仅来自人文主义者，也来自正在进行的教会改革的代表，这些改革由马丁·路德（1483-1546）等独立思想家领导。1517 年，路德发表了他的革命性论文《关于赎罪券权力的 95 条论纲》。约翰内斯·古腾堡当时发明的活字印刷术使路德的思想迅速而广泛地传播到整个欧洲，这首先导致了基督教会的分裂，然后导致了新教的创立。

Criticisms of the Catholic Church came not only from humanists but also from representatives of the ongoing reformation of the church, led by independent thinkers like Martin Luther (1483–1546). In 1517, Luther published his revolutionary tract “95 Theses on the Power of Indulgences.” The very recent development of movable type by Johannes Gutenberg allowed Luther’s ideas to be rapidly and widely distributed all over Europe, and this led first to the splintering of the Christian church, then to the founding of Protestantism.

十六世纪末，自然哲学家的思想开始对人们的思维产生影响。现代科学的雏形由此而来。科学迅速发展，以至于老式的​​基督教神学难以跟上并与之共存。

Toward the end of the sixteenth century, the ideas of the natural philosophers began exerting an influence on people’s thinking in general. Out of this came the first inklings of modern science. Science quickly made such rapid strides that old-fashioned Christian theology had a hard time keeping up with and coexisting with the new types of knowledge about the world.

十六世纪，英国哲学家和外交家弗朗西斯·培根对教会的宗教教义及其作为知识来源的主张提出了质疑（更不用说知识的来源了），他的思想比早期的批评产生了更持久的影响。培根提倡用哲学和自然科学来代替教会的教义，作为理解世界的工具。他认为理性，而不是启示，才是知识的真正来源。

In the sixteenth century, English philosopher and diplomat Francis Bacon called into question the church’s religious teachings and its claim to be a source of knowledge (let alone the source of knowledge), and his ideas had a more durable impact than earlier criticisms had had. In place of the church’s teachings, Bacon advocated philosophy and natural science as tools to understand the world. He believed that reason, not revelation, is the true source of knowledge.

十七世纪，意大利的伽利略、英国的艾萨克·牛顿等自然科学家发展出了一种全新的科学世界观，与教会的教义相矛盾，认为整个宇宙都受永恒的数学自然法则支配。

In the seventeenth century, natural scientists such as Italy’s Galileo Galilei and England’s Isaac Newton developed a brand-new scientific way of looking at the world, which contradicted the church’s teachings and which suggested that the entire universe was ruled by timeless mathematical laws of nature.

在那些快速变化的年代里，任何思想家公开质疑天主教的主流教义都是危险的。事实上，许多人曾警告伽利略不要声称哥白尼的日心说宇宙模型完全正确。（日心说世界观认为地球围绕太阳旋转，而不是相反。天主教会长期以来坚持地心说，即太阳围绕地球旋转。）伽利略漠然地驳斥了所有这些警告，结果，他大胆的理论招致了天主教会的愤怒。在宗教裁判所期间，他被捕并受到酷刑和处决的威胁；然而，在他承认了自己的罪行后，他的惩罚被减为监禁，后来又变成了软禁。

During these years of rapid change, it was risky for thinkers of any sort to publicly question the reigning Catholic doctrines. Many people, in fact, had warned Galileo against asserting that Copernicus’s heliocentric model of the cosmos was literally true. (A heliocentric worldview states that the earth rotates around the sun, rather than the reverse. The Catholic Church stuck for a very long time with the geocentric viewpoint, according to which the sun goes around the earth.) Galileo nonchalantly dismissed all such warnings, and as a result, with his bold theories he brought down on himself the wrath of the Catholic Church. During the Inquisition, he was arrested and threatened with torture and execution; however, after he had confessed his sins, his punishment was reduced to a jail sentence, which then turned into house arrest.

许多人都想知道伽利略是否真的向天主教会官员提供了足够的证据来支持他的日心说观点。当然，今天我们知道他是对的，但可以想象他是出于错误的理由才对的；因此，在某种意义上，人们可能会认为教会拒绝日心说立场是“出于善意”。另一方面，很明显，教会完全准备好折磨或杀死任何敢于反对圣经字面解释的科学家。英国哲学家斯蒂芬·劳在他之前引用的 2011 年著作《人文主义：非常简短的介绍》中写道：

Many people have wondered whether Galileo actually gave the officials of the Catholic Church sufficient evidence for his heliocentric views. Today, of course, we know that he was right, but it’s possible to imagine that he was right for the wrong reasons; therefore, one might, in some sense, maintain that the church acted “in good faith” when it rejected the heliocentric position. On the other hand, it’s clear that the church was perfectly ready to torture or kill any scientist who dared to contradict the literal interpretation of the Bible. In his earlier-cited 2011 book Humanism: A Very Short Introduction, British philosopher Stephen Law writes:

2000 年，教皇约翰·保罗二世公开为教会审判伽利略等事件道歉。然而，1990 年，前教皇本笃十六世枢机主教拉辛格引用了哲学家保罗·费耶阿本德的话，似乎表示赞同：

“在伽利略时代，教会比伽利略本人更忠于理性。对伽利略的审判过程（意为“审判”）是合理而公正的。” 6

In 2000, Pope John Paul II publicly apologized for, among other things, the Church’s trial of Galileo. However, in 1990, Cardinal Ratzinger—the former Pope Benedict—quoted philosopher Paul Feyerabend, seemingly with approval:

“At the time of Galileo the Church remained much more faithful to reason than Galileo himself. The process [meaning “the trial”] against Galileo was reasonable and just.”6

拉辛格这句话究竟意味着什么仍有待商榷，但它显然引起了一些人文主义者的质疑。7

Precisely what Ratzinger meant by this remark is a matter of debate, but it obviously raised a few humanist eyebrows.7

教会准备走多远，可以从乔尔丹诺·布鲁诺 (1548-1600) 的例子看出。布鲁诺是多米尼加教团的一名修道士，在那不勒斯附近的一座修道院里。他对科学和数学的研究使他形成了关于宇宙其他地方可能存在生命的想法——这些想法与天主教会的教义发生了深刻的冲突。结果，他被指控为异端。他别无选择，只能放弃修道院和修道士的服装，先搬到法国，然后搬到英国，再搬到德国。在这些国家，他因丰富的科学知识和独创的记忆记忆技巧等而备受尊敬。但最终，天主教宗教裁判所还是抓住了他，将他关进多个监狱，关押了八年，最后以异端罪名接受审判，被判有罪，并最终于1600年2月17日，在罗马著名的鲜花广场被烧死。这便是当时天主教会对思想家的崇敬。

How far the church was prepared to go is shown by the case of Giordano Bruno (1548–1600). Bruno was a monk in the Dominican order, in a monastery near Naples. His studies of science and mathematics led him to formulate ideas about life possibly existing in other parts of the universe—ideas that clashed profoundly with the Catholic Church’s doctrines. As a result, he was accused of heresy. He had little choice but to abandon the monastery and his monk’s garb, and he moved first to France, then to England, and thence to Germany. In those lands, he was highly respected for, among other things, his vast scientific knowledge and his original mnemonic techniques for memorization. Finally, however, the Catholic Inquisition caught up with him, and he was thrown into jail in various venues over a period of eight years, at the end of which he was put on trial for heresy, found guilty, and finally burned at the stake in Rome’s famous Campo dei Fiori (“Flower Meadow”) on the ignominious date of February 17, 1600. This is the kind of respect the Catholic Church had for thinkers in those days.

理性主义者和经验主义者

Rationalists and Empiricists

在十七世纪，数学和分析工具得到了发展，帮助当时的思想家以系统的方式进一步探索宇宙。

During the seventeenth century, mathematical and analytical tools were developed that helped thinkers of the day explore the universe much further—and in a systematic fashion.

得益于法国哲学家/数学家勒内·笛卡尔（1596-1650）、荷兰哲学家巴鲁克·斯宾诺莎（1632-1677）和德国哲学家/数学家戈特弗里德·威廉·冯·莱布尼茨（1646-1716）等杰出人物的发现，文艺复兴后期思想家获得了更深入分析和理解自然法则的关键工具。

Thanks to the discoveries of such brilliant minds as French philosopher/mathematician René Descartes (1596–1650), Dutch philosopher Baruch Spinoza (1632–1677), and German philosopher/mathematician Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz (1646–1716), later thinkers of the Renaissance acquired key tools for the deeper analysis and comprehension of the laws of nature.

除其他问题外，笛卡尔还思考了我们真正可以确定的知识类型。他试图通过问自己，他的所有信念是否可能不是“邪恶的魔鬼”给他误导性看法的结果，来分析知识的基础。人们怎么能确定事实并非如此呢？

Among other things, Descartes pondered what kinds of knowledge we can truly be sure of. He tried to analyze the basis of knowledge by asking himself whether all of his beliefs might not be the result of an “evil demon” that gave him misleading perceptions. How could one be sure that this is not the case?

他得出结论，至少他自己的存在是毋庸置疑的，因为要想被骗，他至少必须存在。这就是他著名的座右铭“我思故我在”背后的理念。笛卡尔也是一位二元论者，他认为身体和灵魂本质上是不同的物质，身体是三维空间中的物理结构（res extensa）不能思考，而灵魂是一个思考实体（res cogitans），没有物理范围，也没有空间位置。在随后的几个世纪里，笛卡尔的二元论观点对西方思想产生了深远的影响。

He concluded that at least his own existence was beyond doubt, because in order to be tricked, he at least had to exist. This was the idea that lay behind his celebrated motto Cogito ergo sum (“I think, therefore I am”). Descartes was also a dualist who believed that body and soul are essentially different substances, a body being a physical structure in three-dimensional space (res extensa) that cannot think, and a soul being a thinking entity (res cogitans) that has no physical extent and no location in space. In subsequent centuries, Descartes’s dualistic vision had a profound influence on Western thought.

瑞典女王克里斯蒂娜 (1626–1689) 对笛卡尔的思想非常着迷，并邀请他到斯德哥尔摩做她的老师。不幸的是，笛卡尔没有做好应对瑞典严酷冬季的准备，在斯德哥尔摩王宫住了几个月后，就因肺炎去世了。

Sweden’s Queen Christina (1626–1689) was fascinated by Descartes’s ideas and asked him to come to Stockholm to be her teacher. Unfortunately, Descartes was not prepared for the harshness of Swedish winters, and after having spent only a few months in the Royal Palace in Stockholm, he died of pneumonia.

巴鲁克·斯宾诺莎生于犹太家庭，被认为是当时最杰出的理性主义者之一。他认为，知识的来源是我们的理性能力，而不是感官知觉。他对上帝的定义与传统观念截然不同；他将上帝等同于自然，这种观点后来被一些人称为泛神论。他的许多同时代人都认为他是无神论者，因此，在年仅 24 岁时，他就被终身禁止加入阿姆斯特丹的任何犹太教会。

Baruch Spinoza, who by birth was Jewish, is considered as one of the most outstanding rationalists of his day. He maintained that our faculty of reason, not our sensory perceptions, is the source of our knowledge. His definition of God departed strikingly from traditional conceptions; he identified God with nature, a viewpoint that some people later called pantheism. Many of his contemporaries thought of him as an atheist, and for that reason, already at the tender age of twenty-four, he was barred for life from belonging to any Jewish congregation in Amsterdam.

戈特弗里德·威廉·冯·莱布尼茨为当今数学描述自然界所使用的一些基本工具的开发做出了贡献，尤其是微积分，他与艾萨克·牛顿同时发现了微积分。他做出了许多技术发现，其中之一就是“数学机器”，从某种意义上说，它是当今计算机的前身。

Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz contributed to the development of some of the primary tools that are used today in mathematical descriptions of nature, especially calculus, which he discovered simultaneously with Isaac Newton. He made many technical discoveries, one of which was a “mathematics machine” that, in a certain sense, was a forerunner of today’s computers.

这三位理性哲学家的共同点是相信推理是一切知识的基础，而经验主义者则倾向于认为知识源于感官知觉。

What these three rational philosophers had in common is the belief in reasoning as the basis of all knowledge, whereas the empiricists were inclined to see knowledge as originating in sensory perceptions.

经验主义观点最重要的代表人物是英国哲学家约翰·洛克（1632-1704），他的贡献主要集中在十七世纪后期。洛克不仅是英国启蒙运动的杰出人物，还启发了人们关于自由和平等的政治思想。他通常被认为是第一位经验主义者。他否认先天观念的存在，并认为婴儿出生时，其思想是一块白板，即“空白的石板”，在生命过程中会被感觉印象填满。在他的著作《人类理解论》（1689）中，洛克试图解释知识的局限性。

The most important representative of the empiricist point of view was English philosopher John Locke (1632–1704), whose contributions were made mostly in the latter part of the seventeenth century. Aside from being a salient figure of the Enlightenment in the British Isles, Locke inspired political thinking about freedom and equality. He is often considered to have been the first empiricist. He denied the existence of innate ideas and believed that when a baby is born, its mind is a tabula rasa, or “blank slate,” which then gets filled up by sense impressions during the course of life. In his book An Essay concerning Human Understanding (1689), Locke tried to explain the limits of knowledge.

经验主义的另外两个关键人物是爱尔兰哲学家乔治·贝克莱（1685-1753）和苏格兰哲学家大卫·休谟（1711-1776）。我们很快就会看到，休谟也将在即将到来的启蒙运动中扮演核心角色，启蒙运动对宗教进行了严厉批评。

Two other key figures in empiricism were Irish philosopher George Berkeley (1685–1753) and Scottish philosopher David Hume (1711–1776). Hume would also play a central role in the coming Enlightenment, which heavily criticized religion, as we shall soon see.

启蒙运动

The Enlightenment

科学进步、新的数学工具和哲学的理性转向为人们打开了全新的世界观之门。我们人类是否能够以某种方式理解我们自己所居住的世界？我们是否能够借助人类理性和科学教育，在一个完全缺乏神灵指引的世界里安然自处？

Scientific progress, new mathematical tools, and the rational turn in philosophy opened the door to a profoundly new attitude toward the world. Could it be that we human beings might somehow be able to understand ourselves in this world we inhabit? Could it be that, with the help of human reason and scientific education, we might feel comfortable with a world utterly lacking in divine guidance?

此类思想催生了一场新的思想运动，即启蒙运动。这场运动始于 18 世纪中叶，中心在法国。启蒙运动的核心思想是对人性及其理性力量的信仰。启蒙思想家拒绝对统治者和教会权威的盲目信仰。相反，启蒙运动的关键是社会由人组成，所有人都具有同等价值的思想。

Trains of thought of this sort gave rise to a new intellectual movement called the Enlightenment, which was launched in the middle of the 1700s and had its center in France. The key idea of the Enlightenment was a belief in humanity and its power of reason. Blind faith in rulers and in the authority of the church was rejected by Enlightenment thinkers. Rather, the Enlightenment’s linchpin was the idea that society consisted of human beings, all of whom had equal worth.

丹尼斯·狄德罗（1713-1784）是十八世纪法国启蒙运动的主要哲学家之一。他是《百科全书》的主编，这部著作是第一部通用参考书，共三十五卷，耗时三十年（从 1751 年到 1780 年）才完成。这是有史以来出版的最大百科全书，狄德罗亲自撰写了其中约六万篇文章中的几千篇；他还阅读、讨论和纠正了其余大部分文章。他还是一名散文家、哲学家、律师和艺术、文学和音乐评论家。最重要的是，他是一位直言不讳的妇女权利倡导者。8

Denis Diderot (1713–1784) was one of the leading philosophers of the Enlightenment in eighteenth-century France. He was the principal editor of L’Encyclopédie, the first universal reference work, which consisted of thirty-five volumes, and which took thirty years (from 1751 to 1780) to complete. It was the largest encyclopedia ever published, and Diderot himself penned several thousand of its roughly sixty thousand articles; he also read, discussed, and corrected most of the rest. He was also an essayist, philosopher, lawyer, and critic of art, literature, and music. On top of all that, he was an outspoken advocate of women’s rights.8

狄德罗是一位坚定的无神论者，他的《百科全书》包含许多激进和自然主义的思想。在一篇文章中，狄德罗将“开明的思想家”描述为“践踏偏见、传统、普遍认同和权威——总之，践踏所有奴役大多数人思想的东西——敢于独立思考的人”。（至于最后一个词“他自己”，那是女性完全被男性所掩盖的时代。可惜，就连狄德罗也没有完全开明。）

Diderot was a committed atheist, and his Encylopédie contains many radical and naturalistic ideas. In one of his articles, Diderot described “the enlightened thinker” as someone who “trampling on prejudice, tradition, universal consent, and authority—in a word, on all that enslaves most minds—dares to think for himself.” (As for that final word “himself,” well, those were the days when women were totally eclipsed behind men. Even Diderot wasn’t fully enlightened, alas.)

狄德罗在《百科全书》中偷偷加入了几篇批评教会及其神学的文章，尽管这样做非常有争议，并遭到了国家审查者的反对。他的写作室经常被搜查批评宗教、国家或主流道德的文章。《百科全书》在出版前就被禁了，狄德罗本人也多次被捕入狱。他在《哲学思想》（1746 年）中写道：“怀疑主义是迈向真理的第一步。”

Diderot slipped several articles into the Encyclopédie that criticized the church and its theology, even though doing so was very controversial and was opposed by the state-level censor. His writing rooms were often searched for articles that were critical of religion, of the state, or of the reigning morality. The Encyclopédie was banned even before it was published, and Diderot himself was arrested and thrown into prison on numerous occasions. In his Philosophical Thoughts (1746), he wrote that “[s]kepticism is the first step towards the truth.”

狄德罗尽其所能靠写作养活自己，但他也幸运地得到了俄国女皇叶卡捷琳娜二世（1729-1796）的经济资助。在叶卡捷琳娜二世的支持下，狄德罗前往俄国，并帮助她制定了未来俄国大学的计划。

Diderot did his best to support himself through his writing, but he also had the good fortune of being helped financially by Catherine the Great (1729–1796), the empress of Russia. Thanks to her support, Diderot traveled to Russia and helped her develop a plan for a future Russian university.

法国启蒙运动的另一位重要哲学家是弗朗索瓦-玛丽·阿鲁埃，他以笔名伏尔泰（1694-1778）而闻名。他强烈批评天主教会，并勇敢地捍卫人权和言论自由。伏尔泰的一句名言经常被引用，在有关言论自由的讨论中经常被引用：“先生，我不同意您的观点，但我会誓死捍卫您说话的权利。”

Another important philosopher of the French Enlightenment was François-Marie Arouet, better known by his adopted pen name, Voltaire (1694–1778). He was deeply critical of the Catholic Church and made valiant efforts to defend human rights and the freedom of speech. A famous line often attributed to Voltaire and frequently cited in discussions about the freedom of speech is this: “I disagree with what you have to say, Sir, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.”

显然伏尔泰从未说过这句话，但英国作家伊芙琳·比阿特丽斯·霍尔在 1906 年出版的《伏尔泰的朋友》一书中，在伏尔泰去世 128 年后，将这句话转述给了伏尔泰。虽然这不是一句确切的引语，但它确实雄辩地捕捉到了他的态度。

Apparently Voltaire never made this exact statement, but it was put into his mouth 128 years after he died by English writer Evelyn Beatrice Hall in her 1906 book The Friends of Voltaire. Although it is not an exact quote, it certainly captures his attitude eloquently.

伏尔泰反对一切形式的宗教教条主义和迷信，他坚信人类理性的力量有助于塑造一个更美好的世界。他最著名的作品是小说《老实人》（1756 年），这部讽刺小说讲述了天真的潘格罗斯博士的故事，他坚信我们生活在“所有可能的世界中最好的世界”。伏尔泰拒绝基督教，认为宗教是统治阶级奴役普通民众的一种手段。

Voltaire fought against all forms of religious dogmatism and superstition, and he strongly believed in the power of human reason to help shape a better world. His most famous work is the novel Candide (1756), an ironic satire about the naïve Doctor Pangloss, who is convinced that we live in “the best of all possible worlds.” Voltaire, who rejected Christianity, viewed religion as a way for the ruling classes to hold ordinary people in thrall.

伏尔泰在另一部著名著作《论宽容》（1763 年）中，对天主教会进行了猛烈的批判，指出“基督教教条主义精神所激起的强烈激情”。他在书中宣称，只有哲学和宽容才能最终战胜宗教狂热，并以爱尔兰的阿尔斯特叛乱为例：

In another famous work, Traité sur la tolérance (A Treatise on Tolerance), dating from 1763, Voltaire describes, in a powerful attack on the Catholic Church, the “violent passions that are aroused by the dogmatic spirit of Christian religions.” In it, he declares that only philosophy and tolerance can in the end defeat religious fanaticism, and as a case in point, he describes the Ulster Rebellion in Ireland:

一个人口更多、更富裕的爱尔兰将不再看到其天主教公民在两个月内将新教公民献祭给上帝，将他们活埋，将他们的母亲吊在绞刑架上，将他们的女儿绑在母亲的脖子上，看着她们一起死去；或者剖开孕妇的肚子，拉出半成品胚胎，然后把它们扔给狗和猪吃；或者把剑放在囚犯手中，将这些武器指向囚犯的妻子、父亲、母亲和女儿的胸部，希望以这种方式让他们杀死所有最亲近的亲人，不仅杀死他们，而且还确保他们将在地狱中永远受苦。9

A more populous and wealthier Ireland will no longer see its Catholic citizens, over a two-month period, sacrificing its Protestant citizens to God, burying them alive, hanging their mothers on scaffolds, tying their daughters to the necks of their mothers, and watching them expire together; or slicing open the bellies of pregnant women, pulling out the half-formed embryos, and tossing them to dogs and swine for food; or putting swords in the hands of prisoners and pointing these weapons toward the breasts of the prisoners’ wives, fathers, mothers, and daughters, hoping in this way to cause them to murder all their closest kin, and not just murder them but also ensure that they will suffer eternally in hell.9

伏尔泰在这里所描述的“圣战”强烈地使人联想到当今以伊斯兰名义进行的不同极端圣战分子（“圣战者”）之间的战争，尤其是在伊拉克和叙利亚。

The “holy war” that Voltaire here describes is strongly reminiscent of the war raging today between different brands of extremist jihadists (“holy warriors”) in the name of Islam, especially in Iraq and Syria.

伏尔泰和狄德罗的一位著名同代人是德国出生的法国哲学家保罗-亨利·蒂里，霍尔巴赫男爵（1723-1789），他深深致力于启蒙运动，写了许多书，并为《百科全书》做出了贡献。他最重要的著作是《自然体系》（1770 年），该书因其令人反感的内容而被焚毁。

A prominent contemporary of Voltaire and Diderot was German-born French philosopher Paul-Henri Thiry, baron d’Holbach (1723–1789), who was deeply committed to the Enlightenment, wrote a number of books, and contributed to the Encyclopédie. The most important of his own books was Système de la nature (1770), which was burned on account of its objectionable content.

霍尔巴赫是无神论者，他认为基督教不仅与理性相冲突，而且实际上是一种压迫人类的制度。他认为世界上的一切都可以被归结为物质及其支配的规律，他否认神和灵魂的存在。他还批评法国君主制及其造成的社会不平等。

Holbach was an atheist, and he argued that Christianity not only clashed with rationality but also was in fact a system designed to oppress humanity. He believed that everything in the world could be reduced to matter and the laws governing it, and he denied the existence of gods and of the soul. He was also critical of the French monarchy and of the social inequality that it gave rise to.

世俗哲学、道德和政治

Secular Philosophy, Morality, and Politics

1789 年的法国大革命深受启蒙运动哲学家思想的影响。法国以外的启蒙运动伟大思想家之一就是上文提到的苏格兰哲学家大卫·休谟。休谟不仅在知识论和宗教哲学方面做出了重大贡献，而且在道德和政治哲学方面也做出了重大贡献。

The French Revolution, in 1789, was profoundly inspired by the ideas of the philosophers of the Enlightenment. One of the Enlightenment’s great thinkers outside of France was Scottish philosopher David Hume, mentioned earlier. Hume made significant contributions not only to the theory of knowledge and the philosophy of religion but also to moral and political philosophy.

在他的第一本重要著作《人性论》（1739 年）中，休谟阐述了他对宗教的基本批判，而这种批判在早期著作中已经得到发展。由于他的思想被正确地视为提倡无神论，他被剥夺了哲学教授的职位。他关于宗教哲学的最伟大著作《自然宗教对话录》于 1776 年首次出版，他在书中充分阐述了自己的立场。

In his first major book, A Treatise of Human Nature (1739), Hume formulated his fundamental criticism of religion, which he had been developing in earlier writings. As a result of his ideas, which were correctly seen as advocating atheism, he was denied a position as professor of philosophy. His greatest work concerning the philosophy of religion, Dialogues concerning Natural Religion, was first published in 1776, and in it he stated his position with full force.

休谟批评了许多所谓的奇迹和奇事（这些术语意味着违反自然法），他的批评具有强烈的对当时的思想家产生了影响。他以非常普遍的方式分析了我们应该相信个人报告的情况，并得出结论，对于所谓奇迹的奇怪和令人震惊的报道，有比简单地接受这些奇迹确实发生的说法更好的解释。

Hume criticized many claimed testimonies of miracles and wonders (these terms meant violations of natural law), and his criticisms had a strong influence on thinkers of his day. He analyzed in a very general manner the circumstances under which we ought to believe in personal reports, and he concluded that there are far better explanations for strange and astonishing reports of alleged miracles than simply accepting the claims that such miracles actually took place.

十八世纪，启蒙思想迅速传遍欧洲，科学家、哲学家、作家联合起来，进一步发展启蒙思想。

The ideas of the Enlightenment spread rapidly throughout Europe during the eighteenth century. Scientists, philosophers, and writers joined together and further developed the ideas of the Enlightenment.

德国哲学家伊曼纽尔·康德（1724-1804）对启蒙思想产生了重大影响。他在1784年发表的著名论文《回答：什么是启蒙？》中这样描述启蒙：

German philosopher Immanuel Kant (1724–1804) exerted a major impact on the ideas of the Enlightenment. In his famous essay “Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist die Aufklärung?” (An Answer to the Question: What Is Enlightenment?), published in 1784, he describes enlightenment in the following manner:

启蒙是人类从自身强加的不成熟中脱颖而出。不成熟是指不依靠他人指导就无法运用自己的理解。当依赖他人的原因不是缺乏知识，而是缺乏依靠自己和独立于他人的决心和勇气时，这种不成熟就是自我强加的。Sapere aude！敢于求知！有勇气依靠自己的理解！10

Enlightenment is the emergence of human beings from their own self-imposed immaturity. Immaturity is the inability to use one’s understanding without relying on guidance from another person. This immaturity is self-imposed when the reason for reliance on others is not that one lacks knowledge, but rather, that one lacks the determination and the courage to rely on oneself and to be independent of others. Sapere aude! Dare to know! Have the courage to rely on your own understanding!10

康德的文章体现了启蒙运动的信念，即人类能够通过哲学反思、批判性推理、科学研究和政治变革而发展。他的言论“ Sapere aude！ ”（“敢于求知！”或“勇于运用自己的理性！”）甚至可以被视为整个启蒙运动的座右铭。

Kant’s essay captured the Enlightenment’s belief in the ability of humanity to develop through philosophical reflection, critical reasoning, scientific research, and political change. His expression “Sapere aude!” (“Dare to know!,” or “Have the courage to use your own rationality!”) could even be taken to be the motto of the entire Enlightenment.

这一时期英国最重要的启蒙思想家或许是律师兼哲学家杰里米·边沁（1748-1832 年）。在他生命的尽头，他写下了《自然宗教对人类世俗幸福影响的分析》（1822 年），在书中，他将宗教描述为非理性的（尽管可以完全解释为一种自然现象），而且对社会有害。边沁通常被认为是功利主义的创始人，功利主义是基于他的有用性概念的现代哲学。根据边沁的说法，道德原则并非源自超自然，而是完全可以源自一个基本前提：“为最多人谋取最大幸福”。边沁是教育的坚定倡导者，他认为教育是实现更大幸福和建立更美好社会的源泉。

Perhaps Britain’s foremost Enlightenment thinker during this period was lawyer/philosopher Jeremy Bentham (1748–1832). Toward the end of his life, he wrote Analysis of the Influence of Natural Religion on the Temporal Happiness of Mankind (1822), in which he described religion as irrational (although perfectly explicable as a natural phenomenon) and, moreover, as harmful to society. Bentham is usually considered to be the founder of utilitarianism, the modern philosophy based on his notion of usefulness. According to Bentham, the principles of morality do not have a supernatural origin but, instead, can be completely derived from just one basic premise: “The greatest happiness for the greatest number of people.” Bentham was a strong advocate of education, seeing it as a source of greater well-being and a better society.

边沁在动物权利哲学方面也有开创性的想法。例如，在《道德与立法原理导论》 （1789）中，他写道：

Bentham also had pioneering ideas concerning the philosophy of animal rights. For instance, in An Introduction to the Principles of Morals and Legislation (1789), he writes:

也许有一天，其他动物也能获得那些除非遭受暴政的制裁否则无法被剥夺的权利。

也许有一天，人们会认识到，腿的数量、皮肤的绒毛状或骶骨的末端都不足以成为让一个敏感的生物遭受同样命运的理由。

还有什么可以划出这条不可逾越的界线呢？是推理能力，还是话语能力？但一匹成年马或一只成年狗，比出生一天、一周甚至一个月的婴儿更理性，也更善于交谈。但假设它们不是这样，那又有什么用呢？问题不是“它们能推理吗？”也不是“它们能说话吗？”，而是“它们能受苦吗？”为什么法律要拒绝保护任何敏感的生物？人类将把其斗篷延伸到一切呼吸的事物之上的时代终将到来。11

The day may come when the rest of the animal creation may acquire those rights which never could have been withheld from them but by the hand of tyranny.

It may one day come to be recognized that the number of the legs, the villosity of the skin, or the termination of the os sacrum are reasons equally insufficient for abandoning a sensitive being to the same fate.

What else is it that should trace the insuperable line? Is it the faculty of reason, or perhaps the faculty of discourse? But a full-grown horse or dog is beyond comparison a more rational, as well as more conversable animal, than an infant of a day or a week or even a month old. But suppose they were otherwise, what would it avail? The question is not “Can they reason?” nor “Can they talk?,” but “Can they suffer?” Why should the law refuse its protection to any sensitive being? The time will come when humanity will extend its mantle over everything which breathes.11

在英国，启蒙运动的代表人物还包括哲学家、作家兼女权主义者玛丽·沃斯通克拉夫特（1759-1797）。她是玛丽·雪莱（1797-1851）的母亲，玛丽·雪莱于 1818 年创作了小说《弗兰肯斯坦》。玛丽·雪莱的丈夫珀西·比希·雪莱（1792-1822）也属于启蒙思想家群体，他们因持怀疑态度并拒绝接受宗教关于真理的主张而受到惩罚。在与玛丽结婚之前，19 岁的雪莱出版了《无神论的必要性》（1811 年）。由于这一行为，他被牛津大学开除。仅仅几年之后，1822年，伦敦《信使报》的一名记者在得知雪莱在海上丧生的消息后，对这位已故诗人的无神论进行了一次廉价的批评，他写道：“雪莱，这位异教诗歌的作者，已被淹死；现在他知道上帝是否存在了。”

In Great Britain, the Enlightenment was also represented by, among other philosophers, writer and feminist Mary Wollstonecraft (1759–1797). She was the mother of Mary Shelley (1797–1851), who wrote the novel Frankenstein in 1818. Mary Shelley’s husband, Percy Bysshe Shelley (1792–1822), also belonged to the group of Enlightenment thinkers who were punished for their skepticism and their refusal to accept religious claims about truth. Before he married Mary, already as a nineteen-year-old, Shelley published The Necessity of Atheism (1811). For this act, he was expelled from Oxford University. Only a few years later, in 1822, a journalist at the London Courier, upon learning of Shelley’s having perished at sea, took a cheap shot at the late poet’s atheism by writing “Shelley, the writer of some infidel poetry, has been drowned; now he knows whether there is a God or not.”

启蒙运动是一场争取自由的运动

The Enlightenment as a Movement for Freedom

启蒙时代及其哲学被许多人理解为一场自由运动。它的哲学让人们意识到，他们不需要接受宗教或政治的压迫。这种新思想在美国社会中发挥了核心作用。殖民地为摆脱英国殖民统治而进行的斗争，以及美利坚合众国的建立。

The Age of Enlightenment and its philosophy were understood by many as a freedom movement. Its philosophy raised people’s awareness of the fact that they did not need to accept being oppressed, either by religion or by politics. New ideas of this sort came to play a central role in the American colonies’ fight for freedom from Great Britain—and in the creation of the United States of America.

十八世纪英国殖民地争取自由的斗争中的核心人物和政治强人是启蒙思想家、作家、科学家和政治家本杰明·富兰克林（1706-1790）。富兰克林原本是费城的一名书籍印刷工，很快成为北美英国殖民地舆论形成和文化生活中的重要人物。后来，他还因对电的细致研究（他是第一个认识到电有两种——正电和负电）和避雷针的发明而闻名。富兰克林创立了美国哲学学会，为启蒙哲学从欧洲传播到美国做出了贡献。

A central figure and political powerhouse in the fight for freedom in the British colonies in the eighteenth century was Enlightenment thinker, writer, scientist, and politician Benjamin Franklin (1706–1790). Originally a book printer in Philadelphia, Franklin soon became an important figure in the formation of opinions and in the cultural life of the British colonies in North America. Later he also became famous for his careful studies of electricity (he was the first person to recognize that it came in two varieties—positive and negative) and for his invention of the lightning rod. Franklin founded the American Philosophical Society, which contributed to the spreading of the Enlightenment philosophy from European to American soil.

在英国与殖民地的冲突中，富兰克林一度充当中立的中间人，但后来他决定支持殖民者寻求独立。他成为起草《独立宣言》的委员会成员，1776 年 7 月 4 日，十三个殖民地宣布脱离英国独立。这一天成为美国的国庆节。富兰克林与托马斯·杰斐逊 (1743-1826) 合作，帮助建立了一个以启蒙运动哲学理想为基础的美国国家。杰斐逊随后于 1804 年成为该国第三任总统。

In the conflict between Britain and its colonies, Franklin served for a while as a neutral go-between, but then he decided to throw his support behind the colonists’ quest for independence. He became part of the committee that drafted the Declaration of Independence, and on July 4, 1776, the thirteen colonies declared their independence from Great Britain. That date became the national holiday of the United States. Working with Thomas Jefferson (1743–1826), Franklin helped create an American nation that was based on the philosophical ideals of the Enlightenment. Jefferson subsequently became the country’s third president in 1804.

十八世纪另一位重要的启蒙思想家是英国作家托马斯·潘恩（1737-1809）。1774年，他前往北美，倡导殖民地从英国统治中解放出来，事实上，潘恩是提出“美利坚合众国”这个名字的人。他是最早呼吁废除奴隶制和死刑的人之一。他还推动妇女权利，并提出了类似于今天向老年人提供社会保障金的想法。1793年，潘恩在他的著作《理性时代》中写道：

Another important Enlightenment thinker in the eighteenth century was British writer Thomas Paine (1737–1809), who in 1774 traveled to North America, where he advocated the colonies’ liberation from British rule, and in fact Paine was the person who came up with the name “the United States of America.” He was one of the first voices to call for the abolition of slavery and the death penalty. He also pushed for women’s rights and came up with an idea resembling today’s Social Security payments to elderly people. In 1793, in his book The Age of Reason, Paine writes:

我不相信犹太教会、罗马教会、希腊教会、土耳其教会、新教教会或我所知的任何教会所宣扬的教义。我自己的思想就是我自己的教会。所有国家教会机构，无论是犹太教、基督教还是土耳其教会，在我看来都不过是人类的发明，其设立的目的是恐吓和奴役人类，垄断权力和利润。

每当我们读到淫秽的故事、放荡的场面、残酷而曲折的处决、以及圣经中超过一半的内容都是这样的，我们称其为魔鬼的话语而不是上帝的话语更为合适。这是一部邪恶的历史，它使人类腐化和残暴；就我而言，我真心厌恶它，就像我厌恶一切残忍的东西一样。12

I do not believe in the creed professed by the Jewish church, by the Roman church, by the Greek church, by the Turkish church, by the Protestant church, nor by any church that I know of. My own mind is my own church. All national institutions of churches, whether Jewish, Christian or Turkish, appear to me no other than human inventions, set up to terrify and enslave mankind, and monopolize power and profit.

Whenever we read the obscene stories, the voluptuous debaucheries, the cruel and tortuous executions, the unrelenting vindictiveness with which more than half the Bible is filled, it would be more consistent that we call it the word of a demon than the word of God. It is a history of wickedness that has served to corrupt and brutalize mankind; and, for my part, I sincerely detest it, as I detest everything that is cruel.12

在这部作品出版之前，潘恩一直被誉为一位伟大的英雄，但这种反宗教的著作却使许多人反对他。

Up until the publication of this work, Paine had been acclaimed as a great hero, but this kind of antireligious writing turned many people against him.

讽刺的是，如今，正如我们已经指出的，尽管美国建国之初是世俗的，但如今它已成为一个非常宗教化的国家，基督教保守派和原教旨主义运动对美国政治产生了强大的影响。这种令人不安的趋势的一个例子是，托马斯·潘恩去世多年后，通常思想开明、以进步闻名的美国总统西奥多·罗斯福将他描述为“一个肮脏的小无神论者” 。13

Today, ironically, the United States has become, as we have already noted, a very religious country, despite its secular founding, and the Christian conservatives and the fundamentalist movement exert a powerful influence on American politics. An example of this troubling tendency is that Thomas Paine, many years after his death, was described by the usually open-minded and famously progressive American president Theodore Roosevelt as “a filthy little atheist.”13

十九世纪

The Nineteenth Century

19 世纪是科学真正蓬勃发展的世纪。医学和科技的巨大进步迅速改善了许多人的生活条件。

The 1800s were the century when science truly came into bloom. Great steps forward in medicine and technology rapidly changed the conditions of life of many people for the better.

这一时期一位重要的思想家是英国的约翰·斯图亚特·密尔（1806-1873），他的父亲詹姆斯·斯图亚特·密尔是杰里米·边沁的朋友。约翰·斯图亚特·密尔成为十九世纪英国自由主义的领军人物。他最有影响力的两部著作是《论自由》（1859 年）和《妇女的屈从》（1869 年），他与妻子哈丽特·泰勒·密尔共同发展了这两本书的思想。在这两本书中，他主张个人不可侵犯的自由和男女完全平等。他对十九世纪后半叶启蒙思想家的影响尤为强烈。

An important thinker of the period was England’s John Stuart Mill (1806–1873), whose father, James Stuart Mill, was a friend of Jeremy Bentham. John Stuart Mill became the leading figure of nineteenth-century British liberalism. The two works of his that have had the greatest lasting impact are On Liberty (1859) and The Subjection of Women (1869), whose ideas he developed with his wife Harriet Taylor Mill. In them, he argues for the inviolable freedom of the individual and for complete equality of the sexes. His influence on Enlightenment thinkers was particularly strong during the latter half of the nineteenth century.

谈到英国的启蒙运动，就不能不提伟大的博物学家查尔斯·达尔文（1809-1882）和他的同事托马斯·亨利·赫胥黎（1825-1895）。他们两人都不是严格意义上的启蒙哲学家，而是科学家。然而，正如我们前面所看到的，达尔文的自然选择理论和物种起源理论使我们得以绕过上帝的概念，上帝以不可思议的智慧精心设计了人类和动物。达尔文的巨作《物种起源》于 1859 年问世，立即引起了轩然大波。多年后——在1871年——他终于出版了《人类的由来》，具体描述了人类是自然进化的产物。

One could not write about the Enlightenment in Britain without mentioning the great naturalist Charles Darwin (1809–1882) and his colleague Thomas Henry Huxley (1825–1895). Neither of the two was an Enlightenment philosopher in the strict sense of the term; rather, both were scientists. As we saw earlier, however, Darwin’s theory of natural selection and the origin of species made it possible to bypass the idea of a god that, using an inconceivably vast intelligence, carefully designed humans and animals. Darwin’s magnum opus—his book On the Origin of Species—appeared in 1859 and immediately sparked a great uproar. Quite a number of years later—in 1871—he finally published The Descent of Man, which specifically described how human beings are a product of natural evolution.

如前所述，达尔文的进化论曾经被基督教、犹太教和伊斯兰教的宗教原教旨主义者所拒绝，现在仍然如此，但在严肃的科学界，毫无疑问，进化论是描述包括人类在内的所有生物物种发展的正确方式。

As was noted earlier, Darwin’s theory of evolution was, and still is, rejected by religious fundamentalists of the Christian, Jewish, and Islamic faiths, but in serious scientific circles there is no doubt whatsoever that the theory of evolution is the correct way to describe the development of all biological species, including human beings.

达尔文的朋友托马斯·亨利·赫胥黎是一位专攻解剖学的医生。1863 年，他在其著作《人类在自然界中地位的证据》中指出，人类（尽管书名如此，但实际上并非仅限于人类）的大脑结构与猿类十分相似。赫胥黎很快成为达尔文理论最重要的倡导者和推广者。事实上，他的表现为他赢得了“达尔文斗牛犬”这个滑稽的绰号。赫胥黎不仅对科学有着深厚的热情，而且口才极佳，能够巧妙地提出强有力的论据来反驳宗教观点。他创造了“不可知论”一词，而且他还是第一个提出鸟类是由恐龙进化而来的人。

Darwin’s friend Thomas Henry Huxley was a physician who specialized in anatomy. In 1863, he showed, in his book Evidence as to Man’s Place in Nature, the great similarities that exist between the brain structures of people (not only of men, despite his book’s title!) and apes. Huxley soon came to be the most important advocate of, and popularizer of, Darwin’s theory; in fact, his performances earned for him the droll nickname of “Darwin’s bulldog.” Huxley not only had a profound passion for science but also was a very eloquent orator and could skillfully muster powerful arguments against religious viewpoints. It was he who coined the term “agnosticism,” and moreover he was the first person to suggest that birds had evolved from dinosaurs.

1860 年 6 月 30 日，赫胥黎在牛津大学举行了一场精彩的演讲。演讲的双方是赫胥黎和主教塞缪尔·威伯福斯 (1805-1873)。威伯福斯是一位牧师，他主张以最直白的方式解释《圣经》，他“油腔滑调”的举止为他赢得了“肥皂山姆”的绰号。查尔斯·达尔文本应出席，但当时他病得很重，不得不待在家里卧床。威伯福斯主教以半小时的演讲开场，他使用的语言“时而严格合乎逻辑，时而极其轻蔑，总是华丽华丽”——他用这种语言尽可能猛烈地抨击进化论，最后尖刻地问赫胥黎，他（赫胥黎）是母亲那边的猿类后裔，还是父亲那边的猿类后裔。据说赫胥黎的回答大致如下（没有确切的辩论记录）：

One of Huxley’s great rhetorical performances took place at Oxford University on June 30, 1860. The occasion was a debate between Huxley and Bishop Samuel Wilberforce (1805–1873), a preacher who believed in interpreting the Bible in the most literal manner possible, and whose “greasy” demeanor had earned him the nickname of “Soapy Sam.” Charles Darwin would have attended, but he was very ill at the time and had to stay at home in bed. Bishop Wilberforce opened with half an hour of remarks using language that was “now strictly logical, now witheringly dismissive, always flamboyant”—and with this type of language he tore at the theory of evolution as fiercely as he could, concluding snidely by asking Huxley whether it was on his [Huxley’s] mother’s side or his father’s side that he was descended from apes. It is said that Huxley replied more or less as follows (no exact transcript of the debate exists):

我一点也不为自己祖先是猿猴而感到羞耻；另一方面，我为自己与一个滥用自己伟大才能，试图用空洞的言辞掩盖真相的人类有血缘关系而深感羞耻。

I am not in the least ashamed at having an ape as an ancestor; on the other hand, I feel deep shame at the fact of being related to a human being who abuses his great talents by attempting to hide the truth behind smokescreens of empty verbiage.

维维安·格林（Vivian Green）在她的著作《基督教新史》中对赫胥黎的反驳进行了稍微不同的报道，但更加详细，内容如下：

Vivian Green, in her book A New History of Christianity, reports Huxley’s retort somewhat differently but in greater detail, as follows:

一个人没有理由为祖父是猿猴而感到羞耻。如果说有一位祖先让我感到羞耻，那他应该是一位智力永不停歇、多才多艺的人，他不满足于在自己的领域取得成功，而是一头扎进他并不真正了解的科学问题中，结果却用漫无目的的言辞掩盖了这些问题，用雄辩的题外话和巧妙地诉诸宗教偏见来分散听众对真正问题的注意力。14

A man has no reason to be ashamed of having an ape for his grandfather. If there were an ancestor whom I should feel shame in recalling, it would be a man, a man of restless and versatile intellect, who, not content with an success in his own sphere of activity, plunges into scientific questions with which he has no real acquaintance, only to obscure them by an aimless rhetoric, and distract the attention of his hearers from the real point at issue by eloquent digressions, and skilled appeals to religious prejudice.14

无论两位对手究竟说了什么，这都是一个具有里程碑意义的时刻，双方的言辞都非常激烈，因为这是进化论首次被公开辩论。对于两人中谁是这场辩论的“赢家”，目前尚无定论，但这场战斗无疑已经展开。

Whatever the two opponents actually said, it was a monumental occasion, and the words on both sides were very heated, as it was the first time that evolution had ever been publicly debated. There is no consensus as to which of the two was the “winner” of the debate, but the battle had certainly been launched.

在德国，哲学家和神学家路德维希·费尔巴哈（1804-1872）提出，上帝的概念是人类自身内在本性的投射。具体来说，在他 1841 年出版的《基督教的本质》一书中，他试图表明，基督教的上帝概念实际上是理想人类的概念，是每个人心中都持有的概念。（顺便说一句，费尔巴哈的哥哥卡尔·威廉是一位天才数学家，他在 22 岁时发现了欧几里得几何中最美丽的定理之一，简称为“费尔巴哈定理”。不幸的是，他患有一种神秘的精神疾病，很年轻就去世了。）

In Germany, philosopher and theologist Ludwig Feuerbach (1804– 1872) proposed that the idea of God was a projection of humanity’s own inner nature. Specifically, in his 1841 book The Essence of Christianity, he tried to show that the Christian concept of God was in actuality the concept of an ideal human being, a notion that every person carries inside their mind. (Incidentally, Feuerbach’s older brother Karl Wilhelm was a profoundly gifted mathematician who at age twenty-two discovered one of the most beautiful theorems in all of Euclidean geometry, called simply “Feuerbach’s theorem.” Tragically, he suffered from a mysterious mental illness and died very young.)

德国哲学家弗里德里希·尼采（1844-1900）是路德维希·费尔巴哈的同时代人。1869 年，他成为瑞士巴塞尔大学的希腊语教授，但不久因病不得不离职。他强烈批评德国的反犹太主义和民族主义。在 1882 年出版的《快乐的科学》一书中，尼采宣称“上帝已死”，在《查拉图斯特拉如是说》（出版于 1883-1885 年）中，他又回到了这个主题。

German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche (1844–1900) was a contemporary of Ludwig Feuerbach’s. In 1869, he became professor of Greek at the University of Basel in Switzerland, but soon he had to leave his post because of illness. He was strongly critical of German antisemitism and nationalism. In his 1882 book The Gay Science, Nietzsche famously declared “God is dead,” and in Thus Spake Zarathustra (published in 1883–1885), he returned to this theme.

尼采是世界主义（世界公民的理念，与民族主义相对，后者本质上是相信国家和边界）的早期倡导者，他提倡一个统一、无边界的世界。他写道，基督教的道德观念是一种“奴隶道德”，即一种根植于自我否定、自我贬低和愤怒情绪的否定生命的态度，而宗教信仰是一种神经质状态。随着年龄的增长，尼采的心理变得越来越不稳定，最终在 1889 年遭受了严重的精神崩溃。尼采去世后去世后，他的妹妹伊丽莎白·福斯特-尼采 (Elisabeth Förster-Nietzsche) 负责管理她哥哥的档案，直到 1935 年她自己也去世。但不幸的是，她成了纳粹祸害的牺牲品，结果，她竭力把她的哥哥描绘成一位伟大的纳粹思想家——这很荒谬，因为他明确拒绝了一切民族主义和反犹太主义的观念。
