Nietzsche was an early advocate of cosmopolitanism (the idea of being a citizen of the world, as opposed to nationalism, which is essentially the belief in nations and borders), and he advocated a united and border-free world. He wrote that the Christian concept of morality was a “slave morality”—that is, a life-denying attitude rooted in self-denial, self-deprecation, and a sense of rage—and that the state of being religious was a neurotic condition. As he grew older, Nietzsche grew psychologically more and more unstable, and finally, in 1889, he suffered a serious mental breakdown. After Nietzsche’s death, his sister, Elisabeth Förster-Nietzsche, managed her brother’s archives until she herself died in 1935. Unfortunately, though, she fell victim to the scourge of Nazism, and as a result, she did her best to paint her brother as a great Nazi thinker—an absurdity, since he had expressly rejected all notions of nationalism and antisemitism.

在十九世纪的瑞典，也有启蒙思想家批判基督教和教会的权力。1888 年，维克多·伦斯特兰德（Viktor Lennstrand，1861-1895 年）创立了瑞典功利主义学会，并成为其首任会长。伦斯特兰德年轻时原本是一位虔诚的福音派基督徒，但在 20 岁左右时，他脱离了所有宗教，成为一名讲师和作家，主要关注对宗教的批判。由于这一“罪行”，他多次被判入狱。

In Sweden, too, during the nineteenth century, there were Enlightenment thinkers who criticized Christianity and the church’s power. In 1888, Viktor Lennstrand (1861–1895) founded the Swedish Utilitarian Society and became its first president. As a youth, Lennstrand had originally been a deeply believing evangelical Christian, but at around age twenty, he broke away from all religion and became a lecturer and writer focusing mainly on the criticism of religion. For this “crime,” he served numerous prison sentences.

1889 年，维克多·伦斯特兰德 (Viktor Lennstrand) 创办了一份名为《自由思想者：瑞典自由思想者的喉舌》 (Fritänkaren: Organ för Sveriges fritänkare ) 的报纸，他在该报创刊号的头版上解释了需要这样一份报纸的原因：

In 1889, Viktor Lennstrand launched a newspaper called Fritänkaren: Organ för Sveriges fritänkare (The Freethinker: Organ for Sweden’s Free-thinkers), and here is how he explains, on the front page of the newspaper’s first issue, the reasons that such a newspaper was needed:

鉴于我们国家很快将不再有任何地方允许自由思想蓬勃发展，不再有诚实的真理追求者聚集在一起交流思想、鼓动启蒙人民、摆脱中世纪迷信的地方；鉴于反动保守媒体不仅赞同而且公开提倡暴力镇压一切旨在解放推理和思想、培养自我意识的运动……因此，在我们看来，只剩下一个选择：建立我们自己的新闻媒体，作为所有真正自由思想者的守护者；在这个媒体中，我们可以在有思想的公众面前表达真理的语言，在这个媒体中，我们可以洗脱不公正的指控，并向公众法庭提交我们的案件以供审判。15

Whereas there will soon no longer remain any place in our nation where free thought is allowed to thrive and where honest truth-seekers can gather for the purposes of exchanging ideas and agitating for the enlightenment of the people and for liberation from medieval superstitions; and whereas the reactionary and conservative press not only approves of but openly advocates the violent suppression of every movement that aims at the liberation of reasoning and thinking and the fostering of awareness for its own sake . . . it thus seems to us that there is only one choice left: to found our own journalistic medium, acting as a guardian for all true freethinkers of all stripes; a medium in which we, before a thinking public, can present the language of truth, and in which we can exonerate ourselves from unjust accusations and present our case for the judgment of the public court.15

这篇瑞典语社论刊登在 1889 年 6 月 1 日创刊号《Fritänkaren》的头版上。讽刺的是，这份新报纸的编辑和印刷地址是 Kyrkogatan 9A，也就是教堂街 9A 号。

This editorial text, in Swedish, was printed on the front page of the very first edition of Fritänkaren, on June 1, 1889. Ironically, the new newspaper was edited and printed in a building whose address was Kyrkogatan 9A—that is, 9A Church Street.

由于他所作的演讲，如“基督教道德与理性道德”、“来世还有生命吗？”和“我们功利主义者想要什么？”维克多·伦斯特兰德因亵渎神明多次被起诉。他还因侵犯自由而被起诉他在出版《厄勒布鲁六论纲》（以他在一次演讲中提出这些论纲的瑞典小镇命名）时引起了媒体的关注，该论纲内容如下：

As a result of lectures that he gave, bearing titles such as “Christian Morality and Rationalistic Morality,” “Is There a Life after This One?,” and “What Do We Utilitarians want?” Viktor Lennstrand was prosecuted numerous times for blasphemy. He was also prosecuted for violation of freedom of the press when he printed his “Six Theses of Örebro” (named after the Swedish town in which he stated them in a lecture), which ran as follows:

  1. 圣经的书写方式与我们今天写书籍和信件的方式相同。
  2. The books of the bible were written in the same way as we write books and letters today.
  3. 旧约中的神是一个罪人。
  4. The god of the Old Testament is a sinner.
  5. 基督教的诸神并不比奥丁、朱庇特或塞拉皮斯（古希腊埃及神）更伟大。
  6. Christianity’s gods have no greater reality to them than do Odin, Jupiter, or Serapis [an ancient Græco-Egyptian deity].
  7. 自然、人类经验和历史全都证明不存在无所不在的天国和全能的神。
  8. Nature, human experience, and history all are evidence against the existence of an omnipresent heavenly realm and an all-powerful god.
  9. 没有新耶路撒冷，也没有硫磺火地狱，也没有死后的个人意识。
  10. There is no new Jerusalem, nor is there a fire-and-brimstone hell, nor is there a personal consciousness beyond the grave.
  11. 道德和伦理的最高形式与神学或宗教教条无关，服务他人的生活才是最好的生活。16
  12. The highest form of morality and ethics has ties neither to theology nor to religious dogma, and a life of service is the best possible sort of life.16

自由思想者和无神论者

Freethinkers and Atheists

我们已经看到，世俗思想起源于古希腊，然后在意大利文艺复兴时期和英国和法国启蒙运动时期得到进一步发展，直到今天。贯穿所有这些阶段的共同点是自由思想：人类有权利（也是义务！）不受教条束缚，而是借助我们与生俱来的推理能力进行思考。这就是为什么在本书中，“自由思想”一词几乎与非宗教观点的概念，尤其是无神论世界的概念互换使用。

We have seen that secular thinking sprang out of ancient Greek roots, then developed further during the Renaissance in Italy and during the Enlightenment in England and France, until it reached its stage today. A common thread running through all these stages was free thought: the right (and the duty!) of human beings to think without dogmas but with the help of the reasoning faculty that is our innate heritage. That is why, in the present book, the term “free thinking” has been used almost interchangeably with the idea of a nonreligious viewpoint and, particularly, with the idea of a godless world.

某些自由思想家能够想象出一个神，他（或“那个”）是“最初的创造者”，创造了宇宙，使宇宙运转起来，但在随后的事件发展中却没有发挥任何作用。这种对抽象神的态度被称为自然神论。自然神论者认为，即使有（或曾经有）一个创造世界的神圣实体，我们今天的人类也不再与那个实体有任何关系。因此，宗教和教会是人类的发明，它们不具有来自任何更高权力的合法性。

Certain freethinkers were able to imagine a god who (or “that”), being an “original creator,” had launched the universe, setting it into motion but subsequently playing no role in the course of events that ensued. Such an attitude about such an abstract god is called deism. Deists think that even if there is (or once was) a divine entity that created the world, we humans today no longer have any relationship with that entity. And thus, religion and the church are human inventions, and they do not have legitimacy coming from any higher powers.

其他自由思想家则是直言不讳的无神论者。但自由思想的自然神论者和自由思想的无神论者有一个共同点，那就是人类问题应该通过理性分析和仔细研究来解决——并且自由思想家们的思想与启蒙运动的思想相辅相成，他们的观点是建立在人类价值观基础上的道德观，而不是盲目地信仰某种看不见的神。自由思想家的观点与启蒙运动的思想相辅相成。

Other freethinkers were outspoken atheists. But what freethinking deists and freethinking atheists had in common was the view that human problems should be solved through rational analysis and careful study—and with the help of a morality rooted in human values, rather than through a blind faith in some sort of invisible god. The freethinkers’ views thus went hand in hand with the ideas of the Enlightenment as they were developing.

现代形式的自然神论信仰可能是某种神灵引发了大爆炸（宇宙学家假设的传说中的灾难性事件就是我们宇宙诞生的时刻），但除此之外，这种神灵与人类或我们居住的世界无关。这种自然神论观点可能与世俗价值观以及关于社会应如何组织和发展的世俗观念相容，但它肯定与世俗人文主义信仰相矛盾，即世界是可以理性理解和解释的。毕竟，如果宇宙的存在是自然的并且是可以解释的，那么就不可能有任何超自然的和“无法解释的”神创造它。

A modern form of deistic belief might be that some sort of divine being caused the Big Bang (the legendary cataclysmic event postulated by cosmologists to be the moment our universe came into existence), but aside from that, this being has nothing to do with human beings or the world we inhabit. Such a deistic viewpoint might be compatible with secular values and a secular notion of how society should be organized and should develop, but it is certainly not compatible with the secular-humanistic belief that the world is rationally comprehensible and explicable. After all, if the existence of the universe is natural and potentially explicable, then there cannot be any supernatural and “inexplicable” god that created it.

插曲：论自由意志

INTERLUDE: ON FREE WILL

我们人类有自由意志吗？

Do we human beings have free will?

我们的选择要么由过去决定，要么独立于过去。我们要么自由地做出决定，要么不自由。但究竟是哪一种呢？

Either our choices are determined by the past, or they are independent of it. Either we make decisions freely, or we don’t. But which way is it?

这个问题非常棘手，尤其是对我们这些对现实持自然主义观点的人来说。对于相信某种神的人来说，这个问题比较简单；毕竟，对他们来说，人是由身体和灵魂组成的，而这两个现象是分开的。从他们的角度来看，上帝赋予我们每个人自由意志，以便我们可以选择自己的行为。这使得自由意志成为现实的一个自主部分，故事结束。

The question is very tricky, particularly for those of us who have a naturalistic view of reality. The matter is simpler for people who believe in some sort of god; after all, for them, a person consists of a body and a soul, and the two are separate phenomena. From their point of view, God gave each one of us a free will so that we could choose our actions. That makes free will an autonomous part of reality, end of story.

但对于我们这些不接受这一观念的人来说，情况又如何呢？我们这些不把任何经文视为神圣的人，我们这些拒绝相信永恒灵魂被上帝赋予自由意志的人，又如何看待自由意志这个概念呢？

But how is it for those of us who don’t accept that notion? What do we—we who hold no scriptures sacred, and who refuse to buy into the idea of eternal souls divinely imbued with free will—think about the notion of free will?

我们知道，所有物理过程都遵循某些精确的数学定律，即自然定律。经典自然定律（直到 20 世纪 20 年代中期，物理学家们都相信这些定律）是确定性的，因此原则上所有事件都是可预测的。量子力学取代了经典定律，它认为确定性可预测的是一组概率，而不是实际结果，而这些结果是爱因斯坦讨厌的“骰子”的结果。虽然量子力学不再像经典物理学那样具有确定性，但它不包括或允许任何“意志”的干预。“意志”的概念不是物理定律的一部分。

We know that all physical processes obey certain precise mathematical laws—the laws of nature. The classical laws of nature (those that physicists believed in until the mid-1920s) were deterministic, and thus all events were in principle predictable. Quantum mechanics, which superseded the classical laws, says that what is deterministically predictable is a set of probabilities rather than actual outcomes, and that the outcomes are a result of the “dice” that Einstein hated. Though it is no longer deterministic in the way classical physics was, quantum mechanics doesn’t include or allow intervention by any kind of “will.” The idea of “will” is not part of the laws of physics.

那么，人类如何拥有自由意志？如果意识是物质及其物理定律的结果，那么这些定律是否也适用于涉及意识的现象？物质——无论是无生命还是有生命——总是遵循自然定律，无论是经典的还是量子力学的，这一事实难道不会彻底摧毁自由意志吗？

And so, how can human beings have free will? If consciousness is an outcome of matter and of physical laws governing it, don’t these laws also apply to phenomena involving consciousness? Doesn’t the fact that physical matter—whether inanimate or animate—always obeys natural law, whether it’s classical or quantum mechanical, throw free will completely down the drain?

我觉得我好像有自由意志。例如，当我去我最喜欢的意大利餐厅时，我可以选择意大利饺子还是意大利烩饭（我也可以同样轻松地选择去印度餐厅）；我可以快速浏览电视上的所有频道，然后决定是想看日本烹饪节目还是老电影英格玛·伯格曼。我所有的选择都是预先确定的，还是都是微小的掷骰子的随机结果？

It feels to me as if I have free will. I can choose, for example, between ravioli and risotto when I go to my favorite Italian restaurant (and I could just as easily have chosen to go to the Indian restaurant); I can rapidly surf all the channels on my television and then decide whether I want to watch the Japanese cooking show or the old Ingmar Bergman movie. Are all my choices predetermined, or are they all random results of microscopic dice throws?

确实，量子力学核心的随机性会不会是我自由意志的来源？乍一听很有吸引力，但不幸的是，这没有任何意义。毕竟，今晚我选择意大利烩饭而不是意大利饺子，感觉上并不是随机的，我选择看《夏夜微笑》而不是《食神》，感觉上也不是随机的。相反：在这两种情况下，我都感觉自己先仔细思考了一下，然后根据我刚才的思考做出了判断。随机性和经过深思熟虑的判断有什么关系呢？

Indeed, could the randomness at the heart of quantum mechanics be the source of my free will? At first it sounds appealing, but unfortunately it doesn’t make any sense. After all, it hardly felt as if my choice of risotto tonight, rather than ravioli, was made at random, nor did it feel as if I chose randomly to watch Smiles of a Summer Night rather than Iron Chef. To the contrary: it felt, in both cases, as if I first thought things through, and then made a judgment call on the basis of my just-made reflections. What would randomness have to do with a carefully thought-out judgment call?

如果我非常仔细、详细地考虑了各种选择及其后果，但我的决策机制却粗暴地忽略了我的想法，只是将抛硬币或掷骰子作为选择的基础，那么我的深思熟虑又有什么用呢？毫无用处！

If I think through the alternatives and their consequences with great care and in great detail, but then if my choice-making mechanism rudely ignores my thoughts and simply takes the flip of a coin or the toss of some dice as the basis for its choice, what purpose did my careful ponderings serve? None at all!

现代神经科学为这些古老的谜题提供了迷人的启示。有实验表明，大脑在我们有意识地做出决定之前就启动了决策过程。神经科学家 JD Haynes 让受试者站在两个按钮前，一个在左边，一个在右边。受试者可以决定何时按下按钮以及按下哪个按钮。在他们这样做的同时，他们的大脑活动被 fMRI 设备（功能性磁共振成像）记录下来。Haynes 发现，有时决策在实际执行前十秒就已经做出了。

Modern neuroscience sheds fascinating light on these ancient enigmas. There are experiments that demonstrate that the brain activates decision-making processes before we consciously make up our minds. Neuroscientist J. D. Haynes placed a subject in front of two buttons, one on the left and one on the right. Subjects were allowed to decide when to push either button, and which button to push. And while they were doing so, their brain activity was being recorded by an fMRI device (functional magnetic-resonance imaging). Haynes discovered that sometimes the decision had already been made as long as ten seconds before it was actually carried out.

似乎这还不够，大脑的不同部位被激活，这取决于接下来的决定是选择左边的按钮还是右边的按钮。因此，选择按哪个按钮的“自由”决定是完全提前决定的。

As if that weren’t enough, different parts of the brain were seen to be activated, depending on whether the upcoming decision was going to be to choose the lefthand button or the righthand button. Thus the “free” decision as to which button to push was completely determined long in advance.

从这类实验来看（已经有很多实验了），我们所有人的印象——即做出有意识的选择——似乎只是一种幻觉。但自由意志真的只是一种幻觉吗？

From experiments of this sort (and there have been many), it seems as if the impression that we all have—namely, that of making conscious choices—is simply an illusion. But can free will truly be nothing but an illusion?

道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特（Douglas Hofstadter）在其著作《我是一个奇怪的循环》第 23 章中欣然接受了“意志”是大脑内部真实存在的（尽管是突发事件）现象的观点，但他认为，认为一个人的意志或任何其他人的意志是“自由的”是一个严重的错误：

Douglas Hofstadter, in chapter 23 of his book I Am a Strange Loop, gladly accepts the idea that “will” is a real (although emergent) phenomenon inside a brain, but he argues that it’s a grave error to think that one’s own will, or anyone else’s will, is “free”:

我很高兴自己有意愿……但我不知道如果我的意愿是自由的，那会是什么感觉。那到底意味着什么？我有时不遵从自己的意愿？好吧，我为什么要这么做？为了挫败自己？我想，如果我想挫败自己，我可能会做出这样的选择——但那只是因为我想挫败自己，因为我的元层次欲望比我平凡的欲望更强烈。

因此，我可能会选择不吃第二份面条，尽管我——或者说，我的一部分——仍然想吃一些，因为我的另一部分希望我不会发胖，而减肥的部分恰好（今晚）比贪吃的部分拥有更多的选票。如果不是这样，那么它就会失败，而我内心的贪吃就会获胜，那就没问题了——但无论哪种情况，我的非自由意志都会胜出，我会遵循大脑中的主导欲望。

是的，当然，我会做出决定，我会通过一种内部投票来做出决定。计票结果会出来，天哪，一方会胜出。但这一切哪里有“自由”可言？……

我们的意志与自由截然相反，它是坚定而稳定的，就像一个内在的陀螺仪，而正是我们非自由意志的稳定性和恒定性，使我成为我，你成为你，也使我成为我，你成为你。17

I am pleased to have a will . . . but I don’t know what it would feel like if my will were free. What on earth would that mean? That I didn’t follow my will sometimes? Well, why would I do that? In order to frustrate myself? I guess that if I wanted to frustrate myself, I might make such a choice—but then it would be because I wanted to frustrate myself, and because my meta-level desire was stronger than my plain-old desire.

Thus I might choose not to take a second helping of noodles even though I—or rather, part of me—would still like some, because there’s another part of me that wants me not to gain weight, and the weight-watching part happens (this evening) to have more votes than the gluttonous part does. If it didn’t, then it would lose and my inner glutton would win, and that would be fine—but in either case, my non-free will would win out and I’d follow the dominant desire in my brain.

Yes, certainly, I’ll make a decision, and I’ll do so by conducting a kind of inner vote. The count of votes will yield a result, and by George, one side will come out the winner. But where’s any “freeness” in all this? . . .

Our will, quite the opposite of being free, is steady and stable, like an inner gyroscope, and it is the stability and constancy of our non-free will that makes me me and you you, and that also keeps me me and you you.17

我非常赞同霍夫施塔特的立场，他本质上声称自由意志之谜只是幻觉造成的伪问题，但尽管我觉得他走在正确的道路上，我还是不敢说今天有人已经彻底解决了自由意志之谜。我们肯定离答案越来越近了，但还没有完全解决。所以在我看来，自由意志问题仍然是现代意识研究和“神经哲学”学科的核心。

I am very sympathetic to Hofstadter’s stance, which essentially claims that the free will riddle is just a pseudo-problem caused by an illusion, but even though I feel he is on the right track, I would hesitate to say that anyone today has definitively solved the free will mystery. We’re surely getting closer, but we’re not all the way there yet. So in my view, the free will question remains central to modern consciousness research and to the discipline called “neurophilosophy.”

无论自由意志是什么（或不是什么），有一件事是肯定的：我们必须按照我们的意志是自由的方式来组织我们的社会和生活。否则，我们将无法想象，因为一旦我们不再相信人们真的会做出决定，不再相信人们真的会做出自己的个人决定，我们就不再有任何理由承担任何形式的道德责任——而这将摧毁我们所熟知的社会。

Whatever free will is (or isn’t), one thing is true for sure: It is crucial that we organize our society and our lives as if our wills were free. It would be unthinkable for us to do otherwise, since the moment that we cease to believe that people really do make up their minds, and that people really do frame their own personal decisions, then we will no longer have any grounds for any sort of moral accountability—and that would destroy society as we know it.

毫无疑问，人类大脑可以学习道德规则和价值观，让我们能够和谐共处。这是人类本性的伟大之处。无论我们有多自由或不自由，我们都可以而且必须欢迎普遍的道德标准。

There’s no doubt that the human brain can learn moral rules and values that make it possible for us to all live together in harmony. This is a great thing about human nature. No matter how free or unfree we are, we can and must welcome universal moral standards.

第十二章

CHAPTER TWELVE

当今的世俗声音关于敬畏、政治和宗教

SECULAR VOICES IN OUR DAY Concerning Awe, Politics, and Religion

无需证据就能断言的事情，同样无需证据就能驳斥。——克里斯托弗·希钦斯1

What can be asserted without evidence can also be dismissed without evidence.—Christopher Hitchens1

我二十世纪，一种被称为“世俗人文主义”的启蒙思想开始盛行。我们将会看到，尽管这种思想在几个世纪后仍然引起争议，但它很早就获得了强有力的拥护者，他们共同推动了西方社会向世俗主义靠拢。

I t was during the twentieth century that the form of enlightenment known as “secular humanism” came into full bloom. As we will see, although it stirred up controversy even after so many centuries, it acquired early and strong advocates who collectively helped forge a Western society leaning toward secularism.

20 世纪欧洲最先提倡这一传统的人或许是英国数学家、哲学家和社会理论家伯特兰·罗素。（罗素的教父是约翰·斯图尔特·密尔，小伯蒂出生仅一年后密尔就去世了。随着罗素逐渐长大，他的思想深受教父思想的影响。）

Perhaps the foremost advocate for this tradition in Europe during the twentieth century was British mathematician, philosopher, and social theorist Bertrand Russell. (Russell’s godfather was John Stuart Mill, who died only one year after little Bertie was born. As he grew older, Russell’s thoughts were deeply affected by his godfather’s thoughts.)

罗素最具影响力的作品之一是他与英国著名哲学家阿尔弗雷德·诺思·怀特黑德（Alfred North Whitehead，1861-1947）合著的三本巨著《数学原理》（1910-1913）。在这部宏伟著作中，两位作者勇敢地努力在纯公理逻辑的基础上发展整个数学。然而，二十年后——1931 年——这两位勇敢思想家的崇高梦想突然被奥地利逻辑学家库尔特·哥德尔的革命性发现永远粉碎了。哥德尔发现，不仅《数学原理》存在根本的、无法弥补的不完整性，而且所有旨在捕捉所有数学真理的公理推理系统也存在根本的、无法弥补的不完整性。罗素从未完全从这次毁灭性的打击中恢复过来。

Among Russell’s most influential works were the three massive tomes called Principia Mathematica (1910–1913), which he coauthored with eminent British philosopher Alfred North Whitehead (1861–1947). In this grandiose work, the two authors valiantly strove to develop all of mathematics on the sole basis of pure axiomatic logic. Two decades later—in 1931—the two brave thinkers’ noble dream, however, was suddenly and forever shattered by Austrian logician Kurt Gödel’s revolutionary discovery of the fundamental and irremediable incompleteness not only of Principia Mathematica but of all axiomatic reasoning systems aiming at capturing all of mathematical truth. Russell never fully recovered from this devastating blow.

在他著名（也是臭名昭著）的著作《我为什么不是基督徒》（1958 年）中，罗素描述了他如何对宗教持怀疑态度；这本书的出版深深震撼了英国文化界。罗素也是一名政治活动家，除其他外，他还为废除核武器而奋斗，晚年，强烈反对越南战争。1967 年，罗素与法国哲学家让-保罗·萨特（1905-1980 年，萨特最著名的著作是《存在与虚无》（1943 年）和《存在主义与人文主义》（1946 年）一起，在斯德哥尔摩成立了国际战争罪法庭（通常简称为“罗素法庭”），其宣称的目的是调查和评估美国的外交政策和对越南的军事干预。许多著名的国际人物都参与其中，罗素引用纽伦堡战争罪审判首席检察官罗伯特·H·杰克逊的话来解释设立法庭背后的理由：

In his famous (and also infamous) book Why I Am Not a Christian (1958), Russell describes how he had come to his skeptical point of view concerning religion; the publication of this book deeply shook up the British cultural establishment. Russell was also a political activist, who, among many other things, fought for the abolishment of nuclear weapons and, in his later years, stridently opposed the Vietnam War. Together with French philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre (1905–1980), among whose most famous works are Being and Nothingness (1943) and Existentialism and Humanism (1946), Russell in 1967 set up the International War Crimes Tribunal (often simply called the “Russell Tribunal”) in Stockholm, whose declared purpose was to investigate and evaluate U.S. foreign policy and military intervention in Vietnam. Many prominent international figures participated, and Russell explains the rationale behind the tribunal by quoting Robert H. Jackson, the chief prosecutor at the Nuremberg War Crimes Trials:

如果某些行为和违反条约的行为是犯罪，那么无论是美国还是德国实施的，它们都是犯罪。我们不愿意制定一条针对他人的犯罪行为规则，而我们自己也不愿意援引这条规则来对付我们。2

If certain acts and violations of treaties are crimes, they are crimes whether the United States does them or whether Germany does them. We are not prepared to lay down a rule of criminal conduct against others which we would not be willing to have invoked against us.2

然而，当被问及北越所犯下的战争罪行是否也将接受该法庭的调查时，罗素的发言人傲慢地回答道：“罗素勋爵不会认为这样做比审判华沙犹太区的犹太人反抗纳粹的起义更愚蠢。” 3

When the issue, however, was raised as to whether alleged war crimes committed by North Vietnam would also be investigated by the tribunal, Russell’s spokesperson haughtily replied: “Lord Russell would think no more of doing that than of trying the Jews of the Warsaw Ghetto for their uprising against the Nazis.”3

毫无疑问，这是一次巧妙的嘲讽式反驳，但有时人们不得不怀疑这种双重标准，即使是伟大的思想家有时也会持有这种标准。毕竟，对鹅来说，酱汁对鹅来说也是酱汁。

This was no doubt a clever retort via mockery, but one sometimes has to wonder about double standards of this sort, which are occasionally held even by great thinkers. What’s sauce for the goose is, after all, sauce for the gander.

不出所料，伯特兰·罗素对世俗人文主义的深入参与引发了问题。在美国，他遭到了强烈的诽谤，尽管 1939 年他被邀请到纽约城市大学担任教授，但他因无神论和“不道德”而受到恶毒攻击，最终他被阻止接受这一职位。1950 年，罗素被授予诺贝尔文学奖，“以表彰他丰富多彩且意义重大的著作，在这些著作中他倡导人道主义理想和思想自由。”

As might be expected, Bertrand Russell’s intense involvement in secular humanism gave rise to problems. In the United States, he was subjected to an intense campaign of slander, and although in 1939 he was offered a professorship at the City College of New York, he was viciously attacked for his atheism and his “immorality,” and eventually he wound up being prevented from taking up the offer. In 1950, Russell was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature “in recognition of his varied and significant writings in which he champions humanitarian ideals and freedom of thought.”

20 世纪世俗人文主义的另一位主要倡导者是奥地利科学哲学家卡尔·波普尔，我们之前在第 4 章中提到过他。波普尔在 AJ 艾尔斯的论文集《人文主义展望》（1968 年）中发表了一篇名为《通过知识实现解放》的文章，他在文中描述了知识在将人类从宗教枷锁中解放出来方面发挥的关键作用。

Another major twentieth-century advocate of secular humanism was Austrian philosopher of science Karl Popper, whom we earlier met in chapter 4. Popper contributed to A. J. Ayers’s anthology of essays The Humanist Outlook (1968) with an essay called “Emancipation through Knowledge,” in which he described the key role of knowledge in liberating humanity from religious shackles.

有一段时间，波普尔与英国人文主义组织有联系。在他著名的著作《开放社会及其敌人》（1945 年）中，他雄辩地主张自由开放的民主社会，反对极权主义和原教旨主义观点。波普尔还主张对宇宙的自然主义理解和对真理的客观概念。在他 1976 年出版的《无尽的探索：知识自传》一书中，他宣称：“我坚信存在一个真实的世界，知识的问题就是如何发现这个世界的问题。” 4

For a while, Popper was associated with the British Humanist Organization. In his famous book The Open Society and Its Enemies (1945), he eloquently argues for a free and open democratic society and against totalitarian and fundamentalist points of view. Popper also argued for a naturalistic understanding of the universe and for an objective conception of truth. In his 1976 book Unended Quest: An Intellectual Autobiography, he declares: “My conviction [is] that there is a real world, and that the problem of knowledge is the problem of how to discover this world.”4

波普尔对真理相对主义（认为真理依赖于观察者）和后现代主义思想（即我们“创造自己的现实”）嗤之以鼻。他在自传中写道：“我的社会责任感告诉我，认真对待这些问题是对知识分子的一种背叛——也是对我们本该花在真正问题上的时间的浪费。” 5

Popper had nothing but contempt for truth-relativism (the notion that truth is observer-dependent) and for postmodern ideas to the effect that we “create our own realities.” Again in his autobiography, he writes: “My sense of social responsibility told me that taking such problems seriously was a kind of treason of the intellectuals—and a misuse of the time we ought to be spending on real problems.”5

美国第一个人文主义协会

The First Humanist Society in the United States

1929 年，一神论牧师查尔斯·弗朗西斯·波特（Charles Francis Potter，1885-1962 年）创立了纽约市第一人文主义协会。这一大胆举动是他漫长的精神旅程的顶峰；波特最初是一名浸信会牧师，后来放弃了信仰，皈依一神论，但最终他也放弃了一神论，因为在他看来，即使是如此自由的讲坛也无法给他必要的言论自由。

In the year 1929, Unitarian minister Charles Francis Potter (1885–1962) founded the First Humanist Society of New York City. This daring act was the culmination of a long spiritual trek; Potter had started out as a Baptist minister, then had left the faith and converted to Unitarianism, but eventually he abandoned Unitarianism as well because, in his opinion, even such a liberal pulpit did not afford him the necessary freedom of expression.

1923 年和 1924 年，波特与约翰·罗奇·斯特拉顿博士举行了一系列备受瞩目的广播辩论，斯特拉顿博士是一位原教旨主义浸信会牧师，本身就是一个非常多才多艺的人物。（例如，斯特拉顿非常崇拜 14 岁的传教士乌尔丁·乌特利，以至于他邀请她到纽约市的加略山教堂布道。）波特-斯特拉顿广播辩论很快就出版了四卷，标题颇具挑衅性，分别是《圣经之战》、《进化论与创造论》 、《童女生子——事实还是虚构？》和《基督是人也是神吗？》。

In 1923 and 1924, Potter held a series of highly publicized radio debates with Dr. John Roach Straton, a fundamentalist Baptist pastor and a highly colorful character in his own right. (For instance, Straton was such a great admirer of Uldine Utley, a fourteen-year-old preacher, that he invited her to preach in his Calvary church in New York City.) The Potter-Straton radio debates were soon published in four volumes provocatively titled The Battle over the Bible, Evolution versus Creation, The Virgin Birth—Fact or Fiction?, and Was Christ Both Man and God?

查尔斯·波特 (Charles Potter) 于 1929 年创立了第一人文主义协会，他认为人文主义本身是一种激进的新宗教，他这样描述它：

When Charles Potter founded the First Humanist Society in 1929, he felt that humanism itself was a radical new sort of religion, describing it this way:

人文主义不是废除宗教，而是真正宗教的开始。通过使宗教摆脱超自然主义，它将释放出迄今为止受阻的巨大力量。人类等待上帝做他们自己应该做的事情太久了，而且他们完全有能力做到……

人文主义将成为一种常识性的宗教；而人类的最终目的是提高自身，无论是作为个体还是作为种族。6

Humanism is not the abolition of religion but the beginning of real religion. By freeing religion of supernaturalism, it will release tremendous reserves of hitherto thwarted power. Man has waited too long for God to do what man ought to do himself and is fully capable of doing . . .

Humanism will be a religion of common sense; and the chief end of man is to improve himself, both as an individual and as a race.6

波特利用自己新的人文主义“讲坛”，积极倡导多种社会改革，强烈反对死刑，并为生育控制和妇女权利而奔走。此外，几年后，即 1938 年，他创立了美国安乐死协会。

Taking advantage of his new humanist “pulpit,” Potter became a vocal advocate for many sorts of social reform, vigorously opposing capital punishment and campaigning for both birth control and women’s rights. Also, a few years later, in 1938, he founded the Euthanasia Society of America.

第一人文主义协会顾问委员会的早期成员包括当时杰出的知识分子，如朱利安·赫胥黎、约翰·杜威、托马斯·曼和阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦。赫胥黎与第一人文主义协会保持了长期联系，最终创立了国际人文主义和伦理联盟 (IHEU)，该联盟如今已成为全球大约 100 个世俗人文主义团体的伞状组织。

Among the early members of the First Humanist Society’s advisory board were such illustrious intellectual figures of the day as Julian Huxley, John Dewey, Thomas Mann, and Albert Einstein. Huxley remained connected to the First Humanist Society for a long time, eventually going on to found the International Humanist and Ethical Union (IHEU), which today acts as an umbrella organization for roughly a hundred secular humanist groups throughout the world.

爱因斯坦的宗教信仰之谜

The Myth of Albert Einstein’s Religiousness

阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦是波特著名的顾问委员会成员之一，经常被宗教人士拿来作为宗教和科学思想完全兼容的典范。他们渴望将神一般的爱因斯坦纳入他们的俱乐部，并引用了人们经常引用的一句话“上帝不掷骰子”，仿佛这句话证明了爱因斯坦相信上帝的存在。

Albert Einstein, one of Potter’s illustrious advisory-board members, is often trotted out by religious people as a prime example of how religious and scientific thinking are totally compatible. Eager to claim the godlike Einstein as a member of their club, they point to the oft-cited quote “God does not play dice” as if this statement proved that Einstein believed in the existence of God.

然而，这种说法站不住脚。爱因斯坦在任何意义上都不是宗教信徒。“上帝不掷骰子”这句话只是爱因斯坦对当代量子物理学的尖锐批评。事实上，爱因斯坦并不是说“上帝不掷骰子”。真正的德文引文来自爱因斯坦 1926 年写给他的同行物理学家马克斯·玻恩的一封信，内容如下，先是德语，然后是英语：“Jedenfalls bin ich überzeugt, dass der Alte nicht würfelt”（“无论如何，我确信上帝不掷骰子”）。7

The claim, however, does not hold water. Einstein was not in any sense religious. The phrase “God does not play dice” was simply a pointed Einsteinian criticism of contemporary quantum physics. And in fact, what Einstein said was not “God does not play dice.” The actual German quote comes from a letter that Einstein wrote in 1926 to his fellow physicist Max Born, and it runs as follows, first in German and then in English: “Jedenfalls bin ich überzeugt, dass der Alte nicht würfelt” (“In any case, I am convinced that the Old One does not play dice”).7

爱因斯坦在写给朋友的信中使用了“老家伙”这个幽默的表达方式，开玩笑地指宇宙法则的未知来源。特别是，他反对全新的量子论，这部分是由于他自己在 1916-1917 年对辐射的研究，部分是由于玻恩最近的研究，该论断认为基本粒子的行为具有内在的不确定性，某些过程只能以概率的方式预测，而不是像以前那样精确地预测，或者说经典物理定律。尽管爱因斯坦自己的思想在这种概率观点的演变过程中发挥了关键作用，但爱因斯坦从未接受其他人（尤其是他的朋友马克斯·玻恩）得出的结论。他坚信宇宙中的所有现象都遵循精确的数学定律，不存在任何内在随机性。因此，在告诉马克斯·玻恩“上帝不掷骰子”时，爱因斯坦生动、隐喻而又诙谐地表达了他对当时量子力学的怀疑；然而，他的诙谐并没有以任何方式暗示或揭示对任何形式的神的潜在信仰——无论是基督教、犹太教、穆斯林还是其他宗教——甚至没有对上帝或甚至对上帝的潜在信仰。

By using the humorous expression “the Old One” in his letter to his friend, Einstein was jocularly referring to the unknown source of the laws of the universe. In particular, he was objecting to the brand-new quantum thesis, due in part to his own work on radiation in 1916–1917 and in part to Born’s very recent work, that said that elementary particles have an intrinsic uncertainty to their behavior, and that certain processes can only be predicted probabilistically, rather than with the exactitude of the earlier, or classical, laws of physics. Although Einstein’s own ideas had played a key role in the evolution of this probabilistic viewpoint, Einstein never accepted the conclusion that others (especially his friend Max Born) had drawn. He was convinced that all phenomena in the universe obeyed exact mathematical laws and that there was no room for any kind of intrinsic randomness. Therefore, in telling Max Born that “the Old One does not play dice,” Einstein was vividly, metaphorically, and wittily expressing his skepticism about quantum mechanics as it then stood; his wit, however, did not in any way imply or reveal an underlying belief in any kind of god—whether Christian, Jewish, Muslim, or otherwise—or even in an Old One.

今天，尽管量子力学的预测令人费解，但已为各种精妙的实验所证实，其精确度常常达到小数点后十位或十二位。尽管量子力学毫无疑问是整个科学中最精确、最完整的理论，但它尚未被证明能够将其与我们对现实本质的直观理解统一起来。因此，对量子力学的解读至今仍是激烈争论的根源；但是（如前所述，特别是在第 2 章和第 9 章中），专家们对量子力学的争议性并不意味着量子物理学为各种宗教或新时代思想提供了支持。但不幸的是，宗教团体和新时代团体仍经常引用量子口号，好像它们是这些团体非科学观点的理想支持。

Today, the predictions of quantum mechanics, though mind bending, have been confirmed by all sorts of subtle experiments, often to an astonishing ten or twelve decimal places of accuracy. Although quantum mechanics is without a shadow of a doubt the most exact and complete theory in all of science, it has not yet proven possible to unify it with our intuitive understandings of the nature of reality. The interpretation of quantum mechanics is therefore still a source of lively controversy today; however (as was discussed earlier, especially in chapters 2 and 9), its controversiality to experts does not mean that quantum physics provides support for various religious or New Age–inspired ideas. Unfortunately, though, quantum slogans are still often cited by religious and New Age groups as if they were the ideal support for the groups’ unscientific views.

与一些宗教人士的期望相反，阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦参与第一人文主义协会表明，他可能将自己描述为世俗人文主义者，这是当今意义上的世俗人文主义者。他隐喻性地使用“老者”一词，应该理解为代表他对宇宙的至高敬畏和惊叹。这是他谈论自然法则的个人诗意方式。

In contrast to what some religious people would like, Albert Einstein’s involvement in the First Humanist Society suggests that he would have described himself as a secular humanist, in today’s sense of the term. His metaphorical use of the term “the Old One” should be understood as representing his supreme sense of awe and wonder for the universe. It was his personal poetic fashion of talking about the laws of nature.

爱因斯坦在 1930 年左右写的一篇文章《我眼中的世界》中说道：

In “The World as I See It,” an essay written around 1930, Einstein states:

我们所能拥有的最美好的体验就是神秘。它是真正的艺术和真正的科学摇篮里最基本的情感。谁不了解它，谁就不再好奇，不再惊叹，谁就等于死了，他的眼睛也变得模糊。正是神秘的体验——即使夹杂着恐惧——产生了宗教。一种我们无法理解的存在的认知，一种对最深奥的理性和最灿烂的美的感知，只有它们最原始的形式才能被我们的思想所理解：正是这种认知和这种构成真正宗教信仰的情感。从这个意义上说，也只有从这个意义上说，我是一个虔诚的宗教信徒。……我对生命永恒的奥秘感到满意，对存在的奇妙结构感到满意——以及谦卑地尝试去理解自然界中体现的哪怕是很小一部分的理性。8

The most beautiful experience we can have is the mysterious. It is the fundamental emotion that stands at the cradle of true art and true science. Whoever does not know it and can no longer wonder, no longer marvel, is as good as dead, and his eyes are dimmed. It was the experience of mystery—even if mixed with fear—that engendered religion. A knowledge of the existence of something we cannot penetrate, our perceptions of the profoundest reason and the most radiant beauty, which only in their most primitive forms are accessible to our minds: it is this knowledge and this emotion that constitute true religiosity. In this sense, and only this sense, I am a deeply religious man. . . . I am satisfied with the mystery of life’s eternity and with a knowledge, a sense, of the marvelous structure of existence—as well as the humble attempt to understand even a tiny portion of the Reason that manifests itself in nature.8

在这句话中，爱因斯坦没有向传统的宗教思想、任何形式的神秘主义或对超自然现象的信仰做出任何让步。事实上，他对上帝或死后生活的想法毫无耐心。对爱因斯坦来说，“神秘”一词表示他对宇宙遵循规则的模式深感敬畏——研究人员的职责就是尝试使用理性的途径来发现和理解这些模式。正如他所说：

In this statement, Einstein makes no concession whatsoever to traditional religious thought, nor to any form of mysticism or belief in supernatural phenomena. Indeed, he had no patience with the idea of a god or a life after death. For Einstein, the term “mystery” denoted his deeply felt sense of awe for the rule-following patterns of the universe—which it is the researcher’s duty to try to discover and comprehend, using the pathways of reason. As he puts it:

我无法想象一个上帝会奖赏和惩罚他所创造的对象，他的目的与我们的目的相同——简而言之，上帝只是人类弱点的反映。我也不相信个体在肉体死亡后还能继续存在，尽管脆弱的灵魂会因为恐惧或荒谬的自私而怀有这种想法。9

I cannot imagine a God who rewards and punishes the objects of his creation, whose purposes are modeled after our own—a God, in short, who is but a reflection of human frailty. Neither can I believe that the individual survives the death of his body, although feeble souls harbor such thoughts through fear or ridiculous egotisms.9

当爱因斯坦申请苏黎世居留许可时（他后来在其他国家也申请过几次），他在“宗教”一栏填写了“无宗教信仰”。当时，发表这样的声明是极具争议的（就像今天在世界许多地方一样），他大胆而诚实的行为给他带来了不少额外的麻烦。10

When Einstein applied for a residence permit in Zurich (something he did several other times later in his life, in other countries), he filled in the blank labeled “religion” with “no religious affiliation.” At that time, making such a statement was highly controversial (just as it is in many parts of the world even today), and his bold but honest act caused him quite a lot of additional trouble.10

爱因斯坦的另一句名言经常被有组织的宗教的拥护者引用来作为这位伟大科学家宗教信仰的“证据”，那就是：“没有宗教的科学是跛脚的，没有科学的宗教是盲目的。”

Another quote from Einstein that is often dragged out by advocates of organized religion as a “proof” of the great scientist’s religiousness is this: “Science without religion is lame; religion without science is blind.”

爱因斯坦的这些挑衅性言论既不是对上帝的信仰，也不是对无根基信仰的尊重。相反，他谈论的是人们理解他们所居住的宇宙的原始动力，以及他个人对实现这种理解的可能性的信念。以下是该短语的更广泛背景，摘自爱因斯坦的揭露性回忆录《晚年回忆录》 ：

With these provocative words, Einstein was expressing neither a belief in God nor a respect for ungrounded faith. Rather, he was talking about people’s primordial drive to understand the universe they inhabit, and about his own personal faith in the possibility of reaching such understanding. Here is the wider context of the phrase in question, taken from Einstein’s revealing memoir Out of My Later Years:

只有那些对真理和理解充满渴望的人才能创造科学。然而，这种情感的源泉来自宗教领域。信仰也属于宗教领域存在世界的有效规则是合理的，也就是说，是理性可以理解的。我无法想象一个真正的科学家没有这种深刻的信仰。这种情况可以用一个形象的比喻来表达：没有宗教的科学是跛脚的，没有科学的宗教是盲目的。11

Science can only be created by those who are thoroughly imbued with the aspiration toward truth and understanding. This source of feeling, however, springs from the sphere of religion. To this there also belongs the faith in the possibility that the regulations valid for the world of existence are rational, that is, comprehensible to reason. I cannot conceive of a genuine scientist without that profound faith. The situation may be expressed by an image: Science without religion is lame, religion without science is blind.11

显然，爱因斯坦在这里指的是，传统的宗教形象中，上帝以一种可以理解的方式创造了宇宙，这可以看作是科学理论的历史先驱，也是人类理解“上帝之作”的深层目标的历史先驱。当然，这并不意味着真的有这样的上帝，或者爱因斯坦认为有这样的上帝。

As is clear, Einstein here is referring to the fact that the traditional religious image of a god who created the universe in a comprehensible manner can be seen as a historical precursor of scientific theories and of humanity’s deep-seated goal of coming to understand “God’s works.” This of course doesn’t mean that there really is such a god, or that Einstein thought that there was one.

事实上，随着时间的推移，爱因斯坦越来越恼火于那些故意和出于宗教动机扭曲他的话的人。1953 年 7 月，他收到了一封充满热情赞赏的信，信中引用了圣经中的许多内容，这封信来自一位浸信会牧师，这位牧师问爱因斯坦是否考虑过自己不朽的灵魂及其与造物主的关系，以及他是否感到死后永生的保证。在这封信的空白处，爱因斯坦亲笔用英文写道：“我不相信个人不朽，我认为伦理道德是人类独有的关注点，背后没有超人的权威。”目前尚不清楚他是否真的给牧师回了信。12

Indeed, throughout time, Einstein grew increasingly annoyed by deliberate and religiously motivated distortions of his words. In July 1953, he received a warmly appreciative letter, rife with biblical quotations, from a Baptist pastor, who asked Einstein whether he had reflected about his immortal soul and its relationship to the Creator, and whether he felt assurance of everlasting life after death. In the margin of this letter, Einstein wrote, in his own hand, and in English: “I do not believe in immortality of the individual, and I consider ethics to be an exclusively human concern with no superhuman authority behind it.” It is not known whether he actually sent an answer to the pastor or not.12

爱因斯坦越来越不满于被认为是传统意义上的宗教信徒，这一点在他的信件中表现得非常明显。例如，1954 年，一位无神论者在读到一篇关于爱因斯坦是宗教信徒的文章后，从意大利写信给爱因斯坦，询问他这是否属实，爱因斯坦这样回答他：

Einstein’s growing frustration with being considered conventionally religious emerges very clearly in his correspondence. For instance, in 1954, an atheistic man who had read a claim that Einstein was religious wrote Einstein from Italy to ask him whether or not this was true, and Einstein answered him as follows:

当然，你所读到的关于我的宗教信仰的文章都是谎言，而且这个谎言正在被系统地重复。我不相信个人的上帝，我从未否认过这一点，但我明确地表达了这一点。如果说我身上有什么可以称为宗教的东西，那就是对我们的科学所能揭示的世界结构的无限钦佩。13

It was, of course, a lie what you read about my religious convictions, a lie which is being systematically repeated. I do not believe in a personal God and I have never denied this but have expressed it clearly. If something is in me which can be called religious, then it is the unbounded admiration for the structure of the world so far as our science can reveal it.13

同年，也就是他去世前一年，爱因斯坦给哲学家埃里克·古特金德（Eric Gutkind）写了一封信，信中写道：

The same year, only one year before he died, Einstein wrote a letter to the philosopher Eric Gutkind where he states the following:

对我来说，“上帝”这个词不过是人类弱点的表达和产物；《圣经》是一本光荣的但仍然原始的传说集，尽管如此，这些传说还是相当幼稚的。没有解释，不管多么微妙，才能（对我来说）改变这一点。……对我来说，犹太教和所有其他宗教一样，都是最幼稚迷信的化身。14

The word “God” is for me nothing more than the expression and product of human weaknesses; the Bible a collection of honourable but still primitive legends, which are nevertheless pretty childish. No interpretation, no matter how subtle, can (for me) change this. . . . For me, the Jewish religion, like all other religions, is an incarnation of the most childish superstitions.14

很少有人会质疑阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦是二十世纪最杰出的科学家，因此，任何宗教团体都会认为，能够宣称如此杰出的人才属于他们的阵营，是一种巨大的成功。但正如我们刚刚看到的，爱因斯坦所谓的宗教信仰纯属神话。可以肯定的是，确实存在一些传统上信教的科学家（尽管人们发现，随着科学成就的提升，他们的比例迅速减少）——但爱因斯坦不在其中。

Few would dispute that Albert Einstein was the twentieth century’s foremost scientist, and for this reason, any religious group would have considered it a great coup to be able to claim that such an outstanding mind belonged to their camp. But as we have just seen, Einstein’s supposed religiosity is sheer myth. To be sure, there do exist conventionally religious scientists here and there (although one finds that their proportion diminishes rapidly as one moves up the ladder of scientific achievement)—but Einstein was not among them.

阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦于 1922 年才获得诺贝尔物理学奖，但他并不是因为著名的相对论而获奖，而是因为发现了鲜为人知的“光电效应定律”。诺贝尔奖的引文措辞颇具讽刺意味，揭示了爱因斯坦最伟大的贡献并未被诺贝尔委员会理解。

Albert Einstein was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for 1921, although it was only given to him in 1922—and it was not for his celebrated theory of relativity but for his discovery of the little-known “law of the photoelectric effect.” There is a great irony in the way the Nobel citation was worded, revealing that Einstein’s greatest contributions were not understood by the Nobel committee.

“光电效应诺贝尔奖”的奇异传奇始于 1905 年，当时名不见经传、刚刚获得博士学位的 25 岁阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦（在瑞士一家低级专利局工作）写了一篇文章，声称根据他设计的巧妙类比，光是由粒子（他称之为“光量子”）而不是波组成的。这位年轻的三等专利局职员的大胆主张与当时物理学家对光的所有神圣观念完全相反，它与詹姆斯·克拉克·麦克斯韦关于电磁的深刻方程完全矛盾，而世界各地的物理学家认为这些方程是过去或将来任何物理定律中最为可靠的。因此，多年来，没有人把这位傲慢的新贵阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦的光量子假说当真。

The strange saga of the “photoelectric effect Nobel Prize” began way back in 1905, when the totally unknown and freshly minted twenty-five-year-old PhD Albert Einstein (working in a lowly patent office in Switzerland) wrote an article claiming, on the basis of a subtle analogy that he had devised, that light was made of particles (“light quanta,” as he called them)—not waves. This audacious claim from the young patent clerk third class ran smack in the face against everything that physicists of the day held sacred about light, and it flat-out contradicted James Clerk Maxwell’s profound equations for electricity and magnetism, which were considered by physicists the world over to be as solidly confirmed as any law of physics ever had been or would be. Consequently, no one took the brash upstart Albert Einstein’s light-quantum hypothesis in the least seriously for many years.

在 1905 年的文章中，爱因斯坦不仅对光的性质做出了打破传统的猜测，还巧妙地利用了他的猜测来预测金属中电子被光击中后会如何被抛出。这就是“光电效应”，尽管一些专家对此有所了解，但尚未深入研究，当时人们对它的了解很少。爱因斯坦对逃逸电子流强度（作为入射光颜色的函数）的计算是一个大胆的预测，在数学精度方面远远超出了极限，这是他向同事们的温和暗示，检查电子流的行为详细阐述鲜为人知的光电效应将是检验他的光量子假设的好方法。

In his 1905 article, Einstein not only made a tradition-smashing guess about light’s nature but also cleverly exploited his guess to predict how electrons in metals struck by light would be ejected. This was the “photo-electric effect,” and though it was known a little bit by a few specialists, it had not been studied deeply and was very little understood at that time. Einstein’s calculation of the intensity of the stream of escaping electrons (as a function of the color of the incident light) was a daring prediction that went way out on a limb in its mathematical precision, and this was his gentle hint to his colleagues that checking out the behavior of the little-known photoelectric effect in detail would be a good way to test his hypothesis of light quanta.

1912 年左右，爱因斯坦的光电效应预言终于得到了加州理工学院著名的美国物理学家罗伯特·密立根的检验。经过数年的艰苦工作，密立根发表了他的成果，表明爱因斯坦的预言通过了检验，得到了圆满的证实。这对密立根和爱因斯坦来说都是一个巨大的胜利；然而，密立根随后又补充了一些非常奇怪的评论。他说，爱因斯坦的预言被证实是一件了不起的事情，因为这个预言背后的思想——即光量子假说——显然是无稽之谈，他最后说，光电效应的神秘行为仍在等待一个合理的科学解释。密立根甚至厚颜无耻地声称（没有任何事实依据）爱因斯坦本人终于放弃了对光量子的信仰。

Around 1912, Einstein’s photoelectric-effect prediction was at last put to the test by Robert Millikan, a famed American physicist at Caltech. After several years of painstaking work, Millikan published his results, showing that Einstein’s prediction had passed the test with flying colors: the prediction was fully and perfectly confirmed. This was a great triumph both for Millikan and for Einstein; however, Millikan then added some very strange comments. He said that it was remarkable that Einstein’s prediction had been verified, since the underlying idea from which it had sprung—namely, the hypothesis of light quanta—was clearly nonsensical, and he concluded by saying that the mysterious behavior of the photoelectric effect was still awaiting a plausible scientific explanation. Millikan even had the gall to claim (without any basis in fact) that Einstein himself had finally dropped his belief in light quanta.

几年后——1921 年——除了爱因斯坦本人，地球上仍然没有一位物理学家相信光量子。但讽刺的是，物理学家们都接受了爱因斯坦光电效应预测的正确性，却没有注意到它源自爱因斯坦对光的激进观点。因此，诺贝尔委员会选择将当年的诺贝尔奖仅仅授予爱因斯坦“光电效应定律的发现”，这是非常胆怯的，因为爱因斯坦真正伟大的发现、真正深刻的发现是光是由粒子组成的——这是一个革命性的发现！——而他预测光电效应详细行为的定律是一个相当小的发现，无论如何它直接来自光量子思想。物理学家的这种态度在今天看来几乎是不可理解的。

Several years later—in 1921—there still was no physicist on the face of the earth, other than Einstein himself, who believed in light quanta. But ironically enough, physicists all had accepted the correctness of Einstein’s photoelectric-effect prediction, while paying no attention to its origin in Einstein’s radical vision of light. Therefore, the Nobel committee’s choice to award that year’s prize solely for Einstein’s “discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect” was exceedingly timid, since Einstein’s truly great discovery, his truly deep discovery, was that light is made of particles—this was a revolutionary discovery!—whereas his law predicting the detailed behavior of the photoelectric effect was a quite minor discovery, and in any case it came straight out of the light-quantum idea. This attitude on the part of physicists seems almost incomprehensible today.

爱因斯坦总是将光量子存在的假设称为“我一生中最具革命性的想法”，但他的诺贝尔奖肯定不是因为这个想法而颁发的，而是因为一个从这个想法中衍生出来的非革命性想法。真是讽刺。

Einstein always referred to his hypothesis of the existence of light quanta as “the most revolutionary idea I ever had,” but his Nobel Prize was certainly not given for that idea, but for a nonrevolutionary idea that followed trivially from it. What an irony.

最后补充一点，1923 年，当阿瑟·霍利·康普顿 (Arthur Holly Compton) 研究光从原子中绕轨道旋转的电子上反射的行为时，他发现了一种神秘的行为，这种行为无法用麦克斯韦方程来解释，但却与爱因斯坦的光量子理论完全一致。“康普顿效应”在许多实验室中被复制和扩展，这一发展迅速颠覆了世界各地物理学家的观点。很快，所有专家都加入了光量子潮流。

And—as a final footnote—in 1923, when Arthur Holly Compton studied the behavior of light bouncing off of orbiting electrons in atoms, he found mysterious behavior that couldn’t be explained by Maxwell’s equations but that perfectly agreed with Einstein’s light-quantum idea. The “Compton effect” was reproduced and extended in many laboratories, and this development rapidly reversed the opinions of physicists the world over. Soon all the experts had jumped on the light-quantum bandwagon.

1926 年，“光子”这个朗朗上口的词被创造出来，爱因斯坦生动的术语“光量子”成为历史。如今，每个人都听说过光子，当提到“光粒子”这个概念时，没有人会眨眨眼。这就是科学进步：一个曾经如此激进、几乎没有专家相信的想法，现在得到了证实，并被广泛接受，最终甚至被小学生视为理所当然。

In 1926, the catchy word “photon” was coined, and Einstein’s picturesque term “light quantum” became a relic. Today everybody has heard of photons, and no one bats an eyelash when the idea of “particles of light” is mentioned. Such is scientific progress: what once was so radical an idea that virtually no expert anywhere believed it gets confirmed, becomes widely accepted, and finally winds up being taken totally for granted even by tiny schoolchildren.

当今世俗声音

Secular Voices Today

今天，世俗人文主义在国际舞台上的代表人物有丽贝卡·戈德斯坦、史蒂芬·平克、丹尼尔·丹尼特、彼得·辛格、安东尼·格雷林、米歇尔·翁弗雷和斯蒂芬·劳等著名哲学家；有史蒂芬·温伯格、E.O.威尔逊、理查德·道金斯、萨姆·哈里斯、吉姆·阿尔哈利利和布莱恩·考克斯等杰出科学家；有翁贝托·艾柯、芭芭拉·埃伦赖希、卡罗琳·福瑞斯特、萨尔曼·拉什迪、艾丽丝·沃克、乔伊斯·卡罗尔·奥茨、沃尔·索因卡、塔斯利玛·纳斯林、菲利普·普尔曼和阿亚​​安·希尔西·阿里等杰出作家。当然，还有很多很多。

Today, secular humanism is represented on the international stage by such well-known philosophers as Rebecca Goldstein, Steven Pinker, Daniel Dennett, Peter Singer, Anthony Grayling, Michel Onfray, and Stephen Law; by such eminent scientists as Steven Weinberg, E. O. Wilson, Richard Dawkins, Sam Harris, Jim al-Khalili, and Brian Cox; and by such illustrious writers as Umberto Eco, Barbara Ehrenreich, Caroline Fourest, Salman Rushdie, Alice Walker, Joyce Carol Oates, Wole Soyinka, Taslima Nasrin, Philip Pullman, and Ayaan Hirsi Ali. And of course there are many, many more.

1962 年出生于孟加拉国的医生兼作家塔斯利玛·纳斯林多年来一直为妇女权利和伊斯兰世界的世俗原则而奋斗。她在祖国工作，直到 1994 年，她因不断收到死亡威胁而被迫逃离。如今，她生活在保镖的保护下，但尽管有风险，她仍不断写作和旅行，发表关于她的世俗观点的演讲。

Physician and writer Taslima Nasrin, born in Bangladesh in 1962, has fought for many years for women’s rights and for secular principles in the world of Islam. She worked in her native land until 1994, when repeated death threats forced her to flee. Today she lives under the protection of bodyguards, but despite the risks, she constantly writes and travels, giving lectures on her secular vision.

她的几本书都涉及穆斯林占多数的国家对宗教少数派的压迫。1993 年，她在孟加拉国的报纸上发表了关于这一主题的文章，激怒了一些穆斯林原教旨主义者，他们要求处决她。从那时起，她就觉得自己别无选择，只能流亡，有时流亡瑞典。近年来，纳斯林一直住在印度，但在那里她继续受到原教旨主义者的威胁。

Several of her books deal with the oppression of religious minorities in countries with Muslim majorities. When she wrote newspaper articles on this topic in Bangladesh in 1993, she stirred up the wrath of certain Muslim fundamentalists, who called for her execution. Ever since then, she has felt she has no choice but to live in exile, at times in Sweden. In recent years, Nasrin has lived in India, but there she continues to be threatened by fundamentalists.

1942 年出生的美国哲学教授丹尼尔·丹尼特仔细分析了宗教作为一种纯自然现象，是进化选择的特定心理过程的结果。他从一个简单的问题开始：“宗教为什么存在？”

American professor of philosophy Daniel Dennett, born in 1942, has given a careful analysis of religion as a purely natural phenomenon, due to specific sorts of mental processes that evolution has selected for. He starts from the following simple question: “Why does religion exist?”

丹尼特这个简单问题的答案当然非常简单——只要你承认确实 有一位要求服从的神，服从神的存在，以及人类对神的绝对崇敬。（完全可以想象一个神创造了宇宙，但他让宇宙自然发展，既不干预也不透露宇宙是如何被创造的。但是，人类所联系的神总是参与到我们的事务中，下到（或上到？）人间建立他们的使馆——教堂、清真寺、寺庙——并生下儿子或其他类型的继承人……这种非常平凡的类人行为是否足以证明这些神是人类的创造物？）

The answer to Dennett’s simple question is of course very simple—as long as you grant that there actually is a god who demands submission, obe dience, and unquestioning reverence from humans. (It is perfectly possible to imagine a god who created the universe but who then let the creation run its own course without meddling with it in any way, or revealing how it was created. But the gods that humans tend to relate to are always mixing themselves up in our affairs, coming down (or up?) to earth in order to set up their embassies—churches, mosques, temples—and also producing a son or some other type of heir. . . . Could this very mundane humanlike behavior be sufficient proof of the fact that the gods in question are human inventions?)

当然，尝试在另一种情况下回答丹内特的问题也同样重要——即没有上帝的情况。在这种情况下，什么可以解释世界上宗教的存在？回答这个问题是丹内特 2006 年出版的《打破魔咒：宗教作为一种自然现象》一书的核心使命。丹内特写道：

Of course, it’s equally important to try to answer Dennett’s question in the other case—namely, the case where there is no god. In that case, what could explain the existence of religion in the world? To answer this question is the central mission of Dennett’s 2006 book Breaking the Spell: Religion as a Natural Phenomenon. Dennett writes:

我的意思可能是，宗教是自然的，而不是超自然的，它是一种人类现象，由事件、有机体、物体、结构、模式等组成，它们都遵循物理或生物定律，因此不涉及奇迹。这就是我的意思。请注意，上帝确实存在，上帝确实是我们所有人的智慧、意识和慈爱的创造者，但宗教本身作为一组复杂的现象，仍然是一种完全自然的现象。15

I might mean that religion is natural as opposed to supernatural, that it is a human phenomenon composed of events, organisms, objects, structures, patterns, and the like that all obey the laws of physics or biology, and hence do not involve miracles. And that is what I mean. Notice that it could be true that God exists, that God is indeed an intelligent, conscious, loving creator of us all, and yet still religion itself, as a complex set of phenomena, is a perfectly natural phenomenon.15

1954 年出生的美国心理学教授史蒂芬·平克经常撰文谈论对新启蒙运动的需要，他担心在学术界的某些领域和文化辩论中兴起的后现代主义和反科学运动。人文主义者经常严厉批评科学思维的倡导者，因为他们提倡“科学主义”（批评者认为这是一个贬义词，表示一种夸张甚至教条的信仰，相信科学能够带来关于一切的知识，解决世界上所有的问题）。但在一篇题为《科学不是你的敌人》的文章中，平克热情地接受了“科学主义”的概念，并以积极而非消极的眼光看待它：

American professor of psychology Steven Pinker, born in 1954, often writes about the need for a new enlightenment, and he worries about the flourishing postmodernist and anti-science movements that have arisen in certain areas of the academic world and in debates about culture. Advocates of scientific thinking are often raked over the coals by humanists for advocating “scientism” (a pejorative term that, for the critics, denotes an exaggerated, even dogmatic faith in science’s power to yield knowledge about everything, and to solve all the world’s problems). But, in an article titled “Science Is Not Your Enemy,” Pinker warmly embraces the notion of “scientism,” casting it in a positive light rather than a negative one:

科学主义，从好的意义上讲，并不是相信被称为“科学”的职业行会的成员特别聪明或高尚。相反，科学的定义实践，包括公开辩论、同行评审和双盲方法，都明确旨在避免科学家作为人类容易犯的错误和罪孽。科学主义并不意味着所有当前的科学假设都是正确的；大多数新假设都不是，因为猜想和反驳的循环是科学的命脉。科学并非占领人文学科的帝国主义驱动力；科学的承诺是丰富和多样化人文学术的智力工具，而不是消灭它们。科学也不是物质是唯一存在的教条。科学家本身沉浸在虚无缥缈的信息媒介中，包括数学真理、理论逻辑和指导他们事业的价值观。从这个概念来看，科学与哲学、理性和启蒙人文主义是一体的。16

Scientism, in this good sense, is not the belief that members of the occupational guild called “science” are particularly wise or noble. On the contrary, the defining practices of science, including open debate, peer review, and double-blind methods, are explicitly designed to circumvent the errors and sins to which scientists, being human, are vulnerable. Scientism does not mean that all current scientific hypotheses are true; most new ones are not, since the cycle of conjecture and refutation is the lifeblood of science. It is not an imperialistic drive to occupy the humanities; the promise of science is to enrich and diversify the intellectual tools of humanistic scholarship, not to obliterate them. And it is not the dogma that physical stuff is the only thing that exists. Scientists themselves are immersed in the ethereal medium of information, including the truths of mathematics, the logic of their theories, and the values that guide their enterprise. In this conception, science is of a piece with philosophy, reason, and Enlightenment humanism.16

平克对宗教世界观的批评非常严厉（同样摘自同一篇文章）：

Pinker’s criticism of the religious worldview is very harsh (again taken from the same article):

首先，科学发现意味着，世界上所有传统宗教和文化的信仰体系——它们关于生命、人类和社会起源的理论——在事实上都是错误的。我们知道，但我们的祖先不知道，人类属于一种非洲灵长类动物，这种动物在人类历史的晚期才发展出农业、政府和文字。我们知道，人类是谱系树上的一个细小分支，这个谱系树涵盖了所有生物，大约四十亿年前从生命起源前的化学物质中出现。我们知道，我们生活在一个围绕银河系中一千亿颗恒星之一旋转的星球上，而这个恒星只是 138 亿年前的宇宙中一千亿个星系中的一个，可能是众多宇宙中的一个。我们知道，我们对空间、时间、物质和因果关系的直觉与现实的本质在非常大和非常小的尺度上是无法比拟的。我们知道，支配物质世界的法则（包括事故、疾病和其他不幸）并不以人类福祉为目标。没有命运、天意、因果报应、符咒、诅咒、占卜、神报或祈祷应验之类的东西——尽管概率法则和认知运作之间的差异可能解释了为什么人们相信存在这些事物。我们知道，我们并不总是知道这些事情，每个时代和文化所钟爱的信念都可能被决定性地证伪，无疑包括我们今天所持有的一些信念。17

To begin with, the findings of science entail that the belief systems of all the world’s traditional religions and cultures—their theories of the origins of life, humans, and societies—are factually mistaken. We know, but our ancestors did not, that humans belong to a single species of African primate that developed agriculture, government, and writing late in its history. We know that our species is a tiny twig of a genealogical tree that embraces all living things and that emerged from prebiotic chemicals almost four billion years ago. We know that we live on a planet that revolves around one of a hundred billion stars in our galaxy, which is one of a hundred billion galaxies in a 13.8-billion-year-old universe, possibly one of a vast number of universes. We know that our intuitions about space, time, matter, and causation are incommensurable with the nature of reality on scales that are very large and very small. We know that the laws governing the physical world (including accidents, disease, and other misfortunes) have no goals that pertain to human well-being. There is no such thing as fate, providence, karma, spells, curses, augury, divine retribution, or answered prayers—though the discrepancy between the laws of probability and the workings of cognition may explain why people believe there are. And we know that we did not always know these things, that the beloved convictions of every time and culture may be decisively falsified, doubtless including some we hold today.17

换句话说，当今指导受过教育的人的道德和精神价值观的世界观是科学赋予我们的世界观。

In other words, the worldview that guides the moral and spiritual values of an educated person today is the worldview given to us by science.

在其新书《人性中的善良天使》（2011）中，史蒂芬·平克也试图表明，随着世俗化、教育和繁荣的发展，人类的暴力和残忍倾向实际上几个世纪以来一直在减少，而不是相反。

In his recent book The Better Angels of Our Nature (2011), Steven Pinker also tried to show that the human inclination toward violence and cruelty has in fact diminished throughout the centuries, rather than the reverse, keeping pace with secularization, education, and the development of prosperity.

英国作家、进化生物学家理查德·道金斯出生于 1941 年，被许多人认为是当今最严厉的宗教批评者。在他的著作《上帝错觉》（2006 年）中，他严厉批评了宗教思想及其对世界的影响。道金斯还写了《现实的魔力：我们如何知道什么是真正的事实》（2011 年），他在书中列出了一系列神话，并对这些现象给出了科学解释。在 2013 年接受《Sans》杂志采访时，他从进化生物学的角度描述了宗教现象：

British writer and evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins, born in 1941, is considered by many to be our day’s harshest critic of religion. In his book The God Delusion (2006), he mounts a severe attack on religious ideas and their consequences in the world. Dawkins also wrote The Magic of Reality: How We Know What’s Really True (2011), in which he lists a series of myths and gives scientific explanations of those phenomena. In an interview in 2013 with the magazine Sans, he describes the phenomenon of religion, using an evolutionary-biology perspective:

我认为我们应该把它（宗教）看作是某些心理倾向的副产品。我不认为人们可以说宗教是人类发展而来的一种特性，因为它具有进化优势。这也许是真的——可能是因为宗教人士患溃疡的几率较低，因为他们不像其他人那样担心——但我不认为这种宗教理论会受到热烈欢迎。更有可能的是，宗教在某些心理倾向方面具有优势，比如服从权威人物的倾向。人们很容易理解为什么自然选择会青睐一条内在的经验法则，即“相信父母告诉你的话！”因为这个世界很危险，人类的孩子非常脆弱。如果在非洲，一个孩子的父母说：“不要抓蛇！”，那是一个非常好的生存建议。然后，当父母后来又说了别的话，比如“一定要牺牲一只山羊，这样我们就不会收成不好”，孩子的大脑无法区分明智的建议和愚蠢的建议。由于孩子的大脑已经被编程为相信父母说的任何话，它本质上很容易受到无意义思想的寄生攻击——就像计算机容易受到来自外部的病毒攻击一样。计算机是一种盲目服从所收到指令的机器，它应该是这样的。但正是出于这个原因，它本质上很容易受到病毒的攻击，病毒会说：“毁掉这个人的硬盘，把这个病毒程序复制到另一台电脑上！”我认为宗教与计算机病毒类似。18

I think that we should see it [religion] as a byproduct of certain psychological tendencies. I don’t think that one can say that religion is a human trait that we have developed because it has evolutionary advantages. That might be true—it might be the case that religious people live longer because they have less chance of developing ulcers, as they are not as worried as other people are—but I don’t think that such a theory of religion would be enthusiastically received. It’s more likely that being religious has advantages in terms of certain psychological tendencies, such as a tendency to obey authority figures. One can easily see why natural selection would favor an inbuilt rule of thumb that says, “Believe what your parents tell you!” since the world is dangerous and human children are very vulnerable. If, in Africa, a child’s parents say, “Don’t pick up snakes!,” that’s a very good piece of advice for survival. And then when a parent later says something else, such as “Make sure to sacrifice a goat, so that we won’t have a bad harvest,” the child’s brain has no way of distinguishing between sensible and silly advice. Since the child’s brain has been programmed to believe whatever a parent says, it is intrinsically susceptible to parasitic attacks of nonsensical ideas—just as a computer is vulnerable to virus attacks coming from the outside. A computer is a machine that blindly obeys the instructions it receives, and that’s how it should be. But for that very reason, it is intrinsically vulnerable to a virus that says, “Destroy this person’s hard disk and copy this virus program to another computer!” And I see religion as being analogous to computer viruses.18

如今，理查德·道金斯几乎全身心地致力于世俗化和科学进步。2006 年，他创立了理查德·道金斯科学与理性基金会，这是一个面向启蒙主义导向人士和希望提高世俗思想知名度的人士的在线聚会场所。

Today, Richard Dawkins devotes himself almost exclusively to working for secularization and the advancement of science. In 2006, he founded the Richard Dawkins Foundation for Science and Reason, which is an online meeting place for people who are Enlightenment oriented and who wish to increase the visibility of secular ideas.

另一位当代宗教批评家是已故作家兼记者克里斯托弗·希钦斯（1949-2011）。他的著作《上帝并不伟大：为什么 《宗教毒害一切》（2009）是近年来对宗教的批评中最具影响力的著作之一。

Another contemporary critic of religion is the late writer and journalist Christopher Hitchens (1949–2011). His book God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything (2009) is one of the most influential of recent criticisms of religion.

希钦斯认为，宗教渗透并毒害了世界上许多政治冲突，因此他被许多反对者称为“激进的新无神论者”。他在书中写道：

Hitchens’s orientation toward religion, which, in his view, infiltrates and poisons many of the world’s political conflicts, earned him the label “aggressive neo-atheist” from numerous opponents. In his book, he writes:

2001 年 9 月 11 日事件发生前一周，我参加了丹尼斯·普拉格的座谈会，他是美国最知名的宗教广播员之一。他当众向我提出挑战，要求我回答一个他称之为“直接是非问题”的问题，我欣然答应了。他说：“很好。”我想象自己在夜幕降临时身处一座陌生的城市。想象我看到一大群人朝我走来。现在——如果我得知他们刚从祈祷会回来，我会感到更安全还是更不安全？读者会看到，这不是一个可以给出是非答案的问题。但我能够像假设一样回答它。 “仅仅局限于‘B’字母，我实际上在贝尔法斯特、贝鲁特、孟买、贝尔格莱德、伯利恒和巴格达都有过这样的经历。在每种情况下，我都可以肯定地说，并且可以给出我的理由，为什么如果我认为黄昏时分向我走来的那群人是来参加宗教仪式的，我会立即感到受到威胁。” 19

A week before the events of September 11, 2001, I was on a panel with Dennis Prager, who is one of America’s better-known religious broadcasters. He challenged me in public to answer what he called a “straight yes/ no question,” and I happily agreed. Very well, he said. I was to imagine myself in a strange city as the evening was coming on. Toward me I was to imagine that I saw a large group of men approaching. Now—would I feel safer, or less safe, if I was to learn that they were just coming from a prayer meeting? As the reader will see, this is not a question to which a yes/no answer can be given. But I was able to answer it as if it were not hypothetical. “Just to stay within the letter ‘B,’ I have actually had that experience in Belfast, Beirut, Bombay, Belgrade, Bethlehem, and Baghdad. In each case I can say absolutely, and can give my reasons, why I would feel immediately threatened if I thought that the group of men approaching me in the dusk were coming from a religious observance.”19

后来他描述了自己在这些地方所见所闻。例如，他这样描述北爱尔兰首都贝尔法斯特：

Later he describes what he witnessed in such places. For example, he writes this about Belfast, the capital of Northern Ireland:

在贝尔法斯特，我看到整条街道被基督教不同教派之间的宗派战争烧毁，我也采访过一些人，他们的亲朋好友被敌对宗教敢死队绑架、杀害或折磨，而他们遭受的折磨往往仅仅因为他们属于另一个教派。20

In Belfast, I have seen whole streets burned out by sectarian warfare between different sects of Christianity, and interviewed people whose relatives and friends have been kidnapped and killed or tortured by rival religious death squads, often for no other reason than membership in another confession.20

关于黎巴嫩首都贝鲁特：

And about Beirut, the capital of Lebanon:

以色列当年 [1982] 入侵黎巴嫩也推动了真主党的诞生，这个谦虚的组织的名字是“真主党”，它动员了什叶派下层阶级，并逐渐将其置于三年前上台的伊朗神权独裁政权的领导之下。在可爱的黎巴嫩，信徒们学会了与有组织犯罪团伙分享绑架业务，然后开始向我们介绍自杀式爆炸的魅力。我仍然能看到法国大使馆外几乎被摧毁的路上那颗被砍下的头颅。总的来说，当祈祷会结束时，我倾向于过马路。21

Israel’s irruption into Lebanon that year [1982] also gave an impetus to the birth of Hezbollah, the modestly named “Party of God,” which mobilized the Shia underclass and gradually placed it under the leadership of the theocratic dictatorship in Iran that had come to power three years previously. It was in lovely Lebanon, too, having learned to share the kidnapping business with the ranks of organized crime, that the faithful moved on to introduce us to the beauties of suicide bombing. I can still see that severed head in the road outside the near-shattered French embassy. On the whole, I tended to cross the street when the prayer meetings broke up.21

阅读克里斯托弗·希钦斯的作品令人非常不安。他对宗教的态度狂野而不合理。他的大部分职业生涯都致力于批判宗教和各种形式的极权主义意识形态。

To read the writings of Christopher Hitchens is very disturbing. His orientation toward religion is wild and unreasonable. Much of his professional life was devoted to criticizing religion and totalitarian ideologies of all forms.

2011 年，希钦斯因食道癌去世，享年 62 岁。他没有将自己描述为无神论者（“没有上帝的人”），而是反神论者——上帝的反对者。在他最后一本书《死亡》 （2012 年）中，他生动地描绘了自己与癌症的斗争。他以惯常的讽刺和黑色幽默写道：

Hitchens died of esophageal cancer in 2011 at the age of sixty-two. He didn’t describe himself as an atheist (“someone without god”) but, instead, as an antitheist—an opponent of god. In his final book, Mortality (2012), he paints a vivid picture of his battle against cancer. With his usual sarcasm and black humor, he writes:

《信仰为何重要》一书的作者、洛杉矶一家大型教会的领袖拉比戴维·沃尔普也说过同样的话。他曾是我的辩论伙伴，还有几位新教福音派保守派人士，比如新圣安德鲁斯学院的道格拉斯·威尔逊牧师和阿拉巴马州伯明翰固定点基金会的拉里·汤顿。他们都写信说，他们的教会正在为我祈祷。而我第一个想到的回信就是写给他们的，我问道：为什么祈祷？……

威尔逊牧师回答说，当他听到这个消息时，他为三件事祈祷：希望我能战胜疾病，希望我能永生，希望这个过程能让我们两人重新联系。他忍不住调皮地补充说，第三个祈祷已经得到了回应……

许多世俗和无神论的朋友都对我说了一些鼓舞人心、奉承人的话，比如“如果有人能战胜癌症，那你也能”；“癌症对你这样的人毫无胜算”；“我们知道你能战胜癌症。”在糟糕的日子里，甚至在好日子里，这样的劝告都会让人感到有点沮丧。如果我放弃的话，我就会让所有这些同志失望。我还想到了另一个世俗问题：如果我挺过来了，虔诚派心满意足地声称他们的祈祷得到了回应，那该怎么办？那会让人有点恼火……

布莱斯·帕斯卡是基督教最有理智的捍卫者之一，早在 17 世纪，他就把基督教的本质简化为一场赌注。他提出，如果你信仰全能者，你就会得到一切。如果你拒绝上天的恩赐，如果结果相反，你就会失去一切。（一些哲学家也称之为帕斯卡的策略。）

尽管帕斯卡的文章推理过程十分巧妙——他是概率论的创始人之一——但他假设上帝是玩世不恭的，人类是卑鄙的机会主义者。如果我抛弃一生坚持的原则，希望在最后一刻获得青睐，那会怎样？我希望并相信，没有一个严肃的人会对这样的情况印象深刻骗子的选择。同时，奖励这种懦弱和不诚实并惩罚不可调和的怀疑的神是我不相信的众多神之一。22

Rabbi David Wolpe, author of Why Faith Matters and the leader of a major congregation in Los Angeles, said the same. He has been a debating partner of mine, as have several Protestant evangelical conservatives like Pastor Douglas Wilson of the New Saint Andrews College and Larry Taunton of the Fixed Point Foundation in Birmingham, Alabama. Both wrote to say that their assemblies were praying for me. And it was to them that it first occurred to me to write back, asking: Praying for what? . . .

Pastor Wilson responded that when he heard the news he prayed for three things: that I would fight off the disease, that I would make myself right with eternity, and that the process would bring the two of us back into contact. He couldn’t resist adding rather puckishly that the third prayer had already been answered. . . .

An enormous number of secular and atheist friends have told me encouraging and flattering things like, “If anyone can beat this, you can”; “Cancer has no chance against someone like you”; “We know you can vanquish this.” On bad days, and even on better ones, such exhortations can have a vaguely depressing effect. If I check out, I’ll be letting all these comrades down. A different secular problem also occurs to me: What if I pulled through and the pious faction contentedly claimed that their prayers had been answered? That would somehow be irritating. . . .

One of Christianity’s most cerebral defenders, Blaise Pascal, reduced the essentials to a wager as far back as the seventeenth century. Put your faith in the almighty, he proposed, and you stand to gain everything. Decline the heavenly offer and you lose everything if the coin falls the other way. (Some philosophers also call this Pascal’s Gambit.)

Ingenious though the full reasoning of his essay may be—he was one of the founders of probability theory—Pascal assumes both a cynical god and an abjectly opportunistic human being. Suppose I ditch the principles I have held for a lifetime, in the hope of gaining favor at the last minute? I hope and trust that no serious person would be at all impressed by such a hucksterish choice. Meanwhile, the god who would reward such cowardice and dishonesty and punish irreconcilable doubt is among the many gods in which (whom?) I do not believe.22

喜剧演员瑞奇·热维斯的态度则轻松一些，他经常以许多人认为具有挑衅性的方式嘲笑宗教。他在推特上评论道：“这几乎就像是圣经是由种族主义、性别歧视、恐同、暴力、性压抑的男人写的，而不是由慈爱的上帝写的。真奇怪。” 23

A more lighthearted attitude is held by comedian Ricky Gervais, who often pokes fun at religion in what for many people is a provocative manner. On Twitter, he comments: “It’s almost as if the Bible was written by racist, sexist, homophobic, violent, sexually frustrated men, instead of a loving God. Weird.”23

在另一个场景中，热维斯提出了以下诙谐的多项选择题：“上帝不会阻止可怕的事情发生，因为：（1）他不能；（2）他不想；（3）他造成了这些事情；（4）他不存在。请现在投票。”

In another context, Gervais poses the following witty multiple-choice question: “God doesn’t prevent terrible things because: (1) He can’t; (2) He doesn’t want to; (3) He causes them; (4) He doesn’t exist. Please vote now.”

许多其他著名的文化人物、演员和艺术家，如喜剧演员比尔·马赫、斯蒂芬·弗莱和艾迪·伊扎德，以及魔术师詹姆斯·兰迪和音乐家蒂姆·明钦，都在各种场合公开支持世俗观点。（蒂姆·明钦是澳大利亚钢琴家、歌手、作曲家和艺术家，他制作了一个关于宗教、新时代运动和伪科学的精彩视频，可以在我的网站上观看。24）

Many other notable cultural figures, actors, and artists, such as comedians Bill Maher, Stephen Fry, and Eddie Izzard, as well as magician James Randi and musician Tim Minchin, have spoken out in favor of the secular perspective in various venues. (Tim Minchin is an Australian pianist, singer, composer, and artist, who made a remarkable video about religion, the New Age movement, and pseudoscience, which can be viewed on my website.24)

显然，在二十一世纪的头几年，这一事业变得更加紧迫和迫切。自 2001 年 9 月 11 日世界贸易中心遭受袭击以来，越来越多的人意识到捍卫世俗主义的紧迫性。在我的网站上可以找到一份支持世俗主义的知名人士的长名单。25

It’s clear that during the first years of the twenty-first century, this cause has become more urgent and pressing. Since the attacks on the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001, more and more people have realized the urgency of defending secularism. A lengthy list of well-known people who support secularism can be found on my website.25

世俗人士仍然普遍认为宗教与道德价值观之间存在着必然联系。一个特别明显的例子是，在瑞典，小学和中学的宗教和伦理教学仍然在同一个课堂上进行，这被称为“宗教教育”。我将在后面的章节中回到这个话题。

It is still common to find secular people who believe that there is a necessary connection between religion and moral values. A particularly clear example of this is the fact that in Sweden, the teaching of religion and ethics at both the elementary and secondary levels still takes place in one and the same class, which is called “religious education.” I will return to this topic in a later chapter.

伦理研究员 Birgitta Forsman 在其著作《无神的道德》（Gudlös etik，2011 年）中这样描述道德与宗教戒律的独立性：

Ethics researcher Birgitta Forsman, in her book Gudlös etik (Godless Morality, 2011), describes the independence of morality from religious precepts in the following way:

在社会发展之前，宗教信仰、分享的情感，或许还有对音乐的热爱，都可能在帮助人类生存方面发挥了作用。分享使群体团结在一起，因此我们的祖先能够击败他们的原始人竞争对手（例如尼安德特人）。另一方面，宗教信仰另一方面，可能并没有促进我们的进化；所需要的只是它没有那么有害以至于真正威胁到生存。但现在可能是时候改变现状了。在一个拥有原子武器和激光射线的高科技世界里，命令我们采取某些行动的神灵幻想可能真的威胁着我们的生存。26

Religiousness, the feeling of sharing, and perhaps the love of music may all have played roles in helping humans to survive before society developed. Sharing held groups together, so that our ancestors were able to defeat their hominid competitors [e.g., the Neanderthals]. Religiousness, on the other hand, may not have furthered our evolution; all that was needed was that it wasn’t so harmful as to actually threaten survival. But now the time may have come for things to change. In a highly technological world with atomic weapons and laser rays, it may be that fantasies about gods that order us to carry out certain actions are genuinely threatening our survival.26

当我问瑞典著名演员斯特兰·斯卡斯加德 (Stellan Skarsgård) 是否曾思考过上帝是否存在的问题时，他这样说道：

And the well-known Swedish actor Stellan Skarsgård, when I asked him if he had ever grappled with the question of God’s existence, said the following:

不。我认为整个问题都很荒谬，毫无趣味，因为如果上帝是善良的，那么他就能观察我的所有行为并做出判断，如果他如此虚荣以至于想要别人向他祈祷，那么他根本不值得我向他祈祷。我会相信上帝不存在，直到相反的观点被证明成立。对我来说，上帝就像圣诞老人一样可信。我觉得没有必要纠结上帝是否存在的问题，但这并不意味着我相信唯一存在的就是我们能看到的东西。我们感知现实的能力实际上非常有限；它是在人类还是狩猎者和采集者的时候进化而来的，当时他们生活在大约 60 人的小群体中。

许多动物只看到它们生存所需的东西。我们的感官也是如此——我们当然无法感知一切。当我告诉米洛斯·福尔曼（捷克裔美国电影导演）我是无神论者时，他说：“但如果一个人放弃所有神秘感，生活就会变得如此贫乏！”我回答说，放弃神秘感的是宗教。这就是宗教的全部问题所在。我们这个世界上所有不可理解和令人惊奇的东西都被缩小为一个以青铜时代的神为中心的两千年神话。如果不是否认神秘，那又是什么呢？我对未解问题很着迷。我们当然应该尽可能多地去理解。但是，当你不理解某件事时就跳到上帝的想法——好吧，这只是在逃避神秘。27

No. I see the whole question as absurd and totally devoid of interest, because if there is a god that is good, then he will be able to watch all my behaviors and judge them, and if he is so vain that he wants to be prayed to, then he simply isn’t worth praying to. I will believe that God doesn’t exist until the opposite is proven to hold. To me, God is just as plausible as Santa Claus. I don’t feel any need to grapple with the question of God’s existence, but that doesn’t mean that I believe that the only things that exist are things that we can see. Our ability to perceive reality is in fact enormously limited; it evolved during a time when humans were hunters and gatherers living in small groups of roughly sixty people altogether.

Many animals see only what they need to see in order to survive. And so it is also with our sense organs—we certainly can’t perceive everything. When I told Milos Forman [Czech American film director] that I was an atheist, he said, “But life is so poor if one foregoes all mystical feelings!” I replied that it is religion that foregoes mystical feelings. That’s the whole problem with religion. Everything that is incomprehensible and astonishing about our world is shrunk down to a two-thousand-year-old myth centered on a Bronze Age god. What is that, if not denial of mysteriousness? I am fascinated by unanswered questions. We should of course try to understand as much as we can. But to jump to the idea of God the moment that you don’t understand something—well, that is just running away from mystery.27

对于那些对十九世纪、二十世纪和二十一世纪世俗声音感兴趣的人，我强烈推荐《不信仰的偶像：无神论者、不可知论者和世俗主义者》一书，由 ST Joshi 编辑（2008 年），书中描绘了一些著名人物，例如西格蒙德·弗洛伊德、HP洛夫克拉夫特、阿亚安·希尔西·阿里、理查德·道金斯、卡尔·萨根、马克·吐温等。

For those who are interested in secular voices from the nineteenth, twentieth, and twenty-first centuries, I strongly recommend the book Icons of Unbelief: Atheists, Agnostics, and Secularists, edited by S. T. Joshi (2008), in which portraits are given of such notable people as Sigmund Freud, H. P. Lovecraft, Ayaan Hirsi Ali, Richard Dawkins, Carl Sagan, Mark Twain, and many more.

插曲：关于心灵传送和对死亡的恐惧

INTERLUDE: ON TELEPORTATION AND THE FEAR OF DEATH

您或许还记得《星际迷航》，不是吗？

You probably remember Star Trek, don’t you?

在美国企业号航空母舰上有一个传送器——这是一种可以将你（或任何人）从一个地方传送到另一个地方的机器，它在原子层面上将你拆解，然后在其他地方将你的原子重新组装起来。

On board the USS Enterprise there was a teleporter—a machine that could send you (or any person) from one spot to another by disassembling you at an atomic level and then reassembling your atoms somewhere else.

我们知道物体是由原子组成的，特定元素的所有原子都是相同的。如果我们能够一次一个原子地完整地描绘出一个物体，那么我们就可以用相同的原子精确地重建该物体，但位置不同。这样我们就会得到一个与原始物体完全相同的物体。我们或任何人都无法区分它们。

We know that objects consist of atoms, and that all atoms of a specific element are identical. If we were able to map an object out completely, one atom at a time, then we could precisely reconstruct that object using identical atoms, but in a different place. We would then have a truly identical object to the original. There would be no way for us, or for anyone, to distinguish between them.

但如果重建的对象是人呢？如果我们对人类持有哲学唯物主义的观点，那么我们刚才所说的也必须适用于人。但传送器真的能传送人吗？我们人类真的能接受我们只不过是物质对象的说法吗？相信这样的论点说起来容易做起来难。考虑以下思想实验。

But what if the reconstructed object is a person? If we have a philosophically materialistic viewpoint about human beings, then what we just said would have to hold for people as well. But would a teleporter really be able to transport people? Can we humans actually reconcile ourselves with the claim that we are nothing but material objects? To believe such a thesis is easier said than done. Consider the following thought experiment.

想象一下，未来某一天，你可以安全地在两地之间进行传送。传送的方式是，你体内的所有原子首先被记录在一个巨大的计算机内存中（它们的类型和确切位置，尽可能精确），然后它们全部被摧毁。之后，不同地方的相同原子被聚集在一起，以完全相同的方式组装起来，从而在新的地方制造出一个与你身体完全相同的复制品。这是一种非常快速且非常有效的将人从一个地方传送到另一个地方的方法。

Imagine that someday in the future you can be safely teleported between two spots. The way this happens is that all the atoms in your body are first recorded in a huge computer memory (their types and their exact locations, as precisely as is necessary), and then they are all destroyed. After that, identical atoms in a different place are brought together and assembled in exactly the same fashion, thus making an identical copy of your body in the new place. It’s a very quick and remarkably efficient way of transporting a person from one place to another.

当你躺在传送机里，你体内的所有原子都即将被毁灭时，你还有什么理由感到一丝对死亡的恐惧呢？

As you are lying there in the teleportation machine, with all your atoms just about to be obliterated, might there be any grounds for you to feel a slight fear of dying?

也许不是。毕竟，你坚信人类和其他一切一样，都是由原子组成的，所以你很冷静。你也知道，在你之​​前，成千上万的人已经以完全相同的方式被传送。这对他们有效，所以对你来说也应该有效。

Perhaps not. After all, you’re convinced that a human being, like everything else, is made of atoms, so you’re quite calm. You also know that before you, thousands of people have been teleported in exactly the same way. It worked for them, so it ought to work for you, too.

但是让我们再给这个场景添加一个额外的部分。你躺在机器里，等待被传送，但什么也没发生。然后你听到有人敲门，机器操作员走了进来，礼貌地让你爬出来。她说：“抱歉——出了点小故障。你被安全送到了目的地，所以那边一切都很好。但是这边出了点问题，所以目前有两个你的副本——一个是全新的，远在你要去的地方，另一个是旧的，还在这里。当然这是不可接受的，所以我们现在必须消灭这里的你的副本。所以请跟我沿着这条走廊走下去，到尽头的小房间……”

But let’s just add one extra piece to the scenario. You’re lying there in the machine, waiting to be teleported, but nothing happens. Then you hear a knock at the door, and the operator of the machine steps in and politely asks you to climb out of it. She says, “Sorry—there’s been a little glitch. You were delivered safe and sound at your destination, so everything is fine at that end. But something went wrong at this end, so at the moment there are two copies of you—the brand-new one, far away where you were headed, and this old one, still right here. Of course this is unacceptable, so we’ll now have to eliminate the copy of you that’s here. So please follow me down this hallway, to the little room at the end . . .”

当你走近房间时，你注意到门上方挂着一个小牌子，上面写着“末日房间”，牌子下面有一个可爱的笑脸。操作员笑着说：“这个房间的名字是不是很有趣？几乎每个人都喜欢它。快进来吧！”

As you approach the room, you notice a small sign hanging just above the door with the words “Doom Room” on it, and just underneath the sign there’s a cute smiley face. The operator laughs and says, “Isn’t that a delightful name for the room? Just about everybody likes it. Hop on in!”

那么现在感觉如何？原则上，一切都应该很好，因为一个完整而完美的你的复制品刚刚在其他地方被制造出来。但是，当操作员带你进入可爱的小毁灭之室时，你感觉一切都很好吗？

So how does it feel now? In principle, everything should be just fine, since an intact and perfect copy of you has just been constructed somewhere else. But still and all, does everything feel just right to you, as the operator ushers you into the cute little Doom Room?

这个思想实验表明，我们多么不习惯将身体和灵魂视为一个实体的两个不同方面。尽管如此，科学确实告诉我们，身体和灵魂是同一个东西。但有时，直觉和科学事实并不容易相互调和。

This thought experiment shows how unaccustomed we are to thinking of body and soul as merely two different facets of a single entity. Nonetheless, science certainly tells us that body and soul are one and the same. But sometimes, one’s intuition and scientific facts are not so easy to reconcile with each other.

第十三章

CHAPTER THIRTEEN

启示关于自由、权利和尊重

ENLIGHTENMENT Concerning Freedoms, Rights, and Respect

那些能让你相信荒谬之事的人，也能让你犯下暴行。——弗朗索瓦-玛丽·阿鲁埃（又名伏尔泰），《奇迹问题》（1765 年）

Those who can make you believe absurdities, can make you commit atrocities.—François-Marie Arouet (aka Voltaire), “Questions sur les miracles” (1765)

否现在是时候展望未来，提出一些解决方案，而不是仅仅列出问题。在这个如此深陷非理性、各种极端主义、强烈信仰的宗教教条以及左右翼民主制度分崩离析的世界里，我们该如何行动？

Now is the time for us to look toward the future and to offer some solutions instead of just listing problems. How should we act in this world that is so profoundly drenched in irrationality, in various forms of extremism, in intensely believed religious dogmas, and in democracies that are falling to pieces left and right?

世俗启蒙运动为社会提供了一种清晰的愿景，即所有人，无论其文化背景或人生哲学如何，都能共存并享有平等的地位。这样的社会将宗教与政治划清界限。在制定政治和法律决策时，古代先知的言论将不再具有相关性。这些决策的基础将是人类所能提供的最佳思想，而不是神和先知所谓的主张。

The secular enlightenment provides a clear vision of a society in which all people, no matter what their cultural background or philosophy of life is, can coexist and have equal standing. Such a society would draw a sharp distinction between religion and politics. The utterances of ancient prophets would not be considered relevant when it comes to the making of political and legal decisions. The basis for such decisions will be the best thinking that humanity can offer, not the claims supposedly made by gods and prophets.

在这样一个世俗民主国家，任何个人的宗教信仰当然都会影响其投票方式，而政客当然也可以利用自己的宗教信仰作为灵感来源。议员可以自由地声称议会应该根据某个神灵的支持来决定某一问题；这是言论自由所保障的权利；然而，在这样一个社会中，即使是最虔诚的政客也会意识到，为了得到他人的重视，他们必须提出非宗教的论据来说服他人接受他们的立场。

In such a secular democracy, the religious beliefs of any individual can of course influence how that person votes, and politicians can of course use their own religious beliefs as sources of inspiration.
