A member of parliament would be free to claim that the parliament should decide a certain issue on the basis of its being supported by some deity or other; this is a right that is guaranteed by freedom of speech; however, even the most pious of politicians in such a society would realize that in order to be taken seriously by others, they would have to present nonreligious arguments to convince others of their stance.

今天，我们拥有世俗手段，可以尝试朝着世俗启蒙的愿景迈进。我们可以利用民主、教育、科学和技术等所有工具来促进人类事业。幸福和自由，以及改善全世界人民的生活条件的目标。

Today, we have the secular means at our disposal to try to move toward that vision of secular enlightenment. All the tools of democracy, education, science, and technology are available to us to further the causes of human happiness and freedom, as well as the goal of improving the living conditions of people all around the globe.

普世权利与人类解放

Universal Rights and Human Liberation

世俗启蒙运动的一个关键方面是人权的普遍性理念。所有人，无论其出身或文化如何，都应享有相同的基本权利。理论上这听起来不错，但在实践中意味着什么呢？

A key aspect of the project of secular enlightenment is the idea of the universality of human rights. All people, whatever their origin or their culture might be, should be granted the same basic rights. In theory this sounds good, but what does it mean in practice?

首先，我们必须指出，这不是一个科学问题，而是一个价值观问题。当然，人们可以通过经验证明，这样的政策将减少痛苦，带来更多自由和平等，但这一切是否可取，则是一个价值观问题。从根本上说，这一切都关乎人们对自决权的信仰。或者换句话说，借用伊曼纽尔·康德的术语，启蒙就是人们“摆脱自我强加的不成熟”。关键问题是人们是否摆脱了外部约束，从而能够根据自己的目标和价值观行事。1

First of all, we have to point out that this is not a scientific question but, instead, a matter of values. Of course one might be able to demonstrate empirically that such a policy would lead to less suffering, greater freedom, and more equality, but whether all this is desirable is a question of values. Fundamentally, it’s all about the belief in people’s right to self-determination. Or to put it another way, borrowing Immanuel Kant’s terminology, enlightenment is all about people’s “emergence from their self-imposed immaturity.” The key issue is whether people are free of external constraints, so that they can act on the basis of their own goals and values.1

价值观和权利的普遍性原则与文化相对主义直接冲突，文化相对主义否认存在任何普遍权利。支持这种观点的人声称，任何与道德有关的文化价值观都不可能“优于”其他文化价值观。他们的观点是，基本的生物学事实是将人与人联系在一起的唯一因素，人与人之间所有重大差异都是由他们所属的不同文化决定的。因此，他们会说，人类可以分为不同的类别，你所属的类别决定了你的需求和愿望，进而也决定了你的自由和权利。

The principle of universality of values and rights is in direct conflict with cultural relativism, which denies that there are any universal rights. Those who advocate this point of view claim that no cultural value that bears on morality can possibly be “better” than any other cultural value. Their viewpoint is that basic biological facts are the only things that link human beings to each other, and that all significant differences between people are defined by the various cultures that they belong to. Thus they would say that the human race can be separated into diverse categories, and the category to which you belong determines your needs and desires, and by extension, it also determines your freedoms and rights.

这条路很危险。如果一个人有这样的观点，那么他原则上可以为任何犯罪或违法行为辩护。历史已经表明，将一群人单独挑出来，认为他们与自己有着根本的不同，是多么悲惨——例如，德国的犹太人、当代欧洲的吉普赛人、卢旺达的图西人和巴尔干半岛的穆斯林。

This is a dangerous pathway down which to tread. If one has such a viewpoint, one can in principle justify any crime or transgression whatsoever. History has shown how tragic it is to single out one group of people as being fundamentally different from one’s own—for instance, the Jews in Germany, the Gypsies in contemporary Europe, the Tutsi people in Rwanda, and the Muslims in the Balkans.

幸运的是，文化相对主义似乎正在失去立足之地——至少从科学的角度来看是如此。具体来说，神经科学、社会学、语言学、进化心理学、实验经济学和进化论的研究所有人类学的研究都指向同一个结论：将人类视为一个跨越所有不同文化的统一物种是正确的。

Fortunately, cultural relativism seems to be losing ground—at least from a scientific point of view. To be concrete, research in neuroscience, sociology, linguistics, evolutionary psychology, experimental economics, and evolution ary anthropology all points toward the same conclusion: it is correct to speak about humanity as one uniform species, cutting across all different cultures.

有时，普遍主义信条被批评为“帝国主义”或“西方中心主义”。但这是一种错误的观点。纵观历史，所有文化和传统都提倡人类自由。在思想史上，随处可见对这一原则的信仰。诚然，在不同的时代和地方，这一思想被削弱和压制，但这一思想本身肯定不仅限于西方文化。

Sometimes the universalist credo is criticized for being “imperialistic” or “Western centered.” But this is an incorrect view. All cultures and traditions, throughout history, have advocated human freedom. Belief in this principle can be found everywhere in the history of ideas. To be sure, in various eras and places, that idea has been undermined and suppressed, but the idea itself is certainly not limited to Western cultures.

实现普遍权利的先决条件是深刻的平等观念。因此，我们需要克服对女性和男性的刻板印象以及其他不合理的人际分类。美国社会哲学家约翰·罗尔斯（1921-2002）在其著作《正义论》（1971 年）中提出了“正义的第一原则”，如下：“每个人都应享有最广泛的基本自由体系，该体系应与所有人的类似自由体系相兼容。” 2（罗尔斯以上述著作而闻名，他在书中发展了自己的政治哲学，以取代与功利主义密切相关的“结果主义”传统。）

A prerequisite to the realization of universal rights is a deep notion of equality. Thus we need to overcome stereotyped views of women and men, and other unjustified categorizations of people. In his book A Theory of Justice (1971), American social philosopher John Rawls (1921–2002) formulated the “First Principle of Justice” as follows: “Each person is to have an equal right to the most extensive total system of equal basic liberties compatible with a similar system of liberty for all.”2 (Rawls is best known for the above-mentioned book, in which he develops his own alternative to the “consequentialist” tradition, closely related to utilitarianism, in political philosophy.)

人权的普及只是迈向文明社会的第一步。人权也必须得到认真对待，而不能只是听起来高尚的雄辩宣言。

For human rights to become universal is merely the first step toward an enlightened society. Human rights must also be taken seriously, not merely be eloquent pronouncements having a fine noble ring to them.

身份陷阱

Identity as a Trap

认为一个人是由几个简单的标签来定义的，这是一个严重的错误。当然，我们可以指出某些有助于确定一个人身份的特征，例如生理性别、性取向、年龄、肤色、民族血统或公民身份。但人们很容易认为，仅凭这几个标准（或类似的标准），我们就能预测某人的所有其他属性。事实上，碰巧具有相同性取向或相同民族血统的人，在其他方面通常是完全不同的。

It is a grievous error to think that an individual human being is defined by a handful of simple labels. Of course we can point to certain traits that contribute to one’s identity, such as biological gender, sexual orientation, age, skin color, ethnic origin, or citizenship. But it is just too tempting to think that, solely on the basis of these few criteria (or similar ones), we can predict all of someone’s other properties. The fact is, people who happen to have the same sexual orientation or the same ethnic origin are, as a rule, completely different from each other in other regards.

纵观历史，人们给别人分类的方式有很多种。种族生物学、颅相学和占星术都证明了我们人类想要把彼此放在整齐的小盒子里的愿望。为什么我们人类似乎需要如此简单的身份概念？显然是因为我们相信，如果我们能把复杂而混乱的世界分解成简单的构建块，那么我们就能更轻松地处理它。事实上，然而，如此简单的标签只会让生活变得更加困难，而且不幸的是，也更加危险。

Throughout history many names have been given to people’s ways of categorizing other people. Race biology, phrenology, and astrology all testify to our human desire to place one another in neat little boxes. Why do we humans seem to need such simplistic notions of identity? Apparently it’s because we believe that if we can break our complex and chaotic world up into simple building blocks, then we can deal with it more easily. In truth, though, such simplistic labeling only makes life more difficult—and, unfortunately, more dangerous.

哲学家兼经济学家阿马蒂亚·森指出，在我们这个全球化的世界里，标签化的需求日益增加，不幸的是，其后果令人担忧。森因研究个人和集体理性而于 1998 年获得诺贝尔经济学奖。他于 2006 年出版的《身份与暴力：命运的幻觉》一书探讨了身份的概念以及赋予其过多含义的危险。在书中，他描述了一种误区，即认为一个人的表面身份揭示了其性格中所有隐藏的方面。

Philosopher and economist Amartya Sen has pointed out that the need for labeling has been increasing in our globalized world, unfortunately with very worrisome consequences. Sen, who was awarded the 1998 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, is best known for his studies of individual and collective rationality. His book Identity and Violence: The Illusion of Destiny published in 2006, deals with the concept of identity and with the danger of assigning too much meaning to it. In the book, he describes the trap of thinking that someone’s superficial identity reveals all the hidden facets of their character.

事实上，任何个人都可以拥有多种多样的身份，例如，穆斯林或基督徒可以是白人或黑人、女同性恋或异性恋、保守派或激进派、世俗派或正统派、社会主义者或自由主义者、女权主义者或女权主义批评者、重金属或前巴洛克合唱音乐爱好者、国际象棋选手或羽毛球运动员、理论物理学家或文盲流浪者。对于特定个人而言，这些身份中没有一种必然比其他身份更重要。

The truth is that any individual can have many diverse identities, for example, a Muslim or a Christian can be white or black, lesbian or straight, conservative or radical, secular or orthodox, socialist or libertarian, feminist or feminist-basher, a lover of heavy metal or of pre-baroque choral music, a chess player or badminton player, or theoretical physicist or illiterate homeless person. And for a particular individual, none of these identities is necessarily more important than any of the others.

可以肯定的是，一个人身份的某些方面可以根植于肤色、性别、性取向或年龄等特征。其他方面可以根植于一个人的态度或信仰，例如宗教信仰或政治价值观。还有一些方面可以根植于环境，例如一个人的出生地，或随机因素，例如一个人的母语或成长过程中的文化传统。特征、态度和随机因素不必混合在一起——但这在政治和公共话语中经常发生。它甚至发生在瑞典反歧视法的第一段中！看看吧：

To be sure, certain aspects of one’s identity can be rooted in traits such as skin color, sex, sexual orientation, or age. Others can be rooted in one’s attitudes or beliefs, such as religious convictions or political values. And yet others can be rooted in circumstances, such as where one happened to be born, or random factors, such as one’s native language or the cultural traditions that one grew up with. Traits, attitudes, and random factors don’t have to be mixed together—but that’s what constantly happens in politics and in public discourse. It happens even in the first paragraph of the Swedish law on discrimination! Check it out:

这部法律的目的是反对一切形式的歧视，支持所有人享有平等的权利和机会，无论其性别、性别认同、自我表达方式、种族归属、宗教或其他信仰、残疾、性取向或年龄如何。3

The purpose of this law is to oppose all forms of discrimination, and to support equal rights and possibilities for all, regardless of a person’s sex, sexual identity, or way of expressing oneself, ethnic affiliation, religion or other type of belief, handicaps, sexual orientation, or age.3

在这篇文章中，特征（例如一个人的年龄、性别或遗传缺陷）与态度（例如一个人的宗教或其他观点）混合在一起。当然，人们可以有效地谈论这些领域中的任何一个或所有领域的歧视，但特征、态度和随机因素有很大不同，不应以同样的方式对待。例如，人们可以不要批评别人的信仰，但不要批评他们的先天特质。毕竟，信仰和态度（与先天特质不同）至少在原则上总是可以重新考虑或改变的；因此，它们也应该受到质疑。如果某人的宗教信仰给其他人带来了负面影响，那么这个人应该对这些后果承担责任。

In this passage, traits (such as a person’s age, gender, or genetic handicaps) are mixed together with attitudes (such as a person’s religion or other points of view). Of course one can validly talk about discrimination within any or all of these areas, but traits, attitudes, and random factors are deeply different and should not be treated in the same way. For instance, one can criticize someone else’s beliefs but not their innate traits. After all, beliefs and attitudes (unlike innate traits) can always, at least in principle, be reconsidered or changed; therefore, they should also be open to being questioned. If someone’s religious beliefs result in negative consequences for other people, then that person should bear the responsibility for these consequences.

如果法律将一个人的宗教信仰视为一种特质，即其个性中固定不变的元素，那么实际上，在法律上，宗教人士将被视为没有独立思考的能力。在这种情况下，你对你的宗教信仰（或其任何后果）的责任，就像你的性别、肤色或年龄一样微不足道。如果你因为圣经中阐述的性别歧视教义而犯罪，你只需被赦免，因为你的行为源于你的宗教（可能是固定不变的）特质。相反，在这种情况下，对宗教的客观合理批评将被视为非法的歧视行为。这种情况相当荒谬。

If a body of laws were to treat a person’s religious faith as a trait—that is, as a fixed, unchangeable element of their personality—then, in effect, religious people would be seen, under the law, as being incapable of thinking for themselves. In such a scenario, you couldn’t be held responsible for your religious beliefs (or any of their consequences) any more than for your gender, your skin color, or your age. If you committed a crime on the basis of, say, a sexist doctrine enunciated in a sacred text, you would simply have to be pardoned, since your act would have been derived from the (presumably fixed and immutable) trait of your religion. And conversely, an objectively justifiable criticism of a religion would be seen, in such a scenario, as an illegal act of discrimination. Such a scenario is quite absurd.

伊斯兰教与宗教批判

Islam and the Criticism of Religion

当今瑞典的一个极具煽动性的话题是伊斯兰教。当一种“外来”宗教开始在瑞典社会露面时，瑞典人突然注意到一种被称为“宗教”的东西的存在。毕竟，大多数瑞典人都心照不宣地认为，我们的瑞典传统要么是完全没有宗教，要么是某种形式的基督教。一些瑞典人认为穆斯林对我们的“基督教价值观”构成了威胁；另一些人则害怕批评被定义为穆斯林的观点。不愿批评与伊斯兰教有关的思想和价值观，源于害怕被贴上“仇视伊斯兰教”的标签。

A highly inflammatory topic in Sweden today is Islam. When an “alien” religion begins to show its face in Swedish society, Swedes suddenly take notice of the fact that something called “religion” exists. After all, most Swedes tacitly assume that our Swedish tradition is either no religion at all, or some form of Christianity. Some Swedes see Muslims as a danger to our “Christian values”; others are frightened to death about criticizing viewpoints defined as Muslim. Reluctance to criticize thoughts and values connected with Islam stems from a fear of being labeled “Islamophobic.”

但事实是，穆斯林来自不同的国家，有着不同的兴趣、教育背景、性取向、职业和价值观。他们对如何理解伊斯兰教也有不同的看法。除了他们将自己的一些信仰和态度贴上“穆斯林”的标签外，他们彼此之间并没有太多共同之处。

The truth is, though, Muslims come from all sorts of countries and have all sorts of interests, educational backgrounds, sexual orientations, professions, and values. They also have diverse opinions about how Islam should be understood. Apart from the fact that they label some of their beliefs and attitudes as “Muslim,” they don’t have particularly much in common with each other.

概括“所有穆斯林”并不比概括“所有基督徒”、“所有犹太人”、“所有印度教徒”、“所有世俗人文主义者”或任何恰好对生活抱有某种观点的群体的所有成员更合理。人们可以调查任何群体的价值观和规范通过研究诸如“这个群体（无论是穆斯林、犹太人、基督徒、世俗人文主义者，还是其他什么人）中有多少比例的人对女性或同性恋等持特定态度？”这样的问题，显然，通过细致的社会研究，这样的问题能够得到解答。

It is no more valid to generalize about “all Muslims” than to generalize about “all Christians,” “all Jews,” “all Hindus,” “all secular humanists,” or all members of any group of people who happen to share a certain viewpoint about life. One can survey any group of people about their values and norms by researching such questions as “What proportion of the members of this group (be they Muslims, Jews, Christians, secular humanists, or what have you) have a certain attitude about, say, women or homosexuality?” Obviously, such questions can be answered by doing careful social research.

如果进行这样的研究，将有助于我们理解所谓的“主流伊斯兰教”、“主流基督教”或“主流人文主义”。然而，今天，人们反对用这种统计方式进行概括，尤其是关于伊斯兰教。甚至有人声称，不能对伊斯兰教或任何其他宗教信仰做出任何陈述。这种善意立场的目的可能是削弱对穆斯林的偏见，但不幸的后果是，即使是对某一宗教的客观和合理的批评也会因此变得高度可疑。因此，宗教免于一切批评，因为没有确切的定义。这不是一条通往健康对话的有希望的途径。

And if such research is done, it will help us understand what might be called “mainstream Islam,” “mainstream Christianity,” or “mainstream humanism.” Today, however, there is a resistance to generalizing in this sort of statistical fashion, especially about Islam. There are even people who claim that no statements of any sort can be made about Islam or any other religious belief. The goal of such a well-meaning stance may be to undercut prejudices about Muslims, but the unfortunate consequence is that even objective and justified criticisms of one religion or another are thereby rendered highly suspect. Religion is thus exempted from all criticism, since there is no precise definition of what it is. This is not a promising avenue toward healthy dialogue.

相比之下，一个更重要的见解是：即使人们可以对伊斯兰教（或任何其他信仰体系）成员的信仰和观点做出有理有据的统计总结，也无法得出任何关于某个孤立个体是否拥有这些信仰的明确结论。我们可以泛泛地谈论不同的人生哲学及其相互关系。我们可以——也应该——分析它们的后果并批判性地分析它们的内容。但我们永远无法预测某个穆斯林（或某个基督教徒、印度教徒或世俗人文主义者）对某个特定问题的看法，除非我们直接询问那个人。

By contrast, a much more important insight is this: Even if one can make a well-founded statistical summary about the beliefs and outlooks of members of Islam (or any other belief system), one can’t draw any firm conclusions about an isolated individual having those beliefs. We can speak in general about different philosophies of life and their relationships with each other. We can—and we should—analyze their consequences and critically analyze their content. But we cannot ever predict what an individual Muslim (or individual Christian, Hindu, or secular humanist) will think about a specific issue, unless we ask that person directly.

本质主义与人性观

Essentialism and Viewpoints on Humanity

2014 年瑞典大选中，瑞典民主党的得票率是上届的两倍多，下降了 13%。他们迅速利用了新获得的权力地位，在瑞典制造了议会混乱。同样，欧洲许多地方的民粹主义和民族主义势力也在不断壮大。这是一个不祥之兆，让人想起欧洲在 20 世纪的黑暗历史。这些新潮流背后是一种非理性的人性观，为错误思想的泛滥铺平了道路，民粹主义和极端主义就是建立在这些错误思想之上的。

In the Swedish elections of 2014, the Swedish Democrats more than doubled their previous performance, pulling down 13 percent of the votes. They quickly exploited their new position of power, creating parliamentary chaos in Sweden. Similarly, populist and nationalist forces are increasing in strength in many parts of Europe. This is an ominous sign, and it is a reminder of Europe’s dark history during the twentieth century. Underlying these new currents is an irrational viewpoint about humanity that is clearing a pathway for the flourishing of false ideas, such as those on which populism and extremism are based.

我指的是人性的本质主义观点，它构成了宗教人性观的基础，而且不幸的是，它渗透着民粹主义、极右翼和种族主义观点——既包括纯粹的生物种族主义，也包括广义的种族主义，即基于种族、文化和宗教的身份政治。

I am referring to the essentialist viewpoint of human nature, which forms the basis of religious conceptions of humanity, and which also sadly permeates populist, extreme right-wing, and racist viewpoints—meaning both purely biological racism and racism in an extended sense, which is to say, ethnic, cultural, and religion-based identity politics.

本质主义认为某些实体必然具有某些属性，而其他属性则是偶然的，或者仅仅是可能的。一种常见的本质主义思维涉及“男性气质”和“女性气质”的刻板印象。这种观点意味着男性和女性的思维存在根本差异，这些差异与性别有着不可逆转的联系，源于男性和女性的生物学本质。这意味着男性和女性思维之间的差异不会受到诸如文化之类的因素的影响。

Essentialism is the thesis that certain entities necessarily possess certain properties, while other properties are contingent, or merely possible. A common type of essentialist thinking involves stereotypes of “masculinity” and “femininity.” This viewpoint implies that there are fundamental differences between men’s and women’s thinking, and that these differences are irrevocably linked with gender, coming out of the biological nature of males and females. This would imply that the differences between men’s and women’s thinking cannot be influenced by such things as culture.

相反的观点认为，每个人是由他们的思想、价值观、行为和选择决定的。正是这些因素决定了一个人成为他们自己。或者，引用让-保罗·萨特的话，“存在先于本质”。我们首先存在，然后我们创造自己和我们的“本质”。这种观点与宗教教条截然相反，宗教教条认为每个人都是按照上帝的形象创造的，并且带有“神圣的火花”。

The opposite viewpoint starts from the idea that each person is defined by their thoughts, values, actions, and choices. These are the things that result in someone being the person that they are. Or, to quote Jean-Paul Sartre, “Existence precedes essence.” First we come into existence, and then we create ourselves and our “essence.” This view stands in direct opposition to the religious dogma that every person is created in God’s image and carries a “divine spark” in them.

宗教教条和民族主义教条都暗示所有人生来就具有先天的本质。这种本质要么是上帝预先赋予的，要么是由一个人的“种族”、文化、宗教或民族决定的。性别歧视的观点认为一个人的性别是其天性的固定、决定性的本质。

Both religious dogma and nationalistic dogma imply that all people are born with a preexisting essence. Either that essence is pre-given by God, or else it is dictated by one’s “race,” one’s culture, one’s religion, or one’s ethnicity. A sexist viewpoint presumes one’s gender to be a fixed, determining essence of one’s nature.

在瑞典社会，某些本质主义思维方式比其他思维方式更受接受。令人惊讶的是，尽管如今许多瑞典人似乎敏锐地意识到，人们永远不应该说“所有黑人都具有以下特性……”这样的话，但他们似乎完全没有意识到“所有女性都具有以下特性……”等说法中固有的类似偏见。你多久会听到这样的话：“经商的女性必须模仿男性才能成功”？想想看，你听到“经商的黑人必须模仿白人才能成功”这样的话的可能性有多大——听起来又是多么令人反感。

In Swedish society, some essentialist forms of thinking are viewed as more acceptable than others. Remarkably enough, although many Swedes today seem to be keenly aware that one should never say such things as “All black people have the following properties . . .,” they seem to be utterly unaware of the analogous prejudice inherent in statements such as “All women have the following properties . . .” How often do you hear remarks such as “Women who go into business have to imitate men in order to succeed”? Just think how unlikely you would be to hear a statement such as “Black people who go into business have to imitate white people in order to succeed”—and how deeply offensive it would sound.

本质主义的另一个例子是欧洲许多极右翼运动中仍然存在的种族主义观点。它不仅在道德上应受谴责，而且在科学上也是错误的。

Another example of essentialism is the racist view that still persists in many extreme-right movements in Europe. It is not only morally reprehensible but also scientifically fallacious.

例如，DNA 分析显示，东非人和欧洲人的基因重叠度比东非人和西非人的基因重叠度更大。大约七万年前，东非人从非洲移居到欧洲，首先穿过阿拉伯半岛。这就是为什么东非人和欧洲人在基因上比东非人和西非人更接近。这给种族主义者带来了一个令人费解的困境。

DNA analyses show, for example, that East Africans and Europeans have a greater genetic overlap than East Africans and West Africans. It was East Africans who, roughly seventy thousand years ago, emigrated from Africa, first through the Arabian Peninsula and then into Europe. This is why East Africans and Europeans are genetically closer than East Africans and West Africans are. This creates a puzzling dilemma for racists.

研究表明，大约三万年前，尼安德特人和我们人类都曾存在过，但后来尼安德特人灭绝了；然而，现代人类与尼安德特人通婚，因此今天，我们 DNA 中大约 2% 到 4% 的基因来自尼安德特人的染色体。除了纯种非洲人之外，所有人类都是如此。他们是目前唯一没有一丝尼安德特人 DNA 痕迹的人类。

Research has shown that some thirty thousand years ago, Neanderthals and humans of our species were both alive, but then the Neanderthals died out; however, modern humans mated with Neanderthals, so that today, somewhere between 2 and 4 percent of our DNA comes from Neanderthal chromosomes. This holds for all humans except for pure Africans. They are the only people now alive who don’t have a single trace of Neanderthal DNA.

性别本质主义和性别视角

Gender Essentialism and the Lens of Gender

女权运动让我们对性别有了新的认识，特别是对性别作为一种社会建构有了新的认识。从性别的角度看社会意味着关注偏见、期望和与性别相关的规范是如何在我们一生中投射到我们每个人身上的。一种可以让男人获得较高社会地位的行为方式，对表现出同样行为的女人来说，可能会产生完全相反的影响（当然，反之亦然）。“适当”男性和女性行为的社会准则往往是不言而喻的，我们通过与他人的互动来获得它们，或者它们通过大众媒体和广告中的潜意识信息悄悄潜入我们的脑海。毫无疑问，这种普遍的社会影响在我们文化成员如何被塑造成“男人”或“女人”的过程中起着核心作用，而不仅仅是我们在特定性别的生物学身份。

The feminist movement has given us new insights into gender—specifically, into gender as a social construct. Looking at society through the lens of gender means paying attention to how prejudices, expectations, and sex-linked norms are projected onto each one of us throughout our entire lives. A form of behavior that could give a man a high social status can have entirely the opposite effect on a woman who exhibits the identical behavior (and, of course, vice versa). The social codes for “proper” masculine and feminine behavior are often unspoken, and we pick them up through our interactions with others, or they sneak silently into our minds via the mass media and subliminal messages in advertisements. There can be no doubt that this type of pervasive social influence plays a central role in how we members of a culture are shaped into “men” or “women” over and above our biological membership in a particular sex.

不幸的是，一些女权主义者和性别问题作家蔑视科学，认为对男女之间的生物学或认知差异进行科学研究是有害的，甚至是彻头彻尾的邪恶；然而，科学研究不应受意识形态或政治目标的控制。真正的问题不是研究本身或其结果，而是从此类研究中得出的不合理结论。如果发现两性之间存在某种生物学差异，不应将其作为支持传统性别角色或支持区别对待男孩和女孩（或男性和女性）的论据。

Unfortunately, some feminists and writers about gender hold science in contempt and consider that it is harmful, if not downright evil, to carry out scientific research on biological or cognitive differences between men and women; however, scientific research should not be controlled by ideological or political goals. The true problem is not the research or its findings; it is the irrational conclusions that far too often are drawn from such research. If some sort of biological differences are found between the sexes, these should not be cited as arguments in favor of traditional gender roles or in favor of treating boys and girls (or men and women) differently.

假设经过大量研究，发现男性和女性在某种智力活动中的平均表现存在差异（通常声称这种差异错误百出）。即使情况如此，属于同一性别的不同个体之间的差异也远大于两个平均值之间的差异。由于性别内的巨大差异，基于性别的特殊待遇的整个理念完全瓦解。

Suppose that after considerable research, there turned out to be a difference between the average performance of men and that of women in some type of intellectual activity (the usual claims cited for such differences being error ridden). Even if that were the case, the differences between diverse individuals belonging to a single gender would be far larger than the difference between the two averages. Thanks to this enormous intragender variability, the whole idea of special treatment based on gender falls completely apart.

一个更微妙的逻辑陷阱是只比较男性和女性，而忽略了其他可能划分人群的方式。例如，如果我们比较惯用右手的人和惯用左手的人，或者矮个子和高个子的人，我们很可能会发现这些群体的平均水平差异同样大，甚至更大。我们想让社会政策基于这样的发现吗？我们大多数人会对这样的建议嗤之以鼻——然而，我们一生都倾向于用性别刻板印象来思考问题，这阻止了我们采取不带偏见的态度，就像对待具有特定头发颜色、惯用手、身高等的人群一样。

A subtler logical trap is the very idea of comparing just men and women, ignoring other potential ways of dividing people up. If, for example, we were to compare righthanded and lefthanded people, or short and tall people, we might very well discover equally great, or even greater, differences between the averages of such groups. Would we want social policies to be based on such discoveries? Most of us would simply scoff at such a suggestion—and yet our lifelong tendency to think in terms of gender stereotypes prevents us from having an unbiased attitude, as we would for groups of people having a specific hair color, handedness, height, and so on.

我认为，为了形成一种没有偏见的对人的看法，我们必须完全抛弃本质主义。这是新启蒙运动项目的关键要素。

I believe that in order to develop a view of people that is free from prejudice, we have to totally abandon essentialism. This is a crucial ingredient in the project of a new enlightenment.

什么是宗教自由？

What Is Religious Freedom?

宗教自由被写入瑞典和美国的法律，但这究竟意味着什么呢？当然，这意味着任何人都可以相信他们想要相信的任何东西；这应该是一项绝对的、不受限制的权利。然而，世俗国家应该能够限制宗教自由，限制宗教信仰的表达方式（即决定人们的行为）。人们不应该被允许以宗教的名义为所欲为。这就是政治冲突和争议出现的地方。

Religious freedom is written into Swedish and U.S. law, but what does this really entail? Of course, it means that anyone can believe whatever they wish; this should be an absolute and unrestricted right. A secular state should, however, be able to place limitations on religious freedom in terms of how religious beliefs can be expressed (in the sense of determining people’s actions). People should not be allowed to do just anything they please in the name of their religion. This is where political conflicts and controversies come into the picture.

在联合国《世界人权宣言》第 18 条中，我们看到这样的说法：“人人有思想、良心和宗教自由的权利。” 联合国人权委员会在 1993 年的一篇评论中对这一说法进行了澄清：“第 18 条保护有神论、非有神论和无神论信仰，以及不信奉任何宗教或信仰的权利。” 4

In article 18 of the United Nations (UN) Universal Declaration of Human Rights, we find the following statement: “Everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience, and religion.” In a commentary in 1993, the United Nations committee on human rights clarified this statement as follows: “Article 18 protects theistic, non-theistic and atheistic beliefs, as well as the right not to profess any religion or belief.”4

瑞典宪法还规定，我们每个人都有不受限制地言论、不受限制地传递和接收信息、不受限制地集会、不受限制地示威、不受限制地组织团体以及不受限制地信奉任何宗教的权利。

The Swedish constitution also states that we all have the right to speak without restriction, to transmit and receive information without restriction, to gather without restriction, to demonstrate without restriction, to organize groups without restriction, and to practice any religion without restriction.

从历史上看，宗教自由的动机是反对各种形式的胁迫或迫害宗教少数派。想想看，就在 1951 年，离开瑞典路德教会是违法的，除非同时成为其他宗教派别的成员。今天，仍然有一些国家，任何放弃伊斯兰教而皈依基督教或过无神生活方式的人都会被监禁，甚至死刑。这就是联合国宣言如此重要的原因。

Historically, religious freedom was motivated by the need to react against various forms of coercion or persecution of religious minorities. Consider that, as recently as 1951, it was illegal to leave the Swedish Lutheran Church unless one simultaneously became a member of some other religious denomination. There are still lands today in which anyone who renounces Islam for Christianity or a lifestyle without any god is subject to imprisonment if not capital punishment. This is why the UN declaration is important.

每个人都应该有权表达自己的信仰、与他人聚会以及建立基于共同信仰的团体。同样，遵循自己的习俗（无论是宗教习俗还是文化习俗）的权利也应受到保护——但前提是这些习俗不与其他法律相冲突。

Every person should have the right to express their beliefs, to gather with others, and to form groups based on common beliefs. Similarly, the right to follow one’s own customs, whether they are religious or cultural, should be protected—but only as long as those customs do not conflict with other laws.

联合国人权宣言所规定的宗教自由，在某些情况下实际上是逻辑上自相矛盾的。以罗马天主教会为例。天主教要求天主教父母以天主教信仰抚养子女，以便他们也能成为信奉天主教并实践天主教的教徒。联合国宣言通过尊重宗教自由，赋予这些父母履行这一宗教“义务”的权利。另一方面，根据联合国儿童权利公约，所有儿童都有自己的权利。特别是，儿童有自己的宗教自由权利，这意味着他们不能被强迫参与天主教信仰或其仪式。因此，我们看到，“宗教自由”的概念本身就包含两个逻辑上不相容的原则。

Religious freedom, as it is formulated in the UN Declaration of Human Rights, is actually logically inconsistent, in certain cases. Take, for instance, the case of the Roman Catholic Church. Catholicism requires Catholic parents to raise their children in the Catholic faith, so that they too will become believing and practicing Catholics. The UN declaration, through its respect for religious freedom, gives these parents the right to carry out this religious “duty.” On the other hand, according to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, all children have their own rights. In particular, children have their own right to religious freedom, and this means that they cannot be coerced to participate in the Catholic faith or its rites. We thus see that the very notion of “religious freedom” involves two logically incompatible principles.

实际上，瑞典社会以宗教自由的名义接受的、不受其他法律约束的事情非常少。成年耶和华见证人信徒和其他信仰的成年人一样，可以拒绝为自己输血，但他们不能合法地阻止自己的孩子接受输血。这可能被视为对他们宗教自由的限制，但保护儿童生命的世俗法律优先于此。

In practice, Swedish society accepts very few things in the name of religious freedom that are not covered by other laws. Adult Jehovah’s Witnesses, just like adults of any other belief, can refuse to accept a blood transfusion for themselves, but they cannot legally prevent their children from receiving blood transfusions. This might be seen as a limitation of their religious freedom, but the secular law that safeguards children’s lives takes precedence.

瑞典法律也不允许那些宗教信仰坚持屠宰动物的人在未使用麻醉剂的情况下屠宰动物。这种困境恰恰反映在关于瑞典是否应允许按照犹太教或清真教习俗屠宰动物的争论中。事实证明，在瑞典，进口按照清真教或犹太教习俗在国外生产的肉类仍然是合法的；这必须被视为我们法律体系中的不一致之处法律。当然，法律应该始终如一地适用。动物的权利应该始终受到尊重，无论是宗教屠宰方法，还是休闲狩猎麋鹿或雷鸟。

Nor does Swedish law permit the slaughter of animals without anesthesia by people whose religion would insist that this is how slaughter should take place. It is precisely this dilemma that is reflected in the debate over whether animal slaughter according to kosher (Jewish) or halal (Islamic) conventions should be allowed in Sweden. It turns out that in Sweden it is still legal to import meat that is produced abroad in accordance with halal or kosher conventions; this has to be seen as an inconsistency in our body of laws. Of course, laws should be applied consistently. Animals’ rights should always be respected, whether the issue is religious slaughter methods, or recreational hunting for elk or ptarmigans.

另一个问题是，哪些信仰体系可以被解释为宗教，从而得到同等对待。那些声称自己有权拥有某些习俗或着装方式，并认为这些传统根植于基督教、犹太教或伊斯兰教等著名宗教的人通常会受到相当程度的尊重。但如果有人声称自己信仰古老的北欧宗教或自称崇敬自然，就会受到怀疑或被视为有点疯狂。

Another question concerns which belief systems are interpreted as religions, and are thus treated with equal merit. People who claim the right to certain customs or modes of dress, arguing that these traditions are rooted in a well-known religion such as Christianity, Judaism, or Islam, are usually granted a fair degree of respect. But someone who cites their belief in an old Norse religion or who professes a reverence for nature will be looked upon with skepticism or will be seen as slightly nutty.

那么，在判断不同（所谓的）宗教的严肃性时，应该采用哪些标准呢？特别是既然我们应该尊重宗教自由？是信徒的数量？还是信仰体系的历史根源？还是信仰体系经文的文学质量？显然，这种判断在很大程度上是武断的。法律对待“宗教”的概念本身就充满了反复无常和不一致的做法，因为“宗教”一词没有明确的定义。对某种神的信仰是否是将一组信仰视为宗教的必要标准？在这种情况下，传统佛教不应被视为宗教，因为它是一种无神论的人生哲学。或者，对某种事物的非理性崇拜如何将一群人聚集在一起？在这种情况下，我们必须将一群热情的足球迷视为宗教信仰的成员。

And which criteria should apply in passing judgment on the seriousness of different (claimed) religions, especially since we are supposed to respect religious freedom? Is it the number of believers? Or the belief system’s historical roots? Or the literary quality of the belief system’s scriptures? It seems pretty clear that such judgments are, to a large extent, arbitrary. The very notion of “religion,” as it is treated by the law, is filled with capricious and inconsistent practices, since there is no clear definition of the word “religion.” Is a belief in some sort of god a necessary criterion for a collection of beliefs to be considered a religion? In that case, traditional Buddhism ought not to be counted as a religion, since it is a godless philosophy of life. Or how about an irrational worship of something, which brings together a group of people? In that case, we would have to consider a group of passionate soccer fans to be members of a religious faith.

很难找到任何客观理由来支持包括信仰上帝在内的信仰体系有权获得特殊的法律保护。更合理的做法是扩大权利范围，让所有人都有权自由实践他们的存在主义信仰，无论这些信仰是否涉及某种上帝的存在。5

It is hard to find any objective reason that a belief system that includes a belief in God should have the right to special legal protection. It would be more reasonable to broaden the scope of rights so that all people have a right to freely practice their existential beliefs, whether or not those beliefs involve the existence of some kind of god.5

和平主义——一种拒绝使用暴力的意识形态，即使是在自卫的情况下——就是这种现象的一个典型例子。拒绝携带武器或使用暴力的人当然可以有宗教原因。但这种拒绝也可能植根于世俗信仰体系或哲学信念。如果一个国家有义务服兵役，包括使用武器，但也接受宗教和平主义者不需要服兵役的观念，那么同样的豁免也应该适用于和平主义者，他们的和平主义来自非宗教的理由（如人文主义伦理）。任何其他法律立场都是不合理的。

Pacifism—the ideology that rejects the use of violence, even in cases of self-defense—gives a clear example of this kind of thing. Someone who refuses to bear weapons or to use violence can of course have a religious reason for doing so. But this kind of refusal can equally well be rooted in a secular belief system or a philosophical conviction. If a country has obligatory military service that includes the use of weapons, but also accepts the idea that religious pacifists do not need to serve, then the same exemption should apply to a pacificist whose pacifism comes from nonreligious grounds (such as a humanist set of ethics). Any other legal position would be unreasonable.

例如：锡克教徒和刀

Example: Sikhs and Knives

根据瑞典法律，禁止在公共场所、学校区域或进入公共场所的车辆中携带刀具或其他危险物品。但根据 16 世纪印度创立的锡克教，入教的锡克教徒必须具备五项特征：未剪头发（男性留胡须）；梳子；kirpan（剑或匕首）；钢臂章；及膝内衣。

According to Swedish law, it is forbidden to carry knives or other dangerous objects in public places, in school areas, or in vehicles that enter public places. But according to the religion known as Sikhism, founded in sixteenth-century India, an initiated Sikh should always have five characteristics: unshorn hair (and for men, a beard); a comb; a kirpan (a sword or dagger); a steel armband; and knee-length underwear.

这导致了宗教自由与禁止在公共场所携带刀具的法律之间的冲突。加拿大的一个著名案例对这一冲突进行了法律检验，在加拿大，携带刀具在学校是违法的。Balvir Singh Multani 是加拿大公民，也是一名正统的锡克教徒，他带着儿子就读于魁北克的圣凯瑟琳·拉布雷学校。父亲希望儿子一直随身携带一把kirpan（一种具有宗教意义的刀），在锡克教传统中，它象征着荣誉和高贵。6

This gives rise to a conflict between religious freedom and the law proscribing the bearing of knives in public places. This conflict was put to a legal test in a very well-known case in Canada, where it is illegal to carry a knife in a school. Balvir Singh Multani, a Canadian citizen and an orthodox Sikh, went with his son to the Saint Catherine Labouré School in Quebec. The father wanted his son always to be carrying a kirpan (a knife with religious meaning), which symbolized honor and nobility in the Sikh religious tradition.6

学校管理部门拒绝允许将刀带入校园，因为校园内不允许携带武器。管理人员认为他们有责任确保所有学生的安全。他们认为，如果男孩随身携带刀，那么任何人都可能夺走它并暴力使用它。

The school administration refused to allow the knife on campus, since no weapons were to be allowed on school grounds. The administrators felt it was their responsibility to assure the safety of all the schoolchildren. Their view was that if the knife was carried around by the boy, then anyone at all might seize it and use it violently.

加拿大最高法院裁定锡克教徒胜诉，称学校禁止携带刀具侵犯了他们的宗教自由；但禁止携带刀具的规定仍然适用于所有其他可能希望携带刀具进入校园的学生。只有出于宗教原因，这项法律才有例外。

The highest court in Canada ruled in favor of the Sikhs and stated that the exclusion of all knives in the school violated their freedom of religion; however, the prohibition against knives was ruled as still applying to all other students who might wish to carry knives onto the school grounds. Only for religious reasons could this law have exceptions.

现在假设这个男孩不是锡克教徒，而是加拿大土地上一个世代相传的乡村传统家族的成员。许多文化都有“当男孩成为男人时”应该举行的仪式。这种仪式的一个主要特点是，男孩的父亲会给儿子一把代代相传的特殊刀。通常这类仪式在男孩十四五岁时举行。男孩随身携带这把刀象征着他作为成年人的身份和他与前几代人的联系。7

Now suppose that this boy had not been a Sikh but was a member of a family with a rural tradition on Canadian soil going back many generations. There are many cultures that have rituals of passing that are supposed to take place “when a boy becomes a man.” A central feature of such a ceremony occurs when the boy’s father presents his son with a special knife that has been handed down from one generation to the next. Usually these kinds of rites take place when the boy is fourteen or fifteen years old. The boy’s identity as an adult and his link to previous generations are symbolized by his carrying this knife on him at all times.7

无论是在加拿大还是在其他任何国家，这个假想的男孩都不允许携带刀具进入校园，尽管在许多这位锡克教男孩很有可能被允许在学校携带刀具。

Neither in Canada nor in any other country would this hypothetical boy be permitted to carry his knife onto school grounds, even though in many lands the Sikh boy would have very good chances of being granted permission to have the knife with him in school.

在这里，我们清楚地看到宗教自由的概念如何导致对人类行为、道德价值观和态度的不一致且（从长远来看）站不住脚的观点。毋庸置疑，道德态度不会仅仅因为基于宗教观念或传统而“更强大”或“更有价值”。态度和行动对个人来说可能或多或少受到强烈的激励和意义，完全独立于其根源。

Here we clearly see how the notion of religious freedom gives rise to an inconsistent and thus (in the long run ) untenable view of human behavior, ethical values, and attitudes. It goes without saying that a moral attitude isn’t “stronger” or “worth more” simply because it is based on religious notions or traditions. Attitudes and actions can be more or less strongly motivated and meaningful for individual people, completely independently of what they are rooted in.

追求道德独立而非宗教自由

For Ethical Independence Rather Than Religious Freedom

也许是时候用一个更具包容性和中立性的概念来取代立法中的宗教自由概念了。例如，我们可以利用“道德独立”的概念，根据这一概念，每个公民都有权独立于国家和公众。这个想法是由英裔美国法哲学教授罗纳德·德沃金（Ronald Dworkin，1931-2013）提出的，他在其著作《没有上帝的宗教》（2013）中对这一概念进行了定义：

It may be time to replace the notion of religious freedom in legislation with a more inclusive and neutral concept. We might, for instance, make use of the concept “ethical independence,” according to which every citizen has the right to independence relative to the state and relative to the general public. This idea was suggested by British American professor of legal philosophy Ronald Dworkin (1931–2013), who defines it in his book Religion without God (2013):

道德独立意味着政府绝不能仅仅因为认为人们的一种生活方式（一种关于什么样的生活最值得过的想法）本质上比另一种生活方式更好而限制自由，这并不是因为这种方式的后果更好，而是因为以这种方式生活的人是更好的人。8

Ethical independence means that government must never restrict freedom just because it assumes that one way for people to live their lives—one idea about what lives are most worth living just in themselves—is intrinsically better than another, not because its consequences are better but because people who live that way are better people.8

因此，道德独立的一个关键原则是，国家无权强迫人们遵守一套特定的道德规则。这意味着，例如，国家不能仅仅因为毒品对健康有害就禁止使用毒品。另一方面，国家可以出于其他原因介入个人的生活选择——例如，为了防止伤害无辜者的行为。这可能意味着，例如，如果确定使用某种药物会对整个社会造成有害影响，就通过立法禁止使用这种药物；这样的法律还可以帮助减少社会照顾滥用药物者的成本。德沃金建议我们放弃这样的想法：宗教自由在权利上具有特殊地位，而我们应该对所有思想和信仰都采取同样的自由态度，无论它们是否有宗教、世俗或哲学根源，换言之，对所有信仰一视同仁。

One key principle of ethical independence would thus be that the state has no right to coerce people to follow a certain set of ethical rules. This means, for example, that a state cannot prohibit the use of drugs simply because drugs are known to be harmful to one’s health. On the other hand, the state can become involved in the life choices of individuals for other reasons—for example, in order to prevent acts that harm innocent people. This might mean, for instance, passing legislation against the use of some drug if it is determined that the use of said drug can cause harmful effects to society at large; such a law could also help reduce the cost to society of taking care of misusers of the drug. Dworkin suggests that we should abandon the idea that religious freedom has a special status in terms of rights. Instead, we should apply the same attitude of freedom to all thoughts and beliefs, whether or not they have religious, secular, or philosophical roots. In other words, equal treatment for all beliefs.

我们当然认为，如果宗教自由的概念从法律中被删除，取而代之的是道德独立权，其他自由仍将存在，例如言论自由、信息自由、集会自由、示威自由和举行会议自由。这些自由合在一起，保护所有人按照自己的意愿信仰的权利，以及独自或与他人一起实践宗教信仰的权利，只要这样做不会伤害他人。

We of course presume that if the notion of religious freedom were removed from the law and were replaced by the right to ethical independence, other freedoms would remain, such as the freedom of speech, the freedom of information, the freedom to gather, the freedom to demonstrate, and the freedom to hold meetings. These freedoms, taken together, protect all people’s right to believe as they wish, and to practice their religious faith, either alone or together with other people, as long as doing so does not harm other people.

宗教与医学伦理

Religion and Medical Ethics

如今，医学界的新发现和新发明层出不穷。DNA分析、代孕、产前检查和干细胞研究只是引发重要伦理问题的几个例子，而这些问题绝非易事。即使在纯粹的世俗社会中，也会存在这种需要仔细思考的棘手伦理困境，但当宗教教条被允许阻碍医学研究和进步时，事情就真的变得一团糟了。一个非常明显的例子就是胚胎干细胞研究。

These days, new medical discoveries and inventions are appearing on the scene at a very rapid pace. DNA analysis, surrogate motherhood, prenatal tests, and stem-cell research are just a few examples that raise important ethical questions, and these questions are by no means simple. Even in a purely secular society, there would be difficult ethical dilemmas of this sort, which would need to be thought through very carefully, but when religious dogmas are allowed to stand in the way and block medical research and progress, something has really gone haywire. A crystal-clear example is research into embryonic stem cells.

英国发育生物学家约翰·格登（John Gurdon，1933- ）被认为是干细胞研究的先驱。1958 年，他首次克隆出动物——他从成年青蛙的细胞中克隆出了一只小青蛙。凭借这项工作，他于 2012 年获得了诺贝尔医学奖。今天，干细胞研究是寻找治疗阿尔茨海默病、帕金森病、肌萎缩侧索硬化症（ALS）等许多目前无法治愈的疾病的方法中最有希望的方法之一。但如今在世界许多地方，由于宗教原因，干细胞研究是非法的或受到严格限制。这种反对背后的宗教信仰是，人类灵魂据称是在受孕的那一刻由上帝创造的。另一方面，没有任何世俗理由禁止干细胞研究。

British developmental biologist John Gurdon (1933– ) is considered to be the pioneer of stem-cell research. In 1958, he was the first to clone an animal—he cloned a baby frog from a cell taken from an adult frog. For this work, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 2012. Today, stem-cell research is one of the most promising methods to find cures for such terrible scourges as Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, Lou Gehrig’s disease (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, ALS), and many other currently uncurable diseases. But in many parts of the world today, stem-cell research is illegal or highly restricted for religious reasons. The religious belief that underlies this opposition is that the human soul is allegedly created by God at the very moment of conception. On the other hand, there is no secular reason to forbid stem-cell research.

在干细胞研究中，胚胎干细胞取自囊胚——即受孕后几天的一小群细胞发育。这些细胞是在受精卵分裂几次后收集起来的，从而产生大约三百个细胞。要了解这样一个细胞群的大小，可以想象一下家蝇的大脑大约有十万个细胞。

In stem-cell research, embryonic stem cells are taken from a blastocyst—that is, from a small group of cells that have had a few days after conception to develop. These cells are collected when the fertilized egg has divided several times, thus giving rise to roughly three hundred cells. For an idea of the size of such a cell group, consider that the brain of a housefly contains roughly one hundred thousand cells.

在早期发育阶段，胚胎细胞尚未开始分化；它们中的任何一个都有可能发育成任何类型的特化细胞——例如，骨髓细胞、肝细胞或肾细胞。因此，胚胎干细胞与人类胎儿的细胞非常不同——而且无论如何，干细胞都不会从人类胎儿身上提取。

At that early stage of development, the embryonic cells have not yet started to specialize; any one of them has the potential to develop into any kind of specialized cell—for example, into a bone-marrow cell, a liver cell, or a kidney cell. Embryonic stem cells are thus very different from cells in a human fetus—and in any case, stem cells are never taken from human fetuses.

如今，世界各地的许多生育诊所都使用体外受精（以前称为“试管受精”）技术来帮助那些无法生育的夫妇。在这项技术中，一些受精卵在体外生长几天，然后通过手术将其中一个或多个卵子植入女性子宫。剩余的卵子要么被丢弃，要么被冷冻，以备将来第一次尝试失败时再次尝试让女性怀孕。干细胞就是从这些受精卵中提取出来的。

Today, many fertility clinics the world over use the technique known as in vitro fertilization (formerly known as “test-tube fertilization”) to help couples who otherwise cannot have babies. In this technique, a few fertilized ova are grown externally for a few days, and then one or more of them are surgically inserted into the woman’s uterus. The remaining eggs are either discarded or are frozen, to serve in possible future attempts to impregnate the woman, in case the first attempt fails. It is from such fertilized ova that stem cells can be taken.

干细胞研究是医学界拯救生命和赐予生命礼物这一目标的直接产物。由于世俗伦理试图将人类的痛苦降到最低，它鼓励干细胞研究作为治疗残疾的良药，并为目前无法治愈的疾病患者带来希望。

Stem-cell research is a direct outcome of medical science’s goal of saving lives and giving the gift of life. Since secular ethics tries to minimize human suffering, it encourages stem-cell research as a remedy to impairments and as a source of hope to people with diseases that today are incurable.

如今，新的医学发现不断迫使我们面对新的道德困境，在有关此类话题的辩论中，尊重宗教和科学之间的区别至关重要。

These days, new medical discoveries are constantly forcing us to face new kinds of ethical dilemmas, and in debates on such topics it is critical to respect the distinction between religion and science.

论世俗主义与社会健康

On Secularism and Social Health

不管上帝是否存在，相信上帝是否有益健康？即使上帝不存在，安慰剂效应是否也有效？如果人们相信上帝，他们是否会变得更善良、更诚实、更慷慨？这种因果关系可能在某些个案中存在，但我们想在这里研究的问题是整个社会层面的情况如何。换句话说，一个特定社会中宗教人士的比例与该社会的整体幸福感和健康状况之间是否存在相关性？

Is it possible that believing in God is healthy, whether or not God actually exists? Could it be that the placebo effect works well, even if God doesn’t exist? Might it be the case that people are kinder, more honest, and more generous if they believe in God? Such a causal link might possibly exist in certain individual cases, but the question we wish to examine here is how things are at the level of a whole society. In other words, is there a correlation between the proportion of religious people in a given society, and that society’s overall well-being and health?

大约 5% 的美国公民将自己定义为无神论者。但根据哥伦比亚大学心理学家梅兰妮·布鲁斯特的说法，美国监狱中只有0.09 % 的囚犯说他们是无神论者。9换句话说，与总人口相比，美国监狱中无神论者的比例低了 50 倍。当然，这个统计数据本身并不意味着无神论者比宗教人士更善良、更诚实或更慷慨，但它确实发人深省。这可能只是一种统计相关性，并不代表任何因果关系。但无论如何，这个统计数据根本不支持相反的结论——即信仰上帝的人在道德上比无神论者更好。

Roughly 5 percent of U.S. citizens define themselves as atheists. But according to Columbia University psychologist Melanie Brewster, only 0.09 percent of the prisoners in American jails say they are atheistic.9 In other words, in comparison with the overall population, atheists are underrepresented in American jails by a factor of fifty. Of course this statistic on its own doesn’t imply that atheists are kinder, more honest, or more generous than religious people, but it is certainly thought provoking. It might just be a statistical correlation that doesn’t represent any sort of causal link. But in any case, this statistic doesn’t lend any support at all to the opposite conclusion—namely, that believers in God are morally better people than atheists.

我们知道，世俗国家中真正不信教者（相对于被迫宣称不信教者）的比例较高，是世界上最健康、教育程度最高、最开放的社会之一。这些国家的婴儿死亡率也较低，男女平等程度也较高。

We know that secular countries with a higher proportion of genuine nonbelievers (as contrasted with people who are coerced into stating they are nonbelievers) are among the healthiest, best educated, and most open societies in the world. Such countries also have a lower infant mortality rate and a higher level of equality between women and men.

根据欧盟的民意调查，欧洲无宗教信仰者的比例正在增加。例如，在英国，自称无神论者的人数比例从 1963 年的 14% 增长到 2012 年的 42%。10在瑞典，只有29 % 的人口自称有宗教信仰，而在日本，这一比例甚至更低：只有 16% 。11

According to opinion polls conducted by the European Union, the percentage of nonreligious people in Europe is increasing. In Great Britain, for example, the percentage of people who call themselves atheists grew from 14 percent in 1963 to 42 percent in 2012.10 In Sweden, only 29 percent of the population describes itself as religious, and in Japan the percentage is even lower: only 16 percent.11

联合国《2018 年人类发展报告》对12187个国家进行了人类发展指数排名（该指数由巴基斯坦经济学家 Mahbub ul Haq 和印度经济学家 Amartya Sen 共同制定）。该指数基于预期寿命、人均收入、识字率（阅读和写作）、教育水平、婴儿死亡率等。人类发展指数最高的十个国家如下：

In the United Nations’ 2018 Human Development Report,12 187 countries were ranked by their Human Development Index (a measure jointly developed by Pakistani economist Mahbub ul Haq and Indian economist Amartya Sen). This index is based on life expectancy, per capita income, literacy (both for reading and for writing), educational level, infant mortality rate, and so forth. The ten countries having the highest HDI were the following:

  1. 挪威
  2. Norway
  3. 瑞士
  4. Switzerland
  5. 澳大利亚
  6. Australia
  7. 爱尔兰
  8. Ireland
  9. 德国
  10. Germany
  11. 冰岛
  12. Iceland
  13. 中国香港
  14. Hong Kong, China
  15. 瑞典
  16. Sweden
  17. 新加坡
  18. Singapore
  19. 荷兰
  20. Netherlands

人类发展指数 (HDI) 最低的 10 个国家如下：

The ten countries having the lowest HDI were the following:

180.莫桑比克

180. Mozambique

181.利比里亚

181. Liberia

182.马里

182. Mali

183.布基纳法索

183. Burkina Faso

184.塞拉利昂

184. Sierra Leone

185.布隆迪

185. Burundi

186.乍得

186. Chad

187.南苏丹

187. South Sudan

188.中非共和国

188. Central African Republic

189.尼日尔

189. Niger

这份榜单上前 25 名的所有国家，无宗教信仰者的比例都高得惊人，只有两个国家例外——爱尔兰和美国。尽管爱尔兰传统上是坚定的天主教徒，但它在 2018 年投票允许堕胎，还推翻了中世纪的亵渎法；此外，它还有一位印度裔同性恋总理。根据在这些国家进行的民意调查，在所有这些国家，无宗教信仰的人生观都发挥着强大的影响力。

All of the countries occupying the top twenty-five slots in this list had a strikingly high proportion of nonreligious people, with two exceptions—namely, Ireland and the United States. But although Ireland is traditionally strongly Catholic, in 2018 it voted to allow abortion and it also overturned a medieval blasphemy law; moreover, it has a gay prime minister of Indian origin. In all these countries, nonreligious views on life exert a strong influence, according to opinion polls that have been conducted in them.

排名最低的二十五个国家无宗教信仰者比例非常低，在孟加拉国、尼泊尔、阿富汗和巴基斯坦等国家，基本上所有人都信仰某种神。

The countries occupying the twenty-five lowest ranks have a very low proportion of nonreligious citizens, and in countries like Bangladesh, Nepal, Afghanistan, and Pakistan, essentially everyone in the entire population is a believer in some sort of god.

谋杀率最高的国家往往是信教者比例极高的国家，而谋杀率最低的国家往往是非信教者比例最高的国家。婴儿死亡率最高的 75 个国家都是虔诚的宗教国家。13

The countries with the highest murder rates are ones that have a very high percentage of believers, while the lowest murder rates coincide with the highest levels of nonbelievers. The seventy-five countries with the highest infant mortality rates are all deeply religious countries.13

英国救助儿童会每年都会发布一份“生育指数”，列出最适合和最不适合当母亲的国家。该指数的制定需要考虑许多参数，例如分娩护理、婴儿死亡率以及产妇（和父亲）的休假时间。榜单上排名前十的国家基本都是世俗国家，而排名后十的国家都是虔诚的宗教国家。14

British organization Save the Children comes out annually with a “maternity index,” which lists the best and the worst countries in which to be a mother. Many parameters go into making such determinations, such as childbirth care, infant mortality rate, and maternal (and paternal) leaves from work. The top ten countries in the list are all largely secular, while the bottom ten are all deeply religious.14

那么和平程度如何？哪些国家最和平？人类愿景组织每年都会发布一份全球和平指数，该指数基于一系列变量，例如主观的安全感和安全、暴力犯罪率、战争参与率和武器获取率。这一维度的模式也是一样的。最世俗化的国家是最和平的，而最不和平的国家都是高度宗教化的。

And what about peacefulness? Which are the most peaceful lands? The organization Vision of Humanity annually publishes a Global Peace Index based on a number of variables, such as the subjective feeling of safety and security, the rate of violent crimes, wars engaged in, and access to weapons. The pattern is the same in this dimension as well. The most secular countries are the most peaceful, while the least peaceful are all highly religious.

我们从这些中可以得出什么结论呢？首先，让我们先说一些我们无法得出的结论。虽然幸福感程度和世俗化程度之间存在明显的统计相关性，但我们不能假设这是一种因果关系。这些数字并不能证明世俗化是幸福感的原因，也不能证明宗教信仰是贫穷和疾病的原因。尽管如此，统计上的联系是不可否认的。世俗社会和世俗态度与健康和幸福息息相关。从历史角度来看，世俗化显然是社会进步的主要驱动因素之一，尤其是在妇女和同性恋者的权利方面。15

What conclusions can we draw from all this? To start with, let us mention some conclusions that we cannot draw. Although there is a clear statistical correlation between the degree of well-being and the degree of secularism, we cannot presume that this is a causal link. The figures don’t prove that secularism is the reason for well-being or that religiosity is the reason for poverty and disease. Nonetheless, the statistical connection is undeniable. Secular societies and secular attitudes go hand in hand with health and well-being. From a historical perspective, it’s also clear that secularism has been one of the main driving causes behind social progress in many ways, not least concerning the rights of women and homosexuals.15

许多宗教保守派，无论是基督教徒、穆斯林、犹太教徒还是印度教徒，都声称要建立一个和平繁荣的社会，所有公民都必须侍奉上帝并服从上帝。以色列/巴勒斯坦西岸的正统犹太教士、沙特阿拉伯的瓦哈比教长、伊拉克和叙利亚的萨拉菲派、梵蒂冈的教皇和美国的基督教右翼都同样强烈地主张这一主张。他们都声称上帝的旨意是社会生活的核心，只有我们屈服于上帝，我们才能确保拥有道德、成功、健康和安全的共存。一般来说，这些权威人士还认为，当一个社会中的许多人否认上帝的存在时，社会的稳定就会受到破坏。因此，社会中的所有罪恶——例如犯罪、贫困、教育水平低下、艾滋病等等——都可以归咎于敬畏上帝的公民人数的下降。16

Many religious conservatives, whether they are Christians, Muslims, Jews, or Hindus, claim that to create a peaceful and prosperous society, it is necessary for all citizens to serve God and to submit to God. This claim is made equally strongly by orthodox rabbis on the West Bank in Israel/Palestine, by Wahhabi sheikhs in Saudi Arabia, by Salafists in Iraq and Syria, by the pope in the Vatican, and by the Christian Right in the United States. They all claim that God’s will forms the core of social life, and that only if we bow down to God can we be assured of having a moral, successful, healthy, and safe coexistence. As a rule, these authorities also believe that when many people in a society deny God’s existence, society’s stability will be undermined. All the evils in a society—for example, crime, poverty, poor education, AIDS, and so on—can thus be pinned on the falling number of God-fearing citizens.16

如果情况确实如此，那么人们应该可以预料到，世界上宗教信仰最少（或无神论最严重）的国家将受到犯罪、贫困和疾病的严重打击。同样，宗教信仰最强烈的国家将是社会稳定的典范。然而事实却恰恰相反。非宗教公民比例最高的国家是最和平、最稳定、最自由、最富裕和最繁荣的国家，而宗教信仰最强烈的国家则是最不稳定、最暴力、最压迫和最贫穷的国家。

Well, if this were indeed the case, then one should expect that the least religious (or most atheistic) countries in the world would be the hardest hit by crime, poverty, and illness. And by the same token, the most religious countries would be paragons of social stability. And yet exactly the opposite is the case. Those countries with the highest proportion of nonreligious citizens are the most peaceful, most stable, most free, most well-off, and most prosperous, while the most religious countries are the most unstable, violent, oppressive, and poor.

从所有这些统计数据中可以得出一个明显的结论：世俗主义不会导致不道德或文明崩溃。诚然，对上帝的信仰可能对个人来说是一种安慰，但无论宗教权威如何宣称，世俗主义的社会显然是最健康的社会。

An obvious conclusion from all these statistics is that secularism does not lead to immorality or to the collapse of civilization. To be sure, a belief in God may be a comfort for an individual, but societies that have a secular style seem clearly to be the healthiest ones—no matter what religious authorities may claim.

当今世界宗教信仰正在兴起还是衰落？

Is Religious Belief Rising or Falling in Today’s World?

毫无疑问，宗教对政治的影响在全球许多国家都在上升。在当今世界，人们经常听到“上帝归来”的说法。同样明显的是，在世界各大宗教中，某些宗教宣言正变得越来越强烈和极端。基督教、犹太教和伊斯兰教，更不用说印度教和佛教，到处都出现了保守的解释。（瑞典路德教会是这一趋势的一个例外；它对基督教经文的自由甚至世俗的解释，处于另一个极端。）然而自相矛盾的是，自称有宗教信仰的人的比例似乎随着时间的推移而下降。

There can be no doubt that the influence of religion on politics is rising in many countries around the globe. One often hears about “the return of God” in today’s world. It is also clear that certain sorts of religious pronouncements are becoming ever stronger and more extreme in all the world’s main religions. Conservative interpretations are sprouting everywhere in Christendom, Judaism, and Islam, not to mention Hinduism and Buddhism. (The Swedish Lutheran Church is an exception to this trend; in its liberal and even secular interpretation of Christian scriptures, it is at the extreme other end of the spectrum.) And yet paradoxically, it seems that the percentage of people who call themselves religious is actually declining with time.

在美国，大约有 20% 到 30% 的人表示他们不属于任何有组织的宗教。相比之下，1990 年，只有 10% 的美国公民这样说。这种转变在年轻美国人中更加明显：30 岁以下的美国人中 32% 的人声称属于有组织的宗教。20 世纪 80 年代，在 30 岁以下的人群中，福音派基督徒的数量是无宗教信仰者的两倍。今天，这一比例正好相反：30 岁以下无宗教信仰者的数量是该年龄段福音派基督徒的两倍。17

In the United States, somewhere between 20 and 30 percent of the people state that they don’t belong to any organized religion. By contrast, in 1990, only 10 percent of U.S. citizens made that statement. The shift is even clearer among young Americans: 32 percent of Americans under thirty years old claim to belong to an organized religion. In the 1980s, among people under thirty years old, there were twice as many evangelical Christians as there were people without any religious affiliation. Today the ratio is exactly the opposite: there are twice as many nonreligious people under thirty as there are evangelical Christians in that age group.17

根据盖洛普国际民意调查，许多国家在 2005 年至 2012 年的短短时间内发生了所有这些惊人的变化。表 13.1显示了自称“有宗教信仰”或“无宗教信仰”的人的百分比。对于全球 37 个国家，2005 年自称“有宗教信仰”的人的百分比与 2012 年的百分比并列显示。这些国家按宗教信仰程度从高到低（2012 年）的顺序列出。最后一栏显示了 2005 年至 2012 年之间的百分比变化。18

According to a poll taken by Gallup International, there are many countries in which all of these striking changes have taken place in just the brief period between 2005 and 2012. Table 13.1 shows the percentage of people who describe themselves as “religious” or as “nonreligious.” For thirty-seven countries throughout the world, the percentage of self-described “religious people” in 2005 is shown side by side with the percentage in 2012. The countries are listed in the order of most religious to least religious (in the year 2012). The final column shows the percent change between 2005 and 2012.18

从表 13.1可以看出，在许多国家，人们越来越远离宗教：在其中 24 个国家，信徒的比例下降，而在其中 11 个国家，信徒的比例上升。

As can be seen in table 13.1, in many countries, people are increasingly moving away from religion: in twenty-four of these countries, the proportion of believers went down, while in eleven of them it went up.

因此，“上帝回归”的说法只有一个方面是正确的——即宗教在世界许多地方似乎变得越来越危险，回归到一种更古老的方式，例如天主教会公开进行火刑和其他各种可怕的酷刑。但就人类对超自然力量或全能造物主的信仰倾向而言，这种倾向似乎正在慢慢消失。

The claim of “the return of God” is thus correct in only one aspect—namely, religion seems to be growing more and more dangerous in many parts of the world, reverting to a far older style, such as when the Catholic Church carried out public burnings at the stake and other kinds of horrendous tortures. But as far as the human inclination to believe in supernatural powers or in an almighty creator is concerned, that seems to be slowly fading out of existence.

表 13.1. 各国自报宗教信仰者百分比

Table 13.1. Percentage of Self-Reported Religiosity by Country

国家 2005 年（%） 2012年（%） 改变
加纳 96 96 0
尼日利亚 94 93 –1
马其顿 85 90 +5
罗马尼亚 85 89 +4
肯尼亚 89 88 –1
秘鲁 84 86 +2
巴基斯坦 78 84 +6
摩尔达维亚 78 83 +5
哥伦比亚 83 83 0
喀麦隆 86 82 –4
马来西亚 77 81 +4
印度 87 81 –6
波兰 85 81 –4
塞尔维亚 72 77 +5
意大利 72 73 +1
阿根廷 80 72 –8
乌克兰 70 71 +1
厄瓜多尔 85 70 –15
立陶宛 75 69 –6
波斯尼亚和黑塞哥维那 74 67 –7
南非 83 64 –19
美国 73 60 –13
保加利亚 63 59 –4
冰岛 74 57 –17

西班牙 55 52 –3

瑞士 71 50 –21
